lead_paragraph: On Thursday, G-Star will open its new Fifth Avenue store across from the New York Public Library. Inside the expansive space — the first to open since Pharrell Williams became an owner of the denim label in February — you’ll find a number of 3-D floating legs and a central mezzanine display that showcases unconventional styles, like the men’s Staq jeans ($260) tacked at intervals to produce the namesake “stacking” effect and women’s Pouch jeans ($170) with a large central pocket meant to take the place of a handbag. At 475 Fifth Avenue.

headline: Female Cinematographers, Not Content to Hide Behind the Camera
abstract: Women in the field are using several strategies in an effort to overcome gender inequity.
lead_paragraph: It was the fall women’s meeting of Local 600, the cinematographers’ union, that kindled the idea. Gathered in the Nyack, N.Y., home of Ellen Kuras, an Oscar nominee who shot “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind,” female directors of photography, assistants and camera operators swapped stories of their trade — and the challenges of being underrepresented in it.

headline: Fearing Drugs’ Rare Side Effects, Millions Take Their Chances With Osteoporosis
abstract: Use of the most commonly prescribed osteoporosis drugs fell 50 percent from 2008 to 2012 after reports of rotting jaws and snapped thighbones.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans are missing out on a chance to avoid debilitating fractures from weakened bones, researchers say, because they are terrified of exceedingly rare side effects from drugs that can help them.

headline: Janice Crouch, ‘Gospel of Prosperity’ Disciple, Dies at 78
abstract: The Trinity Broadcasting Network and its “gospel of prosperity” reached millions of viewers around the world and had lately been fighting multiple lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: Janice Crouch, who founded the Trinity Broadcasting Network with her husband, Paul, and preached a “gospel of prosperity” with him on TBN programs, reaching millions of viewers around the world, died on Tuesday. She was 78.

lead_paragraph: The head of Hispanic media relations at the Republican National Committee is resigning this month in what appears to be another indication of the lingering discomfort some party officials have about working to elect Donald J. Trump president.

lead_paragraph: The donation Donald Trump made to veterans’ charities is small compared with those of some fellow billionaires. Then again, veterans charities don’t appear to be a big cause for billionaires.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: A fired police officer was charged Wednesday in the killing of a legally armed black musician who had apparently thrown his weapon and was running away when he was shot, prosecutors and court documents said. The former officer, Nouman Raja, was arrested and charged with attempted murder and manslaughter in the Oct. 18 death of Corey Jones, 31, after a grand jury found the shooting was unjustified, Palm Beach County State Attorney Dave Aronberg said. Mr. Jones’s sport utility vehicle had broken down on a highway ramp. He had gotten out and was on the phone with roadside assistance when Mr. Raja, who is of South Asian descent, pulled up in an unmarked van. The men’s exchange was captured on the call center recording. “At no time during the recording did Raja say he was a police officer,” the affidavit said. “Instead, Raja replied by asking the single word ‘Really?’ when Jones twice said, ‘I’m good.’ ” Both men apparently pulled guns. Mr. Raja, 38, fired six shots, hitting Mr. Jones three times. Mr. Jones never fired. (AP)

headline: Militias in Libya Advance on ISIS Stronghold of Surt With Separate Agendas
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The battle for the coastal city, which could harbor as many as 6,500 Islamic State fighters, is at the center of a fractious struggle by rival groups for control of Libya’s future.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Fighters aligned with Libya’s United Nations-backed unity government are advancing along the Mediterranean coast toward the Islamic State stronghold of Surt, signaling the first major assault on territory that, since last year, has become the terrorist group’s largest base outside Iraq and Syria.

headline: Review: Jennifer Koh Asks 32 Musicians to Respond to Paganini
abstract: A concert of the results, all solo violin pieces played at National Sawdust, showed just how much disagreement still exists about virtuosity.
lead_paragraph: When Paganini published his 24 Caprices for solo violin in 1820, the technical limits of virtuosity were in flux. But its purpose in music was well defined: Difficulty was central as a measure of skill, of course, but also to give a sense of showmanship, mixed with an acrobatic element of danger.

headline: Shabab Attack on Hotel in Mogadishu, Somalia, Kills Over a Dozen
abstract: The Shabab militant organization claimed responsibility for the attack by gunmen and a car bomb, directed at a popular hotel in Mogadishu, the capital.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Militants detonated a deafening car bomb at the gates of a popular hotel in Somalia on Wednesday evening, and gunmen then stormed the hotel, leaving at least 15 people dead and creating a fiery scene of wrecked cars, crumbled buildings, panic and smoke that stretched for blocks in the heart of Mogadishu, the capital.

headline: Treasury Imposes Sanctions on North Korea, Cutting Access to Banks

abstract: The Treasury, employing techniques used on Iran, wants to cut Pyongyang off from the American financial system with what are known as secondary sanctions.
lead_paragraph: With private cybersecurity firms linking North Korea to recent computer attacks that absconded with at least $81 million, the Treasury Department moved on Wednesday to choke off Pyongyang’s remaining access to the global financial system, designating the country a “primary” money launderer.

headline: William Bell, a Stax Records Team Player, Upholds and Extends
abstract: Mr. Bell, who has a new album, helped put the label on the map and says he feels a certain accountability about sharing music under the Stax name.
lead_paragraph: The pioneering label Stax Records is best known for gritty, down-and-dirty soul classics by such giants as Otis Redding, Rufus Thomas, and Sam and Dave. But one of the singles that first put the Memphis company on the map was the stately, elegant ballad “You Don’t Miss Your Water,” written and recorded in 1961 by a rising local singer named William Bell. Though the song only grazed the charts, it was a defining cornerstone of the Southern soul sound.

headline: Real Estate Boom Pinches a Produce Supply in the Hudson Valley
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', "Farmers' Markets", 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A City Council proposal would set aside money from the municipal budget to stave off new development efforts on farmland in upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: STONE RIDGE, N.Y. — Apple trees have blossomed, and soon fruit will begin emerging at Elizabeth Ryan’s orchard in the Hudson Valley. Before long, her harvest will head south to Manhattan, where Miro Uskokovic, the pastry chef at Gramercy Tavern, will use it to create an apple and carob cake, while Michael Anthony, the executive chef at the Studio Cafe inside the Whitney Museum of American Art, will turn it into an apple compote spread over pie dough and covered with a streusel.

headline: Andre Iguodala Remains Warriors’ Unsung Hero
abstract: Iguodala, the N.B.A. finals M.V.P. last season, will probably draw the assignment of guarding LeBron James again. But if he had success doing so last year, he is the last one who will say so.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Over the past four years, Andre Iguodala has been an Eastern Conference All-Star, a gold-medal-winning Olympian for the United States and the most valuable player of the N.B.A. finals.

headline: Chairman of Sony Pictures TV, Steve Mosko, to Leave Studio
abstract: The departure is the latest in a series of recent exits of recent television executives.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A changing of the small-screen guard continued on Wednesday, with Steve Mosko, the chairman of Sony Pictures Television, leaving the studio after having carried out a hard-fought turnaround.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Portray Donald Trump’s Foreign Policy Positions as Dangerous
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: A speech will cast her likely Republican rival as a threat to bipartisan tenets of American diplomacy and declare him unfit for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton plans to deliver a scorching assessment of Donald J. Trump’s foreign policy prescriptions on Thursday, casting her likely Republican rival as a threat to decades of bipartisan tenets of American diplomacy and declaring him unfit for the presidency.

headline: Children’s Toy
abstract: Susan Gelfand’s crossword theme might jump right out at you.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Just yesterday we were discussing how you can’t always expect to find a crossword theme in the long Across entries, and today we have another example of just that. Susan Gelfand is back with a theme that will jump right out at you, if you know where to look.

headline: Live Nation Postpones Six New York Concerts in Wake of Shooting
abstract: The concert giant said it was postponing performances at Irving Plaza and the Gramercy Theater after a fatal shooting last week.
lead_paragraph: As the police continue to investigate a shooting during a hip-hop concert at a Manhattan nightclub last week that left one person dead and three injured, the concert promoter behind the club is postponing a series of shows, including many rap events.

headline: After Years of Struggles, Bronx Woman Earns Her Prize: A Criminal Justice Degree
abstract: JoAnne Carpenter, who received money through the Neediest Cases Fund, coped with bouts of depression and worked part-time jobs while raising two children.
lead_paragraph: As hundreds of newly anointed graduates of John Jay College of Criminal Justice made their way across the commencement stage at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, the college’s president, Jeremy Travis, beamed with pride at one particular student. The graduate, a 34-year-old Bronx woman named JoAnne Carpenter, had taken a remarkable, circuitous route to the ceremony.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Season 4, Episode 12: A Different Side of Things
abstract: Paige is getting a new sense of how dangerous her parents’ work must be, and the F.B.I. is suddenly getting much closer to catching the Jenningses.
lead_paragraph: We have not always been kind in this space to Paige Jennings, or to Holly Taylor, the 18-year-old Canadian actress who plays her. When “The Americans” was balancing its Paige story line (teenager finds out her parents are Soviet spies) with its Martha story line (woman finds out her husband is a Soviet spy), we were solidly on Team Martha — her plot won on dramatic and emotional grounds and Alison Wright acted up a storm as the lonely secretary willing to commit treason for love. (Even if her lover was actually Paige’s bigamous father.)

headline: Yankees Are Swept by Blue Jays
abstract: Toronto’s Aaron Sanchez shut out the Yankees in six and two-thirds innings.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Pitchers are perpetual tinkerers. If they are not this way by nature, they are made so by circumstance — having so much time on their hands by virtue of having four days between starts or many idle innings in the bullpen.

headline: For a Collegial Court, Justices Lunch Together, and Forbid Talk of Cases
abstract: The secret ingredients include talk of books, vacations and grandchildren; an occasional drink; and singing ‘Happy Birthday’ to one another.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Supreme Court term enters the homestretch, just hours before an internal deadline on Wednesday for circulating all draft majority opinions, two justices made an unusual joint appearance to discuss the secret ingredient for a collegial court.

headline: Adversity Doesn’t Extinguish the Fiery Yulia Putintseva
abstract: Putintseva, 21, has slowly found success after a precocious junior career. Now she finds herself facing Serena Williams in the French Open quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In tennis, where shouting fiery self-exhortations after nearly every point has become nearly Pavlovian, Yulia Putintseva’s intensity may burn most searingly of all.

headline: Donald Trump Vows to ‘Make a Real Run’ at California in November
abstract: The presumptive Republican nominee, referring to the general election, told a crowd in Sacramento that he would work to win Washington and Oregon as well.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Donald J. Trump is the only candidate left in the Republican primary, yet his campaign schedule is adhering fairly closely to the primary calendar, with him spending the second part of last week and the rest of this week holding rallies across California, which votes on Tuesday.

headline: Payday Loans’ Debt Spiral to Be Curtailed
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Payday Loans', 'Consumer Protection', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Protections are coming from a consumer agency that likens the lending to “getting into a taxi just to ride across town and finding yourself stuck in a ruinously expensive cross-country journey.”
lead_paragraph: The payday loan industry, which is vilified for charging exorbitant interest rates on short-term loans that many Americans depend on, could soon be gutted by a set of rules that federal regulators plan to unveil on Thursday.

headline: Rookies Lift Penguins to Another Win in Stanley Cup Finals
abstract: Conor Sheary scored 2 minutes 35 seconds into overtime after San Jose had tied the score late in the third period, and goaltender Matt Murray made 21 saves.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The Penguins moved another win closer to claiming the Stanley Cup on Wednesday night, and again it was rookies that helped get them there.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 2, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “He left me in my pajamas looking at the charred body and told me: ‘You’re the acting president. I’m going to Angola.’”

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, June 2, 2016.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: The comic Quincy Jones leaves a legacy on HBO; Eddie Huang goes home to Orlando, Fla.; and don’t read reviews of “10 Cloverfield Lane.” Just see it.
lead_paragraph: You’ll laugh, and you’ll cry: Quincy Jones, a comedian battling mesothelioma, fulfills a dream with an HBO special. Eddie Huang goes home to Orlando, Fla. And don’t bother reading reviews of “10 Cloverfield Lane.” Just see it.

headline: E.C.B. Keeps Rates Steady as Inflation Shows Signs of Rising
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The central bank, which was not expected to make significant policy moves, expressed slightly more optimism about the prospects for growth in the region
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank made no changes on Thursday in its program to revive the eurozone economy, as it expressed slightly more optimism about the prospects for growth in the region.

headline: At Look3, Brazil’s Dams Submerge Tribal Life
abstract: Among the exhibits at this year’s Look3 festival is Aaron Vincent Elkaim’s project on the consequences of Brazil’s ambitious plans to build dams to propel its economy.
lead_paragraph: Among the exhibits at this year’s Look3 festival is Aaron Vincent Elkaim’s project on the consequences of Brazil’s ambitious plans to build dams to propel its economy.

headline: How Will ‘Brexit’ Vote Go? Monty Python May Offer Clue
abstract: Underneath the campaign’s theatrics lie questions of identity: Have Britons, many of whom see the European Union as a money-sucking abstraction, ever felt like part of Europe?
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — Jackie O’Neill, a 54-year-old administrative assistant, was explaining the other day why Britain should vote to divorce itself from the European Union in this month’s referendum. As she enumerated her many grievances, I couldn’t help thinking of the scene in Monty Python’s “Life of Brian” in which a bunch of disaffected Judeans sit around, complaining about the Romans.

headline: N.B.A. Finals: How the Warriors and Cavaliers Match Up
abstract: In a rematch of last year’s N.B.A. finals, the Warriors will try to win their second consecutive title. Game 1 is Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: 2016 N.B.A. Finals: Golden State Warriors (73-9) vs. Cleveland Cavaliers (57-25)

headline: Brazil’s Dams Submerge Tribal Life
abstract: Among the exhibits at this year’s Look3 festival is Aaron Vincent Elkaim’s project on the consequences of Brazil’s ambitious plans to build dams to propel its economy.
lead_paragraph: When Aaron Vincent Elkaim reached the Xingu River basin in Brazil’s Amazon rain forest in 2014, he found a lush and humid green expanse that made him feel as if he were infinitesimally small, living “inside a single giant organism.” The region is one of the world’s most biologically and ethnically diverse areas, home to about 25,000 indigenous people, many of whom live as their ancestors did in close relationship to the land.

headline: China’s Foreign Minister Castigates Canadian Reporter for Rights Question
abstract: The minister, Wang Yi, browbeat a journalist who asked about the Chinese government’s detention of human rights advocates and a Canadian couple accused of spying.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Canadians, apart perhaps from hockey players, seem to pride themselves on being affable people averse to confrontation. But China’s foreign minister, Wang Yi, clearly decided that being in Canada was no reason to hold his temper. Especially when it comes to questions on his country’s human rights record.

headline: Veterans Aren’t Campaign Props
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Philanthropy']
abstract: What the symbolism of service members is used to sell.
lead_paragraph: ON Tuesday, Donald J. Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, called a news conference to discuss his promise to donate to veterans’ charities, made with a splash in January, but not quite fulfilled until reporters looked into whether the donation was actually made.

headline: Tightwad Trump Explodes
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Veterans', 'Philanthropy', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Donald, just show us the money for veterans.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has a simple reason for his long delay in explaining what happened to the money he raised for veterans’ charities: He didn’t want any publicity.

headline: A Chill Wind Blows
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'News and News Media', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: Trump’s rhetoric suggests that in his mind, adulation is the only honesty.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump, a man who tosses the truth around with the callous disdain of a spoiled child with a toy he has outgrown, has spent much of his campaign calling the media dishonest, even though his manipulation of the media is the only reason he’s the last Republican standing.

headline: Kansas Schools, Victims of Bad Tax Policy
abstract: A Republican governor and legislators are battling the state Supreme Court over the effect of tax cuts on the state’s education system.
lead_paragraph: The grand myth of modern Republican politics — the trickle-down theory that sweeping tax cuts generate rising revenues — has come crashing down in Kansas.

headline: The Millions Who Are Just Getting By
abstract: A Fed survey documenting Americans’ struggles offers insight to politicians while giving policy makers cause to hesitate before raising interest rates.
lead_paragraph: In the United States, nearly one-third of adults, about 76 million people, are either “struggling to get by” or “just getting by,” according to the third annual survey of households by the Federal Reserve Board.

headline: Too Small to Fail
abstract: To get more kids to college, invest in infants.
lead_paragraph: First, a quiz: What’s the most common “vegetable” eaten by American toddlers?

headline: A Big Merger May Flatten America’s Beer Market
keywords: ['Beer', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Anheuser-Busch InBev’s takeover of SABMiller could mean disaster for small brewers if antitrust officials don’t take action.
lead_paragraph: ANHEUSER BUSCH-INBEV, the world’s largest brewer, recently made headlines by announcing that it would temporarily rename Budweiser, one of its best-selling beers, as America. It’s a curious name choice, not only because AB-InBev is based in Belgium, but also because of what the new name stands for: independence.

headline: Hustling Dollars for Public Health
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Zika Virus', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Birth Defects', 'Microcephaly', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Officials should not have to go begging to Congress every time an emergency like Zika happens.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, a woman infected with the Zika virus gave birth to a girl with microcephaly, a malformed head, in New Jersey. Federal officials say there are more than 300 pregnant women possibly infected with Zika around the country. Yet every time an emergency like this happens, public health officials must go begging bowl in hand to Congress for the funds to deal with it. And as the current squabble between Republicans and President Obama over money for the Zika virus shows, there’s no guarantee of significant or even timely relief.

headline: How the Democratic Race Will Probably End
abstract: Hillary Clinton will most likely be named the presumptive nominee before the polls even close in California on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic race is about to end.

headline: Expanding Medicare Would Solve Some Problems, Create New Ones
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Elderly']
abstract: The Obamacare marketplace would inevitably be affected by the move, in ways that are tricky to predict.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, President Bill Clinton suggested a partial solution to help millions of Americans without health insurance: The country should let those 55 and older without employer coverage buy into the government Medicare system.

headline: News Q’s | J.K. Rowling Just Can’t Let Harry Potter Go
abstract: How do you feel about “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child,” a play being advertised as the official “eighth story in the Harry Potter canon”?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activity is based on the article “J. K. Rowling Just Can’t Let Harry Potter Go.”

headline: Upper West Side: Prewar to Postwar
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: After years in a building that dated to 1915, it was time for Richard Zoglin to try a home on the newer side.
lead_paragraph: When Richard Zoglin married in 1992, he and his wife, Charla Krupp, rented a one-bedroom on the Upper West Side. Four years later, for $435,000, they bought a two-bedroom co-op in a 1915 building in the West 80s.

headline: In Istanbul’s Taxis, Buckling Up Is an Insult
abstract: What’s the matter, don’t you trust my driving? You must be from out of town. (And, please, pay no attention to the speedometer.)
lead_paragraph: It can be hard to find a functioning seatbelt in an Istanbul taxicab, and when I do, I think twice about putting it on. Why? Because it always seems to outrage the driver — and sometimes leaves me having to defend my very identity as a Turk.

headline: Studies of Moth and Butterfly Genes Color In a Scientific Classic
abstract: The studies identified the mutation at the heart of a lesson about adaptive evolution taught in many science classes.
lead_paragraph: The story of the black peppered moth, which changed colors from Oreo milkshake to dark chocolate during the Industrial Revolution in Britain, is the iconic tale of adaptive evolution taught in science classes. And today its plot thickens: In a study published in Nature, researchers have pinpointed the precise genetic mutation that led to the darker moth and determined just when this mutation occurred. The same gene, called cortex, was also found to control color patterns on the wings of tropical butterflies in a separate study.

headline: Donald Trump’s Secret Weapon: Letters of Love, Flattery and Revenge
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s personal letters, alternately admiring and acidic, offer an archive of his emotional states and have become mementos for hundreds of recipients.
lead_paragraph: In one letter, Donald J. Trump ranted about the crisis of unsightly hot dog vendors on his beloved Fifth Avenue. “Having ketchup and mustard splattered all over the sidewalk,” he wrote, “is disgraceful.”

headline: Student Question | Is This Teenage Prank Art?
abstract: Have you read about the teenagers who left a pair of glasses on a museum floor, then watched as visitors assumed they were a work of art? If you were visiting this museum, do you think you would have viewed the glasses as a work of art?
lead_paragraph: Have you read about the teenagers who left a pair of glasses on the floor of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, then watched as visitors assumed they were a work of art?

lead_paragraph: When Barbara A. Res, Donald J. Trump’s longtime construction executive, decided to leave his company in 1984, he bought her a bracelet and gave her a card with a warm, handwritten message.

headline: B & K French Cuisine Brings Paris to Harlem

lead_paragraph: Among the city’s million unseen threads, this one starts at B & K French Cuisine, a tiny Harlem counter with a few metal stools and a kitchen bereft of gas, and leads across the ocean to Restaurant Alain Ducasse at the Plaza Athénée Paris, where the ceiling rains down Swarovski crystals.

headline: Morning Agenda: Uber Receives $3.5 Billion from Saudi Arabia
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consumer Protection', 'Credit and Debt', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Law and Legislation', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Payday Loans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Start-ups', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Payday Loan Industry Could Soon Be Gutted | Sumner Redstone’s Granddaughter Sides With Viacom Directors
lead_paragraph: UBER RECEIVES $3.5 BILLION FROM SAUDI ARABIA | Uber has turned to the Middle East in its quest to build a global empire. It raised $3.5 billion from Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund in one of the largest ever investments into a privately held start-up,Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced report in The New York Times. This round of fund-raising continued to value the company at $62.5 billion.

headline: Using Meditation to Help Close the Achievement Gap
abstract: When a troubled school taught students Transcendental Meditation, suspensions dropped and attendance and students’ grade point averages rose.
lead_paragraph: Closing the so-called achievement gap between poor inner-city children and their more affluent suburban counterparts is among the biggest challenges for education reformers. The success of some schools’ efforts suggests that meditation might significantly improve children’s school performance – and help close that gap.

abstract: Accustomed to a career mix of recognition and indifference, the musical comedian says he was eager to give the show, starting a fifth season on Friday, a whirl.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Weird Al Yankovic, the enduring musical satirist, appears in the season premiere of IFC’s “Comedy Bang! Bang!” to introduce himself as the new bandleader of this ersatz talk show and settle in for his first steady television gig in nearly 20 years, this is the heartfelt welcome he receives from its host, Scott Aukerman.

abstract: When it’s a close call, weighing these factors can help anyone make a smarter housing decision.
lead_paragraph: Whether to buy or rent a home is among the biggest financial decisions most of us make. It is basically a complex math problem in which the reward for getting it right can be tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars — and the punishment for getting it wrong similarly enormous.

headline: The Ritz Paris Is Back
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks']
abstract: Changes, subtle and grand, mark the hotel’s reopening June 6 after lengthy renovations.
lead_paragraph: “When I dream of afterlife in heaven,” Ernest Hemingway once wrote in a letter to his friend and fellow writer A.E. Hotchner, “the action always takes place in the Paris Ritz.”

headline: German Parliament Recognizes Armenian Genocide, Angering Turkey
keywords: ['Armenians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Ottoman Empire', 'International Relations']
abstract: The Turkish government angrily denounced the vote as “null and void” and recalled its ambassador.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German Parliament overwhelmingly adopted a symbolic but fraught resolution on Thursday declaring the killings of Armenians by Ottoman Turks in 1915 a genocide, escalating tensions with Turkey at a diplomatically delicate juncture.

headline: Reader Idea | Teaching and Learning About Body Image in the Social Media Age
abstract: Jane Michel of our teenage Student Council makes an impassioned plea for teaching and learning about body image at a time when social media can warp teenage perceptions of what is normal.
lead_paragraph: This month we’ve been featuring projects conceived and written by members of our teenage Student Council, and this one is 17-year-old Jane Michel’s impassioned plea for teaching and learning about body image at a time when social media can warp young people’s perceptions of what is normal.

headline: Oliver Sacks Tribute Captures His Quirks and Insights
abstract: Readers, friends, colleagues and former patients gathered for a celebration of his life and work at an event for the World Science Festival.
lead_paragraph: Many people miss Oliver Sacks, the neurologist, best-selling author and philosopher of the mind who died of cancer last August at 82.

headline: Michael Lewis Explores Why People Tend to Go With Their Guts
abstract: Mr. Lewis tackles that question in “The Undoing Project: A Friendship That Changed Minds,” which W.W. Norton & Company will release in December.
lead_paragraph: Michael Lewis specializes in narratives about quirky individuals who zig when everyone else zags. In “Moneyball,” he tracked the astonishing success of Billy Beane, the general manager who turned the Oakland A’s from underdogs into championship contenders by relying on statistics rather than acquiring star players. His 2010 book “The Big Short” dissected how a handful of renegades foresaw the collapse of the housing market, while everyone else was pouring money into subprime mortgages.

headline: Inside the Battle for Sumner Redstone’s $40 Billion Media Empire
abstract: War has spread across the empire of Sumner Redstone, one of the entertainment industry’s most tenacious titans. At stake are the fortunes of his family and confidants, as well as the fate of Viacom and CBS.
lead_paragraph: War has spread across the empire of Sumner Redstone, one of the entertainment industry’s most tenacious titans. At stake are the fortunes of his family and confidants, as well as the fate of Viacom and CBS.

headline: Yannick Nézet-Séguin to Succeed James Levine as Met Opera’s Music Director
abstract: Mr. Nézet-Séguin, who conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra, assumes the post full-time in 2020. He begins as music director designate in 2017.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in four decades, the Metropolitan Opera has a new music director. The company announced on Thursday that it was passing the baton long held by James Levine to Yannick Nézet-Séguin, music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, known for vital, visceral music making.

headline: Is Yannick Nézet-Séguin Worth the Wait at the Met?
abstract: The conductor will become the next music director of the Metropolitan Opera, but he does not officially begin his tenure until the start of the 2020-21 season.
lead_paragraph: That the brilliant Canadian conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin, 41, will become the next music director of the Metropolitan Opera is not much of a surprise. Peter Gelb, the Met’s general manager, has been dropping hints of this move for months — for a couple of years, really. After the announcement in April that James Levine was stepping aside, it took just six weeks for the details of Mr. Nézet-Séguin’s appointment to be worked out.

headline: The Maestro With the Turtle Tattoo: The Met’s New Conductor
abstract: Yannick Nézet-Séguin has long affiliations with the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Rotterdam Philharmonic Orchestra and the Orchestre Métropolitain in Montreal.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera said on Thursday that the Canadian conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin would be its next music director. Here are some facts about him.

headline: 26 Men's Style Tastemakers on Their Secret Summer Destinations
abstract: Hidden beaches, obscure restaurants, out-of-the-way hikes and hotels. Miguel, James Harden and others in the know reveal their favorite spots.
lead_paragraph: Hidden beaches, obscure restaurants, out-of-the-way hikes and hotels. Miguel, James Harden and others in the know reveal their favorite spots.

headline: Another N.B.A. Finals Appearance Gives LeBron James a Rare Distinction
abstract: No player has made six consecutive trips to the N.B.A. finals since the Celtics dynasty of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: No player has made six consecutive trips to the N.B.A. finals since the Celtics dynasty of the 1960s.

keywords: ['Bible', 'Emojis and Emoticons', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Slang', 'Translation and Interpreters']

lead_paragraph: And God said, “Let there be emojis.”

headline: U.S. Bans Commercial Trade of African Elephant Ivory
keywords: ['Ivory', 'Elephants', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The new rules aim to protect the endangered African elephant and curb the illegal importation of ivory into the United States.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States Fish and Wildlife Service announced a near-total ban on the commercial trade of African elephant ivory on Thursday.

headline: 1916: Britain Hit in Battle of Jutland
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In June 1916, Britain hit in battle of Jutland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Admiralty this evening publishes [June 2] the following official communiqué: “During the afternoon of Wednesday, May 31, a naval battle was engaged off the coast of Jutland. The British warships which had to meet the shock consisted of battle cruisers and light cruisers, supported by four fast battleships. The losses were heavy among these ships. The battle-cruisers Queen Mary, Indefatigable and Invincible, and the cruisers Defence and Black Prince, were sunk. The Warrior was disabled, and, after having been towed for some time, had to be abandoned by her crew.” — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 3, 1916

headline: King Tut’s Dagger Made of ‘Iron From the Sky,’ Researchers Say
keywords: ['Egyptian Civilization', 'Tombs and Tombstones', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Meteors and Meteorites']
abstract: Using X-ray technology, Italian and Egyptian experts found that the blade’s composition was an approximate match for a meteorite that landed in northern Egypt.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The iron blade of an ornate dagger buried in Egypt with King Tutankhamen probably came from a fallen meteorite, researchers have determined — a form of metal so prized by ancient Egyptians that they called it “iron from the sky.”

headline: Snakes Outside Boston: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Jess Bidgood wrote about a plan to save Rattlesnakes from extinction. She’d already encountered a member of the species — in a dark wood near Boston.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Jess Bidgood, a reporter who wrote about a controversial rattlesnake conservation plan, describes her first encounter with the venomous reptile.

headline: Rare Visit to Taiwan by Siberian Crane Is a Bird-Watcher’s Dream
abstract: The only Siberian crane ever seen in Taiwan set off a frenzy by sightseers, the hiring of a 24-hour guard and environmental efforts to welcome such migratory species.
lead_paragraph: JINSHAN, Taiwan — The paparazzi gathered by the dozens, braving cold and rain and sticky heat. Sometimes their lanky quarry would lead them on long chases. Other times the celebrity would cooperate, particularly if crab or snail was on offer, drawing huge crowds to this farming hamlet on the northern coast of Taiwan after each sighting.

headline: What Saudi Arabia’s $3.5 Billion in Uber Buys
abstract: Uber is now worth four United Airlines, 2 billion rides across Midtown Manhattan and a good day at Google.
lead_paragraph: What are we to make of Saudi Arabia’s investment in Uber?

headline: Finding Your Family by Phone
abstract: Apps and services that use a smartphone’s GPS coordinates can help a parent know a child’s location, even when the child is out of sight.
lead_paragraph: Q. Can a parent with an iPhone keep tabs on the location of a child with an Android device with the “find my phone” tracking feature?

headline: Cincinnati Police Wrap Up Gorilla Investigation
abstract: A spokeswoman said no decision has been made on charging a mother whose son fell into a zoo enclosure. A recording of her 911 call was released.
lead_paragraph: The Cincinnati police have handed over to a prosecutor the results of their investigation into the actions of the family of a boy whose foray into an enclosure at the city’s zoo led to the killing of an endangered gorilla, officials said on Thursday.

headline: North Korea’s Missile Tests Timed to Bolster Standing With China, Analysts Say
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Relations']
abstract: The country has conducted a series of unsuccessful launches, said to reflect a frantic drive by the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, ahead of talks with Beijing.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A recent string of unsuccessful missile tests by North Korea, and the release of a video showing the launch of a different weapon, reflected a frantic drive by its leader, Kim Jong-un, to bolster his political standing before a high-profile dialogue with China, analysts said on Thursday.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Tired Gardener
abstract: What is wrong with a lively 67-year-old gardener who develops a daily fever and shaking chills along with chest pain and a dry cough?
lead_paragraph: The Challenge: Can you figure out what is wrong with a lively 67-year-old gardener who develops a daily fever and shaking chills along with chest pain and a dry cough?

headline: Saudi Oil Chief Khalid al-Falih Tells OPEC Changes Are Coming
abstract: The message came after the cartel decide to maintain high levels of production, citing the recent rise in prices and signs that the global petroleum glut might be easing.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The new oil minister in Saudi Arabia, the de facto leader of the OPEC countries, had a message for the global market: Don’t expect us to influence the price of crude oil by adjusting supplies.

headline: $100 Million to Change the World
abstract: Can enough money "solve" a social problem?

abstract: Police released the emergency call a mother made after her 3-year-old son fell into the gorilla pit at the Cincinnati Zoo.
lead_paragraph: Police released the emergency call a mother made after her 3-year-old son fell into the gorilla pit at the Cincinnati Zoo.

headline: Review: Andy Samberg Spoofs Pop Stars Without Spite. And That’s 4 Real.
abstract: The Lonely Island trio has created a mockumentary featuring the fictional Conner4Real, a former boy-band star trying to make it as a solo act.
lead_paragraph: This is not Spinal Tap, but that’s O.K. Times have changed.

headline: With Obama in Japan, and a Puppy in Brooklyn
abstract: Our soon-to-be Tokyo bureau chief learns to love Snapchat.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Motoko Rich, The Times’s soon-to-be Tokyo bureau chief, writes about learning to improvise in front of the camera — covering President Obama’s historic visit to Hiroshima via Facebook Live by day, and FaceTiming and Snapchatting with her children 13 hours behind her in Brooklyn by night.

headline: Britain Is Losing Its Religion, or at Least Its Official One
abstract: The Anglican God inherited over generations from Henry VIII’s day has long ceased to represent an exclusive franchise.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In these times of flux and challenge, when Britain’s post-imperial place in a globalized world has rarely been so minutely scrutinized and the nation’s very identity can appear to be little more than a work in progress, pity the poor parish priest.

headline: From Paris to Bavaria, Heavy Rains Cause Deadly Floods
abstract: About 5,000 people across France have been evacuated, and the Louvre and Musée d’Orsay announced closings. Meanwhile, rains have claimed several lives in Germany.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Torrential rains have caused deadly flooding in central and northeastern France this week, forcing the evacuation of thousands of people, some on boats or kayaks, and threatening works of art stored in Paris’s most celebrated museums.

headline: ‘Islamism Is Dead!’ Long Live Muslim Democrats
abstract: The country that led the Arab Spring is now the birthplace of the world’s first post-Islamist political party.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — “Islamism is dead!” announced Said Ferjani, a leader of the progressive wing of Ennahda, Tunisia’s main Islamist party, as we drank coffee in a hotel cafe here last month. Mr. Ferjani, a former hard-liner who once plotted a coup against the regime of President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, was upbeat as he described the historic transition his party was about to make.

headline: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan Will Not Back Donald Trump
abstract: “I’ve stayed out of the whole thing, and I’m going to continue to,” said the governor, who has faced his own struggles in Michigan amid the Flint water problems.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan will not support Donald J. Trump, his party’s presumptive presidential nominee, making him the latest prominent Republican to distance himself from the party’s new de facto leader.

headline: In Turner Paintings at the Met, the Bloody Business of Whaling
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has united four pictures by Turner, showing whalers and their ships, in a lushly atmospheric exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Among the most revered works by the great British painter Joseph Mallord William Turner (1775–1851) are those representing the world dissolved by light, steam, fog, smoke, rain, wind and snow. One of his favorite settings for his evocations of elemental chaos was the ocean, a place where nature regularly overwhelms human challenges to its dominion.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Rate Employees With Adjectives, Not Numbers
abstract: The Wall Street firm said it was overhauling performance evaluations in several ways, including discarding a numerical scale in favor of adjectives.
lead_paragraph: For years, Morgan Stanley employees were graded in part on a numerical scale that rated them from 1 to 5.

headline: Vito Acconci, an Artist as Influential as He Is Eccentric
abstract: Mr. Acconci’s most important work can seem more like legend than fact. This month he is having his first American survey in more than 30 years.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1960s, the artist Vito Acconci wandered into a movie theater near Times Square hoping to catch an art film and was confused to see a group of ragged-looking musicians take the stage. That group turned out to be the Velvet Underground, whose first album sold poorly but whose influence was so profound, as Brian Eno later said, that everyone who bought the record started a band.

headline: Did You Watch ‘Bloodline’? Let’s Talk About It
abstract: The Netflix series is nothing if not an exercise in mood. If the Rayburns return for a Season 3, will you join them?
lead_paragraph: Guilty admission: I didn’t make it beyond Episode 2 of Netflix’s “Bloodline” when the series premiered in March 2015. Despite an ensemble of actors I love — Sam Shepard, Sissy Spacek, Ben Mendelsohn and Kyle Chandler — something about its languid pacing required more patience than I had to give. But during a boat trip through the Florida Keys in January, I grew familiar with the rhythm of the islands, their placid waters hiding jagged outcroppings that can easily draw blood. And soon I was lured back into the lair of the Rayburns, those good people who keep doing bad, bad things.

headline: Video Replay in Soccer to Get Wider Testing in Six Countries
abstract: Major League Soccer is among the entities approved to experiment with replay, FIFA and the International Football Association Board said.
lead_paragraph: Soccer will experiment with video replay in league and cup competitions in six countries this year, FIFA and the body that governs the rules of the game announced on Thursday, with the intention of approving full use of the technology in matches over the next year.

headline: Bob Kerrey’s War Record Fuels Debate in Vietnam on His Role at New University
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Vietnam War', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Some question whether Mr. Kerrey, a former senator who has admitted that he and commandos he led in 1969 killed women and children, should lead Fulbright University Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The appointment of former Senator Bob Kerrey to lead a new American-backed university in Vietnam has set off a sharp debate among Vietnamese over whether he should be disqualified because of his part in killing women and children as a Navy SEAL during the Vietnam War.

headline: Can You Solve This Maze?
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Road Trips', 'Games', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Pass the time with two elaborate mazes and games that readers suggest you play on the road.
lead_paragraph: If you’re going on vacation, chances are you’ll spend some time waiting — in the car, in a security line at the airport — or simply lolling around on a beach. The architect Rolf Myller kept his hands busy creating visually stunning mazes, some of which were published in his 1976 book called “Mazes,” during his downtime. Feel free to try to solve them with your family during yours. Click here for printable versions of two of his mazes, including the one below, and here for the solutions.

headline: Summer Movies Preview: 10 Trailers for June
abstract: Popstars, orcs and a wiener-dog are coming to the big screen this month.
lead_paragraph: Popstars, orcs and a wiener-dog are coming to the big screen this month.

headline: Novak Djokovic’s Latest Opponent in His French Open Quest? His Temper
abstract: The top-ranked Djokovic rolled past Tomas Berdych and will face 22-year-old Dominic Thiem, who beat David Goffin to reach his first Grand Slam semifinal.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Novak Djokovic was back within striking range of his first French Open title on Thursday after a 6-3, 7-5, 6-3 victory over Tomas Berdych.

headline: Five Super-Simple Swimsuit Brands to Know
abstract: Just in time for summer, a guide to fuss-free bathing suits to last this season — and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Since launching her eponymous line in 2012, the designer Shaina Mote has won die-hard fans, who rely on the Los Angeles-based label for its versatile, elevated basics. Those fans, however, have had to fend for themselves in the swimwear category — until now. Today, Mote launches a capsule line of swimwear that stays true to the distinctive, functional aesthetic she’s perfected in her main line. The expansion was borne out of Mote’s struggle to find a suit that fit into her own life: “I felt there was a little bit of a void for a type of swimwear that can be used in an active environment as well as one that’s leisurely,” she says. To fulfill that mandate, Mote created a six-piece collection, which was inspired by the clean lines found in the work of the Mexican architect Luis Barragán. One innovation she struck upon: She eliminated the top stitch typically found on swimsuits, so that each style would “mesh into the body, and lie more flush with the skin.” With so much attention paid to the fit and cut, it’s no wonder Mote decided to keep the color palette as simple as possible. Every piece in the line, which has been crafted from dead-stock Italian fabric, is black. “I wanted to make sure I was presenting the customer with something that was really accessible and travels well,” she says. “Since this is my first swimwear collection, I really wanted to nail down those basics and core styles.”

headline: Bookshelf: Little Kids, Big Machines
abstract: New picture books include “With Any Luck, I'll Drive a Truck” and “You Must Be This Tall.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include “With Any Luck, I'll Drive a Truck” and “You Must Be This Tall.”

headline: Review: ‘The Threepenny Opera,’ ‘Romeo and Juliet’ and ‘Human Animals.’
abstract: New ‘‘Threepenny Opera’’ on London stage delivers on promise of Brecht and Weill’s classic.
lead_paragraph: To the list of recent happy theatrical surprises, add this one: Rory Kinnear sings, and very well, too.

headline: Trey Pearson, a Popular Christian Rocker, Tells Fans He’s Gay
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: Mr. Pearson, 35, lead singer of Everyday Sunday, joins several other Christian musicians who have come out.
lead_paragraph: The lead singer of the popular Christian rock band Everyday Sunday, Trey Pearson, came out as gay on Tuesday in an open letter to his fans, ending a yearslong personal struggle between faith and sexuality and joining a flock of Christian musicians who have come out as gay or lesbian in recent years.

headline: Video Review: With Pacifica, Chrysler Makes the Minivan Relevant
abstract: The company moves the defunct Pacifica’s name over to the defunct Town & Country, producing a minivan that is handsome and supremely useful.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps my deep-seated need to be helpful is a result of growing up in Minnesota. Certainly, crossovers and sport utility vehicles are the vehicles that families want. Minivans have lost their allure. My northern sensibility pines to tell you, however, that there’s something magical about vans for making life easier.

headline: Three Young Artists Interpret Reality in a Digital Era
abstract: Britta Thie, Rachel Rose and Timur Si-Qin talk about their pieces that are featured in Julia Stoschek Collection’s first Berlin exhibition.
lead_paragraph: “What if everything we think is real is just an illusion?” began A. O. Scott’s review of the 1973 made-for-German-TV movie by Rainer Werner Fassbinder, “Welt Am Draht” (in English, “World on a Wire”). Now, the title of that sci-fi film has been repurposed by the collector Julia Stoschek for the inaugural show in her new Berlin space, which brings together a contingent of multimedia artists who are likewise reevaluating the meaning of reality — this time in the digital era. The works — which include videos, live simulations, performances and sculptures — range from satirical cultural commentaries to visualizations of future metropolises. Here, three of the creators, all born in the mid-’80s, explain their contributions.

headline: 1941: Lou Gehrig Dies at 37
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In June 1941, Lou Gehrig dies at 37.
lead_paragraph: Lou Gehrig, former captain and first baseman of the New York Yankees, and one of the greatest baseball stars of all time, died at 10 o’clock last night [June 1] at his home, 5204 Delafield Avenue, Fieldston, the Bronx. He would have been 38 years old on June 19.

headline: Almost 100, ‘Forgotten Legend of Basketball’ Still Marvels at the Game
abstract: Watching hoops and catching up with John Kundla, who won five professional titles with the Minneapolis Lakers in the 1940s and ’50s.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — John Kundla sat in a wheelchair playing cribbage opposite his 68-year-old son, calling out numbers in a quiet, deep voice. The efficiency apartment here had a twin bed under a painting of Jesus tending sheep; a desk topped with a large magnifying glass and a Bible; and, resting on a shelf, a photograph taken on a basketball court in 1952 showing Kundla atop the shoulders of a jubilant George Mikan, the sport’s most dominant big man in the first half of the 20th century.

headline: Exelon to Close 2 Nuclear Plants in Illinois
abstract: The power provider plans to shut down the money-losing Clinton Power Station and the Quad Cities Generating Station.
lead_paragraph: Exelon, a leading competitive power provider, plans to shut two money-losing nuclear plants in Illinois, the company said Thursday, after efforts to push a bailout through the state’s Legislature fell apart.

headline: U.C.L.A. Gunman May Have Targeted 2nd Professor and Killed Woman
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Colleges and Universities', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: The gunman who killed a professor and himself may have also killed a woman in Minnesota, and may have intended to kill another professor, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Before he fatally shot a U.C.L.A. professor he had studied under, a gunman apparently killed a woman near his home in Minnesota, then drove to California planning to gun down two professors, but found only one of them, law enforcement officials said Thursday.

abstract: A college lecturer says “safe spaces” shouldn’t be written off.

headline: Inside the Transformational Makeover Salon
abstract: At the artist Erica Prince’s experimental beauty parlor, participants can receive new looks intended to enhance perspective — but not, necessarily, prettiness.
lead_paragraph: At the artist Erica Prince’s experimental beauty parlor, participants can receive new looks intended to enhance perspective — but not, necessarily, prettiness.

headline: I Got a Radical Makeover — for Art’s Sake
abstract: One woman’s experience inside an experimental beauty salon created to enhance perspective — but not, necessarily, prettiness.
lead_paragraph: “It started when I was a teenager. I became really interested in playing with makeup in the same way I would with any art supply,” says the artist Erica Prince, 30, as she leads me up the stairs to In Limbo. The airy Williamsburg apartment-cum-gallery has been transformed into a temporary beauty parlor where, through June 5, Prince is seeking participants for the Transformational Makeover Salon. Each brave soul visits the gallery alone, and after a consultation, receives a new look. For the artist, who typically works in drawing and sculpture, this sort of intimate performance is a departure from her usual practice. “The idea of doing a relational project really scared me at first, but it’s been amazing to get away from my studio and out of my solitary conversation with myself,” she says. “It’s an exercise in being present.”

headline: As Bangladesh Counts Rohingya, Some Fear Forced Relocation
keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Census']
abstract: It is the first time the country has conducted a census of the refugees who have poured across the border fleeing persecution in Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: COX’S BAZAR, Bangladesh — Bangladesh’s government began its first census of undocumented Rohingya refugees on Thursday, setting off fears that it might lead to a mass relocation or forcible repatriation of the refugees to Myanmar.

headline: Migraines Tied to Increased Risk of Heart Problems
abstract: Women with migraines were more likely to have heart attacks and strokes than women who didn’t have the painful headaches.
lead_paragraph: Women who suffer from migraines are at higher risk of developing cardiovascular disease than women who aren’t plagued by the severe headaches, and they are more likely to have a stroke, heart attack or to die of heart disease, a new study reports.

headline: Serena Williams Survives a Shaky Quarterfinal at the French Open
abstract: The top-ranked Williams was down a set to Yulia Putintseva before rallying to reach the semifinals, where she will face No. 58 Kiki Bertens.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A few moments after Serena Williams narrowly avoided a crushing upset at the hands of a player ranked 60th in the world, she met with her coach, Patrick Mouratoglou, and lamented her performance.

abstract: Our solar system’s sixth planet will be at opposition, providing one of the best opportunities to see it with the naked eye.

headline: Riding Out Storms, and Loneliness, in the Ocean Search for Flight 370
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370', 'Sonar']
abstract: A ship’s 30-member crew has braved towering waves and other hazards as it looks for debris of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet on the ocean floor.
lead_paragraph: FREMANTLE, Australia — For Scott Miller, part of a team searching for the remains of a doomed Malaysia Airlines flight, the worst hours in a lifetime at sea came when his 215-foot vessel was caught last year between two powerful tropical cyclones and lashed by hurricane-force winds.

headline: No! There’s Something About Me You Haven’t Googled?
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Online Dating']
abstract: Somewhere between going into a date completely blind and compiling a dossier worthy of J. Edgar Hoover, there has to be a happy medium.
lead_paragraph: I was scheduled to go on a first date with a guy I’d met online a while back, and wishing to be helpful, a friend sent me everything she could find on him. His résumé, a speech he gave, pictures of him and his ex-wife in a magazine. Everything, really, but his I.R.S. files. There should be a name for this kind-of sort-of online dossier. “Webssier,” maybe? It sounds like the beginning of that kids’ song:

headline: Revisiting Godello, a Grape That Spain Has Rescued
abstract: These white wines call to mind chenin blanc, viognier or marsanne.
lead_paragraph: The world of wine often seems like a laboratory with multiple experiments in progress. This is particularly so in Spain, where winemaking roots are ancient yet so much seems new again.

headline: U.S. Accuses Dutch Citizen of Reaping Millions in Mail-Fraud Scheme
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: A complaint filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn this week accuses Erik Dekker and companies he owned of stealing up to $18 million a year since at least 2012 by targeting older Americans.
lead_paragraph: A Dutch citizen and two companies he owned ran a multimillion-dollar mail-fraud scheme that targeted hundreds of thousands of older Americans, according to a civil complaint announced on Thursday by federal prosecutors in Brooklyn.

headline: 1966-2016 | The Last Hot-Type Printer Puts Down His Tools
abstract: Rudolph Stocker, the last printer at The Times to have operated a Linotype casting machine, retired on May 18.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David W. Dunlap, a metro reporter, looks back at the 50-year career of Rudolph Stocker.

abstract: One reader suggests that if Bernie Sanders drops out now, it could actually hurt Hillary Clinton’s chances; another offers Mrs. Clinton a one-word slogan.

headline: A-Fib Is More Dangerous for Blacks Than Whites
abstract: Atrial fibrillation, an irregular heartbeat associated with various types of cardiovascular problems, is more dangerous in black people than in whites, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: Atrial fibrillation, or A-fib, an irregular heartbeat associated with various types of cardiovascular problems, is more dangerous, and more often fatal, in black people than in whites, a new study has found.

headline: Rufus Wainwright, Michael Strahan and More On How to Travel in Style
abstract: Michael Strahan, Rufus Wainwright, Vic Mensa, Tom Colicchio and Andrew Smith describe their travel necessities, from carry-ons to headphones.
lead_paragraph: Michael Strahan, Rufus Wainwright, Vic Mensa, Tom Colicchio and Andrew Smith describe their travel necessities, from carry-ons to headphones.

headline: An Artist Takes On Cancer
abstract: A video uses mesmerizing imagery to explore cancer treatment, the fear of death and the hope for a cure.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, at age 28, the songwriter and performer Benjamin Scheuer was given a diagnosis of stage 4 Hodgkin lymphoma, a cancer of the lymph nodes. He recounted his experience, along with other family perplexities, when he played himself in his one-man autobiographical musical, “The Lion,” which opened Off Broadway last year. In the new video “Cure,” directed by Peter Baynton and premiered here on Well, Mr. Scheuer conveys the dread that brands cancer patients, whether or not their type of disease is treatable.

headline: Mitski’s ‘Puberty 2’ Mines Her Scars for Raw Meaning
abstract: The singer’s new album doubles down on grit while rounding things out with a buffer of soul.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — For most of Mitski Miyawaki’s childhood, she was on the move. Because of her father’s job, she lived in 13 countries — a constant carousel of arrivals and departures, attaching and detaching, trying to fit in, if only for the moment.

abstract: The chancellor of the City University of New York and others discuss its prospects.
