headline: Tegan and Sara Talk About ‘Love You to Death,’ a Deeper Dive Into the Pop Mainstream
abstract: The twins open up about their new album, their pop ambitions and the absence of an openly gay female megastar.
lead_paragraph: It’s practically a music industry cliché that with age comes more acoustic guitars, those tools for slowing down and projecting serious wisdom. But Tegan and Sara flipped the script.

headline: Libor Prosecution Snares Two Former Deutsche Traders
abstract: The former traders are the latest Wall Street workers to be ensnared in the government’s crackdown on interest rate manipulation.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department announced criminal charges on Thursday against two former Deutsche Bank traders accused of manipulating interest rates, the latest Wall Street employees to be ensnared in the government’s wide-ranging crackdown.

headline: MacArthur Foundation Will Award $100 Million for Solution to a Global Problem
abstract: The prize will be given not to individuals or government entities, but to any nonprofit or for-profit organization that identifies a problem and offers a fix.
lead_paragraph: The MacArthur Foundation, known for bestowing “genius” grants on artists, actors and other creative people, introduced a new competition on Thursday that would award $100 million to an organization with the best proposal to solve a global problem.

headline: Where Did Dogs Come From? There May Be Two Answers.
abstract: A scientist studying the origins of dogs suggests they may have been domesticated twice.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have done well in scouring the DNA of humans to track our origins to the African continent.

headline: ‘Rembrandt’s First Masterpiece,’ a Portrait of a Biblical Betrayal
abstract: The painting “Judas Returning the Thirty Pieces of Silver,” at the Morgan Library & Museum, forecasts what would define the Dutch master’s style.
lead_paragraph: “Are you looking at me? I certainly hope so.” If pictures could speak, these would be the words delivered by a small bust-length ink drawing of a youngish man with a big nose, small eyes, the ghost of a mustache and artfully tousled hair, at the Morgan Library & Museum. He frowns a little, as if wary of attention, but you can tell he’s kidding-serious, trying out a pose of artist as prodigy.

headline: The Playwright Mac Rogers Explores Robots, Aliens and Allegory
abstract: Mr. Rogers, whose play “Universal Robots” is opening at the Sheen Center, said science fiction “makes tackling challenging ideas a lot more fun.”
lead_paragraph: “I’m a little unnerved,” the playwright Mac Rogers said.

headline: ‘More Perfect,’ a Spinoff of ‘Radiolab,’ Comes to WNYC
abstract: This series about untold stories of the Supreme Court aims to make the court seem accessible while not being overly simple about it.
lead_paragraph: “Radiolab,” the popular and influential documentary podcast from WNYC, began its first spinoff on Thursday with “More Perfect,” a series about untold stories of the Supreme Court.

headline: Jeff Hornacek to Be Introduced as Knicks Coach on Friday
abstract: The Knicks will introduce Hornacek as their new coach at a news conference on Friday.
lead_paragraph: It took a while, but the Knicks will officially introduce Jeff Hornacek as their new coach on Friday, the news conference coming about two weeks after it became known that he was coming aboard.

headline: Brazil’s Soccer Prowess Has Been Consumed by Years of Neglect
abstract: As the Copa América Centenario kicks off this weekend and the Rio Olympics loom later this summer, Brazil’s national team is a shadow of its past.
lead_paragraph: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil — Around here, they don’t talk about that night a whole lot anymore.

headline: Scientists Announce HGP-Write, Project to Synthesize the Human Genome
abstract: The formal announcement of the plans, which leaked last month, seeks to raise $100 million this year. The total price tag could exceed $1 billion.
lead_paragraph: Scientists on Thursday formally announced the start of a 10-year project aimed at vastly improving the ability to chemically manufacture DNA, with one of the goals being to synthetically create an entire human genome.

headline: Prince Died From Accidental Overdose of Opioid Painkiller
keywords: ['Music', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Pain', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: Officials in Minnesota said the singer sustained an accidental overdose of self-administered fentanyl, a type of synthetic opiate.
lead_paragraph: Prince, the music icon who struggled with debilitating hip pain during his career, died from an accidental overdose of self-administered fentanyl, a type of synthetic opiate, officials in Minnesota said Thursday.

headline: Obama Tells Air Force Cadets to Embrace Diplomacy
keywords: ['Commencement Speeches', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: At the Air Force Academy’s commencement, the president said the military must be willing to use the full arsenal of America’s defense, including its nonlethal tools, to resolve disputes.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — President Obama on Thursday used his final commencement address to a United States military academy to urge Air Force cadets to find the right balance between force and diplomacy as they join the ranks of the country’s armed forces.

headline: Put a Ring on It? Why It Doesn't Matter
abstract: Readers react to an article about men wearing wedding rings, or not.
lead_paragraph: Readers react to an article about men wearing wedding rings, or not.

headline: “Flora Powers”
abstract: For the next three days in Berlin, residents and visitors can order five strange, ephemeral flower sculptures — each designed by an artist exhibiting in the city’s Biennale.
lead_paragraph: For the next three days in Berlin, residents and visitors can order five strange, ephemeral flower sculptures — each designed by an artist exhibiting in the city’s Biennale.

headline: Imaginative Flowers, Designed by Artists — and Available to Order
abstract: For a few days during the Berlin Biennale, a fly-by-night floral delivery service in the city offers unconventional posies inspired by pigeons, petroleum and more.
lead_paragraph: For the next three days in Berlin, residents and visitors can order decidedly unconventional floral posies — variously inspired by pigeons’ nests, deep-sea creatures and the petroleum industry — for delivery. The five ephemeral flower sculptures on offer, each designed by an artist exhibiting in the city’s Biennale and priced between $70 and $80, function as a sort of Interflora for the conceptual set. “Flora Powers is not meant to be anything more lofty than a flower delivery service,” explains Andrea Hill of Paloma Powers, the irreverent creative agency that has produced the project. “Flowers are a very personal gift, and their delivery is a great moment to celebrate alongside the artists exhibiting in the Berlin Biennale.”

headline: Speaker Paul Ryan, After an Awkward Courtship, Endorses Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Endorsements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: After weeks of apparent reluctance, the speaker said he was confident that his party’s presumptive nominee would press “our agenda” if elected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ending weeks of reluctance to embrace his party’s presumptive nominee, Speaker Paul D. Ryan endorsed Donald J. Trump for president on Thursday in a modest but unequivocal backing of a candidate whose views Mr. Ryan has frequently condemned.

headline: Why Can’t My BFF and My New Boyfriend Get Along?
abstract: Also, how to handle gender ambiguity, friends who are too heavy on the salt, and dinner guests who are only half-thankful.
lead_paragraph: I have been single for several years, and my best friend and I have come to count on each other for daily check-ins, frequent dinners and weekend plans — almost like a couple, but without the sex. Recently, I met a great guy, and we’ve been dating. I was really looking forward to introducing them. But it was a disaster. Later, he said, “She’s totally possessive of you and mean.” She said, “He’s all wrong for you.” I decided to give them a break from each other until I consulted with you. What should I do?

headline: Review: ‘The Witness,’ a Brother’s Quest to Put Kitty Genovese Case to Rest
keywords: ['Movies', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: James Solomon’s documentary traces Bill Genovese’s efforts to unravel his sister’s 1964 murder, a Queens case long seen as the epitome of urban apathy.
lead_paragraph: In March 1964, the fatal stabbing in Kew Gardens, Queens, of 28-year-old Catherine Genovese, known as Kitty, caused international outrage. A front-page article in The New York Times at the time said 38 people had witnessed her murder and failed to act, embodiments of urban indifference. Now James Solomon’s seamless documentary, “The Witness,” traces the yearslong efforts of Ms. Genovese’s younger brother Bill, who was close to Kitty, to get to the bottom of what actually happened.

headline: Walmart Looks to Drones to Speed Distribution
abstract: The retailer is testing flying drones to handle inventory at its warehouses. The machines could help catalog in a day what now takes employees about a month.
lead_paragraph: BENTONVILLE, Ark. — Soon, the labyrinthine aisles at Walmart’s distribution centers — stocked high with canned beans, toys and many other products — could also have a low humming sound.

headline: At Carnegie Hall, a New Leader With a Son Named Hendrix
abstract: Robert Smith, 53, a philanthropist and co-founder and chief executive of Vista Equity Partners, was on Forbes’s list of the richest Americans last year.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Smith, the private equity titan who was named the richest African-American man by Forbes last year after making a fortune in software, also has a quirky musical side.

headline: Political Violence Roils the Republic of Congo
keywords: ['Elections', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: Since the country’s longtime president was re-elected in March, humanitarian groups have reported airstrikes and ground offensives in opposition strongholds of the capital, Brazzaville.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Denis Sassou-Nguesso’s new term in office, a continuation of his decades in power after a murky re-election, has gotten off to a rocky start since violence in the Republic of Congo has left his political opponents fearing for their lives.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘American Psycho’
abstract: Mary Harron narrates a sequence from her 2000 film “American Psycho,” which will screen as part of the Woman is a Genre series at Film Forum in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Mary Harron narrates a sequence from her 2000 film “American Psycho,” which will screen as part of the Woman is a Genre series at Film Forum in Manhattan.

headline: Letters From a Secret Courtship in 19th-Century Brooklyn Evoke a Jane Austen Plot
abstract: Romantic scheming that a Brooklyn teenager hid from her parents in the 1810s will be exposed at an auction this month.
lead_paragraph: Romantic scheming that a Brooklyn teenager hid from her parents in the 1810s will be exposed this month when three binders filled with letters go on sale in Manhattan. On June 21, Swann Auction Galleries will offer Jane Schenck’s correspondence with an unsuitable suitor named Ralph Malbone. Their letters, estimated at $2,000 to $3,000 for the lot, solve some mysteries about the couple’s relationship.

headline: Former Morgan Stanley Deal Makers Reunite on Exchange Merger
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The merger between Deutsche Börse and the London Stock Exchange highlights a changing market for merger advice as boutique investment banks prosper.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The main investment bankers involved in the merger between Deutsche Börse and the London Stock Exchange worked at one of Wall Street’s biggest companies, Morgan Stanley, the last time the two exchanges flirted with the idea of getting married.

headline: Floods Sweep Through Germany and France
abstract: Heavy rains brought devastating flooding to Germany and France this week. Thousands were displaced from their homes in both countries, and at least nine people were killed in Germany.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rains brought devastating flooding to Germany and France this week. Thousands were displaced from their homes in both countries, and at least nine people were killed in Germany.

headline: Mary Harron Narrates a Scene From ‘American Psycho’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from her 2000 film featuring Christian Bale.
lead_paragraph: The films of female directors working in genre cinema (including film noir, horror, action and sexploitation) will be celebrated in “Genre Is a Woman,” a series at Film Forum running June 3-16. The series includes the 2000 horror film “American Psycho,” based on the novel by Bret Easton Ellis and directed by Mary Harron. That film, about an investment banker (Christian Bale) with serial-killer tendencies, satirized masculinity and social climbing in a pitch black way. The film inspired a Broadway musical and helped propel Mr. Bale’s Hollywood career.

headline: Roger Enrico, PepsiCo Chief During 1980s ‘Cola Wars,’ Dies at 71
abstract: He made marketing deals with celebrities like Michael Jackson, Madonna, Cindy Crawford and Michael J. Fox to try to gain market share from Coca-Cola.
lead_paragraph: Roger Enrico, the PepsiCo chief executive who nearly dethroned Coca-Cola in the 1980s, died on Wednesday while vacationing in the Cayman Islands. He was 71.

headline: Sponsors Driven Away by Golf’s Angel Investor
abstract: Running for president seems bad for some of Trump’s businesses, including some sports-related ones.
lead_paragraph: To the many things you can say about Donald J. Trump’s presidential bid, add this: Running for president can be bad for business.

headline: Sexploitation Films, Short on Good Taste, Still Have Devotees
abstract: The documentary "That’s Sexploitation!” looks at the bygone days of sex-centered independent filmmaking.
lead_paragraph: Exploitation cinema is a sleazy United Nations. Its membership includes blaxploitation (“Foxy Brown”), Ozploitation (“Dead End Drive-In” from Australia), European nunsploitation (“Killer Nun”) and other internationally NSFW categories unpalatable for family reading.

headline: Minnesota Death Tied to U.C.L.A. Gunman
abstract: The police in Brooklyn Park, Minn., said a woman found dead in her apartment had appeared on a “hit list” left by the man who killed a U.C.L.A. professor and himself.
lead_paragraph: The police in Brooklyn Park, Minn., said a woman found dead in her apartment had appeared on a “hit list” left by the man who killed a U.C.L.A. professor and himself.

headline: Hillary Clinton Warns That Donald Trump’s ‘Thin Skin’ Would Set Off War or Economic Crisis
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton on Thursday unleashed a new attack on Mr. Trump, saying that electing him as president would be a “historic mistake.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton delivered a lacerating rebuke on Thursday of her likely Republican opponent, Donald J. Trump, declaring that he was hopelessly unprepared and temperamentally unfit to be commander in chief. Electing him, she said, would be a “historic mistake.”

headline: One Guantánamo Detainee Pleads for Release, but Another Does Not Appear
abstract: In one hearing, the author of a memoir about his time in prison was portrayed as a model prisoner, while elsewhere disruptions at the facility were described.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two longtime detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, made rare public appearances in separate military hearings on Thursday, including Mohamedou Ould Slahi, whose memoir recounting abuse by American interrogators became a best-seller last year after he waged a yearslong battle with the government for permission to publish it.

headline: Evocative Photos of New York City — Through the Eyes of a Native
abstract: In describing his process, Harry McNally says he sees the camera as “an obstacle between me and an image. I try not to let it get in the way.”
lead_paragraph: In describing his process, Harry McNally says he sees the camera as “an obstacle between me and an image. I try not to let it get in the way.”

headline: Donald Verrilli Will Step Down as U.S. Solicitor General
abstract: Mr. Verrilli successfully argued the Obama administration’s position on the Affordable Care Act and same-sex marriage before the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department announced on Thursday that Donald B. Verrilli Jr., who won historic Supreme Court rulings for the Obama administration on its signature health care law and on same-sex marriage, would be stepping down as the nation’s top appellate lawyer.

headline: Johnson & Johnson Is Urged to Slim Down
abstract: The health care giant is criticized by many investors for its mediocre shareholder returns and its lack of merger-and-acquisition activity.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson weighs heavy. The bulging health care conglomerate is swallowing the hair-care company Vogue International for $3.3 billion in defiance of calls to break up. Johnson & Johnson’s $312 billion market value makes it a hard target for activists. Yet its size has created ailments, including poor merger-and-acquisition activity and mediocre shareholder returns.

headline: Winners of Our Seventh Annual Found Poem Contest
abstract: Over 1,000 teenagers sent in entries to our contest, and we’ve finally settled on our favorites. Here, a full list of winners, runners-up and honorable mentions, as well as a PDF of the names of those whose work made it to the final round.
lead_paragraph: Over 1,000 teenagers entered our Seventh Annual Found Poem Contest, and, after much agonizing, we’ve settled on our favorites. Below, you can find a full list of winners, runners-up and honorable mentions, as well as a PDF of the names of those whose work made it to the final round.

headline: In Sumner Redstone Affair, His Decline Upends Estate Planning
abstract: As Americans live longer, experts warn that the elderly are increasingly at risk from those close to them taking advantage of their faltering minds.
lead_paragraph: With a fortune estimated at over $5 billion, Sumner M. Redstone could afford the best estate planning that money could buy.

headline: Longevity Pose: Teaching Yoga at Age 97
abstract: At 97, Tao Porchon-Lynch is still teaching yoga, enjoying wine, driving and entering dance contests.
lead_paragraph: Tao Porchon-Lynch, 97, breezed into her regular Wednesday evening yoga class in a brightly colored outfit: stretch pants, sleeveless top, flowing scarf and three-inch heels.

headline: Eight Straw Bags for the Beach (and Beyond)
abstract: Adorned with pompoms or tassels, festive carryalls for the summer months.
lead_paragraph: Adorned with pompoms or tassels, festive carryalls for the summer months.

headline: Sony Entertainment Chief Revamps TV Division
abstract: Sony said the move was intended to integrate its television unit more fully into the broader studio.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Michael Lynton, the chief executive of Sony Entertainment, revamped the studio’s growing television division on Thursday, a move that will streamline operations and increase his personal oversight.

headline: After Harambe’s Death, Rethinking Zoos
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Circuses', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Zoos']
abstract: One of the tragedies of the death of Harambe at the Cincinnati Zoo is that, captive from birth, he never experienced what it was like to be a gorilla.
lead_paragraph: ON May 9, 2004, when he was 6, my younger son took his first photographs. I know the date because digital photography is relentlessly precise. We were at the Bronx Zoo. While wandering the glass-lined corridors in the extraordinary Congo Gorilla Forest, Jack snapped this portrait of one of the western lowland gorillas.

headline: Review: ‘The Wailing’ Will Scare You, and Break Your Heart
abstract: Na Hong-jin’s movie about demonic possession is an expansive and often excruciating horror film from South Korea.
lead_paragraph: “The Wailing” is an expansive and often excruciating horror film from South Korea. It is the work of the director Na Hong-jin, whose 2009 debut feature, the action thriller  “The Chaser,” made a huge impression not least for its almost staggering flouting of genre convention. “The Wailing,” about demonic possession, is similarly uncompromising.

headline: Review: ‘The Thoughts That Once We Had,’ a Cinematic Flight
abstract: A montage of film clips that takes us on a wild ride through cinematic history.
lead_paragraph: Meaning plays hide-and-seek with montage in “The Thoughts That Once We Had,” Thom Andersen’s deeply personal, cheekily digressive dance through most of movie history. Yet this by turns transporting, brow-furrowing, nostalgic and obtuse visual essay — inspired in part by the writings of the French philosopher Gilles Deleuze — never feels overwhelming. Even if you don’t recognize the majority of the unidentified clips assembled here, or the quotations that divide and guide them, the fascination they exert is all their own.

headline: In Atlanta, Delta Designs a New Security Line
abstract: Working with the T.S.A., Delta has introduced what it calls innovation lanes to help speed passengers through airport security.
lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines is making a push to help speed up increasingly long airport security lines.

headline: Megan Fox on ‘Ninja Turtles’ and Female Stereotypes in Film
abstract: The actress discusses comparing Michael Bay to Hitler, and her comfort with not being overly ambitious. “I don’t feel validated by being on a set, or making a movie.”
lead_paragraph: Fans of Megan Fox have had to exercise patience: The actress, by her own admission, doesn’t work much. “I’ve never made more than two movies a year,” she said. Her recent arc on the Fox series “New Girl,” was, then, an unexpected treat, and she will reappear next season, she said, as a love interest and sharp-tongued comic foil. And she returns as April, the adventurous reporter and stalwart buddy in the sequel “Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows,” out on Friday, June 3.

headline: William Eggleston Joins Zwirner Gallery
abstract: Mr. Eggleston, 76, has joined David Zwirner’s gallery after having been represented by Larry Gagosian for five years.
lead_paragraph: “I think the photo community sometimes takes their own and holds them hostage,” said the dealer David Zwirner. “It’s important for Eggleston’s work to be seen among the great art that’s being made. I know that’s very important for him in choosing our gallery.”

headline: Review: With the Latest ‘Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,’ an Existential Crisis
abstract: In “Out of the Shadows” the superheros contend with an apocalyptic villain and wonder what it means to be normal.
lead_paragraph: In 2014’s “Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,” the title characters, on meeting the journalist April O’Neil, comment with aggressive enthusiasm on her good looks. They subsequently learn that April cared for them when they were just regular turtles, and, hence, is kind of like a big sister. At that point, a viewer might expect the fellows to stop hitting on her, but this reboot of the whimsical superhero franchise is partially produced by Michael Bay, so, no.

headline: A Man Goes on a Journey
abstract: Unsatisfied with their lots in life, these guys took off for points unknown. When they got back home, something had definitely changed.
lead_paragraph: Ron Silver, the owner of the Bubby’s restaurants in Manhattan, was fighting with his business partner. His marriage was collapsing. So he decided to disappear.

headline: Review: Arthur Lubow’s Diane Arbus Biography Recalls an Underworld Voyager
abstract: This account of Arbus’s life, while not skimping on sordid details, demonstrates the defects and virtues of consummate professionalism.
lead_paragraph: Diane Arbus’s most memorable photographs — of identical siblings, circus dwarfs, transgender people, nudists, the mentally impaired — have an element of myth about them. Since her suicide at 48 in 1971, her personal story, like Sylvia Plath’s, has also slipped into the realm of myth. Lines that Plath wrote in her journals — “I desire the things which will destroy me in the end” — could have been Arbus’s.

headline: Review: ‘The President,’ a Sweeping Tale Inspired by the Arab Spring
abstract: A dictator and his grandson, on the run during a political revolution, hide incognito among the citizenry in this film from Mohsen Makhmalbaf.
lead_paragraph: The Iranian director Mohsen Makhmalbaf (“A Moment of Innocence,” “Kandahar”) is not known for his kineticism, but “The President” — which he has suggested is his comment on the Arab Spring — has surprising urgency and sweep. The film is set in an unknown country (everyone speaks Georgian), where a dictator (Misha Gomiashvili) thinks nothing of approving a teenager’s execution in front of his grandson (Dachi Orvelashvili), who looks to be about 5. He then invites the child to play a game: They’ll turn the power on and off in the city below the presidential palace.

headline: Review: ‘Gurukulam’ Offers Sights and Sounds of a Spiritual Awakening
abstract: This documentary follows students and their teacher, Swami Dayananda Saraswati, as they explore the Hindu philosophy of oneness in a forest ashram in India.
lead_paragraph: A string of luxurious retreats stretches from Goa to the Himalayas, promising wisdom and renewal. Swami Dayananda Saraswati’s modest ashram in Tamil Nadu, in southern India, is graced by verdant forest surroundings, but runs on communal labor.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, June 4 Through June 12
abstract: Gregory Porter, the jazz and soul musician, will perform at the Mayo Performing Arts Center on June 9 in Morristown, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘The God Cells’ Advocates Fetal Tissue Therapy Without Debate
abstract: A company that markets stem cell therapy cooperated with the filmmaker on this one-sided documentary focusing on treatment success stories.
lead_paragraph: “The God Cells,” a one-sided documentary advocating fetal stem cell injections, is short on credibility but long on stories about the miraculous reversals of catastrophic medical conditions. That will make it catnip for people who are desperate for help for themselves or a sick child.

headline: Review: ‘The Final Master,’ a Martial Arts Story of Transitions
abstract: A kung fu master seeks a wife and a place to teach in Tianjin, and finds what he needs, if not what he was looking for.
lead_paragraph: Xu Haofeng, the screenwriter of Wong Kar-wai’s 2013 film, “The Grandmaster,” adapts his own short story for this not-necessarily-for-novices martial arts tale. Like “The Grandmaster,” “The Final Master” is about the world of martial arts in the early 20th century, a transitional time not just for fighting styles but also for Asia itself.

headline: Edgar Feuchtwanger Bore Witness, Horribly Close to Hitler
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The writer and historian grew up perhaps 100 yards from Adolf Hitler during the Nazi era, before escaping Germany.
lead_paragraph: To be a Jew in Germany in the 1930s was not comfortable. Edgar Feuchtwanger, a schoolboy in Munich at the time, knew the fear and the dread shared by all German Jews witnessing the unstoppable ascent of a madman. Yet his situation was different. Very different.

headline: Theater Listings for June 3-9
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: Review: In ‘Approaching the Unknown,’ Mark Strong Trades Earth for Mars
abstract: This Mark Elijah Rosenberg film centers on an astronaut and has echoes of movies like “2001: A Space Odyssey” and “Interstellar.”
lead_paragraph: “Approaching the Unknown” can’t avoid comparisons with “The Martian” from last fall. Both movies feature a solo astronaut (Mark Strong here, Matt Damon in that Ridley Scott film) who fends off probable death with Rube Goldberg solutions. In this case, the problems begin long before Mars is reached.

headline: Review: In ‘Andron,’ Deadly Games With Alec Baldwin and Danny Glover
abstract: A knockoff of “The Hunger Games” and “The Maze Runner,” this film adds up to less than the sum of its parts.
lead_paragraph: If it were at all original, “Andron” would be merely a bad movie poorly executed. That it is instead a knockoff of “The Hunger Games” and “The Maze Runner” makes it all the more condemnable.

headline: Review: Ballet BC Touches All the Bases, but One Yearns for More
abstract: The works at the Joyce Theater were full of yearning, and performers who could bend and stretch like taffy.
lead_paragraph: These days, having three female choreographers on a ballet program is an anomaly. Apparently, Emily Molnar, artistic director of the Canadian group Ballet BC, isn’t afraid of being bold. But does her bold move translate into a satisfying evening of dance? For her company’s opening at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday, Ms. Molnar showed that female choreographers — Sharon Eyal (working with Gai Behar), Crystal Pite and herself — can be just as derivative as their male counterparts.

headline: Chrysler Hopes New Pacifica Can Make Minivan Cool
abstract: A reinvented model uses improved fold-flat back seats, high-definition video screens and a sculptured design to overcome a stodgy image.
lead_paragraph: For years, automakers have been stumped by this question: How do you make a minivan seem cool?

headline: Review: ‘Time to Choose’ Extols Renewable Energy to Combat Global Warming
keywords: ['Movies', 'Global Warming', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Charles Ferguson’s documentary is a sobering polemic about climate change that balances predictions of planetary doom with a survey of innovations in energy technology.
lead_paragraph: Charles Ferguson’s latest documentary, “Time to Choose,” is a sobering polemic about global warming that balances familiar predictions of planetary doom with a survey of innovations in renewable energy technology that hold out some hope for the future. Unless the carbon-based energy sources on which we have relied are replaced with solar and wind power (the movie doesn’t address nuclear energy), we are ruined.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Art in review, from Times critics.

headline: Review: In ‘Me Before You,’ a Broken Man Meets a Free Spirit
abstract: This floppy British romance, directed by Thea Sharrock and adapted by Jojo Moyes from her best-selling novel, stars Emilia Clarke and Sam Claflin.
lead_paragraph: A recent screening of “Me Before You” concluded with audible sniffles and even a sob or two. Why not gales of laughter or quiet snores? These are the mysteries that trouble a critic’s uneasy mind. This floppy British romance, directed by Thea Sharrock and adapted by Jojo Moyes from her best-selling novel, sits at the point where tedium, ridiculousness and heartfelt sentiment converge, separated by an all-but-imperceptible distance. You can’t really argue with someone else’s tears. You can, however, find yourself mystified by them.

headline: Around Town for June 3-9
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: Review: ‘Art Bastard’ Depicts Robert Cenedella, a Rebel Artist
abstract: This documentary zeros in on a painter who defied art-world conventions with teeming satirical paintings.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not what they show, it’s what they don’t show,” the painter Robert Cenedella complains in “Art Bastard,” Victor Kanefsky’s robust, plain-talking documentary portrait of this lifelong rebel and art-world gadfly. “They” are museum curators and gallerists who are not interested in showing the work of Mr. Cenedella, a gifted painter and visual satirist.

headline: Comedy Listings for June 3-9
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Review: In ‘The Fits,’ a Graceful Tale of a Girl Who Follows Her Own Beat
abstract: This debut feature from Anna Rose Holmer centers on an 11-year-old tomboy who trains as a boxer only to discover an interest in joining an all-female dance team.
lead_paragraph: “The Fits,” a dreamy, beautifully syncopated coming-of-age tale, takes place in and around a recreational center that could not look less inviting. It’s the usual impersonal slab, the kind that municipalities have been building for decades to educate, or sometimes just to warehouse, restless young bodies and minds. The girls who congregate at this particular center in Cincinnati, though, have their own desires, which they express with fists and feet, grace and power. They move — fluidly, ferociously and with escalating mystery — to their own transporting beat.

headline: Nicole Eisenman, Fluidly Merging Past, Present and Future
abstract: Ms. Eisenman’s works rarely fail to delight with surprising colors, lush paint passages, and telling details.
lead_paragraph: Few figurative painters are doing what Nicole Eisenman is, jumping back and forth among starkly different styles while inviting us to consider an equally broad range of urgent themes.

headline: Germany Charges 4 Syrians in Plot to Attack Düsseldorf
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: Three Syrians who were arrested Thursday in Germany, plus one in custody in France, were charged in connection with a plan that involved suicide bombings, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German police arrested three Syrians on Thursday who are suspected of traveling to Europe on behalf of the Islamic State to attack a popular district of the western city of Düsseldorf, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Gucci Cruise 2017
abstract: Alessandro Michele described the collection as “punks, Victoriana and schoolboys,” a.k.a. a promenade through centuries of English history.
lead_paragraph: Alessandro Michele described the collection as “punks, Victoriana and schoolboys,” a.k.a. a promenade through centuries of English history.

headline: Gucci in Westminster: Blasphemy or Blessing?
abstract: The Italian brand had its cruise show in the shrine, in front of a congregation of industry insiders, devoted believers and some who took offense.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The concept of worshiping at the altar of fashion took new form on Thursday, as Gucci held its cruise 2017 catwalk show amid the Gothic 13th-century cloisters of Westminster Abbey, one of the most sacred sites in Britain.

headline: Once a Cavalier, Now a Warrior, and Always Hard to Miss
abstract: Anderson Varejao is the only player ever to have been employed in the same season by the two teams in the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Anderson Varejao has a postgame ritual. As his teammates make their way to the locker room, he waits outside the door to greet each of them, one by one. Varejao is always the last player to enter. He makes sure of it. It is one of the small ways in which he contributes to the fabric of the team.

headline: Council Considers Big Changes in How New York Approves Landmarks
abstract: A bill would require the Landmarks Preservation Commission to vote a proposed landmark up or down within a year; some preservationists call the time limit too short.
lead_paragraph: As New York’s Landmarks Law enters its sixth decade, the City Council wants to rewrite the rules governing historic properties.

headline: U.N. Plans No Imminent Airdrops of Aid in Syria, Despite Expired Deadline
abstract: United Nations officials were cautious about the prospect of airdrops, saying that they would need the consent of the Syrian government.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations on Thursday dimmed any prospect of immediate airdrops of aid to Syrian civilians trapped by the war, despite an expired deadline imposed on Syria’s government to allow unfettered humanitarian access by land.

headline: Prince Overdosed on Fentanyl. What Is It?
abstract: Minnesota officials said that Prince died in April of an overdose of the opiate, often used to treat severe pain. Here’s what we know about the drug.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota officials reported on Thursday that Prince died in April of an overdose of the opiate fentanyl. The authorities have not revealed how the musician obtained the drug or whether a doctor had prescribed it. But it has been reported that he had hip surgery in the mid-2000s and may have still been in pain.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda Said to Be Leaving Broadway’s ‘Hamilton’ Soon
abstract: Mr. Miranda, who was never expected to play Alexander Hamilton forever, may be departing as soon as July 9, according to The Hollywood Reporter.
lead_paragraph: “Hamilton” is going to run for a long time. But Lin-Manuel Miranda’s time in the title role is about to end.

headline: N.B.A. Finals Game 1: Highlights and Analysis
abstract: In a rematch of last year’s N.B.A. finals, the Golden State Warriors dominated the Cavaliers in Game 1 behind a strong effort from their bench.

headline: Ancient Civilization of Microbes, Not Greeks, Built ‘Lost City’
abstract: Scientists have discovered why underwater “ruins” off a Greek island showed no signs of human habitation beyond what appeared to be stonework.
lead_paragraph: So much for the Lost City of Zakynthos.

headline: Review: In ‘Outcast,’ Hell, as a Plot Device, Has Its Limits
abstract: The show centers on a man who lives in a part of West Virginia that apparently has a demonic-possession problem.
lead_paragraph: Hell apparently has a heck of an agent. It’s all over television these days, and Cinemax gives it yet another foothold on Friday with “Outcast,” a new series based on Robert Kirkman and Paul Azaceta’s comic books.

headline: Review: In ‘Fender Bender,’ Makenzie Vega Is Pursued by a Homicidal Maniac
abstract: This horror movie on Chiller will make you think twice about swapping contact information with the stranger who just dinged your car.
lead_paragraph: For seven years Makenzie Vega played the central family’s daughter on “The Good Wife,” a critically acclaimed series in which her character, Grace Florrick, often struggled with her parents’ actions and decisions. On Friday Ms. Vega turns up in a much more lowbrow offering, and in this one her character’s parents do something far worse than anything the Florricks ever did: They leave her home alone when there’s a homicidal maniac on the loose.

headline: At Odds Publicly, Donald Trump and Karl Rove Hold a Private Meeting
abstract: The strategist for George W. Bush’s presidential elections and influential Republican fund-raiser had referred to Mr. Trump as “graceless and divisive.”
lead_paragraph: Karl Rove, the architect of George W. Bush’s victorious presidential campaigns and founder of a constellation of political fund-raising groups, has called Donald J. Trump “a complete idiot.” He has described him as “graceless and divisive.” He has said Mr. Trump’s boasts about beating Hillary Clinton in the polls are false.

headline: With Room at the Top, Jostling Begins at the Memorial
abstract: Jason Day, Jordan Spieth and Rory McIlroy — golf’s Big Three — are facing off at a tournament hosted by Jack Nicklaus.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — The N.B.A. finals is billed as the Cleveland Cavaliers’ LeBron James versus the Golden State Warriors’ Stephen Curry. Yet when these teams met for the title last year, the Warriors’ Andre Iguodala emerged as the Most Valuable Player. It is what makes sports so compelling: The result is what happens after everyone has written the ending.

headline: A Lame Response to Predatory Loans
keywords: ['Payday Loans', 'Editorials', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Consumer Protection', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau needs to come up with a stronger plan to protect borrowers from the payday lending industry.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has been promising for more than a year to rein in the payday lending industry, whose business model relies on luring Americans into ruinously priced loans that can carry interest rates exceeding 400 percent. The proposal that the agency unveiled Thursday represents a down payment on that promise. But the final rule — expected next year — will need stronger, more explicit consumer protections for the new regulatory system to be effective.

lead_paragraph: Nine scientists have won this year’s Kavli Prizes for work that detected the echoes of colliding black holes, revealed how adaptable the nervous system is, and created a technique for sculpting structures on the nanoscale.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Margolies was considered the country’s foremost photographer of vernacular architecture.

headline: John Margolies, Photographer of Whimsical Architecture, Dies at 76
abstract: For decades, Mr. Margolies went out of his way to capture images of unusual sites like the Donut Hole in La Puente, Calif.
lead_paragraph: From sea to shining sea, John Margolies knew, there was much that cried to be photographed. There was the Long Island poultry store in the shape of a vast white duck; the gaping alligator’s mouth through which visitors entered a Kissimmee, Fla., zoo; the 65-foot-long muskie in Bena, Minn., that housed the Big Fish Supper Club; and the Donut Hole, a doughnut shop in the form of — what else? — in La Puente, Calif.

headline: Kidsfilmfest Is Back, With a Villainous Teddy Bear and Surfer Dudes
abstract: The 15 shorts in this international festival in Brooklyn include a moving testament by an Iranian filmmaker and a caper made with an iPhone.
lead_paragraph: Film festivals usually attract eager, ambitious young directors. But not many feature auteurs quite as young as some of the participants in the 12th kidsfilmfest.

headline: Belgium’s Interior Minister Visits New York Police to Discuss Terror Threats
abstract: The minister, Jan Jambon, expressed interest in the New York Police Department’s counterterrorism technology and bomb-sniffing dogs.
lead_paragraph: Belgium’s interior minister, who nearly resigned after the Brussels bombings by Islamic State militants more than two months ago, met with New York police officials and counterterrorism specialists on Thursday in what he described as a useful visit.

lead_paragraph: A minivan with out-of-state license plates rolled up to a hospital two miles from the scene of a fatal shooting last week, the police said. Out hobbled a Brooklyn rapper known as Troy Ave with a gunshot wound to his leg.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: A special prosecutor will handle the case of a white Chicago police officer who shot a black teenager, a judge said Thursday, while civil rights lawyers pressed for a broader investigation into whether other officers attempted a cover-up. A dashboard camera video of the October 2014 killing of Laquan McDonald, 17, showed Officer Jason Van Dyke, firing 16 shots into Mr. McDonald’s body even after he crumpled to the ground. Judge Vincent Gaughan said that he would search for an outside prosecutor after the Cook County state’s attorney, Anita Alvarez, asked last month to step aside. She lost a March primary election under criticism of her handling of the case. (AP)

headline: Jeremy Steig, Flutist Who Bridged Jazz and Rock, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Steig was the leader of one of the first jazz-rock bands, Jeremy & the Satyrs.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Steig, an acclaimed jazz flutist and the leader of one of the first jazz-rock bands, died on April 13 in Yokohama, Japan. He was 73.

headline: Mohammed Abdelaziz, Advocate of an Independent Western Sahara, Dies at 68
abstract: The Polisario Front, led for four decades by Mr. Abdelaziz, has tried to establish a sovereign state for the disputed region’s Berber tribesmen.
lead_paragraph: Mohammed Abdelaziz, the longtime leader of a movement to create an independent state for the indigenous people of Western Sahara, died on Tuesday. He was 68.

headline: Doctor Says Sumner Redstone Has ‘Legal Mental Capacity’
abstract: In excerpts from a report filed with a lawsuit, a psychiatrist says Mr. Redstone had told him he no longer trusted two longtime Viacom confidants.
lead_paragraph: A geriatric psychiatrist hired by Sumner M. Redstone has concluded that the ailing mogul had the “legal mental capacity” to oust two longtime confidants from the trust that will control his $40 billion media empire after he dies or is declared incompetent.

headline: Warriors’ Bench Blisters Cavaliers on a Quiet Night for Stephen Curry
abstract: Golden State, which is seeking its second straight championship, routed Cleveland in Game 1 at Oracle Arena.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The bad news for the Cleveland Cavaliers on Thursday night was a 104-89 loss to the Golden State Warriors. The worse news was that Stephen Curry and Klay Thompson had little to do with it.

headline: Roads to Nowhere and Anywhere, With Kelly Reichardt and Wim Wenders
abstract: Anomie and oppressive banality are themes in Ms. Reichardt’s “River of Grass” (1994) and the early films from Mr. Wenders in the set “The Road Trilogy.”
lead_paragraph: The characters in Kelly Reichardt’s movies are often lost in space, their lives on earth notwithstanding. The unmoored loners who populate her movies are isolated even in groups or pairs. It’s an existential condition evident as early as her first feature, “River of Grass” (1994), restored and out on disc from Oscilloscope.

lead_paragraph: Robert Kirkman, the man behind “The Walking Dead,” wrestles with exorcism in “Outcast.” Weird Al Yankovic leads the band on a new season of “Comedy Bang! Bang!” And Gugu Mbatha-Raw toys with destruction as a superstar hip-hop vixen in “Beyond the Lights.”

headline: N.B.A. Finals: Here’s What We Learned in Game 1
abstract: The Cavaliers have a lot to overcome if they’re going to have a chance against the Warriors in this series.
lead_paragraph: It was a truly unusual night, as the Golden State Warriors beat the Cleveland Cavaliers, 104-89, in Game 1 of the N.B.A. Finals. But the Warriors never felt comfortable thanks to the struggles of Stephen Curry and Klay Thompson. As they go about figuring out what went wrong with their star shooters, dissecting what went right for Golden State is far easier. Meanwhile, the Cavaliers have nothing but questions. Here’s what we learned in Game 1.

headline: Japanese Boy, 7, Left on Mountain by Parents Is Found Alive
abstract: Missing for nearly a week, the boy was found in a cabin on a remote military base exhausted but apparently uninjured.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A 7-year-old Japanese boy who disappeared nearly a week ago after his parents left him on the side of a mountain road to discipline him was found unharmed on Friday, the Japanese authorities said.

headline: Copa América 2016: Who’s In, Who’s Hurt and Who Could Win It
abstract: The tournament, South America’s continental championship, kicks off Friday night when the United States faces Colombia in Santa Clara, Calif.
lead_paragraph: The Copa América Centenario, born in scandal and saved only by the promise of better behavior (and the presence of some pretty good soccer teams), kicks off Friday night when the United States faces Colombia in Santa Clara, Calif. The 16-team event is being played outside South America for the first time as a celebration of its 100th anniversary, and while a handful of top players have been left out or ruled out by injury, there is plenty left in the cupboard, including four of the eight quarterfinalists from the last World Cup. Here’s what you need to know before the tournament begins.

headline: Gun Control Group Backs Hillary Clinton and Pledges Help With Primary
abstract: The group, Everytown for Gun Safety, announced its endorsement early on Friday, the day after its National Gun Violence Awareness Day campaign.
lead_paragraph: A major gun control group has endorsed Hillary Clinton, offering a lift to her campaign in a tighter-than-expected primary race in California and as she tries to pivot to a general election matchup with Donald J. Trump.

headline: Why Are Cars With Killer Airbags Still Being Sold?
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Editorials', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Faulty devices are being knowingly sold in new cars, often without the buyers’ awareness of that fact.
lead_paragraph: Some 100 million vehicles with defective Takata airbags have been recalled around the world, about 60 million of them in the United States, which make it the largest auto recall in history. On Thursday, several companies, including General Motors and Ford, recalled an additional four million cars with those airbags, which have been linked to at least 13 deaths worldwide and more than 100 injuries.

headline: The Smart Way to Help Ex-Convicts, and Society
keywords: ['Ex-Convicts', 'United States Economy', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Vocational Training', 'Poverty']
abstract: Investing in former prison inmates is not only morally right, it’s economically smart.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY gave a talk at the state prison in San Quentin, Calif. At the event, a former inmate said, “I don’t understand why over the 18-year period of my incarceration, over $900,000 was paid to keep me in prison. But when I was paroled, I was given $200 and told ‘good luck.’ ”

headline: Where Does Georgetown Start? By Listening
abstract: The university’s sale of African-Americans in 1838 must be addressed today, particularly for the descendants of its victims.
lead_paragraph: The story of the Jesuit priests who sold 272 enslaved African-Americans into bondage in the Deep South to save a struggling school that became Georgetown University dates back to 1838. That seems a long time ago, but pain and anguish are still deeply felt by the descendants of those who were sacrificed.

headline: The Id That Ate the Planet
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Global Warming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Climate change can be countered and the environment saved, but not if the hair spray-obsessed, science-denying Donald Trump is elected.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday the political arm of the Natural Resources Defense Council, one of America’s most influential environmentalist groups, made its first presidential endorsement ever, giving the nod to Hillary Clinton. This meant jumping the gun by a week on her inevitable designation as the presumptive Democratic nominee, but the NRDC Action Fund is obviously eager to get on with the general election.

headline: Where America Is Working
abstract: We should build on our success and not, like the Trump campaign, wallow in despair of what we’ve lost.
lead_paragraph: As individuals, we all try to build on our strengths and work on our weaknesses, and it’s probably a good idea to balance these two activities. But as a country we are completely messing this up.

headline: Let Smokers See the Warning They Need
abstract: Tobacco companies have blocked the F.D.A.’s graphic labels on cigarette packs for too long.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — FIVE years ago this month, the Food and Drug Administration released some striking images of the damage that smoking can do. These stark and disturbing pictures dominated the news cycle, as millions of Americans got a glimpse of the unvarnished truth.

headline: A Young Man Quits His Old Life and Goes West
abstract: Zach Both left his office job last summer, customized a Chevy van and hit the road. He hasn’t looked back since.
lead_paragraph: Zach Both was living in Boston and working as an art director for a 3D printing start-up when the road beckoned. He felt restless behind a desk. He had wanted to be a filmmaker since age 9. He knew he needed to take a creative risk. Then he watched a video of Alex Honnold, the free-solo rock climber, who lives in a customized van and travels from mountain to mountain.

headline: China’s Internet Speed Ranks 91st in the World
abstract: While trying to emphasize China’s connectivity, a report by a state newspaper acknowledged the creeping pace of connections in the country.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Anyone who spends any time online in China knows surfing the internet is like wading through quicksand. That is especially true when browsing websites not hosted on a Chinese server.

headline: Getting Hitched in Beijing? Try to Look the Part, Please
abstract: The authorities in Beijing have determined that many couples showing up to register their marriages are just too casual.
lead_paragraph: Beijing can be a pretty informal place. People walk outside in their pajamas, and when it’s hot some men lift up their shirts to expose their bellies. Even President Xi Jinping dresses down, usually in his trademark dark windbreaker.

abstract: When a neuroscience student gets dumped, she finds comfort (and an over-the-counter remedy) in her knowledge of the physiology of romantic rejection.

headline: Remembering Tiananmen in Hong Kong, but Not Without Divisions
abstract: For years, activists, student leaders and politicians gathered to declare solidarity in a continuing struggle for political change in China. This year is different.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Every June 4 for the past 26 years, tens of thousands of Hong Kong residents have gathered for a candlelight vigil in Victoria Park to commemorate those who were killed in the Chinese military’s suppression of the 1989 democracy protests in Beijing. Activists from the Chinese mainland and Hong Kong student leaders and politicians have shared the stage to declare their solidarity in a continuing struggle for political change in China.

But although her campaign had described the speech as a major foreign policy address, Mrs. Clinton spent more time ridiculing and dismantling Mr. Trump’s statements than she did elucidating her positions. Here are a few key issues she did not discuss.

headline: Yes, It’s Genocide
keywords: ['Armenians', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Germany can be proud of its vote to recognize the Armenian genocide, in defiance of the threats from Turkey’s president.
lead_paragraph: In what has become an almost annual exercise, Turkey has thrown a fit because someone has spoken the truth about its dark past. This time, it has pulled its ambassador from Berlin and threatened dire consequences over a resolution, passed overwhelmingly by the German Parliament on Thursday, declaring that the century-old massacre of Ottoman Armenians was a genocide. That is what Turkey does every time a foreign government dares to challenge its discredited claim that the Armenians perished in the cruel fog of World War I, and not in a premeditated attempt to eradicate a people. Germany’s claims to the contrary, Turkish legislators huffed in a statement, are “based on biased, distorted and various subjective political motives.”

headline: The Timeless Temptation of Despots
keywords: ['Elections', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Populists may play the system to gain power, but if they continue to undermine it, they will either destroy their nation, or it will destroy them.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Archaeologists excavating two mass graves in an ancient cemetery at the site of Athens’s new opera house suggested in April that the skeletons of 80 men — 36 of whom they found buried in iron shackles — may have been supporters of an ancient Athenian sports hero who tried to grab power around 632 B.C. The would-be tyrant, Cylon, thought that his glory as an Olympic Games champion would ensure popular support in his bid to replace his fellow aristocrats with himself. It seems the people were not sufficiently unhappy to join his revolt and it was crushed by the city’s leaders.

headline: Educate Your Immune System
abstract: Our bodies are confused by this 21st-century world.
lead_paragraph: IN the last half-century, the prevalence of autoimmune disease — disorders in which the immune system attacks healthy tissue in the body — has increased sharply in the developed world. An estimated one in 13 Americans has one of these often debilitating, generally lifelong conditions. Many, like Type 1 diabetes and celiac disease, are linked with specific gene variants of the immune system, suggesting a strong genetic component. But their prevalence has increased much faster — in two or three generations — than it’s likely the human gene pool has changed.

headline: 1966: Linkup in Space Is Delayed
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In 1966, Gemini-9 linkup with a target vehicle in space is delayed.
lead_paragraph: CAPE KENNEDY — Gemini-9 astronauts Thomas P. Stafford and Eugene A. Cernan soared into orbit today [June 3] after a perfect takeoff, but problems threatened the scheduled linkup with a target vehicle in space. Gemini’s orbital manoeuvres started off well with a successful docking adapter (ATDA). But then, with the target only ten feet away, the astronauts found their linkup blocked by a shroud over the docking cone that made the target look like an ‘‘angry alligator’’ with its jaws agape. Ground control then postponed the linkup indefinitely, leaving open the possibility that Lt. Comdr. Cernan might be sent into space to dislodge the shroud. As Gemini-9 approached the ATDA on the first rendezvous Lt. Col. Stafford reported: ‘‘I’ve got a weird-looking machine up here. It’s got alligator jaws.” — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 4, 1966

headline: Can the Big Apple Circus Be Saved?
abstract: The cherished New York institution, its finances depleted, is turning to online crowdfunding to sustain it.
lead_paragraph: IN CUNNINGHAM PARK at the eastern end of Queens, the Big Apple Circus is currently riding out the second half of its 38th season. Ninety percent of those who attend the circus come from not very far away — for years it has been one place where New Yorkers can reliably avoid tourists. But invariably, like so much else in the city that is appreciated by the people who live here, the circus is endangered, its finances depleted to the point that the current production may be the last ever staged.

headline: 1910: The Great Flood in Paris

abstract: There is a lot of discussion about income inequality, but issues surrounding the inequality of work may be no less important.
lead_paragraph: John Maynard Keynes, the great British economist, prophesied that by 2030 people in wealthy nations would work no more than 15 hours a week. It isn’t turning out that way.

headline: In Brief: Creative Stay in London; New Option Near Yosemite
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: The new Green Rooms hotel in London may be the city’s most affordable stay amid a creative community, and travelers to Yosemite have new accommodations to consider.
lead_paragraph: Short of couch surfing in an artist’s home, the new Green Rooms hotel in London may be the city’s most affordable stay amid a creative community. The nonprofit concept is meant to attract artists, musicians and actors visiting and working in London. The hotel also has partnerships with local cultural institutions including Somerset House and the Royal Court theater to house their visiting artists. But the developers say some rooms, which include 22 doubles, two studio apartments and two dormitory rooms, one that sleeps 12 and the other 16, will always be available to the public. Lodged in a 1935-vintage power company building, Green Rooms is in North London across from the Wood Green Underground station, about a 20-minute ride from the West End. Rates start at £18 (about $26) a night.

headline: America Is Hitting the Road Again
keywords: ['Youth', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Automobiles', 'Road Trips', 'Millennial Generation', 'Baby Boomers', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Recreational Vehicles']
abstract: Gas is cheaper than it has been in over a decade, and a nation weary of cutting back is getting behind the wheel and spending to make road trip memories.
lead_paragraph: ON ROUTE 66 IN NEW MEXICO — Bob Pack forgot to bring his James Taylor CDs. Still, he and his brother and sister were having a blast, rolling among the sandstone mesas, ghost towns and kitschy tourist attractions.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Stephanie Danler, whose foodie novel, “Sweetbitter,” is No. 14 on the hardcover fiction list, prefers restaurants “where I can feel the staff a little bit, they have a little bit of a personality.”
lead_paragraph: Service Game: When my parents met, in the summer of 1959, my father was working as a busboy. My brothers and I followed suit in our turn, refilling water glasses at local restaurants, running bread to the tables and clearing dirty dishes. But I’m pretty sure none of us ever sold drugs to “every server within a 10-block radius,” the way one busboy does in “Sweetbitter,” Stephanie Danler’s racy novel about the high-end restaurant world of New York City, new at No. 14 on the hardcover fiction list. Set in a fictional version of Danny Meyer’s Union Square Cafe, where Danler was hired after arriving in the city in 2006, the book features lots of casual sex and substance abuse — think of it as a female version of “Bright Lights, Big City,” with professional kitchens instead of magazine offices as a backdrop. “I would always think to myself as I was waiting tables,” Danler told NPR last month, “if the guests had any idea of the rich life that is going on behind the scene and the drama and the sexual tension and the sadness and the joy and the friendship — I think that those currents add a lot of energy to restaurants. Like, I prefer to dine in places where I can feel the staff a little bit, they have a little bit of a personality. But I hadn’t ever seen it written about. I saw that there was a space to create something there.”

abstract: As leading chefs are turning away from the sea and toward sustainable hatcheries, it seems we’ve just begun to skim the surface of aquaculture.
lead_paragraph: As leading chefs are turning away from the sea and toward sustainable hatcheries, it seems we’ve just begun to skim the surface of aquaculture.

headline: The Season’s Prettiest Flower, for Eco-Friendly Delivery
abstract: Farmgirl, which sources its ultra-fresh blooms exclusively from U.S. growers, is offering guaranteed-pick-me-up peony bouquets for a limited time.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco-based florist Christina Stembel founded Farmgirl Flowers as a corrective measure for the ills of a modern industry. Eighty percent of the flowers sold in the U.S. are imported, which perpetuates tons of waste and terrible working conditions in developing nations — not to mention droopy flowers that have been in transit for 8 to 10 days by the time they reach stores. Farmgirl sources all of its flowers domestically, so when they’re delivered to addresses nationwide they’re much fresher. (Adorably, the bouquets are also packaged in burlap repurposed from coffee sacks.)

headline: Republicans’ Latest Attempt to Discredit Fetal Tissue Research
abstract: New accusations are the next step in an investigation that has never had any reason to exist.
lead_paragraph: As part of their continuing war on fetal tissue research, House Republicans are now accusing a tissue procurement company and three abortion clinics of violating federal privacy law.

headline: Bernie’s Last Stand
abstract: Even if Sanders were to concede after Tuesday, he could boast of having moved the Democratic Party to the populist left.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — DURING the final days of a most improbable presidential primary season, the home to Disneyland was for a time the unhappiest place on earth. Rumbling and roaring his way across California, Senator Bernie Sanders brought his political revolution to the neighborhood of Goofy and Mickey.

headline: Dinosaurs’ Star Power Has Yet to Translate at Auction
abstract: Efforts to promote a market for the skeletons of dinosaurs and other rare wonders of the natural world have met only moderate success.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Dinosaurs make for good box office. Steven Spielberg’s 1993 “Jurassic Park” and its three sequels have become the tyrannosaurus rex of movie franchises, grossing more than $3.7 billion, and there are people of a certain age who cannot forget the sight of a pterosaur carrying off Raquel Welch in the 1966 kitsch classic “One Million Years B.C.”

headline: Needing Cash, Some Small Business Owners Bypass the Bank
abstract: For some entrepreneurs, growing their businesses has a lot to do with their risk tolerance and how they think about cash flow and partnerships.
lead_paragraph: After losing her job at LivingSocial, the online deal company that went nearly bankrupt three years ago, Kate Levenstien decided to take a chance on a business that combined two things she loved: bacon and beer.

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘All in With Cam Newton,’ ‘Jurassic Park’ and ‘Southland’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small, famous and esoteric, to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. Our most recent suggestions also appear below. To receive our guide straight to your inbox, sign up here.

headline: Review: Herb Alpert and Lani Hall, Still Upbeat and Authentic
abstract: These married musicians performed medleys of their ’60s hits, along with standards by composers from Irving Berlin to the Beatles, at Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: Happy music made by happy people. As Herb Alpert and Lani Hall, his wife of 42 years, played and sang together on Tuesday evening at Café Carlyle, it struck me how increasingly rare it is nowadays to hear popular music that isn’t fraught with conflict or grandiose self-advertisement. By happy music, I don’t mean officially inspirational pop of the Disney variety, with its commercialized sentimentality and cheer, but ebullient performances by musicians who convey the pleasure of playing together.

headline: A Suburban Experiment Aims for Free Energy
abstract: Twenty homes in a California subdivision are testing a zero net energy goal: to make at least as much energy as they use over a year.
lead_paragraph: FONTANA, Calif. — At first glance, Anthony and Vanessa Genau’s home in a subdivision beneath the San Gabriel Mountains here is like any other gracious new suburban dwelling, with an open-plan living space, granite countertops and stainless steel appliances.

headline: Review: John Scofield, Brad Mehldau and Mark Guiliana Debut as an All-Star Trio
abstract: Drawing on a tangle of prior working relationships, the three deftly balanced ruggedness and finesse in a mix of postbop, prog-rock and soul-jazz selections.
lead_paragraph: The new-groove super trio making its world premiere at the Blue Note this week — John Scofield on guitars, Brad Mehldau on keyboards, Mark Guiliana on drums — plants its flag at the convergence of ruggedness and finesse. Just past the midpoint of its first set on Wednesday night, the band nailed that balance almost perfectly on something called “The Scoville Scale.”

headline: Red Sox Hew Rough Diamonds Into Bats That Are a Cut Above
abstract: With a stockpile of young hitters led by Mookie Betts, Xander Bogaerts and Jackie Bradley Jr., Boston has the best record in the American League and the most runs in the majors.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — David Price signed with the Boston Red Sox last winter for the most lucrative contract ever given to a pitcher. The terms of his deal — $217 million for seven years — tend to eclipse any other reason people will accept for his decision.

abstract: Ms. Zimmer has made a specialty of playing tough, pointed women, but she finds new colors on her palette in her Lifetime series.
lead_paragraph: In the first five minutes of the new season of “UnREAL,” beginning June 6 on Lifetime, Constance Zimmer’s character, Quinn King, gets a vulgar tattoo, plies executives with cocaine in a Las Vegas hotel room and makes potty-mouthed plans to turn racism into ratings gold.

headline: Finra Arbitration Case Offers a Peek Into a Murky World
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Forced arbitration can circumvent legal rights, but Finra’s version of arbitration comes with an additional dollop of what seems like bias.
lead_paragraph: In a recent series of articles, The New York Times explored how corporations are increasingly forcing their customers, clients and employees – through little-read provisions in seemingly innocuous contracts — to use an opaque system of arbitration to settle financial and other disputes.

headline: How China Fell Off the Miracle Path
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: After years of rapid growth, China has taken on so much debt that its economy is at great risk.
lead_paragraph: FOR years now, Donald J. Trump has been sounding the alarm on China, calling it an economic bully that has been “eating our lunch.” The crux of Mr. Trump’s attack is that Beijing manipulates its currency to keep it cheap and give Chinese exports an unfair advantage. But that narrative is so last decade. China is now a threat to the United States not because it is strong but because it is fragile.

headline: ‘Symbol of Hope’: Refugee Team Named for Rio Olympics
abstract: A squad of 10 athletes, from South Sudan, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Syria and Ethiopia, will march behind the Olympic flag in the opening ceremony in August.
lead_paragraph: Ten athletes were chosen on Friday for a team that will represent the world’s refugees at the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro.

The only recollection of a conversation Hornacek could cite on Friday was when he played for the Utah Jazz in the 1997 and 1998 N.B.A. finals against the Chicago Bulls, who were coached by Jackson.

headline: U.S. Women’s Soccer Team Can’t Strike Before Olympics, Judge Rules
abstract: The team is bound by its collective bargaining agreement with U.S. Soccer through the end of the year, but the ruling has no effect on a separate wage-discrimination complaint.
lead_paragraph: The United States women’s national soccer team is bound by the terms of its collective bargaining agreement with U.S. Soccer, a federal judge ruled Friday. The decision means the players cannot strike before August’s Rio Olympics in their quest for better pay, but it has no effect on a separate federal wage-discrimination complaint filed by five players this year.

lead_paragraph: What makes for a good Style section story?

headline: ‘Casual’ Doesn’t Begin to Describe It
abstract: After winding up Season 1 with two almost unforgivable breaches of family trust (and sexual etiquette), Michaela Watkins is back for Season 2 on Hulu.
lead_paragraph: How does a responsibly repressed therapist become that woman — you know, the kind who guts her already dysfunctional family by sleeping with the ones they love? Last season on Hulu’s “Casual,” Valerie (Michaela Watkins) was left by her husband for a younger woman; packed up her precocious teenage daughter, Laura (Tara Lynne Barr), moved in with her brother, Alex (Tommy Dewey), a dating-site creator; and went a bit bonkers as she navigated singledom with him as her wingman. The show left us as Alex discovered Valerie after she had an Ecstasy-fueled encounter with his girlfriend; before that, she had sex with Laura’s teacher crush.

headline: Northside Festival Keeps Growing in Brooklyn
abstract: This celebration of innovation and music offers a pass to more than two dozen clubs. Acts include D.J. Grandmaster Flash and Brian Wilson.
lead_paragraph: The Northside Festival, Brooklyn’s answer to South by Southwest, keeps expanding. Its music component offers a pass to shows at more than two dozen clubs from Thursday, June 9, through Sunday, June 12, for $94.24; tickets for individual shows are also available.

headline: Ed Koch’s Words ‘If You Can’t Afford to Live Here’ Haunt Us
abstract: That advice becomes the title of a Mitchell-Innes & Nash art exhibition that revisits Martha Rosler’s “If You Lived Here …” show.
lead_paragraph: Martha Rosler, the Brooklyn artist who four years ago turned the Museum of Modern Art’s atrium into a mammoth garage sale, has also focused on social issues within cities.

headline: The Playlist: Beck Wows, the Avalanches Collapse and Kanye West Finds a Few Champions
abstract: Hear the tracks that caught our pop critics’ attention, from Angel Olsen’s “Intern” to Xenia Rubinos’s “Lonely Lover.”
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, The New York Times pop critics weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing — in a new version of the Playlist column. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like the new format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

headline: When Brian De Palma Kind of Made ‘Vertigo’
abstract: Cliff Robertson and Geneviève Bujold star in “Obsession” (1976), part of a De Palma retrospective at Metrograph.
lead_paragraph: Brian De Palma has never made a secret of his reverence for Alfred Hitchcock. “Obsession,” his underappreciated, glossy 1976 homage to “Vertigo,” is a high point of a De Palma retrospective at the Metrograph that runs through June 30.

headline: Performance Mix Festival Celebrates 30 Years With Tap, Tonics and More
abstract: The festival returns to Abrons Arts Center with 13 events featuring 40 artists over six days.
lead_paragraph: Wading into the calendar for the Performance Mix Festival can feel like embarking on a convoluted mission. The curator Karen Bernard plays by no rules, other than rounding up an inspired multitude of genres and voices each year. For its 30th birthday, the festival returns to its original Lower East Side home, Abrons Arts Center, with 13 events featuring 40 artists over six days, beginning Monday, June 6.

headline: Going Young and Bicoastal at Lincoln Center
abstract: The Brooklyn Youth Chorus and the San Francisco Girls Chorus join voices for a double bill with the Knights.
lead_paragraph: As part of the NY Phil Biennial, the hard-working members of the impressive Brooklyn Youth Chorus and the San Francisco Girls Chorus will unite on Thursday, June 9, for an adventurous collaboration with the Knights, the dynamic chamber orchestra.

headline: 3 Somali-Americans Found Guilty of Trying to Join Islamic State
abstract: The convictions in Minnesota capped a two-year investigation and led to six other young men pleading guilty to terrorism charges.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Three Somali-American friends were found guilty on Friday of federal charges that they tried to travel to Syria to join the Islamic State, a plan that prosecutors said unfolded through propaganda videos and social media exchanges, and while they played basketball and paintball.

headline: Battle Lines: As Clinton Vilifies Trump, Ryan Endorses Him
abstract: Readers praise Mrs. Clinton’s speech, berate Republicans who won’t attend the convention and chide Paul Ryan for choosing winning over principles.

headline: In Hollywood, a Focus on Manson and His Women
abstract: He has inspired a spate of independent features and television projects; the focus seems to be shifting to his female followers, with women directing.
lead_paragraph: Late in Season 1 of NBC’s “Aquarius,” the character of Charles Manson is confronted by his mother, who gave birth to him at 16 and abandoned him when he reached adolescence. Despite his anger and resentment, this Manson cowers in her presence and reveals a vulnerable streak at odds with the public image of him as evil incarnate.

headline: The Economy Needs Help That Only Congress Can Provide
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans in Congress need to step up and help create jobs for Americans.
lead_paragraph: Given the dismal employment report for May, released on Friday, it would be cruel and unusual for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates at its policy meeting later this month. The report is more evidence that the economy is already slowing; it clearly does not need the Fed to tap the brakes by raising rates.

headline: A Singer-Songwriter Who Puts His Garden First
abstract: When he’s not on tour, Gregory Alan Isakov can be found tending heirloom vegetables on a farm in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Alan Isakov sees a through line between his two passions, music and farming: “I realize that the more I do both, they’re both things that I’ll never master,” he says. Not that he isn’t willing to try. When the singer-songwriter isn’t on tour, as he soon will be in support of his new album, “Gregory Alan Isakov with the Colorado Symphony,” out June 10, he resides here: on a four-and-a-half acre farm outside Boulder, where he and seven friends tend to over 100 varieties of heirloom vegetables, plus beehives, chickens, medical cannabis and a group of sheep they call “the T-Swift pack.” It’s the perfect place for the musician to unwind, if an unlikely one. “I work on music and then garden for a few hours and come back,” says Isakov, who counts several bandmates among the farm’s residents. “It just seems like natural workflow to let things settle that way.”

abstract: At the museum’s annual garden gala, talk of a more sober art market prevailed among the artists and plutocrats.
lead_paragraph: Nothing says spring quite like a garden party with a dozen plutocrats, along with a handful of big stars. This was what happened two years ago when Madonna and Daniel Craig showed up to the Museum of Modern Art’s annual spring gala and rubbed shoulders with the financial world titans Michael R. Bloomberg and Henry Kravis.

headline: Four Arrested in Beating Death of Transgender Man in Vermont Homeless Camp
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Homeless Persons', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
