abstract: The two men and two women fled in a Chevy Malibu to California, where they were arrested on second-degree murder charges, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Four homeless people face murder charges after using their fists and feet to fatally beat a transgender man in an encampment in Vermont, and then fleeing across the country to a San Diego beach, where they were arrested, officials said on Friday.

headline: An ‘Eat Pray Love’ Story That Built a Children’s Home in Nepal
abstract: Ten years after the release of her best-selling memoir, Elizabeth Gilbert raised money for a nonprofit by facing her fear of singing in public.
lead_paragraph: Just before the March release of “Eat Pray Love Made Me Do It,” an anthology of essays written by people who were inspired by Elizabeth Gilbert’s best-selling 2006 memoir, “Eat Pray Love,” Ms. Gilbert was looking to offload a 7,000-pound Buddha statue.

headline: Paris Floods Close Louvre and Other Tourist Attractions
abstract: Because of heavy rains, a number of popular sites in Paris are temporarily closed, including the Louvre and Orsay museums. Here, a list of other closures.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most popular tourist attractions in Paris, like the Louvre Museum, are temporarily closed to visitors because of heavy rains that have caused the Seine River to rise to its highest levels since 1982. But despite these closures, Myriam Guyon, the founder of the Paris-based travel consultancy Voyages Confidentiels, said that tourists currently in the city aren’t lacking in sightseeing options.

headline: Who Would Pay $300,000 for a Handbag?
abstract: Christie’s Hong Kong breaks the record for the most expensive handbag ever auctioned. Welcome to the weird, frenzied world of the Birkin investor.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In a packed bidding room last Monday, Christie’s Hong Kong hosted its 30th-anniversary auction. The tightly curated catalog featured 30 lots, each chosen for its desirability and origin in categories such as fine art, ancient ceramics, jewelry, watches and rare wines.

headline: William Norwich: Elegance at Home and in Fiction
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The former Vogue editor, society gossip columnist and novelist lives on the Upper East Side.
lead_paragraph: William Norwich, a former Vogue editor and New York Post society gossip columnist, has a sense of humor about his symbiotic relationship with the One Percent.

headline: What I Love | William Norwich
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: William Norwich, the editor, former gossip columnist and author of the recent novel “My Mrs. Brown,” lives in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: William Norwich, the editor, former gossip columnist and author of the recent novel “My Mrs. Brown,” lives in Manhattan.

headline: Shareholder Initiatives Show Their Value
abstract: A plethora of examples involving companies like Dell, Facebook and Tribune Publishing prove that shareholder votes can be of great consequence.
lead_paragraph: For all its imperfections, shareholder democracy has real value. For evidence, look no further than a plethora of cases this week in which voting is proving to be of great consequence.

headline: U.S. to Return $6 Million to Diamondback Capital in Insider Trading Case
abstract: The hedge fund forfeited the money as part of a non-prosecution agreement, according to a court filing.
lead_paragraph: Another hedge fund that was caught up in the federal government’s crackdown on insider trading is getting back money it forfeited to authorities in the course of the investigation.

headline: John Jasperse Returns to Sarah Lawrence Dance, as Director
abstract: Mr. Jasperse, who graduated from the college and has a company, John Jasperse Projects, will take over from Sara Rudner this fall.
lead_paragraph: The Sarah Lawrence College Dance Program — which was led during its formative decades by Bessie Schönberg, for whom New York’s dance awards, the “Bessies,” are named — announced a new director this week: John Jasperse, the choreographer and dancer.

headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader on America: Don’t Trust, Don’t Cooperate
abstract: A nationally televised speech by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei seemed to signal that Iran’s senior leadership would not allow any easing of hostility toward the United States.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s top leader said Friday that trusting or cooperating with the United States would be a big mistake, an assertion that seemed to rule out any greater collaboration despite the nuclear deal reached nearly a year ago.

headline: Mets’ David Wright Is Expected to Miss 6 to 8 Weeks as Health Concerns Deepen
abstract: Wright was placed on the disabled list with a herniated disk in his neck, adding to the team’s injury problems and raising doubts about his future in the majors.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — David Wright went into the 2016 season with a lot of anxious looks being cast in his direction. At 33, could he still be a productive player as he dealt with the fact that he has spinal stenosis? Or was he inevitably headed toward a diminished role on the field and perhaps an injury retirement long before his contract with the Mets expires at the end of the 2020 season?

headline: Scientists Find Form of Crispr Gene Editing With New Capabilities
abstract: A common bacterium contains molecules that target RNA, not DNA. If it can be harnessed for use in humans, the process may lead to new forms of bioengineering.
lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, Crispr was a cipher — something that sounded to most ears like a device for keeping lettuce fresh. Today, Crispr-Cas9 is widely known as a powerful way to edit genes. Scientists are deploying it in promising experiments, and a number of companies are already using it to develop drugs to treat conditions ranging from cancer to sickle-cell anemia.

headline: Why the Seine River Is Bursting Its Banks in Paris
abstract: Not only has the Paris region been inundated by rain, but dams upstream were already near capacity.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Paris experienced its worst floods since 1982 on Friday as the Seine River climbed to about 20 feet. It was not as bad as the catastrophic deluge of 1910 (26.2 feet), or the smaller but still destructive flood of 1955 (23.7 feet), but it prompted the hasty movement of masterpieces at the Louvre, created havoc for commuters and disrupted at least one wedding. South of the French capital, the heavy rains caused extensive property damage.

headline: Tony Fadell Steps Down Amid Tumult at Nest, a Google Acquisition
abstract: Mr. Fadell, a star executive known for his aggressive management style, helped found the maker of high-tech home devices and sold it to Google for $3.2 billion 2014.
lead_paragraph: Time to move on. That is the explanation Tony Fadell, a former star executive at Apple known for his aggressive management style, offers for his departure from Nest, a maker of digital versions of household staples like thermostats and smoke detectors that he helped found and sold to Google.

headline: The Simple Yet Effective Beauty Product Application to Know
abstract: To increase the benefits of toners and serums, and tone the muscles of the face, try pressing the products in with your hands, over and over and over.
lead_paragraph: An hour with the celebrity facialist Joanna Czech defies all modern convention. Just when you begin to expect a blast of hot steam to open your pores, she’ll firmly wipe you down with a swab soaked with ice-cold toner. You think you need a soothing lotion to even your skin out, maybe calm it down? She knows better: a prickly, slightly stinging solution is just the thing. And instead of delicately applying masks and creams, she uses her whole (petite) body to essentially force them into your epidermis — at times politely, yet firmly, slapping them into your face. And so it comes as little surprise that the massage and application techniques she created for La Mer, as the brand’s global skin-care adviser, aren’t designed for a light touch.

headline: Houses Keep Getting Bigger, Even as Families Get Smaller
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Although the pace of the increase has slowed a bit, the trend continues: more square feet, more bedrooms, more bathrooms.
lead_paragraph: When your adult child comes back to live with you, there is a good reason he or she won’t be exiled to the basement.

headline: Fearing Zika, a Top American Will Skip the Olympics. He May Not Be the Last.
abstract: Organizers of the Rio Games may not see the virus as a serious health threat this summer, but the cyclist Tejay van Garderen and his pregnant wife, a former national cycling champion, do.
lead_paragraph: Organizers of this year’s Olympics in Rio de Janeiro tried their best on Thursday to make the Zika virus seem not so scary after all.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jim Dwyer, Diaa Hadid and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Stanford Audience Unmoved by an Informed Debate Over the Need for a Nuclear Renaissance
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Global Warming', 'Nobel Prizes', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: A vibrant debate, including a couple of Nobel Prize winners, tests the merits and drawbacks of nuclear power in a post-carbon world. The audience? Unchanged.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, I discussed several encouraging aspects of a big intergovernmental meeting on clean energy that was held earlier this week in San Francisco. But I lamented that the agenda lacked any discussion of the role of nuclear energy in moving beyond fossil fuels in this century. (Keep in mind that even if you hate existing or planned nuclear plants, this energy source is still advancing in many countries, so discussing issues related to safety and security, as well as cost, would seem wise.)

headline: Trying to Fill Void, France Holds Talks on Mideast Peace Process
abstract: With tensions flaring between the Israelis and the Palestinians, France decided to propose a new process.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With the Obama administration having effectively given up on negotiating a deal between the Israelis and the Palestinians, France tried its hand on Friday at making Middle East peace but ended the day with little to show for its efforts.

headline: Navigating to New York by the Wind and Waves
abstract: A canoe sails into New York Harbor, proof of exceptional indigenous navigation.
lead_paragraph: These aren’t great times for indigenous peoples. When they get noticed at all, it’s often because of poverty or alcoholism or health crises. Even among my own ethnic Hawaiian ancestors, the news has often been negative, from the fight over telescopes atop Mauna Kea to the news from Bloomberg about millionaires battling billionaires on the Kona Coast, with no mention of the initial dispossession of the Hawaiians.

headline: A Small-Town Resident’s Secret for 48 Years: He Was a Fugitive
abstract: Bob Stackowitz of Sherman, Conn., used an alias after escaping from prison in 1968, but was recently discovered when he sought benefits under his real name. Even his longtime girlfriend was shocked.
lead_paragraph: SHERMAN, Conn. — Bob Stackowitz escaped from a Georgia prison so long ago that he eventually stopped acting like he was on the run. He bought a house in this rural town in western Connecticut, fixed boat engines for a living and, on occasion, forgot to use his alias, Bob Gordon.

headline: Are You in Despair? That’s Good
abstract: People who have more nuanced views of their emotions — indignation versus general misery, say — are healthier, studies find.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the world gets you down, do you feel just generally “bad”? Or do you have more precise emotional experiences, such as grief or despair or gloom?

headline: Evening Hours | Events Starting June 1
abstract: Bill Cunningham covers events: The Museum of Modern Art held its annual party in the garden on a fantastic summerlike night and more
lead_paragraph: Bill Cunningham covers events: The Museum of Modern Art held its annual party in the garden on a fantastic summerlike night and more

headline: Palestinians Elect a New President (on a Reality TV Show)
abstract: “The President,” a reality show, allowed Palestinians to choose a leader, which they have not had the chance to do in more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — “Mr. President!” a woman called out to Waad Qannam at a rally last week in East Jerusalem. “We want you to represent us!” The crowd cheered passionately, even though Mr. Qannam was actually running for president on a reality television show.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Duality
abstract: The contrast between black and white is a favorite, no matter the generation.
lead_paragraph: The contrast between black and white is a favorite, no matter the generation. It showed up in bold graphics and in romantic 1950s silhouettes and prints as the young crowd offered its interpretation of the combination.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: The Tired Gardener Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a previously healthy 67-year-old gardener who is too exhausted and feverish to garden.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the case of a previously healthy 67-year-old gardener who abandoned his garden one summer, alarming his wife and adult children. For weeks this vibrant and energetic man had been the last one out of bed — something his family had never seen before. And his days were interrupted each afternoon with a fever that left him shaking and pale. More than 300 readers suggested diagnoses for this classic presentation of an unusual disease, and a couple dozen of you nailed it.

headline: Review: ‘Andy Warhol’s Tropico’: Ever Get Stuck in a Dream?
abstract: The dance, by the troupe the Feath3r Theory, at Danspace Project, has something to do with Andy Warhol and a Lana Del Rey video.
lead_paragraph: Quite a ways into “Andy Warhol’s Tropico,” by the dance-theater troupe the Feath3r Theory, Raja Feather Kelly explains that what the audience has been watching is a re-enactment of his dreams. He points out the difference between dream time and real time: how a dream that might seem to last for hours can be compressed into a few minutes of sleep.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s New Attack on Donald Trump Cheers Her Allies and Worries His
abstract: Mrs. Clinton showed the first indication of confronting an unconventional opponent, while Mr. Trump’s supporters have seen his unwillingness to adapt to the demands of a general election.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s blistering new assault on Donald J. Trump has mollified many Democrats alarmed about the closer-than-expected presidential race — while inflaming Republican fears that Mr. Trump’s improvisational style and skeletal campaign will prove inadequate in repelling the type of attack Mrs. Clinton unleashed on Thursday.

headline: Stephen Cohen, Senior S.E.C. Enforcement Official, to Depart
abstract: A tenure that included overseeing some of the agency’s most prominent financial cases is ending after 12 years.
lead_paragraph: Steve Cohen is moving on. Not the one investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, but the one who works there.

headline: Review: Ballet Arizona Performs ‘Round’ in a Dreamy Desert Ambience
abstract: This work, shared in the round with shifting symmetries and dissolving images, underscores how this company is one of the most enterprising anywhere.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — For centuries, ballet has focused all of its stage deportment on one specific arc of space, through a proscenium arch to a large audience. Yet this is such a three-dimensional art that it’s baffling how few experiments have been made to choreograph it in the round.

headline: Review: Watch Nat Geo Dine on Wildebeests for Three Hours
abstract: Enough of those cute animal videos. “Africa’s Deadliest” brings on the real deal, with lessons on survival.
lead_paragraph: Death is thick in the air Sunday night on Nat Geo Wild, and the carnage can’t come soon enough for me. I’ve seen about all the cute videos of dogs playing with ocelots that I can stand.

headline: Hillary Clinton Expresses Confidence in Securing Nomination Next Week
abstract: At a rally in California backed by several actresses, Mrs. Clinton said that “if all goes well,” the Democratic primary fight will end Tuesday as six states vote.
lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — A day after offering a forceful denunciation of Donald J. Trump, Hillary Clinton on Friday expressed hope that she was only days away from putting the long-running Democratic nominating fight behind her.

headline: Review: ‘Feed the Beast,’ AMC’s Solemn New Restaurant and Crime Drama
abstract: David Schwimmer and Jim Sturgess star as business partners who struggle to restart a restaurant.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 12 years since “Friends” went off the air, and David Schwimmer still has “kick me” tattooed to his forehead. His doleful, hangdog expression and strangled vocal delivery give all his characters an air of grievance and self-pity — no one’s feelings hurt more than theirs.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Embraces Business Casual
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Workplace Environment', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The bank told its workers on Friday that it was relaxing its dress code, but there are still rules. Denim is considered inappropriate, along with athletic clothing, shorts and hats.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street may be known as the home of one of the most buttoned-up industries in the country, but JPMorgan Chase is letting its employees relax a little bit.

headline: Bo Burnham, Discovered on the Internet, Now Challenges It
abstract: The comedian, whose new special has been released on Netflix, takes a tougher look at fame and those who search for it.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a decade since Bo Burnham, then 16, uploaded a video of himself to a fairly new site called YouTube. He was singing a song about how his family thought he was gay.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Your Friday Evening Briefing
lead_paragraph: Your Friday Evening Briefing

headline: Ai Weiwei and Warhol, Together Again
abstract: Their paths crossed in New York: Ai Weiwei was a hungry kid, and Andy Warhol was a star. But they had more in common than not, as a new show illustrates.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — One was a wildly successful artist, the son of Slovakian immigrants, whose alabaster complexion and shock of white hair made him instantly recognizable on the streets of Manhattan.

headline: ‘Elle,’ Starring Isabelle Huppert as a Rape Victim Who Turns the Tables, Rivets Critics
abstract: After making a splash in Cannes, the film opened in French theaters last weekend, intriguing many with its mix of violence and comedy and its ironic take on gender roles.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “No role is hard for me. It’s never hard.”

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump, Golden State Warriors
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: Yvonne Rainer’s ‘The Concept of Dust’ Keeps Viewers on Their Toes
abstract: Ms. Rainer creates a tapestry of movement and text that relate to aging and mortality in “Dust,” at the Kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Yvonne Rainer got us good. (Warning: Rare dance spoiler alert below.)

headline: Review: Aaron Weinstein, Wunderkind as Highbrow Dandy
abstract: In Mr. Weinstein’s show at Pangea, he mixes comedy bits (a parody of an intellectual music review) with American songbook and show-tune standards.
lead_paragraph: The jazz violinist and mandolinist Aaron Weinstein is an entertainer of almost as many parts as a Rube Goldberg contraption. A major musical talent with a sideline in comedy, Mr. Weinstein presents himself as a highbrow dandy in the tradition of Jack Benny, Victor Borge and Oscar Levant. And at his show “Violinspiration” at Pangea on Thursday evening, he expertly played off the various sides of his personality.

headline: Crying Jordan: The Meme That Just Won’t Die
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Plastering Michael Jordan’s crying face onto the defeated offers clues about our ambivalent relationship to alpha males.
lead_paragraph: He won six N.B.A. championships, is the greatest scorer ever and once netted 38 points while battling the flu. The logo of a billion-dollar sneaker brand is a silhouette of him flying through the air. But on Twitter, Michael Jordan is a loser.

headline: Review: Wilde’s Wacky ‘Earnest,’ Now With Arias
abstract: In its American stage premiere at the Rose Theater, Gerald Barry’s adaptation of “The Importance of Being Earnest” looks a lot like improv.
lead_paragraph: When Oscar Wilde’s “The Importance of Being Earnest” opened in London in 1895, a delighted reviewer described it as “a ‘rondo capriccioso,’ in which the artist’s fingers run with crisp irresponsibility up and down the keyboard of life.” Gerald Barry’s 2010 opera based on the play, which received its American stage premiere at the Rose Theater, Jazz at Lincoln Center, on Thursday, sounds much the same way — except that the composer seems to have attacked the keyboard not just with his fingers but also with the occasional elbow and boot.

headline: ‘Look at My African-American Over Here,’ Donald Trump Says at Rally
abstract: While recalling a past protest involving a black supporter, the candidate singled out a spectator in the crowd who was also black.
lead_paragraph: REDDING, Calif. — In a speech in which he promoted the backing of Chinese-Americans in Los Angeles and called protesters at a rally in San Jose “thugs,” Donald J. Trump on Friday sought to project support from African-Americans for his campaign on a single man in the audience.

headline: Immigrants Want List of Names and Addresses Kept From a Texas Judge
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: A group of four, protected under President Obama’s executive actions, filed a petition to keep a federal judge from obtaining the personal information of immigrants in 26 states.
lead_paragraph: Four young immigrants, who received extended protections from deportation under executive actions taken by President Obama, made an emergency request to an appeals court on Friday to prevent a federal judge in Texas from obtaining a list of the protected immigrants’ names and addresses.

headline: Redstone’s Lawyers Argue That His Mental Health Is Irrelevant in Dispute
abstract: The ousting of the Viacom executives Philippe Dauman and George Abrams from Sumner Redstone’s trust would have happened regardless of Mr. Redstone’s competency, his lawyers said.
lead_paragraph: In an unexpected twist in an already tumultuous legal fight, lawyers for Sumner M. Redstone argued in court filings on Friday that the competency of the ailing 93-year-old mogul did not matter in the dispute over his $40 billion media empire.

headline: A Smart Way to Help People Eat Less Salt
abstract: Voluntary guidelines from the F.D.A. focus on packaged foods and restaurant meals, where most of the sodium people consume comes from.
lead_paragraph: Public health officials have long struggled to get Americans to eat less sodium to reduce high blood pressure, and hence cut the risk of heart attacks and strokes. After years of debate, this week the Food and Drug Administration issued guidelines for food manufacturers and restaurants to  reduce the salt they put into their products. Though voluntary, the standards could give consumers more choices.

headline: Justice Dept. to Tighten Rules on Testimony by Scientists
abstract: The measures are part of the government’s response to reports that F.B.I. scientists have often vastly overstated their level of certainty about forensic test results.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department, stung by reports that F.B.I. scientists have often vastly overstated their level of certainty in matching hair samples and other evidence, issued new rules on Friday meant to ensure that the experts’ testimony in criminal cases is “supported by sound science.”

headline: Michelle Obama Denounces Donald Trump in CUNY Commencement Speech
abstract: In her final address to college graduates as first lady, Mrs. Obama warned of “leaders who demonize and dehumanize entire groups of people.”
lead_paragraph: In tones both aspirational and political, Michelle Obama on Friday used her last commencement address as first lady to salute graduates of the City College of New York as “living, breathing proof that the American dream endures,” while also criticizing “name-calling” leaders who engage in “anger and intolerance.”

headline: NRG Shifts Focus Away From Empowering Consumers
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: The strategy emerging under the current chief de-emphasizes the idea of a power system that would let consumers generate power and feed it back to the grid.
lead_paragraph: When Mauricio Gutierrez became chief executive at NRG after his predecessor’s ouster last year, analysts and investors anticipated that the company would retreat from its money-burning rush into green energy. Instead, they expected it to focus on the conventional power business that had made it a leading — and profitable — supplier in a competitive energy market.

headline: The Benghazi Committee’s Dead End
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: After wasting millions of dollars in hopes of sinking Hillary Clinton’s presidential ambitions, Republican lawmakers seem to have nothing to show.
lead_paragraph: After running a congressional oversight committee like a Republican opposition research shop for more than two years, Representative Trey Gowdy appears to be gearing up for the finale. Democrats on the Select Committee on Benghazi expect that a final report will drop soon, just as Hillary Clinton appears poised to clinch the Democratic nomination.

headline: Walmart Worker Advocates Express Skepticism Over Raises
abstract: Employees more critical of the company say it has found subtle ways to hinder workers’ compensation, such as a training program that can keep pay at $9 an hour.
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, Ark. — This week, as part of the festivities that surround Walmart’s annual shareholder meeting, “Eye of the Tiger” blasted through loudspeakers as employees entered an arena at the University of Arkansas. Handpicked by their managers out of Walmart’s work force of more than a million, the employees arrived ready to cheer.

headline: High School’s Administrators Faulted in Sexual Harassment and Theft Cases
abstract: An investigation found that administrators failed to report the matters at the long-struggling Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The challenges facing the long-struggling Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn seemed to mount on Friday, when the New York City Education Department said an investigation found that its principal and two other administrators had failed to report an allegation of sexual harassment and a suspicion that students had stolen and used a department credit card.

headline: Mitch McConnell’s Memoir Reveals Tactician’s Approach to Politics
abstract: In a new book, the majority leader writes about his approach to reporters, the sports cars of his youth and how he values repetition in politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Once, when Mitch McConnell was dishing privately to me on the congressional crisis of the moment, I thanked him for his candor and insight.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: As part of a legal settlement, the state has agreed to correct widespread faults in its foster care system, promising to improve health care for children, set workload limits for overtaxed foster care workers and ensure more timely investigations of alleged abuse and neglect. Gov. Nikki R. Haley, a Republican, and Susan Alford, the acting director of the State Department of Social Services, are named in the federal lawsuit, which was filed Jan. 15 by child-welfare advocates, including Children’s Rights, a New York-based nonprofit. Listed as plaintiffs were 11 children in the foster care system, which has been criticized for many years as dangerously troubled, with overwhelming worker caseloads, lapses in oversight and a number of child deaths. The settlement was filed Friday in United States District Court in Charleston and requires a judge’s approval to be finalized. RICHARD FAUSSET

headline: United States Falls to Colombia in Copa América Opener
abstract: The Americans struggled in their opener against the No. 3 team in the world, but the road out of the group stage gets somewhat easier from here.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Eight minutes into the first match of Copa América, the Colombians started to dance.

headline: Army Training Goes Back to the Basics
abstract: With less support from contractors, and conflicts shifting to more austere places, the Army is training soldiers to handle more basic survival tasks.
lead_paragraph: With less support from contractors, and conflicts shifting to more austere places, the Army is training soldiers to handle more basic survival tasks.

headline: It’s Rucksacks and Foxholes as Army Goes Old School for New Conflicts
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: With fewer civilian contractors for support, the Army has initiated a training program that goes back to the basics of military self-sufficiency.
lead_paragraph: FORT STEWART, Ga. — When Staff Sgt. Chris Brown headed into the swamplands of Georgia for a military training exercise early this spring, he found himself missing his time in Iraq and Afghanistan — and the relative comforts he had enjoyed there at the height of both wars.

headline: First L.P.G.A. Tournament Doesn’t Intimidate 16-Year-Old Elizabeth Wang
abstract: Wang, who started to golf because she lived next to a Colorado course, has quickly risen from novice to battle-tested amateur.
lead_paragraph: GALLOWAY TOWNSHIP, N.J. — Teachers at San Marino High School in Southern California allowed Elizabeth Wang to finish her sophomore year a week earlier than her classmates. Wang had a compelling reason for the request: She was scheduled to compete in her first L.P.G.A. tournament.

headline: Hillary’s Really Good Day
abstract: A speech laid out voters’ choices: A woman who knows foreign policy or a man who thinks the Miss Universe pageant in Russia is foreign policy experience.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton made a great speech this week. Not what we were expecting, which was just a sturdy slog through the summer. Even though it was a policy address on national security that centered on the listing of six points, it was a super performance.

headline: Sidney Crosby and Joe Thornton Share a Shifty Skill That’s Quicker Than a Glance
abstract: The Penguins’ Crosby and the Sharks’ Thornton have an uncanny ability for passing the puck.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Hockey rewards the setup and the finish equally. In individual scoring races, the crisp pass has the same value as the wrist shot to the top corner. And as events have played out, the player with the highest profile on each team in the 2016 Stanley Cup finals is a master at the art of dishing the puck.

headline: Anti-Trump Voices Amplify on Internet, With Violent Results
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Protests inspired by social media turned violent outside a rally in San Jose, Calif., the result of a combustible mix of the candidate’s fiery oratory and the passion of the anti-Trump movement.
lead_paragraph: REDDING, Calif. — When Mathew Gonzales, a Latino musician from San Jose, heard that Donald J. Trump was coming to town, he knew he had to do something.

headline: Jeff Hornacek, the Knicks’ Latest Coach, Could Win Just by Persevering
abstract: Hornacek follows a succession of head coaches who have been replaced after failing to turn around the team’s fortunes.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Hornacek was introduced on Friday as the Knicks’ 28th head coach. That may have been the team’s first upset victory of the season.

headline: Higher Education in Illinois Is Dying
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: While politicians fight, public colleges in Illinois are collapsing.
lead_paragraph: Urbana, Ill. — THIS spring my friend’s daughter received exciting news: She had been accepted to the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. It’s our hometown campus, but also the state’s flagship public university and one of the best research institutions in the country.

headline: Hugh Honour, Art Historian and Author, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Honour wrote and edited with John Fleming, his life partner, from a base in italy.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Honour, a self-taught art historian who produced indispensable works on Neo-Classicism and romanticism and who, with John Fleming, wrote the monumental survey “The Visual Arts: A History,” one of the first to pay serious attention to non-Western art, died on May 19 at his home in Tofori, Italy. He was 88.

headline: Hooked Projection on a Bird Feather
abstract: Gird your collective loins. Byron Walden and Brad Wilber are back.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — O.K., I might have gotten a bit overconfident yesterday with the whole puzzle-solving thing, where I went on and on about how late-week puzzles were “gettable” and all that. I left out one very important detail.

headline: And if Elected: What President Trump Could or Couldn’t Do
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: In practice, the commander in chief has more power than you might think.
lead_paragraph: DONALD TRUMP clearly holds grudges. He has hurled insults at governors, senators, a judge who recently ruled against him and Miss Universe 2014. He has also attacked the press, arguing that as president he will “open up” libel laws so he can sue newspapers that publish “purposely negative and horrible and false articles” about him.

headline: Dave Swarbrick, British Folk Fiddler With Fairport Convention, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Swarbrick was a prime mover in trad-rock, which connected the ferment of folk-rock and psychedelia to a deep British heritage of storytelling ballads and dance tunes.
lead_paragraph: Dave Swarbrick, a fiddler who electrified the British folk tradition as a member of the band Fairport Convention, died on Friday. He was 75.

headline: Black Teenager’s Death on Staten Island Does Not Appear to Be a Hate Crime, the Police Say
abstract: Initial reports said that Dayshen McKenzie died in May after being chased by a group of youths yelling a racial slur, but the police said the episode was a gang altercation.
lead_paragraph: The initial reports about Dayshen McKenzie’s death on May 27 on Staten Island seemed to echo the crimes of an earlier era: A black teenager was dead after being chased by a mob of youths yelling a stinging racial slur.

headline: A Woman at the Boys’ Reunion
abstract: Do my former classmates accept me as transgender out of compassion or simply loyalty?
lead_paragraph: MY friend Mark and I were in the suburbs of Philadelphia, on the campus of the all-boys Haverford School, where we’d been students 40 years earlier. In the intervening years, I’d become a woman, and he was now in a wheelchair. A lot had changed.

headline: In the Heartland, Trouble for Mr. Trump, and Opportunity for Mrs. Clinton
abstract: At the intersection of three key Midwestern states, voters reject Donald Trump, but pose a challenge for Hillary Clinton, too.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, Minn. — Canton, population 428, was settled by Nordic immigrant farmers. The area’s prim dairy barns, lush hills and deep valleys are what city people picture when they imagine escaping to a quieter life.

headline: Yankees’ Big Efforts Unravel as the Orioles Rally for a Win
abstract: The Yankees’ Mark Teixeira left in the third inning after feeling discomfort in his right knee.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The Yankees might have had plenty of questions around New Year’s Day, but first base was not one of them. They had Mark Teixeira, who had a resurgent season last year until it was ended in mid-August by a freak accident, a foul ball off his shin. They also had a worthy young successor in Greg Bird, who coolly slugged 11 home runs in the final seven weeks.

headline: What the Chicago Police Videos Show, and Don’t Show
abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel, in a move to restore the public’s trust in the city’s police force, released scores of video and audio clips. Here is a selection.
lead_paragraph: Chicago officials on Friday released a series of videos and audio recordings of shootings and other episodes involving the police as part of an effort by the administration of Mayor Rahm Emanuel to restore the public’s trust in the department.

headline: Tommy Haas Named Director of Indian Wells Tournament
abstract: Haas, who at 38 has not retired but has been sidelined by injuries, takes a post vacated when Raymond Moore made derisive comments about women’s tennis.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Tommy Haas was named tournament director of the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells, Calif., on Friday, filling a position vacated by Raymond Moore in March after he made derisive comments about women’s tennis.

headline: Brendan Steele and Matt Kuchar Are Tied for Lead at Memorial
abstract: Steele and Kuchar were at 12 under par (132) after two rounds at Muirfield Village.

headline: Muhammad Ali: ‘What’s My Name?’
abstract: The three-time world champion boxer Muhammad Ali has died. Current and former New York Times reporters and columnists talk about their memories of him and how he became an international icon.
lead_paragraph: The three-time world champion boxer Muhammad Ali has died. Current and former New York Times reporters and columnists talk about their memories of him and how he became an international icon.

headline: A Look Back at the Greatest
abstract: Muhammad Ali, a three-time heavyweight boxing champion, was among the most controversial and charismatic sports figures of the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: Muhammad Ali, a three-time heavyweight boxing champion, was among the most controversial and charismatic sports figures of the 20th century.

headline: Muhammad Ali Dies at 74: Titan of Boxing and the 20th Century
abstract: Ali was the most thrilling if not the best heavyweight boxer of all time, a towering figure with an agile mind who was both admired and vilified for his religious, political and social stances.
lead_paragraph: Muhammad Ali, the three-time world heavyweight boxing champion who helped define his turbulent times as the most charismatic and controversial sports figure of the 20th century, died on Friday in a Phoenix-area hospital. He was 74.

headline: When Muhammad Ali’s Twinkle Shone Brightest
abstract: A portrait of the three-time world heavyweight boxing champion many prefer to remember, before Parkinson’s disease set in.
lead_paragraph: At the end, the mischief was still in his eyes. Even the pall of Parkinson’s disease never took that away, but for too many years before his death, Muhammad Ali was not the Muhammad Ali you wanted to remember. Instead of shouting, “I am the greatest,” he whispered. Instead of whirling in his white boxing shoes with red tassels, he shuffled. And instead of that wonderful face lighting up when he spoke, he wore a cheerless mask.

headline: As Butterfly or as a Bee, Muhammad Ali Always Made an Impression
abstract: Covering Ali at his height and during his slow decline, a reporter was left with enough memories of the former heavyweight champion to fill a smoky arena.
lead_paragraph: At first, he was just a commotion, far down State Street.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Travel to Mars — twice — with “The Martian” and “Approaching the Unknown.” Or careen through vintage New York with “The French Connection.”
lead_paragraph: Nowhere to go on Saturday night? Visit Mars with “The Martian,” then head there again with “Approaching the Unknown.” Take a wild ride through vintage New York with “The French Connection.” Or tour Vienna in “Woman in Gold.”

headline: Muhammad Ali’s Words Stung Like a Bee, Too
abstract: Outside the boxing ring, Ali fought his battles with his mouth.
lead_paragraph: Outside the boxing ring, Ali fought his battles with his mouth.

headline: The World Reacts on Social Media to Muhammad Ali’s Death
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Death and Dying', 'Social Media', 'Boxing', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: After news broke about Ali’s death, many people spoke about his contributions not only to the boxing world but also his influence on Muslim America.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley tech titans. Canadian hockey players. African sheikhs. Muhammad Ali’s athletic might, bold politics and boundless charisma extended his influence far beyond the world of championship boxing. And as news of his death broke, each of these people — and many more — shared their condolences on social media.

headline: Back in the Punk Days, When CBGB Was the Place to Be
abstract: In his photographs of the 1970s music scene, David Godlis helped capture the grit and urgency of the era.
lead_paragraph: In his photographs of the 1970s music scene, David Godlis helped capture the grit and urgency of the era.

headline: In Muhammad Ali, an Example of a Truer Kind of Bravery in Sports
abstract: We talk of courage among athletes. Ali, who at 24 risked his fame, fortune and freedom to speak out against the Vietnam War, showed the world what the word can really mean.
lead_paragraph: I was not yet a teenager when I wandered into the living room of our rent-controlled apartment on the Upper West Side. I saw my parents sitting silently by our black-and-white television, listening as a young black boxer, Muhammad Ali, talked.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 4, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Boy, this is ugly. The losses were deeper and more broad-based than we expected.”

headline: Corrections: June 4, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, June 4, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Back in the Punk Days, When CBGB Was the Place to Be
abstract: In his photographs of the 1970s music scene, David Godlis helped capture the grit and urgency of the era.
lead_paragraph: When David Godlis was shooting off-kilter, kinetic photos of bands like Television, Talking Heads and Blondie, he had a sense that the scene unfolding in the Bowery club CBGB was important. But no less vital than the sound being made was the punk aesthetic — urgent and gritty — that Mr. Godlis was helping define.

headline: In a Times Square Boxing Bar, Glasses Raised to ‘a King Among Men’
abstract: Jimmy’s Corner, a 45-year-old sanctum of boxing ephemera, quieted to an uneasy hush as patrons took in the news of Muhammad Ali’s death.
lead_paragraph: Just past midnight on Saturday, Jimmy Glenn slumped into a small wooden chair in the back room of his bar in Times Square, his face aglow before a cable broadcast. The bar, a 45-year-old sanctum of boxing ephemera called Jimmy’s Corner, was packed with dozens of patrons in various stages of inebriation and celebration, but Mr. Glenn could hardly bring himself to move.

headline: 5 Things That Give Self-Driving Cars Headaches
abstract: Despite their multitude of sensors and processors, autonomous cars have a lot of trouble with some everyday aspects of driving.
lead_paragraph: Despite their multitude of sensors and processors, autonomous cars have a lot of trouble with some everyday aspects of driving.

headline: ‘A Human Life Is Worth More Than an Animal’s’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discuss a gorilla’s death, Donald J. Trump’s criticism of a federal judge, a thwarted date rape, and more.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: From the Past, a Place to Glimpse the Automobile’s Future
abstract: The University of Michigan is a partner in a project to set up an expansive testing site for autonomous vehicles in Ypsilanti, Mich., at G.M.’s former Willow Run assembly plant.
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan is a partner in a project to set up an expansive testing site for autonomous vehicles in Ypsilanti, Mich., at G.M.’s former Willow Run assembly plant.

headline: For Driverless Cars, Citylike Test Sites Offer the Unpredictable
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Testing is being conducted at controlled, secretive locations like Mcity in Michigan because the number of unforeseen challenges on the road is almost limitless.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Here in this college town 40 miles west of Detroit, behind black sheeting attached to an eight-foot-tall chain-link fence, the future of the auto industry is being worked out in a secret setting.

headline: On the Town With a Fleet Week Newbie
abstract: Seeing New York through the eyes of a first-time visitor, a sailor from Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: Seeing New York through the eyes of a first-time visitor, a sailor from Tennessee.

headline: On the Town With a 19-Year-Old Fleet Week Newbie
keywords: ['Fleet Week', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Times Square. The Mean Fiddler. A slice at Two Boots. A 19-year-old sailor visits New York for the first time.
lead_paragraph: Connor Vest, a bespectacled 19-year-old sailor, grew up in Maryville, Tenn., in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains. Until May 29 — the fifth day of Fleet Week — he had never set foot in New York City.

headline: Rufus Wainwright’s 10-Year Journey Back to Judy Garland
abstract: A decade after his concert tribute at Carnegie Hall, the 42-year-old singer prepares for an encore as he deals with a death, a birth and a marriage.
lead_paragraph: Rufus Wainwright remembers June 14, 2006, as the night he climbed a musical Mount Everest. Or jumped off one.

headline: A Harvard Professor Goes ‘Star Wars’ Crazy
abstract: Manhattan’s power elite — George Soros, Samantha Power, Henry Kissinger, Tina Brown — gather to celebrate Cass Sunstein’s foray into pop culture.
lead_paragraph: It was very hot last Tuesday night in the SoHo apartment of Jenna Lyons and Courtney Crangi, and not just because it was about 80 degrees outside and the air-conditioning unit was not up to the job.

headline: In Anchorage, Natural Beauty Isn’t the Only Thing That’s Cheap
abstract: Sure, avocados are very expensive, but if you know where to look, Anchorage is a great frugal destination.
lead_paragraph: Soon after my Alaska Airlines flight had safely touched down at Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport, I noticed I felt a bit off. It was 10:30 p.m. but the sun was still hanging above the horizon and it looked like midmorning. My old Peace Corps friend Isaac and I stood in a parking lot overlooking Cook Inlet, where the famed captain had arrived in 1778 in search of the Northwest Passage.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from a park in Taipei to a the inside of a 19th-century cargo ship.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from a park in Taipei to a the inside of a 19th-century cargo ship.

headline: A Weekend in Chicago
abstract: Three days, 64 people shot, six of them dead: Memorial Day on the streets, and the violence that has engulfed families and neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Three days, 64 people shot, six of them dead: Memorial Day on the streets, and the violence that has engulfed families and neighborhoods.

headline: Muhammad Ali: Worshiped. Misunderstood. Exploited.
abstract: He was the greatest boxer of all time. But he also gave too much, inside the ring and out, and people took advantage of him.
lead_paragraph: Oakland, Calif. — MUHAMMAD ALI, who died Friday at the age of 74, was the greatest boxer of all time, but he was also deeply human, as full of frailty and foibles as anyone. He was physically vulnerable: Early on, doctors warned him and his camp followers that he was getting hit too much while training for his fights. He wouldn’t listen, and no one around him tried to persuade him otherwise.

headline: ‘Liquid’ Cancer Test Offers Hope for Alternative to Painful Biopsies
abstract: “Liquid biopsies,” one of the hottest trends in oncology, could yield a less painful and risky way of diagnosing cancer and monitoring its progression.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A blood test to detect cancer mutations produced results that generally agree with those of an invasive tumor biopsy, researchers reported, heralding a time when diagnosing cancer and monitoring its progression may become less painful and risky.

headline: When Violence Hits Home in Chicago
abstract: This Memorial Day weekend, Todd Heisler, a New York Times staff photographer, was part of a team that looked closely at the people and neighborhoods affected by that city’s wave of gun violence.
lead_paragraph: Last Memorial Day weekend, a team of New York Times photographers and reporters fanned out through Chicago to document how that city’s violence had affected people and neighborhoods. New York Times staff photographer Todd Heisler describes how he and his colleagues sought to portray the story in new ways.

headline: When Violence Hits Home in Chicago
abstract: This Memorial Day weekend, Todd Heisler, a Chicago native and Times staff photographer, was part of a team that looked closely at the people and neighborhoods affected by the city’s gun violence.
lead_paragraph: This Memorial Day weekend, Todd Heisler, a Chicago native and Times staff photographer, was part of a team that looked closely at the people and neighborhoods affected by the city’s gun violence.

headline: Karen Sendler, John Kirkwood
abstract: The couple’s wedding included Jewish and Scottish elements, like breaking glass in a tartan bag.
lead_paragraph: Karen Adele Sendler, the daughter of David A. Sendler of Naples, Fla., and the late Emily I. Sendler was married June 4 to John Kenneth Kirkwood, the son of Kenneth W. Kirkwood and Carol L. Kirkwood of Haddonfield, N.J. Charles L. Burgess, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the home of the groom’s parents.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: If the Economy Is Sinking, Policy Makers Are Far From Prepared
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: It seems hard to think of a time in recent United States history when policy makers have had so little room to maneuver to help the economy.
lead_paragraph: By now you have probably heard that the latest employment report suggests that job growth is slowing. My best guess is that this is a signal that the economy is reverting to a more sustainable rate of growth, rather than anything more drastic.

headline: Okinawa Murder Case Heightens Outcry Over U.S. Military’s Presence
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Okinawans have long complained of violence, noise and other problems associated with American bases. Now the bases’ very existence is drawing a backlash.
lead_paragraph: OKINAWA, Japan — Memorial Day weekend is normally party time on Gate Street, a seedy strip of bars and clubs outside a giant United States Air Force base here.

headline: Farhad and Lydia’s Week in Tech: Twitter Woes and a More Wary Political Class
abstract: Snapchat is enjoying a positive run, and the leading presidential candidates have both expressed skepticism toward the tech industry.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mike is off this week, so Lydia Polgreen, associate masthead editor, filled in.

headline: Garbiñe Muguruza Upsets Serena Williams in French Open Final
abstract: The fourth-seeded Spaniard won her first major title and kept Williams from winning her 22nd Grand Slam title, which would have equaled the Open era record.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For almost two hours, Serena Williams and Garbiñe Muguruza hammered tennis balls back and forth over the net, each one answering the other’s power with power of her own, until the final point.

headline: A Breast Cancer Patient Who Also Wears a White Coat
abstract: After a double mastectomy three years ago, Dr. Lori Wilson, a cancer surgeon and researcher gained a new insight on what she was asking of her patients.
lead_paragraph: Q. When did you know you wanted to be a surgeon?

headline: Scapegoat or Spy? Vatican Consultant Commands Attention at Leaks Trial
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of']
abstract: A hero to some and a villain to others, Francesca Immacolata Chaouqui stands accused with two others of leaking confidential documents to two journalists.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Her accusers call her an ambitious schemer, even a spy. The presiding judge has wondered aloud whether she is “full of hot air.” Vatican prosecutors want her in jail for as many as 15 years, charging that she stole and leaked state secrets.

headline: Everybody Loves a Hero, Especially Facebook Fraudsters
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Online Dating', 'Medal of Honor (US)', 'Social Media', 'Impostors (Criminal)']
abstract: Fake profiles for a real Medal of Honor recipient keep popping up, possibly in connection with romance scams, and Facebook is slow to take them down.
lead_paragraph: The Haggler doesn’t spend a lot of time on Facebook. As a fictional construct, he has no friends, no family, no life and thus nothing to share. Also, the whole enterprise seems frivolous. You want him to “like” your vacation photos? Please. He seeks consumer justice. It’s full-time work.

headline: Credit Suisse Boss Faces Revolt From Bankers Over Strategy Shift
abstract: A drop in bonuses and a move away from investment banking have led traders to grumble about Tidjane Thiam’s plans for the future of the Swiss bank.
lead_paragraph: When Tidjane Thiam took over at Credit Suisse last July, he laid out a new direction for a financial giant with a storied investment banking history: Do less investment banking.

headline: Workers’ Wages Rebound, While Wall Street Squirms
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Recession and Depression', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Inflation (Economics)', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Unemployment', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Corporations']
abstract: Median weekly wages, adjusted for inflation, have finally climbed above their 2009 levels, even as corporate profits have slipped from their recent peak.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street hasn’t had much to cheer about lately. But there are some signs that rank-and-file workers do.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Puns and Anagrams with Mel Taub.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — The nice thing about Puns and Anagrams puzzles is that there is very little room for false advertising. You’re either going to find a pun or an anagram in the clues. They’re dependable and comfy, like a pair of slippers.

headline: Once a Trump Target, John McCain Now Finds Their Political Fates Intertwined
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: The senator says he’ll back his party’s presumptive nominee. But with his own seat on the line and Arizona Hispanics at odds with Donald Trump, it’s a risky position.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON, Ariz. — Senator John McCain does not say much these days about Donald J. Trump’s attack on his five-plus years as a prisoner of war. Instead, he clenches his teeth and says he will support the Republican Party’s presumptive nominee, who once said derisively about the senator’s time in captivity, “I like people that weren’t captured.”

headline: Iraqi Army Seen as Ill Equipped to Retake Mosul From ISIS, Despite U.S. Aid
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Iraqis are having trouble moving supplies to their troops on battlefields, and a planned offensive against the Islamic State’s stronghold will probably have to wait.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An exhausted and ill-equipped Iraqi Army faces daunting obstacles on the battlefield that will most likely delay for months a long-planned major offensive on the Islamic State stronghold of Mosul, American and allied officials say.

headline: Rise of Muhammad Ali
abstract: Milestones and career highlights of Ali, a showman in and outside of the boxing ring.
lead_paragraph: Milestones and career highlights of Ali, a showman in and outside of the boxing ring.

headline: Muhammad Ali and Howard Cosell: Foils and Friends Bound by Mutual Respect
abstract: The camaraderie between the boxer and the broadcaster produced an entertaining union of opposites and a well-suited black-white pairing for the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: They were a 1960s power couple, two hypertalkative showmen: Muhammad Ali, the African-American boxer born with a slave name, and Howard Cosell, the Jewish Brooklyn lawyer who found his calling in sportscasting.

headline: President Obama’s Statement on Muhammad Ali
abstract: The president and Michelle Obama, the first lady, issued a statement Saturday on the death of Muhammad Ali
lead_paragraph: The president and Michelle Obama, the first lady, issued a statement Saturday on the death of Muhammad Ali.

headline: The Cost of Staying Safe
abstract: Readers respond to “Waiting in Line for the Illusion of Security” (May 29).

headline: Pay Cuts at the Top
abstract: Readers respond to “Top C.E.O. Pay Fell — Yes, Fell” (May 29).
lead_paragraph: Based on an Equilar survey of 200 chief executives of American companies, “Top C.E.O. Pay Fell — Yes, Fell” (May 29) reported that average compensation last year fell 15 percent from 2014, to $19.3 million.

headline: Tigers Are Rescued in Thailand
abstract: As many as 137 tigers were taken from a zoo run by Buddhist monks amid claims the sanctuary was a front for illegal trafficking of tiger parts.
lead_paragraph: As many as 137 tigers were taken from a zoo run by Buddhist monks amid claims the sanctuary was a front for illegal trafficking of tiger parts.

headline: Tiger Sanctuary in Thailand Closes Amid Accusations of Wildlife Trafficking
abstract: Conservationists had long believed that the zoo, run by Buddhist monks, was a front for illegal trafficking in tiger parts.
lead_paragraph: SAI YOK, Thailand — The last tiger, sedated and caged, left the Tiger Temple in Thailand on Saturday in the back of a pickup truck. The abbot who founded the Buddhist-themed zoo has vanished. And five people, including three monks, have been arrested on suspicion of wildlife trafficking.

headline: Parkinson’s: A Progressive, Incurable Disease
abstract: What are the likely causes of the disorder that afflicted Muhammad Ali for decades? And what’s the prognosis for those with a Parkinson’s diagnosis?
lead_paragraph: Muhammad Ali, who died on Friday after a long struggle with Parkinson’s disease, was given the diagnosis in 1984 when he was 42. The world witnessed his gradual decline over the decades as tremors and stiffness set in, replacing his athletic stride with a shuffle, silencing his exuberant voice and freezing his face into an expressionless mask.

headline: The World Remembers Muhammad Ali
abstract: Athletes, celebrities, lawmakers and artists paid tribute to a superstar in and out of the ring.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said he “shook up the world, and the world’s better for it.” George Foreman called him royalty, but added that the “common man was his pal.” Paul McCartney remembered his sense of humor and how he “would often pull a pack of cards out of his pocket, no matter how posh the occasion, and do a card trick for you.”

headline: Mets’ Neil Walker Brings Solid Bat and Values From Pittsburgh
abstract: Walker, who has thrived at the plate in his first season in New York, still has deep ties to his native city.
lead_paragraph: Neil Walker knew it would end. Pittsburgh had been part of him for 30 years, from the day he was born there, in 1985, to the day he was drafted by the Pirates, in 2004, right up until last December. He had one year left until free agency and had been unable to agree to a long-term contract with his hometown team.

headline: Rufus Wainwright, Back at Carnegie Hall
abstract: The singer-songwriter rehearsed in the hall in preparation for his Judy Garland concert this month.
lead_paragraph: The singer-songwriter rehearsed in the hall in preparation for his Judy Garland concert this month.

headline: Tennis Integrity Unit Is Finding Doubters
abstract: A finding of “no evidence of corrupt activity” in a mixed doubles match at the Australian Open raises further doubts about the sport’s anticorruption efforts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Tennis Integrity Unit found “no evidence of corrupt activity” in its investigation into a mixed doubles match at the Australian Open in January that raised suspicions of possible match fixing — a finding that clears the players involved but raises further doubts about the effectiveness of the sport’s anticorruption efforts.

headline: Richard Jefferson’s 15-Year N.B.A. Title Search Boasts a Vaunted Crew
abstract: The Cavaliers forward has no championship rings despite playing with Jason Kidd, Tim Duncan, Stephen Curry, Dirk Nowitzki and LeBron James.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — From Jason Kidd to LeBron James, Richard Jefferson wants the world to know how blessed he is to be back in the N.B.A. finals 13 years after almost believing that landing on professional basketball’s grand stage might be an annual occurrence, just like his birthday.

headline: As Chances Dwindle, Dale Earnhardt Jr.’s Confidence Doesn’t
abstract: The 41-year-old driver, who is seeking his first Nascar title, remains hopeful about qualifying for this year’s playoff despite a rough stretch on the track.
lead_paragraph: LONG POND, Pa. — A black golf cart with mag wheels rolled to a stop Friday afternoon and was promptly surrounded by three dozen stock car fans who had waited in a drizzle. A driver in a red and yellow fire suit hopped out and signed autographs while on the move.

headline: Big Money Rearranges Its Election Bets
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Political Advertising', 'Political Action Committees', 'State Legislatures', 'States (US)', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The power of money in politics is being felt ever deeper down the ballot.
lead_paragraph: Like practiced horseplayers at a racetrack, wealthy campaign donors are adjusting their bets as the primary season ends and the political field narrows. This is particularly true of Republican megadonors who cannot abide Donald Trump and are thus doubling down on keeping G.O.P. control of the Senate as a firewall against a possible Democratic president, while investing heavily in keeping statehouses in Republican hands.

headline: Thousands Rally in Hong Kong to Mark Tiananmen Anniversary
abstract: People gathered to do what those across the border in mainland China could not: mark the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Beijing.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Tens of thousands of people gathered in a Hong Kong park on Saturday evening to do what people across the border in mainland China could not: commemorate the anniversary of the bloody crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in Beijing’s Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989.

headline: 6 Tips for (Gracefully) Handling Rain on Your Wedding Day
abstract: From couples who have been there.
lead_paragraph: If the weather hadn’t been so foul, the most dramatic moment of Tiffany Mallory’s wedding to Jerrell Moore would never have happened.

headline: Auston Matthews, N.H.L.’s Top Prospect, Is Comfortable on Ice and Under Heat
abstract: The Toronto Maple Leafs, who have the first pick in this month’s draft, are known for a Stanley Cup drought, a rabid fan base and combative media corps.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — All week his utterances were duly noted and parsed for meaning, his moves scrutinized and assigned a score. In many ways, the interviews and the physical testing of top amateur prospects taking place here as part of the N.H.L. scouting combine, in advance of the draft, may help prepare Auston Matthews for the likely crucible of playing for the Toronto Maple Leafs next season.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Unless You’re Oprah, ‘Be Yourself’ Is Terrible Advice.
abstract: We pay a high price socially, personally and professionally for being authentic. There’s a better alternative.
lead_paragraph: IT was going to be the biggest presentation of my life — my first appearance on the TED Conference main stage — and I had already thrown out seven drafts. Searching for a new direction, I asked colleagues and friends for suggestions. “The most important thing,” the first one said, “is to be yourself.” The next six people I asked gave me the same tip.

headline: A Baseball Success Story Awaits the Draft
abstract: Corey Ray, a junior outfielder for the University of Louisville, is a product of baseball’s efforts to attract African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: Sometime this Thursday, probably in the early part of the first round of the annual baseball draft, a major league team will welcome Corey Ray. He will begin his journey in professional baseball, like so many others, lured by the challenge of the one-on-one battles within a team sport.

headline: No Exceptions for a Nuclear India
abstract: Membership in the Nuclear Suppliers Group will not be merited until India meets the group’s standards.
lead_paragraph: America’s relationship with India has blossomed under President Obama, who will meet with Prime Minister Narendra Modi this week. Ideally, Mr. Obama could take advantage of the ties he has built and press for India to adhere to the standards on nuclear proliferation to which other nuclear weapons states adhere.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Investor Protections in the Cross Hairs
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consumer Protection', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Financial Planners']
abstract: Financial-industry groups have sued over new rules requiring advisers dealing with retirement accounts to act in their clients’ best interests.
lead_paragraph: You would think the financial industry would be too embarrassed to object to the idea that advisers should act in their clients’ best interests when giving advice and selling investments for retirement accounts. But last week industry groups filed two federal lawsuits against new rules that say just that.

headline: Italy Feels Our Pain
abstract: Across the Atlantic, they shudder at Donald Trump and the international havoc he could wreak. They also recognize him.
lead_paragraph: Rome — DURING the circuslike years of Silvio Berlusconi, Italians grew flinchingly accustomed to being the butts of the world’s jokes.

headline: What Does a Lifetime of Leers Do to Us?
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Sex Crimes', "Women's Rights", 'Cyberharassment', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Feminism has made the world a better place, which is why we need to talk about our unfinished work.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I was a child, I had recurring nightmares about wolves — beasts the size of skyscrapers that walked on their hind legs around New York City blocks, chasing and eventually devouring me. My mother says she made the mistake of bringing me to see a live performance of “Little Red Riding Hood” when I was a toddler, and that the man dressed as the wolf terrified me. I started having the dreams almost immediately after I saw the play, and they lasted into high school; I don’t remember when they stopped.

headline: Meet Sultana, the Taliban’s Worst Fear
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Education (K-12)', 'Terrorism', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: An Afghan girl’s hunger for knowledge is stronger than the threat of an acid attack.
lead_paragraph: OF all the students preparing to go to college this fall, perhaps none have faced a more hazardous journey than a young woman named Sultana. One measure of the hazard is that I’m not disclosing her last name or hometown for fear that she might be shot.

headline: John Adams Was a Hermaphrodite?
abstract: Lin-Manuel Miranda of “Hamilton” fame says this campaign is no more bizarre than 1800’s, which had slurs that make Donald Trump look like a piker.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — THIS is a town where scripts routinely come back to writers from entertainment executives with the same scrawled command about a female character: “Make her more likable.”

headline: Pro Golfers Know Working on Short Game Goes a Long Way
abstract: For pros like Jason Day, working on their short game may not be nearly as fun as hitting drives, but they know how important it is.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — Jason Day’s long and winding road to the world No. 1 ranking began with him circumventing the short-game practice area at his boarding school in Australia. Defying the orders of his instructor, Colin Swatton, Day chose to play a par-3 course over working on his chipping and putting, leading to a loud row with Swatton that Day paved over with a public apology.

headline: Graduating and Looking for Your Passion? Just Be Patient
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Youth', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Commencement Speeches']
abstract: A psychologist who studies world-class achievers says finding your passion takes time. Seek purpose, work hard and make the most of every opportunity.
lead_paragraph: For all their grandeur and euphoria, graduation ceremonies can be harrowing. Until that momentous day, you’re a student whose job is to do what your teacher asks. Now you have to ask things of yourself — but what?

headline: The Families That Can’t Afford Summer
keywords: ['Summer (Season)', 'Child Care', 'Families and Family Life', 'Camps and Camping', 'Education', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The depressing reality of a season we mistakenly refer to as “vacation.”
lead_paragraph: WHAT are your kids up to this summer? Sounds like a casual question. But for working parents at this time of year, it’s loaded. What have you managed to pull together that will keep your kids engaged, healthy, happy and safe, while still allowing you to keep feeding and clothing them? For most parents, summer, that beloved institution, is a financial and logistical nightmare.

headline: Governor of Jakarta Bucks Indonesia’s Party Politics
abstract: With support especially from younger voters, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama has shaken the establishment by vowing to run as an independent when he seeks to keep his office next year.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Since becoming governor of Jakarta in 2014, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama has shown little patience for incompetent bureaucrats or alleged “budget irregularities” — the local term for corruption.

headline: At Vassar, Seeing the Heavens With Paint, Pencil and Cocaine
abstract: An exhibition featuring the works of 19 artists tries to take on the mysteries of the universe.
lead_paragraph: With an imposing stance, the astronaut Gordon Cooper towers over visitors to the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College. Everything about him glows: his metallic spacesuit, the soles of his shoes, the helmet he clutches in the crook of his arm. His head is an otherworldly blue, his hair and eyes blaze white.

headline: Peter Thiel’s Dropout Army
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: His prodigies want to rewire the world. Will that mean more than inventing the next Snapchat?
lead_paragraph: THE battle between Gawker and the tech titan Peter Thiel has made him look like a spiteful manipulator with a bully wallet. But this characterization is incomplete. The stakes and ambitions of Mr. Thiel’s back-room lawsuit-jiggering are fairly trivial compared with many of his endeavors — some stealthy, some gleefully public — to rewire the world to his liking.

headline: Review: ‘Thoroughly Modern Millie’ in Northport Tap-Dances Around Dated Mores
abstract: The show at the John W. Engeman Theater reinforces a sense of nostalgia for the 1920s, when a smart girl’s “modern” goal was to marry for money.
lead_paragraph: As you watch “Thoroughly Modern Millie,” it is difficult to remember that the old-fashioned musical set in 1922 dates only to a 2002 Broadway debut. Its staging at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport reinforces that sense of nostalgia, as it blithely features a time when the “modern” goal of a smart gal was to marry for money instead of love, and when “white slavery” was something to joke about.

headline: How to Force Out Rent-Controlled Tenants
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Landlords who endanger their residents rarely face severe punishment.
lead_paragraph: THE arraignment of the notorious New York landlord Steven Croman last month was a rare bit of good news for the tenants in his buildings, many of whom have said they have endured hazardous conditions designed to force them out of their homes. Mr. Croman was charged with 20 felonies related to his rental income (he has pleaded not guilty), and faces a civil suit accusing him of using illegal means to force tenants out of their rent-stabilized apartments, in order to renovate them and find new tenants to pay market rates.

headline: The City of Lights, When It Was First Lighted
abstract: “Electric Paris,” an exhibition of paintings, prints and photographs at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, examines the city through the lens of nighttime illumination.
lead_paragraph: During the second half of the 19th century, the French emperor Napoleon III assigned the prefect Baron Georges-Eugène Haussmann to modernize Paris. In addition to razing crooked medieval streets to build grand boulevards and public gardens, Haussmann oversaw the installation of approximately 20,000 gaslights throughout the city. His purported slogan: “Light before all else.”

headline: The Marriage Puzzle
abstract: What are the secrets of a good marriage? Are we inclined to marry the wrong person?
lead_paragraph: What are the secrets of a good marriage? Are we inclined to marry the wrong person?

headline: Restaurants Where the Italian Family Tradition Endures
abstract: The ritual of leisurely dining in a welcoming atmosphere lives on at Sam’s, Francesco’s or La Manda’s.
lead_paragraph: A linebacker for the Green Bay Packers understood exactly why we love the enduring, family-run Italian restaurant. The October 1974 issue of Esquire magazine included a feature on where N.F.L. players liked to eat, in which that linebacker, Jim Carter, gave this description of a Chicago favorite: “Food keeps coming, and they’re insulted if you don’t eat everything — or spend less than three hours on a meal.”

headline: Pope Francis Sets Guidelines for Removing Bishops Who Mishandle Sex Abuse Cases
abstract: Following up on a 2015 promise, a papal decree called for dismissal if a bishop had, “through negligence, committed or omitted acts that have caused grave harm to others.”
lead_paragraph: ROME — A year after approving the creation of a new tribunal to discipline bishops who covered up child sex abuse by priests, Pope Francis scrapped that plan on Saturday and issued new guidelines to oust those who have been “negligent” in handling such cases.

headline: Jim Lahey
abstract: A bread baker who loves all things “Hamilton,” British mystery shows, African music and kung fu.
lead_paragraph: Jim Lahey is a James Beard Award-winning baker and the owner of Sullivan Street Bakery in New York. His “no-knead” bread recipe went viral 10 years ago and is still the go-to technique for home bread bakers.

headline: Are Opioids the Next Antidepressant?
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Buprenorphine (Drug)', 'Opium', 'Heroin', 'OxyContin (Drug)', 'ANTIDEPRESSANTS']
abstract: The only time she felt functional was when she was hooked on heroin.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the most painful experiences of being a psychiatrist is having a patient for whom none of the available therapies or medications work.

headline: Jurgen Klinsmann Brushes Off Opening Loss for U.S. Team in Copa América
abstract: The Americans had obvious problems in a 2-0 defeat against Colombia, but Klinsmann chose to look on the bright side.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Shortly after watching what had appeared to be a disheartening defeat to Colombia in the opening game of the Copa América, United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann was an exemplar of serenity.

headline: For Jim Courier, Remembering When America’s Big 4 Ruled the Men’s Game
