abstract: It has been 25 years since Courier beat his Compatriot Andre Agassi for the French Open title, a time when American men dominated tennis.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Sunday before the French Open men’s final, if all goes according to plan, Jim Courier will step back in time and onto the red clay with his 1-year-old son, Kellan.

headline: Jury Out on Effectiveness as Some States Make Voting Easier
abstract: While officials hope automatic registration fuels a jump in voter turnout, the results of experiments in Oregon and elsewhere have been decidedly mixed.
lead_paragraph: SALEM, Ore. — A parade of Republican-controlled states in recent years has made it more difficult to cast a ballot, imposing strict identification requirements at polling stations, paring back early-voting periods and requiring proof of citizenship to register.

headline: Review: American Cut Bar & Grill in Englewood Cliffs
abstract: The restaurant, part of a small chain, specializes in classic dishes, including a huge porterhouse and a cold seafood bar.
lead_paragraph: You don’t need a special occasion to dine at American Cut Bar & Grill in Englewood Cliffs. The glamorous Art Deco-inspired décor within the bi-level restaurant, which has been open since February, tends to obscure the fact that the finest item there is a very good steak.

headline: No, He’s Not Hitler. And Yet ...
abstract: History may not repeat itself, but it does yield warnings.
lead_paragraph: We are supposed to find some solace these days in the assurance that Donald Trump is “not Hitler.” One reasonable response is this: Of course he isn’t. Only Hitler is Hitler, and he died in a bunker in 1945. There is no such thing as reincarnation, and history is nothing more than a long, linear series of individual people and events that come and go. It is, as the saying goes, “just one damn thing after another.”

headline: Review: Manna in Water Mill
abstract: A new restaurant in the space once occupied by beloved local favorite Mirko’s seeks to become a mainstay worthy of its longtime predecessor.
lead_paragraph: Manna Restaurant and Bar, an upscale yet intimate restaurant that opened in January in Water Mill, has big shoes to fill.

headline: Muhammad Ali Evolved From a Blockbuster Fighter to a Country’s Conscience
abstract: Ali was at the center of American culture in part because he turned boxing into a condition of the American self: Punch or be punched.
lead_paragraph: “Jaws,” they say, invented the blockbuster. But damn if Muhammad Ali didn’t get there first. From 1971 to 1974, he starred in two of the greatest events in the history of American sports, fights with Joe Frazier at Madison Square Garden and George Foreman in Kinshasa that had names that belonged on a movie studio’s release schedule: “The Fight of the Century” and “The Rumble in the Jungle.”

headline: In Middlefield, Green Ski Slopes, Foie Gras and Caviar
abstract: The Fire at the Ridge restaurant, at the base lodge of a family ski hill, has great aspirations.
lead_paragraph: Fire at the Ridge, at Powder Ridge ski area in Middlefield, isn’t what one would expect. A restaurant in a base lodge at a family ski hill serving foie gras, salad with duck confit and a $32 steak? An unwritten rule of restaurant economy holds that “base lodge” may never appear in the same sentence as “pistachio sage gremolata” or “lemongrass nage.” Fire at the Ridge blithely defies it.

headline: On the Trail: The Week of May 29
abstract: The candidates lashed out at each other in California and demonstrations became violent outside Trump rallies.
lead_paragraph: The candidates lashed out at each other in California and demonstrations became violent outside Trump rallies.

headline: Bow Ties, but No Waxed Mustaches
abstract: On top of having old-school swagger, customers say that at Hudson Malone in Midtown East, the drinks are served by the best bartender in New York City.
lead_paragraph: On top of having old-school swagger, customers say that at Hudson Malone in Midtown East, the drinks are served by the best bartender in New York City.

headline: The Revenge Pub on East 53rd Street
abstract: Doug Quinn, whom a Hudson Malone regular called the best bartender in New York, opened the bar after he was abruptly fired by P.J. Clarke’s.
lead_paragraph: Midtown East has long been known as an area of expensive hotels, easy access to Grand Central Terminal and the United Nations. But proper pubs? Not really. The area (those who live there call it Turtle Bay) has long specialized in rowdy white-collar hookup joints, expensive wine bars and paint-by-number Irish saloons. Not to mention the occasional sketchy massage parlor.

headline: The Fable of a Wall Street Titan, Invented by a Character Just as Peculiar
abstract: “The Book of Daniel Drew” is a fictional account of a real-life financier, and the biography of its author, Bouck White, is equally outlandish.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’m reading about the Wall Street shenanigans of the late 19th century, and I was curious about a recently reprinted 1910 book, “The Book of Daniel Drew,” by Bouck White, who said he had assembled the autobiography from a jumble of Drew’s papers. Is it reliable?

headline: T. Marshall Hahn Jr., Who Remade Virginia Tech as President, Dies at 89
abstract: Dr. Hahn transformed a regional military college with a mostly white, male student body into a diverse, internationally renowned research university.
lead_paragraph: T. Marshall Hahn Jr., who as president of Virginia Tech transformed it from a regional military college with a mostly white, mostly male student body into a diverse, internationally renowned research university, died on May 29 at his home outside Blacksburg, Va. He was 89.

headline: How Maya Shetreat-Klein, Pediatric Neurologist, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: An evangelist for combining Western medicine with botanical remedies, Dr. Shetreat-Klein treats herself with fresh-laid eggs, forest bathing and a family movie night.
lead_paragraph: The pastoral life is probably not what many New Yorkers associate with the Bronx, but for Dr. Maya Shetreat-Klein, a pediatric neurologist who lives and works — and raises chickens — in Riverdale, the borough offers a deep retreat from the urban experience. In her practice, Dr. Shetreat-Klein, 42, combines Western medicine with diet and botanical remedies to treat children with migraines, seizures, attention deficit disorders and other health problems. Her recent book, “The Dirt Cure: Growing Healthy Kids With Food Straight From Soil,” addresses her work. At home, she grows herbs and vegetables, and takes advantage of the Bronx’s many acres of parkland. “We eat their eggs,” she said of her eight avian household members. “We have not eaten the chickens.” In addition to the birds, the doctor lives with her husband, Avni, 44, a physiatrist, their three children and a golden retriever.

headline: The Many Lives of a New York S.R.O.
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Single-Room Occupancy', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: After decades of housing the poor, frail or troubled on a brownstone block of the Upper West Side, Capitol Hall is renovated with the help of its neighbors.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, while most Upper West Siders were breathing a sigh of relief that the neighborhood’s seedy, sometimes menacing single-room-occupancy hotels were being converted into co-ops, a few residents of West 87th Street worried about the fate of the hotels’ tenants, particularly those in the S.R.O. on their block, the Capitol Hall.

headline: The Quinceañera, a Rite of Passage in Transition
abstract: The celebration, an increasingly elaborate affair, reflects the changing landscape of Latinos in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Cedillo family was already running an hour late, so when the Range Rover stretch limo dropped them off at St. Agatha Church in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, Lucero Cedillo and her court of nine chambelanes, the equivalent of groomsmen, dashed out of the car.

headline: Word Search
abstract: Tom McCoy has us looking for trouble.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — The total number of puzzle themes can sometimes seem limited in scope, but there is always someone who is willing to give an oft-repeated theme a twist. Today, Tom McCoy offers us such a puzzle.

headline: In Turkey, a Syrian Child ‘Has to Work to Survive’
keywords: ['Youth', 'Child Labor', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: Over one million Syrian children live in Turkey, and thousands work in factories or sweatshops to provide for their families, rather than attend school.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — When he was 9, Ahmad Suleiman watched his father die from a battlefield wound in Syria. Four years later, he now puts in 12-hour shifts at a damp and squalid textile factory in Istanbul as the primary breadwinner for his family, which fled to Turkey after his father’s death.

headline: Firebombs and Accusations Fly in ‘Ruthless’ Election Campaigns in Mexico
abstract: Candidates all over the country have hurled accusations of corruption at one another ahead of municipal and regional elections on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Trailing badly in the polls, and with elections just around the corner, Roxana Luna reached for transcendental salvation.

headline: California Senate Race Is a Tale of Diversity and a Flailing G.O.P.
abstract: As the state’s open primary on Tuesday approaches, two Democratic women, one black and one Latina, are the leading contenders to advance to the November election.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Kamala Harris made history when she became the first black woman to be elected attorney general in California. Now she is vying for the United States Senate, and she has managed to stay the front-runner in the race ever since she announced last year, just days after Senator Barbara Boxer, a fellow Democrat, said she would leave the seat she won in 1992.

headline: Serena Williams’s Toughest Rival, This Time, Isn’t Herself
abstract: Garbiñe Muguruza did not shrink from the pressure and played to win in her victory over Williams at the French Open.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Serena Williams versus Serena Williams is supposed to be the internal conflict that decides Grand Slam tournaments in this long-running, top-heavy era in women’s tennis.

headline: Yankees Put Mark Teixeira on the Disabled List With Torn Knee Cartilage
abstract: The first baseman will meet with the team’s physician on Monday to determine whether surgery is necessary.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Mark Teixeira’s career as a Yankee began here in his hometown, where Orioles fans showered him with boos on opening day in 2009, loathing him for accepting the richest contract he was offered.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, June 5, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Shooting in Chicago is like a cancer. It’s starting to spread out.”

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 2, Episode 9: ‘A Dragonfly in Amber’
abstract: This series has comfortably settled back into its old rhythm, slowing down its pace and calibrating the emotional dynamics of its characters.
lead_paragraph: At a pivotal point in this week’s episode, Claire refuses to return to Lallybroch despite all the ways in which the coming war is affecting her psyche. She tells Jamie, “If I go back then it would be like lying in that ditch again. Helpless and powerless to move like a dragonfly in amber.” That this is the most powerful moment speaks to how subdued this episode is.

headline: Donald Trump Reflects on His Relationship With Muhammad Ali
abstract: The presumptive Republican nominee had known the boxer since the 1980s, but their association may have cooled in recent months over Mr. Trump’s stance on Muslims.
lead_paragraph: As he reflected on Saturday on the death of Muhammad Ali, Donald J. Trump gushed, calling him a “terrific guy,” “so generous,” and an “amazing poet.”

headline: Big 12 Conference Passes on Vote to Expand, for Now
abstract: Though it will play a championship football game next season, its board of directors was “not ready to vote” on adding teams at its spring meeting.
lead_paragraph: The Big 12 Conference will play a championship football game in 2017. What remains unclear is whether it will still be a 10-team league.

headline: Brooke Conti, Patrick Trousdale
abstract: The couple grew up in neighboring towns and knew each other, but didn’t begin dating until July 2012.
lead_paragraph: Brooke Amber Conti, the daughter of Gina M. Conti and Kurt G. Conti of Murray Hill, N.J., was married June 4 to Patrick Donahue Trousdale, a son of Mary Lee Donahue Trousdale and William H. Trousdale of Summit, N.J. The Rev. Otto Hentz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Teresa of Avila Church in Summit.

headline: Meghan Everlanka, Paul Sipio
abstract: The couple met in 2010 during internships at the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey in Camden, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Meghan Kelly Everlanka, the daughter of Karen A. Everlanka of Kingwood, Tex., and the late Robert T. Everlanka, was married June 4 to Paul Joseph Sipio, a son of Susan C. Sipio and Dr. James C. Sipio of Mount Laurel, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Capella, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

headline: Laura Fletcher, Daniel Rauch
abstract: The bride and groom met at Princeton, from which they graduated. In May, the bride received an M.B.A. and the groom a law degree, both from Yale.
lead_paragraph: Laura Parker Fletcher, a daughter of Lynn R. Fletcher and Robert P. Fletcher of Falls Church, Va., was married June 4 to Daniel Eric Rauch, a son of Elizabeth E. Rauch and Allan N. Rauch of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Amy Schwartzman officiated at the East Hall in Union Station in Washington.

headline: Andrea Hawksley, Andy Lutomirski
abstract: The couple, who both have degrees from M.I.T., met in 2012 through a mutual friend at a sailing and camping trip in Inverness, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Johanna Hawksley and Andrew Michael Lutomirski are to be married June 5 in the garden of their home in Hillsborough, Calif. Rabbi Sara Mason-Barkin is to officate.

headline: Lyndsay Hoy, Vincent Nguyen
abstract: The bride and groom, both doctors, were married at the Rodin Museum in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Lyndsay Mihoko Hoy, the daughter of Elizabeth A. Hoy and Dr. Fredrick B. Y. Hoy of Peoria, Ill., was married June 4 to Dr. Vincent Quang Nguyen, the son of Phi P. Nguyen and Vinh Q. Nguyen of Oklahoma City. Maria-Odilia Romeu, a nondenominational minister ordained through Journeys of the Heart, officiated at the Rodin Museum in Philadelphia.

headline: Benjamin Linder, Matthew Long
abstract: The couple met through OkCupid in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Michael Linder, the son of Joan Phillips Linder and Alan E. Linder of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., was married June 3 to Matthew Posler Long, the son of Barbara Posler and William S. Long of Albuquerque, N.M. Jessica Linder, Mr. Linder’s sister, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Jennifer Rudin, Andrew Finkelstein
abstract: The bride, a casting director, and the groom, a “Dateline” video editor, met at a New York Cycle Club event.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Anne Rudin and Andrew Carl Finkelstein were married June 4 at Larchmont Temple in Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Eve Rudin, the bride’s sister, officiated, assisted by their father, Rabbi A. James Rudin.

headline: Rebecca Ende, Drew Lichtenberg
abstract: The couple, who both work in the theater, met at a play in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Ann Ende, the daughter of Ellen U. Ende and Dr. Frederick I. Ende of Richmond, Va., was married June 4 to Drew Arthur Lichtenberg, a son of Dr. Debora J. Lichtenberg and Andrew A. Lichtenberg of Pelham, Mass. The groom’s father, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Sanderling Resort in Duck, N.C.

headline: Maren Shapiro, William Eger
abstract: The bride and groom have degrees from Harvard and the University of Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Maren Alissa Shapiro, a daughter of Natalie A. Gustafson and Matthew M. Shapiro of Riverside, Conn., was married June 4 to William Edmond Eger, the son of Holly Hodder Eger and Edmond I. Eger III of Portola Valley, Calif. The Rev. Susan Harris, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Allen Farm in Chilmark, Mass.

headline: Jisoo Suh, Andrew Hua
abstract: The couple, who met at the University of Virginia, were married in Faber, Va.
lead_paragraph: Jisoo Suh, a daughter of Hae Sook Park and Byoung Hyun Suh of Manila, was married June 4 to Andrew Gu Hua, the son of Julia Gu Hua and Fred Hua of Hollis, Queens. The Rev. Claire Goodman, a Universal Interfaith minister, officiated at DelFosse Vineyards and Winery in Faber, Va.

headline: Alison Murray, Thomas Winkler
abstract: The couple met in 2011 on the dance floor of a music club in Amagansett, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Alison Reeve Murray, the daughter of Lauren Ingersoll Murray and Thomas A. Murray of Alexandria, Va., was married June 4 to Thomas Patrick Winkler, a son of Patricia A. Winkler and Thomas G. Winkler of St. Louis. Msgr. Donald Hanson performed the ceremony at the Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

headline: Mary Elizabeth Edwards, Nicholas Rockwell
abstract: The couple met in high school while attending the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Mary Elizabeth Edwards, the daughter of Carole H. Edwards and Dr. Michael J. Edwards of Cincinnati, was married June 4 to Nicholas Holt Rockwell, the son of Sarah F. Robinson and Andrew R. Rockwell of Boston. The Rev. Adam H. Webb, a Baptist minister and a cousin of the bride, officiated at Oxmoor Farm in Louisville, Ky.

headline: Christopher Lloyd, Scott Harding
abstract: The couple, who met through OkCupid in 2012, were married in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Allan Lloyd and Scott David Harding Jr. were married June 4 at Meridian House, an event space in Washington. Antoinette L. Murphy, a friend of the couple who received authorization from the Superior Court of the District of Columbia for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Joy Liu, Jovian Yu
abstract: The couple met at Brown University, from which they graduated and received medical degrees.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Joy Jia Liu, the daughter of Huijia Dong and Dr. Chen Liu of Edison, N.J., was married June 4 to Dr. Jovian Yu, a son of Weijie Yang and Bin Yu of East Greenwich, R.I. Darlene Shlesinger, who was ordained by Rose Ministries, officiated at the Kay Chapel in Newport, R.I.

headline: Monica Ferreira, Matthew Gimlett
abstract: The bride is a graduate of Cornell. The groom graduated from Notre Dame.
lead_paragraph: Monica Lauren Ferreira, the daughter of Miriam. C. Ferreira and Carlos C. Ferreira of Rego Park, Queens, was married June 4 to Matthew Kevin Gimlett, a son of Linda M. Gimlett and Brian F. Gimlett of Greenville, Del. The Rev. Michael Tidd, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan, with Msgr. Robert T. Ritchie, the cathedral’s rector, taking part.

headline: Elizabeth Doe, Zachary Stone
abstract: The couple met in 2013 through mutual friends at an outdoor concert in Charlottesville, Va.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Walch Doe, a daughter of Mimi Doe and Thomas G. Doe of Concord, Mass., was married June 4 to Zachary Emerson Stone, a son of Angela C. Stone and Lawson G. Stone of Wilmore, Ky. The Rev. Marilu J. Thomas performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Charlottesville, Va., where she is an associate rector. The groom’s father, a United Methodist minister, offered a blessing.

headline: Laura Deck, Charles Stones IV
abstract: The couple met in 2011 while working as summer associates at a law firm in Boston.
lead_paragraph: Laura Elizabeth Deck and Charles William Stones IV were married June 4. Donald M. O’Day, a friend of the couple who received permission from Massachusetts to solemnize the marriage, officiated at Glen Magna Farms, a historic house and event space in Danvers, Mass.

headline: Melissa Danesh, William Feldman
abstract: The couple met in medical school at the University of California, San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Melissa Jasmine Danesh and Dr. William Brand Feldman were married June 4. Rabbi Joshua Levine Grater officiated at the Langham Huntington hotel in Pasadena, Calif.

headline: Juliana Shulman, Stephen Laniel
abstract: The couple, who met on OkCupid in 2011, were married in Fairlee, Vt.
lead_paragraph: Juliana Tropper Shulman, a daughter of Dr. Pamela J. Tropper and Dennis G. Shulman of Demarest, N.J., was married June 4 to Stephen Richard Laniel, a son of Faye E. Laniel and David D. Laniel of Shelburne, Vt. The bride’s father, a rabbi, officiated at Ohana, a family camp in Fairlee, Vt.

headline: Sarah Lebovitz, Ahmed Suria

headline: Muhammad Ali Shaped My Life
abstract: His courageous and articulate stance seeped into my awareness. He was our John Henry. He was sweat and bone, blood and pain.
lead_paragraph: When I was 15 years old some kid at my school asked me what I felt about the draft and Vietnam. He wanted to know if I expected to go to war and if I was happy about that possibility. I told him that I had no intention of fighting the Vietnamese, “first, and most importantly, because I have no desire to be killed or maimed and secondly, because I feel no hatred toward or fear of the Vietnamese people.” These are the words I used and even at the time I wondered where they had come from.

headline: 1941: Germans Raid Egypt
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In June 1941, German troops raid Egypt.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Germany has begun her direct offensive against Egypt and the Suez Canal. That was the interpretation in well informed quarters tonight [June 5] of the Nazi raid last night on Alexandria, Great Britain’s main naval base in the eastern Mediterranean. More than one hundred persons were killed and hundreds of others were wounded. One of Fuehrer Adolf Hitler’s first objectives, following the capture of Crete, would be to render untenable the British naval headquarters in Egypt, cripple the Royal Navy and leave Germany in control of the eastern Mediterranean, informed circles at London declared. The more the Nazis could disorganize the British fleet’s positions in those waters the easier a sea invasion of Cyprus and Syria would become, it was pointed out. It was believed here that last night’s attack on Alexandria was the forerunner of increasingly heavy bombing raids on that port. The Nazi planes, operating, it is believed from airports in Greece and the Dodecanese Islands, poured tons of high explosives and incendiary bombs on Alexandria, according to a communiqué issued by the Egyptian Ministry of the Interior. Many buildings were destroyed in the ninety-minute raid. — New York Herald Tribune, June 6, 1941

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Little by little the story of last week’s battle in the North Sea is being pieced together, and while it will necessarily be some time before the fullest details of the greatest naval fight in European waters since Trafalgar can be told, there is sufficient information to show that heavy as the losses sustained by Admiral Sir David Beatty’s gallant squadron were in throwing down the gauntlet to the whole German High Sea Fleet in its own waters, he did not come off the worse in the terrible encounter which followed.

Two new books — one by Moira Weigel, a doctoral candidate at Yale, and the other by the essayist, novelist and professional aperçu generator Alain de Botton — take strikingly different approaches to analyzing how we seek out and hold on to love.

abstract: With a par on the second playoff hole, McGirt broke his maiden in his 165th Tour start while Jon Curran extended his winless streak to 55 Tour appearances.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — The top three players in the world came into the Memorial Tournament fresh off victories. A lot of good that did them. Rory McIlroy, the world’s No. 2 golfer, backed into a tie for fourth. Top-ranked Jason Day finished tied for 27th, and Jordan Spieth was tied for 57th.

headline: Muhammad Ali Remembered, by Those Who Knew Him as Cassius
abstract: Friends and relatives of Ali’s in his hometown of Louisville, Ky., recalled the young fighter shadowboxing in school hallways and trying to impress girls by racing the bus home on foot.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Muhammad Ali filled the middle of three screens in the small theater. In footage taken a few years after his 1960 Olympic gold medal performance, he was explaining his decision to sit out the Vietnam War to a group of white male college students.

headline: After Rain Delay, Orioles Pounce to Topple the Yankees
abstract: The Orioles scored three runs in the bottom of the eighth for the win.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — As the Yankees’ first-base coach, Tony Pena, stood in the dugout Sunday morning, he was asked to consider a hypothetical situation. What if his son, Francisco, came to the plate for the Baltimore Orioles with two outs, the bases loaded and the Yankees clinging to a one-run lead?

headline: With Closing of East Village Shop, Little Ukraine Grows Smaller
abstract: The owner of Surma, one of a dwindling number of Eastern European emporiums in New York’s Little Ukraine, said the shop will close this month.
lead_paragraph: In July 1910, a teenager named Myron Surmach left his village in Ukraine, boarded the ship Atlanta with a third-class ticket and headed across the ocean to an improbably big city called New York. For 21 days, Mr. Surmach sucked on a lemon to stave off seasickness until he reached Ellis Island. There, he told an interviewer decades later, he was shocked to find an American guard welcoming him to the United States in perfect Ukrainian.

headline: Andy Murray’s Misfortune: He’s the Same Age as Novak Djokovic
abstract: Murray has beaten Djokovic on occasion, but not in their last five meetings in major tournaments.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Andy Murray was born May 15, 1987, in Glasgow, a wee lad destined to resurrect Britain’s fortunes in men’s tennis.

headline: Cultivating Brand Loyalty in Even the Toughest Customer
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Customer Loyalty Programs', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: As Americans rack up more rewards memberships, but use fewer of them regularly, companies are rethinking their loyalty programs.
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS are both more loyal and more fickle than ever before, judging by the number of customer rewards cards they have and the number they actually use.

headline: How the G.O.P. Plans to Restrict de Blasio’s Control of New York City Schools
abstract: The bill, introduced by the Senate Republican majority leader, John J. Flanagan, would appoint an “education inspector” who could overrule much of the mayor’s authority.
lead_paragraph: In his latest swipe at Mayor Bill de Blasio, the State Senate majority leader, John J. Flanagan, introduced a bill on Friday that would extend mayoral control of New York City schools by only one year, while allowing the governor to appoint an “education inspector” with substantial power to interfere in the management of the schools.

headline: In a Reversal, Germany’s Military Growth Is Met With Western Relief
abstract: As Europe faces pressure from ISIS and a more muscular Russia, Germany has pledged to bolster its military, reversing its decades-long instinctive pacifism.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — You know times have changed when the Germans announce they are expanding their army for the first time in 25 years — and no one objects.

headline: Greed, Corruption and Danger: A Tarnished Afghan Gem Trade
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Metals and Minerals']
abstract: The government’s muted response to a militia’s takeover of a giant lapis mine suggests an aligning of interests among insurgents and the political elite.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The local people called the militia’s takeover of the giant lapis mine in northeastern Badakhshan Province a white coup — easy and bloodless. Perhaps, but the seizure has become a lesson in how the lack of accountability and rule of law in Afghanistan can turn bounty into ruin.

headline: Mike Breen Becomes N.B.A. Finals Play-by-Play Fixture
abstract: Breen, who is announcing a record 11th N.B.A. finals, chooses a smooth and steady play-by-play style over the gimmicks abused by other broadcasters.
lead_paragraph: Mike Breen has sneaked up on us — if stealth is possible when you’ve called Knicks games on radio and TV for a quarter-century and been the lead voice of the N.B.A. on ESPN and ABC for a decade.

headline: Natalie Gulbis’s Motivation Turns to Motherhood
abstract: The popular Gulbis, 33, who didn’t make the cut at the ShopRite L.P.G.A. Classic, is looking to the future as her long career winds down.
lead_paragraph: GALLOWAY TOWNSHIP, N.J. — After Natalie Gulbis finished her rounds on Friday and Saturday at the ShopRite L.P.G.A. Classic, dozens of fans lined up near the green to interact with her. As Gulbis walked off the course, she signed autographs, posed for photos and engaged in small talk with anyone who approached.

headline: Smaller Chips May Depend on Vacuum Tube Technology
abstract: The vacuum tube, a 100-year-old technology replaced by transistors, could make a comeback as a way to shrink computer chips beyond the limits of silicon.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — The future of computing may be in its past.

headline: Led Zeppelin’s ‘Stairway to Heaven’ to Be Scrutinized in Court in Copyright Case
abstract: This case — in which a lawsuit claims that part of the classic hit was copied from “Taurus,” a tune by Spirit — is being watched as a test of the limits of copyright.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé is on tour, Drake is setting streaming records and Taylor Swift has split up with her boyfriend. But next week, the most gripping news for the music industry may come out of a federal courtroom in Los Angeles.

headline: The Trump Show, a Hit for Now, Faces a Test in the Fall
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: The Donald Trump media operation, which has dominated the political conversation so far, faces a bigger challenge in the general election.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to stop calling Donald J. Trump’s presidential operation “the Trump campaign.” It would be far more accurate to call it “Trump Productions Inc.”

headline: Why the Economic Payoff From Technology Is So Elusive
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Productivity', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Areas like computing and mobile devices have made advances, but the government has reported disappointingly slow growth and continuing stagnation in productivity.
lead_paragraph: Your smartphone allows you to get almost instantaneous answers to the most obscure questions. It also allows you to waste hours scrolling through Facebook or looking for the latest deals on Amazon.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, June 6, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “We were left making these headstones because death is easy here.”

headline: For N.H.L.’s Black Aces, It’s an Opportunity in Spades
abstract: When N.H.L. rosters expand during the playoffs, the players who are called up, known as Black Aces, are just an injury away from taking the ice.
lead_paragraph: By every measure, 2015-16 was a breakthrough season for the San Jose Sharks prospect Ryan Carpenter.

headline: Prevention Magazine Will Become Ad-Free
abstract: The health and wellness magazine, which is published by the family-owned Rodale company, will also raise subscription rates and introduce a paywall.
lead_paragraph: Most magazines these days are trying to attract print advertising dollars. Not Prevention.

headline: Branded a ‘Terrorist’ for Reporting Two Sides of Ukraine’s War
abstract: A journalist has had guns pointed at him, slept in a shipping container, and walked past corpses, but until now had never been listed as a terrorist by a nationalist website.
lead_paragraph: I have had guns pointed at me, slept in a shipping container and walked past the corpses of shelling victims since the separatist insurgency in eastern Ukraine began two years ago. But I had never been blacklisted as a terrorist before.

headline: Ali’s Least Memorable Fight
abstract: In 1976, Muhammad Ali battled Japanese wrestler Antonio Inoki. It was not a thrilla.
lead_paragraph: Muhammad Ali, who died Friday, was part of some of the most memorable sporting moments of the 20th century.

headline: Songs, Toasts and Tales of the Past at a Broadway Bartender’s Very Last Call
abstract: At Sardi’s in Manhattan, regulars offered their thanks and goodbyes to a man who mixed their drinks for decades.
lead_paragraph: The post-matinee crowd began streaming into Sardi’s restaurant on Saturday, just as it had for decades. After passing through the Chianti-red facade, many patrons entered the Little Bar, an alcove-like room to the left of the entrance. Then they settled in for drinks and conversation in the company of a tall man wearing a maroon jacket, a white starched shirt and a black bow tie who had long been a steady presence there.

headline: Thomas Schaefer, 85, Ranking Officer Among American Hostages in Iran, Dies
abstract: Mr. Schaefer endured death threats, a hunger strike and three months of solitary confinement during 444 days as a hostage in Tehran.
lead_paragraph: Thomas E. Schaefer, a retired Air Force colonel who endured death threats, harsh interrogation and solitary confinement as the ranking military officer among the 52 Americans held hostage for 444 days in Iran in the closing stages of the Carter administration, died on Tuesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 85.

headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Season 3, Episode 7: Stop, Beta Time
abstract: Sunday’s episode touches smartly on trust, friendship and the lies we tell our friends and ourselves.
lead_paragraph: Until the last mouse click of “To Build a Better Beta,” Pied Piper has existed only in the abstract, with endless promise and limitless value. Richard’s compression platform could be worth billions. It could be the next Facebook. It could change the world. Alternately, it could be utterly worthless, one of the countless failed start-ups that pile up in Silicon Valley like E.T. cartridges in a New Mexico landfill. As Erlich Bachman, the father of such stillborn incubees as Aviato and Nip Alert, says, “Shuttering a company in the Valley like a rite of passage, like herpes simplex one.” The metaphor gets more disgusting from there.

headline: Warriors, Resilient at Home, Cruise Against the Cavaliers
abstract: Draymond Green scored 28 to help Golden State take another step toward defending its N.B.A. title with a 33-point victory in Game 2 of the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Steve Kerr, the coach of the Golden State Warriors, is fairly open about the fact that he plays favorites. When it comes to shooting the basketball, Stephen Curry and Klay Thompson are allowed to do whatever they want. They can chuck shots from the bleachers. Bad shots do not exist for them.

headline: Ramadan Is Here. What Islam’s Holiest Month Is About.
abstract: A professor who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history explains the practices and meaning of Ramadan.
lead_paragraph: Hossein Kamaly is a professor at Barnard College who specializes in Islamic studies and Middle Eastern history. In an interview, he explained the basic tenets of Ramadan, the holiest month of the Muslim calendar, which begins on Monday for most of the world’s Muslims. The interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: The Right Way to Observe Ramadan
abstract: Fasting during the Islamic holy month should be a choice, not a compulsion.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — THE Islamic holy month of Ramadan begins today and with it the long hours of fasting by hundreds of millions of Muslims. The daylong fast during the lunar month in which we Muslims believe that the Quran was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad is one of the five pillars of Islam. It is a way for Muslims to show their devotion to God, and, some say, to understand the suffering of those who have no choice but to go without food.

headline: ‘Veep’ Season 5, Episode 7: Do a Little Dance ...
abstract: The speed, fury and totality of Selina’s power is a joy to watch.
lead_paragraph: Through nearly five seasons of “Veep,” we’ve seen Selina Meyer suffer embarrassments galore and absorb loss after loss, to the point that some may wonder how anyone so gaffe-prone and ineffectual ever wound up in the Oval Office. This week’s episode answers that question: It’s because Selina can be vicious. “Veep” can rarely be called triumphant, but toward the end of this episode, when a dazzlingly attired President Meyer is demolishing her enemies with devastating words and a killer smile … well, for a few moments she actually is the most powerful person in the free world. She’s stunning, in every sense of the word.

headline: ‘The Humans’ and ‘Shuffle Along’ Take Top Honors at Drama Desk Awards
abstract: “The Humans” won for outstanding play and “Shuffle Along” for outstanding musical. The musical “She Loves Me” won for outstanding revival.
lead_paragraph: “The Humans” and “Shuffle Along” each earned four awards, with “The Humans” winning for outstanding play and “Shuffle Along” for outstanding musical, at the Drama Desk Awards on Sunday night.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 6, Episode 7: Never Too Late
abstract: An old friend returned. Sansa and Jon Snow tried to win over supporters and Arya made plans.
lead_paragraph: “Never too late to come back.”

abstract: The police said the three-time Pro Bowler had been hospitalized with wounds that were not believed to be life-threatening.
lead_paragraph: Denver Broncos cornerback Aqib Talib was shot in the leg at a nightclub in Dallas, a team spokesman said Sunday.

headline: Report Accuses Mexico of Crimes Against Humanity in Drug War
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Organized Crime', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Drug Cartels']
abstract: A study by the Open Society Justice Initiative concluded that indiscriminate force — killings, forced disappearances and torture — and impunity are a part of state policy.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Two days after Jorge Antonio Parral Rabadán was kidnapped by a criminal gang, the Mexican Army raided the remote ranch where he was a prisoner and killed him. As he instinctively raised his hands in defense, the soldiers fired over and over at point-blank range.

headline: Pedro Kuczynski Holds Thin Lead Over Keiko Fujimori in Peru Presidential Election
abstract: Mr. Kuczynski, a former prime minister, held a narrow advantage over Ms. Fujimori, the daughter of a former president, as officials said they would keep counting votes.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — An economist who served as Peru’s prime minister held a razor-thin lead in the presidential contest on Sunday against the daughter of an imprisoned former president who was seeking to return her family to power.

headline: Wu Tong on Traversing Musical Boundaries in China
abstract: Mr. Wu, one of China’s most successful crossover musicians, discusses his new album and what it was like to be a rock musician in China in the ’90s.
lead_paragraph: As a master sheng player and vocalist, Wu Tong is one of China’s most successful crossover musicians. In 1991, he and four conservatory classmates founded the band Lunhui, or Again, which in 2000 became the first rock band to play on national television in China. In more recent years, Mr. Wu has traded in his rocker uniform for the less raucous, though no less energetic, world music circuit. He is a founding member of Yo-Yo Ma’s Silk Road Ensemble, the international music collective, which in April released the album “Sing Me Home.” In an interview, Mr. Wu, 44, talked about the new album, his evolving relationship with the sheng and what it was like to be a rock musician in China in the 1990s.

headline: Pilots Find Pride in Russia’s Skies
abstract: After attending an air show at a military training base, Maxim Babenko set out to document the servicemen in Russia’s Air Force, and to showcase the unseen facets of their military lives.
lead_paragraph: After attending an air show at a military training base, Maxim Babenko set out to document the servicemen in Russia’s Air Force, and to showcase the unseen facets of their military lives.

headline: Pilots Find Pride in Russia’s Skies
abstract: After attending an air show at a military training base, Maxim Babenko set out to document the servicemen in Russia’s Air Force, and to showcase the unseen facets of their military lives.
lead_paragraph: Maxim Babenko was at a Russian military training base a few months ago, sitting among thousands of spectators at an air show. Looking around, he was impressed by the crowd’s seemingly unconditional admiration for the pilots. The applause was riotous; dozens of people reached out just to touch the pilots; children posed endless questions to them about how they could one day fly a fighter jet.

headline: A Pause That Distresses
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Recession and Depression', 'Interest Rates', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: After a disappointing jobs report: Don’t panic, but do worry.
lead_paragraph: Friday’s employment report was a major disappointment: only 38,000 jobs added, a big step down from the more than 200,000 a month average since January 2013. Special factors, notably the Verizon strike, explain part of the bad news, and in any case job growth is a noisy series, so you shouldn’t make too much of one month’s data. Still, all the evidence points to slowing growth. It’s not a recession, at least not yet, but it is definitely a pause in the economy’s progress.

headline: Sanders Fans, I Get Your Pain. But Let’s Unite Against Trump.
abstract: A Clinton supporter set aside his anger when she lost to Barack Obama in 2008. Now he calls on Bernie Sanders supporters to do the same for her.
lead_paragraph: WE had lost. And I was as sure as I’ve been about anything else in my life that my party was making an enormous mistake. My candidate had won 23 primaries, about 1,900 delegates and, by one count, the popular vote. My candidate may have actually gotten more votes than the guy we Democrats were about to nominate, who was inexperienced and, I thought, unelectable.

headline: Muhammad Ali: Never the White Man’s Negro
abstract: When he was a young man, the best black boxers were expected to be cautious and restrained. But Ali would have none of it.
lead_paragraph: CASSIUS CLAY, born in 1942, was the grandson of a slave; in the United States of his boyhood and young manhood, the role of the black athlete, particularly the black boxer, was a forced self-effacement.

headline: To Stop Bad Prosecutors, Call the Feds
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Prosecutorial Misconduct', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Constitution (US)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'District Attorneys', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Prosecutorial misconduct remains rampant, but the Justice Department has an as-yet-unused tool to fight it.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors are the most powerful players in the American criminal justice system. Their decisions — like whom to charge with a crime, and what sentence to seek — have profound consequences.

headline: Brazil’s Gold Medal for Corruption
abstract: To earn the trust of his countrymen, the interim president needs to take meaningful steps against corruption.
lead_paragraph: Michel Temer, Brazil’s interim president, displayed poor judgment on his first day in office last month when he appointed an all-white, all-male cabinet. This understandably angered many in racially diverse Brazil.

headline: The Madness of America
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Violence by either Trump supporters or those opposed to him is self-defeating.
lead_paragraph: The candidacy of Donald Trump, the fervor of those who support it, and the fierce opposition of those who don’t is making America mad — both angry and insane, as the dual definitions of the word implies.

lead_paragraph: The following lesson activity is based on the obituary “Muhammad Ali Dies at 74: Titan of Boxing and the 20th Century.”

headline: The Transcendent Artistry of a Legendary Dancer, Four Decades In
abstract: At 64, the choreographer, director, dancer and writer Bill T. Jones is making some of the most personal work of his career.
lead_paragraph: “FAME,” WROTE Rainer Maria Rilke, in 1902, “is, after all, only the sum of all the misunderstandings that gather around a new name.” The line appears at the beginning of a short book on Auguste Rodin that a 27-year-old Rilke published when the world-­famous sculptor was 63. However much we think we know about Rodin, the young poet argued, we’re wrong. And yet, Rilke goes on to say, it’s not even worth taking the time to disabuse us of our errors, “for they gathered around the name, not around the work.”

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Chances of Winning Have Faded, but His Rallies Haven’t
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Thousands are still crowding in for a chance to see Mr. Sanders, some as a sort of farewell, but others in the belief he can still snag the nomination.
lead_paragraph: DAVIS, Calif. — In a rally here last week, 9,000 people came to hear Senator Bernie Sanders speak, some catching a glimpse from a parking garage roof.

headline: In Mississippi Town, Some Fear School Desegregation Ruling May Backfire
abstract: Cleveland wonders whether it should fight to maintain the modicum of integration it has achieved, or accept the federal government’s more vigorous efforts to desegregate.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND, Miss. — The multicultural high school band kicked off a punchy “Pomp and Circumstance” as the 2016 graduates of Cleveland High School marched across the gymnasium. They were a near-equal mix of black and white students, with the occasional Nguyen, Patel or Rojas sprinkled among them.

headline: Student Question | Is ‘Be Yourself’ Bad Advice?
abstract: What does “be yourself” really mean? And is it good or bad advice?
lead_paragraph: How many times in your life have you been told all you have to do is be yourself? What were the situations in which you received this advice?

headline: War Wounds That Time Alone Can’t Heal
abstract: Moral injury resembles post-traumatic stress disorder with an added burden of guilt, and requires different treatment.
lead_paragraph: No doubt in the course of your life, you did something, or failed to do something, that left you feeling guilty or ashamed. What if that something was in such violation of your moral compass that you felt unable to forgive yourself, undeserving of happiness, perhaps even unfit to live?

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Hong Kong’s Murder Mystery: Who Is Poisoning the Dogs?
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Poisoning and Poisons']
abstract: Over 200 dogs may have been poisoned since the 1980s, but officials do not know who is responsible or what the motives may be.
lead_paragraph: Grim reminders of some of Hong Kong’s most gruesome murders line Bowen Road: signs posted every few hundred steps that warn, “Beware of Dog Poisoning.”

headline: Cold Brew in the Form of an Ice Pop
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Coffee']
abstract: This refreshing summer treat delivers a surge of iced coffee.
lead_paragraph: Cold-brew coffee, emphasis on the cold, is what you get in this new ice pop from Brewla, a company whose other flavors are fruit based. The bar is a lightly sweetened mixture of the coffee and organic milk: Brewla Barista, box of five, $5.99 at Union Market stores in Manhattan and Brooklyn, brewlabars.com.

headline: Lifting the Curtain on New York’s Food Scene
abstract: A new book offers the stories behind some of the city’s bars, restaurants and corporate kitchens.
lead_paragraph: A survey of the personalities who make New York’s food scene tick are collected in this compelling volume by a writer whose beat is not food. What she offers are first-person accounts from more than 50 individuals behind city institutions like Zabar’s and Peter Luger. You will find Justo Thomas, the fish butcher at Le Bernardin; Jeb Burke, the head chef at Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation; and Nino Esposito, an owner of Sette Mezzo. And there are plenty of opinions to savor, like Mr. Esposito’s point that “New Yorkers like to see and be seen by people they know”: “Food and the City” by Ina Yalof (G. P. Putnam’s Sons, $28).

headline: The Bartender’s Bar Cart
abstract: Three of the city’s mixologists design high-end bar carts.
lead_paragraph: To create a series of bar carts, USM Modular Furniture tapped the expertise of three New York mixologists: Ivy Mix of Leyenda, Jane Danger of Mother of Pearl, and St. John Frizell of Fort Defiance. Using the company’s colorful modular Haller shelving, each has come up with a rolling bar cart that can be used indoors or out. For hers, Ms. Danger included a shelf to hold a record player. The height of each cart varies according to the designer. None include a built-in cutting board, something I would want, but the people at USM say it can be added. The carts are worth considering for a very special dad, graduate or newlyweds: Limited Edition Bar Carts, $3,778 to $5,466 at USM Modular, 28 Greene Street (Grand Street), 212-371-1230, usm.com.

Shares in Credit Suisse are also down 50 percent over the last year.

lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Three officers of the Jordanian intelligence service and two other employees of the service were killed on Monday in a Palestinian refugee camp near the capital, Amman, in what the government said was a terrorist attack.

headline: New Opioid Limits Challenge the Most Pain-Prone
abstract: Use and abuse of painkillers has been historically lower among older patients than younger ones, but experts say that could be changing.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve come to rely on opioids for chronic pain, as a growing proportion of older adults has, you may have noticed that the drugs are becoming more difficult to get.

headline: Early Puberty in Girls Raises the Risk of Depression
abstract: Those who developed breasts younger than their peers had a higher risk of depression, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: When girls come in for their physical exams, one of the questions I routinely ask is “Do you get your period?” I try to ask before I expect the answer to be yes, so that if a girl doesn’t seem to know about the changes of puberty that lie ahead, I can encourage her to talk about them with her mother, and offer to help answer questions. And I often point out that even those who have not yet embarked on puberty themselves are likely to have classmates who are going through these changes, so, again, it’s important to let kids know that their questions are welcome, and will be answered accurately.

headline: Donald Trump Makes His First Congressional Endorsement
abstract: Mr. Trump backed Representative Renee Ellmers, who is running in a redrawn congressional district in North Carolina and has been a target of conservatives for months.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump made his first congressional endorsement this weekend, backing Representative Renee Ellmers in a North Carolina primary race in which she has been opposed by heavily funded adversaries.

headline: Congress Returns From Break to Face a Backlog
abstract: In a year shortened by elections and national political conventions, lawmakers must tackle a pileup of legislation over Zika, drugs and the Pentagon.
lead_paragraph: Congress returns this week after a Memorial Day break, with lawmakers needing to get busy on a pileup of legislation in a year shortened by the elections and by national political conventions in July.

headline: Donald Trump Questioned About Previous Positions on Libya and Iraq
abstract: Mr. Trump has described himself in his campaign as having opposed interventions in both countries, but his critics point to evidence to the contrary.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump found himself on the defensive on Sunday over his claims that he had opposed the intervention in Libya and the war in Iraq.

headline: Candidates Prepare for One Last Heave in California
abstract: Supporters of Hillary Clinton and of Donald Trump will be hoping that their campaigns will soon be able to focus on the November fight.
lead_paragraph: Democratic supporters of Hillary Clinton will be hoping that Tuesday, when the California primaries take place, will be the moment she can start looking forward to facing Donald J. Trump with a united front.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Secretary of the Admiralty communicates to the press the following telegram, which he received at 10.30 a.m. today [June 6] from the Commander-in-Chief of the Grand Fleet:

headline: Race Appears Over for Bernie Sanders, but California Still Offers Drama
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: With a victory, Mr. Sanders could continue making his case to change the minds of superdelegates heading into the convention.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic race may already be over by the time the California polls open. According to The Associated Press, Hillary Clinton has already earned the 2,383 delegates needed to win the nomination. Yet in some ways California is still the most interesting contest between her and Bernie Sanders so far.

headline: On One California Night, Triumph and Tragedy
abstract: “In many ways, the personal characteristics of Robert Kennedy are very much like the dominant characteristics of the American people,” The New York Times wrote on June 6, 1968, the day he died.
lead_paragraph: “In many ways, the personal characteristics of Robert Kennedy are very much like the dominant characteristics of the American people,” The New York Times wrote on June 6, 1968, the day he died.

headline: Joel McHale Takes On the CFDA Awards: ‘Everyone Should Be Ready’
abstract: The comedian isn’t known as a Friend of Fashion, but maybe that’s why he was asked to do the event.
lead_paragraph: The Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, a.k.a. the Oscars of fashion, taking place Monday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom in New York, can feel like Groundhog Day, with the same names nominated over and over again. This year, every nominee for women’s wear designer of the year has already won that accolade at least once. And one, Marc Jacobs, has already won a lifetime achievement award.

headline: The Cavs That LeBron James Assembled Are Getting Clobbered
abstract: This was the team the King himself courted. It is down, two games to none and, thus far, embarrassing itself.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Before excuses are made for LeBron James, before the bulk of the blame for consecutive horror shows at Oracle Arena is heaped on a supporting cast of Cleveland Cavaliers that has turned to dust when removed from a comfy Eastern Conference refuge, it must be reiterated that this was the team the King himself courted.

headline: Where Nearly Half of Pupils Are Homeless, School Aims to Be Teacher, Therapist, Even Santa
abstract: Housing projects and four shelters surround Public School 188 in Manhattan, where students and teachers grapple with problems that stretch the very idea of what a school is supposed to be.
lead_paragraph: There are supposed to be 27 children in Harold Boyd IV’s second-grade classroom, but how many of them will be there on a given day is anyone’s guess.

headline: Only in Europe Can Britain Be Great
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Referendums', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: There’s nothing glorious about isolation. True patriotism shows in voting for a positive role within the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With just days remaining before the referendum on European Union membership, two anxieties are colliding: the fear of job losses if Britain leaves and the fear of high immigration if it remains. News headlines reflect a country that is not at ease with itself, trapped between what a former American secretary of state, Dean Acheson, once described as an imperial past it finds hard to relinquish and a future role it is reluctant to embrace.

headline: China Pushes Back Against U.S. Complaints of Industrial Overcapacity
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Steel and Iron', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Washington did not complain when Beijing’s spending helped global growth, a Chinese official said, adding that the impact of closing factories was hard to estimate.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese finance minister jabbed back on Monday at complaints from his American counterpart that China’s glut of factories making mountains of steel, aluminum and other products was overwhelming foreign markets and makers.

headline: The U.S. Is Failing in Infant Mortality, Starting at One Month Old
abstract: The United States does worse than about two dozen other industrialized nations in this crucial measure of public health.
lead_paragraph: Many more babies die in the United States than you might think. In 2014, more than 23,000 infants died in their first year of life, or about six for every 1,000 born. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 25 other industrialized nations do better than the United States at keeping babies alive.

headline: Newt Gingrich’s Criticism on Judge Remarks Surprises Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Gingrich, the former House speaker, and Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, denounced Mr. Trump’s words about a judge handling the Trump University lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump expressed surprise on Monday that one of his supporters from the Republican Party, Newt Gingrich, had criticized him for his remarks about the heritage of the federal judge overseeing a lawsuit against the defunct Trump University.

headline: Uber Rolls Out App Improvements to Meet Driver Demands
abstract: Uber is changing its app to address driver demands, including making it easier for them to take breaks and helping them find places to buy inexpensive gas.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Tensions have long simmered between Uber and its drivers who power the ride-hailing service. Drivers held protests when Uber cut fares with little warning and have filed class-action lawsuits to be recognized as company employees rather than independent contractors.

headline: Ukraine Struggles to Shake Off Legacy of Corruption
abstract: The resignation of Aivaras Abromavicius, the economy and trade minister, amid allegations of cronyism was a worrying sign in the fight against graft.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The text message to Ukraine’s minister of economy and trade was as unwelcome as it was unexpected. The sender, a stranger, wrote that he wanted to be the new deputy minister.

headline: And Like a Tweet in the Night, Kanye Was Gone
keywords: ['Music', 'Governors Ball Music Festival', 'Summer Jam (Music Festival)', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: After storms ended the Governors Ball and part of the Hot 97’s Summer Jam on Sunday, fans gathered in the East Village, summoned by a Kanye West who never played.
lead_paragraph: Just past 2 a.m. Monday, Kanye West poked his head through the roof of a car heading north on Third Avenue in the East Village and surveyed what he had wrought. On East 11th Street, outside Webster Hall, maybe a couple of thousand young people were clustered — in the street, on the sidewalks, on stoops, on balconies, sitting atop Postal Service trucks — waiting for a just-announced concert that was beginning to seem as if it might not happen. When Mr. West rode by, a few hundred of them spied him and peeled off, surrounding his car, taking pictures, reaching for handshakes.

headline: At Ceausescu’s Villa, Focus Is on Décor, Not Dictatorship
abstract: The mansion where Nicolae Ceausescu lived with his wife, Elena, during the 24 years he ruled Romania was shrouded in secrecy. It is now a museum.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — In the 24 years that Nicolae Ceausescu ruled Romania, the mansion where he lived with his wife, Elena, was shrouded in secrecy.

headline: ScienceTake | Looking Into a Fly’s Brain
abstract: Scientists have developed a new method for peeking into the brain of a freely walking fruit fly — by peeling back its head.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have developed a new method for peeking into the brain of a freely walking fruit fly — by peeling back its head.

headline: Creating a Window Into a Fly’s Brain
abstract: Researchers develop a method for observing brain activity in a freely moving fly.
lead_paragraph: Fruit flies are far from human, but not as far as you might think.

headline: In Search of Tech’s Productivity Boost
abstract: Smartphones, the internet and other gadgets have become ubiquitous. But economists wonder why they are not making us more efficient.
lead_paragraph: The dominant theme in the technology industry for more than a few years now has been social media and on-demand services. Facebook and Twitter. Uber and Airbnb. And a whole lot of other companies that have come and gone or are still going strong.

headline: Expanding the Start Menu
abstract: The version of the Start Menu included with Windows 10 gives you more control over both the size of your app tiles and the menu itself.
lead_paragraph: Q. Can I change the size of the tiles in the Windows 10 Start menu? I want to make the apps I use the most bigger so I can find them faster.

headline: Joachim Gauck, German President, Won’t Seek Second Term
abstract: Even though the office is largely ceremonial, the announcement could create more problems for Chancellor Angela Merkel.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — President Joachim Gauck of Germany announced on Monday that he would not seek a second five-year term for the largely ceremonial office, a declaration that could create more problems for Chancellor Angela Merkel.

headline: Obama Is Eager to Hit the Stump for Hillary Clinton and Shred Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Advisers say Mr. Obama, who sees a Democratic successor as critical to his legacy, is impatient to begin campaigning and is taking nothing for granted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, after months of sitting on the sidelines of the rancorous contest to succeed him, is now ready to aggressively campaign for Hillary Clinton, starting with a formal endorsement of her candidacy as early as this week.

headline: Not Your Typical Meat and Two
abstract: Three Brooklyn companies team up for a meaty Father’s Day gift.
lead_paragraph: Sample Brooklyn with this handsome gift. Nils Wessell, who owns Brooklyn Butcher Blocks in Sunset Park, has teamed up with Michael Zieba of Zieba Knives in Greenpoint and John Ratliff, the charcutier and owner of Ends Meat in Industry City, to assemble a folding knife and some meaty salumi to go with one of his serious cutting boards: Father’s Day Gift Box, $99 including shipping, brooklynbutcherblocks.com and endsmeatnyc.com.

headline: After Okinawa Car Crash, U.S. Prohibits Its Sailors in Japan From Drinking
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES']
abstract: The roughly 19,000 Navy personnel in the country were also confined to their bases after a sailor thought to have been inebriated was involved in a car accident.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The United States Navy imposed a drinking ban on its roughly 19,000 personnel in Japan on Monday, ordering them confined to their bases after a sailor who was thought to have been drinking was arrested on the island of Okinawa in connection with a car accident that left two Japanese civilians injured.

headline: Questions Surround Sumner Redstone’s New Team of Representatives
abstract: Some longtime confidants of the media mogul question whether a lawyer and a spokesman acting on Mr. Redstone’s behalf have even met with him.
lead_paragraph: For several decades, Sumner M. Redstone ran his media empire with forceful, fiery and sometimes fear-inducing resolve. Whether he was heatedly pursuing an acquisition or churning through chief executives, there was never much doubt about what he wanted.

headline: Louvre and Musée d’Orsay Prepare to Reopen as Floodwaters Recede in Paris
abstract: The museums closed their doors and moved tens of thousands of artworks to higher floors last week as a precaution against the rain-swollen Seine River.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Louvre and the Musée d’Orsay were preparing on Monday to reopen after they moved tens of thousands of artworks to higher floors last week as a precaution against the rising level of the Seine River. Other French cultural institutions, including the historic Château de Chambord in the Loire Valley, reopened and were assessing the damage.

headline: Contemplating the Reality of Brexit
abstract: A reader writes that few people in Britain are aware of what the European Union actually does, and few care very much about it.

headline: If Mark Zuckerberg Can Be Hacked on Twitter, So Can You
abstract: A key lesson from a data breach of Mark Zuckerberg’s social media accounts: Quit using the same password for multiple websites.
lead_paragraph: There are several lessons to be learned from a data breach in which hackers gained access to Mark Zuckerberg’s social media accounts, but chief among them is probably this: Quit using the same password for multiple websites.

headline: Was There an Ice Age in the Southern Hemisphere?
abstract: Glacial periods affect all parts of the Earth, but there are big differences between hemispheres, because the north has more land.
lead_paragraph: Q. Was there an ice age in the Southern Hemisphere?

abstract: The justices will consider cases questioning the roles race and intellectual disability might play in capital prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday agreed to hear two appeals raising questions about the roles race and intellectual disability might play in capital prosecutions.

headline: Fish Tales and Other Recipes
abstract: This morning, it’s all about delicious food from the sea. Also, fried chicken.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: How to Improve on Baseball
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'Sporting Goods and Equipment']
abstract: Teams are using radar, cameras and lasers to place their fielders. But why stop there?
lead_paragraph: Lasers don’t go far enough.

headline: Italy’s Five Star Movement Leads in Rome’s Mayoral Election
abstract: A victory for the movement’s candidate, Virginia Raggi, in a runoff in two weeks would be a blow to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi, whose Democratic Party struggled in the first round.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Italy’s anti-establishment Five Star Movement moved one step closer to governing Rome on Monday, when returns released from nationwide municipal elections over the weekend took its candidate to a runoff vote in two weeks.

headline: Brock Lesnar Returns to the U.F.C. Against Mark Hunt
abstract: Lesnar, a professional wrestler who was once mixed martial arts’ biggest star, is returning to the sport after a five-year absence.
lead_paragraph: Back in the days when mixed martial arts was still a vaguely disreputable spectacle that had not yet moved toward the sports mainstream, its biggest star was a former professional wrestler, Brock Lesnar. Now after an absence of almost five years, he is returning to the sport, at least for one night.

headline: Libor-Rigging at Deutsche Bank May Be Harder to Prove
abstract: A recent court decision may present the Justice Department with a substantial hurdle to show that its evidence can support a conviction for wire fraud.
lead_paragraph: Reports a few years ago that global banks manipulated the London interbank offered rate, or Libor, to reap profits on their investments showed how easy it was to manipulate benchmarks used to set rates for trillions of dollars in mortgages, student loans and other financial products. Tell a few lies about the interest rates, and then watch the profits roll in – sounds like a classic fraud if ever there was one.

headline: Did Americans Lose Something on the Path to Modernity?
abstract: If restoring a sense of community is as hard as a new book suggests, it may be because those fleeing communal places knew what they were doing.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you are a terrorist leader bent on humbling the United States. What would be the smartest strategy at this moment?

headline: The Candy Store
abstract: How many jelly beans are in the jar? See if you can figure out the exact count — not just an estimate.
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was suggested by Sunil Singh, a regular Numberplay contributor and math consultant with Scolab, an educational technology laboratory based in Montreal. Sunil’s challenge seems impossible at first, but has a beautiful solution. Let’s try —

lead_paragraph: Give the classic brownie a sophisticated update with caramel and a sprinkle of sea salt.

headline: Brownies With Caramel: Sweet and Salty in a Committed Relationship
abstract: The guys at Baked perfected the brownie, but they couldn’t leave it alone.
lead_paragraph: “Ultimately, there’s nothing you can make with chocolate that’s better than a brownie,” said Renato Poliafito, owner of two Baked bakeries in New York City with his partner and co-founder, Matt Lewis. “You can make things that are fancier, or lighter, or creamier, but they won’t be better.”

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']

lead_paragraph: The death of a 3-month-old girl who was found unconscious by officers in a Staten Island apartment last summer has been ruled a homicide, the police said on Monday.

headline: A Doctor on Schedule, Rarely on Time
abstract: Everyone can tell when I’m behind. Every visit is pared to essentials. Paperwork is postponed, chatting minimized.
lead_paragraph: The minute I got on that bus, I knew I was in trouble. The driver sat at the stop just long enough to miss the green light. Then he inched along till he missed the next light and the one after that. He stopped at every stop even though not a soul was waiting.

headline: Muhammad Ali: The Champion Who Never Sold Out
abstract: Ali showed that being an active, conscious black person in America meant traveling a road on which wealth and trinkets would test the will of men and women.

headline: A Lavash That’s the Perfect Bread for Summer
abstract: At Joe & Misses Doe in the East Village, the lavash with spring-pea butter is hot and beautifully simple.
lead_paragraph: Ripping off a warm piece of the lavash at Joe & Misses Doe, a small East Village restaurant with a devoted neighborhood following, feels like an apt way to honor our move into summer.

headline: Janet Yellen Speech Indicates Fed Will Rethink Interest-Rate Plans
abstract: A previous assurance that rates would be raised “in the coming months” was dropped from a speech that Ms. Yellen gave on Monday.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Federal Reserve, mindful of unexpectedly weak job growth last month, has abandoned hope of raising interest rates at its next meeting in June, but Fed officials say they are still thinking seriously about raising rates in July or September.

headline: De Blasio Shifts Away From His Re-election Message of ‘One City’
abstract: As investigations have swamped City Hall, the notion that Mayor Bill de Blasio has brought about a unified New York appears to have all but vanished as an argument for his winning a second term.
lead_paragraph: The central message of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s re-election pitch appeared clear, even early in his administration: After a winning 2013 campaign that deplored the “tale of two cities,” the mayor’s bid for a second term would be founded on his mission to create “one city” for all New Yorkers.

headline: Hotels Aim to Stand Out With Local Art
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Art', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: To compete with Airbnb and other popular services, hotel brands are trying to remove the cookie-cutter approach to design.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to appeal to guests’ desire for new experiences and stand out in a competitive market, hotel brand managers are mining their local art communities for everything from inspiration to installations.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: “The Bureau,” Éric Rochant’s hit French spy thriller, infiltrates the United States. “UnREAL” returns with an African-American suitor. And “Rizzoli & Isles” begins its final season.
lead_paragraph: “The Bureau,” Éric Rochant’s spy thriller and one of the most popular shows in France, infiltrates the United States. “UnREAL” returns with a Peabody Award and an African-American suitor. And “Rizzoli & Isles” begins its final season.

headline: The Greatest? Here’s Why.
abstract: Don’t keep your chin up. Don’t drop your hands. Don’t get pinned in the corner. Muhammad Ali’s boxing style defied all these conventions. And yet, he was the greatest.
lead_paragraph: Don’t keep your chin up. Don’t drop your hands. Don’t get pinned in the corner. Muhammad Ali’s boxing style defied all these conventions. And yet, he was the greatest.

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘UnREAL,’ ‘Angie Tribeca’ and ‘Wentworth’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small, famous and esoteric, to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. Our most recent suggestions also appear below. To receive our guide straight to your inbox, sign up here.

headline: 1891: London Omnibus Strike
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In June 1891, London Omnibus Strike.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The directors of the London General Omnibus Company refused to see a deputation of their men today [June 7]; so in obedience to the manifesto issued by the ‘Bus and Tram Men’s Union,’ the bus drivers from all parts of London made their way early this (Sunday) morning in thousands to the Royal Victoria Hall, Waterloo Bridge Road, to finally give their sanction to strike. Mr. T. Sutherst, the President of the Union, made a stirring speech, at the end of which he called out on strike every omnibus driver, conductor, stableman and horse keeper. If they did their duty, the strike would be at an end by Tuesday. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 7, 1891

headline: Pretrial Detention
abstract: A law professor writes that when the rich buy their way out of harsh pretrial detention, they are buying only that to which everyone is entitled.

headline: Iraqis Who Flee Fighting in Falluja Find Hardship and Hunger
abstract: Survivors reach aid camps hungry, thirsty and scared, and their ordeals are not over: They are in the arms of a government without the resources to care for them.
lead_paragraph: AMIRIYAT FALLUJA, Iraq — One of the Iraqi civilians who risked an escape from the sprawling battle for Falluja made it as far as the Euphrates River. He was there for all to see on Sunday morning: His body, tied to the side of a boat, bobbed in the muddy waters next to a rickety bridge that separates Baghdad from the violence of Anbar Province.

headline: No More ‘Groundhog Day’ for One Powerful Producer

lead_paragraph: Scott Rudin, a prolific and powerful producer on Broadway and in Hollywood, has withdrawn from a much-anticipated project to adapt the popular movie “Groundhog Day” into a stage musical.

headline: Payday Lenders’ Fight Against Regulator Would Be a Long Shot
keywords: ['Payday Loans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: New guidelines from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau are certain to face legal challenges, but those claims will probably fail.
lead_paragraph: The new payday lending rule, once complete, will force many payday lenders out of business. That means that a legal challenge is certain, and also the courts, which worry about regulations that require bankruptcies, will take it seriously.

headline: On Hart Island, Missed Friends and Common Graves
abstract: Friends of a man whose body was buried there request that his ashes be returned; a law professor asks what is wrong with a common grave.

headline: A Disappointment for Kanye West Fans
abstract: Thousands of Kanye West fans gathered outside Webster Hall in the East Village after the rapper announced an impromptu 2 a.m. concert. But it was canceled, and police officers arrived to clear the streets.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Kanye West fans gathered outside Webster Hall in the East Village after the rapper announced an impromptu 2 a.m. concert. But it was canceled, and police officers arrived to clear the streets.
