abstract: Nascent technology firms risk running short on cash, but a recent revival of initial public offerings could offer them hope.
lead_paragraph: Wheezing unicorns may get a breath of fresh air from initial public offerings.

headline: Kenya’s Collective ‘Uh-Oh’: Another Election Is Coming
abstract: The contest for president is next year, but protests and violence have already begun. A 5-year-old was shot on Monday, and demonstrations are hurting the economy.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — By 9 a.m. on Monday, clouds of black smoke blotted out the sky. A mountain of tires burned. Roads were blocked. Young men poured into the streets of a slum in Nairobi, gleefully carrying huge, jagged pieces of concrete.

headline: Do Gorillas Even Belong in Zoos? Harambe’s Death Spurs Debate
keywords: ['Monkeys and Apes', 'Zoos', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: Gorillas have been shown to thrive in captivity, but some wonder if their display is tailored to the interests of the animals or the onlookers.
lead_paragraph: Harambe, the 17-year-old Western lowland gorilla shot dead at the Cincinnati Zoo late last month after a 3-year-old boy fell into his enclosure, may be physically gone, his tissues harvested for research and his sperm extracted to help diversify the captive breeding gene pool.

headline: Streaming Carries Drake’s ‘Views’ to a Fifth Week at No. 1
abstract: Dierks Bentley’s “Black” sold 88,000 to Drake’s 37,000, but the rapper’s strong streaming numbers carry him to the top of the chart.
lead_paragraph: Another week, another No. 1 for Drake.

headline: Hot 97’s Summer Jam 2016

lead_paragraph: Severe weather on Sunday took a toll on the annual event, but what remained was a show that focused more intently on New York hip-hop than in recent years.

headline: Muhammad Ali in Vietnam
keywords: ['Vietnam War', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Conscientious Objectors', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Black soldiers admired Ali’s defiance even while risking their lives for America.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Muhammad Ali said, “I ain’t got no quarrel with them Vietcong. No Vietcong ever called me nigger,” he spoke for many of the black soldiers and Marines who were in Vietnam fighting for an America that continued to oppress and marginalize them. One night in Chu Lai, I heard a black Marine say to a white one, “Look, I don’t want to hear ‘gook’ or ‘dink’ ’cause I don’t know what you’ll call me tomorrow.”

headline: No Charges for Mother Over Dead Gorilla
abstract: An Ohio prosecutor said Monday that there will be no charges brought against a mother whose child fell into a Cincinnati Zoo enclosure, leading to the death of a silverback gorilla.
lead_paragraph: An Ohio prosecutor said Monday that there will be no charges brought against a mother whose child fell into a Cincinnati Zoo enclosure, leading to the death of a silverback gorilla.

headline: Letters to the Editor
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Vehicles', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Children and Childhood', 'Plastic Surgery']
abstract: Readers react to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Light Sentence for Brock Turner in Stanford Rape Case Draws Outrage
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: In court, the victim denounced her attacker’s six-month sentence, while the attacker’s father complained that his son’s life had been ruined for “20 minutes of action.”
lead_paragraph: A recall effort against a California judge was announced on Monday in a sexual assault case at Stanford University that ignited public outrage after the defendant was sentenced to a mere six months in jail and his father complained that his son’s life had been ruined for “20 minutes of action” fueled by alcohol and promiscuity.

headline: Street Style: Governors Ball
abstract: The festival was cut short by stormy weather, but there was plenty of style in attendance.
lead_paragraph: The festival was cut short by stormy weather, but there was plenty of style in attendance.

headline: When Eels Get Aggressive
abstract: Researchers studied how eels can use targeted, high-voltage volleys to attack their prey.
lead_paragraph: Researchers studied how eels can use targeted, high-voltage volleys to attack their prey.

headline: Like a Slimy Taser, Electric Eels Can Leap Out and Zap Their Prey
abstract: Electric eels do not just send their high-voltage pulses through the water to paralyze their prey; they can jump out of the water to shock them too.
lead_paragraph: This summer’s science horror blockbuster is a remake: Return of the Leaping Electric Eel!

headline: Peter Shaffer Dies at 90; Playwright Won Tonys for ‘Equus’ and ‘Amadeus’
abstract: Movie versions of Mr. Shaffer’s ambitious plays helped elevate his status at home in Britain and in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Peter Shaffer, a leading British playwright whose Tony-winning dramas “Equus” and “Amadeus” explored the male psyche through the entwined anguish of dual protagonists, died on Monday in County Cork, Ireland. He was 90.

headline: New York Attorney General Seeks to Halt Sale of 2 Nursing Homes Amid Inquiries
abstract: The office of Eric T. Schneiderman said it was objecting to the sale of two centers to the Allure Group, citing “misrepresentations” by the company.
lead_paragraph: Citing misrepresentations and broken promises, the New York State attorney general’s office is seeking to prevent the purchase of two nursing centers by a company that was involved in transactions that put a Manhattan nursing home in the hands of luxury condominium developers.

headline: A Day in Milan With Lorenzo Serafini
abstract: The designer takes T on a walking tour of his favorite places in his home city.
lead_paragraph: The designer takes T on a walking tour of his favorite places in his home city.

headline: Photos of Summer Fashion at Governors Ball
abstract: The festival was cut short by stormy weather, but there was plenty of style in attendance.
lead_paragraph: The Governors Ball music festival came to Randalls Island this weekend, bringing out the stylish crowds, as well as the music. See photos from the festival above.

headline: A Day in Milan — With One of Its Rising Fashion Stars
abstract: Lorenzo Serafini, the designer of Philosophy di Lorenzo Serafini, takes T to his favorite places in his home city.
lead_paragraph: On a recent stormy Monday in Milan, Lorenzo Serafini, the designer of Philosophy di Lorenzo Serafini, set off on foot to spend an afternoon at his favorite local haunts. The crush of work designing the spring/summer 2017 collection was only beginning, and Serafini — tan and unshaven after a week of scuba diving in the Maldives — was still relaxed.

headline: A Weekend in Chicago
abstract: Over Memorial Day weekend, 64 people were shot in Chicago, six fatally. Our team of journalists tracked the violence that has engulfed families and neighborhoods. Note: This video contains profanity.
lead_paragraph: Over Memorial Day weekend, 64 people were shot in Chicago, six fatally. Our team of journalists tracked the violence that has engulfed families and neighborhoods. Note: This video contains profanity.

headline: Direct-to-Consumer Lab Tests, No Doctor Visit Required
abstract: Firms promise to help consumers spot metabolic red flags. Critics say the services persuade healthy people to seek unneeded treatment.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Kristi Wood was tired and achy and could not think clearly, and she had no idea why.

headline: Next Feat for Novak Djokovic? Perhaps a Grand Slam
abstract: Djokovic’s first win at the French Open gives him a real shot at the Grand Slam, and at Roger Federer’s record for major singles titles.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A day or so before the French Open began and the rain started to fall, Novak Djokovic shot a series of short, amusing commercials with Gustavo Kuerten, the genial, mop-topped, three-time French Open champion from Brazil.

headline: Sanders Attacks Trump in California
abstract: In a final push before California’s presidential primary on Tuesday, Bernie Sanders criticized Donald J. Trump’s comments about a federal judge, Gonzalo Curiel.
lead_paragraph: In a final push before California’s presidential primary on Tuesday, Bernie Sanders criticized Donald J. Trump’s comments about a federal judge, Gonzalo Curiel.

headline: Telfar Partners With Asger Carlsen for the Berlin Biennale
abstract: The designer’s family models his 13 most popular T-shirt styles for a portfolio by the legendary photographer.
lead_paragraph: The designer’s family models his 13 most popular T-shirt styles for a portfolio by the legendary photographer.

headline: Nina Yashar’s Staged Living Space in London
abstract: The Nilufar gallerist takes T on a tour of Squat London, a pop-up exhibition filled with luxurious furnishings.
lead_paragraph: The Nilufar gallerist takes T on a tour of Squat London, a pop-up exhibition filled with luxurious furnishings.

headline: ‘The Glass Menagerie’ Heads Back to Broadway, With Sally Field
abstract: Joe Mantello and Finn Wittrock will also star in Tennessee Williams’s 1944 drama, which will be directed by Sam Gold and start showing on Feb. 14.
lead_paragraph: Only four years after its last revival, “The Glass Menagerie” will return to Broadway, starring two-time Academy Award winner Sally Field as Amanda Wingfield.

headline: A Traveling Design Show’s Very Chic London Iteration
abstract: Ironically called “Squat,” Nina Yashar’s new exhibition in Mayfair offers furnishings to match million-dollar artworks.
lead_paragraph: “London was my dream place to host the show,” says Nina Yashar, the grande dame of the Milanese design scene whose gallery, Nilufar, has decamped to London for the fifth iteration of its traveling exhibition Squat. “It’s the place for talent. So many of my designers are based here — Martino Gamper, Bethan Laura Wood, Michael Anastassiades. It’s incredible.” It’s already popped up in Paris and been to Beirut, but now Nilufar’s eclectic offerings of historical and contemporary design objects inhabit the first floor apartment in a Victorian terra-cotta building above Erdem’s store in Mayfair. The sumptuous space, which couldn’t be further from the threadbare realities that its title summons, has over the last five months been restored by the interior and architectural designer Shalini Misra. There are gems at every turn, and everything you see is for sale, from the floral configurations of Gio Ponti ceiling lights to the customized Dedar curtains and elegant Matisse sketch that hangs discreetly on the reception room wall — to even the property itself.

headline: “Courts 02” by Ward Roberts
abstract: This series took the photographer from New York to Hong Kong to Melbourne.
lead_paragraph: This series took the photographer from New York to Hong Kong to Melbourne.

headline: Painterly, and Imperfect, Pictures of Athletic Courts
abstract: Ahead of the publication of Ward Roberts’s “Courts 02,” the photographer is releasing a trio of posters.
lead_paragraph: “Growing up, connecting with other people was difficult,” says the Melbourne-born, Hong Kong-raised and now Brooklyn-based photographer Ward Roberts. “Even today, finding the right words is a substantial struggle,” he admits. “But, playing sport in China or in Australia — or America, Europe, Indonesia — is something that most people understand.”

headline: An Irreverent New York Designer Heads to Berlin
abstract: At the Berlin Biennale, Telfar Clemens unveils an exhibition of his most popular T-shirts — and has partnered with the photographer Asger Carlsen.
lead_paragraph: The designer Telfar Clemens creates clothes that are difficult to define. In the 11 years that have passed since he presented his first collection, his designs have been interpretations of basic, gender-neutral garments — an aesthetic Clemens describes on his website as “neither conceptual nor accessible — but both in extremis.” Or, as the designer along with the brand’s creative director, Babak Radboy, have termed it: “Extremely Normal.”

headline: Spotify Hires Troy Carter as a Liaison With Artists
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Music']
abstract: Mr. Carter, the former manager of Lady Gaga, is expected to oversee relationships with musicians as competition mounts in the streaming business.
lead_paragraph: As the music industry’s streaming wars intensify, Spotify is turning to the former manager of Lady Gaga to help compete against players like Apple and Tidal.

headline: Investigators’ Report on How a Prison Escape Happened
abstract: A year after two murderers escaped from Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y., the state inspector general's office released a report documenting a series of security failings that enabled the prison break.
lead_paragraph: A year after two murderers escaped from Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y., the state inspector general's office released a report documenting a series of security failings that enabled the prison break.

headline: ‘Systemic’ Lapses Found in Escape of 2 Killers From Dannemora Prison
abstract: Guards testified they faked records to make it appear they were making rounds, but instead read books or did puzzles, a report said.
lead_paragraph: The two murderers who escaped from the Clinton Correctional Facility last year intentionally picked a Friday night when they knew an officer named Ronald Blair was on duty.

headline: David Lamb, Author and War Correspondent in Vietnam, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Lamb covered the war in Vietnam and later opened a news bureau there; his work as a foreign correspondent led to books on the Arabs and Africans.
lead_paragraph: David Lamb, a dauntless foreign correspondent for The Los Angeles Times who also wrote critically acclaimed books about the Arab world and Africa, died on Sunday in Alexandria, Va. He was 76.

headline: Migrants Willing to Pay Price Not to Change Diet, Study Says
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Migrant Labor (Agriculture)']
abstract: According to M.I.T., poor migrants within India stuck with their preferences even when nearly malnourished and though the local crop was much cheaper.
lead_paragraph: When migrants move, they often keep to the cuisine of their homeland even if it costs them more money and even if they have to eat significantly less, a new study has found.

headline: European Union Seeks U.N. Approval to Intercept Libya-Bound Arms
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Europe wants permission to expand an existing naval operation’s mandate from intercepting migrant boats leaving Libya to blocking weapons heading in.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A year after it received the United Nations Security Council’s approval to try to stop human smuggling out of Libya, Europe is seeking the Council’s authorization to intercept illegal arms going into Libya.

headline: No Escape From Black Holes? Stephen Hawking Points to a Possible Exit
abstract: New calculations by Dr. Hawking and other researchers suggest that essential properties of whatever falls into these cosmic pits may survive.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — “A black hole has no hair.”

headline: Escape From Falluja
abstract: Thousands of civilians have fled the Iraqi city of Falluja in the past two weeks, after government forces launched an offensive to retake the city from ISIS control.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of civilians have fled the Iraqi city of Falluja in the past two weeks, after government forces launched an offensive to retake the city from ISIS control.

headline: For His Latest Trick, John Oliver Forgives $15 Million in Medical Debt
abstract: The host of HBO’s “Last Week Tonight” has perfected the art of explaining complicated subjects.
lead_paragraph: Would you rather spend 20 minutes reading about the hazards of predatory debt collection, or would you rather spend 20 minutes watching someone forgive millions of dollars in debt, complete with a giveaway that professed to put Oprah Winfrey’s famous “You Get a Car!” gimmick to shame?

headline: Baltimore Judge, Not Jury, to Decide Freddie Gray Murder Case
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A judge will decide the guilt or innocence of the city police officer who drove the van in which Mr. Gray suffered a fatal spinal cord injury.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The police officer charged with murder in the death of Freddie Gray chose on Monday to have a bench trial, eliminating a jury from his emotionally charged case and placing the verdict in the hands of the same judge who acquitted another officer two weeks ago.

headline: ‘Growing Up Coy’ Explores the Fallout After a Family Fought for Its Transgender Child
abstract: After 6-year-old Coy Mathis, who identifies as female, was denied access to the girls’ restroom at school, her family stood up for her rights.
lead_paragraph: Before North Carolina passed its controversial bathroom law, before Caitlyn Jenner transitioned and before “Transparent” became a hit TV series, a little kid in rural Colorado was told she couldn’t use the girls’ restroom at school anymore.

headline: An Obama Nominee’s Crushed Hopes
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: She was ready. She was qualified. But she was forced to wait and wait — until it was too late.
lead_paragraph: In early 2014, after decades of government and nonprofit work that reflected a passion for public service, Cassandra Butts got a reward — or so she thought. She was nominated by President Obama to be the next United States ambassador to the Bahamas.

headline: Review: In ‘Ordinarily Well,’ Peter D. Kramer Goes to the Antidepressant Ramparts
abstract: Peter D. Kramer, the psychiatrist who wrote “Listening to Prozac,” pushes back against critics who say drug therapy is often no better than placebos.
lead_paragraph: A bit of advice before reading Peter D. Kramer’s timely book, “Ordinarily Well: The Case for Antidepressants”: Skip the preface. There’s too much Peter Kramer in it, and it’s off-putting. He casts himself as a reluctant and oversensitive hero, one who only waded back into the arena when he had no choice, forced to defend both himself and his most cherished principles.

headline: David Carr’s Memoir Is to Be Made Into AMC Mini-Series
abstract: The cable network said the project was being conceived as a six-part mini-series, and Bob Odenkirk would play the title role.
lead_paragraph: AMC is developing a mini-series based on the memoir of the late New York Times columnist David Carr.

headline: Indian Students Lured by Recruiters Asked to Leave University
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Foreign Students (in US)']
abstract: A Western Kentucky University official said nearly 40 students did not meet the requirements of their admission and at least 25 must leave.
lead_paragraph: An aggressive campaign to recruit graduate students from India to study at Western Kentucky University has ended badly, with more than one-third of the students asked to leave the program after their first semester, a university official said.

headline: Review: At NY Phil Biennial, Interlochen Rises to the Occasion
abstract: This arts academy from Michigan excelled in the “Young Americans” program, which featured works by Ashley Fure, Nico Muhly and others.
lead_paragraph: One of the nobler aspects of the NY Phil Biennial, the New York Philharmonic’s festival of new music, is the involvement of young performers from educational institutions. On Sunday afternoon, high school students of the venerable Interlochen Arts Academy in Michigan, drawn from around the nation and abroad, took the stage of David Geffen Hall with the “Young Americans” program.

headline: Kalashnikov, Maker of AK-47, Looks to Rebrand
keywords: ['Firearms', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Arms Trade']
abstract: After American sanctions cut off one of its biggest markets, the Russian gun maker embarked on changes that executives say are yielding results.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A shipment of Kalashnikov rifles, popularly known as AK-47s, was destined for the United States when it was stopped and quickly rerouted to Venezuela. Washington had just slapped Moscow with sanctions over the Ukraine crisis, and the Russian gun maker Kalashnikov Kontsern suddenly found one of its biggest markets off limits.

headline: Rolex Names the Protégés in Its Arts Program
abstract: “This year the geographical diversity is really great,” the director of the Rolex Mentor and Protégé Initiative said, with winners coming from South America, South Asia and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The Rolex Mentor and Protégé Arts Initiative, a program that pairs major figures in seven disciplines with emerging artists, has announced those chosen for the 2016-17 cycle of the program, which began in 2002.

headline: Confusion in a Romanian Village as 3 Vasile Cepois Run for Mayor
abstract: The citizens of Draguseni, Romania, were presented with a predicament on Sunday when they had to decide who should lead their village.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The citizens of Draguseni, Romania, were presented with a predicament on Sunday when they had to decide who should lead their village of 2,500: the incumbent mayor, Vasile Cepoi, or one of four challengers — two of whom were also named Vasile Cepoi.

headline: Let It Go Go Go! Three Stage Versions of ‘Frozen’ Are on the Way
abstract: Here’s what we know about the three live-performance versions of “Frozen” underway — including one by sea.
lead_paragraph: In 1957, Walt Disney laid out what was then an astonishing plan for an entertainment ecosystem: Animated movies would fuel theme park attractions, which in turn would power merchandise sales, which would create interest in more movies. Today, with “Frozen,” the plan has evolved further.

headline: Democrats Jump on Allies of Donald Trump in Judge Dispute
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Mexican-Americans', 'Muslim Americans', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A report that Mr. Trump urged his supporters to defend his criticisms of a judge’s Mexican heritage, and then rebuked his staff for having suggested otherwise, gave his rivals added ammunition.
lead_paragraph: Democratic leaders nationwide sought to exact a political price from Republican officials and candidates on Monday for continuing to support Donald J. Trump after his explosive remarks challenging the objectivity of judges with Mexican or Muslim backgrounds.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: National Amusements Alters Viacom Bylaws to Stymie Sale of Paramount
abstract: The theater chain, through which Sumner Redstone controls his empire, said it wanted to ensure that any sale was part of a long-term strategy.
lead_paragraph: For Viacom, selling a stake in its Paramount film studio has become potentially more difficult — thanks to its controlling shareholder.

headline: Political Impasse in Canada Puts Assisted Suicide in Legal Limbo
abstract: Canada’s Supreme Court overturned criminal laws banning assisted suicide last year, and new legislation has not been put into place.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A court-ordered deadline and a parliamentary showdown have combined to leave most of Canada without any law governing physician-assisted suicide as of Tuesday.

headline: Turning Cemeteries Into Wine at a California Diocese
abstract: The Catholic Church had a problem: meeting graveyard expenses as more and more people chose cremation over burial. The answer: Bishop’s Vineyard.
lead_paragraph: HAYWARD, Calif. — For an additional $1,000, a family can have a loved one buried near the chardonnay vines glistening in the sun, or if they prefer, near the pinot noir vines at a cemetery here in an East Bay suburb of San Francisco.

headline: One Loss Into Copa América, U.S. Men Know the Stakes Are High
abstract: To advance from the tournament’s group stage, the United States likely needs to win Tuesday’s game against Costa Rica.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The United States men’s national soccer team faces what its coach, Jurgen Klinsmann, flatly declared a “must-win” game against Costa Rica in the Copa América Centenario on Tuesday night. But if the Americans are feeling the pressure, they are not showing it.

headline: Strategist Now Backing Donald Trump Previously Called Him a Danger
abstract: Alex Castellanos argued in a confidential memo last year that it would be dangerous to give Mr. Trump the power to launch a global war.
lead_paragraph: A veteran Republican strategist now helping lead a “super PAC” in support of Donald J. Trump argued in a confidential memo last year that it would be dangerous to give Mr. Trump the power to launch a global war.

headline: Chinatown Street Food vs. Mom’s
abstract: A woman selling deung, sticky rice with lots of food wrapped in bamboo leaves, reminded a man of the delicacies his mother made every spring.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Regulators Fear $1 Billion Coal Cleanup Bill
abstract: Officials worry that failed coal companies will use bankruptcy courts to pay off debts to banks and hedge funds, leaving behind their environmental obligations.
lead_paragraph: Regulators are wrangling with bankrupt coal companies to set aside enough money to clean up Appalachia’s polluted rivers and mountains so that taxpayers are not stuck with the $1 billion bill.

headline: The Work of David Gilkey, NPR Journalist Killed in Afghanistan
abstract: Mr. Gilkey, who was killed Sunday in Afghanistan along with his translator, Zabihullah Tamanna, was an award-winning photographer and videographer with wide experience around the globe. Here is a glimpse at his portfolio.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Gilkey, who was killed Sunday in Afghanistan along with his translator, Zabihullah Tamanna, was an award-winning photographer and videographer with wide experience around the globe. Here is a glimpse at his portfolio.

headline: Mets’ Juan Lagares Has Torn Thumb Ligament but Stays on Active Roster
abstract: Manager Terry Collins said Lagares could be available in the short term as a pinch-runner but would have to be ready to hit and field in three or four days to avoid the disabled list
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The Mets had news on center fielder Juan Lagares on Monday. Whether it was good or bad was hard to tell.

headline: Law Firm Salaries Jump for the First Time in Nearly a Decade
abstract: The elite New York firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore said it had raised salaries for associates by $20,000 to $35,000, increases that other major firms are likely to match.
lead_paragraph: In a move sure to bring cheer to junior associates at major law firms, one of the industry’s most elite, Cravath, Swaine & Moore, on Monday said it had increased the annual salary for its first-year lawyers to $180,000, from $160,000.

headline: Havanna, a Confectioner, Has Argentina’s First Local I.P.O. in 6 Years
abstract: The company raised $11.47 million, pricing shares at the top of the marketed range as a result of high demand.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Havanna, a confectioner from Argentina, raised $11.47 million on Monday in the first local initial public offering by the South American nation in nearly six years.

headline: Graft Fighter in Egypt Finds Himself a Defendant in Court
abstract: Hisham Geneina, who was once the head of Egypt’s Central Auditing Authority, is charged of spreading false news after he said graft had cost Egypt $76 billion.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s anti-corruption czar thought he was just doing his job when he estimated how much endemic graft had cost his country: About $76 billion, he said, mostly in corrupt land deals. But the estimate, it turned out, was itself a criminal offense.

headline: Who Decides ‘Fair Value?’ In Dell’s Case, a Judge
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A court’s decision that Dell Inc. sold for $6 billion too little means that companies don’t simply have to find the highest bidder, but that a judge may deem what the price should be.
lead_paragraph: Here come the lawyers.

headline: Russian Sports Ministry Pledges Doping Reforms in Twitter Q. and A.
abstract: Natalia Zhelanova, the antidoping adviser to Russia’s sports minister, Vitaly Mutko, acknowledged “past problems” and posted that “we are working tirelessly” toward addressing them.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s sports ministry is embracing an uncharacteristic openness as it tries to project an atmosphere of reform to the global sports officials and the American authorities who are scrutinizing Russia over allegations of a government-run doping program.

headline: Saudis Pressure U.N. to Remove Them From List of Children’s Rights Violators
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']
abstract: A report found a Saudi-led coalition responsible for most of the child deaths and injuries in Yemen last year, but the United Nations removed them from a list of rights violators.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — For two years in a row, the exercise of naming and shaming armies that kill and maim children on the battlefield has been subject to intense political jockeying among the powerful at the United Nations.

headline: Donald Trump’s Contempt for the Rule of Law
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Discrimination', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Muslim Americans', 'Mexican-Americans']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s support of ethnic and religious litmus tests for federal judges illustrates his disregard for America’s rule of law.
lead_paragraph: Federal judges have repeatedly and emphatically refused to recuse themselves from cases because of their race or ethnicity. These rulings were driven by two realizations: Ethnically based challenges would reduce every judge to a racial category, which would be racist in itself. And such challenges would make judges vulnerable to recusal motions — for reasons of race, ethnicity, gender or religion — in every case that came before them.

headline: Panama Papers Point to Tax Evasion
abstract: Many of the schemes involving people based in the United States are suspicious and demand federal investigation.
lead_paragraph: It was quite a revelation when leaked documents, made public in April, showed that Mossack Fonseca, a Panamanian law firm, had helped 14,000 clients worldwide create offshore accounts to conceal assets or dodge taxes. On Monday, a report by The Times found that there were at least 2,400 clients based in the United States over the past decade.

headline: Hillary Clinton Has Clinched Democratic Nomination, Survey Reports
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: On the eve of the New Jersey and California primaries, an Associated Press survey of superdelegates indicated that Mrs. Clinton had gone over the top.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton became the first woman to capture the presidential nomination of one of the country’s major political parties on Monday night, according to an Associated Press survey of Democratic superdelegates, securing enough of them to overcome a bruising challenge from Senator Bernie Sanders and turn to a brutal five-month campaign against Donald J. Trump.

headline: A Biased Judge? Donald Trump Has Claimed It Before
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Mexican-Americans']
abstract: Unlike most plaintiffs, who try to curry the favor of judges, Mr. Trump can turn publicly hostile toward them, assailing their motives, biography and fitness.
lead_paragraph: The circumstances sound eerily familiar: Donald J. Trump and his legal team had suffered a setback in a major court case. So they leveled an attack on the presiding judge, calling him irredeemably biased and unfair.

headline: Leaving Home
abstract: Hundreds of members of the Missionary Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary have passed through the doors of the residence on East 15th Street in Manhattan since 1948. Now it is on the market.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of members of the Missionary Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary have passed through the doors of the residence on East 15th Street in Manhattan since 1948. Now it is on the market.

headline: Down to One Resident in 15,600 Square Feet, a Missionary Sisterhood’s Home Is for Sale
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Nuns', 'Missionaries', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Hundreds of members of the Missionary Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary have passed through the doors of the residence on East 15th Street since 1948. Now it is all but empty.
lead_paragraph: The Missionary Sisters of the Immaculate Heart of Mary have served others across the world for more than a century. They have salved wounds in the slums of India, prayed with prisoners in Brazil, built schools in Cameroon and provided aid to a shaken Haiti.

headline: Mid Pleasures and Palaces
abstract: Peter A. Collins builds on his past successes.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — When is a crossword puzzle not just a crossword puzzle?

headline: Review: ‘War,’ a Deathbed Drama About Identity by Branden Jacobs-Jenkins
abstract: This play at Lincoln Center’s Claire Tow Theater conjures a fractious family in a hospital setting, a limbo populated by apes, and a wartime romance.
lead_paragraph: Identity. Look hard — and then harder — at that word until it wavers, fragments and dissolves before your eyes, and you begin to wonder if it amounts to anything other than an assemblage of diversely shaped letters that might as well be runes. It’s enough to give you a headache, isn’t it?

headline: Review: ‘An Act of God’ Is Back, With Sean Hayes
abstract: God reprises his stage role as a gay white male sitcom star in “an hour and a half of comedy heaven” at the Booth Theater.
lead_paragraph: I know it’s traditionally said that the Jews are God’s chosen people. But evidence to the contrary is currently on view on Broadway, where “An Act of God” opened (or rather reopened) on Monday at the Booth Theater.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: A serial killer known as the “Grim Sleeper” should be sentenced to death in the murders of nine women and a teenage girl over more than two decades in South Los Angeles, a jury decided on Monday. Lonnie Franklin Jr., 63, was convicted of 10 counts of first-degree murder last month for crimes dating back more than 30 years. A defense lawyer had asked jurors to sentence him to life without parole to hasten the healing for members of the victims’ families. Sentencing was set for Aug. 10. Most of the victims were dumped in alleys and trash bins in the impoverished area where Mr. Franklin lived. He had been called the “Grim Sleeper” because of a perceived interval in the killings, between 1988 and 2002. The authorities now believe there were killings during that period. (AP)

headline: Yankees’ Bats Heat Up in a Win Over the Angels
abstract: After struggling against Los Angeles starter Matt Shoemaker, Yankees hitters awoke in the seventh inning, and the team rallied for a victory.
lead_paragraph: There has been a new tradition introduced at Yankee Stadium this season, in which the building’s lights flash like strobes after each Yankees home run.

headline: Phyllis Curtin, American Soprano Who Championed New Music, Dies at 94
abstract: A mainstay of the New York City Opera in the 1950s and ‘60s, Ms. Curtin sang many leading roles yet operatic superstardom eluded her.
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Curtin, an American soprano celebrated as a champion of new music, died on Sunday at her home in Great Barrington, Mass. She was 94.

headline: Viktor Korchnoi, Chess Giant Who Drew Soviet Ire, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Korchnoi was widely considered one of the best players in history, though he never won a world championship. He defected from the Soviet Union in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Viktor Korchnoi, who was widely considered one of the greatest chess players in history but never captured the world championship in more than 60 years as an elite competitor, died on Monday in Switzerland, where he had lived for decades after defecting from the Soviet Union. He was 85.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Broke Glass Ceiling for Women in Construction Industry

headline: The Supreme Court Is Afraid of Racial Justice
abstract: How the court 40 years ago diminished the meaning of the Equal Protection Clause.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco — ASK people to identify a few landmark Supreme Court decisions on race, and they are likely to point to classics like Brown v. Board of Education, which ended segregation in schools, or Loving v. Virginia, which prohibited restrictions on interracial marriages. But 40 years ago Tuesday, the Supreme Court decided a pivotal case on race and equality whose legacy has profoundly shaped American race relations. And most people have never heard of it.

lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — Lives can turn in an instant. For former Senator Bob Kerrey, that moment came on Feb. 25, 1969, when, as a young lieutenant in the Navy SEALs, he led his squad into the Vietnamese village of Thanh Phong. By the time they withdrew, 20 civilians had been slaughtered, including 13 children, according to survivors.

headline: Is the Election ‘Rigged’?
keywords: ['English Language', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Talking about politics in terms of cheating reflects widespread frustration — and may also create it.
lead_paragraph: In an episode called “Hope” on the most recent season of ABC’s hit sitcom “Black-­ish,” three generations of an African-­American family gather in the living room to watch the news. They’re waiting to learn whether a police officer will be indicted on a charge of repeatedly firing a Taser gun at an unarmed black man. The characters — who have basically achieved the American dream but don’t always feel comfortable living it — debate who is to blame, and how much, before their discussion culminates in a dispirited conclusion: “The system is rigged against us.”

lead_paragraph: Martin Creed, the British artist, was standing in the Park Avenue Armory’s 55,000-square-foot drill hall one day last week when the curator Tom Eccles turned to him with a question. The two were watching a short film from Mr. Creed’s new “Mouth” series, which will be the centerpiece of a retrospective that opens on Wednesday. The film, projected far larger than life, shows a distinguished-looking woman — the artist’s mother — opening her mouth in slow motion to reveal something white on her tongue.

headline: Good Samaritan Helps Boy Survive ‘Internal Decapitation’ in Idaho Car Crash

headline: How to Zip Through Airport Security

While signing up for T.S.A. Precheck, a program that makes preflight risk assessments, is the most common piece of advice to fliers looking to shorten their waits, there are other ways, according to Michael Holtz, the owner of SmartFlyer, a global travel consultancy specializing in airfare. Below, he shares his tips for speeding through airport screening.

headline: Celebrating Robby Müller, Who Created Look of Indie Film Classics

lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Anyone familiar with the movies of Wim Wenders, Jim Jarmusch or Lars von Trier knows Robby Müller’s work, even if they can’t immediately say why. As director of photography, Mr. Müller, a Dutch cinematographer, created an enduring visual palette for such independent classics as Mr. Wenders’s “Paris, Texas,” Mr. Jarmusch’s “Down By Law” and Mr. von Trier’s “Breaking the Waves.”

headline: 1916: Lord Kitchener Mourned
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'GREAT BRITAIN', 'Ships and Shipping', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In June 1916, Lord Kitchener Mourned.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The people of England who are today [June 7] in mourning for Lord Kitchener realize that their grief is shared by the Empire and by their Allies, while among the countless messages of condolence and high tribute to the memory of the great Field-Marshal and Minister of War are many from America and from other neutral countries the world over. Chief among such messages is a telegram, which was received by the King yesterday from M. Poincaré, the French President. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 8, 1916

headline: Review: A ‘Eugene Onegin’ That Fills In Tchaikovsky’s Blanks
abstract: The new production at the Garsington, directed by Michael Boyd, follows a general rule that the best way to do ‘Onegin’ is with simple, spare transparency.
lead_paragraph: STOKENCHURCH, England — Tchaikovsky’s opera “Eugene Onegin” is a story of two lives haunted by youthful miscalculation and a third wiped out in the process. It’s no laughing matter. But the tragedy is lightly told, with Russo-French refinement rather than Italian sobs. And last weekend’s new staging to open the season at the Garsington Opera — one of Britain’s fashionable country-house opera fixtures — followed a general rule that the best way to do it is with simple, spare transparency.

headline: Aging, but Still Working, in Singapore
abstract: The city-state already has the world’s longest working hours. Soon, it’ll have the longest working lives, too.
lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — The food courts in the basements of shopping malls and the ubiquitous “hawker centers,” covered markets where scores of stall-holders sell cooked food, are a mainstay of eating out in Singapore. At one of my regular lunch spots, I watch the cleaners diligently tidy away the trays. They scrape leftovers into bins and wipe the tables and floors with disinfectant.

headline: Dorothy Parker’s Obituary
abstract: Dorothy Parker never met a contemporary she couldn't skewer. Here’s her obituary.
lead_paragraph: Dorothy Parker never met a contemporary she couldn't skewer. Here’s her obituary.

headline: Chocolates for a Beer Lover
abstract: This assortment of truffles is filled with craft beers from Oregon.
lead_paragraph: Chocolate truffles that mimic the bottle caps from four Oregon craft breweries deliver fillings flavored with the beers they represent. The tastes of the beers come through, especially for the Widmer Brothers Hefeweizen and the Full Sail IPA: Moonstruck Oregon Craft Brewers Collection, 12 pieces, $30; 20 pieces of a single flavor, $50; moonstruckchocolate.com.

headline: Paul Ryan Calls Donald Trump’s Attack on Judge ‘Racist,’ but Still Backs Him
abstract: Donald Trump’s attack on a Hispanic-American federal judge was “the textbook definition of a racist comment,” Mr. Ryan said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan, the nation’s highest-ranking Republican, on Tuesday called Donald J. Trump’s remarks about a Latino judge “racist,” an extraordinary indictment that generated a fresh wave of criticism and panic from other Republicans. By the end of the day, Mr. Trump was forced into a rare moment of damage control and said that his words had been “misconstrued.”

headline: New Actress-Inspired Lipsticks
abstract: The makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury turned to her clients as muse for a new collection.
lead_paragraph: The beloved celebrity makeup artist Charlotte Tilbury’s new collection of lipsticks — in glowy shades from pale nude to retro coral to rich mulberry — are each named after a different woman she works with, from Helena Bonham Carter to Nicole Kidman, and each come with a square, angled tip for the most precise application.

headline: A Chef’s Favorite Fishmonger Now Sells to the Public
abstract: F. Rozzo & Sons has teamed up with an online retailer to deliver fish direct.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago, I walked into the F. Rozzo & Sons storefront on Ninth Avenue because chefs like André Soltner of Lutèce had lauded the quality of the fish. There was not a fish in sight, and I was told it was wholesale only. That policy has changed. Under the direction of Louis Rozzo, whose Neapolitan grandfather started the company in 1900 and bought the building in 1905, F. Rozzo & Sons occasionally accommodated a retail customer. But now they have started selling a limited array of seafood across the country. They are working with FoodyDirect in Menlo Park, Calif., an online resource that ships food from a long list of purveyors. I ordered wild king salmon and cod, and like most of the choices, they were available only as four seven-ounce fillets. They were shipped overnight and came to my doorstep on time, excellently fresh: F. Rozzo & Sons at foodydirect.com.

headline: The Eternally Quotable Dorothy Parker
abstract: Dorothy Parker was famous for her bons mots. Here are some of our favorites.
lead_paragraph: Dorothy Parker was famous for her bons mots. Here are some of our favorites.

headline: Meryl Streep Does a Number on Donald Trump at Public Theater’s Gala
abstract: Ms. Streep impersonated Mr. Trump, pursed lips and braggadocio-inflected voice and all, in a number with Christine Baranski.
lead_paragraph: At the moment that Hillary Clinton was all but clinching the Democratic nomination for president, Meryl Streep was on a stage in Central Park, impersonating Donald J. Trump.

headline: 1966: Bonn-Paris Pact Uncertain
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In June 1966, Bonn-Paris Pact Uncertain.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The final outcome was uncertain today [June 7] as NATO foreign ministers struggled to find a compromise on negotiating procedures to keep French troops in West Germany.

headline: The Spanish Town That Runs on Twitter
abstract: Jun, on the outskirts of Granada and with a population of 3,500, has turned to the social network to help the town provide many public services.
lead_paragraph: JUN, Spain — When José Antonio Rodríguez Salas’s daughter, Martina, was born in April, he — like many proud new parents — turned to social media to share the news.

headline: The Challenges of Closing the Digital Divide
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Mignon Clyburn, an F.C.C. commissioner, discusses the agency’s efforts to bring broadband to low-income individuals and rural areas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — United States history is marked by modernization efforts aimed at leaving no one behind. In the 1930s, it was lighting up farmsteads with electricity. In the 1950s, it was paving highways to every town. Today, the federal government is trying to bring broadband, which it considers a utility, to an estimated 33 percent of residents who don’t have the service.

headline: South Sudan Needs Truth, Not Trials
abstract: South Sudan’s leaders argue for a national commission for reconciliation.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ Note: June 11, 2016

headline: Tidal, on Prince’s Birthday, Adds His Albums to Its Catalog
keywords: ['Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The musician, who died of an overdose of the painkiller fentanyl in April, would have turned 58 today.
lead_paragraph: The streaming service Tidal added more than 15 Prince albums to its catalog early Tuesday, on what would have been his 58th birthday.

headline: A Revitalizing Summer Face Mask Recipe — From the Garden
abstract: The horticulture books editor Juree Sondker recently began selling small batches of plant-based serum in Portland, Ore.
lead_paragraph: As an editor of horticulture books at Timber Press in Portland, Ore., for eight years, Juree Sondker learned a thing or two about plants. But she didn’t fully understand their power — until she edited JJ Pursell’s “The Herbal Apothecary.” “I was always interested in taking herbs internally, but I had never thought about their topical uses,” Sondker says. Working with Pursell, a highly regarded naturopath, Sondker got a crash course in foraging and distilling natural remedies to cure everything from muscle aches to insomnia. The postscript to completing the manuscript: Sondker applied her extensive knowledge of the plant kingdom into Horticulture Skin Care, her own beauty company, which launched recently. Her first offering is Plant Potion, a natural serum composed of 14 different essential oils to firm and hydrate the skin.

headline: Online Culture’s Depths and Heights
abstract: A closer look at the state of the internet, from the question of empathy to digital games that spill into the real world.
lead_paragraph: By turns toxic and tantalizing, the digital cultures spurred by the internet have become an endless source of fascination.

headline: An Outlier on a Big Soccer Stage, Haiti Is Eager to Take Its Shot at Brazil
abstract: Ranked 74th in the world by FIFA, Haiti will take on the five-time world champions for the first time in the Copa América on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Haiti’s national soccer team botched several scoring chances Saturday in Seattle, lost a 1-0 heartbreaker to Peru in the Copa América Centenario, and then boarded a 2,500-mile flight to Orlando, Fla. — where mighty Brazil awaits on Wednesday night in a probable mismatch.

headline: La Sirena
abstract: Perpetual motion at the chef Mario Batali’s latest restaurant in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: Perpetual motion at the chef Mario Batali’s latest restaurant in Chelsea.

headline: At La Sirena, the Pleasures and Pitfalls of a Big Restaurant
abstract: Mario Batali’s new place in Chelsea gives the main courses layers of complexity that go beyond standard trattoria cooking.
lead_paragraph: Somebody’s always on the move at La Sirena.

headline: Fighting Lyme Disease in the Genes of Nantucket’s Mice
abstract: Residents there heard a proposal Monday from an M.I.T. scientist to use genetically engineered mice to stop the spread of the tick-borne disease.
lead_paragraph: Can genetically engineered mice save Nantucket from the scourge of Lyme disease?

headline: ‘UnREAL’ Season 2 Premiere: We Don’t Solve Problems
abstract: New suitor, new season, same great show.
lead_paragraph: Early in the Season 2 premiere, Rachel pulls up to the “Everlasting” house with Darius, this season’s suitor. He balks. And so Rachel does what she does so well — she goes hunting, looking for anything that will bring him in line: resentment, Darius’s embarrassment at participating, his mother’s opinion of it all. Finally, she offers this line: “This does not make you who you are.”

headline: Jewish Woman Detained for Taking Torah Scroll to Western Wall in Jerusalem
abstract: The woman, Lesley Sachs, the executive director of Women of the Wall, was held for a few hours after she protested restrictions on women at the holy site.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli police briefly detained a leader of a Jewish women’s rights group on Tuesday for bringing a Torah scroll to the Western Wall, signaling a resumption of the battle over rituals at the holy site here.

headline: Trump’s New Handlers Have a Tough Task Ahead
abstract: Though Donald J. Trump has hired veteran strategists to win over a broader base of voters, they may be thwarted by their candidate’s volatility.
lead_paragraph: As Republican candidates began televised debates last summer, the Republican campaign strategist Mike Murphy invented a term for Donald J. Trump: “zombie front-runner.”

headline: David Bouley Plans to Retool His Restaurants, and Himself
abstract: At 63, the influential TriBeCa chef will shut Bouley and reopen it in a smaller space with a mission of health.
lead_paragraph: David Bouley wanted to be clear about this, so he reached for a Sharpie and a pad of paper the size of a painter’s easel. “I’m going to write it all down right here,” he said.

headline: Assad Vows to Take Back Syria
abstract: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria promised Parliament that the armed conflicts in the country would continue as long as the Islamic State posed a threat.
lead_paragraph: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria promised Parliament that the armed conflicts in the country would continue as long as the Islamic State posed a threat.

headline: The Metallic Muse: Fashion’s Sci-Fi Obsession
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Metals and Minerals', 'Robots and Robotics']
abstract: From metal-clad runway models to video-game heroines as muses, the future is more current than ever.
lead_paragraph: Not since Goldfinger ordered the gilt body of his double-crossing gal pal dumped in James Bond’s bed has the metalized body had such a cultural moment. The intergalactic sheen of the inorganic seems omnipresent, tinging everything from eyes, lips and nails to gilded temporary tattoos, cutaneous body adornments, to even the most ubiquitous handheld device, the rose gold iPhone 6s. Metal-mania may have reached a saturation point at the recent Met Gala, where glittering guests were greeted by a phalanx of chrome-helmeted, silver-lashed cyber-models. Not to be outdone, many of the partiers — resplendent in spangled Balmain spacesuits, shiny ear cuffs and chromed accouterments — seemed on the verge of some metallurgic transmogrification themselves.

headline: A Populist Electoral Upset in Rome
abstract: Corruption and other failures give the Five Star Movement a chance to win the mayor’s office.
lead_paragraph: With millions voting in some 1,300 mayoral elections in Italy on Sunday, the biggest news came out of Rome, where voters, fed up with appallingly corrupt and ineffective government, handed a first-round victory to the anti-establishment Five Star Movement candidate Virginia Raggi. Ms. Raggi’s performance could further undermine support for Prime Minister Matteo Renzi’s center-left Democratic Party, and give a lift to the populist wave of discontent that is sweeping Europe.

headline: NBC’s Savannah Guthrie Says She Is Pregnant and Won’t Go to Olympics Because of Zika
abstract: Ms. Guthrie, a co-anchor of the “Today” program, says she will avoid going to Rio de Janeiro because of concerns about the virus.
lead_paragraph: The “Today” anchor Savannah Guthrie said on Tuesday that she was pregnant and, as a result, would not participate in NBC’s coverage of the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro because of concerns about the Zika virus.

headline: Ryan Disavows Trump’s Remarks on Judge
abstract: Speaker Paul D. Ryan called Donald J. Trump’s comments about a Hispanic-American judge “racist,” but said there was more “common ground” with him than with his presidential rival.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Paul D. Ryan called Donald J. Trump’s comments about a Hispanic-American judge “racist,” but said there was more “common ground” with him than with his presidential rival.

headline: A Riding Program for Disabled Children Finds Stables It Can Call Home
abstract: GallopNYC, which began 11 years ago teaching riding skills to children with physical and intellectual disabilities, will expand with a move to Howard Beach, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Luis Rodriguez, 5, who has autism, cannot speak and walks awkwardly on his toes. But on a recent spring afternoon he sat perfectly astride a blond pony in a barn in Forest Hills, Queens, and showed everyone how he felt, erupting into applause at his accomplishment.

headline: Tribune Publishing Vote Hands Board a Rebuke
abstract: More than 40 percent of shareholders withheld votes for Tribune’s slate of directors, virtually unheard of when proxy advisers support the candidates.
lead_paragraph: Tribune Publishing’s board gets an A-plus in testing the patience of shareholders. More than 40 percent withheld votes for the eight directors put forward by the company, publisher of The Los Angeles Times. That is virtually unheard of, especially when proxy advisers like Institutional Shareholder Services favor the candidates.

headline: Daniel Rose Makes His American Debut at Le Coucou
abstract: Beach Bistro 96, Chikarashi, Hey Hey Canteen, Indie Fresh and Teremok are also among new restaurants in the city.
lead_paragraph: Le Coucou White brick, glass, impressive chandeliers and a sleek, wide-open state-of-the-art kitchen provide the stage for the American debut of Daniel Rose. The Chicago native built his reputation in Paris at his restaurants, Spring and La Bourse et La Vie. In partnership with the prolific restaurateur Stephen Starr, he is taking on New York, where French cooking is enjoying a renaissance. French dishes include pigs’ feet with caviar, pike quenelles, fish stew bourride and poached chicken for two to four. But the other day, Mr. Rose was sampling cheeses from Vermont and California. “I’m trying to find American-made products that remind me of France,” he said. His pastry chef, Daniel Skurnick, is working on an updated version of riz au lait impératrice, the classic glazed rice dessert rarely seen these days. (Opens Monday): 138 Lafayette Street (Howard Street), 212-271-4252, lecoucou.com.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Road to the Democratic Nomination
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s 14-month campaign to become the presumptive Democratic nominee, the first woman in U.S. history to achieve that from a major party.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s 14-month campaign to become the presumptive Democratic nominee, the first woman in U.S. history to achieve that from a major party.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Long, Grueling Quest
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Blacks', 'Black People', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: As a politician’s wife, first lady, senator and secretary of state — and as a two-time candidate for president — Hillary Clinton has continually redefined the role of women in American politics.
lead_paragraph: If there was a single moment that captured what would carry Hillary Clinton to the 2016 Democratic nomination, it came not during her sun-splashed campaign kickoff in New York last June, or in any of her speeches celebrating hard-fought primary victories over Senator Bernie Sanders.

headline: Guy Hands Resumes Legal Fight With Citigroup Over EMI Deal
abstract: Mr. Hands, the founder of the private equity firm Terra Firma, claims that Citigroup executives misled him before a deal for EMI in 2007.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nearly a decade ago, Guy Hands, the British founder of the European private equity firm Terra Firma Capital Partners, made a big bet on the storied music group EMI.

headline: The Look
abstract: One man’s sad little fashion evolution.
lead_paragraph: Congratulations: You settled on a look. It’s been a long time coming, from the thrift-shop bowling shirts of your college days, through the failed sartorial experiments of your late-night years. Now that you’ve calmed down a little, you have a pair of slightly expensive European jeans, a few pairs of pants that could be called slacks, 12 button-down shirts with unfrayed collars and four blazers from medium-level designers found on a discount site a year after they left the department store. You feel all right with the look, on the whole. You’re presentable. Nobody stares. But deep down, you know you resemble a magazine photographer from 1981.

headline: Can Driverless Be Flawless?
abstract: A reader has some doubts about self-driving cars.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Wizard Comes to the Stage: ‘Harry Potter and the Cursed Child’ Begins Previews in London
abstract: J.K. Rowling’s Potter saga, in its latest incarnation, comes to the Palace Theater amid much anticipation about the characters’ fates.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The eighth installment of the Harry Potter series was presented on Tuesday evening at the Palace Theater here. Neither a book nor a film, it was a play, “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child.” But whatever the medium, the Potter saga continued with unabated interest: fans dressed in Hogwarts costumes, curiosity about the fate of long-beloved characters and the allure of magic.

headline: 7 Tips for Avoiding a Wedding Toast Disaster
abstract: Saying a few words at the wedding reception? Don’t worry, it should go well — if you follow a few simple guidelines.
lead_paragraph: Click here to read more on how to craft the perfect wedding toast.

abstract: Things can go terribly astray when raising a glass, but so much can go right, too.
lead_paragraph: Click here for tips, and videos of terrible on-screen toasts.

headline: F.B.I. Steps Up Use of Stings in ISIS Cases
abstract: A sharp rise in the number of undercover operations, once considered a last resort, has come with little public or congressional scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. has significantly increased its use of stings in terrorism cases, employing agents and informants to pose as jihadists, bomb makers, gun dealers or online “friends” in hundreds of investigations into Americans suspected of supporting the Islamic State, records and interviews show.

headline: Bob Kerrey in Vietnam
abstract: A former Vietnamese ambassador says Fulbright University Vietnam is not the right place for the former senator.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Builders Pierce California’s Environmental Shield With New Weapon: The Ballot
abstract: The state’s ballot initiative process allows city officials to approve projects without a vote by residents, bypassing environmental laws and speeding construction.
lead_paragraph: MORENO VALLEY, Calif. — Once heralded as a vital check on corporate influence over government, California’s ballot initiative system — which allows residents to propose laws and approve them by popular vote — has been used to sharply cut property taxes and to enact the country’s first medical marijuana law.

headline: Donald Trump Doesn’t Listen
abstract: Mr. Trump seems unwilling to take advice from anyone. If he becomes president, that will be a big problem.
lead_paragraph: “My primary consultant is myself,” Donald Trump said back in March when asked whom he turns to for foreign policy advice. This turns out to be his approach to pretty much everything.

headline: Desert Art Installation Is Defaced
abstract: Ugo Rondinone’s work, “Seven Magic Mountains,” was hit by vandals over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Vandals with spray-paint struck a towering new artwork that was recently opened to the public in the desert outside of Las Vegas, forcing the site around the sculptures to be closed on Monday and Tuesday so the graffiti could be cleaned off, officials with the Nevada Museum of Art in Reno said.

headline: Mourning Bretagne, a Search Dog and Symbol of 9/11 Heroism
abstract: The golden retriever worked 12-hour shifts in the aftermath of attacks with her handler, Denise Corliss, searching for survivors among the rubble at the World Trade Center site.
lead_paragraph: Bretagne, a golden retriever believed to be the last surviving search-and-rescue dog to brave the rubble of the World Trade Center site, looking for survivors of the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, died at a veterinarian’s office in Cypress, Tex., on Monday. She was 16 years old.

lead_paragraph: This Sunday, the Tony Awards will honor the best of Broadway and likely deliver many of the biggest prizes to “Hamilton,” the Public Theater’s biggest hit since “A Chorus Line” had its debut in 1975.

headline: Longtime U.S. Prosecutor to Join Covington & Burling
abstract: The prosecutor, Arlo Devlin-Brown, went after Wall Street giants like SAC Capital before leading the United States attorney’s public corruption unit.
lead_paragraph: Arlo Devlin-Brown, a veteran federal prosecutor in Manhattan who led a string of prominent Wall Street cases and more recently oversaw the prosecutions of two of New York State’s most powerful politicians, is departing for the private sector.

lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. became the latest victim in a string of recent high-profile Twitter hoaxes and hackings after its verified account sent a series of tweets saying that Roger Goodell, the league’s commissioner, had died.

abstract: “How very proud I am of my party,” a Democrat writes. Another reader objects to The Times’s coverage: “The superdelegates who support her have not voted.”

headline: Defiant Bashar al-Assad Vows to Retake ‘Every Inch’ of Syria
abstract: Syria’s president offered no hint of compromise in a national speech, dimming hope for peace talks and rejecting the West’s efforts to provide aid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Syria’s president promised to retake “every inch” of the country from his foes on Tuesday in a defiant speech that appeared to reject the humanitarian relief effort and peaceful transition of power that the United States, Russia and more than a dozen other nations have pressed for since last fall.

headline: 5 Catalan Cities Step Away From Spain With New Jewish History Network
abstract: The cities in Catalonia have decided to withdraw from a Spanish network of cities with historic Jewish medieval quarters to create their own network.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Catalans may still be weighing whether to quit Spain, but Catalan cities with Jewish histories have already made up their minds. Quietly, last month, they decided to withdraw from a Spanish network of cities with historic Jewish medieval quarters.

headline: 5 Key Factors to the New York Prison Escape, in a Killer’s Words
abstract: David Sweat, one of two convicted murderers who broke out of the Clinton Correctional Facility last year, spoke at length to officials about what helped the plot succeed.
lead_paragraph: By the time David Sweat spoke to investigators from the office of New York State’s inspector general last year, he had spent three weeks on the run, been shot by a state trooper, and was facing the prospect of spending the rest of his life in solitary confinement for pulling off a Hollywood-ready prison break that riveted the country.

headline: A Rise in Mediterranean Deaths
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The founder of the Migrant Offshore Aid Station (MOAS), Christopher Catrambone, spoke about the rising death toll in the central Mediterranean, driven by migrant drownings.
lead_paragraph: The founder of the Migrant Offshore Aid Station (MOAS), Christopher Catrambone, spoke about the rising death toll in the central Mediterranean, driven by migrant drownings.

headline: Société Générale Is Ordered to Pay Trader Who Almost Ruined It
abstract: Jérôme Kerviel persuaded a French labor tribunal that he should not have been fired for his trades, which nearly brought about the demise of the bank.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the eight years since he was fired by the French bank Société Générale, Jérôme Kerviel has never denied making 50 billion euros’ worth of unauthorized trades or committing forgery and fraud to cover them up.

headline: Salty Surprises in the Food You Eat
abstract: The government has created guidelines to reduce salt in the food we eat. Here are places where you may be picking up salt in your diet that you may not have realized.
lead_paragraph: The government has created guidelines to reduce salt in the food we eat. Here are places where you may be picking up salt in your diet that you may not have realized.
