headline: In the Ring He Was Ali, but in the Newspapers He Was Still Clay
abstract: The New York Times and other newspapers did not begin to regularly call the fighter Muhammad Ali until 1970, six years after he changed his name.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after he defeated Sonny Liston to win the heavyweight title in February 1964, Cassius Clay changed his name to Muhammad Ali.

headline: Poignant Pictures That Capture the Humanity in Historical Moments
abstract: Burk Uzzle has photographed everything from Woodstock and Martin Luther King Jr.’s funeral to state fairs and motorcycle rallies.
lead_paragraph: Burk Uzzle has photographed everything from Woodstock and Martin Luther King Jr.’s funeral to state fairs and motorcycle rallies.

headline: Cleaner Political Donations
abstract: Elected officials should take one important step to help eliminate a form of “legalized bribery,” the Greenburgh (N.Y.) town supervisor says.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cracks Appear in Merger of Williams and Energy Transfer Equity
abstract: Slumping oil prices have spurred questions about the deal, and Williams now says it expects to cut its dividend if the sale goes through.
lead_paragraph: A supposedly ironclad $22 billion pipeline deal is showing some cracks. The Williams Companies said on Wednesday that it expected to cut its dividend if its sale to its rival, Energy Transfer Equity, fell through. Despite Energy Transfer’s attempts to renegotiate or wriggle out of the merger, Williams has held firm until now. The payout warning may be a tactic, but the target now seems to be admitting the possibility of failure.

headline: Rafael Nadal Withdraws From Wimbledon
abstract: Nadal will not play Wimbledon as he continues to recover from a left wrist injury that forced him out of the French Open after the second round.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Nadal announced Thursday that he would not play Wimbledon as he continues to recover from a left wrist injury, which also forced him to withdraw from the French Open.

headline: How Safe Is Your City From a Flood?
abstract: The mayor of New Orleans, a FEMA official and New York City experts discuss the problem of flooding.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sanders to Meet with Clinton
abstract: The Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders announced that he will talk with Hillary Clinton soon about making sure Donald J. Trump does not become president.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders announced that he will talk with Hillary Clinton soon about making sure Donald J. Trump does not become president.

headline: ‘The Witch’ and Five Hedy Lamarr Films Come to Disc, Casting Spells
abstract: Robert Eggers’s horror film about a rural Puritan family is released, as are 1930s and ’40s offerings starring Lamarr, the Viennese beauty and inventor.
lead_paragraph: An isolated, deeply religious settler family in the 1630s is destroyed by occult forces in “The Witch” — an independent first feature written and directed by Robert Eggers and one of the most intelligent American horror films of recent years.

headline: At Film Forum, Hailing Women Behind the Camera
abstract: The “Genre Is a Woman” festival features the diverse work of women as directors, from the pioneers of early cinema to modern day.
lead_paragraph: While savage inequities persist when it comes to opportunities for women as directors in Hollywood, there have been exceptions over the decades, if far too few. So thank Film Forum for its series “Genre Is a Woman,” continuing through Thursday, June 16, which honors auteurs who paved the way. Pioneers include the silent film director Alice Guy Blaché — her “Babies From Cabbages” (1902), “The Detective’s Dog” (circa 1912) and “The Pit and the Pendulum” (1913) screen on Sunday — and the indie favorite Kelly Reichardt, whose 2011 western “Meek’s Cutoff” screens on multiple days.

headline: Sky-High Prices for Broadway Hits Like ‘Hamilton’
abstract: Responses to Lin-Manuel Miranda’s Op-Ed article on how “ticket bots” are depriving the public of a chance to get affordable tickets.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Obama Endorses Hillary Clinton, and Urges Democrats to Unite
abstract: With Senator Bernie Sanders still in the race, the president said the stakes were too high to let divisions stand in the way of defeating Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama told Senator Bernie Sanders in an Oval Office meeting on Thursday to channel the energy of his presidential campaign’s millions of supporters behind Hillary Clinton, and said that Mr. Sanders would play a central role in shaping the Democratic agenda if he did.

headline: ‘Central Intelligence,’ Buddy Cops and the Art of Mismatched Pairs
abstract: Dwayne Johnson and Kevin Hart join an action-comedy genre with a rich tradition that includes “48 Hours” and “Lethal Weapon.”
lead_paragraph: Here’s how to tell if you’re watching a buddy-cop movie. Has a cop on foot flagged down a civilian to borrow her car? (“Police business!”) Is there a bluesy soundtrack? What about a bureaucrat absolutely losing his mind about the off-the-book antics of a renegade officer? If the answer is always yes, then you could be watching one of four “Lethal Weapon” movies or three “Rush Hour” installments or maybe even “Turner & Hooch.”

headline: Iceland Carbon Dioxide Storage Project Locks Away Gas, and Fast
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Capture and Sequestration']
abstract: Researchers report success in an experiment that keeps a gas tied to global warming out of the atmosphere permanently.
lead_paragraph: For years, scientists and others concerned about climate change have been talking about the need for carbon capture and sequestration.

headline: How Keeping Up Appearances Ruined a Former Dallas Banker
abstract: S.E.C. and criminal complaints paint Thomas C. Davis, considered a pillar of the business community, as a man in “desperate” financial straits.
lead_paragraph: At age 67, Thomas C. Davis should be enjoying all the perks of a long and distinguished career at the pinnacle of Wall Street and the Texas business elite. These include golfing at the prestigious Dallas Country Club and Preston Trail Golf Club, where he was a member; trips to Las Vegas and golf tournaments on the private jet he co-owned; and fractional ownership of two professional sports teams, the Texas Rangers and the Dallas Stars.

headline: Muhammad Ali Was Her First, and Greatest, Love
abstract: For 30 years, friends said in interviews, Lonnie Ali was not only Muhammad Ali’s doting wife, but also a hard-nosed M.B.A. who managed his affairs.
lead_paragraph: The pretty woman walked into the Ringside Cafe in Louisville, Ky., and approached the three-time heavyweight boxing champion, who led her to a quiet corner. The restaurant’s owner, John Ramsey, surreptitiously watched as Muhammad Ali flirted shamelessly with the pretty woman, who six years earlier had become his fourth wife. On that day in 1992, Ramsey learned all he needed to know about Lonnie Ali by observing the effect she had on his longtime friend.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘The Conjuring 2’
abstract: James Wan narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: James Wan narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: James Wan Narrates a Scene From ‘The Conjuring 2’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence in the film.
lead_paragraph: More possessions, more sinister creatures and more Patrick Wilson and Vera Farmiga are in “The Conjuring 2,” which is based on the paranormal investigations of Ed and Lorraine Warren. In this scene, Ed conducts an interview with Janet Hodgson (Madison Wolfe), a young girl who may be possessed. The film’s director James Wan recently discussed the sequence. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: ‘Shut Down the Presses as Soon as Possible’
abstract: A stop-press order is usually not as dramatic as it is depicted in the movies. The drama is elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David W. Dunlap, a Metro reporter, looks back at some of The Times’s  stop-press orders.

headline: Belmont Stakes 2016: Here’s Who We Think Will Win
abstract: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times weigh in on the contenders for the 148th running of the Belmont Stakes.
lead_paragraph: The horses for the 148th running of the Belmont Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Eric Donovan of the New York Racing Association.

headline: Scientists Find Genes That Let These Bees Reproduce Without Males
abstract: In a subspecies of honey bees from South Africa, female workers can escape a queen’s control and produce offspring of their own. Scientists say a gene explains how.
lead_paragraph: The female Cape bee is a renegade. She breaks all kinds of rules and disregards orders. In this isolated subspecies of honey bees from South Africa, female worker bees can escape their queen’s control, take over other colonies and reproduce asexually — with no need for males. Scientists identified the genes most likely to have instigated this unusually powerful worker bee behavior, according to a study published Thursday in PLOS Genetics.

headline: United Nations Chief Exposes Limits to His Authority by Citing Saudi Threat
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Children and Childhood', 'International Relations']
abstract: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said he removed a Saudi-led coalition that is bombing Yemen from a list of children’s rights violators after the Saudis threatened to withhold funding.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations secretary general is supposed to answer to every nation on earth — and no nation at all.

headline: Brexit Vote Gives Tabloids Chance to Unleash Anti-European Tendencies
abstract: The hostility of some papers to the European Union is a problem for Prime Minister David Cameron, who is trying to persuade Britons to vote to remain.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britons could lose control of their coastline. Their country could be scrapped or merged with France. And a nation in which tea-making is a daily ritual faces the prospect of a ban on its kettles.

headline: Rockettes Tradition, Set Free by a ‘Banshee Artist’
abstract: The choreographer Mia Michaels springs from Fox’s “So You Think You Can Dance” (and more) to the latest Radio City Music Hall spectacular.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to feel small in Radio City Music Hall. On a recent weekday afternoon, at a tech rehearsal for the Rockettes’ “New York Spectacular,” the world’s largest proscenium arch dwarfed the dancers, who looked less glamazon than usual in their practice leggings and tank tops. But at the soundboard, the choreographer Mia Michaels seemed in no way intimidated. “It’s so cool to have Radio City as my playground,” she whispered. “It’s a really big playground!”

headline: Viacom Rumblings: Stacking the Board and Maybe Remerging With CBS
abstract: An effort to replace some directors is said to be underway, and there may be a possibility of recombining Viacom and CBS, which split in 2006.
lead_paragraph: National Amusements, the theater chain through which Sumner M. Redstone controls his $40 billion empire, is preparing to replace a handful of directors on the Viacom board, a move that is expected to serve as a prelude to the ouster of the company’s embattled chief executive.

headline: The Ninth Circuit’s Firearms Ruling
abstract: A Federal appeals court ruled that the Second Amendment of the Constitution does not guarantee the right of gun-owners to carry concealed weapons in public, upholding a California law restricting who may be granted a concealed-carry permit.
lead_paragraph: A Federal appeals court ruled that the Second Amendment of the Constitution does not guarantee the right of gun-owners to carry concealed weapons in public, upholding a California law restricting who may be granted a concealed-carry permit.

headline: 2nd Amendment Does Not Guarantee Right to Carry Concealed Guns, Court Rules
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Firearms', 'Constitution (US)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A federal appeals court in San Francisco upheld a California law that imposes stringent conditions on who may be granted a concealed-carry permit.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled Thursday that the Second Amendment of the Constitution does not guarantee the right of gun owners to carry concealed weapons in public places, upholding a California law that imposes stringent conditions on who may be granted a concealed-carry permit.

headline: Freddie Gray Died From ‘Rough Ride,’ Prosecutors Assert
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The murder trial of Caesar R. Goodson Jr., the police officer charged in the death of Mr. Gray, got underway in Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Freddie Gray died after a “rough ride” in a police van, prosecutors here said on Thursday, laying out for the first time their murder case against the officer who drove the transport wagon in which Mr. Gray, a 25-year-old black man, suffered the “diving-type injury” that broke his neck and later killed him.

headline: Owl Hugs Man*
abstract: *An expert said, “I would be surprised if it had anything to do with its reaction to its handler.” Still, the internet swooned at photos showing a great horned owl embracing a wildlife volunteer in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: They call Doug Pojeky the bird whisperer.

headline: Expelled Basketball Player Sues Yale
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Basketball (College)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)']
abstract: Jack Montague, who was expelled in February after a university committee concluded he had raped a fellow student, accused the university of a “deeply flawed process.”
lead_paragraph: The Yale basketball player who was expelled in February after a university committee found that he had raped a fellow student sued the university on Thursday, accusing it of a “deeply flawed process.”

headline: Netanyahu Confirms Third Suspect Arrest
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said another person had been arrested following a deadly shooting in Tel Aviv, and he described other security measures put in place.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said another person had been arrested following a deadly shooting in Tel Aviv, and he described other security measures put in place.

headline: Jack Montague Statement and Lawsuit Against Yale
abstract: The Yale basketball player who was expelled in February after a university committee found he had raped a fellow student has sued the university, accusing it of a “deeply flawed process.”
lead_paragraph: The Yale basketball player who was expelled in February after a university committee found he had raped a fellow student has sued the university, accusing it of a “deeply flawed process.”

headline: Delay Pregnancy in Areas With Zika, W.H.O. Suggests
abstract: The advice affects millions of couples in 46 countries across Latin America and the Caribbean where Zika transmission is occurring or expected.
lead_paragraph: People living in areas where the Zika virus is circulating should consider delaying pregnancy to avoid having babies with birth defects, the World Health Organization has concluded.

headline: Shabab Attack in Somalia Sets Off Predawn Gun Battle
abstract: Militants stormed an African Union base after an explosive-laden car rammed into the gates, and scores of soldiers and militants were killed in the gun battle that followed.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A suicide bomber rammed an explosive-laden car into the gates of an African Union base in central Somalia on Thursday, setting off a predawn gun battle between militants and African Union soldiers.

headline: Tighter Rules on Money Transfers Put Squeeze on Businesses
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Remittances', 'Small Business', 'Money Laundering', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Banks are refusing to do business with money transmitters, closing or freezing accounts over concerns about money laundering and regulatory scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: For years, Fernando Lopez’s storefront money-transfer business in Atlantic City was a place where local residents could wire money to family and friends abroad. But that business, Interamericana Express, which handled a lot of transmittals to Mexico, is dwindling as banks and regulators take a stricter view of cross-border money transfers.

headline: Review: In ‘Warcraft,’ Orcs of a Different Domain, Fighting With Heart
abstract: Directed by Duncan Jones, this cinematic extension of the brand that began as a video game features invading orcs, embattled humans and much pummeling.
lead_paragraph: Probably the best way to experience “Warcraft,” a generally amusing and sometimes visually arresting absurdity, is stoned. If watching the big screen through a cannabis cloud isn’t your idea of a good movie time, though, I suggest that you do what I did and just go with the incoherent flow. You may not grasp who the Bluto-like creatures with simian arms and woolly mammoth tusks are or why they seem permanently engorged with rage. But there’s more to movies than narrative coherency, as anyone who has sampled the cinema of Michael Bay or certain art films well knows.

headline: Review: Help Me, Obi-Wan Kenobi
abstract: “The World According to Star Wars” by Cass R. Sunstein is at once vast and sketchy, sometimes condescending, and explains too much and too little.
lead_paragraph: Cass R. Sunstein is a professor at Harvard Law School, a former official in the Obama administration, an expert in behavioral science and constitutional jurisprudence, and the author of many books, including the best-selling (and somewhat controversial) “Nudge.” He is, in other words, a formidably accomplished intellectual, an authority on matters that lie beyond the ken of most ordinary citizens.

headline: Review: Eric Comstock Waxes Worldly Wise in Broadway Songs at Pangea
abstract: With funny selections like “Home Sweet Heaven,” Mr. Comstock also projects a wistful poignancy.
lead_paragraph: Witty, name-dropping list songs dripping with innuendo by the likes of Noël Coward and Cole Porter are a treasured subgenre of Broadway musicals. One of the funniest and more obscure, slyly performed by the singer and pianist Eric Comstock at Pangea on Tuesday evening, is “Home Sweet Heaven” from the 1964 musical “High Spirits,” adapted from Coward’s play “Blithe Spirit.”

headline: Review: ‘Call Her Applebroog,’ Beth B’s Portrait of a Still-Vital Artist
abstract: Beth B, Ida Applebroog’s daughter, takes an intimate look at the artist’s drawings, paintings and emphatic engagement with others.
lead_paragraph: “Call Her Applebroog,” a brief feature about the inventive, provocative artist Ida Applebroog, is less a documentary than a love letter. A love letter that conveys its affection and respect via a particular kind of discretion.

headline: Election 2016: 10 Ways for Students to Stay Engaged This Summer
abstract: Though our lesson plans will be on vacation until mid-August, election news will continue to dominate the headlines all summer long. Here are a few ways students can keep up with the candidates, campaigns, conventions and controversies — and make their own opinions heard.
lead_paragraph: Though our lesson plans will be on vacation until mid-August, election news will continue to dominate the headlines all summer long.

headline: Biden Calls Victim in Stanford Rape Case a ‘Warrior’
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. wrote that the woman had a “solid steel spine,” and lawmakers read excerpts of her statement on the House floor.
lead_paragraph: The furor surrounding a Stanford rape case extended to the nation’s capital on Thursday: A congresswoman read an excerpt from the victim’s statement on the House floor, a congressman called for the judge to be removed, and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. wrote an open letter to the victim, calling her “a warrior — with a solid steel spine.”

headline: Review: ‘Careful What You Wish For,’ Starring Nick Jonas as a Naïve Teenage Lover
abstract: Elizabeth Allen’s film casts Mr. Jonas as a boy who takes up with the beautiful woman next door in a summer idyll that proves anything but.
lead_paragraph: Nick Jonas, who is 23, made a convincing college student in the television series “Scream Queens” last season, but he makes an exceedingly unconvincing high school student in the wretched “Careful What You Wish For,” a film that tries to be both titillating and suspenseful but is neither.

headline: 2 D.E.A. Workers Convicted Over Ownership of Strip Club in New Jersey
abstract: Glen Glover and David Polos were found guilty of making false statements on security clearance forms.
lead_paragraph: Two longtime employees of the Drug Enforcement Administration were convicted on Thursday of making false statements on security clearance forms about their ownership of a strip club in northern New Jersey.

headline: 3 Exhibitions Where Art Melds With Dance
abstract: Three New York museums are featuring works that catch a dance enthusiast’s eye for what they tell us of dancers and dance itself.
lead_paragraph: How can movement be preserved in immobile form? This contradiction in terms has preoccupied artists for millenniums. (It obsesses choreographers and dancers too. “Motion in stillness, stillness in motion” has been a motto for dance forms as diverse as the ancient traditions of Southeast Asia and the avant-garde choreography of Merce Cunningham.)

headline: Review: In ‘Len and Company,’ a Prickly Pop Producer Finds His Solitude Interrupted
abstract: Rhys Ifans stars as a disaffected former rock star who retreats to the countryside after a meltdown, only to host some surprise guests with concerns of their own.
lead_paragraph: If you’re going to make a movie about a onetime rock star, the man to cast is the Welsh actor Rhys Ifans. Mr. Ifans — who is perhaps best known as Hugh Grant’s shaggy roommate in “Notting Hill” and who, unsurprisingly, is also a past member of the band Super Furry Animals — has just the grizzled, weathered authority required. Tim Godsall’s gentle character study “Len and Company” rests easily on Mr. Ifans’s shoulders.

headline: Stuart Davis: A Little Matisse, a Lot of Jazz, All American
abstract: The pioneering modernist is the focus of a restless, zestful exhibition.
lead_paragraph: In 1908, Henri Matisse tried some damage control. Alarmed that his new work was being dismissed as a provoking joke, he responded no, no, no, the critics had him all wrong: His aim was to create the opposite, a soothing, antidepressant art, the visual equivalent of a well-padded armchair. A few decades later, Stuart Davis, who admired Matisse enough to crib from him, was pitching his own radical art as an embodiment of optimism and pleasure of a particularly American kind.

headline: Review: ‘Germans & Jews,’ a New Generation Continues a Difficult Conversation
abstract: In Janina Quint’s documentary, a group of Jewish and non-Jewish Germans, most of them born after World War II, reckon with the past.
lead_paragraph: Don’t expect simple answers in “Germans & Jews.” Just prepare for formidable questions. Those are the real reasons to see this incisive documentary.

headline: Clinton to Trump on Twitter: ‘Delete Your Account’
abstract: The presumptive Democratic nominee was responding to a tweet from the presumptive Republican nominee, and it resonated on social media.
lead_paragraph: Look, we don’t want to write about every presidential campaign tweet that teeters on the brink of the absurd like a fun-house mirror revealing the political Frankentheater that the entire electorate has collaborated to create, whether actively or by submission.

headline: Review: In ‘Tikkun,’ a Hasidic Student’s Visions Merge With Metaphor
abstract: This feature from the Israeli director Avishai Sivan employs fanciful imagery in dark but often funny ways, without abandoning empathy.
lead_paragraph: A heady, sometimes headlong blend of fable and nightmare, with overtones of David Lynch and Franz Kafka and arresting wide-screen black-and-white images, Avishai Sivan’s second feature, “Tikkun,” is the latest evidence of the vitality of Israeli cinema, which has recently been moving away from politics-inflected realism in wilder, more allegorical directions. It is set within the insular world of Jerusalem’s Hasidic Jews, and also in a dream world of the director’s own devising, a place where faith, skepticism and lust entwine in disturbing and surprising ways.

headline: Review: ‘Genius’ Puts Max Perkins and Thomas Wolfe in a Literary Bromance
abstract: Michael Grandage’s 1930s-era biopic is nostalgia for a supposed golden age of masculine artistic potency.
lead_paragraph: Ostensibly a tale of heroic literary creation — of the volatile collaboration between an undisciplined author and his discerning editor — “Genius” is a dress-up box full of second- and thirdhand notions. Set mainly in a picturesquely brown and smoky Manhattan in the 1930s, it gives the buddy-movie treatment to that wild-man novelist Thomas Wolfe and his buttoned-up red-penciler Maxwell Perkins.

headline: Questions About Suspect’s Identity Circle Human Trafficking Case
keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Extradition', 'Smuggling', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Doubts about the identity of an Eritrean suspect taken into custody were raised within hours of the announcement that an arrest had been made.
lead_paragraph: One day after trumpeting the capture and extradition of an Eritrean man they said was responsible for the deaths of hundreds of African migrants, the Italian authorities said on Thursday they were looking into the possibility that they had the wrong man.

headline: Review: ‘Puerto Ricans in Paris’ Combines Comedy and Crime
abstract: Two New York police officers get a break from their home lives when they are asked to help stop a counterfeiter in France.
lead_paragraph: Ian Edelman’s ephemeral fish-out-of-water comedy, “Puerto Ricans in Paris,” despite its feather-light plot and humorous contrivances, has minor pleasures.

headline: Kara Walker Talks to One of Her Biggest Influences: Her Father
abstract: The contemporary-art juggernaut sat down with T and her dad, Larry, on the eve of the opening of a show she curated of his work.
lead_paragraph: For Kara Walker and her father Larry, art has always been a family affair — and a longstanding one. “The intent to become an artist was there early on, from about age 7 or 8,” Larry explained of his own creative development earlier this week, sitting next to Kara, who has curated a show of her father’s work that opens today at Sikkema Jenkins. As a teenager, Larry visited MoMA on Sundays; he remembers, too, being transfixed by his brother-in-law’s glass paintings displayed in his family’s sixth-floor walk-up apartment off 145th Street in Harlem.

headline: Review: Brian De Palma Says He Is Hitchcock’s True Heir
abstract: In the documentary “De Palma,” Mr. De Palma explores his muse, and the juxtaposition of images from both of their works goes beyond glib shorthand.
lead_paragraph: Brian De Palma is a devotee of the long take. His oeuvre is a catalog of extended following shots, seamless action sequences and slow-building scenes of intimacy and brutality. So it seems only fitting that “De Palma,” an affectionate and absorbing documentary by Noah Baumbach and Jake Paltrow, has the appearance of a single, uninterrupted encounter between camera and subject. Mr. De Palma, dressed in two layers of blue, tells the story of his career with energy and good humor, occasionally interrupted by clips from his own films and some by other directors that are relevant to his work.

headline: Can I Meddle to Reunite My Dying Partner With His Siblings?
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Families and Family Life', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: Also, public criticism of a stranger, inviting divorcing friends to a wedding, and a pastor’s day off.
lead_paragraph: My longtime partner has severe emphysema and will probably die soon. He has four siblings who live in our small town. Over the years, he has been closer with two of them, but they are all ignoring him now. My partner says he doesn’t mind; in fact, he says he prefers it. But his face lights up whenever any of them is mentioned. I don’t want or need their help taking care of him,  though I got along fine with them when we were in touch. Should I do anything here? (A year ago, I asked his sister to call more often. She said she would, but she hasn’t.)

headline: Review: Taking the Long Way Home in ‘Last Cab to Darwin’
abstract: A dying man who works as a cabby longs to leave the world on his own terms, so he turns the wheel toward eternity.
lead_paragraph: Since the hero of “Last Cab to Darwin” is a loner who spends most of his days in his car on a desperate quest across the Australian outback, you might be forgiven for thinking it’s too soon for another “Mad Max” installment.

headline: Why the Stanford Rape Trial Actually Represents Progress
abstract: The outraged reaction to Brock Turner’s light sentence suggests that it has become increasingly unacceptable to excuse sexual aggression because of drinking.
lead_paragraph: In the week since he received a six-month jail sentence for committing sexual assault, the former Stanford University student Brock Turner has become a symbol of the rapist who got off easy. But other aspects of the case suggest a different interpretation, signaling that the cultural and legal responses to rape are shifting, in the direction that victims and their supporters have long fought for. Turner’s light sentence means that the reform they advocate is incomplete. But his conviction, the punishment he received from Stanford and the public outcry over his sentence all suggest that men who act like Turner have far more reason to think they’ll pay a price than they once had.

headline: From Garbage to Grassland
abstract: What was once the world’s largest landfill, on the western shore of Staten Island, is slowly becoming a verdant expanse of green.
lead_paragraph: What was once the world’s largest landfill, on the western shore of Staten Island, is slowly becoming a verdant expanse of green.

headline: Review: ‘Diary of a Chambermaid’ Stars Léa Seydoux as an Abused Maid
abstract: Taking a period role memorably played by Paulette Goddard and Jeanne Moreau, Ms. Seydoux evokes the mutual loathing of the haves and have-nots.
lead_paragraph: The French director Benoît Jacquot’s screen adaptation of “Diary of a Chambermaid” has serious narrative glitches and a shaky timeline, but at least it is true to the bitterly misanthropic spirit of Octave Mirbeau’s 1900 novel about masters and servants. Léa Seydoux (“Blue Is the Warmest Color”), as beautiful and seductive as she has ever been onscreen, plays the title character, Célestine, a wily young siren contemptuously observing the follies of her wealthy, abusive employers.

headline: Where Coyotes, Foxes and Bobolinks Find a New Home: Freshkills Park
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Birds', 'ANIMALS']
abstract: As mountains of garbage on Staten Island go from landfill to grassland, the 2,200-acre habitat is attracting wildlife, including nearly a dozen species that are considered rare in the city.
lead_paragraph: The world’s largest landfill is slowly becoming a park — very slowly. The conversion of Freshkills on the western shore of Staten Island into a verdant expanse of green is now in its second decade, with two more to go before it is finished.

headline: Volkswagen Not Alone in Flouting Pollution Limits
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Other carmakers in Europe have taken advantage of a loophole that allows them to reduce emissions controls whenever there is risk of engine damage.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — One diesel car tested by the German government emitted more than 12 times as much poisonous nitrogen oxide as allowed. Another was five times over the limit, and yet another six times over.

headline: Review: ‘Now You See Me 2’ Illusionists Are Out to Save the World
abstract: The sleight-of-hand the Four Horsemen must pull off in this cartoonish movie, directed by Jon M. Chu, would protect everyone’s computers.
lead_paragraph: The main sleight-of-hand at play in the illusion-themed sequel, “Now You See Me 2,” will be convincing audiences that a single oddball idea — and four bickering, bragging leads — can support a successful franchise. And while the first movie had a certain goofy charm, its appeal barely stretched to feature length. This time the director, Louis Leterrier, has been replaced by Jon M. Chu, who, with “G.I. Joe: Retaliation” (2013), has proved himself more than comfortable with noise and nonsense.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Art in review, from Times critics.

headline: Review: Men Will Be Boys and Sometimes Infants
abstract: In this new piece, the choreographer Vanessa Anspaugh does not seek the demise of the male gender. She just wants to improve it.
lead_paragraph: What does a feminist work look like without women?

headline: Review: In ‘King Jack,’ a 15-Year-Old Trapped in a Cycle of Bullying
abstract: Felix Johnson’s coming-of-age story portrays a teenage boy in a small town in which a bully exercises his capacity for cruelty.
lead_paragraph: For everyone who ever had a close call as an adolescent and kept it from the grown-ups, “King Jack” will hit you where you live. The same for everyone who’s been pummeled by a bully or been left vulnerable by releasing a graphic selfie into the textosphere.

headline: Review: In ‘Be Somebody,’ a Teenage Idol Goes AWOL With an Ordinary Girl
abstract: Matthew Espinosa plays a pop star who has had enough with his tour handlers and sees how the other folks live.
lead_paragraph: What, you haven’t heard of Matthew Espinosa? Nor had I, until I sat in a theater full of screaming, giggling teenage girls ardently anticipating a screening of “Be Somebody,” Mr. Espinosa’s innocuous first feature, directed by Joshua Caldwell. Mr. Espinosa, not quite 19, is a nonsinging Justin Bieber look-alike and a Magcon boy. What, you don’t know the Magcon boys? They’re young social media stars, best known through Vine, who make harmless videos and attract the aforementioned vocal legion of admirers. The Japanese have a term for a certain type of character in manga (comic books) and anime: bishonen — pubescent in appearance, devoid of facial hair, sensitive, unthreatening. That would be Mr. Espinosa.

headline: Two Candidates. Two Speeches. One Cliché After Another From Clinton and Trump.
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump delivered victory speeches on Tuesday that leaned heavily on campaign clichés — in many cases, the same ones.
lead_paragraph: It was a historic night that called for soaring rhetoric and unvarnished authenticity. Instead, Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump delivered victory speeches on Tuesday that leaned heavily on campaign clichés — in many cases, the same ones.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling Counters Pennsylvania Judge on Recusal
abstract: The justices also ruled in narrow decisions on double jeopardy in a Puerto Rico case and on recalling jurors in civil cases after a mistake in a verdict.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A judge may not hear an appeal in a death penalty case that he worked on as a prosecutor, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday in a 5-to-3 decision. The court also issued divided decisions in two other cases, ruling that Puerto Rico cannot try defendants in local courts for conduct already prosecuted in federal court, and that discharged juries may be called back in some cases to fix mistakes in their verdicts.

headline: Review: In ‘The Conjuring 2,’ Ghostly Violence Has a British Accent
abstract: James Wan’s sequel to his horror hit concerns a London poltergeist in 1977. Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson return as paranormal investigators.
lead_paragraph: The 2013 film “The Conjuring,” about a possessed farmhouse in Rhode Island, was one of the better horror movies to come along in a while, and “The Conjuring 2” does everything you want a sequel to do. It’s as well made as the original, but the location and the story are different enough that it’s not just the same thing all over again.

headline: Review: ‘The Music of Strangers,’ on Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble
abstract: Morgan Neville’s documentary follows the ensemble and discusses the relevance of music in a violent world. Lovely to watch, it’s even more beautiful to hear.
lead_paragraph: If the screen went dark during “The Music of Strangers,” that would be a disappointment. But if the sound failed, that would be a tragedy. While this documentary, subtitled “Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble,” is lovely to watch, it’s even more beautiful to hear.

headline: 110 Pieces by Major Artists Go to Menil Drawing Institute
abstract: The donation includes work by Jasper Johns, Agnes Martin, Jackson Pollock and Robert Rauschenberg, and will serve as a backbone for the center.
lead_paragraph: With the rise of the art market and the power of the auction world over the past several years, the medium of drawing can often feel lost in a conversation dominated by wall-power paintings and room-filling sculpture. But over roughly that same period, the Menil Collection in Houston has been developing a center devoted exclusively to modern and contemporary drawing, and last year it broke ground on a free-standing building for the Menil Drawing Institute, founded in 2008.

headline: Ex-Vice President of Maldives Convicted of Trying to Kill President
abstract: Ahmed Adeeb was accused of masterminding a plot to kill President Abdulla Yameen by planting a bomb on his speedboat last year. He was sentenced to 15 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: MALE, Maldives — A former vice president of the Maldives was convicted on Thursday of trying to assassinate the country’s president by planting a bomb on his speedboat last year.

headline: Finding Common Ground in Interfaith Marriage
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Religion and Belief', 'Marriages', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: With the growth of mixed-religion couples in the United States has come new counseling options for couples seeking to work it out.
lead_paragraph: When Dan Diamond was 12, his mother gave him a book titled “It All Begins With a Date: Jewish Concerns About Intermarriage.” At the time, it seemed a bizarre gift for someone so young, but its aim was clear.

headline: A Sotheby’s Specialist Defects to Christie’s
abstract: Alex Rotter, who was Sotheby’s co-chairman of contemporary art, has joined Christie’s in the post-buyout migration from the auction house
lead_paragraph: Ever since Alex Rotter announced in February that he was leaving Sotheby’s — one of several top specialists who departed in the wake of a buyout offer and the arrival of Amy Cappellazzo’s art advisory group — this column has been asking the former co-chairman of contemporary art worldwide if he planned to cross over to Christie’s.

headline: Thomas J. Perkins, Pioneering Venture Capitalist in Silicon Valley, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Perkins, a co-founder of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, nurtured both the venture capital industry and a generation of technology.
lead_paragraph: Thomas J. Perkins, who nurtured Silicon Valley’s venture capital industry into a force that later helped foster the growth of companies like Google and Amazon, died Tuesday night at his home in Marin County, Calif. He was 84.

headline: The Met Explores an Islamic Dynasty’s All-Embracing Big Tent
abstract: “Court & Cosmos: The Great Age of the Seljuqs” examines an empire that occupied most of Western Asia and the Middle East from 1040 to 1157.
lead_paragraph: Empires rise and fall. Some, like the ancient Egyptians’, last thousands of years and bequeath to posterity tremendous monuments. Others subsist for just a few generations, leaving barely a trace of their glories. The Great Seljuq Empire, which occupied most of western Asia and the Middle East from around 1040 to 1157, was among the more short-lived, and it left a comparatively modest material inheritance. But if the Seljuq dynasty produced nothing so grand as the pyramids, the Parthenon or the Taj Mahal, it nevertheless presided over a cosmopolitan multicultural age of terrific artistic and intellectual vitality and innovation. That period of creative fertility is reflected in “Court & Cosmos: The Great Age of the Seljuqs,” an absorbing and enlightening exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Would You Pay $849 for Tickets to ‘Hamilton’? Readers Respond.
abstract: The news that premium seats for this megahit musical will rise brought a flurry of reactions about Broadway ticket prices in general.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the producers of the megahit musical “Hamilton” announced that they were raising the price for premium seats to $849. The news sparked debate among Times readers about the continued high cost of going to Broadway, and what should be done to combat scalpers from making a killing.

headline: Review: In ‘Therapy for a Vampire,’ the Count Really Wants to Change
abstract: Sigmund Freud takes a vampire as a patient in this comedy written and directed by David Ruehm.
lead_paragraph: The title of the Austrian movie “Therapy for a Vampire” sounds like the setup for a joke or an unlikely self-help book. It’s a promising title given that Sigmund Freud treated a patient whom he called the Wolf Man, a constipated Russian aristocrat who dreamed of white wolves. It’s promising, too, given Freud’s writings on the uncanny, the return of the repressed and what he called our “our unmistakable tendency to push death aside.”

headline: Tesla Model S Suspension Failures Under Scrutiny by Safety Agency
keywords: ['Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration also warned Tesla Motors to refrain from encouraging Model S drivers not to report safety concerns.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors, the maverick electric-car maker, is under scrutiny from federal regulators over suspension failures attributed to its biggest-selling model — along with reports that it had asked owners not to disclose the problem.

headline: Idaho Town Is Rattled Months After Reports of a Brutal Assault
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Abuse of the Disabled', 'Education (K-12)', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Three students have been charged with sexual assault after an episode in October, and now anonymous callers from distant area codes are unleashing tirades.
lead_paragraph: DIETRICH, Idaho — Anonymous phone callers from distant area codes have unleashed tirades of invective on the residents of this tiny rural town. Strangers cruise its paved and dirt roads, seeming to drive through just for a look. And come fall, Dean Grissom’s 7- and 11-year-old grandchildren will be going to another school.

headline: Lord of the Lies
abstract: Given the scale of Trump’s mendacity, we should go into the fall debates with a new rule: an instant fact-check on statements made by the candidates.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the world’s most battle-scarred cable news network did something extraordinary in this year of vaporous political contrails. While Donald Trump was delivering one of his easily debunked lies, CNN fact-checked him — in near real time at the bottom of the screen.

headline: How to Heal a Traumatized Dog: Read It a Story
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Pets', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Volunteers for a program at the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals help dogs recover from abuse or neglect by reading aloud to them.
lead_paragraph: “Hi, Violet,” said the man in the orange “ASPCA Volunteer” shirt. He set up a little folding camp stool, fired up his iPad and began to read aloud in a gentle, even voice.

headline: To Beat Anti-Semitic Trolls Online, Some Co-Opt Their Weapons and Mock Them
abstract: After a news site reported that neo-Nazis were using parentheses to target social media users for harassment campaigns, a countercampaign began.
lead_paragraph: The internet is full of bad people. This is not breaking news.

headline: A Steel Mill Lives Again, in a Setback for China
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Steel and Iron', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Local officials and businesses buck Beijing’s efforts to close the inefficient industries that are hobbling the country’s economic growth.
lead_paragraph: TANGSHAN, China — The hulking, white-and-brown buildings of the Songting Iron & Steel Company stood silent one chilly February afternoon. The only signs of life came from the handful of guards at the compound’s gate, and from the disheveled middle-aged man who emerged to shout to the plant’s visitors, “Get lost!”

headline: Ready to Form! Three Animated Reboots for Kids
abstract: Revivals of Voltron, Peter Pan and even Teletubbies come to television.
lead_paragraph: Recycling, revisiting, reimagining — they’re all the rage on grown-up television, what with “Fargo” and the revival of “Gilmore Girls” and such, but they’re also a thing on the little-kid side of the spectrum. Here’s a quick look at three new oldies but goodies, all of them animated and aimed at a young (sometimes very young) crowd:

headline: Hillary Clinton, Tel Aviv, Carbon Dioxide: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Bronx Man Who Killed Friend Then Threw Her Off Roof Gets 25 Years
abstract: Prosecutors said Duvale Stevens had stabbed Andrea Hurd more than two dozen times after they got into an argument.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx man was sentenced on Thursday to 25 years in prison for fatally stabbing his friend after an argument and then throwing her body off the roof of her apartment building, prosecutors said.

headline: Dump-Trump Talk Returns, but Actually Doing It Won’t Be Easy
abstract: Donald Trump’s attack on a Mexican-American judge has some Republicans wondering if there will be a point when they must consider deposing their nominee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Republicans try to move past the furor that Donald J. Trump provoked with his attack on a Mexican-American judge, party leaders are finding themselves in the unpleasant position of asking yet again just how far is too far — and what, if anything, they can do to keep Mr. Trump in check.

headline: Review: In ‘Lone Star Spirits,’ Haunting High School Memories
abstract: In a ratty Texas liquor store, several people show up, along with that small-town specter, the rift between those who leave and grow and those who don’t.
lead_paragraph: We’re still a month from the release of the new “Ghostbusters” movie, but a rollicking good ghost story is being told right now at the Fourth Street Theater. It’s also a very fine coming-home story, reconciliation story and small-town-hero story — another spunky, funny work by Josh Tobiessen.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Billy Ray Cyrus, Like Miley, Knows About Reinvention
abstract: The singer and actor has a new original series, “Still the King,” which premieres Sunday, June 12, on CMT.
lead_paragraph: Surrounded by images of music icons, Billy Ray Cyrus, the actor and country singer, saw a bit of himself in David Bowie.

headline: David Zwirner Gallery to Open Outpost in Hong Kong in 2017
abstract: The dealer, who already has spaces in New York and London, said the city had become “a hub” for Asian collectors and curators.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In the fall of 2017, David Zwirner Gallery will open its first outpost in Asia in Hong Kong, the continent’s fast-growing hub for contemporary art.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Warcraft,” “Tikkun” and “The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble.”

headline: Founder of a Minuteman Border Group Is Convicted of Child Molestation
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Chris Simcox, co-founder of the border patrol group the Minuteman Civil Defense Corps, was convicted of molesting the 5-year-old friend of his daughter.
lead_paragraph: A founder of the now-disbanded Minuteman border patrol group has been convicted in Arizona of molesting a 5-year-old girl, bringing to an end a case that gained the attention of the nation’s highest court after he tried to cross-examine the young victim.

headline: Research Traces Link Between Combat Blasts and PTSD
keywords: ['Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Brain', 'Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy', 'Veterans', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Researchers say they have found evidence of tissue damage caused by explosions alone, not by concussions or other injuries.
lead_paragraph: They are among war’s invisible wounds: the emotional and cognitive problems that many troops experience years after combat explosions sent huge shock waves through their brains. Whereas the link between concussions and post-traumatic stress disorder has become clearer in recent years, a specific connection between PTSD and blast waves has remained elusive.

headline: Martin Creed’s Anti-Spectacle at the Park Avenue Armory
abstract: The British maverick is the first artist to be given the run of the armory’s entire first floor, where he created an exhibition titled “The Back Door.”
lead_paragraph: A kind of extended happening, or maybe a series of short ones, has gently taken over the Park Avenue Armory, one of the architectural gems of New York. Numerous moving parts, animate and inanimate, are involved, and they are all the doing of the British maverick Martin Creed, the first artist to be given the run of the armory’s entire first floor, where he created an exhibition titled “The Back Door.”

headline: Loan of Cuban Works to Bronx Museum Is Delayed
abstract: The exchange has been held up because of legal, diplomatic and logistical hurdles.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx Museum of the Arts said Thursday that a long-planned show of works to be lent from the National Museum of Fine Arts in Cuba — part of a major exchange originally scheduled to happen this year — would be delayed until early next year at the soonest because of legal, diplomatic and logistical hurdles.

headline: Survey of Tony Award Voters
abstract: In early June, The New York Times and Siena College conducted a survey of Tony Award voters. Michael Paulson, a New York Times theater reporter, invited randomly selected voters to participate in the online survey that included questions about some of their vote choices and their opinions on issues facing Broadway.
lead_paragraph: In early June, The New York Times and Siena College conducted a survey of Tony Award voters. Michael Paulson, a New York Times theater reporter, invited randomly selected voters to participate in the online survey that included questions about some of their vote choices and their opinions on issues facing Broadway.

headline: Hamilton’s New First Name? Tony
abstract: The News Surveys team at The Times and Siena College Research sampled the voters to predict the winners. A certain musical comes up big.
lead_paragraph: SPOILER alert: “Hamilton” is going to win the Tony Award for best new musical on Sunday night.

headline: Review: The Vision Festival Gives Experimental Jazz a Big Hug
abstract: This event, with an improvisational bent, includes acts like the Sun Ra Arkestra and the multidisciplinary artist Jen Shyu.
lead_paragraph: At best, performances at the Vision Festival don’t seem like gigs, but manifestations or happenings or extended-family parties. It’s normal there for music to spill over into dance or poetry or visual-art projections or some other performative act: that breadth has been the essence of the festival since it started in 1996. Vision, overseen by the artist-run nonprofit organization Arts for Art, draws on the spirit of cooperative, self-determined, experimental jazz as an aesthetic, an ethic and a continuity, extending back to the 1960s — primarily to the New York version of such music and events, but also to kindred scenes in Chicago and elsewhere. Nostalgia isn’t the point of the festival, and neither is rediscovery. Sticking around is the point.

headline: The Artist Who Beautified California Banks
abstract: Millard Sheets’s murals and artworks graced the facades and walls of numerous suburban banks in California in the 1950s as well as other buildings.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s, California corporate executives wrapped suburban banks in murals and mosaics to attract customers. The walls, meant to signify prosperity, were patterned with glittering city skylines, flourishing orange groves and portraits of Hollywood stars and early California missionaries. The best-known designer of the works, Millard Sheets, recalled in a 1988 interview that when bank patrons were asked what appealed to them about the buildings, they replied, “We like to be associated with something beautiful.”

keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Libyan fighters aligned with the United Nations-backed unity government on Thursday battled their way toward the center of Surt, the Islamic State’s coastal stronghold, in a rapid offensive that has confounded expectations and upended Western strategic calculations.

headline: Film About Russian Lawyer’s Death Creates an Uproar
keywords: ['Movies', 'Whistle-Blowers', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Critics are trying to block a Washington screening of a documentary that portrays Sergei L. Magnitsky, who died in a Moscow prison cell, as an accomplice rather than a victim.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Six years after his mysterious death in a Moscow prison cell, Sergei L. Magnitsky has become a byword for brutality in President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia. Now, a documentary film that paints Mr. Magnitsky as an accomplice rather than a victim is generating a furor, with critics trying to block a screening of it next week in Washington.

abstract: Matthew Broderick is a man haunted by his wife’s ghost and seeking help from a therapist whose life eerily mirrors his own in Conor McPherson’s play.
lead_paragraph: Seeing a ghost has done wonders for Matthew Broderick. Portraying a widower driven from his home by visions of his dead wife in Conor McPherson’s “Shining City,” a great play being given an exemplary revival by the Irish Repertory Theater, Mr. Broderick turns in his most assured and affecting stage performance in years.

lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — There are two main reasons why I liked this 15 x 16 puzzle from David Steinberg: The first is that it’s an exceptionally well-made puzzle, and the second is because it made me nostalgic for the innocent days when my kids were really, really into the late 1990s virtual pet website NEOPETS.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: Roman Catholic legislators say they have been publicly shamed during Mass and disinvited from parish events as the Philadelphia Archdiocese campaigns against a bill that would give victims of child sexual abuse more time to sue the church. State Representative Nick Miccarelli said he was shocked to learn that the weekly bulletin at his church targeted him. Under the headline “Just So You Are Aware,” the announcement read, “State Representative Miccarelli voted in favor of House Bill 1947, which states that private institutions can be sued as far as 40 years ago for millions of dollars, while public institutions may not be sued for any crimes.” Last weekend, a letter by Archbishop Charles J. Chaput was given to all 219 archdiocese parishes urging parishioners to ask their state senators to vote against the bill. Archbishop Chaput wrote that potential lawsuits would unfairly affect schools and parishes that had nothing to do with the long-ago abuse. He also said the financial ramifications could cripple the ministry. The House overwhelmingly approved the bill in April, and it is being considered by the Senate. (AP)

lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Curtis Granderson leads off for the Mets despite a poor on-base percentage because Manager Terry Collins feels he has no better option. Granderson’s .094 average with runners in scoring position entering Thursday night makes dropping him lower in the order problematic as well.

headline: Don’t Force Students to Sign Away Their Rights
keywords: ['Editorials', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'For-Profit Schools']
abstract: For-profit schools often set up a process that makes it less likely that grievances will be settled fairly.
lead_paragraph: The class-action lawsuit brought by former students of the now-defunct Trump University has loomed large in the presidential campaign since a federal judge ordered the release of documents last month showing that the for-profit school used high-pressure sales tactics and encouraged applicants to pay tens of thousands of dollars in tuition with credit cards. At least these former students could take their complaints to court, an option that students at many other for-profit schools don’t have because they have been asked to sign away their rights.

headline: Hillary and the Horizontals
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: In America, you can’t avoid the race question.
lead_paragraph: I spent much of this politically momentous week at a workshop on inequality, where papers were presented on everything from the causes of wage disparities to the effects of inequality on happiness. As so often happens at conferences, however, what really got me thinking was a question during coffee break: “Why don’t you talk more about horizontal inequality?”

headline: Cuomo v. Citizens United
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The New York governor’s plan to fight the legal means of buying elections is commendable, if he can pull it off.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s 2010 decision in Citizens United, which opened the floodgates to the buying and selling of elections, is a ruling Democrats love to deplore but nobody ever seems able to do anything about. Yet an intriguing idea came from a most unexpected quarter on Wednesday afternoon, when Gov. Andrew Cuomo, as part of his latest speech on cleaning up government, suggested that New York State could take the lead in attacking one of the ruling’s most pernicious effects.

headline: The Unity Illusion
abstract: You can’t be teammates with Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Paul Ryan says it’s time for Republicans to unite with the presumptive nominee Donald Trump. Sure, Trump says racist things sometimes and disagrees with most of our proposals, but Republicans have to go into this campaign as a team. There has to be a Republican majority in Congress to give ballast to a Trump presidency or block the excesses of a Clinton one. If Republicans are divided from now until Election Day they will lose everything.

headline: When Feminists Take On Judges Over Rape
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A sexual assault case at Stanford marks the latest instance of women challenging judges for treating perpetrators with kid gloves.
lead_paragraph: Stanford, Calif. — OUTRAGE is fueling a rare electoral effort to recall a California judge who sentenced a former Stanford athlete to a mere six months in jail for three counts of sexual assault. Regardless of the results of the recall campaign, the real test will be whether this controversy changes the way we think about rape. The aftermaths of two past judicial recalls involving rape cases are mixed. Perhaps this time, anger will lead to change.

headline: Will Big Coal Pay to Clean Up Its Messes?
abstract: Bankruptcy filings shouldn’t absolve companies from responsibility for repairing damage to the environment.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s leading coal companies are increasingly filing for bankruptcy, leaving behind enormous tracts of scarred terrain and rising doubts that they will ever meet their legal commitments to repair the earth. Concern is growing that the companies and their debtors will use Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to force the costs of mine reclamation onto taxpayers, despite the industry’s standing obligations to pay.

headline: News Q’s | Where Coyotes, Foxes and Bobolinks Find a New Home: Freshkills Park
abstract: What is Freshkills? Why is it famous? What transformation has it undergone in the past 15 years?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activity is based on the article “Where Coyotes, Foxes and Bobolinks Find a New Home: Freshkills Park”

headline: Could Long-Lost Amber Room Be Stashed in a Nazi Bunker in Poland?
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A museum in the country’s northeast says it has evidence of a hidden chamber inside a compound used by German forces, and that it may contain the treasure lost during World War II.
lead_paragraph: There is perhaps no lost-treasure mystery more seductive than that of the priceless Amber Room of Peter the Great, which disappeared in the chaotic closing hours of World War II. Now Bartlomiej Plebanczyk, an unassuming historian and museum director in northeastern Poland, believes he has found it.

headline: Tiny Home Test Drive
abstract: A night in one of New York City’s new micro apartments.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the first tenants moved into the city’s first micro apartment development on East 27th Street. I did, too, for one night.

headline: What if PTSD Is More Physical Than Psychological?
keywords: ['Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'Veterans', 'Brain', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Concussions', 'Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy']
abstract: A new study supports what a small group of military researchers has suspected for decades: that modern warfare destroys the brain.
lead_paragraph: In early 2012, a neuropathologist named Daniel Perl was examining a slide of human brain tissue when he saw something odd and unfamiliar in the wormlike squiggles and folds. It looked like brown dust; a distinctive pattern of tiny scars. Perl was intrigued. At 69, he had examined 20,000 brains over a four-decade career, focusing mostly on Alzheimer’s and other degenerative disorders. He had peered through his microscope at countless malformed proteins and twisted axons. He knew as much about the biology of brain disease as just about anyone on earth. But he had never seen anything like this.

headline: What Hillary Clinton’s To-Do List Might Look Like Now
abstract: Head off Donald Trump in the Midwest, look to Bernie Sanders backers, and roll out some Republican support.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton enters the general election with considerable advantages over Donald J. Trump: She has a stronger and better-funded organization, and the electoral map is tilted in her favor. President Obama’s endorsement on Thursday accelerated the process of rallying Democrats around her candidacy.

headline: Learning Humanity From Dogs
abstract: After his marriage unravels, a man is left with a sleeping bag, two 150-pound pets and a lot to figure out about life and love.
lead_paragraph: I came home from work on a rainy November afternoon more than a decade ago to find a 20-foot U-Haul truck in my driveway and, behind it, a police car. My first thought was fast, clear, instinctive: Are we being evicted?

headline: How to Tiptoe Around a Depressed Mother
abstract: Silence is what your mother craves, but it is also her weapon. She actively ignores you.
lead_paragraph: A depressed mother hates noise. She hates a lot of things — sometimes it seems as if she hates everything. But noise is her particular enemy. This is because she needs her sleep. She doesn’t always seem tired. But sleep is sacred to her, and you must never interfere with it. Particularly in the mornings. This makes life complicated if your bedroom — the nursery — is directly above hers and the floors are covered in linoleum, as they are in London in the 1960s. When you wake up and need to go to the bathroom you must avoid certain creaky spots. So you navigate like a cat burglar, tiptoeing on the more solid sections until you get to the stairs down to the bathroom. You hold your breath as you pee as if not breathing will somehow mitigate the sound. Do you flush? Not at this ungodly hour.

headline: A Delicate Matter in the Examination Room
keywords: ['Translation and Interpreters', 'Testicles', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Medicine and Health', 'English Language', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: For medical interpreters, the right word can sometimes seem wrong.
lead_paragraph: Unlike most refugees, I wasn’t scared when I came to this country from Ethiopia many years ago. I was confused. But early on, I understood that the first thing you need to do is survive. After a couple of months in Buffalo, I moved to Houston. For three years, I worked as a waitress and did odd jobs, and then I began volunteering at a refugee center in Hillcroft, one of the most crowded places in the city, filled with social-­service organizations, apartments and grocery stores and restaurants that sell food from around the world. The refugee center hired me as its program manager, and I received formal training from the state to do medical interpretation.

headline: How to Overcome Aquaphobia
abstract: Walk around in the shallow end. Trust the water.
lead_paragraph: “Fear is a wound to your heart,” says M. Ellen Dash, who founded a national swim school for adults afraid of the water. Don’t bother with the mechanics of freestyle or backstroke until you’ve dealt with the panic. Start slow. “No scrambling, no hurry, no tension, no worry,” Dash says. Walk around in the shallow end of a pool. Keep your mind on the present; notice the sensation of liquid against skin. Allow yourself to feel in control. “Don’t manage your fear,” Dash says. “Heal it.”

headline: The Unconsciously Chic Influences of Sigmund Freud’s Great-Granddaughter
abstract: The fashion designer Bella Freud discusses her childhood and what’s next. (Hint, it’s all happening in the bedroom.)
lead_paragraph: Before the advent of hashtags and the surplus of shirts that tout them, the English designer Bella Freud was working with wordplay. Knitted with phrases like “Ginsberg is God,” “Dad” (her father is Lucien Freud) and “Psychoanalysis” (her great-grandfather is Sigmund), her sloganed sweaters have been a hit for more than a decade. Freud’s influences — French New Wave power couples, Rastafarians — are as unexpected as her androgynous hippie look. The 55-year-old, who has a teenage son with the writer James Fox, has made short films with John Malkovich and even penned a column on beauty for The Sunday Telegraph. Now, she’s thinking about starting a line of pajamas and bedding. “I’m always rummaging around markets for vintage striped sheets,” Freud says. “I’m currently in love with the idea of making all the things I want to have in my home.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Noah Hawley, whose thriller “Before the Fall” is No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list, says “Our news now comes prefiltered for ‘meaning.’ ”
lead_paragraph: Bad News: On the surface, Noah Hawley’s novel “Before the Fall” — new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 2 — is a standard thriller: It opens with the crash of a private jet off Martha’s Vineyard, then backs up to examine the lives of the passengers in an effort to figure out what went wrong. Dig a little deeper, though, and the book turns out to contain an unexpected strand of media criticism. David Bateman, who hired the jet, runs a television station very like Fox News, and one of the novel’s main story lines involves the efforts of his channel’s populist blowhard anchor to demonize a survivor. “It’s definitely a look at the dangers of personality-driven media,” Hawley told USA Today last month. “We have these personas like O’Reilly or Chris Matthews or Megyn Kelly, the people who in some ways become the story as well.” But Hawley (who, as the showrunner for “Fargo” on FX, works in the same Rupert Murdoch-owned universe as Fox News) emphasized that he had no particular models in mind. “My job as a novelist isn’t to draw a thinly veiled version of real people and institutions,” he told me via email. “It is to try to find the truth of a thing by recreating it in a different form.” In this case, he added, the goal was to point out the danger of leaping to conclusions based on limited facts: “What happened? What does it mean? These are different questions. Historically the news media’s role was to answer the first and leave the second to informed viewers. But somewhere around the turn of the century a shift occurred. Our news now comes prefiltered for ‘meaning,’ the ‘relevant’ facts arranged to fit a certain worldview — conservative, liberal — and then delivered as if they were objective truth. Facts that don’t fit that worldview are left out. As a result, conservative people live in a different America than liberal people. Not only can we no longer agree on the meaning of events. We literally can’t agree on the events themselves.”

headline: Portrait of a Mentor
abstract: A new movie, “Genius,” centers on the relationship between the editor Maxwell Perkins and the novelist Thomas Wolfe.
lead_paragraph: Maxwell Perkins is the rare book editor who achieved lasting fame. His nurture of F. Scott Fitzgerald, Ernest Hemingway and Thomas Wolfe made him something like the Platonic ideal of mentorship. A new movie, “Genius,” is centered on his relationship with Wolfe and the massive edits that preceded the publication of Wolfe’s novel “Look Homeward, Angel.”

abstract: Relief trucks delivered food to Daraya, a town outside Damascus, but residents reported that it was soon bombed by the Syrian military.

headline: David Swinson’s ‘The Second Girl,’ and More
abstract: In “The Second Girl,” a private investigator with a drug habit agrees to look for a missing teenager.
lead_paragraph: How do you soften up a tough-guy hero anyway? The conventional approach is to make him a widowed or divorced dad who pines for his little girl. That, or give him some icky disease. With these and other clichés so close to hand, it’s actually refreshing to pick up THE SECOND GIRL (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $26), a sweaty crime novel by the veteran police detective David Swinson, and come across a protagonist with a cocaine addiction.

headline: 1966: New Soviet Aid to Vietnam
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In June 1966, Vietnam gets a new Soviet aid.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Communist party chief Leonid L. Brezhnev told Soviet voters today [June 10] their country was ‘‘taking new measures and making new efforts to help speed the victory of the heroic Vietnamese people.’’ The implication of still more Soviet aid to help defeat the United States in Vietnam came during the closing speech of the three-month-long campaign to elect a new rubber-stamp parliament of 1,517 deputies Sunday. He coupled his warning of new Soviet aid to Vietnam with a plea for ‘‘a radical turn in European affairs’’ aimed at improving East-West relations.

headline: Far From Campus, a Different Kind of Violence Against Women
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'Sex Crimes', 'Poverty', 'Women and Girls', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Those who commandeer the cultural conversation online are more apt to know someone who has experienced a traumatic sexual encounter in a dorm than someone who has been beaten by a disgruntled ex-boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: On the night of June 6, Michelle Marks, who was 23 years old and lived in the Albany Houses in Crown Heights, was leaving her job at Fornino, a pizzeria a few miles away in Brooklyn Bridge Park, when she was shot in the head and killed. The day before she died, Ms. Marks had filed a report with the police alleging that her former boyfriend, a man with a criminal record who was three decades her senior, had assaulted her at the Albany Houses, trying to grab her groceries. This was the third domestic incident report involving the couple within the course of a few weeks. On May 16, the police said, Ms. Marks had called 911 after she opened the door to her apartment to find the man, Lamont Wright, lurking in the hallway outside.

headline: Martin Luther King in Connecticut: Closer to a Promised Land
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Smoking and Tobacco', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: As a college student spending summers working tobacco fields, King tasted life without segregation and began to choose a career path.
lead_paragraph: In June 1944, trains carrying 185 students from Morehouse College in Atlanta arrived in a northern Connecticut town about 15 miles west of Hartford. Recruiters had hired the students from one of the country’s top black colleges to harvest shade tobacco, then one of the state’s biggest cash crops. Among them was a 15-year-old incoming freshman named Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: T’s New Beauty Issue: Ways of Seeing
abstract: For this issue, we sought stories that challenge superficial ideas of what is beautiful — by way of a choreographer, an architect, models and more.
lead_paragraph: For this beauty issue, we rounded up stories that come at the subject from a number of different angles. There’s a portfolio of individualistic fashion models whose faces we find idiosyncratic and alluring. And then there are the stories that challenge the superficialities of such a complex term. Physical beauty is only a small part of what makes the otherworldly dancer and choreographer Bill T. Jones so compelling. He’s harnessed that, along with his deep well of anger and sadness, to make his confrontational and often discomfiting work for over 40 years. Wyatt Mason writes an appreciation of Jones, and what it means to be a late-career artist whose undimmed artistic impulse is now joined with the mind and body of an aging man.

headline: Reinventing the International Center of Photography for the Selfie Age
abstract: As is prepares to reopen in a new downtown space, the center is trying to define what image-making means today.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, the International Center of Photography bowed to the realities of Manhattan real estate, giving up its Midtown home on Avenue of the Americas and going dark. Now it is set to reopen on June 23 in a new incarnation downtown, after institutional introspection compelled not only by the move but also by the presiding quandary about what, exactly, defines photography today as the medium keeps morphing and mutating within a vast, evolving technological landscape. The smartphone has turned us all into photographers; social media floods us with an endless array of images; omnipresent video threatens the relevance of the still photograph; and the hovering eye of drone surveillance chronicles our every move. The center had to recalibrate.

headline: 5 Get Life Sentences in India for Rape of Danish Woman in 2014
abstract: The case was said to have “wide ramifications” for India, where an intense national debate about the problem of sexual violence has been taking place.

The assault took place in the wake of a year of intense national debate on the problem of sexual violence in India, set off by a brutal attack that left an Indian woman dead in New Delhi.
