headline: Officials Preparing for Zika Virus to Spread in the U.S.
abstract: No one has contracted Zika from a mosquito in the continental United States, but health experts expect it to happen, so they are drafting a plan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government, preparing for homegrown cases of the Zika virus, is planning to release a proposal for responding to them, health officials said Friday.

headline: Yes, There Have Been Aliens
abstract: They may not exist now. But new discoveries imply that they once did.
lead_paragraph: LAST month astronomers from the Kepler spacecraft team announced the discovery of 1,284 new planets, all orbiting stars outside our solar system. The total number of such “exoplanets” confirmed via Kepler and other methods now stands at more than 3,000.

headline: Astrid Andersen: Spring 2017
abstract: The Danish designer’s spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The Danish designer’s spring looks.

headline: O.K. I’m With Trump. I Mean, He’s Almost the Nominee.
abstract: “He is going to become a much better candidate than expected.” “I think he is a work in progress.” “I would express concern...”
lead_paragraph: There’s no shortage of full-throated Republican endorsements of Donald J. Trump. But there are several Republican leaders who haven’t exactly swooned when describing their support of the presumptive presidential nominee.

headline: Playing for Solange While Living in a Dorm
abstract: Bryndon Cook is the 23-year-old musician behind Starchild & the New Romantic.
lead_paragraph: Name Bryndon Cook

headline: Review: ‘The Purple Lights of Joppa Illinois’ Revels in Unease
abstract: The play, by Adam Rapp at Atlantic Stage 2, finds William Apps as an awkward man wrestling with anxiety.
lead_paragraph: Crack the scarred, hard surface of an Adam Rapp play, and you’ll discover a yielding marshmallow center. Though this dramatist — the author of the recent “Wolf in the River” and the Pulitzer Prize finalist “Red Light Winter” — creates vicious characters who do unspeakable things to one another, he tends to regard their savagery not with a sneer but a furtive tear.

headline: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
abstract: A new guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.
lead_paragraph: A new guide to cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And there's much more where these came from.

headline: Replica of Noah’s Ark Is Damaged in Oslo Harbor Collision
abstract: A large model of the ship collided with a Coast Guard boat on Friday. No people (or animals) were injured during the crash.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — As maritime fender-benders go, this one couldn’t help attracting attention: Noah’s ark crashed into a Norwegian Coast Guard patrol boat in the Port of Oslo on Friday morning.

headline: At the Birthplace of a Graft Scandal, Brazil’s Crisis Is on Full Display
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Money Laundering']
abstract: “Operation Car Wash” has shaken Brazil’s elite and fueled anger among the lower classes about epic and systemic corruption.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The mercantile thrum at the Posto da Torre begins at daybreak with a rush of motorcycle deliverymen and taxi drivers who come to fill their tanks with gas, and their bellies with warm puffs of cheesy bread.

headline: Lab Worker in Pittsburgh Is Accidentally Infected With Zika Virus
abstract: Health officials said the researcher at the University of Pittsburgh struck herself with a needle, in what appeared to be the first-known such case.
lead_paragraph: A researcher at the University of Pittsburgh contracted the Zika virus after accidentally sticking herself with a needle, becoming what appeared to be the first known case of an infection in a lab, officials said.

headline: Gang Violence in Chicago
abstract: A reader bemoans the influence of gangs on inner-city youths.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: At Village Social in Mount Kisco, Making Some Noise
abstract: The Mount Kisco restaurant’s menu and specials attract boisterous families and the bar crowd.
lead_paragraph: After three visits to Village Social Kitchen and Bar in Mount Kisco, I found myself looking for a fair-minded way to say that the sometimes excellent food there doesn’t quite square with the borderline bedlam that can prevail at peak hours.

headline: Lenient Sentence for Rape at Stanford
abstract: “The unjustly light sentence speaks volumes about privilege and criminal justice.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why I Quit Twitter — and Left Behind 35,000 Followers
abstract: For weeks I was barraged by rank anti-Semitism, and Twitter failed to respond.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece, Jonathan Weisman, The Times’s deputy Washington editor, explains his recent decision to quit Twitter.

headline: Review: Katerina Ristorante Italiano in Great Neck
abstract: Katerina Ristorante Italiano has elegant touches like crystal chandeliers and waiters at tableside carts, and many patrons seem to know one another.
lead_paragraph: Remember when Italian restaurants had white tablecloths, crystal chandeliers and tableside carts staffed by waiters who boned fish and flamed sauces? Katerina Ristorante Italiano, which opened in Great Neck a few months ago, offers these touches. It is a pleasant throwback to the 1980s.

headline: Review: At Guilford Mooring, Smooth Sailing After Weathering Storms
abstract: Hurricanes Irene and Sandy were not kind to Guilford Mooring, but it is nothing if not resilient.
lead_paragraph: Any restaurant set directly on a harbor — where docked fishing boats and moored sloops bob just beyond the windows — makes certain implicit promises. The first, of course, is: Good Seafood Served Here.

headline: Keiko Fujimori Concedes in Peru’s Presidential Election
abstract: Ms. Fujimori, a daughter of a former leader, congratulated Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, a former finance minister, who won by 42,000 votes.
lead_paragraph: The runner-up in Peru’s presidential contest conceded defeat on Friday, paving the way for a former finance minister to become the country’s next leader.

headline: Full Faith and Credit: Christian Groups Unite Against Predatory Lending
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Consumer Protection', 'Payday Loans']
abstract: Conservative churches are uniting with more liberal denominations to educate against, and combat the devastating effects of, high-interest “payday loans.”
lead_paragraph: In 1996, Derek Drewery was a young man stationed at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio when he ran into money problems.

headline: Gordie Howe Over the Years
abstract: The professional hockey career of Gordie Howe stretched over five decades. Here are some highlights from each decade of it.
lead_paragraph: The professional hockey career of Gordie Howe, who died Friday at 88, stretched over five decades, from his first game with the Detroit Red Wings in 1946 to his last, with the Hartford Whalers in 1980. (In 1997, at age 69, he even played a shift for the International Hockey League’s Detroit Vipers and could claim to be hockey’s only six-decade professional.) Here are some highlights from each decade of Howe’s career.

headline: More Transparency in Ticket Sales, and No More Bots
abstract: The chief executive of TicketNetwork calls for changes in the industry to stop high markups on ticket resales.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For the Alt-Right, the Message Is in the Punctuation
keywords: ['ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Podcasts', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Symbols']
abstract: This is how a hate symbol rises in 2016: A podcast sound effect becomes a Twitter meme and a browser extension before it finally slithers into the physical world.
lead_paragraph: The Anti-Defamation League added a new symbol this week to Hate on Display, its database of prominent white supremacist imagery. It’s called the “echo,” and it is used online to call attention to Jewish names in the news.

headline: Italy’s Answer to Potato Chips? Taralli, of Course
abstract: In Southern Italy, these round crackers are everywhere. A Bay Area chef makes them even better — rich with olive oil and spicy with black pepper.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Taralli are like the potato chips of southern Italy, according to the chef Rocky Maselli, who runs the A16 restaurants in the Bay Area. “You get them at gas stations but also at fancy hotels,” Mr. Maselli said. “They’re just the ultimate bar snack.”

headline: Women Rule at Ojai Festival, Unannounced
abstract: Kaija Saariaho is the star this weekend, which also includes works by Leila Adu, Du Yun, Tania León, Christine Southworth, among others.
lead_paragraph: OJAI, Calif. — Always a bit low key about its high ambitions, the Ojai Music Festival barely made reference at its opening events on Thursday to the most striking element of this year’s four-day program: Nearly all of the work is by women.

headline: Donald Trump, Racism and the Rule of Law
abstract: Is Donald Trump a threat to the rule of law, as some legal experts believe?
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: L.A. Dance Project Forms Partnership With Luma Foundation
abstract: Benjamin Millepied’s L.A. Dance Project signed a three-year agreement with the French foundation.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Millepied’s L.A. Dance Project has formed a three-year partnership with the Luma Foundation in Arles, France, the foundation announced Friday.

headline: Review: ‘Balanchine and Beyond,’ and Going Beyond Isn’t Easy
abstract: Pennsylvania Ballet presents George Balanchine’s “The Four Temperaments” and three dances by living choreographers who went down different roads.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Ballet, for many people, has never gone further than the creations of George Balanchine. So we could argue about the title of  Pennsylvania Ballet’s new quadruple bill, “Balanchine and Beyond.” Yet on this occasion, we don’t need to. This program ends with “The Four Temperaments,” Balanchine’s 1946 classic of radical modernism, staged by Elyse Borne. What’s evident from the other three works, all by living choreographers, is that each proceeds down avenues that Balanchine never explored.

headline: What We’re Reading
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jenna Wortham, Julie Bloom and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Tricia Nixon's Wedding Cake Recipe
abstract: This final, scaled-down recipe for Tricia Nixon's wedding cake did not work in The New York Times's test kitchen.
lead_paragraph: This final, scaled-down recipe for Tricia Nixon's wedding cake did not work in The New York Times's test kitchen.

headline: In Brief: Visiting Remote Franz Josef Land; Tours in Bhutan
abstract: The polar cruise specialists Poseidon Expeditions is offering trips to Franz Josef Land and Geringer Global Travel is offering a new trip to Bhutan.
lead_paragraph: CRUISES

headline: Obama Loosens Restrictions on U.S. Forces Fighting Taliban in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: The president moved closer to allowing American forces to again directly battle the Taliban in what is expected to be an especially bloody summer fighting season.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the United States braces for an especially bloody summer fighting season in Afghanistan, President Obama inched closer this week to allowing American forces to once again directly battle the Taliban, loosening restrictions on airstrikes and on ground combat in support of Afghan forces, the administration said on Friday.

headline: MoMA Apologizes for Dropping a Film Critical of North Korea
abstract: The museum says a curator was wrong to uninvite “Under the Sun,” a documentary denounced by North Korea for its depiction of that country’s image control.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art has acknowledged it wrongly canceled the New York debut of “Under the Sun,” a documentary about North Korea that has been criticized by that country and Russia.

headline: Sliced Thin and Piled High
abstract: For all the talk of authentic Jewish delis going extinct, three in New Jersey take great pride in their pastrami.
lead_paragraph: For all the talk of authentic Jewish delis going extinct, three in New Jersey take great pride in their pastrami.

headline: Pastrami Is the Priority at These Old-School New Jersey Delis
abstract: Three Jewish delicatessens focus on preparing the ideal spicy meat sandwich.
lead_paragraph: When I asked Harold Jaffe, the owner of Harold’s New York Deli Restaurant in Edison, how much one of his pastrami sandwiches weighed, he said 13 ounces.

headline: Justin Bieber Exercises His Right to Mope
abstract: Hear the tracks that caught our pop critics’ attention, from Esmé Patterson’s “No River” to Kelsey Lu’s “Dreams”
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, The New York Times pop critics weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos — and anything else that strikes them as intriguing — in a new version of the Playlist column. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this  format? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com.

headline: A Late Winner, and a Perfect Start for a Cautious France at Euros
abstract: Amid concerns about strikes and security, a 2-1 victory over Romania on a stunning goal by Dimitri Payet was everything the French could have wanted.
lead_paragraph: ST.-DENIS, France — The barricades went up early. Metal fences, police officers directing traffic, military personnel with guns slung over their shoulders. It was hard to move around the Stade de France on Friday, and this was by design.

headline: Review: In ‘How to Bury a Saint,’ Bocce, the Tarantella and Relationships
abstract: The play at the Schoolhouse Theater in Croton Falls explores how traditions can forge connections or separation.
lead_paragraph: The evil eye hasn’t got a chance when Pasquala Colasuanno, known as Patsy, is in the vicinity. The central character in Janice Maffei’s new play, “How to Bury a Saint,” Patsy has a procedure for combating the malign effects of what she calls the “malocchio.” She has other talents, too. She dispenses couples therapy, culinary tips, tarantella lessons and the occasional shot from a bottle hidden in her yard — all dished out with warmth and high style at the Schoolhouse Theater in Croton Falls, where this sprightly comedy is having its world premiere under the direction of Bram Lewis, Schoolhouse’s artistic director.

headline: Review: ‘West Side Story’ Returns to Paper Mill Playhouse After 25 Years
abstract: This revival in the New Jersey theater stays true to the classic musical with traditional staging, high-flying dances and teenage-fueled emotion.
lead_paragraph: Musicals come — and then most musicals go.

headline: Retrospectives Without Fees
abstract: Museum-quality shows — extensive exhibitions of art 30 years or older — abound now in Manhattan galleries.
lead_paragraph: Museum-quality shows — extensive exhibitions of art 30 years or older — abound now in Manhattan galleries.

headline: Last Chance: Warhol, Basquiat and Other History Lessons
abstract: Museum-quality shows — extensive exhibitions of art 30 years or older — abound now in Manhattan galleries.
lead_paragraph: Right now the New York gallery world is awash in what are often called museum-quality shows. This term generally refers to outstanding commercial-gallery exhibitions of historical material — anything 30 years or older — that might almost as easily be in a museum.

headline: ‘This Is the American Dream’: Readers on Hillary Clinton’s Victory
keywords: ["Alzheimer's Disease", 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: As Hillary Clinton became the presumptive Democratic nominee for president, readers shared memories and hopes for the future.
lead_paragraph: As Hillary Clinton secured enough delegates to become the first female presidential nominee of a major party, readers offered memories of their mothers — and hope for tomorrow’s daughters.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump, Muhammad Ali: Your Friday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: ‘Go down, Moses,’ Romeo Castellucci’s Mostly Wordless Story of Abandonment
abstract: Deploying visceral images and sounds, this production at Montclair State University is a radical transfiguration of the Moses story.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — If theater to you is sustenance, if you are the sort of person who savors the daring and the visionary, then head to New Jersey, where the Italian avant-garde director Romeo Castellucci and his company, Societas Raffaello Sanzio, are offering a thrilling repast at Montclair State University — but only through Sunday.

headline: Review: ‘The Forgotten Woman’ in Sag Harbor Is an Ode to Opera
abstract: Jonathan Tolins’s comedy, having its world premiere at the Bay Street Theater, explores a range of loaded dichotomies through spirited dialogue.
lead_paragraph: Opera “expresses what can’t be spoken,” explains one of the characters in “The Forgotten Woman,” Jonathan Tolins’s brilliantly insightful play having its world premiere at the Bay Street Theater in Sag Harbor.

headline: A Little Girl Lost, Then Found More Than a Century Later
abstract: Mystery surrounds the identity of a child whose coffin was unearthed by a construction crew at a home on property that once housed a cemetery in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A university archaeologist, a city librarian, a genealogist and even a psychic are trying to solve the mystery of the little girl in the coffin.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: The Child Migrants of Africa
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Children and Childhood', 'Photography', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The Italian government has largely kept reporters from entering shelters and interviewing refugees.
lead_paragraph: Palermo, Italy — LAST year, the news media focused intensely on the European refugee crisis. Some 800,000 people crossed the Mediterranean to Greece, many fleeing wars we had a hand in creating, in Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan. Each segment of their journey was carefully documented by thousands of reporters and photographers.

headline: Studying the Tiger Swallowtail, a Familiar Sight Flitting in the City
abstract: These butterflies are not shy, and with a little practice, observers can learn the basics of how they communicate.
lead_paragraph: Though not nearly as famous as the beautiful orange and black monarch butterfly, the Eastern tiger swallowtail is a spectacular butterfly to look for throughout New York City. With sharply patterned, swallow-tailed wings nearly five inches wide, the insects often outshine the flowers they service. By contrast to the well-traveled monarch, the Eastern swallowtail is a homebody, spending its several weeks as a winged adult flitting through a few flowery summer acres — if nothing eats it first. Unlike the monarch, birds find the tiger delicious.

headline: Man on Spire
abstract: Climb to the top of 1 World Trade Center in virtual reality with NYT VR.
lead_paragraph: Download the NYT VR app for Android or iPhone.

headline: New York Food and the People Who Make It
abstract: Ina Yalof lets those in the business, from restaurateurs to street vendors, pastry chefs and a lox-slicer at Zabar’s, tell their stories in “Food and the City.”
lead_paragraph: Ina Yalof’s initiation to the culinary arts was her father’s Bumble Bee salmon patties on Sunday nights and dinner at Wolfie’s or Junior’s coffee shops in Miami Beach. She never worked in a restaurant or wrote about recipes, but after marrying a New Yorker she became expert in one food-related subject: eating.

headline: Student Body President Can Graduate, University of Chicago Says
abstract: Tyler Kissinger had faced expulsion from the college on charges of misconduct for using his position to help protesters gain access to an administration building for a sit-in.
lead_paragraph: The University of Chicago’s student body president said he would be allowed to receive his diploma and march in the university convocation ceremony Saturday, after a hearing on misconduct charges for allowing protesters into the school’s administration building to conduct a sit-in.

headline: Small Relics of a Colossal Disaster
abstract: The New-York Historical Society is exhibiting artifacts related to the 1904 burning of the ship General Slocum, in which over a thousand people died.
lead_paragraph: Around 9 a.m. on June 15, 1904, an overheated horde of Sunday schoolers, most of them from the Lower East Side’s German-American community, piled onto a 13-year-old paddle-wheel boat, giddy at the thought of a scenic, church-sponsored day trip to Locust Grove Picnic Ground at Eatons Neck on Long Island. Of the 1,358 passengers (mostly women and children) who boarded the General Slocum on that summer morning, only 321 made it back alive.

headline: British Judge Orders Proper Pay for Exploited Migrant Workers
abstract: The Lithuanian workers, who caught chickens, were not paid minimum wage and were charged illegal fees, and their wages were improperly withheld.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British judge ruled on Friday in favor of six Lithuanian migrant workers who said they had been lured to Britain with the promise of decent employment but ended up in conditions resembling servitude, catching chickens without adequate pay or access to facilities where they could bathe, rest, eat or drink.

headline: La Caye Means ‘Home’ in Haitian Creole, and It Shows
abstract: The restaurant menu hews closely to traditional Haitian cuisine, and its Thursday night concerts showcase mostly Caribbean and African musicians.
lead_paragraph: On an 80-degree evening last month, three Beninese brothers in an Afropop band performing that night set up their conga drums and keyboards in a corner of La Caye.

headline: Evening Hours | Tending Their Garden
abstract: The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, with its exotic flowering courtyard, held its annual installation of the nasturtium vines on April 1. The museum, which opened in 1903 in a Venetian-style building, is an intensely personal creation using the art of painting, sculpture, music, literature and horticulture.
lead_paragraph: The Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, with its exotic flowering courtyard, held its annual installation of the nasturtium vines on April 1. The museum, which opened in 1903 in a Venetian-style building, is an intensely personal creation using the art of painting, sculpture, music, literature and horticulture.

headline: Comic-Book Heroine to Make Puerto Rico Proud
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Puerto Rican Day', 'Puerto Ricans']
abstract: La Borinqueña, whose comic won’t appear until October, will have a float in the Puerto Rican Day Parade; her name is the title of the commonwealth’s anthem.
lead_paragraph: When Superman made his debut in Action Comics No. 1 in 1938, he had to wait until the next year to take part in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade. The new Puerto Rican heroine La Borinqueña, who is secretly a college student named Marisol Rios De La Luz, will have a float in the National Puerto Rican Day Parade on Sunday, despite having made her first appearance at a news conference just last month. Her comic doesn’t even come out until October.

headline: How Sandy Alderson, Mets General Manager, Spends His Sundays
abstract: With his team off to a solid start again this season, Mr. Alderson spends weekends in the executive box at Citi Field or in Yankee territory with his family in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: When the Mets hired Sandy Alderson as their general manager in 2010, the team was in the dumps: on the field, a series of disappointing seasons; off the field, severe financial constraints caused in part by the owners’ investments with Bernie Madoff. Six years later, the Mets are flying high, thanks largely to Mr. Alderson, 68. A former Marine lieutenant and Vietnam veteran with a Harvard Law degree, he brought stability and confidence to the front office, and in 2015 the team made a surprise trip to the World Series. This year the Mets have had a solid start, with a talented pitching staff and one of the best records in the National League. Mr. Alderson, who lives in a penthouse on the Upper East Side of Manhattan with his wife, Linda, and their 11-year-old golden retriever, Buddy, is Zen about it. “My job,” he said, “is like watching the tide come in and out — observing, ruminating, trying to figure out where the team is and where we should make changes.”

headline: Bill Cunningham | Champagne and Polo
abstract: On June 4, picnickers boarded ferries at Battery Park for the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic, held at Liberty State Park. It was a whimsical display of fashion for the start of summer as guests wore wide-brimmed straw hats, ruffles, bright floral dresses and flower crowns.
lead_paragraph: On June 4, picnickers boarded ferries at Battery Park for the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic, held at Liberty State Park. It was a whimsical display of fashion for the start of summer as guests wore wide-brimmed straw hats, ruffles, bright floral dresses and flower crowns.

headline: Vinyl Mania Can’t Save the Greenwich Village Record Stores
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Gentrification']
abstract: After 28 years, Rebel Rebel, named for a David Bowie song, will close as more high-end clothing stores move onto Bleecker Street.
lead_paragraph: “Music stores encapsulate a moment in history,” said Emily Judem, co-director of “For the Records,” a  documentary about the demise of the Manhattan music mecca Bleecker Bob’s in 2013. “When you walk into one, they bring you back to a time that seems to be disappearing.”

headline: Friday Night Music: I’m With Her, Redux
abstract: It’s just about the music, really.
lead_paragraph: Sorry about the long blog silence. We had a bizarre technical problem (hate you, Yosemite!) that locked me out of the blog for most of a week, then real life kicked in. Long posts on Brexit and monetary policy in train. But meanwhile, for some reason — can’t imagine what — events this week had me thinking about Sara Watkins, Sarah Jarosz, and Aoife O’Donovan. Here’s a lovely acoustic performance:

headline: Apple Starts to Woo Its App Developers
abstract: With growing competition from the likes of Google and Amazon, Apple appears to be working to improve its relationship with app makers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s iPhone would be just a well-made phone without the apps that allow people to personalize it with their favorite games, news, business, social and video services. Software makers need Apple, too: They badly want to be on the devices that people carry with them everywhere, especially as traditional websites and desktop computers fade in importance.

headline: Review: Kids Dance Begins With Poise, Ends With Shrieks
abstract: The troupe, led by the choreographer Eliot Feld, ended its run at the Joyce with a program that included works by Brian Brooks and Julia Eichten.
lead_paragraph: If an exclamation point has a theatrical equivalent, it might be the sound of nearly 40 dancers ages 11 to 16 shrieking onstage at the top of their lungs. That’s how Kids Dance, the company led by the choreographer Eliot Feld, ended its exuberant program at the Joyce Theater on Thursday. It was the most kidlike these dancers had acted all night, a hard-earned giddy outburst after showing just how poised and sophisticated they could be.

headline: Maria Sharapova Bungled Her Doping Case, but Her Appeal Has a Chance
abstract: The tennis star was not the only actor at fault in the clumsy handling of the ban on meldonium, and she shouldn’t be the only one to pay for that.
lead_paragraph: Maria Sharapova has been cleared of intentionally cheating by an International Tennis Federation tribunal, but she and her advisers have hardly emerged unscathed.

headline: Toyota Names Vehicles That Still Have Faulty Airbags
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker also told dealers to tell potential buyers about defective airbags.
lead_paragraph: Toyota said on Friday that it had instructed its dealers to disclose which of its new cars still use airbags that may deteriorate over time and become prone to violent ruptures. And the automaker said it had instructed dealers to tell potential buyers about the issue.

headline: At Westchester Airport, Where Bald Eagles (and Their Friends) Dare
abstract: As the birds and other wildlife have become more common at airports, the potential for collisions has also increased.
lead_paragraph: One morning in April 2015 at Westchester County Airport, the main runway had to be closed unexpectedly. Steve Ferguson, the airport’s assistant manager and a private pilot, was the only one waiting to take off when an air traffic controller made a surprising announcement over the radio: A bald eagle stood at the end of the runway.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: Chief Sean Whent of the Oakland police has resigned amid an investigation of sexual misconduct allegations involving several officers. Chief Whent said in a statement late Thursday that he had worked to make the city safer by forging better ties with its diverse communities, and that the vast majority of Oakland officers shared that commitment. He gave no reason for stepping down. Chief Whent made his own decision about leaving the job, Mayor Libby Schaaf said Friday. The long troubled department is investigating allegations that several officers had sex with an underage girl. Two officers have resigned and two others remain on paid leave. Prosecutors are reviewing the Police Department’s initial investigation of the allegations, the mayor said. Ben H. Fairow, deputy police chief at the regional transit system, replaces Chief Whent. (REUTERS)

headline: Hillary Clinton Supporters Push to Define Donald Trump Early
abstract: A “super PAC” backing Mrs. Clinton is widening the audience for its ad showing Mr. Trump seeming to mock a reporter with a disability.
lead_paragraph: To voters in New Hampshire, the video of Donald J. Trump seemingly mocking a reporter with a disability was well known by the time the Feb. 9 primary arrived. The “super PAC” backing Hillary Clinton is banking that it will be unfamiliar and off-putting to a general election audience in several swing states, and it is using the video in an ad called “Grace.”

headline: Review: Brooks Moving Company, Hewing to Uniformity
abstract: “Wilderness,” performed at the Kitchen, is the work of a choreographer whose reputation is rising.
lead_paragraph: Wilderness probably isn’t the first word that pops into your mind when considering dances by the choreographer Brian Brooks. His work, which lives in a place of repetition and lines, moves bodies through space with serene calculation. A manicured forest perhaps, but nothing wild, nothing untamed. On Thursday at the Kitchen, he unveiled “Wilderness” as part of a season presented by the American Dance Institute. For Mr. Brooks, this exploration of fluidity — lugubrious, ponderous — offered little in the way of a change of course.

headline: Wildfire Awakens the Sorrow of an Arizona Town Still Scarred by Loss
abstract: As a fire roared to the edge of Yarnell, Ariz., this week, painful memories resurfaced of the day in 2013 when 19 firefighters died in the same area.
lead_paragraph: YARNELL, Ariz. — Ben Palm, the fire chief here, got a call on Wednesday afternoon alerting him to a fire burning on the mountains on the edge of town. Those were familiar words.

headline: Coal Production Plummets to Lowest Level in 35 Years
keywords: ['Coal', 'Mines and Mining', 'Solar Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: Above-normal temperatures lowered electricity demand, but tougher regulations and cheaper alternatives have hurt the industry as well.
lead_paragraph: Coal production in the United States is plummeting to levels not seen since a crippling coal strike 35 years ago, according to a report released by the Energy Department on Friday.

headline: Police Seek Arsonist After Attacks on 2 Staten Island Churches
abstract: The evidence from fires in the borough’s Stapleton neighborhood is nearly identical, the authorities said, and they believe the person is responsible for both.
lead_paragraph: Had the floors of the St. Paul’s Episcopal Church on Staten Island not been made of slate, the 150-year-old house of worship might have burned to the ground on Sunday, when, the police said, a person threw a burning bottle filled with flammable liquid through an open window. The bottle flamed out on the stone floor.

headline: A Humble Shield Safeguards the Sharks’ Net
abstract: San Jose goaltender Martin Jones, who became an N.H.L. starter for the first time this season, was the first goalie to record multiple 40-save games in the Stanley Cup finals since the league’s 1967 expansion.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — On Friday morning, the San Jose Sharks hopped on a charter flight from here to their home base in Silicon Valley, happy to have found a way to keep their championship hopes alive.

headline: Ban Ki-moon’s Thankless Position
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: The complexity and competing interests of the U.N. do not allow for moral absolutism.
lead_paragraph: It is distressing, but not surprising, that the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, succumbed to pressure from Saudi Arabia to erase a Saudi-led military coalition in Yemen from a list of armies that kill and maim children. What is surprising is that Mr. Ban made the incident public and declared that the sort of pressure he came under was unacceptable.

headline: An Invitation to Abuse by Check-Cashing Stores
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'State Legislatures', 'Payday Loans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: The New York State Legislature has a new bad idea that could pave the way for the return of predatory lending to low-income communities.
lead_paragraph: New York State financial regulators have done a good job of fending off online lenders who try to illegally saddle New Yorkers with loans that can carry annual interest rates of 1,000 percent. But the State Legislature has periodically tried to undermine regulators by supporting bills that could pave the way for the return of predatory lending to low-income neighborhoods.

headline: Vigilantes Patrol Parts of Europe Where Few Migrants Set Foot
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Vigilantes', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Discrimination', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: In countries like Slovakia and Hungary, vigilante groups are portraying a menacing incursion of asylum seekers to build support for their xenophobic agendas.
lead_paragraph: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia — The People’s Party-Our Slovakia, after months of stirring up fears about foreigners and Muslim migrants, decided to take action: This spring, the group’s leader proudly stood in front of the main railway station in Zvolen, Slovakia, and announced that a new group of volunteers would begin patrolling passenger trains to keep the “decent citizens” of Slovakia safe from criminals and minorities.

headline: Gawker’s Appeal in Sale May Be Its E-Commerce Potential
abstract: Its Lifehacker, Kotaku, Kinja Deals and other sites have been generating commissions for Gawker and are of interest to Ziff Davis, a suitor.
lead_paragraph: The Gawker Media Group is up for sale. The question now is not just who will buy it, but what exactly they will be paying for.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Call Each Other Unfit for Presidency
abstract: The two presumptive nominees sought to rev up their core supporters by previewing the arguments they will make over the next five months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With their nomination contests finally locked up, Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump sought to rev up their core supporters on Friday during dueling speeches in which each cast the other as unfit for the presidency.

headline: Drug Maker’s Former Employees Accused of Shady Dealings With Doctors
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Two former employees of Insys are accused of paying doctors to participate in “sham” educational programs in exchange for prescribing the powerful painkiller fentanyl.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Roper, once a sales manager at Insys Therapeutics, a small pharmaceutical company, had a problem. The end of the quarter was near, and for the first time, Insys was in danger of missing sales goals for its only product, a spray called Subsys that contains the powerful painkiller fentanyl.

headline: Cassius Clay Defeats Sonny Liston: ‘Eat Your Words’
abstract: The wild, bragging young Clay won a heavyweight title in February 1964 and silenced a skeptical crowd.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in The New York Times on Feb. 26, 1964.

headline: LeBron James Awards Game Balls to Friends and Foes
abstract: James is not only in charge of the Cavaliers’ offense, but he has also been giving out game balls to his teammates, and theoretical ones to the Warriors.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — In hockey, they award the three stars. In soccer, the top performer is named the man of the match. And in the N.B.A. — well, someone often gets a Bronny.

headline: Contest to Fill Rangel’s Seat: It’s Old vs. New
abstract: Two candidates to replace Representative Charles B. Rangel carry famous names in Harlem’s political history, while others reflect the district’s shifting demographics.
lead_paragraph: It was 1970 in Harlem, a vibrant neighborhood struggling with poverty, neglect, drugs and crime amid the turmoil of the civil rights era. Against that troubled backdrop emerged a young congressman named Charles B. Rangel.

headline: Bernie Sanders to Meet With His Inner Circle on Sunday
abstract: Several of the candidate’s most important supporters and advisers will join him in Burlington, Vt., for a meeting that centers, in part, on the state of the race.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders plans to meet with several of his most important supporters and advisers in Burlington, Vt., on Sunday, as he faces increasing pressure to drop out of the Democratic presidential race.

headline: Muhammad Ali Grew Into Many Roles
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Boxing']
abstract: Lovable clown to an evolving young man to sociopolitical spokesman, Ali, at 22, is ever elusive.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 25, 1964.

headline: Through the Streets of Muhammad Ali’s Childhood Home, a Final Send-Off
abstract: In an hourslong procession that wove 20 miles through Louisville, Ky., spectators lined up 10 deep to honor Muhammad Ali.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Inside a big arena, the likes of Bill Clinton, Billy Crystal and Bryant Gumbel and a diverse range of family members and religious leaders spoke weighty and witty words about Muhammad Ali not long after he was laid to rest Friday in a cemetery here.

headline: A Stirring Farewell to Muhammad Ali, Just as He Scripted It
abstract: After a funeral procession through Louisville, Ky., relatives, celebrities, politicians and others close to Ali reflected on his life.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Muhammad Ali spent the better part of a decade planning his funeral, his friends and family said, and by late Friday afternoon it was evident what had taken him so long. In a spectacle that fanned across miles of his hometown, in memories that stretched over some of 20th-century America’s most turbulent years, and in prayers from the palette of faiths that he honored as paths to truth, he was laid to rest, one week after his death at age 74.

headline: It Was Better to Bern Out
abstract: Bernie Sanders brought passion about the needs of struggling Americans to what might have been a detached and complacent Democratic campaign.
lead_paragraph: Thursday’s cordial get-together between Bernie Sanders and President Obama was a good deal shorter than the eight years that Mr. Sanders’s fervent supporters had hoped he would spend in the Oval Office. Still, it said much about the improbable success of a candidacy that had far more impact than anyone predicted when Mr. Sanders, a 74-year-old Vermont socialist with a Brooklyn accent and no big-money backers, launched his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination with a 10-minute, sparsely attended news conference in the marble glare of the Capitol. There he promised “a movement which says we have got to stand together as a people and say that this Capitol, this beautiful Capitol, our country, belongs to all of us and not the billionaire class.” If in the end he couldn’t succeed without money from the billionaires, he added, he’d at least show “what a sad state of affairs that is for American democracy.”

headline: ‘Mr. Muhammad Ali Has Just Refused to Be Inducted’
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Vietnam War', 'Boxing']
abstract: Declining draft induction for religious reasons costs Ali his titles.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in The New York Times on April 29, 1967.

headline: How a Clerk Spared Muhammad Ali From Prison
keywords: ['Conscientious Objectors', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Boxing', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A Supreme Court justice’s aide convinced his boss of Ali’s sincerity in resisting draft induction.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in The New York Times on Dec. 17, 1979.

headline: Joe Frazier Beats Muhammad Ali in ‘Fight of Century’
abstract: Frazier broke the wings of the butterfly and smashed the stinger of the bee in winning a unanimous 15-round decision over Ali at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in The New York Times on March 9, 1971.

headline: The Snobs and Me
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Women and Girls', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: I thought Princeton wouldn’t want to claim me as an alum. Maybe the problem was all in my head.
lead_paragraph: I GRADUATED from Princeton in 1991, and my debut novel was published almost exactly 10 years later, in May 2001. When that first box of hardcovers arrived, I sent copies to a few of my famous professors, then spent the next month acting out my fantasy about my work’s reception.

headline: Isn’t Honesty the Best Policy?
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Financial Planners', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: If the fiduciary standard is good enough for medical care, legal advice and accounting, it is good enough for financial retirement advice.
lead_paragraph: A RETIRED mechanic and a fourth-grade teacher from my home state, Russell and Christine Kazda, are having a tough time getting by. While Mrs. Kazda still teaches, Mr. Kazda suffered an injury last year and retired early after a 30-year career. Over the years, the Kazdas did what they were supposed to do and saved for retirement. They made it clear to their retirement advisers that they wanted to invest conservatively — then they had to dip into their savings earlier than expected.

headline: Morton White, Philosopher of Holistic Pragmatism, Dies at 99
abstract: Professor White said his intellect awoke in college. Before that he was a “child of the streets” more conversant with baseball players than books.
lead_paragraph: Morton White, a philosopher and historian of ideas whose innovative theory of “holistic pragmatism” showed the way toward a more socially engaged, interdisciplinary role for philosophy, died on May 27 in Skillman, N.J. He was 99.

headline: Title Retained After Ugly End to the ‘Thrilla in Manila’
abstract: The third bout in a five-year rivalry between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier leaves both fighters exhausted.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2, 1975.

headline: Construction Company Guilty of Manslaughter in Immigrant Worker’s Death
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: A closely watched case brings felony convictions in the death of Carlos Moncayo, who was crushed last year in a Lower Manhattan construction site.
lead_paragraph: A general contracting company was convicted of manslaughter and other charges on Friday in the death last year of a construction worker at a Lower Manhattan building site.

headline: Yankees’ Parmelee Will Miss at Least a Month With Hamstring Injury
abstract: Rob Refsnyder, a rookie infielder, will replace Chris Parmelee at first base, for now.
lead_paragraph: After tests on Friday revealed that Chris Parmelee’s strained right hamstring could displace him for at least a month, the Yankees were forced to swallow down a difficult question about their situation at first base: Who’s left?

headline: What ‘Hamilton’ Forgets About Hamilton
keywords: ['Theater', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Where are the songs about his disdain for the lower classes?
lead_paragraph: ALEXANDER HAMILTON is all the rage. Sold out for months in advance, the musical “Hamilton,” Lin-Manuel Miranda’s remarkable hip-hop dramatization of this founder’s life, is arguably the most celebrated American cultural phenomenon of our time. Reported on from every conceivable angle, the show has helped keep Hamilton on the $10 bill and prompted a new nickname for this weekend’s Broadway awards ceremony: the “Hamiltonys.”

headline: No Triple Crown This Year, but an American Pharoah Effect
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Nyquist (Race Horse)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: American Pharoah’s intoxicating victories last year have evolved into a mild hangover as the Belmont Stakes is set to go off Saturday without a Triple Crown on the line.
lead_paragraph: In an instant, less time than it took American Pharoah to pull away from his rivals in the homestretch at Belmont Park last year, 37 years of agony and heartbreak gave way to ecstasy and jubilation.

headline: Review: Stories Eugene O’Neill Told When He Was Very Young
abstract: In the century-old “Recklessness” and “Now I Ask You,” revived at the Metropolitan Playhouse, O’Neill deals with a scandalous affair and bohemianism.
lead_paragraph: The bitter play fares best in “O’Neill (Unexpected),” a program of two nearly forgotten works by Eugene O’Neill being produced by the Metropolitan Playhouse. While one piece, a comedy, drums up a few laughs, it’s the tragedy that packs the real power here.

headline: Muhammad Ali Turns Vulnerability Into Strength at ’96 Olympics
abstract: His body slowed by Parkinson’s, Ali made a surprise appearance at the opening ceremony to light the caldron at the Summer Games in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in The New York Times on July 21, 1996.

headline: Way Cool
abstract: Andrew Kingsley returns with a themeless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Andrew Kingsley, he was making his debut in a Friday puzzle.

headline: Honor at the United Nations Recognizes the International Reach of a Legendary Figure
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan presented Muhammad Ali with the Messenger of Peace honor.
lead_paragraph: This article originally appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 16, 1998.

headline: Memos Imply That City Hall Knew of Nursing Home Deal
abstract: The de Blasio administration has claimed for months that top officials knew nothing about deed restrictions lifted on a nursing home, but documents obtained by The New York Times indicate otherwise.
lead_paragraph: For months, the de Blasio administration has insisted that its top officials knew nothing about deed restrictions that were lifted by a city agency on a nursing home on the Lower East Side of Manhattan — learning of it only in late February, after the building was sold to luxury condominium developers for $116 million.

headline: Who’s on First? Who Knows?
abstract: In the age of the shift, no one on the baseball field is where he’s supposed to be anymore.
lead_paragraph: I have fond memories of playing summer softball as a pre-teenager at Ramapo Country Day Camp in New Jersey. Looking back, I realize that when my brother hit ground balls so I could practice breaking up the double play on poor unassuming middle infielder Ivan Kolodny, I was in extreme violation of today’s slide rule. And that when I moved into foul territory as a first baseman because a kid kept hooking foul balls past first, I was doing something that wouldn’t be allowed in today’s game.

headline: In Their Own Words: Eulogies for Muhammad Ali
abstract: Lonnie Ali, Billy Crystal, Bryant Gumbel and Bill Clinton spoke at Ali’s funeral.

headline: A Sport Comes With a Curse
abstract: A diagnosis ensures one last fight, with Parkinson’s disease.

headline: Michael Hubbard, Alabama House Speaker, Is Convicted on 12 Felony Ethics Charges
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: A jury’s decision left Mr. Hubbard, a Republican who had been accused of soliciting work from registered lobbyists, facing decades in prison and removal from office.
lead_paragraph: Michael G. Hubbard, the speaker of the Alabama House of Representatives, whose sharp-elbowed approach to politics propelled the Republican Party to dominance in his state, was convicted Friday on 12 felony ethics charges, leaving him stripped of power and facing the possibility of decades in prison.

headline: Even the Mets Marvel at Drafting Two Long Islanders
abstract: In selecting the right-hander Justin Dunn and and the left-hander Anthony Kay, the team was almost as surprised at how things worked out as everyone else.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who grew up on Long Island, or at least in greater New York, might appreciate the Mets scouting director Tommy Tanous’s tone when he described how the team had come to choose Long Islanders with its first two picks in baseball’s amateur draft.

headline: Gowanus Canal Cleanup Could Evict Brooklyn Film Studio
abstract: The site of the Eastern Effects studio was picked by the city and approved by the federal government to be used as a staging area for a huge sewage tank.
lead_paragraph: It is among the success stories of industrial New York: A warehouse that once housed a copper company was transformed into a film studio replete with stages, sound rooms and sets as the city experienced a boom in film and television production.

headline: Donald Trump Wants Sports Stars, Not Politicians, on Convention Stage
abstract: Donald J. Trump said he would prefer “winners” like Bobby Knight, Tom Brady and Ben Roethlisberger to speak at the convention rather than politicians.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Donald J. Trump has some ideas for how to jazz up the Republican National Convention, and he previewed one at a rally here on Friday evening: a “winner’s evening” of sports celebrities and champions addressing the convention rather than politicians.

headline: A Mellower Belmont Stakes Brings Out the Regulars
abstract: This year, with no Triple Crown in contention, the Belmont Stakes on Saturday will be somewhat quieter. And that’s just fine with horse-racing aficionados.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Jeff Strang, a longtime horse owner, braved the crowds of 90,000 at the Belmont Stakes for a chance to witness, after a 37-year drought, a Triple Crown win.

headline: A Terror on the Ice, Gordie Howe Is Remembered as a Gentleman Off It
abstract: Howe, who played 25 seasons with the Detroit Red Wings and won four Stanley Cups with them, still holds the record for the most N.H.L. regular-season games played. He died Friday at 88.
lead_paragraph: Gordie Howe was known to generations of players and fans as Mr. Hockey.

headline: Warriors Win and Move a Game Away From the N.B.A. Title
abstract: Golden State beat the Cavaliers in Cleveland to take a commanding lead in the finals.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The questions buzzed around Stephen Curry and Klay Thompson like tiny insects. Where was their familiar form? Why were they missing so many shots? Curry and Thompson, the star backcourt of the Golden State Warriors, did what they could to evade all the noise in the hours before Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals on Friday night.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 11, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I was, like, a fire? We’re still recovering from a fire.”

headline: Matt Harvey’s Confidence Grows, and the Mets Scratch Out a Victory
abstract: Harvey allowed one run on two hits in six innings and struck out eight against the Brewers in his second quality start in a row. The Mets’ offense did just enough to win in 11 innings.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Mets manager Terry Collins believed. Rather than fret about Matt Harvey’s shaky outings in April and May that had elicited so much angst among Mets fans, Collins took Harvey’s back-to-back effective starts heading into Friday night as evidence the Dark Knight had emerged from his darkest period.

headline: Steve Wolfe, a Painter of Books by Their Covers, Dies at 60
abstract: Mr. Wolfe was best known for creating trompe l’oeil portraits of well-loved titles by Chandler, Proust and Joyce.
lead_paragraph: Steve Wolfe, an internationally renowned artist whose best-known works are books — or are they? — died last month at his home in San Francisco. He was 60.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: “O.J.: Made in America,” a nearly eight-hour “30 for 30” presentation, chronicles the life and times of O.J. Simpson. “Everest” and “Meru” follow some daring mountain climbers.
lead_paragraph: “O. J.: Made in America,” a nearly eight-hour “30 for 30” presentation, chronicles the life and times of O. J. Simpson. “Everest” looks back at the deadly 1996 season on the world’s highest mountain. But “Meru,” which follows a breathtaking attempt to surmount the Shark’s Fin in the Himalayas, does the climbing thing better.

headline: Another Delicate Topic With Aging: When Is It Time to Give Up Guns?
abstract: In a society where guns have proliferated and the population is aging, firearm removal has been added to the burdens of caring for older relatives.
lead_paragraph: SHOW LOW, Ariz. — The shooting range here has been Gregg Schnepp’s second home, the place he gathers with buddies who call one another “old fogy” as they send shotgun pellets flying through the air.

headline: ‘Let This Woman’s Brave Statement Peel the Blinders Off’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers discuss the Stanford rape case, Hillary Clinton’s victory in the primaries and Muhammad Ali’s death.

headline: The Chinese Hackers in the Back Office
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Welding and Welders', 'Industrial Espionage']
abstract: A dusty old computer in a mom-and-pop Wisconsin welding shop is giving a digital security firm a window into the operations of Chinese hackers.
lead_paragraph: BELLEVILLE, Wis. — Drive past the dairy farms, cornfields and horse pastures here and you will eventually arrive at Cate Machine & Welding, a small-town business run by Gene and Lori Cate and their sons. For 46 years, the Cates have welded many things — fertilizer tanks, jet-fighter parts, cheese molds, even a farmer’s broken glasses.

headline: The End of Reflection
abstract: In a world in which a phone or computer is rarely more than arm’s length away, are we eliminating introspection?
lead_paragraph: There are many moments throughout my average day that, lacking print reading material in a previous era, were once occupied by thinking or observing my surroundings: walking or waiting somewhere, riding the subway, lying in bed unable to sleep or before mustering the energy to get up.

headline: Day Drinking With the ‘Sweetbitter’ Author Stephanie Danler
abstract: The former restaurant worker and newly best-selling writer sips wine before her first public reading — and admits to drinking Yellow Tail.
lead_paragraph: Stephanie Danler was ready to start drinking.

headline: Will This Guy Shut Off the Lights in the Sanders Campaign?
abstract: Jeff Weaver, the campaign manager, has been quite vocal about fighting till the convention. After that, it’s anyone’s guess what he’ll do.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-eight years ago, Jeff Weaver was a lowly campaign aide driving an obscure left-wing congressional candidate around Vermont in a Yugo.

headline: Rocking It on Prom Night, African Style
abstract: A new breed of style stars celebrate their heritage in a mash-up of prints.
lead_paragraph: This spring, Azara Bernard, 18, turned to her sister, Archel Bernard, a designer in her native Liberia, to whip up a dress for her prom in Atlanta. “I wanted to wear the most beautiful and vibrant blue print I could find, one that would highlight my difference,” she said.

headline: Visiting Ecuador After the Earthquake
abstract: The epicenter was on the northwest coast, but areas popular with tourists, like Quito, were spared. Travel firms say the country will remain a draw.
lead_paragraph: The 7.8-magnitude earthquake in Ecuador in April that killed at least 410 people and injured more than 2,000 emotionally devastated the country and caused enormous damage. A disaster that severe can often lead to a downturn in tourism, but that may not be the case in Ecuador.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Dakar, Senegal, to an Alaskan highway.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Dakar, Senegal, to an Alaskan highway.

headline: How Donald Trump Bankrupted His Atlantic City Casinos, but Still Earned Millions
abstract: Mr. Trump boasts of his success at the Jersey Shore resort, but regulatory reviews, court records and security filings indicate otherwise. And others paid the price.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — The Trump Plaza Casino and Hotel is now closed, its windows clouded over by sea salt. Only a faint outline of the gold letters spelling out T-R-U-M-P remains visible on the exterior of what was once this city’s premier casino.

headline: In a Corner of the Everglades, a Way of Life Ebbs
keywords: ['Wetlands', 'Boats and Boating', 'Land Use Policies', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Where others see only a swamp with alligators and mosquitoes, the dwindling number of airboat operators in Everglades National Park see only beauty.
lead_paragraph: EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK, Fla. — As the airboat skimmed across the shallow water, scattering blue dragonflies and launching a heron into the air, Keith Price squinted into the sun and relished the isolation of Florida’s unrivaled river of grass.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.

headline: On The Trail: The Week of June 5
abstract: Hillary Clinton became the presumptive Democratic nominee, Donald J. Trump tried to be more presidential and Senator Bernie Sanders kept fighting.

keywords: ['Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Why Hillary Clinton’s three-word tweet resonated on Twitter. And some other stuff.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

abstract: Responsibility for removing debris; illegal parking signs; and keeping a co-op safe.

abstract: The suspect, Virendra Tawde, is said to have clashed with Dr. Dabholkar over the physician’s crusade against spiritual practices he considered fraudulent.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — A court in western India on Saturday ordered a member of a right-wing Hindu sect held in connection with the 2013 murder of Narendra Dabholkar, a physician who spent his adult life crusading against spiritual practices he considered fraudulent.

headline: Calling the Shots
abstract: Gregg Schnepp reflects on how aging will affect the shooting hobby that is a major part of his life.
lead_paragraph: Gregg Schnepp reflects on how aging will affect the shooting hobby that is a major part of his life.

headline: Navigating Fertility Clinics With a Click
abstract: Three costly, unsuccessful rounds of fertility treatments led a couple to start a free website that helps other would-be parents assess doctors and clinics.
lead_paragraph: Jake Anderson and Deborah Bialis of San Francisco planned to start a family not long after their wedding in 2012. But they soon ran into a roadblock: infertility. At 27, Ms. Bialis was told that her prospects for a successful pregnancy were dim because of an earlier medical condition. Not sure where to turn, the couple sought out a fertility doctor to assess their options.

headline: Australia Reconsiders How Far Flight 370 May Have Flown
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Malaysia Airlines Flight 370']
abstract: As survey ships near the end of a search for the missing jet, officials take a last-ditch look at how far a plane might travel after using up its fuel.
lead_paragraph: PERTH, Australia — The search for Malaysia Airlines’ missing Flight 370 on the floor of the southern Indian Ocean is nearing an end with no sign of the plane in the area that investigators had concluded it most likely went down, prompting a last-ditch reassessment of assumptions used to calculate its final descent and draw the search zone.

headline: Solar Aircraft, Bound Around World, Soars Over Statue of Liberty
abstract: A pioneering effort to fly a solar-powered aircraft around the world makes a high-profile stop in the city that never sleeps.
lead_paragraph: On the fourteenth leg of a journey around the world, Solar Impulse 2, a remarkable aircraft powered by 17,000 solar cells and lithium polymer batteries, soared over New York Harbor before landing at Kennedy International Airport early this morning.

headline: Gas Is Going Up, but Maybe Not Enough
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Automobiles', 'Gasoline Tax (US)']
abstract: Few drivers want to pay more for fuel, but with higher prices comes increased interest in fuel efficiency and less harm to the environment.
lead_paragraph: Gas prices have been rising, though you may not be aware of it because they are still extraordinarily low.

headline: A Knife Sharpener Who Went From the Garage to the Grindstone
abstract: Curt West uses grinders and polishers to put a razor-sharp edge on about 200 pocketknives a day. He says his eye for detail came from fixing auto bodies.

headline: Meg Whitman Likens Donald Trump to Fascists, Shaking G.O.P.’s Brief Truce
abstract: Ms. Whitman, the Hewlett Packard Enterprise chief executive, warned Republicans not to compromise their principles to win an election, according to attendees of a closed-door meeting.

Trump to Hitler and Mussolini, Mr. Trump and Mitt Romney reignited their feud, and one of Mr. Trump’s aides took a shot at an important campaign ally.
