headline: In Silicon Valley Suburbs, Calls to Limit the Soaring Rents
keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Referendums']
abstract: Bay Area towns that tech made rich as considering rent control, an urban tactic, to save a middle class squeezed by years of punishing rent increases.
lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — After years of punishing rent increases, activists across Silicon Valley and the San Francisco Bay Area are pushing a spate of rent control proposals, driven by outrage over soaring housing prices and fears that the growing income gap is turning middle-class families into an endangered species. Those campaigns, if successful, would lead to the largest expansion of tenant laws since the 1970s.

headline: While Young Britons Favor Staying in E.U., They Aren’t Big on Voting
abstract: Holding the attention of young voters — and getting them to turn out on June 23 for a referendum on whether Britain should stay in the European Union — is a challenge.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On June 23, tens of thousands of young Britons will be gathered at the Glastonbury music festival, whose headliners include Coldplay, Muse and Adele. Others will be avidly following the European Soccer Championship in France or biting their nails in anticipation of the next episode of hit teenage soap “Hollyoaks.”

headline: Message to Graduates: Times Are Tough, but You Can Make It
abstract: If commencement speeches reflect the times we live in, then this year’s entries suggest the times are bleak — but there is hope.
lead_paragraph: If commencement speeches reflect the times we live in, then this year’s entries suggest the times are bleak — but there is hope.

headline: Variety: A Colorful Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon bring some color to our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Joyce Carol OATES is a brilliant novelist and short story writer, but an apparently reluctant memoirist. For all she tells us about her coloring in today’s acrostic quote from “THE LOST LANDSCAPE,” she hides more important stories from the reader.

headline: Kenneth Axelson, Who Troubleshot New York City’s Fiscal Crisis, Dies at 93
abstract: The city enlisted Mr. Axelson, an executive of J. C. Penney, as a deputy mayor in 1975 to help balance its budget and stave off bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth S. Axelson, a J. C. Penney executive who was foisted on New York City Hall as a deputy mayor during the 1975 fiscal crisis to restore integrity to the city’s extravagant budget, and who left after a year with his goal largely accomplished, died on May 23 in Rockport, Me. He was 93.

headline: ‘Uncle Buck’ on ABC Makes a Nanny Out of the Man
abstract: This uncle is back, with his backfiring car and giant-pancake breakfasts.
lead_paragraph: When Vincent Canby reviewed the 1989 John Hughes movie “Uncle Buck” for The New York Times, he called the premise a “good sitcom idea.” Nearly three decades later, that assessment is being put to the test by ABC, with a sitcom based on the film that starts Tuesday, June 14. But there’s a big difference: The title character, played by John Candy in the film, is now black, as is the rest of the central family in the show. Mike Epps portrays Buck, a ne’er-do-well who is pressed into service as a weekend babysitter by his brother and sister-in-law (James Lesure and Nia Long).

headline: The Evolution of Louise Fishman, Brash and Fierce
abstract: One exhibition is at Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, N.Y., and another is at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: The New York artist Louise Fishman was on the front lines of the early feminist movement of the 1960s, and out in the streets for gay liberation. She was also hard at work in the studio, as she has been for 50 years. Now, at 77, she’s having her first full-dress retrospective, at the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, N.Y., through July.

headline: China Tries to Redistribute Education to the Poor, Igniting Class Conflict
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Income Inequality', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: A plan to expand higher education to students from impoverished regions, at the expense of the urban middle class, has set off an intense backlash.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Cheng Nan has spent years trying to ensure that her 16-year-old daughter gets into a college near their home in Nanjing, an affluent city in eastern China. She wakes her at 5:30 a.m. to study math and Chinese poetry and packs her schedule so tightly that she has only 20 days of summer vacation.

headline: E.Tautz: Spring 2017
abstract: Spring 2017 from E.Tautz
lead_paragraph: Spring 2017 from E.Tautz

headline: ACT, Citing Breach, Cancels Exam in South Korea and Hong Kong
abstract: More than 5,000 students were prevented from taking the college entrance test on Saturday in what a spokesman said was the first known nationwide cancellation in its history.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The ACT college entrance exam was canceled on Saturday for thousands of students in South Korea and Hong Kong, after the test’s administrator said it had verified a breach of the testing materials.

headline: Norgard in New York Celebrates Per Norgard
abstract: The profile of this 83-year-old Danish composer has risen in the United States thanks to his being championed by the New York Philharmonic and others.
lead_paragraph: The kaleidoscopic, enigmatic music of the Danish composer Per Norgard, 83, has been seldom performed in America until recently being championed by the New York Philharmonic and others. This week, a three-day festival called Norgard in New York offers an ideal chance to discover the visceral music of this fascinating composer.

headline: Hip-Hop and Empathy, Absolutely Free at River to River
abstract: Dance luminaries like Eiko Otake, Ephrat Asherie and Luciana Achugar will perform ideas of emotion and musicality in this 15th annual festival.
lead_paragraph: As downtown theaters start their summer vacations, take it as a sign: It’s time to go outside. Beginning on Thursday, June 16, the River to River Festival, gracing the nooks and crannies of Lower Manhattan as well as Governors Island, hosts some of the city’s most rewarding dance offerings. And they’re free.

headline: The Cure Hits New York with Three Shows at the Garden
abstract: The shows rest on the group’s familiar blend of morbidity and ecstatic release, with the trademark Robert Smith vocals.
lead_paragraph: When the Cure last played New York in 2011, the show was dedicated to the band’s restless first three albums, before it found its way as an innovator of stadium-scale mope. The group returns this week for three shows at Madison Square Garden — part of a lengthy American tour — with a broader, career-spanning mandate.

headline: Man Who Shot Christina Grimmie, a Singer on ‘The Voice,’ Is Identified
abstract: The gunman, Kevin James Loibl, 27, fatally shot Ms. Grimmie in a premeditated attack at a Florida concert hall, the police say, and then killed himself.
lead_paragraph: The police on Saturday identified the man who shot and killed Christina Grimmie, a former cast member of the reality TV singing competition “The Voice” and a viral YouTube star, as a 27-year-old man from St. Petersburg, Fla.

headline: CD Reissues: Van Morrison, Sarah Vaughan and More
abstract: Other albums include the sensual, thrusting and lightly comic rap of Egyptian Lover, and the Rasta jazz of Count Ossie.
lead_paragraph: Van Morrison

headline: The Source of Passion
abstract: Readers respond to “No Passion? Don’t Panic” (June 5).

headline: What’s Fair in 401(k)’s?
abstract: Readers respond to “When Duty to Retirees Comes Last” (June 5).
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: To Understand Clinton’s Moment, Consider That It Came 32 Years After Ferraro’s
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 1984', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: A look back to when Geraldine A. Ferraro was on the Democratic ticket in 1984 can tell a lot about how the country has changed, and how it has not.
lead_paragraph: The scenes blend like images from a kaleidoscope. A woman, blond, jubilant in a white dress, shown magnified on a convention center screen in San Francisco. It is Geraldine A. Ferraro in 1984 accepting the Democratic nomination that made her the first woman in the nation to be tapped by a major party to run for vice president.

headline: Casely-Hayford: Spring 2017
abstract: The father-and-son duo present their spring looks.
lead_paragraph: The father-and-son duo present their spring looks.

headline: Soccer Teams Raise the Curtain on the Live Show in Stadium Tunnels
abstract: In the top echelon of soccer, the stadium tunnels — and what happens there — have become a big part of the televised spectacle.
lead_paragraph: There are cages. There are escalators. Sometimes there is claustrophobia. Usually there are children milling about, and in at least one instance, the whole setting (purposely) looks like a  mine shaft.

headline: With Playoff Drought Over, Pittsburgh Pirates Are Meticulous About Advancing
abstract: Pittsburgh has made three consecutive postseasons but is still seeking its first playoff series win since 1979.
lead_paragraph: Clint Hurdle keeps a jar of chocolate-covered almonds on his desk at PNC Park. He does not eat them anymore, he said, but visitors can help themselves. On the side of the jar is written one word: “Joy.”

headline: Dreams of My Muslim Son
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Discrimination']
abstract: My boy aspires to become president. But I wonder if anti-Muslim vitriol is ruining that ambition.
lead_paragraph: LONG before I came to the United States, I was fascinated by the American electoral process. I grew up in Pakistan in the 1980s, during the brutally repressive military dictatorship of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, when fear crushed hope.

headline: Helping Children Thrive
abstract: Readers offer their suggestions, from reading programs to stable housing to better child care options.
lead_paragraph: Readers offer ideas, from reading programs to stable housing to quality child care.

headline: A Corruption Crusade in Guatemala
abstract: In a region where graft is often business as usual, an attorney general is confronting the problem head on.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Guatemalans watched in awe as their president, Otto Pérez Molina, and his vice president, Roxana Baldetti, were charged in a kickback scheme and forced from power. This month brought a  startling revelation  from the country’s attorney general, Thelma Aldana: Investigators have determined that the case that brought down Mr. Pérez Molina was just a sliver of a sprawling criminal enterprise run by the state.

headline: The Russian Peasant’s Workout
abstract: Tolstoy called days spent scything “blissful moments.”
lead_paragraph: Islay, Scotland — DAWN is yet to arrive and I am standing at the edge of my morning’s work: a small, succulent meadow. It is late spring in Islay, a remote island famous for its whisky in the Inner Hebrides, a three-hour ferry crossing from mainland Scotland.

headline: Girl Squad
abstract: Hil and Liz celebrate the historic occasion with a secretive sisterhood meeting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton greets Elizabeth Warren in the cream-and-coral sunroom of her home on Embassy Row.

headline: When Auto Dealers Profit From Bias
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Automobiles', 'Discrimination', 'Consumer Protection', 'Automobile Financing', 'Law and Legislation', 'Interest Rates', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: A House bill would effectively stop current investigations and condone racial bias in auto lending.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a year, a bipartisan majority in the House has pushed a bill that would make discrimination in auto lending harder to police. Now, members are maneuvering to add the measure to a pending House appropriations bill, which would raise the odds for passage. The problem, they say, is that the evidence of discrimination is murky. What’s clear is the lawmakers’ fealty to auto dealers in their districts, who do not want their lending practices scrutinized.

headline: The First Gay President?
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: A rising Democratic star in the Midwest makes you wonder about the barriers yet to be broken.
lead_paragraph: South Bend, Ind. — IF you went into some laboratory to concoct a perfect Democratic candidate, you’d be hard pressed to improve on Pete Buttigieg, the 34-year-old second-term mayor of this Rust Belt city, where he grew up and now lives just two blocks from his parents.

headline: Dear Conservatives, You Can Go Green Again
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Environment', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Conservation of Resources']
abstract: Republicans were once leaders in preserving our shared natural heritage.
lead_paragraph: NOT long ago I wrote an essay on how to talk about environmental issues with conservatives. Talk persuasively, that is, not confrontationally. A conservative promptly replied that I was afflicted with “fundamental ignorance,” and possibly worse. The gist of it was that conservatives are already environmentalists, and the rest of us are just too stupid to recognize it. I put on my cheerfully positive face and suggested that he amplify his point by listing 10 pro-environment actions by conservatives in this century. (O.K., maybe that was my passive-aggressive face, given that George W. Bush was president for eight of those 16 years.) He replied with more name-calling.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Latino Crucible
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: Will Republican candidates back Donald Trump’s divisive campaign or take a longer-term view and start building a more inclusive party?
lead_paragraph: Republican leaders laid out a blueprint for the revival of their party after the defeat of Mitt Romney in the 2012 presidential race. “If Hispanics think we do not want them here, they will close their ears to our policies,” the so-called autopsy report warned, noting that Mr. Romney had received 27 percent of the Latino vote, down from George W. Bush’s 44 percent in 2004. Quoting Dick Armey, the former House Republican leader from Texas, the report cautioned, “You can’t call someone ugly and expect them to go to the prom with you.”

headline: Is It a Crime to Be Poor?
abstract: The modern equivalent of debtors’ prisons lock people up if they cannot pay.
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — IN the 1830s, the civilized world began to close debtors’ prisons, recognizing them as barbaric and also silly: The one way to ensure that citizens cannot repay debts is to lock them up.

headline: Belmont Stakes Race Day
abstract: Activity usually begins early at Belmont Park, but there was more than usual on the day of the Belmont Stakes, the third jewel of the Triple Crown.
lead_paragraph: Activity usually begins early at Belmont Park, but there was more than usual on the day of the Belmont Stakes, the third jewel of the Triple Crown.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: For a Real-Life Superhero, the Images Are Enduring

headline: Laid-Off Americans, Required to Zip Lips on Way Out, Grow Bolder
abstract: Those who have lost jobs to foreigners on temporary visas, in particular, have begun to speak out despite their severance agreements with companies.
lead_paragraph: LIBERTYVILLE, Ill. — American corporations are under new scrutiny from federal lawmakers after well-publicized episodes in which the companies laid off American workers and gave the jobs to foreigners on temporary visas.

headline: How to Be a Great Vice President
keywords: ['Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: A running mate might ideally help in getting the ticket elected, but more important is the ability to govern.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump make their picks in the coming weeks, the running mates will be viewed through two lenses: the impact they will have on the election, and the effect they might have on running the government.

headline: Should I Make My Daughter Clean Her Room?
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Orderliness and Clutter', 'Hoarding', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Children and Childhood', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Education (Pre-School)']
abstract: I assumed that raising her to be tidy would give her a happier, better life.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY received an email from my daughter Zelda’s preschool director titled “The Importance of Messy Play.” Children learn through process, she wrote. The act of creating is more important than the result. She pleaded with parents to allow our kids space for disarray.

headline: Oakmont’s Water Hazards Have No Water but Sink Golfers Just the Same
abstract: The 116th United States Open will be held at Oakmont Country Club, where the drainage ditches provide a most unusual hazard.
lead_paragraph: For a golf course considered one of the most arduous in the country, the 18 holes at Oakmont Country Club, which will host the United States Open for a record ninth time starting Thursday, lack many of the most fundamental golf-design elements.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Andre Iguodala Could Repeat as M.V.P. of N.B.A. Finals
abstract: Andre Iguodala, the veteran swingman, who won the award last season, has guarded LeBron James and made valuable offensive contributions.
lead_paragraph: With the Golden State Warriors a game away from winning back-to-back N.B.A. championships, they are once again in a position where they do not yet have an obvious most valuable player candidate for the finals should they finish off the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: Muhammad Ali Inspires Writers in Life and Death
abstract: Ali was always a muse for authors, and his death will most likely not dim his attraction as new titles continue to emerge.
lead_paragraph: Norman Mailer, the pugilistic literary lion, opened “The Fight,” his account of Muhammad Ali’s victory in Zaire over George Foreman in 1974, with a ripe evocation of Ali’s magnetism, a sort of carnal electricity, which made him such a compelling subject.

headline: Inside the Ring or Out, Muhammad Ali Fought as if He Would Live Forever
abstract: In the end, Ali showed physical and moral courage against an invincible opponent: Parkinson’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Muhammad Ali told me in 1997 that he planned on living until age 90. We were on a bus in Boston en route to an elementary school for an assembly devoted to teaching students about tolerance and understanding. Ali’s speech was noticeably affected by then as a consequence of Parkinson’s syndrome. But he was still physically strong, and his thought processes were clear.

headline: Freed From Prison, Zainab al-Khawaja Flees Bahrain
abstract: Zainab al-Khawaja, imprisoned for opposing that country’s ruling monarchy, has left the Persian Gulf state in fear of being rearrested and separated from her son.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A political dissident from Bahrain, who was recently released from prison after the government there faced international outrage, said on Saturday that she had fled the country after she was threatened again with detention.

headline: Recalling a Time When Gordie Howe and His Sons Were the Power
abstract: At 45, Gordie Howe left retirement to have the chance to play with his two sons in the World Hockey Association.
lead_paragraph: After almost 800 N.H.L. goals, after 21 All-Star stints, after six Most Valuable Player Awards, Gordie Howe left hockey a bit sad. He had wanted to play on the same team with his sons.

headline: With Siren and Flashing Lights, Belmont Has a Model Alert System
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: Belmont Park uses an air-raid siren and 20 solar-powered lights around the mile-and-a-half track to warn riders.
lead_paragraph: Belmont Park is always awash in activity during Belmont Stakes week, but preparations for the 148th running of the race, which was won Saturday afternoon by Creator, were temporarily interrupted by a few odd occurrences during training hours.

headline: Cleveland Realizes a Championship After All, Thanks to the Monsters
abstract: The Lake Erie Monsters, the top farm team for the N.H.L.’s Columbus Blue Jackets, completed a sweep of the Hershey Bears to win the American Hockey League title on Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Late Saturday morning, about 10 hours after the Cleveland Cavaliers lost to the Golden State Warriors in Game 4 of the N.B.A. finals, dozens of workers in wine-colored shirts were stuffing trash bags and sweeping out the aisles inside Quicken Loans Arena.

headline: Attending Physicians
abstract: Finn Vigeland is interested in our health.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — There is nothing more important than looking after your health, and Finn Vigeland is back today to remind us to see our DOCTORs. If you look carefully, you’ll find plenty of them in today’s crossword.

headline: Doctor’s Plan for Full-Body Transplants Raises Doubts Even in Daring China
keywords: ['Transplants', 'Medicine and Health', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Head (Body Part)', 'Paralysis', 'Spine (Body Part)', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: Patients suffering from paralysis and muscular wasting diseases are enthusiastic, but medical experts say the idea is “at best premature and at worst reckless.”
lead_paragraph: HARBIN, China — Six years ago, Wang Huanming was paralyzed from the neck down after being injured wrestling with a friend. Today, he hopes he has found the answer to walking again: a new body for his head.

headline: Creator Wins the Belmont Stakes
abstract: The 3-year-old colt’s win on Saturday upended Exaggerator’s bid to follow up his victory at the Preakness Stakes and his second-place finish at the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: They hit the wire together in a blur, two gray horses that had shown promise on their way to the Kentucky Derby but once beneath those iconic twin spires looked as if they hardly belonged in America’s greatest race. Maybe they had excuses.

headline: South Korean Families Watch Ferry’s Salvaging, Hoping Truth Surfaces
abstract: Distrustful of the government’s response to the 2014 Sewol disaster, victims’ families have camped out on a rocky island to monitor the salvage operation.
lead_paragraph: DONGGEOCHADO, South Korea — Since last summer, Oh Byung-hwan has visited this island off southwestern South Korea more than a dozen times, camping out in a tent and braving monsoon rains and winter storms to watch the sea from a hilltop perch.

headline: Bangladesh Arrests Over 3,000 to Halt Attacks
abstract: The arrests were part of a series of raids intended to quell a wave of deadly machete attacks against bloggers, minorities and others, the police said.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — More than 3,000 people, some of them known Islamist militants, have been arrested in a series of police raids intended to quell a wave of deadly machete attacks against bloggers, minorities and others, the police said Saturday.

headline: Responding to Christina Grimmie's Death
abstract: The police chief in Orlando, Fla., discussed the fatal shooting of Ms. Grimmie, a former contestant on the TV singing contest “The Voice,” and a fan recalled seeing the performer shortly before the attack happened after a concert Friday.
lead_paragraph: The police chief in Orlando, Fla., discussed the fatal shooting of Ms. Grimmie, a former contestant on the TV singing contest “The Voice,” and a fan recalled seeing the performer shortly before the attack happened after a concert Friday.

headline: America’s Appellate Lawyer Recaps 5 Years of Legal ‘High Drama’
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: The Obama administration’s solicitor general, Donald B. Verrilli Jr., is exiting after 37 Supreme Court arguments on divisive issues from health care to gay marriage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “I really felt like the roof had caved in on me,” Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. said the other day, recalling the low point of his five years as the Obama administration’s top appellate lawyer.

abstract: Download NYT VR now for iPhone and Android
lead_paragraph: Download NYT VR now for iPhone and Android

headline: As Strikes Continue in France, Garbage and Resentment Pile Up
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Organized Labor', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: After terrorist attacks, floods and other labor strife, a walkout by trash workers was the latest insult just as the weather warmed and fans arrived for the European Championship soccer tournament.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The mound of torn black garbage bags spilling rubbish was stacked waist high under an elegant 16th-century carved turret.

headline: A Rare Start and Sweltering Weather Leave the Mets Feeling Scorched
abstract: The Brewers hit five home runs, two by Ryan Braun and the first-career homer by pitcher Wily Peralta, in a spot start by the Mets’ Logan Verrett.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Expectations often drop when a team dips into its bullpen for a spot starter, as the Mets did with Logan Verrett on Saturday. Expectations fall further on a steamy afternoon when the ball is jumping, as it did at Miller Park, where the Mets and the Milwaukee Brewers combined for five home runs in the first five innings and seven in all.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 2, Episode 10: On Your Way, Soldier
abstract: This week’s episode is bookended by tragedy.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of “Outlander” is bookended by tragedy. We open to find Claire looking upon a ghastly sight. The decaying body of a Highlander as snow softly falls. It’s the first in a series of horrific images that shows signs of the war Claire and Jamie find themselves embroiled in despite all their efforts in Paris.

headline: Rebounding From Injury, Logan Couture Looks to Help Sharks Bounce Back
abstract: Couture, who had two leg injuries that cost him significant time in the regular season, leads the N.H.L. in playoff points as San Jose tries to rally against the Penguins.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — The leading scorer in the N.H.L. playoffs offered a simple reason he was able to contribute with a goal and two assists when the San Jose Sharks staved off elimination Thursday in Game 5 of the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: U.S. Advances to Copa América Quarterfinals After Surviving an Ejection
abstract: DeAndre Yedlin received two quick yellow cards after halftime, but the United States held on to beat Paraguay, 1-0, on a Clint Dempsey goal.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The United States knew the Copa América math days before it took the field against Paraguay on Saturday. A win or a tie would mean advancement to the quarterfinals. A loss would mean elimination.

headline: Once Bedeviled, Justin Verlander Conquers His Bronx Demons
abstract: And older and wiser Verlander, who had never won at the new Yankee Stadium, used cunning instead of power to finally get a win in his eighth chance.
lead_paragraph: For all his accomplishments, including the 2011 Most Valuable Player Award, Detroit Tigers pitcher Justin Verlander had never won a start at the new Yankee Stadium. In seven previous attempts, Verlander had compiled a 4.84 E.R.A., more than a full run above his 12-year career average.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 12, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Your conscience shouts, ‘Here’s what you should do,’ while your intuition whispers, ‘Here’s what you could do.’ Listen to that voice that tells you what you could do. Nothing will define your character more than that.”

headline: Roger Federer Falls on His Favorite Surface to Dominic Thiem
abstract: On grass, the Swiss Federer lost to the Austrian Thiem at the Mercedes Cup in Germany. Thiem will meet Philipp Kohlschreiber of Germany in the final.
lead_paragraph: Roger Federer of Switzerland squandered two match points Saturday and lost to Dominic Thiem of Austria, 3-6, 7-6 (7), 6-4, in a rain-interrupted Mercedes Cup semifinal in Stuttgart, Germany.

headline: Ashley Chavis, Devin Vermeulen
abstract: The bride and groom, who met on Tinder, were married in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Suzanne Chavis and Devin David Vermeulen were married June 9 at Aurora, a restaurant in Brooklyn. T. Scott Sanders, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

David Degann of New York. Kelly Hayden-Wimpory, a justice of the peace in Jefferson, N.H., officiated at the Omni Mount Washington Resort in Bretton Woods, N.H.

Portin and Robert J. Portin of Amherst, N.Y. Rabbi James M. Bennett officiated at Westwood Country Club in St. Louis.

Witkin of Tenafly, N.J., was married June 11 to Louis Daniel Bergholz, a son of Eleanor Mallet Bergholz and David Bergholz of Cleveland. Rabbi Dennis S. Ross officiated at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass.

headline: Kyle Gallary, Michael Leahy

lead_paragraph: Kyle Cannon Gallary and Michael Patrick Leahy were married June 11 at the Grace Church in East Dennis, Mass. The Rev. James David, the bishop of the Ecumenical Catholic Diocese of New England, performed the ceremony.

lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Berni Schrott, a daughter of Susan F. Schrott and Dr. Jonathan Schrott of New York, was married June 10 to Dr. Adam Ross Abel, the son of Marjorie I. Abel and Dr. Bruce M. Abel of West Hartford. Rabbi Avrohom Loketch officiated at Wades Beach on Shelter Island, N.Y.

headline: Orlando Gunman Attacks Gay Nightclub, Leaving 50 Dead
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Terrorism', 'Hate Crimes', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Praising ISIS, the gunman, identified as Omar Mateen, opened fire in what emerged as the worst mass shooting in United States history. The massacre early Sunday also left 53 wounded.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — A man who called 911 to proclaim allegiance to the Islamic State terrorist group, and who had been investigated in the past for possible terrorist ties, stormed a gay nightclub here Sunday morning, wielding an assault rifle and a pistol, and carried out the worst mass shooting in United States history, leaving 50 people dead and 53 wounded.

headline: D.J. Doctor Dré Is Waging a Public Battle With Diabetes
abstract: The D.J. and former “Yo! MTV Raps” co-host has lost his sight to the disease, and he says that documenting his weight-loss surgery could promote awareness.
lead_paragraph: Andre Brown has always been a tastemaker. Better known as Doctor Dré — the Long Island original, not the West Coast producer and gangster rapper — he has been sharing his musical tastes since the 1980s as a D.J. for the Beastie Boys, a member of the hip-hop group Original Concept and a co-host of “Yo! MTV Raps.” He and his co-host, Ed Lover, even beat Ice Cube to the barbershop movie genre when they starred in “Who’s the Man?” in 1993.

headline: 1966: Purge in Peking Extends to Provinces
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In June 1966, officials outside the capital became the target of Communist sweeps.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Peking’s current purge of allegedly unorthodox Communist elements is now sweeping beyond the Chinese capital to include important provincial officials. The area under the heaviest fire at present, according to reports received here, is Southwest China, where several party luminaries are being attacked for ‘‘bourgeois’’ and ‘‘revisionist’’ leanings.

headline: Notes on Brexit
abstract: Remain, but with feelings of despair.

headline: Don’t Take A Hike
abstract: No case for raising rates.
lead_paragraph: I’m hearing some buzz that the Fed may still be considering a rate hike at its upcoming meeting, or if not then soon. Let’s really, really hope this is wrong.

headline: Stephanie Hill: Wings, Wigs, Silk Roses and a Little Heavy Artillery
abstract: Ms. Hill, the president and general manager of ship and aviation systems for Lockheed Martin, livens her office with mementos and bits of technology.
lead_paragraph: In January, I moved from Washington to our facility near Baltimore, where we assemble military launch systems. My office is on the northeast corner of the fifth floor, with views overlooking Martin State Airport. Today, it’s a joint civil-military facility, but formerly it was the plant airport of the Glenn L. Martin Company, one of the heritage companies that make up Lockheed Martin. The Maryland Air National Guard is a tenant at the airport, and we occasionally see other flyover operations, including the United States Navy’s Blue Angels.

keywords: ['Art', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: The dealer David Nahmad says whispers won’t force him to give up “Seated Man With a Cane,” a painting at the center of a continuing legal dispute.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The art dealer and billionaire David Nahmad says he is well aware of the scornful whispers that trail him when he travels to Brazil, to New York. He says he feels the disapproving stares when he enters his synagogue at home in Monaco.

headline: Donald Trump Seizes on Orlando Shooting and Repeats Call for Temporary Ban on Muslim Migration
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Mr. Trump criticized Hillary Clinton for her desire to “dramatically increase admissions from the Middle East,” and claimed he had warned of the sort of terrorism that marked the shooting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump on Sunday sought to capitalize on the mass shooting at a gay club in Orlando, reiterating his controversial call for a temporary ban on Muslim migration to the United States and criticizing Hillary Clinton for what he claimed was her desire to “dramatically increase admissions from the Middle East.”

headline: Mets Manager Terry Collins Hospitalized Before Sunday’s Game
abstract: The Mets offered no details on the condition of their manager, but he spoke with reporters two and a half hours before the game and did not seem ill.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Mets Manager Terry Collins felt ill about an hour before Sunday’s game in Milwaukee and was taken to a nearby hospital for tests, the Mets assistant general manager John Ricco said. The bench coach Dick Scott, who last managed with Class A South Bend in 1997, took over for Collins.

headline: After Nightclub Massacre, Obama Expresses Outrage and a Familiar Lament
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Saying the shootings were an “act of terror and an act of hate,” Mr. Obama again called for agreement on gun measures.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The tableau at the White House was chillingly familiar: The somber president, nearing the end of his eight-year term, walked grim-faced to the podium to offer his condolences, promised action in the wake of suffering and pleaded for a new resolve that just might prevent more deaths in a hail of bullets.

headline: ‘Conjuring 2’ Beats This Year’s Curse of Summer Sequels
abstract: The film was No. 1 with the expensive “Warcraft,” a hit overseas, coming in a distant second in North America.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood had a mixed weekend at the box office. “The Conjuring 2” was strong. “Warcraft” was soft. “Now You See Me 2” was a shrug.

headline: The Scope of the Orlando Carnage
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Religion and Belief', 'Terrorism']
abstract: This is bigger, sadder and scarier than any one group of victims.
lead_paragraph: These locations are never random. These targets aren’t accidental. They’re the very vocabulary in which assailants like the Orlando gunman speak, and he chose a place where there’s drinking. And dancing. And where L.G.B.T. people congregate, feeling a sense of welcome, of belonging.

headline: Through Creative Ferment, a Power Plant Reborn
abstract: For its 10th iteration, Toronto’s Luminato Festival has located all of its ambitious programming in a single place: the disused Hearn Generating Station in the city’s Port Lands area.
lead_paragraph: For its 10th iteration, Toronto’s Luminato Festival has located all of its ambitious programming in a single place: the disused Hearn Generating Station in the city’s Port Lands area.

headline: The Luminato Festival Turns a Former Power Plant Into a Creative Engine
abstract: Using technical and artistic ingenuity, planners created interior stages for theater, dance and music in a way that invites brainstorming about the plant’s future.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — In just three and a half weeks, workers here built one of the world’s largest cultural performance spaces inside an abandoned power plant. There are stages for theater, dance and music, as well as multiple art galleries and a high-end French restaurant.

headline: Review: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Debuts Two New Works
abstract: On Thursday and Friday, the troupe offered seven pieces, including Kyle Abraham’s “Untitled America: Second Movement” and Mauro Bigonzetti’s “Deep.”
lead_paragraph: Robert Battle, the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater since 2011, gives an excellent curtain speech. But when the company returned to the David H. Koch Theater on Thursday and Friday, he kept uncharacteristically quiet. What spoke instead was the repertory he has updated and upgraded.

headline: Last Call at Pulse Nightclub, and Then Shots Rang Out
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The gunfire did not let up. As rounds were fired, people dropped, some in panic, some because they were wounded, some because they were dead.
lead_paragraph: It was nearing last call.

headline: Highlights and Analysis of the 2016 Tony Awards
abstract: The night belonged to “Hamilton” at the 70th annual Tony Awards. The nightclub shootings in Orlando, Fla., in which 50 people were killed, added an unwelcome note of sadness and disbelief to Broadway’s big night of celebration.

headline: Review: Father Was a Vicious Bully. Then He Became a Woman.
abstract: In the memoir “In the Darkroom,” Susan Faludi writes of learning that her 76-year-old father, from whom she was estranged, had sex reassignment surgery.
lead_paragraph: On July 7, 2004, Susan Faludi received an email with a one-word subject line: “Changes.” To describe it as an understatement would itself be an understatement. The note was from Ms. Faludi’s father, with whom she had barely spoken in 25 years. He was writing to say that he — now she — had just had sex reassignment surgery in Thailand. Steven Faludi had become Stefánie. He was 76.

headline: Ukraine Shields Gay Rights Parade From Repeat of Violence
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Parades', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: A peaceful march attracting about 2,000 people in Kiev was a striking contrast to what happened last year, when members of far-right organizations attacked the 300 or so participants, injuring dozens.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Gay rights groups in Ukraine celebrated a milestone on Sunday — holding a parade without being chased or attacked by right-wing opponents. But the march, in Kiev, was guarded by police and security forces who sealed off much of the city center and warned participants not to linger afterward.

headline: Review: Alien Ants Become Washington Insiders in ‘BrainDead’
abstract: After a meteor strike, insects from outer space crawl into the ears of government officials and ... transform them.
lead_paragraph: Momentous elections turn on momentous questions. In 2016 the question is clear: What has gotten into people’s heads?

headline: Review: A Dark, Haunting Work by Michael Hersch Gets a Premiere
abstract: Mr. Hersch’s “a breath upwards” takes its inspiration from Dante’s “Inferno” and the etchings of Michael Mazur.
lead_paragraph: Dante’s “Inferno” might seem an unlikely inspiration for an artist trying to escape illness and loss. But the composer Michael Hersch saw hell as a point of departure when writing “a breath upwards,” which received its New York premiere at Saint Peter’s Church in Manhattan on Friday evening, presented by Lex54 Concerts.

headline: New Chapter for Classic Paris Bookstore: Books Printed on Demand
abstract: Les Puf, which shut about 10 years ago because of falling profits and soaring rent, has a new location and business model: books printed before customers’ eyes in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Gauthier Charrier, a graphic design student, stepped inside one of Paris’s newest bookstores and wondered, “Where are all the books?”

headline: Review: NY Phil Biennial’s Ambitious Wrap-Up, From Boulez to Bolcom
abstract: The New York Philharmonic’s citywide festival ended with challenging programs, including pieces by composers vital to the orchestra’s recent past.
lead_paragraph: From the start, Alan Gilbert conceived the NY Phil Biennial as a citywide festival, not a New York Philharmonic showcase. Both New York and international ensembles would perform works by composers young and old in spaces small and large. This year’s ambitious biennial, the second, followed that template, opening May 23 with the JACK Quartet playing premieres in an intimate hall at the 92nd Street Y.

headline: The National Tragedy in Orlando
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Sampling early reactions to “this horrific event.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Year After American Pharoah’s Triumph, an Exciting Belmont Is a Letdown
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Nyquist (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Belmont Stakes']
abstract: Saturday’s race featured a photo finish but lacked a great deal of consequence after Nyquist showed he did not have the talent and luck of American Pharoah.
lead_paragraph: It was hard during Saturday’s Belmont Stakes not to think about American Pharoah, the colt who a year ago delivered a historic performance at the race in becoming just the 12th Triple Crown winner ever and horse racing’s first in 37 years.

headline: Gun Deaths Today Surpass Those In Our Bloodiest War
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Gun Control', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: Examining gun violence in the Civil War and today.
lead_paragraph: When 50 people were shot and killed early Sunday morning at a gay nightclub in Orlando, the toll from gun murders this year rose to somewhere around 6,000 deaths, which means if the trend continues, this year may end up with the highest gun homicide count since Barack Obama took office in 2009. Add to the homicide number the 550 or so victims of police shootings, roughly the same number of accidental gun deaths and the 21,000+ Americans who use a gun to end their own lives, and the total gun mortality number this year may go above 35,000.

headline: Orlando Gunman Used Assault Rifle With Military Roots, Police Say
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Firearms', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The police said the nightclub gunman carried a Sig Sauer MCX assault rifle, the civilian version of a weapon widely used in military service.
lead_paragraph: A firearm that the authorities said was used on Sunday in a mass shooting at a nightclub in Orlando, Fla., is a descendant of one of the world’s most widely distributed and familiar infantry weapons, and a type of rifle that has been involved in previous mass shootings in the United States.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of June 13
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Horseplay
abstract: What, exactly, is Lynn Lempel suggesting?
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Although I enjoyed myself immensely FOOLING AROUND with Lynn Lempel’s puzzle, one question kept bouncing off the insides of my skull: Who is DUNCAN PHYFE, and can someone be “iconic” if I’ve never heard of him?

headline: With Manager Terry Collins Ailing, Mets Fall to the Brewers
abstract: Starter Steven Matz struggles, but he gets little support in the field or at the plate, as the Mets head home after a 5-5 trip.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Mets Manager Terry Collins appeared perfectly fine about two and a half hours before Sunday’s game at Miller Park. Speaking to reporters in his office, Collins reviewed his limited options off the bench: Second baseman Neil Walker (stiff back) and outfielder Michael Conforto (sore wrist) were not starting, and Collins hoped to give shortstop Asdrubal Cabrera his first complete day off this season.

headline: Tigers Pitcher Michael Fulmer Drops Yankees Back Under .500
abstract: Fulmer extended his scoreless innings streak to 28.1 and won his fifth in a row.
lead_paragraph: The rookie right-hander Michael Fulmer, a former Mets prospect who was sent to the Tigers’ system last season as part of a trade for Yoenis Cespedes, dominated the crosstown Yankees Sunday in Detroit’s 4-1 victory at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Bernie Sanders Refuses to Concede Nomination to Hillary Clinton
abstract: Mr. Sanders told reporters at his home in Vermont that he had no intention of leaving the race, though he did recognize the long odds he faced.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders said on Sunday that he would “take our campaign for transforming the Democratic Party into the convention,” refusing to concede the presidential nomination to Hillary Clinton though not explicitly saying he would challenge her for it.

headline: The Week Ahead: Apple to Woo Developers, and Fed to Hold Monthly Meeting
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Consumer Price Index', 'Electronic Entertainment Expo (E3)']
abstract: The Worldwide Developers Conference is scheduled in San Francisco and China awaits a decision that could add its domestic shares to a major global stock index.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at the week ahead:

headline: A Victim Looks Back on a Crime With Hope, Not Fear
abstract: A suspect’s arrest reminds an aging actor of his quick reaction during an attempted break-in in Greenwich Village in 2013.
lead_paragraph: A detective called Tom Ligon last month with the news. There had been an arrest in his case, three years later.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Work to Stanch Loss of Investors
abstract: As funds continue to falter, some managers are negotiating with investors to retain them, and offering newcomers terms that were once just for longtime clients.
lead_paragraph: Hedge fund titans once ran their firms like elite private clubs, picking who made it past the velvet rope and how much they would pay for access to supercharged performance.

headline: Sentencing Memo in Stanford Rape Case
abstract: A memo prepared by the district attorney's office in Santa Clara County, Calif., describing its sentencing recommendations in the case against Brock Turner, who had been convicted of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: A memo prepared by the district attorney's office in Santa Clara County, Calif., describing its sentencing recommendations in the case against Brock Turner, who had been convicted of sexual assault.

headline: Brock Turner Sentencing Packet
abstract: The report from a probation officer in the case against Mr. Turner, the Stanford student who was convicted of three felonies in connection with a sexual assault in January 2015.
lead_paragraph: The report from a probation officer in the case against Mr. Turner, the Stanford student who was convicted of three felonies in connection with a sexual assault in January 2015.

headline: Court Papers Give Insight Into Stanford Sex Assault
abstract: In a case that legal experts say was unusual, the newly released court documents outline the intense national debate over Brock Turner’s sentencing.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Proud parents converged at Stanford University’s commencement on Sunday to hear Ken Burns, the documentary filmmaker, welcome the elite class of graduates into the wider world.

headline: The Colombian Hit Man Who Became a YouTube Star
keywords: ['Drug Cartels', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: John Jairo Velásquez, an ex-enforcer for the Medellín drug cartel, has gained 9.5 million views since he began posting about his past misdeeds.
lead_paragraph: Imagine if the former Mafia boss John Gotti, who went to prison for murder and cultivated the public’s fascination with his flamboyant New York lifestyle and menacing charm, had a YouTube channel.

headline: Tonys Red Carpet 2016
abstract: Broadway’s biggest stars arrived for the 2016 Tony Awards on Sunday night at the Beacon Theater. Here are the arrivals.
lead_paragraph: Broadway’s biggest stars arrived for the 2016 Tony Awards on Sunday night at the Beacon Theater. Here are the arrivals.

headline: Photos: The Arrivals at the 2016 Tony Awards Red Carpet
abstract: It was a somber and slight surreal evening as Broadway’s finest like Sophie Okonedo, Michelle Williams and Cate Blanchett walked the red carpet in the wake of the massacre in Orlando, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Broadway’s biggest stars arrived for the 2016 Tony Awards on Sunday night at the Beacon Theater. The red carpet was gusty (“A wind tunnel,” as the “Girls” actor Andrew Rannells described it), but the mood was solemn in the wake of the mass shooting in Orlando, Fla. The most common accessory was a silver ribbon, worn in memory of the victims.

headline: Canadian Neighborhood Rots in the Shadow of an Unborn Bridge to Detroit
abstract: A long battle between Canadian officials and the owner of the Ambassador Bridge over who will build a second bridge to Detroit has resulted in 100 boarded-up houses in Windsor, Ontario.
lead_paragraph: WINDSOR, Ontario — It is a postapocalyptic streetscape that most Canadians associate with American cities like Detroit: boarded-up houses, burned-out roofs, a mess of scattered shingles, peeling paint and crumbling masonry. In some abandoned homes, the only residents are skunks, raccoons, rats and feral cats.

headline: Anemic New York Legislature May Be More Active at End of Session
keywords: ['State Legislatures', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Fantasy Sports', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Minimum Wage']
abstract: Last-minute agreements could produce laws tightening opiate prescriptions, extending the mayor’s control of New York City schools and allowing Uber and Lyft to expand.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — For skeptics of the chronically criticized members of the New York State Legislature, the 2016 legislative session has often seemed in danger of becoming what some Albany watchdogs used to call a “Seinfeld session” — all about nothing.

headline: In the General Mills Cupboard
abstract: In honor of its 150th anniversary, the world’s sixth-largest food company allowed a peek at some of its artifacts, like the first clay animation models of Poppin’ Fresh, the Pillsbury Doughboy.
lead_paragraph: In honor of its 150th anniversary, the world’s sixth-largest food company allowed a peek at some of its artifacts, like the first clay animation models of Poppin’ Fresh, the Pillsbury Doughboy.

headline: When the Lone Ranger and Gracie Allen Pitched Their Sponsors’ Products
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Slogans and Mottoes', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: For its 150th anniversary, General Mills showed off selected items in its 3,000-square-foot archive, highlighting its brands’ impact on pop culture.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — On a recent episode of his late-night show, Stephen Colbert poured himself a bowl of Lucky Charms cereal and then doused it in Baileys Irish Cream, jokingly referring to the concoction as an Irish continental breakfast.

headline: North Dakotans Reconsider a Corporate Farming Ban, and Their Values
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Referendums', 'Family Business', 'Dairy Products', 'Law and Legislation', 'Ranches']
abstract: With Tuesday’s vote on whether to allow corporations to own farms, North Dakota confronts a vexing question: preserve its heritage of family farms or adapt to stay competitive.
lead_paragraph: WING, N.D. — The Wagner family farmstead in central North Dakota could have been lifted from a Grant Wood painting: bales of hay rest on a gently sloping hill, cattle graze near a bright blue pond, green tendrils of durum and sunflowers peek out of the dirt.

headline: A Computer Security Start-Up Turns the Tables on Hackers
abstract: Area 1 Security heads off cyberattacks by tapping into servers known to be compromised by hackers, and monitoring the attackers’ activities.
lead_paragraph: Standing before a crowded room of entrepreneurs and investors at a conference in San Francisco last summer, former Vice President Al Gore described how climate change could be contained, possibly even reversed.

headline: Tony Award Winners
abstract: A list of winners from the 70th annual Tony Awards.
lead_paragraph: [ Our complete coverage of the Tony Awards ]

headline: Mrs. Sprat’s Ultimate Demise at Katz’s Deli
abstract: Exercise and dieting were no match for an invitation to the famous kosher delicatessen in the Lower East Side.

headline: Warriors’ Draymond Green Suspended for Game 5 After LeBron James Episode
abstract: After reviewing the game, the N.B.A. assessed a flagrant foul against Green for striking James in the groin. That call triggered the punishment because of other playoff violations by Green.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The Golden State Warriors were practicing Sunday when they learned that one of their most important pieces would be absent from Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals on Monday.

headline: Gawker’s General Counsel Takes On a Leadership Role
keywords: ['Bankruptcies', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'News and News Media', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Heather Dietrick, president and general counsel of Gawker Media, has taken a prominent role in dealing with a legal judgment, bankruptcy and sale.
lead_paragraph: Heather Dietrick, Gawker Media’s president and general counsel, has always been close to her 90-year-old grandfather, a prisoner of war during World War II who, she said, “has taught me a lot about fielding a lot of situations.”

headline: Andrew Cuomo’s Anti-Free Speech Move on B.D.S.
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Boycotts', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: In trying to support Israel, the New York governor is restricting people’s rights.
lead_paragraph: IN 1985, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed that New York State divest of its billions of dollars in investments in companies that did business with South Africa “to demonstrate,” he declared, “the abhorrence of our residents to the pernicious system of apartheid.” An opponent of Mr. Cuomo’s plan, the state comptroller, Edward V. Regan, told The New York Times, “We’re not in the foreign-policy business.”

headline: Bill Simmons Prepares to Stand Up to Sports Incorporated
abstract: The influential sportswriter and commentator, who was fired from ESPN after making incendiary remarks concerning the National Football League, begins a new show on HBO on June 22.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Corporate media giants always want what’s cool and edgy until what’s cool and edgy threatens the status quo that keeps the billions flooding in.

headline: A London Subway Experiment: Please Don’t Walk Up the Escalator
abstract: Officials seeking to address overcrowding have asked people at one station to stand side by side on escalators, instead of leaving room for walking, which causes backups.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Perhaps it is all the tourists — 18.6 million international visitors to London last year, a record. Perhaps it is the gradual “Europeanization” of Britain. And perhaps it is just something to do with the blocked traffic on these ancient streets and all the diesel fumes in the air.

headline: At Euro, Fights Keep the Focus Off the Field, a Day After an Alarming Melee
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Assaults', 'UEFA European Football Championship']
abstract: Clashes on Saturday between Russia and England fans and on Sunday between Germany and Ukraine fans continued a wave of violence at the European Championships in France.
lead_paragraph: VILLENEUVE-D’ASCQ, France — An early flurry of memorable goals at the European Championships has been overshadowed by disturbing scenes of fan violence in multiple cities, leading the police to ask for greater resources, the tournament’s organizers to open disciplinary proceedings and the French government on Sunday to ban alcohol sales near stadiums for the duration of the event.

headline: A Game of Musical Chairs, Played With Schools, Divides the Upper West Side
abstract: The city’s Education Department has proposed a convoluted plan to shift students and school buildings in the Manhattan neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: It started as a fairly simple proposition: There were two schools on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, one overcrowded, the other underused. The city’s Education Department proposed to redraw the schools’ attendance zone so that some blocks assigned to the crowded school would be shifted to the emptier one.

headline: As Orlando Grieves, Enduring Questions About Guns and Terror Reverberate
abstract: The gun purchases of the ISIS sympathizer identified as the shooter in Orlando chillingly echo a scenario described by President Obama.
lead_paragraph: Update, June 14 | Read Michael Luo’s Times article: “Orlando Aftermath: Red Flags, Yet Legally Able to Buy a Gun,” to get a feel for how individuals suspected of instability, allegiance to terrorists or threatening behavior can buy guns.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, June 13, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I saw bodies on the floor, people on the floor everywhere. It was a chaos, everybody trying to get out.”

headline: Tickets on Phones? It’s a Big Hang-Up for Some Yankee Fans
abstract: The myriad problems fans are experiencing as they adjust to a new team policy banning print-at-home tickets are producing a long line at the customer service window before each game.
lead_paragraph: When the Yankees announced that they were overhauling their ticketing system this season — introducing mobile ticketing and no longer accepting print-at-home tickets — they said it was to enhance the fan experience.

headline: At Stonewall Inn, a Gay Rights Landmark, a Vigil in Pride and Anger
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Stonewall Riots (1969)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Hundreds of people swarmed Christopher Street in New York in reaction to the mass killing in Orlando, Fla., some to say they would never be silenced again.
lead_paragraph: The red brick facade of the Stonewall Inn has served as the backdrop to countless passages in the history of the gay rights movement.

headline: A Push to Improve Welfare of Horse Racing’s Involuntary Heroes
abstract: Thanks in part to social media, the casual fan is taking an active interest in how equine athletes are treated. Their concerns are compelling some forces within the sport to make reforms.
lead_paragraph: Last year at this time, the thoroughbred horse racing community and casual racing fans alike were riding the high of a milestone: American Pharoah had won the Belmont Stakes to become the first horse in 37 years to complete the Triple Crown.

headline: Was Orlando Shooter Really Acting for ISIS? For ISIS, It’s All the Same
abstract: The terror group has blurred the line between operations planned and carried out by its core fighters and those carried out by its sympathizers.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The revelation that the 29-year-old man who opened fire on Sunday in a gay nightclub had dedicated the killing to the Islamic State has prompted a now-familiar question: Was the killer truly acting under orders from the Islamic State, or just seeking publicity and the group’s approval for a personal act of hate?

headline: Blue Coat to Sell Itself to Symantec, Abandoning I.P.O. Plans
abstract: The $4.65 billion deal will create a big provider of security products, to be helmed by Blue Coat’s chief executive.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Blue Coat Systems seemed poised to begin life as a public company, after selling itself to a private equity firm last year.

headline: Orlando Attack Roils Gay Community, Painfully Accustomed to Violence
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Gay Americans, and those working to advance their rights, spent Sunday grappling with the implications of the mass shooting at a gay nightclub.
lead_paragraph: At 3 o’clock in the morning on Sunday, Benjamin Newbern, a gay rights activist in northern Alabama, arrived home from a gay pride dance party he had organized, glanced at his cellphone and spotted an unsettling social media post: “Prayers for our brothers and sisters at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando.”

headline: Omar Mateen: From Early Promise to F.B.I. Surveillance
abstract: The Orlando gunman’s life once seemed to be on a successful track, but he became the subject of investigations and allegations of abuse.
lead_paragraph: FORT PIERCE, Fla. — Omar Mateen’s life seemed to be on a successful trajectory a decade before he carried out one of the worst cases of mass murder in American history.

headline: Lin-Manuel Miranda’s Sonnet From the Tony Awards
abstract: When Mr. Miranda accepted his award for best score for “Hamilton” at the Tony Awards, he said he was too old to freestyle. He wrote a sonnet instead.
lead_paragraph: Whether Lin-Manuel Miranda is standing with President Obama in the Rose Garden or accepting a Grammy Award onstage, he is known to give his audience a freestyle rap fit for the occasion.

headline: As Yankees Honor the Past on Old-Timers’ Day, Their Prospects Look Murky
abstract: Their pitchers give them a reasonable chance to win most games, leaving the team hopeful, but their offense is a question mark.
lead_paragraph: One man in pinstripes hit a home run on Sunday at Yankee Stadium: Hideki Matsui, who belted a David Cone pitch into the second deck inside the right-field foul pole on Old-Timers’ Day. Matsui turned 42 on Sunday, still younger than Bartolo Colon and Ichiro Suzuki. But he is not coming back to save his old team.

headline: In 6 Hours, 4 Are Killed in Separate Shootings in New York City
abstract: The attacks in the Bronx and Brooklyn late Saturday and early Sunday were a reminder that violent pockets remain in the city, even as it has grown safer.
lead_paragraph: Four people were killed in separate shootings across New York City late Saturday and early Sunday, the police said.

headline: Mexico’s Soccer Coach Climbs Ladder of Success, a Rung at a Time
abstract: Juan Carlos Osorio, and inquisitive and hungry understudy when he was younger, used a small team on Staten Island as a springboard to a decorated career.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — The man who has guided Mexico to international soccer’s longest current unbeaten streak began his coaching career with a small club on Staten Island.

headline: Why the Orlando Shooting Was So Deadly
abstract: The mass shooting at an Orlando nightclub early Sunday was the deadliest in United States history. One out of every three people at the crowded Pulse nightclub was killed or injured.
lead_paragraph: The mass shooting at an Orlando nightclub early Sunday was the deadliest in United States history. One out of every three people at the crowded Pulse nightclub was killed or injured.

headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Season 3, Episode 8: Erlich’s Charade
abstract: His separation from the group this season has given “Silicon Valley” a more varied dynamic, where success and failure can coexist.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the quintessential shot of Erlich Bachman pops up near the end of “Bachman’s Earning’s Over-Ride,” in the moments after the self-styled tech visionary has finally hit bottom. As the Pied Piper team celebrates 100,000 installs in 10 days and smiting its nemeses at Hooli, Erlich sits alone on the back porch, smoking weed out of a formal glass pipe. We’ve seen him inhale through many vessels, so the choice of bong is significant: This is Erlich at his most distinguished and professorial, looking one tweed jacket away from a tenured position at Sarah Lawrence. He is an absurd man who longs to be taken seriously.

headline: Walgreens Cuts Ties to Blood-Testing Company Theranos
abstract: In another blow to Theranos, the embattled blood-testing company, Walgreens said it would no longer offer its laboratory services in 40 of its stores.
lead_paragraph: Walgreens said on Sunday that it was terminating its relationship with Theranos, dealing a severe blow to the embattled blood-testing company. Walgreens said it would immediately close all 40 of the Theranos testing centers in its Arizona drugstores, the source of most of Theranos’s customers.

headline: Penguins Finish Off Sharks to Win Stanley Cup
abstract: Pittsburgh won its second Stanley Cup in eight years and fourth in franchise history.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Much of Game 6 of the Stanley Cup finals was part hockey, part speedskating. When it was over on Sunday night, the Pittsburgh Penguins had their second title in eight years and their fourth in franchise history, defeating the San Jose Sharks, 3-1.

headline: ‘Veep’ Season 5, Episode 8: Into the Woods
abstract: International diplomacy aside, in sitcom terms, Sunday’s episode is a classic story of “two dates on the same night.”
lead_paragraph: This week’s “Veep” brings back an old friend, Finnish stateswoman Minna Hakkinen, who in only three episodes — sprinkled across three seasons — has become one of this show’s All-Stars. Give credit to British actress/comedian Sally Phillips, with her clipped, deadpan line readings: so humorously humorless. But tip a cap too to the “Veep” writers, who get why Minna makes such a great foil to Selina Meyer. She’s everything our fictional president is not: rational, good-hearted and comfortable in her own skin. She represents a viable alternative for how a progressive 21st-century leader should be. If Minna Hakkinen existed in the real world, Michael Moore would’ve already made an admiring documentary about her.

headline: The Colors of the Puerto Rican Pride Parade
abstract: The event in New York City had the feeling of a pep rally at times, trying to raise spirits as the the island faces economic struggles.
lead_paragraph: The event in New York City had the feeling of a pep rally at times, trying to raise spirits as the the island faces economic struggles.

headline: Puerto Rican Pride Shines in Parade Despite the Island’s Woes
abstract: The event in New York City was an opportunity to support the island at a time when it is struggling with more than $70 billion in debt.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico may be in an economic tailspin, but the 59th annual Puerto Rican Day Parade was a moment to celebrate the island’s joys.

headline: A Day of Mourning for the Gay Community
abstract: In support of the victims of the massacre at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla., hundreds gathered outside the Stonewall Inn in New York, where a riot in 1969 helped launch the gay rights movement.
lead_paragraph: In support of the victims of the massacre at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla., hundreds gathered outside the Stonewall Inn in New York, where a riot in 1969 helped launch the gay rights movement.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | truculence
abstract: This word has appeared in eight New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: truculence • \ˈtrə-kyə-lən(t)s also ˈtrü-\ • noun

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 6, Episode 8: I’m Still Me
abstract: Jaime and Brienne reunited. The Hound sought revenge. Things got complicated for Cersei.
lead_paragraph: So it turns out everything with Arya was more or less what it appeared to be last week.

headline: The Tonys: A Polished Night of Selling Broadway, With Nods to a Tragedy
abstract: The host, James Corden, began the show with a short tribute to the mass shooting in Orlando, Fla., and a salute to the inclusiveness of the theater world.
lead_paragraph: Faced with broadcasting an all-singing, all-dancing, happy-faced celebration of art and commerce less than 24 hours after the deadliest mass shooting in American history, CBS did about what you’d expect. The Tony Awards broadcast on Sunday night began with the host, James Corden, standing on the bare stage of the Beacon Theater, his back to the house, delivering a short and careful tribute to the victims of the massacre at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla.

headline: 49 Lives Lost to Horror in Orlando: Mostly Young, Gay and Latino
abstract: Family members and loved ones of those lost in the massacre gathered Monday to hear the names of the dead read aloud.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Louis Omar Ocasio-Capo was 20, worked at a Starbucks in a Target store, and lived to dance. Stanley Almodovar III, a 23-year-old pharmacy technician, had posted a Snapchat video of himself singing and laughing on his way to the Pulse nightclub on Saturday. Eric Ivan Ortiz-Rivera, 36, nicknamed Shaki, had been married to his husband for about a year, worked at a Party City and a Sunglass Hut, and was entranced by interior design.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: “BrainDead,” a comedy from “The Good Wife” creators, explains what’s gotten into politicians. And Sheridan Smith channels the ’60s singer Cilla Black.
lead_paragraph: Finally, an explanation for what’s going on this politician season in “BrainDead,” a new sci-fi comedy from Robert and Michelle King of “The Good Wife.” And Sheridan Smith, the British actress, channels the 1960s pop singer Cilla Black.

headline: Ernie Els’s Inner Voice Was Quieted When His Son Was Slow to Speak
abstract: Els was once viewed as the future of golf, but his son’s autism made him look instead to a better future for children with the condition.
lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — The little evil voice plagued the Big Easy, as if mocking the nickname that had been bestowed upon Ernie Els because of his fluid swing. On bad days, the voice pounded his mind with negative thoughts. Even on Els’s best days, like the Monday playoff in the 1994 United States Open at Oakmont Country Club, the voice cleared its throat on his backswings as he started with a bogey and a triple bogey and found only six fairways before winning on the 20th hole.

headline: The World Could End AIDS if It Tried
abstract: The medicines and know-how are there, but in many countries the money and political will are not.
lead_paragraph: The world has made so much progress in reducing the spread of AIDS and treating people with H.I.V. that the epidemic has receded from the public spotlight. Yet by any measure the disease remains a major threat — 1.1 million people died last year from AIDS-related causes, and 2.1 million people were infected with the virus. And while deaths are down over the last five years, the number of new infections has essentially reached a plateau.

headline: Orlando Gunman Was ‘Cool and Calm’ After Massacre, Police Say
abstract: The Orlando police chief offered new details on the worst shooting in United States history, and other officials said that all but one of the 49 victims had been identified.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The gunman who went on a shooting rampage in a popular gay nightclub here shot nearly all of his victims in the first stages of the assault, then was utterly “cool and calm” while he talked by phone to law enforcement officials about further carnage, claimed allegiance to the Islamic State and praised the Boston Marathon bombers, officials said on Monday.

headline: Teaching and Learning Resources | The Attack in Orlando
abstract: What will be the repercussions from the deadliest mass shooting in U.S. history?
lead_paragraph: Below, we offer some ways to teach and learn about the deadliest mass shooting in U.S. history and the questions it raises.

headline: Soccer’s Zlatan Ibrahimovic Heads Onto the Fashion Field
abstract: The Swede explains why he dreams of being the Rick Owens of athleisure.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Last week, the international soccer star Zlatan Ibrahimovic, captain of the Swedish national team, scheduled a news conference in Paris at precisely 5 p.m., three days before the start of the European Championship in France. Speculation began that the 34-year-old Swedish striker, who last month quit Paris St.-Germain of Ligue 1 after four seasons, was going to announce that he had signed with Manchester United in the English Premier League, a major score in professional soccer. But in Zlatan style, he zigged instead of zagged and faked them all out.

headline: Which Labor Market Data Should You Believe?
abstract: Two important measures of how the job market is doing seem to point in opposite directions.
lead_paragraph: When the unemployment rate falls below 5 percent, it usually means things are going pretty well. It was 4.7 percent in May, a level last seen in November 2007.

headline: A Haven for New York Relics Saved From the Trash Heap. In Connecticut.
abstract: The collector Evan Blum has one of the largest troves of architectural artifacts salvaged from the city’s buildings, in a quiet village a two-hour drive away.
lead_paragraph: IVORYTON, Conn. — If New York had an attic, it could well be the sprawling complex of old brick buildings on Main Street in this sleepy village, a two-hour drive northeast of the city.

headline: ‘Sex Object: A Memoir’ and ‘Shrill: Notes From a Loud Woman’
abstract: Two books examine sexism’s double standards and the rise of online harassment.
lead_paragraph: This past April, editors at The Guardian published the results of a study that analyzed more than 70 million reader comments posted on the news site since 1999. Special attention was paid to the 1.4 million that had been blocked or deleted by moderators for violating community standards. Of the 10 authors who saw the most harassment — whose articles were most routinely met with hostile comments ranging from condescending to life-threatening — eight were women; the two men were black. The No. 1 recipient of such passionate expressions of free speech as “I hope you perish in a gasoline-explosion-­induced car crash” was Jessica Valenti.

headline: Being Transgender as a Fact of Nature
abstract: The current bathroom controversy reflects prejudice and misinformation about people who identify as transgender.
lead_paragraph: In 1952, George Jorgensen, a Bronx-born G.I., underwent surgical and hormonal treatment in Denmark to become Christine Jorgensen, a nightclub entertainer and advocate for gender identity rights. Ever since, health professionals and lay people alike have debated the origins of gender identity, the wisdom of altering one’s biologically determined sex, and whether society should accept the transgender community as a fact of nature.

Brazil’s chaotic and ever-changing political situation, concerns about the Zika virus, security issues: All of these are contributing to trepidation from North Americans, who are reconsidering whether to venture south for the Games.

keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
