headline: Before Orlando, There Was New Orleans
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Hate Crimes']
abstract: Sunday was far from the first time mass murder was visited on America’s L.G.B.T. community.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’s mass murder in Orlando, Fla., was, among other grim superlatives, the worst instance of anti-gay violence in American history. But it was also far from the first. In fact, mass violence and the history of gay liberation go hand in hand.

headline: Lincoln Center Report: We Entertain, Educate, Accept Tax Dollars
abstract: Lincoln Center released a report on how it serves residents and visitors as it prepares to seek city money for renovating David Geffen Hall.
lead_paragraph: Lincoln Center’s organizations spent $785.4 million last season, in large part on the salaries of their 4,547 employees. Their offerings attracted 4.5 million people, a third of whom attended free events. And those ticket buyers from outside the city who said in surveys that visiting Lincoln Center was a “very important reason” for their trips spent an estimated $669 million elsewhere in New York.

headline: Peru Gets Away With a Hand Ball and Eliminates Brazil
abstract: Raúl Ruidíaz batted in the match’s only goal with his arm on Sunday night, ousting Brazil in the group stage of the Copa América.
lead_paragraph: It is the first thing you learn in peewee soccer: Don’t touch the ball with your hand.

headline: 1941: France Relegates Jews in Decree
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Jews and Judaism', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Vichy further relegates Jews in new decree in 1941.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — The status of Jews in France and in French overseas possessions is to be definitely regulated by a decree to take effect immediately. It replaces the provisional law defining the position of Jews in France issued on Oct. 3, 1940, and involves a wide extension of the occupations and callings which Jews are forbidden to pursue. In addition to the fields of journalism, cinema, radio and teaching, the new law prohibits Jews from engaging in banking or brokerage business or any publicity or advertising agents.— New York Herald Tribune, June 14, 1941

headline: Afghanistan and Pakistan Exchange Heavy Gunfire Along Border
abstract: The fighting, which forced the closing of the Torkham crossing, left at least 13 wounded in Pakistan and killed least one Afghan police officer.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Pakistani and Afghan forces exchanged heavy gunfire on Sunday and Monday in an unusually serious escalation of tensions at the border, leaving at least 13 people wounded on the Pakistani side and killing at least one Afghan police officer, according to the police and military officials in both countries.

headline: Keeping an iPhone Online When the Signal Is Weak
abstract: Wi-Fi Assist in iOS 9 can keep your device connected to the internet even when your wireless network signal is wobbly, but you may have to pay for it.
lead_paragraph: Q. Can you tell me how Wi-Fi Assist works and does it use my iPhone data?

headline: The Corrupt Zigzag, an Argentine Dance
abstract: The language almost never changes: The powers that be are corrupt. Throw them out.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina is changing political direction again, in a century-old zigzag from left to right and back. Traumatic though this obsessive ritual is, what is most amazing is that the language almost never changes: The powers that be are corrupt. Throw them out.

headline: Study Calls Snub of Obama’s Supreme Court Pick Unprecedented
abstract: Republicans’ categorical refusal to consider any nominee is new in the nation’s history, two professors said, though a conservative legal writer disagreed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — How unusual is the Republican blockade of the nomination of Judge Merrick B. Garland, President Obama’s pick for the Supreme Court? After a comprehensive look at every past Supreme Court vacancy, two law professors have concluded that it is an unprecedented development.

headline: How Zika Became a Global Threat
keywords: ['Birth Defects', 'Chikungunya Virus', 'Dengue Fever', 'Ebola Virus', 'Epidemics', 'Medicine and Health', 'Microcephaly', 'Research', 'SARS (Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Zika Virus']
abstract: A leading expert traces the history of Zika and explains how the United States should fight the virus.
lead_paragraph: Though the Zika virus was first identified in 1947, little is known about it today. Few researchers have studied the virus because, until the recent outbreak in Latin America, it was not thought to cause serious illness or birth defects. One of the leading scientific experts on Zika is Scott C. Weaver, the director of the Institute for Human Infections and Immunity at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston. In a recent interview, he helped explain how Zika came out of Africa, crossed the Pacific Ocean, came to Brazil and became a dangerous public health threat.

headline: Handful of Advisers Behind Microsoft’s Deal for LinkedIn
abstract: The deal will provide a windfall to Microsoft’s traditional advisers and to boutique investment banks on LinkedIn’s side.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft’s $26.2 billion acquisition of LinkedIn is one of the biggest and most prominent technology deals of the year so far.

headline: Bill Murray to Receive the Mark Twain Prize for Humor
abstract: The “Saturday Night Live” alumnus and comic actor will be presented with the award at the Kennedy Center in October.
lead_paragraph: It’s not easy to forecast where Bill Murray might turn up next: maybe a new Wes Anderson movie, a Netflix Christmas special, a karaoke bar or a kickball game. But it can be more safely said that this unpredictable comic actor will appear at the Kennedy Center in Washington on Oct. 23, when he is presented with its annual Mark Twain Prize for American Humor.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Puerto Rico Law in Debt Restructuring Case
abstract: Justice Clarence Thomas, writing for the majority in a 5-to-2 decision, said the law was at odds with the federal bankruptcy code.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday rejected an effort in Puerto Rico to allow public utilities there to restructure $20 billion in debt, striking down a 2014 Puerto Rico law.

headline: Just Bake

lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: France’s Largest Labor Union May Have Overplayed Its Hand

lead_paragraph: PARIS — There is a back story to the strikes that have made life miserable for millions across France in recent weeks, and it isn’t about high unemployment, immigration or the other issues confronting the country and its increasingly unpopular president, François Hollande.

headline: China’s Call to Young Men: Your Nation Needs Your Sperm
abstract: With sperm banks facing shortages, a government campaign tries to overcome cultural barriers to donation with appeals to patriotism (and some cash).
lead_paragraph: If you’re a man in China between 20 and 45, the government has a message for you: For the sake of your country, please donate sperm.

headline: Jewel-Like Pâtes de Fruits From Locally Grown Berries
abstract: Jellied candies intensely colored and flavored.
lead_paragraph: This collection of intense fruit squares, a confection the French call pâtes de fruits, is from Casey Hickey, a candymaker and chocolatier based in Charlotte, N.C., who studied in Paris. What makes them shine is the fruit she uses, mostly locally grown berries, along with passion fruit, kalamansi and sour cherries. They come in a clear box, lined up in a vibrant gradation of color: Twenty Degrees Chocolates pâtes de fruits, $20 for 12 pieces from mouth.com.

headline: Blaming Muslims After Attack, Donald Trump Tosses Pluralism Aside
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Muslim Americans', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Mr. Trump appeared to broaden his proposed ban on Muslim immigrants, while Hillary Clinton accused him of damaging efforts to defeat terrorism.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump left little doubt on Monday that he intends to run on the same proposals on immigration and terrorism that animated his primary campaign, using his first speech after the massacre in Orlando, Fla., to propose sweeping measures against Muslims that pay little heed to American traditions of pluralism.

headline: Fortnum & Mason Ventures Across the Ocean
abstract: Teas, jams and biscuits from the iconic English purveyor.
lead_paragraph: Founded in 1707 by Hugh Mason, a grocer, and William Fortnum, a royal footman, the English purveyor Fortnum & Mason is famous for its teas, preserves and cookies. For the first time since 1929, some of its products are being sold in America in an exclusive arrangement with Williams-Sonoma. Among the teas are classics like English Breakfast and newer ones like a delicate green Earl Grey. Jams include raspberry, strawberry and grapefruit, and the standouts in the category of biscuits, which we call cookies, are chocolate-macadamia nut, chocolate-dipped, and pistachio with clotted cream. The company’s lavish gift assortments in wicker hampers are also available, and in late fall, there will be Christmas puddings: Fortnum & Mason, Williams-Sonoma stores, williams-sonoma.com.

headline: Which Headlines Attract Most Readers?
abstract: Mark Bulik, a senior editor, shares insight into tests designed to see which headlines attract more readers.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece, Mark Bulik, a senior editor, writes about recent tests designed to see what kind of headlines attract most readers.

headline: 1916: Rush to Name the President
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Rush to renominate President Wilson at the Democratic Convention in 1916.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Delegates to the Democratic National Convention which assembles tomorrow [June 14] in St. Louis are pouring into that city today, and, despite the fact that the gathering will simply resolve itself into a Wilson ratification meeting, the indications are that it will be one of the greatest gatherings in the history of the Democratic party. Governor Fielder, of New Jersey, which is President Wilson’s home state, arrived in St. Louis this evening, and he voiced the feelings of Democratic national leaders when he said that ‘‘President Wilson will be renominated and re-elected because he has fully measured up to the requirements of his great office.—The New York Herald, European Edition, June 14, 1916

headline: The Watermelon as Centerpiece
abstract: A tabletop candle for summertime.
lead_paragraph: A hefty wedge of watermelon can glow on a summertime table or a picnic at the beach. The candle, from an Australian company that specializes in warm-weather accessories, has a mild watermelon scent, which I didn’t mind: Watermelon Candle, $32, Annie’s Blue Ribbon General Store, 232 Fifth Avenue (President Street), Park Slope, Brooklyn, 718-522-9848, blueribbongeneralstore.com.

headline: A Brief History of Attacks at Gay and Lesbian Bars
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Gay and lesbian bars and clubs have often been sanctuaries. Sometimes those sanctuaries have come under siege.
lead_paragraph: The lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community is no stranger to  violence.

headline: 3 New Heirloom Breads From La Brea Bakery
abstract: Using wheat from Montana, with grains including emmer, rye or wheat berries.
lead_paragraph: La Brea Bakery has started using heirloom wheat called fortuna in three new breads it has brought together as La Brea Bakery Reserve. The breads are struan, made with some emmer and spelt and dusted with sesame seeds; pain de campagne, with a crisp crust and great complexity from rye; and fortuna, somewhat denser and riddled with cracked wheat berries. Dean Folkvord, head of Wheat Montana, the grower near Big Sky, said the grain is cultivated on a high plateau from tall stalks, making it more difficult to harvest: La Brea Bakery Reserve, $8 to $10, amazonfresh.com.

headline: The Dual Roles of Money
abstract: Money can be tracked logically on a spreadsheet, but it’s important to understand our emotional response to money as well.
lead_paragraph: Money is an interesting actor that plays two roles in our lives.

headline: Travel Problems
abstract: Three logical challenges to bring on your next vacation.
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenges were suggested by Laura Feiveson, an M.I.T.-trained economist at the Federal Reserve and regular Numberplay contributor. Laura’s an expert at bringing out unexpected twists in classic puzzles, and I’m looking forward to seeing what emerges this week. Let’s join Laura with —

headline: Nakiri, a Japanese Knife Designed for Vegetables
abstract: The nakiri’s blade is optimal for slicing, peeling and chopping.
lead_paragraph: I treasure my Japanese nakiri knife. The blade is rectangular, making it like a cross between a chef’s knife and a light cleaver, and thinner than a standard chef’s knife, all the better for juliennes. And it efficiently scoops up whatever you have cut. The knife is designed for vegetables, and in summer, with fresh zucchini, cucumbers, tomatoes, peppers and herbs, it’s a must-have for slicing, peeling and chopping. Wüsthof, the German knifemaker, has introduced hollow-edge nakiris in two sizes: 5-inch with the standard classic handle, and 7-inch in three styles: classic, gourmet and a curved-handle version called classic ikon (shown): Wüsthof nakiri knives, $79.95 to $159.95, cutleryandmore.com.

headline: Obama Says Orlando Gunman Was Probably a Homegrown Extremist
abstract: The president said that while the gunman appeared to have been inspired by extremist information online, there was no clear evidence he was part of a wider terrorist plot.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Monday that while the gunman in the Orlando massacre had declared allegiance to the Islamic State and appeared to have been inspired by extremist information on the internet, there was no clear evidence that he had been part of a wider plot directed by the terrorist group.

headline: Microsoft and Apple Making Headlines
abstract: Microsoft’s planned acquisition of LinkedIn and Apple’s developer conference were the talk of tech on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The technology industry is kicking off this week’s news with a flurry of action.

headline: Lebanese Designer Brings Traditional Materials Into Modern Age
abstract: In two shows in Paris, Karen Chekerdjian addresses the divide between art and function, and the gap between Western and Arab cultures.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The designer Karen Chekerdjian is known in her native Lebanon for modernist objects made with traditional materials and techniques. Now, two exhibitions in Paris — at the Institut du Monde Arabe and at the private Dutko Gallery — offer a close look at an artist who addresses the divide between art and function, and the wider gap between Western and Arab cultures.

headline: Black Pasta, but Not From Squid Ink
abstract: This noodle is made from beans and is gluten free.
lead_paragraph: Pasta colored black with cuttlefish ink is handsome and delicious, but perhaps not for everyone. Now a company that specializes in legume and rice-based products has introduced black bean pasta that tastes mild, looks stunning and is gluten free. Use it for your next cacio e pepe. They call it spaghetti, though it is more angel hair: Explore Cuisine Organic Black Bean Spaghetti, $30 for six 8-ounce packages, explorecuisine.com.

headline: Britain’s ‘Brexit’ Debate Inflamed by Worries That Turkey Will Join E.U.
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Visas', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The possibility of Turkish membership, however remote, has injected issues of race, religion and tolerance into campaigns leading up to the June 23 vote on whether to stay in the bloc.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With nine days left before Britain votes on whether to remain in the European Union, the possibility of Turkey’s becoming a member of the bloc has inflamed the debate, injecting divisive issues of race, religion and tolerance openly into the campaign.

headline: Is Stephen Curry Changing Basketball, or Just Owning It?
abstract: Purists are left to wonder if the Warriors guard is a unique talent, or a model for future N.B.A. offenses.
lead_paragraph: At the outset of the N.B.A. finals, Adam Silver, the league’s commissioner, paid tribute to Stephen Curry by comparing him to, of all people, Roger Bannister.

headline: Apple Developer Conference: A More Open Siri, and Other Upgrades
abstract: Apple announced new features for the operating systems running its products, reflecting pressure to improve its software and services as hardware sales slow.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Steven P. Jobs ran Apple, the company’s devices were distinguished by their polished software and famous iTunes store. Today, critics and even loyal fans are taking shots at Apple’s buggy software and Apple Music, its new streaming music service.

headline: Comparing Gun Deaths by Country: The U.S. Is in a Different World
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Firearms', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: In most advanced countries, gun homicides are as rare as deaths from falling tree limbs or plane crashes.
lead_paragraph: Gun homicides are a common cause of death in the United States, killing about as many people as car crashes (not counting van, truck, motorcycle or bus accidents).

headline: Highlights from the 2016 Tony Awards
abstract: The musical “Hamilton” fell one Tony shy of breaking the record number of awards in a show that opened with a message of condolence and hope over the massacre in Orlando, Fla.
lead_paragraph: The musical “Hamilton” fell one Tony shy of breaking the record number of awards in a show that opened with a message of condolence and hope over the massacre in Orlando, Fla.

headline: Talking About the Orlando Gunman
abstract: Early on June 12, Omar Mateen entered the nightclub Pulse and opened fire, killing 49 and wounding dozens. Family members and others who knew Mr. Mateen are opening up about him.
lead_paragraph: Early on June 12, Omar Mateen entered the nightclub Pulse and opened fire, killing 49 and wounding dozens. Family members and others who knew Mr. Mateen are opening up about him.

headline: Start-Ups Selling Seats on Private Jets Don’t Always Make It
abstract: With so many companies in the private aviation world, travelers can have difficulty telling the difference between stable and shaky companies.
lead_paragraph: Dannel Schwartz was agonizing over his wife’s 60th birthday gift when she proposed an idea herself.

headline: Tonys Draw Almost 9 Million Viewers to CBS
abstract: The broadcast, which rode on the popularity of “Hamilton,” also came on the heels of a mass shooting in Orlando; the host said, “Hate will never win.”
lead_paragraph: The Tony Awards ceremony had its highest ratings in 15 years on Sunday night, with nearly nine million viewers tuning in to CBS.

headline: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton’s Speeches: What You Missed
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Mr. Trump, the presumed Republican presidential nominee, spoke about terrorism and national security in New Hampshire after Mrs. Clinton, the presumptive Democratic nominee, also spoke, a day after the deadly shootings in Orlando, Fla.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump addressed the massacre in Orlando, Fla., on Monday, one day after the deadliest mass shooting in American history, as part of a broader national security speech in Manchester, N.H., where he  also contrasted himself with Hillary Clinton.

headline: Search Is On for King Henry I, Who May Be Buried Under a Parking Lot
abstract: Nearly four years after archaeologists discovered King Richard III’s grave under a parking lot, experts are hoping to find the remains of Henry under another one.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Looking for a dead medieval king? You might want to check under a parking lot.

headline: Drake and Beyoncé Get New Company on the Chart: Paul Simon
abstract: “Stranger to Stranger” debuted at Mr. Simon’s highest position since “Graceland.”
lead_paragraph: Drake’s “Views” is No. 1 for a sixth straight week on the Billboard album chart, as the album continues to post huge streaming numbers even as its CD and download sales plunge.

headline: Readers’ Reactions
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Zoos', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'War and Revolution', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder']
abstract: From gorillas in captivity to the use of painkillers, articles in the Science Times section elicit varied points of view.
lead_paragraph: Zoos

headline: Clark Art Institute Announces New Leader, From Dallas Museum
abstract: Olivier Meslay, a longtime curator at the Dallas Museum of Art, takes over at the Clark after an ambitious transformation of that museum.
lead_paragraph: The Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in the Berkshires has chosen Olivier Meslay, a longtime curator at the Dallas Museum of Art and before that at the Louvre, as its new director, to succeed Michael Conforti, who led the institution for more than 20 years.

headline: A Face-Reading Fish
abstract: The archerfish can obtain food by shooting down insects with jets of water. Now researchers find that they can apparently tell one face from another.
lead_paragraph: The archerfish, two to three inches long, hunts for food by shooting down insects with jets of water. But its real claim to a place in the bizarre behavior hall of fame: The fish can apparently distinguish one human face from another.

headline: At the Tonys, Moments to Remember
abstract: Performers struck a balance between joy and sober reflection, with occasional flashes of humor, at the awards on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: In a Tony Awards night shadowed by the tragedy in Orlando, Fla., prizewinners and other performers worked hard to strike a balance between joy and reflection. Here are some moments to remember:

headline: What You Should Watch: ‘BrainDead,’ ‘Orange Is the New Black’ and ‘Mr. Robot’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small, famous and esoteric, to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. Our most recent suggestions also appear below. To receive our guide straight to your inbox, sign up here.

headline: Men’s Fashion Shows: J.W. Anderson, Wales Bonner, Pieter
abstract: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections, which were presented during London Collections Men on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections, which were presented during London Collections Men on Sunday.

headline: Libyan Fund Claims Goldman Sachs Exploited Its Financial Naïveté
keywords: ['Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds']
abstract: The Libyan Investment Authority claims in a lawsuit that it lost $1.2 billion after it was misled by the Wall street bank about a series of derivatives transactions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After years of international isolation under the rule of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya sought to emulate its Middle Eastern neighbors by creating a sovereign wealth fund in 2006 to invest the proceeds from its sale of oil.

headline: Monumental Piece of the Old, Old City of Petra
abstract: With the help of drones and satellite imagery, archaeologists have discovered a platform about half the size of a football field at Petra in Jordan.
lead_paragraph: Archaeologists have been combing the ancient city of Petra in southern Jordan for at least two centuries. Now, with drones and satellite imagery, they have discovered  new features, including a monumental platform of nearly 30,000 square feet, or roughly half a football field.

headline: Samuel K. Wasser, a Scientific Detective Tailing Poachers
abstract: A conservation biologist discusses his forensic analysis using DNA to determine the origins of seized elephant ivory.
lead_paragraph: Samuel K. Wasser, 62, a zoologist at the University of Washington, is a Sherlock Holmes of the wildlife trade. With modern biochemical tools and old-fashioned shoe leather, he sleuths out the merchants behind the market for poached animal products.

headline: Finra Names Robert Cook Its Chief Executive
abstract: Mr. Cook, a former Securities and Exchange Commission official, will join the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority in the second half of 2016.
lead_paragraph: The brokerage industry’s overseer, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, on Monday named a former markets regulator, Robert W. Cook, as its president and chief executive officer.

headline: In the Studio with Kiko Kostadinov
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: The 26-year-old men’s wear designer brings T into his workspace in Tottenham in advance of his London Collections Men debut.
lead_paragraph: The 26-year-old men’s wear designer brings T into his workspace in Tottenham in advance of his London Collections Men debut.

headline: ‘Swan Lake,’ and Its 32 Fouettés
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: As this ballet returns to American Ballet Theater’s repertory, a signature whiplash turn will have a starring role.
lead_paragraph: “Swan Lake” rejoined American Ballet Theater’s repertory this week — and, with it, the most notorious step in the ballet repertory: the 32 fouetté turns! Odile, the dangerous but seductive antiheroine, returns to the stage near the climax of her grand pas de deux with the hero, Prince Siegfried, and revolves on one leg 32 times. Her raised leg, never touching the ground, provides most of the propulsion. After the first 16 bars, the music changes character; she carries on regardless.

headline: Person to Know: The Men’s Wear Phenom Straight Out of School
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Kiko Kostadinov, who showed his first collection during London Collections Men today, seeks to make elevated workwear for his generation of creative men.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that you get a spot on the London Collections Men schedule straight out of school. Then again, Kiko Kostadinov is far from an average Central Saint Martins student. Though he graduated from the M.A. Fashion course only last month, the 26-year-old men’s wear designer already has a collaboration with Stüssy under his belt, a NEWGEN Men sponsorship — and a yearlong deal to be exclusively stocked at Dover Street Market.

headline: The Muslim Silence on Gay Rights
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Muslim Americans', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Hate Crimes', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: After the Orlando attack, our community has to have some tough conversations.
lead_paragraph: An Afghan-American Muslim walks into a gay club in Florida on Latin night during Pride Month. In my dreams, that is the beginning of another great story of remix, tolerance and coexistence that is possible only in America. In reality, it’s the start of a nightmare massacre fueled by hatred and perpetrated by a man from a group already scarred by a generation of suspicion and surveillance.

headline: Insects Don’t Need Noses to Sense a Stench
abstract: It’s just that their olfactory receptors are essentially on the outside and not inside a collection organ.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do insects sense and process odors?

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | Jason Alexander Reads ‘Just One Last Swirl Around the Bowl’
abstract: Hear the actor read an essay about a man who plays caregiver to his daughter’s dying fish.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode, an encore of the second Modern Love podcast, the actor and comedian Jason Alexander (“Seinfeld,” “Pretty Woman”) reads “Just One Last Swirl Around the Bowl” by Dan Barry.

headline: In Photos: The Tony Awards After-Parties
abstract: The winners and losers (and the host) kept the night going at various after-parties.
lead_paragraph: The winners and losers (and the host) kept the night going at various after-parties.

headline: When Lawyers Testify Against a Client
abstract: The specter of having to disclose confidential information can have a chilling effect on the attorney-client relationship.
lead_paragraph: There may be no more fertile ground for obtaining damaging information in an investigation than from a lawyer about a client. People tend to be more open with their lawyers, or perhaps worse, try to lie to them to use legal advice to keep from getting caught.

headline: Microsoft’s Deal for LinkedIn Raises Red Flags
abstract: The deal has a strategic logic, but its financial benefits are in short supply.
lead_paragraph: Satya Nadella, the Microsoft chief executive, may have abandoned his prudent approach.

headline: Governor Cuomo and the B.D.S. Movement
abstract: Readers variously object to and applaud the New York governor’s action.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Oprah Winfrey, Lin-Manuel Miranda and Other Tony Winners Party All Night
abstract: After the Tony Awards, winners (and losers) went to after-parties at the Plaza Hotel, Tavern on the Green and the Baccarat Hotel.
lead_paragraph: A year after Anna Wintour staged a fashion intervention on Broadway, a decidedly more glamorous crowd headed Sunday night from the Tony Awards to the various after-parties.

headline: Orlando Shooting Reignites Gun Control Debate in Congress
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Senate Democrats moved swiftly to restart the debate, calling for legislation to ban the sale of weapons to people who have been on terrorist watch lists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Orlando, Fla., massacre reignited on Monday the debate over whether Americans like Omar Mateen who have appeared on the government’s terrorist watch lists, or who were otherwise suspected by the authorities of ties to terrorist groups, should be allowed to buy a gun. In Congress, even some supporters of gun rights seemed to be having second thoughts.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | Lauren Molina Reads ‘A Craigslist ‘Missed Connection’ Lure’
abstract: Hear the Broadway actress and musician read the story of a woman who falls for a mysterious stranger.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the first episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, a new weekly series we’ve been working on with WBUR, Boston’s NPR News station. In this week’s episode, Broadway actress and musician Lauren Molina reads “A Craigslist ‘Missed Connection’ Lure” by Rosemary Counter.

headline: When Poverty and Homelessness Are Criminalized
abstract: The group Care for the Homeless writes of a “growing national trend.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Orlando Gunman Was on Terror Watchlist, F.B.I. Director Says
abstract: Omar Mateen was on the list from 2013 to 2014, but investigations did not produce enough evidence to charge him with a crime.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The F.B.I. director said on Monday that the gunman in the mass killing in Orlando was on a terrorist watchlist from 2013 to 2014, but that months of intense investigation into his foreign travels, his inflammatory language with co-workers and his possible motivations did not produce enough evidence to arrest him.

headline: Soccer Player Ratings: ‘The First Thing Anyone Talks About’
abstract: How player ratings are calculated and why they are so popular.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If 11 is soccer’s dominant number — as in, which 11 players should be on the field? — then 10 is its perpetual pursuit. For after every match at the European Championships, or the Champions League, or the Copa América, as well as a vast majority of league matches played around the world, the most pressing question for fans and participants alike is this:

headline: The Secret to Zadie’s Poached Oysters? Seaweed
abstract: The chef Marco Canora offers a buttery nod to a bygone era at his new oyster room in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Marco Canora, the chef at Hearth in the East Village, has been interested for years in the oyster rooms and cellars that used to dominate New York in the 1890s and early 1900s.

headline: Reeling After the Orlando Massacre
abstract: A horrific event leads readers to address homophobia, religious intolerance, a ban on assault weapons and Donald Trump’s reaction.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘It’s Sacred’: A Gay Refuge, Turned Into a War Zone
keywords: ['Hate Crimes', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: To understand the horror of what happened in Orlando, Fla., it helps to understand the role that gay bars play in the history, lives and imagination of gay people.
lead_paragraph: I remember my therapist’s advice when I was a 22-year-old, not yet out-of-the-closet gay man living in Washington — uncertain, unhappy, unready.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Vote Has European Workers in Britain Unsure of Future
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Referendums', 'Foreign Workers', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: If Britain leaves the European Union, visa rules would have a profound impact on employees in the restaurant, hotel and construction industries.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Filipe Graca hovered over an espresso machine at the British food chain Pret A Manger and frothed out a cafe latte for a waiting customer. Until last year, he had struggled to find any kind of a job in his native Portugal. But when he arrived in London, he was able to work almost right away.

headline: In the Kitchen with Chef Corey Lee at In Situ
abstract: SFMoMA’s new restaurant opens this week, offering recreations of some of the world’s best dishes.
lead_paragraph: SFMoMA’s new restaurant opens this week, offering recreations of some of the world’s best dishes.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Enjoys Best Week Ever at the Broadway Box Office
abstract: The hit musical, which won 11 Tony Awards, grossed over $2 million for the first time. “Hamilton” still lags behind the industry leader, “The Lion King.”
lead_paragraph: It turns out that winning 11 Tony Awards wasn’t the only milestone for “Hamilton” on Sunday.

headline: Review: In ‘Animal Kingdom,’ a Crime Family That Surfs and Steals
abstract: Based on a 2010 movie and transplanted from Australia to California with a crime crew of surfing brothers, this TNT drama is “Sons of Anarchy” crossed with “The O.C.”
lead_paragraph: When you’re basing 10 episodes or more of television on a stand-alone two-hour movie, it might be best to heed the lesson of “Fargo”: Throw out the whole story and start over.

headline: Zlatan Ibrahimovic Wills Sweden Forward Once More
abstract: Sweden’s captain delivered a tie against Ireland at the European Championships, which could be his send-off from the biggest stages of international soccer.
lead_paragraph: ST.-DENIS, France — There was the time Zlatan Ibrahimovic suggested that his own dominance sent an entire country (Denmark) into retirement. There was the time he denied rumors he had purchased a Porsche by saying he actually bought a plane because it was “much faster.” There was the time he described an opposing team (Chelsea) as “11 babies.”

headline: Review: ‘Uncle Buck’ Stars Mike Epps in One More Reboot of the Errant Nanny
abstract: This new ABC sitcom shares a lot of DNA with previous comedies in which a hapless uncle takes charge of the children.
lead_paragraph: Even in a year of derivative network-TV ideas — series based on “MacGyver,” “Lethal Weapon” and “The Exorcist” are coming this fall, for starters — ABC’s “Uncle Buck” outdoes itself in doing to death what’s been done and redone.

headline: Review: ‘Wrecked,’ on TBS, Finds Comedy in a Desperate Situation
abstract: This comedy isn’t above lowbrow humor as it melds elements of “Gilligan’s Island” and “Lost.”
lead_paragraph: If you have long complained that “Gilligan’s Island” needed a lot more crotch humor, your voice has finally been heard. “Wrecked,” the latest effort by TBS to secure a lowbrow-humor beachhead, gives us castaways stranded after a plane crash. These thematic grandchildren of the “Gilligan” misfits are noticeably raunchier than their forebears. Or, if you prefer, these thematic children of the “Lost” crowd are noticeably less earnest than John Locke and company.

headline: Some of the World’s Best Dishes — All on One Menu
abstract: At In Situ, his new restaurant at SFMOMA, chef Corey Lee pays tributes to other famous chefs.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, chef Corey Lee strolled through the ground floor of the newly reopened SFMOMA, past one of Richard Serra’s swirling, imposing sculptures, and said: “Whether we like it or not, food has started to occupy a new role as art.” It’s a statement that underlies every aspect of Lee’s new restaurant in the museum, where he will serve not only as chef, but also curator: When it opens tomorrow, In Situ will be a first-of-its kind gallery where diners can order faithfully replicated dishes from restaurants the world over, past and present.

headline: Orlando Aftermath: Red Flags, Yet Legally Able to Buy a Gun
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Gun Control', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Firearms']
abstract: The shooting rampage in Orlando is one case in a familiar pattern where concerns about a person’s behavior are raised, but have not yet been addressed in court.
lead_paragraph: The gunman in a shooting rampage at a Florida nightclub, identified as Omar Mateen, would seem, in retrospect, to have been the kind of person who should not have been able to buy a gun.

headline: Dizzy and Disoriented, With No Cure in Sight
abstract: A diagnosis of vestibular migraine forced the author to choose between living with disabling dizziness or a treatment that triggered disabling nightmares.
lead_paragraph: It started in 2010 when I smoked pot for the first time since college. It was cheap, gristly weed I’d had in my freezer for nearly six years, but four hours after taking one hit I was still so dizzy I couldn’t stand up without holding on to the furniture. The next day I was still dizzy, and the next, and the next, but it tapered off gradually until about a month later I was mostly fine.

headline: A Nigerian Designer, Inspired by Home
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Adebayo Oke-Lawal of the brand Orange Culture seeks to make fashion that caters to a “new generation of African men.”
lead_paragraph: For the 26-year-old Nigerian designer Adebayo Oke-Lawal, whose brand Orange Culture held a presentation in a showroom at London Collections Men this weekend, fashion is a very personal business. “We’re trying to communicate the idea of a new generation of African men,” he told T of the intentions behind his gender-fluid men’s wear line. “As a child growing up, I found I was very lost in trying to figure out who I was as a person. I wanted to create a brand that sort of represented that sphere of men: a man that’s vulnerable, a man that’s a bit soft, a man that’s emotional.”

headline: Border Clashes Between Ethiopia and Eritrea Heighten Fears of War
abstract: Reports of fighting and possible deaths — and the lack of solid information — raise fears that Ethiopia and Eritrea are sliding once more into war.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The Eritrean Embassy in Kenya sent a text message alert Monday morning: The Ethiopians had attacked. Fighting on the border. Situation unfolding.

headline: Review: Young Lovers Imprisoned by Technology in ‘The Cell’
abstract: The Opera Upper West singers performed in an intimate setting, juxtaposing two small-scale works involving telephones.
lead_paragraph: As small, scrappy opera enterprises increasingly pervade the streets of New York, one may soon show up almost on your doorstep. For me, that happened over the weekend, with the roaming Opera Upper West’s production “The Cell” at the LuLu Lounge in the basement of Cafe Tallulah on, yes, the Upper West Side.

headline: Manager Terry Collins Cleared to Return to Mets
abstract: Collins missed the team’s game on Sunday after feeling ill but was set to be back in the dugout Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Mets Manager Terry Collins, who missed his team’s game Sunday after feeling ill that morning in Milwaukee, will be back in the dugout Tuesday.

headline: Globally, Orlando Attack Strikes Now-Familiar Fault Lines
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Gun Control', 'Terrorism', 'Hate Crimes', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: The Orlando massacre resonated across the world not as an American anomaly, but because it felt so universal.
lead_paragraph: ROME — By Monday morning, the grim, if now familiar, global ritual had begun. Leaders across Europe, Asia and elsewhere sent messages of sympathy and outrage. Editorialists opined against extremism and violence. Symbolic gestures — another special lighting of the Eiffel Tower — were announced. Solidarity hashtags circled the virtual globe.

headline: ‘UnREAL’ Season 2, Episode 2: Everybody’s Manipulating Everybody
abstract: One of the reasons this series is so absorbing is because it never lets us sympathize with any single character for too long.
lead_paragraph: Quinn giveth and Quinn taketh away.

headline: Weasels Are Built for the Hunt
abstract: Members of the mustelid family, including badgers, ferrets and otters, have evolved into remarkable predators.
lead_paragraph: At birth, the least weasel is as small and light as a paper clip, and the tiny ribs that press visibly against its silvery pink skin give it a segmented look, like that of an insect. A newborn kit is exceptionally underdeveloped, with sealed eyes and ears that won’t open for five or six weeks, an age when puppies and kittens are ready to be weaned.

headline: Review: In ‘Homegoing,’ What Slavery Costs One Family
abstract: Yaa Gyasi’s debut novel chronicles some 250 years of history in Africa and America.
lead_paragraph: “Homegoing,” the wildly ambitious debut novel by a 26-year-old writer named Yaa Gyasi, tackles some 250 years of history on two continents. It’s a novel that seems to have been inspired by such disparate family sagas as Gabriel García Márquez’s “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” Alex Haley’s “Roots” and Thomas Mann’s “Buddenbrooks,” a novel that sets itself the daunting task of tracing the legacy of sorrow that slavery has left on eight generations of one family.

abstract: A young drummer from Chicago, Mr. McCraven performed at Le Poisson Rouge in New York, playing jazz that was experimentally forward and backward reaching.

The gunman burst into the bathroom, went straight to the stall next to them and shot the people inside.

headline: Time for a ‘No Buy’ List on Guns
abstract: Our right to bear arms is no more fundamental than our right to privacy. Treating them similarly can help keep us safe.
lead_paragraph: THE massacre in Florida is a horrifying reminder that terrorists don’t need airplanes to kill scores of people: All they need are commonplace firearms. Gun-control groups are already issuing calls to do more to keep suspected terrorists from buying guns, while those against stricter gun laws say we shouldn’t deny people their constitutional rights on the basis of mere suspicion. They are both correct. But there is a solution.

Andrew M. Cuomo without Joseph Percoco, his closest aide and the enduring mainstay of his life in politics.

abstract: A Chicago beautician redefined coiffure for women of the 1960s and decades beyond, thanks to aerosol spray and a favorite hat.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Vinci Heldt, a Chicago beautician who, with the aid of hair spray and a favorite hat, redefined coiffure for women of the 1960s and the decades beyond when she created the sky-scraping hairdo known as the beehive, died on Friday in Elmhurst, Ill. She was 98.

headline: Anatol Kovarsky, New Yorker Cartoonist for Decades, Dies at 97

lead_paragraph: Anatol Kovarsky, an artist and illustrator whose sense of whimsy and the absurd made him a fixture at The New Yorker from the late 1940s through the 1960s as both a cartoonist and a cover artist, died on June 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 97.

headline: A Moment of Solidarity at the Stonewall Inn, a Gay Rights Landmark
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Gun Control', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Hate Crimes', 'Stonewall Riots (1969)']
abstract: Thousands converged on the bar in Manhattan on Monday, including Mayor Bill de Blasio, who criticized Donald J. Trump for his response to the Orlando attack.
lead_paragraph: From a thousand miles away, they watched as the horrors replayed in an endless loop, the death count climbing to an unimaginable high. For lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender New Yorkers coping with news of the massacre in Orlando, Fla., the grief was compounded by a sense of helplessness. Donations of money could do only so much, and calls for gun control are so often unheeded. Even giving blood was not an option for gay men, who are largely barred from donating.

headline: Cavs Still Alive After Beating Warriors in Game 5 of the N.B.A. Finals

lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The key to a series-saving victory for the Cleveland Cavaliers in Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals could be reasonably traced to Game 4, three days and three time zones removed. That was when and where LeBron James tangled with Draymond Green, which eventually led to a flagrant foul on Green that kept him out of Game 5 with a suspension.

headline: What to See First: Your GPS Guide to the Tate Modern
abstract: The new 10-story wing of a London museum that attracts millions each year promises a fresh way to see art.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On Friday the world’s most popular modern art museum, the Tate Modern, opens a new 10-story wing designed by the Swiss architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron. Called the Switch House, the extension will show off contemporary work, including film, installation and live performance, and will add 60 percent more space to the already enormous former power station on the banks of the Thames.

Trump.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'Cloud Computing', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Money Laundering', 'Referendums', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Software', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds']

headline: Rethinking Embryo Research Rules
abstract: Scientists can now sustain human embryonic material longer in vitro, so we need a rational public debate about time limits.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Few areas of scientific investigation are more controversial than embryo research, yet few are more brimming with potential. The field promises valuable insights into early human development and new possibilities for treating diseases and disorders.

headline: Tips from Daniel Radcliffe on Playing Dead in a Movie
abstract: He spoke about his role in “Swiss Army Man,” in which he plays a zombie-esque character who helps out Paul Dano, who is stranded on a deserted island.
lead_paragraph: Since ending his turn as an amiable wizard in a certain long-running film franchise, Daniel Radcliffe has played an accused rapist with horns growing out of his forehead (“Horns”), a morphine-addicted physician during the Russian Revolution (“A Young Doctor’s Notebook”) and the beat poet Allen Ginsberg (“Kill Your Darlings”).

headline: How Golf Makes You Confront Your Mortality
keywords: ['Golf', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Age, Chronological', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Buddhism', 'Sports Injuries', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: More than any other sport, it forces a standoff between body and mind.
lead_paragraph: Golf is deceitful above all things. It hovers over your late 20s, shaking its head as terms like “shin splints” and “plantar fasciitis” filter into your vocabulary. When the chubby ex-frat boys who flock to the Y.M.C.A. basketball courts after market close make fun of your “old-man moves,” golf clears its throat and lets loose a short, condescending whistle. And when the litany of bodily ailments has grown long enough but you haven’t quite accepted the inevitable, golf sidles up next to you with a pamphlet fit for a pyramid scheme and a reassuring smile. Life is long, golf says. Forget the body’s betrayals; golf is a game of the mind.

headline: Just How ‘Smart’ Do You Want Your Blender to Be?
keywords: ['Home Automation and Smart Homes', 'Home Appliances', 'English Language', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Silicon Valley can upgrade practically any household item these days, but owning one often means giving in to surveillance.
lead_paragraph: In the land rush to digitize the world, the home is the new frontier. Over the past few years, practically every household item within reach has been technologically upgraded and rendered “smart”: toothbrushes, cutlery, baby monitors, refrigerators, thermostats, slow cookers, sprinkler systems, sex toys, even the locks in doors. Before they achieved enlightenment, they could perform only their rote, mechanical duties; now they can do so while connected to the internet. In the case of the telephone, this has been nothing short of revolutionary, but no other “smart” object has managed to replicate its success. The absurdity of the phenomenon was made unavoidably apparent in May, when a start-up unveiled a “smart tampon,” called my.Flow. If women wear the my.Flow and the sensor that attaches to the tampon by a string (and clips neatly onto your waistband) and use the my.Flow app, they could now, at last, track their periods’ duration and flow.

headline: After Mass Shootings, It’s Often Easier to Buy a Gun
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'States (US)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Research finds that the policy response tends to be the opposite of what you might expect.
lead_paragraph: A mass shooting takes place, followed by emotional vigils, intensive news media coverage and sorrowful statements by politicians. But what does it actually mean for laws and policies around guns?

headline: Donald Trump, in Interviews, Seems to Abandon a Pledge to ‘Pivot’
abstract: He stood by his ban on Muslim immigrants and said that President Obama knew much more than he was letting on about the type of terrorist threat the U.S. faces.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has repeatedly promised a “pivot” toward a softer, gentler, more refined version of his candidacy since he emerged as the presumptive Republican nominee. But on Monday, Mr. Trump’s television interviews and speeches made clear that such a pivot would never come.

headline: ‘Swiss Army Man,’ the Strangest Movie Shown at Sundance?
abstract: Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert’s “Swiss Army Man” is an absurd bromance in which one of the bros — played by Daniel Radcliffe — appears to be dead.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In “Swiss Army Man,” Hank (Paul Dano), a castaway stranded on a deserted island, spies a body washed up on the beach. Driven half-mad by hunger and despair, he rushes into the surf, only to discover that the body, played by Daniel Radcliffe, is lifeless. Or is it? To Hank’s surprise, the corpse breaks wind, loudly and lustily. Moments later, Hank whoops with glee as he pilots the gas-powered Mr. Radcliffe across a sun-kissed ocean.

headline: A Year Alongside Omar Mateen
abstract: Daniel Gilroy, a former co-worker of Omar Mateen, describes what he calls “unstable” and at times frightening behavior.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Gilroy, a former co-worker of Omar Mateen, describes what he calls “unstable” and at times frightening behavior.

headline: Killing Twice for ISIS and Saying So Live on Facebook
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Larossi Abballa, who stabbed a police captain and his companion to death, was released almost immediately after his conviction in 2013.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — He stabbed an off-duty police officer and left him bleeding to death on his own doorstep. He forced his way inside the home and stabbed and killed the officer’s female companion. He then sat down and videotaped himself live on Facebook declaring allegiance to the Islamic State, according to the French law enforcement authorities.

headline: Incendiary Memoir by Chinese Rights Lawyer Reaches Bookshelves Abroad

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A book written by Gao Zhisheng, a Chinese human rights lawyer who spent years in prison, has made it out of China and been published in Taiwan.

headline: A Portrait of Grief in Orlando
abstract: Ashley Summers was at the Pulse nightclub when an assailant began shooting. She tells her story and reflects on the trauma the attack has left on her Florida community.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Summers was at the Pulse nightclub when an assailant began shooting. She tells her story and reflects on the trauma the attack has left on her Florida community.

headline: 1891: New Steamship La Touraine
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In June 1891, new steamship La Touraine is shown in France.
lead_paragraph: Yet another ‘‘ocean greyhound’’ has been added to the magnificent fleet belonging to the Compagnie Transatlantique. Yesterday, La Touraine, the latest development of French shipbuilding, was shown to some two thousand invited guests. La Touraine lay right along the dock, looking like a floating palace. The first thing to state about her is that internally she is the most luxurious passenger ship ever turned out. Secondly, that the decorations — rich as they are — are in the best of taste. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 15, 1891

headline: Review: ‘Tristan und Isolde,’ From an Unsettled English National Opera
abstract: The sculptor Anish Kapoor’s sets are a highlight of this new production, directed by Daniel Kramer, recently named to lead the company.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” is the kind of work that opera companies do to prove they can. Hugely demanding of resources, time and self-belief, it makes a statement. And the statement in the new production that opened last Thursday and runs until July 9 at the English National Opera here is that this much loved but beleaguered company, struggling to survive near-terminal misfortunes, can still show a brave face to the world.

headline: LeBron James and Kyrie Irving Make It Look Easy
abstract: In Game 5 on Monday night, James and Irving became the first teammates in an N.B.A. finals to score 40 or more points in the same game.
lead_paragraph: After combining for 82 points Monday night in Game 5 of the N.B.A. finals, LeBron James and Kyrie Irving of the Cleveland Cavaliers sat down to answer questions from members of the news media and seemed relaxed for the first time since James returned to Cleveland. They joked with each other, bantered with reporters and made the drama of the last few days seem like a distant memory.

headline: As Fans Turn Violent at Euros, Russia Faces a Threat: Expulsion
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'UEFA European Football Championship']
abstract: Russia was given a suspended disqualification from the European Championships as punishment for fan violence, putting the team on the verge of being kicked out of the competition.
lead_paragraph: VILLENEUVE-D’ASCQ, France — The Russian soccer federation was fined about $170,000 and given a suspended disqualification from the European Championships on Tuesday as punishment for in-stadium fan violence. The sanction essentially leaves the Russian team on the verge of being kicked out of the continent’s most prestigious tournament two years before Russia hosts the World Cup.

headline: Smithsonian to Open London Exhibition Space With Victoria and Albert Museum
abstract: The American institution’s first permanent outpost abroad will be part of a complex in the east of the city called Olympicopolis, to open in 2021.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For the first time in its 170-year history, the Smithsonian Institution will establish a permanent presence outside the United States. The Washington-based Smithsonian and the Victoria and Albert Museum in the British capital announced on Monday that they would collaborate on a new exhibition space in the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park in East London, the site of the 2012 Games.

headline: Conservative Donor’s Group Presses Ballot Access for a Third-Party Candidate
abstract: The donor, John Kingston, said the candidate will come once the ballot access is secured. His group, called Better for America, is plainly, in part, a “Stop Trump” effort.
lead_paragraph: A conservative donor who has been scouring Republican ranks for a third-party candidate is pressing ahead with a group to get on the ballot in dozens of states. The candidate will come once the group sees that the ballot access is possible.

headline: Orlando Shooting Survivors Cope With the Trauma of Good Fortune

headline: Australian Rodent Is First Mammal Made Extinct by Human-Driven Climate Change, Scientists Say
abstract: In 2014, researchers used traps and cameras to try to determine how many Bramble Cay melomys were left on a tiny outcrop in the Great Barrier Reef. They found none.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australian researchers say rising sea levels have wiped out a rodent that lived on a tiny outcrop in the Great Barrier Reef, in what they say is the first documented extinction of a mammal species due to human-caused climate change.

abstract: After a fire at the UpStairs Lounge in 1973 that killed 32 people, there were no vigils and only a halfhearted investigation. Many victims were never identified.
lead_paragraph: The terrorist attack that killed 49 and wounded 53 in Orlando, Fla., was the largest mass killing of gay people in American history, but before Sunday that grim distinction was held by a largely forgotten arson at a New Orleans bar in 1973 that killed 32 people at a time of pernicious anti-gay stigma.

headline: Orthodox Churches’ Council, Centuries in Making, Falters as Russia Exits

headline: Can Apple Think Outside the Device?

headline: LeBron James, Replying to Taunts, Takes Step Toward Historic Comeback
abstract: Fans screamed at James, calling him a player past his prime. Then they watched him reach into his bag of greatness and steer the Cavaliers away from a cliff.

The game was about a half-hour from even starting.

headline: Moving to Make Amends, Georgetown President Meets With Descendant of Slaves
abstract: A meeting between John J. DeGioia, the university’s president, and a great-great-great-granddaughter of two slaves sold to aid the college may have been historic.
lead_paragraph: More than a century after Georgetown University used some of the profits from the sale of 272 enslaved African-Americans to help ensure its survival, John J. DeGioia, the university’s president, took a first step on Monday toward making amends to their descendants.

headline: 1916: Democrats Laud President
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In June 1916, U.S. Democrats laud President Wilson.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — Former Governor Martin H. Glynn, of New York, as temporary chairman of the National Democratic Convention, which opened its session in St. Louis today [June 14], struck what will be the keynote of the Democratic campaign, when in lauding President Wilson as the man of the hour, he declared that in preserving a firm, honorable neutrality, the President had achieved the most notable diplomatic triumph in the nation’s history and without plunging the country into the great and bloody war, had forced one of the belligerents to abandon a savage, illegal form of warfare that reached the apex of horror when the Lusitania was sunk. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 15, 1916

headline: Britain’s Top Tabloid, The Sun, Urges Exit From European Union
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'News and News Media', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']

headline: Finishing His Sentences
abstract: In a Father’s Day tribute, Walter Mosley recalls how his father turned him into a storyteller.
lead_paragraph: Two thousand sixteen marks the 100-year anniversary of my father, Leroy Mosley’s, birth. He was and is my inspiration, the man who taught me to bob and weave in life and art. I came into being shaped by the stories about his childhood in Louisiana and the grinding poverty he endured there, the bloodletting and laughter in the Fifth Ward in Houston and the harsh enlightenment he received in the Army.

headline: The Debatable Premise Underlying Paul Ryan’s Antipoverty Plan

headline: What a ‘Ghostbusters’ Online Attack Says About the Digital Age
keywords: ['Movies', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A man whose YouTube channel has 2.1 million subscribers took aim at the new “Ghostbusters,” and an online furor followed.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The rage was immediate. As soon as the Hollywood trades reported that Sony Pictures was going to reboot “Ghostbusters” with women in the lead roles, internet trolls tumbled out of their caves to insta-condemn the effort.

headline: Warriors Wobble in an Altered Continuum
abstract: The suspension of Draymond Green for Game 5 against the Cavaliers on Monday night did nothing short of changing everything about the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: As a child, I read and reread a Ray Bradbury short story about a hunter who traveled back to the distant past to bag a dinosaur, illegally stepped off a levitating walkway and mistakenly crushed a butterfly. When he returned to his time, everything was the same, and everything — language, culture, politics — was subtly off.

headline: ‘The Girls’ Author Recalls Driving Past Manson’s ‘House’ as a Child
abstract: Emma Cline’s urge to understand the dark impulses that drove Charles Manson’s acolytes gave rise to her debut novel.
lead_paragraph: Emma Cline remembers driving past San Quentin State Prison in Marin County, Calif., with her family when she was 7 years old. That’s Charles Manson’s house, her parents would say.

headline: Drinks on a Farm With Upstate Diary
abstract: Artists and photographers, one gallerist and a filmmaker celebrate their rural community of creatives.
lead_paragraph: Artists and photographers, one gallerist and a filmmaker celebrate their rural community of creatives.

headline: Bringing Together Creatives in Upstate New York
abstract: Kate Orne, who founded the publication Upstate Diary in 2014, brings T to a recent cocktail party on a farm.
lead_paragraph: “Last year, I clocked 14,500 miles just driving upstate,” says Kate Orne, who crisscrosses from the Catskills to the Berkshires, even down to Connecticut, to interview and photograph subjects for Upstate Diary, the art-oriented publication she launched in 2014. That figure on her odometer is more or less the distance from New York City to New Delhi and back again, and yet Orne betrays not the slightest hint of fatigue as she describes her project with an almost evangelical passion.

headline: Gray Kunz Returns to New York (State) at Salt & Char
abstract: Also, Carla Hall brings the South to Brooklyn, the Upper West Side gets a French wine bar, and more.
lead_paragraph: Salt & Char After about 10 years in Hong Kong, the acclaimed former Lespinasse chef Gray Kunz is back in New York. That is, upstate New York. He has joined the Adelphi Hospitality Group, which owns the newly renovated Adelphi Hotel in Saratoga Springs and his new steakhouse next door. “I always wanted to do a steakhouse,” he said. “This is in an area where there are farms and local markets filled with meat and produce.” He knows the territory well, having had a home in the Hudson Valley for decades. He expects to serve what he calls “forgotten cuts,” the lesser-known steaks that are attracting attention in New York. His executive chef is Braden Reardon, who was at the NYY Steakhouse in Manhattan. Christophe Chatron-Michaud, who may be familiar to many New York restaurantgoers, is returning from Asia to be the general manager. Mr. Kunz will not sever his ties with Café Gray Deluxe, his restaurant in the Upper House, a boutique hotel in Hong Kong. As for a New York City encore, “there are plans to come back to Manhattan,” he said. “But not right now.” (Opens Friday): 353 Broadway, Saratoga Springs, N.Y., 518-450-7500, saltandchar.com.

headline: Inside a Floating, Eco-Conscious Art Project
abstract: Mary Mattingly’s “WetLand” is part houseboat, part sculpture, part DIY sustainability demonstration site.
lead_paragraph: This summer on Long Island’s East End, one exhibition features artwork that’s a far cry from the stereotypical blue-chip Hamptons summer style, with utopian aspirations and often provisional aesthetics. “Radical Seafaring,” organized by the Parrish Art Museum curator Andrea Grover, brings together 25 artists and collectives who create, as she writes, “land art, only afloat”: installations and performances designed to be experienced off dry land. The show traces the history of the genre, from midcentury Conceptualists such as Bas Jan Ader (who was tragically lost at sea during a 1975 sailing performance), Chris Burden and the obscure Japanese collective The Play to contemporary makers like Mark Dion, Duke Riley and Swoon. And for two weeks this summer, the New York-based artist Mary Mattingly brings the exhibition truly offshore with “WetLand,” a houseboat sculpture docked beside yachts at the Long Wharf in Sag Harbor.

headline: Man, Can You Hear That Crazy Forest Green?

headline: Portraits of an Italian Town That Time (Almost) Left Behind
abstract: In 1993, Stephen Shore photographed the inhabitants of Luzzara, a traditional community embracing modernity.
lead_paragraph: In 1993, Stephen Shore traveled to Luzzara, a rural district in Northern Italy, to photograph its residents. The resulting portfolio paints a picture of a traditional community slowly embracing modernity. In one image, a young woman holds a child whose disposable diaper is visible behind the edge of his bodysuit. In another, a woman smokes a cigarette astride an old bicycle, protected from the weather in a zippered plastic rain jacket. These portraits are juxtaposed with images of ornate wrought-iron work, immaculately tended fields and crumbling plaster walls.

headline: Why Do Terrorists Commit Terrorism?
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Fort Hood Shooting (2009)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: After reviewing hundreds of cases, I’ve found that there might be no way to pinpoint an attacker’s motive.

headline: Inside Zaha Hadid’s Design for “Kurt Schwitters: Merz”
abstract: The architect’s installation at Galerie Gmurzynska in Zurich was created in homage to the influential Dadaist artist.
lead_paragraph: The architect’s installation at Galerie Gmurzynska in Zurich was created in homage to the influential Dadaist artist.

headline: Zaha Hadid’s Last Project: A Tribute to a Dada Master
abstract: The architect’s installation at Galerie Gmurzynska in Zurich — part iceberg, part cave, part shrine — was created in homage to Kurt Schwitters.
lead_paragraph: Cocooning the entire lower floor of Zurich’s Galerie Gmurzynska, an installation conceived by Zaha Hadid opens this week that is part iceberg, part cave and part shrine, created in homage to the influential Dadaist artist Kurt Schwitters. Inspired by Schwitters’s destroyed “Merzbau” (1923-1937), an ever-changing collage sculpture that consumed his entire workspace, Hadid designed an all-encompassing grotto on which to show the artist’s works. As with the “Merzbau,” Hadid’s structural collage includes artworks as well as “readymade” furniture and architectural features. Here, the artworks are assemblages and reliefs from across Schwitters’s career, as well as a selection of illustrated and often surreal personal correspondence. They’re offset by Hadid’s furniture: undulating marble tables, modular seating elements and hybrid shelving systems that swoop and curve like melting glaciers.

headline: Beyond the Multiplex: Brooklyn’s Show of Independent Film
abstract: BAMcinemaFest, which opens on Wednesday with Ira Sachs’s “Little Men,” again offers an intriguing lineup, including films by Todd Solondz and Werner Herzog.
lead_paragraph: The best local answer to the malaise of blockbuster season, BAMcinemaFest offers New Yorkers a chance to survey the glories and limitations of American independent cinema. Each year, the program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music (which starts its eighth iteration on Wednesday) plucks promising features and documentaries from Sundance, South by Southwest and elsewhere, and arranges them into a bouquet of puzzles, provocations and delights. The unevenness of the offerings is part of the festival’s appeal, and so is a palpable but hard-to-define consistency of themes, methods and attitudes.

lead_paragraph: It’s hard to get one’s head around it: An initial public offering that would value a company in the trillions of dollars. That’s trillions, with a T.

headline: F.B.I. Asks Help in Investigating Banker’s Killing in Puerto Rico
abstract: The agency said it had possible suspects in the death of Maurice Spagnoletti, a top executive of Doral Financial, in June 2011.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has identified possible suspects in its long-running investigation into the murder of a banker in Puerto Rico, but it is now asking the public for help in solving the 2011 killing.

headline: Morning Shock at Zabar’s, as Man Accidentally Shoots Himself
abstract: Officials said the firearm discharged as Louis Lester Anderson was adjusting his waistband after buying coffee and a bagel at the upscale Manhattan market.
lead_paragraph: Just before 9 a.m. on Tuesday, while the cafe at Zabar’s in Manhattan was still busy with the breakfast rush, an unmistakable sound interrupted the chatter: A gun was fired.

headline: ‘Bright Star,’ by Steve Martin and Edie Brickell, to Close on Broadway
abstract: The musical, which has struggled to find an audience, will close June 26 after 30 previews and 109 regular performances.
lead_paragraph: The new musical “Bright Star” will be shining for just a few more weeks.

headline: Everything We Know About Omar Mateen
abstract: An updated video on Mr. Mateen's background, marriages and his possible motives behind the deadly attack in Orlando, Fla.
lead_paragraph: An updated video on Mr. Mateen's background, marriages and his possible motives behind the deadly attack in Orlando, Fla.

headline: U.S. Chamber Out of Step With Its Board, Report Finds
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Global Warming', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Boards of Directors']
abstract: A Senate report says no board members explicitly backed the chamber’s campaign against antismoking laws and curbs on global warming.
lead_paragraph: None of the 108 board members of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce came forward to explicitly support the lobbying group’s policies on tobacco and climate change, according to a new report from a group of eight Senate Democrats, including Senator Elizabeth Warren and Senator Bernie Sanders.

headline: Twitter Invests $70 Million in SoundCloud Music Service
abstract: The deal will mean money for SoundCloud, which has had losses despite its popularity, and it could clarify how Twitter deals with entertainment.
lead_paragraph: Twitter has invested about $70 million in the streaming music service SoundCloud in a deal that may help both companies attract more users.

headline: MSCI Delays Adding China Stock to Emerging Markets Benchmark
abstract: The index provider’s decision to once again postpone the inclusion of mainland stocks in its influential benchmark reflected continuing concerns over Chinese government intervention.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Chinese stocks had seemed poised to join an important global benchmark, paving the way for overseas money to pour into the country’s markets.

headline: Iran Said to Have Deal With Boeing to Buy Passenger Planes
abstract: Such an agreement, if completed, would amount to the most prominent commercial transaction between an American company and Iran since antinuclear sanctions were lifted six months ago.
lead_paragraph: Iran has reached an agreement with the Boeing Company for the acquisition of new passenger planes to help modernize its outdated fleet, state-run Iranian news media reported on Tuesday.

headline: W.H.O. Says Olympics Should Go Ahead in Brazil Despite Zika Virus
abstract: The agency said that, with the exception of pregnant women, athletes and spectators should not hesitate to attend the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro this summer.
lead_paragraph: The Olympic Games should go on as planned, the World Health Organization said Tuesday, and athletes and spectators, except for pregnant women, should not hesitate to attend so long as they take precautions against infection with the Zika virus.

headline: Rhoda Blumberg, Whose Children’s Books Brought History to Life, Dies at 98
abstract: Turning to history in her mid-50s, Ms. Blumberg infused her nonfiction with enlightening nuggets that tantalized young readers.
lead_paragraph: Rhoda Blumberg, who was barely interested in reading until she was 10, began writing historical books for children when she was in her mid-50s, and produced more than two dozen over three decades, died on June 6 at her home in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. She was 98.

abstract: With songs and colored lights, people from Los Angeles to France gathered in a show of solidarity with those killed by Omar Mateen at a gay nightclub in Florida.

headline: Orlando Injuries Were Severe, but Trauma Care Was Nearby
keywords: ['Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Firearms', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Rescues']

lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — In a scene more like a battlefield than an emergency room in a large American city, dozens of people hit by gunfire poured into the Orlando Regional Medical Center in the dark predawn hours of Sunday morning, lining the hallways and filling the operating rooms.

headline: Jason Day Says He’s Better for His 2015 Bout of Vertigo
abstract: The malady scuttled his chance to win last year’s United States Open, but Day, now the world’s top-ranked golfer, contends that the setback helped push him forward.
lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — With his gait wobbly, his eyes struggling to focus and his head spinning so quickly he eventually collapsed to the ground, Jason Day would be forgiven if he remembered last year’s United States Open as a house of horrors.

headline: In Detroit, Gordie Howe Is Remembered as a Soft-Spoken Star

headline: Spending Bill Sets Off Senate Debate Over Gun Laws
abstract: Just days after the Orlando shootings, an appropriations bill covering law enforcement became the latest vehicle for partisan wrangling over proposed gun-sale restrictions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A fierce debate over tougher gun control laws, ignited by the mass shooting in Orlando, Fla., began in the Capitol corridors on Tuesday afternoon as the Senate moved to take up an annual appropriations bill that covers the F.B.I. and other federal law enforcement programs.

headline: Gawker Article on Trump’s Hair Draws Threat From Hulk Hogan’s Lawyer
