headline: Fairness on the Internet
abstract: A federal appeals court has come down forcefully in favor of competition and consumer protection.
lead_paragraph: With a ruling on Tuesday that high-speed internet service should be equally accessible to all Americans, a federal appeals court has come down forcefully in favor of competition and consumer protection. The 2-to-1 decision by a three-judge panel prevents cable and phone companies from blocking websites or creating fast and slow lanes for delivering content on the internet.

headline: Review: ‘Seen / By Everyone’ Repurposes Your Social Media Words
abstract: This play, directed by Kristin Marting, emphasizes love and mourning through a collage of real online posts.
lead_paragraph: The writing credit on “Seen / By Everyone,” the new show from Five on a Match at Here, may come as something of a surprise. According to the program, it’s “written by you.”

headline: There’s No Easy Solution to the Mets’ Problems
abstract: Manager Terry Collins was back on the job, but the Mets were missing Neil Walker (back) and Michael Conforto (wrist), as well as three starters already on the D.L.
lead_paragraph: Of the Mets’ many recent health concerns, one had resolved itself by Tuesday. Manager Terry Collins was back on the job, delivering the lineup card as usual before the Mets played the Pittsburgh Pirates at Citi Field. He had felt disoriented before Sunday’s game in Milwaukee — dehydration, he guessed — and was taken to a hospital. But his tests had found nothing alarming.

headline: In a Race to Save a Man on the Tracks, a Reminder of What’s Good in the World
abstract: Three men jumped down from a subway platform in Manhattan to rescue a man who had fallen onto the tracks, a moment that was recorded by a witness.
lead_paragraph: By rights, on a bright Friday afternoon in late spring, Sumeja Tulic had every reason to relish walking the streets of New York, a city she moved to nine months ago from London for graduate school. “When the weather is good, it’s very hard to find a reason to be depressed or melancholic or dissatisfied with the city,” Ms. Tulic said.

headline: Friends Arrived Just Moments Before Orlando Shooting Began
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: Demetrice Naulings, 34, survived the deadly rampage at Pulse nightclub, but his friend Eddie Justice was killed.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Hanging out at home with a friend last Saturday, Demetrice Naulings decided there was still night enough to party. It was a snap decision. So he and his friends headed to Pulse, the gay nightclub where he often worked as a host, arriving just before 2 a.m. He was the last person to walk into the club — a decision that shatters him still.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Powerful Words About Terrorism
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Muslim Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)']

headline: Senate Votes to Require Women to Register for the Draft
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)']

The bill passed with language calling for a review of the current rules. Read more in our fact check of viral claims to the contrary.

headline: Chips Moman, Hit-Making Producer and Songwriter, Dies at 79

lead_paragraph: Chips Moman, a producer and songwriter who helped define the Memphis sound in soul music in the 1960s, generated dozens of pop, soul and country hits and helped resuscitate Elvis Presley’s career in the late ’60s, died on Monday in LaGrange, Ga. He was 79.

headline: Review: Pun Like an Egyptian Comic Strip in ‘The Tomb of King Tot’

The three-dimensional world has a willful way of creeping into and subverting the two-dimensional comic strip at the center of “The Tomb of King Tot,” the sweet and spiky new tragicomedy by Olivia Dufault, which opened on Tuesday night at the Wild Project as part of Clubbed Thumb’s Summerworks festival.

headline: Some See the Verrazano Bridge. Others See a Big Typo.

abstract: Mr. Masuzoe, who will step down on Tuesday, is the second governor of the city to quit over a financial scandal in two and a half years.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The governor of Tokyo resigned on Wednesday, after he admitted using funds intended for political campaigns to pay for personal travel and entertainment, setting off a public furor.

headline: How the Cultural Revolution Sowed the Seeds of Dissent in China
keywords: ['Cultural Revolution', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The sociologist Guobin Yang explains how the turmoil of those years paved the way for the political debates and artistic experiments that followed Mao Zedong’s death.
lead_paragraph: Guobin Yang is a sociologist at the University of Pennsylvania best known for his research on the internet in China. But in his latest book, “The Red Guard Generation and Political Activism in China,’’ he turns back to examine the upheavals of the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution and the imprint they left on a generation of Chinese who became radicals and Red Guards in the name of Mao Zedong. The book explores the cultural background to the violence of the Cultural Revolution, and how those experiences nurtured dissenting ideas and the cultural experimentation that burst into flower after Mao’s death in 1976. In an interview, Mr. Yang explained how that happened.

headline: The Teenager With One Foot Out the Door
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: With their parting maneuvers, young people are subconsciously tempering the emotionally intense, landmark moment of leaving home.
lead_paragraph: High school graduation can give way to an uneasy season in the raising of a teenager. In place of a summer of family togetherness, parents often feel out of step with adolescents who are preparing to leave home. Though there are certainly joys that come with having a young adult around the house, they can’t cancel out the parting tensions that many families face.

headline: Orlando, Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton: Your Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Karl Lagerfeld, a Renaissance Man Among Renaissance Masters
abstract: An exhibition of photographs by the prolific designer shares space with Raphaels, Titians and Tintorettos in Florence’s Palazzo Pitti.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — The 15th-century Palazzo Pitti, by the banks of the Arno, is one of the great storehouses of Italian Renaissance painting, an embarrassment of riches by Raphael, Titian and Tintoretto. But the fashion industry is never shy of gilding the lily. This week, on the occasion of the semiannual Pitti Uomo men’s wear fair, an installation of photography by Karl Lagerfeld, fashion’s own Renaissance man, joined the work of the past masters, hanging or posted among them, beside them and, in some cases, over them.

headline: European Interest Rates Are Not as Low as They Look
abstract: Negative rates may seem strange, but when adjusting for inflation, companies are still not getting cheap loans.
lead_paragraph: Interest rates in Europe got a little crazier this week when the yield on the 10-year German government bond fell below zero.

headline: Extreme Coaster Makeovers
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Roller Coasters', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS']
abstract: One company is adding a twist and rehabilitating old wooden coasters, giving them new features, a new look and new life.
lead_paragraph: Wooden coasters: towering, majestic, beautifully designed, classic. But the same woodies that look so wondrous from afar can be rickety, shaky and head-jangling to ride. As trains wear down their wood tracks, a coaster that was once smooth becomes more and more difficult to handle over time. How do you solve the problem? The answer used to be to call in experts to repair the tracks. But now park owners are turning to a new option: replacing the wood tracks with bendable, pliable steel, and turning the coaster into a thrilling hybrid.

headline: Theme Park Dining Beyond Burgers and Turkey Legs
keywords: ['AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Food Trucks and Vendors', 'Restaurants', 'Food']
abstract: At three theme parks — Knott’s Berry Farm, Universal Studios and Dollywood — it takes some work to find good food. But it exists.
lead_paragraph: The bad reputation of theme park food has been, let’s face it, pretty well deserved: All the negative aspects you might find at a state fair — sugary, greasy and overpriced — minus any of the quirky homespun charm. Mass-produced and joylessly prone to corporate tie-ins, it’s the ultimate iteration of the theme park’s overriding mission: to separate you from every last dollar in your pocket.

headline: Hotels That Rival Nearby Theme Parks
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Hotels near major theme parks are becoming destinations in their own right, with water slides, nighttime storytelling, mini-golf and more.
lead_paragraph: Hotels near theme parks do more than offer a convenient respite from the lines and crowds. Largely aimed at families, the most elaborate of them operate as park extensions, with immersive design and enough amenities to ensure that you can retire to your room after a busy day and won’t have to leave it again till morning. The following new and improved resorts champion proximity and entertainment, and many come with perks such as free shuttles to the theme park, on-site ticket sales, early park admission and line-jumping status.

headline: Roller Coasters, Class of ’16
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Roller Coasters', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)']
abstract: New rides take passengers to higher heights, at greater speeds, and, with virtual reality headsets, are more transportive than ever.
lead_paragraph: Each year’s class of new roller coasters promises to break speed and height records. This year’s models are no exception, but this time around, virtual reality is thrown in for good measure. For maximum thrills, dare to ride the following new rails.

headline: New York Today: City-Centric Books
abstract: Wednesday: Our metropolis in words, sweaty weather, and boozier brunches.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:46 a.m.

headline: Morning Agenda: MSCI Holds Off Adding China to Emerging Markets Benchmark
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Crowdfunding (Internet)', 'Foreign Investments', 'Gambling', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Start-ups', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: The Global Stakes of a Saudi Aramco I.P.O. | Wall St. Scion Had Gambling Addiction, Lawyer Says

headline: Judge John Hodgman on a Family’s Fantasy Food World
abstract: Settling a dispute between “the Saladeterian” and “the Lollipop Lady” is bound to get messy.
lead_paragraph: Thomas writes: My wife and I play a game with our 5-year-old in which I pretend to be a man obsessed with salad, called the Saladetarian. She calls herself the Lollipop Lady and will only eat food on a stick. Searching for a food that could satisfy both of us, my daughter suggested a miniature caesar-salad wrap on a toothpick. I think this is an elegant solution, but my wife argues that a salad inside a tortilla is no longer a salad. Please resolve this dispute.

headline: W. Kamau Bell Has Just the Thing to End Racism
abstract: The television host and comedian on why celebrities don’t transcend race, how Muhammad Ali helped him find his blackness and why, sometimes, gimmicks work.
lead_paragraph: Your show, “United Shades of America,” debuted this year on CNN, but one of your side gigs is co-­hosting a podcast called “Denzel Washington Is the Greatest Actor of All Time Period.” When you ask, “Who’s the greatest of all time, period?” you hear a lot of the same actors: De Niro, Pacino, DiCaprio. Why can’t it be Denzel? The podcast has also become, in part, about diversity in Hollywood, but the people who listen to the podcast get really mad if we don’t talk about Denzel Washington enough.

headline: Trump Takes Heat From Clinton and Obama as a Poll Hints at Trouble
abstract: President Obama denounced Donald Trump for playing to the nation’s worst fears, and Hillary Clinton painted him as something of an oddball.
lead_paragraph: Four significant things happened in the last 24 hours of the 2016 presidential race:

headline: Should a Friend Be Told the Real Reason He Didn’t Get the Job?
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Poverty', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when social considerations are trumped by expectations of confidentiality and what to do when someone in your co-op is renting out her apartment on Airbnb.
lead_paragraph: A friend whom I like and admire a great deal applied for a teaching job at a private school where my wife used to work, and where she and I maintain friendly connections with top decision-makers. On the face of it, our friend exceeded all qualifications for the job, and my wife and I each wrote glowing recommendations for him, including to the head of the department to which he was applying. We thought he was a slam-dunk for the position.

headline: Can Netflix Survive in the New World It Created?
abstract: It helped to develop all the new ways we watch TV — on-demand, bingeing, mobile. But the Silicon Valley company still has to keep reinventing itself.
lead_paragraph: One night in early January, a little after 9 o’clock, a dozen Netflix employees gathered in the cavernous Palazzo ballroom of the Venetian in Las Vegas. They had come to rehearse an announcement the company would be making the next morning at the Consumer Electronics Show, the tech industry’s gigantic annual conference. For the previous year, Netflix had been plotting secretly to expand the availability of its streaming entertainment service, then accessible in about 60 countries, to most of the rest of the world. Up to this point, Netflix had been entering one or two countries at a time, to lots of fanfare. Now it was going to move into 130 new countries all at once, including major markets like Russia, India and South Korea. (The only significant holdout, for now, was China, where the company says it is still “exploring potential partnerships.”) Netflix executives saw this as a significant step toward the future they have long imagined for the company, a supremacy in home entertainment akin to what Facebook enjoys in social media, Uber in urban transportation or Amazon in online retailing.

headline: There’s a Disconnect in Americans’ Worry About Terrorism
abstract: Despite expressing fears, people keep going to concerts and other public events, and overseas vacations are increasing.
lead_paragraph: Terrorists don’t set out only to kill.

headline: She’s the Hidden Architect of Modern Comedy
abstract: Charna Halpern — who, with the Chicago improv pioneer Del Close, devised a seminal improv technique — is a crucial conduit to “Saturday Night Live.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As soon as Charna Halpern walked backstage at the iO theater here, the 20 or so comedians in the room got quiet, their eyes focused on her. They were about to perform for a full house, but she was the only audience that mattered.

headline: Not Forgotten: The Surprisingly Quiet Ella Fitzgerald
abstract: A listener would not have realized it hearing her crooning, belting or scatting, but Ella Fitzgerald was a quiet person in private.
lead_paragraph: A listener would not have realized it hearing her crooning, belting or scatting, but Ella Fitzgerald was a quiet person in private.

headline: Australian Businessman, Sentenced in China, Gets Early Release Back Home
abstract: Matthew Ng, convicted of bribery and fraud charges, had been returned to Sydney under a prisoner exchange treaty.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — An Australian businessman who was jailed in China after a dispute over his company there has been granted early release from a prison in Australia, 19 months after being returned to his home country to complete his sentence, under a treaty between the two countries.

headline: Worries Flare Over Yang Maodong, Jailed Chinese Dissident on Hunger Strike
abstract: For more than a month, Mr. Yang has resisted eating to protest his conditions in prison and to demand sweeping political change, his family said.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — One of China’s best-known imprisoned dissidents, Yang Maodong, is putting his already fragile health at risk after weeks on a hunger strike, his wife and sister said on Wednesday, after his sister said she had unsuccessfully asked the prison authorities to be allowed to see him and beg him to stop fasting.

headline: At Pitti Uomo, a Few Shirts and a Sportswear Slant
abstract: The men’s wear trade fair reflects the influence American style has had on global fashion.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — Next time you’re debating whether to pack lightly or check a bag, give a thought to Mike Hodis.

headline: The Orlando Attack and Its Global Echoes
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Hate Crimes', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The best tribute to the victims would be to push back against laws around the world that treat being gay as a crime.
lead_paragraph: The massacre of 49 people at a gay club in Orlando, Fla., on Sunday by a gunman claiming inspiration from the Islamic State resonated instantly around the world. Though it echoed recent terrorist attacks in Paris, Brussels, Beirut and Bamako, it also raised painful memories of attacks targeting gay men and women, from the arson at a gay bar in New Orleans in 1973 that took 32 lives to the nail-bomb explosion at a London pub in 1999.

headline: Obama and Dalai Lama Meet Over China’s Objection
abstract: A Chinese official warned that a meeting between the American president and the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader would “undermine mutual trust and cooperation” between the two countries.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Chinese official warned on Wednesday that a scheduled meeting between President Obama and the Dalai Lama in Washington would “undermine mutual trust and cooperation” between the two countries.

headline: Coffee May Protect Against Cancer, W.H.O. Concludes
abstract: In a rare reversal, an influential panel of experts convened by the World Health Organization concluded that regularly drinking coffee could help protect against some types of cancer.
lead_paragraph: An influential panel of experts convened by the World Health Organization concluded on Wednesday that regularly drinking coffee could protect against at least two types of cancer, a decision that followed decades of research pointing to the beverage’s many health benefits. The panel also said there was a lack of evidence that it might cause other types of cancer.

headline: Indonesian Doctors’ Group Rejects Decree on Chemical Castration
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Castration', 'Doctors', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The decree, by President Joko Widodo, is meant to punish convicted child molesters, but the national medical association says it prefers longer prison sentences.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s national medical association has told its members not to cooperate with a presidential decree authorizing the country’s courts to punish convicted child molesters with chemical castration, escalating a nationwide debate over the legality, medical ethics and efficacy of the procedure after a series of recent rapes and murders.

headline: Finding Refuge in Jordan, and Adding to Its Cultural Mix
abstract: Jordan has absorbed successive waves of people fleeing war and chaos. Some Jordanians blame the newcomers for unwanted changes; others say they have made Amman better.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Jordan’s national census takers made something of a stark discovery earlier this year when they found that nearly a third of the country’s 9.5 million residents are not, technically speaking, Jordanians.

lead_paragraph: Q. Is it possible to have the photos I upload from my digital camera card to my Mac directly backed up online to Google Photos, too?

abstract: A ruling on how you get internet content means the neighbor’s blog matters as much as Netflix. And Netflix can’t be charged extra for being a data hog.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago broadband might have been confused with a style of cummerbund. Now, a federal court has ruled, it is an essential part of American life.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Chinese court has sentenced the wife and son of the country’s former security chief to prison, a year after the family patriarch was sentenced to life in prison for corruption and leaking state secrets.

lead_paragraph: Turn off your cellphones. Unwrap your candy. And put on those headsets.

headline: Oscar Pistorius Removes His Artificial Legs at Sentencing Hearing
abstract: Mr. Pistorius’s lawyers were trying to highlight the sense of vulnerability they say he felt when, acting out of fear and confusion, he fatally shot his girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Oscar Pistorius, the Olympic runner, removed his artificial legs and shuffled his way to the front of a courtroom in South Africa on Wednesday, the third day of a hearing to determine his sentence for the 2013 murder of his girlfriend.

headline: Bondage Fantasies at the WSJ
abstract: It’s always the government’s fault.
lead_paragraph: Back in early 2009 the Wall Street Journal looked at a blip in interest rates — which was obviously, even at the time, driven by optimism about economic recovery, which unfortunately proved misplaced — and declared that the bond vigilantes were back. Rising rates, the paper declared, were a sign that all-wise markets feared budget deficits and inflation. Soaring rates were proof that government was the problem.

headline: ‘From Wolf to Woof!’ and ‘Babak the Beetle’
abstract: Two new books artfully blend fact and fiction about animal life.
lead_paragraph: If you read a lot of books to children, you may come up against the syndrome I call story fatigue: when a child who ordinarily likes a good story becomes sick of hearing about imaginary characters and their made-up scenarios. Or you may know a child with what seems like congenital story fatigue, who likes stories fine but always perks up around anything factual.

headline: Banana Pudding

lead_paragraph: Learn how to make old-school banana pudding, using a bed of Nilla wafers and topped with meringue.

headline: 1941: Vichy Troops Evacuate Sidon
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In June 1941, Vichy troops evacuate Sidon.
lead_paragraph: VICHY — Loss of the Lebanese coastal town of Sidon (Saida), sixty miles north of the Palestine frontier and about twenty miles south of Beirut, was admitted in a French communiqué issued here tonight [June 15] which said that the defending troops, after regaining possession of the town from Australian forces by a brilliant counter-attack and holding it all day yesterday, were compelled during last night to withdraw to fresh positions farther north. Bombardment of Sidon by ten British warships was said to have made the town untenable. — New York Herald Tribune, June 16, 1941

headline: Four Up-and-Coming Angeleno Artists to Know Now
abstract: T’s picks among the daring, thought-provoking — and funny — works on view at “Made in L.A.,” the Hammer Museum’s biennial survey of homegrown art.
lead_paragraph: This week, the third edition of Los Angeles’s homegrown biennial survey of art from SoCal, “Made in L.A.,” opened at the Hammer Museum in Westwood. Curated by the institution’s own Aram Moshayedi with Hamza Walker from Chicago’s Renaissance Society, this year’s show is tighter than previous iterations in the number of artists featured — just 26 — but somehow more expansive in the breadth of disciplines and practices that are integrated. Case in point: The subtitle of the show is itself an artwork: a poem by the biennial’s most senior artist, the minimalist writer Aram Saroyan. It goes “a, the, though, only,” a string of words that evoke particularity and universality at the same time. Here are four other highlights from “Made in L.A. 2016.”

abstract: The Gagosian had bought the piece from Maya Widmaier-Picasso in 2015 and sold it to Mr. Black; but the Qatari royal family said it bought the work in 2014.
lead_paragraph: The collector Leon Black is the legal victor in a dispute over the ownership of a famed Picasso sculpture and will take possession of it.

lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera has been transmitting performances live for a decade. The National Theater in London jumped on board a few years later. But Broadway, facing both financial and philosophical obstacles, has been slow to join the trend.

headline: De Blasio’s $325 Million Ferry Push: Rides to 5 Boroughs, at Subway Price
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan, which includes three new routes by the end of June 2017, would be one of the biggest bets any city in the world has made on boats as vehicles for mass transit.
lead_paragraph: With New York City’s subway trains jammed to capacity and more people than ever pouring into neighborhoods outside Manhattan, Mayor Bill de Blasio is embarking on an ambitious and expensive plan to create a fleet of city-owned ferryboats that would crisscross the surrounding waterways and connect all five boroughs.

headline: India Sentences Man-Eating Lion to Life — in the Zoo
abstract: Lion attacks on humans are rare, but in the first six months of this year there have been six killings in the western state of Gujarat.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — While investigating a rare cluster of deadly lion attacks, the authorities in an area of forested hills in the western Indian state of Gujarat took the unusual step of capturing and caging an entire pride of 17 lions, sending their dung to a forensic laboratory to be tested for traces of human remains.

headline: Can Gun Control Still Pass Muster in the Supreme Court?
abstract: By recognizing an individual right to bear arms in overturning handgun bans, the court seemed to put gun control efforts in jeopardy. Did it?

headline: 1966: U.K. Keeps Troops in Far East
abstract: From the archives of the International herald Tribune: In June 1966, the U.K. keeps troops in Far East.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Harold Wilson told critics within his governing Labour party today that Britain must keep troops in the Far East to prevent the dangers of an ‘‘eyeball-to-eyeball’’ nuclear confrontation between the United States and China. But he pledged there would be a massive reduction of the 50,000 British forces there once Indonesia ratified an end to its declared war against the Commonwealth nation of Malaysia. Mr. Wilson spoke in a meeting of Labour members of Parliament which crushed, by 225 votes to 54, a left and right-wing revolt against his East-of-Suez policies. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 16, 1966

headline: France Eases Rules for Police to Carry Guns While Off Duty

lead_paragraph: PARIS — France eased its gun rules on Wednesday to allow off-duty police officers to carry their sidearms even if the nation is not in a state of emergency. The move was a response to an attack on Monday in which an Islamic State assailant fatally stabbed a policeman and his companion at their home while their child was there.

headline: The Procrastinator’s $99 Tuxedo
abstract: New Era Factory Outlet specializes in men’s suits and formal wear, especially for people shopping at the last minute.
lead_paragraph: When the Lower East Side was teeming with garment shops, even a decade ago, New Era Factory Outlet had plenty of foot traffic. The neighborhood today, however, is hardly recognizable; Orchard Street has just as many art galleries, restaurants and bars as clothes sellers, and New Era now does most of its business online. But a few years ago, Robert Zaiger, New Era’s owner, noticed a new kind of customer at the shop: The young man looking for a tuxedo, often for his first formal occasion, and usually a procrastinator. It wasn’t the bubble-gum pink suit in the window that caught his eye, but a couple of dozen impassioned Yelp reviewers who raved about Mr. Zaiger’s service and low, low prices.

headline: Folic Acid During Pregnancy May Lower Risk of Childhood Obesity
keywords: ['Birth Defects', 'Folic Acid', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Pregnant women are advised to take folic acid to prevent birth defects. It may also lower the risk of obesity in their offspring.
lead_paragraph: Pregnant women should take folic acid, a B vitamin, during pregnancy to prevent neural tube defects in their babies. Now a new study, in JAMA Pediatrics, has found that sufficient folic acid during pregnancy may reduce the risk for obesity in children.

abstract: Dr. Selzer, who spent years as a surgeon, turned his operating-room experiences into fictional stories about modern medicine.
lead_paragraph: Richard Selzer, a surgeon who turned his operating-room experiences into fictional stories that blended the gore, the beauty and the absurdity of modern medicine, died on Wednesday in North Branford, Conn. He was 87.

headline: A Flare in the Stands Signals Trouble for Russia
abstract: UEFA hinted that the appearance of a flare among Russian fans, banned by its rules, would not lead to Russia’s expulsion from Euro 2016. Its play in a 2-1 loss to Slovakia might, however.
lead_paragraph: VILLENEUVE-D’ASCQ, France — Late Wednesday afternoon, seconds after Russia’s Denis Glushakov had scored with a sharp, well-placed header, a fan in the Russian supporters’ end of Stade Pierre-Mauroy lit a flare. The flame was dark red. The fan held it above his head while other spectators danced and cheered, the sparks licking the air while the smoke rose.

headline: Scientists Hear a Second Chirp From Colliding Black Holes
abstract: The noise, which lasted about a second, emanated from the collision of black holes roughly 14 and 8 times as massive as the sun.
lead_paragraph: When astronomers announced in February that they had detected the ripples in space-time known as gravitational waves from a pair of black holes colliding, the discovery was hailed as the advent of a new window on nature.

headline: Orlando Shooting Victims, Remembered
abstract: Family members and loved ones of the victims of the attack at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., have been paying tribute in interviews and in messages across social media.
lead_paragraph: Family members and loved ones of the victims of the attack at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., have been paying tribute in interviews and in messages across social media.

headline: TNT’s Craig Sager Will Join ABC for Game 6 Broadcast of N.B.A. Finals
abstract: Sager, the sideline reporter who has leukemia and is renowned for his vivid wardrobe, has never worked the sideline at a finals game.
lead_paragraph: In an unusual act of cooperation between rival networks, Craig Sager, TNT’s vividly attired N.B.A. sideline reporter, will be on ABC’s broadcast for Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals from Cleveland on Thursday night. He is scheduled to cover the Golden State Warriors.

headline: Visium Hedge Fund Managers Charged With Insider Trading
abstract: Two Visium employees were accused of trading on confidential information provided by a former F.D.A. employee, who was also charged in the case.
lead_paragraph: A multibillion-dollar hedge fund focused on health care had an inside view of the drug approval process at the Food and Drug Administration through a former high-ranking official turned consultant.

headline: Put Yourself in the Soccer Game (No Shin Guards Needed)
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Soccer', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'Android (Operating System)', 'UEFA European Football Championship']
abstract: The UEFA Euro 2016 soccer championships are taking place in France, a good time to get to know the global game. Apps offer stats, scores and games.
lead_paragraph: MANY soccer aficionados — which means pretty much half the world — are focused right now on the UEFA Euro 2016 championship, a big event that has brought together two dozen teams from countries across Europe. That makes it an opportune time to look at some apps that can help fans keep up with news of the sport, understand the championships and get a flavor of what it is like to play soccer.

headline: Omar Mateen Told Police He’d Strap Bombs to Hostages, Orlando Mayor Says
abstract: The gunman said during the attack that he would strap explosives to four hostages and place them in the corners of the nightclub, the mayor said.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Amid the massacre at a gay nightclub here, while the gunman held dozens of people hostage, the police got word from multiple sources that the killer had booby-trapped himself, hostages and the building with explosives, Orlando’s mayor said on Wednesday.

headline: What Duro Olowu Wears Each Day
abstract: The fashion designer and curator of the forthcoming exhibition “Making and Unmaking” shares his ritual of getting dressed in the morning.
lead_paragraph: The fashion designer and curator of the forthcoming exhibition “Making and Unmaking” shares his ritual of getting dressed in the morning.

headline: How Duro Olowu Gets Dressed in the Morning
abstract: For the fashion designer and curator of the new exhibition “Making and Unmaking,” it’s not about “look at me clothes ... it’s about making an effort.”
lead_paragraph: When it comes to that most personal, yet universal, of rituals — the daily act of getting dressed — Duro Olowu leaves little room for deviation. The fashion designer’s finely honed routine begins, without fail, with a shirt: “It’s not something I do consciously, but I always dress from the top down — that’s my ritual,” says the former lawyer, who takes no time when it comes to compiling his outfits (but spends ages in the shower). Thanks to his armory of bulk-bought basics, Olowu’s multilayered look is effortlessly streamlined. Though when it comes to packing, he’s anything but: “I’m notorious for not traveling light. I’m Nigerian!” laughs Olowu, who goes between London and New York, where his wife, the Studio Museum director Thelma Golden, is based. “I hate to go unprepared. Even for a three-day trip, I have serious luggage.”

headline: Celebrating July 4 — in South America
abstract: From skiing to hikes to desert excursions, resorts in South America are offering deals in July.
lead_paragraph: Instead of a stateside getaway for the long July 4 weekend, why not get into a different kind of American spirit by heading to South America?

headline: Why the I.R.S. Fails to Crack the Small-Business Tax Nut
abstract: The government has been trying to figure out how small-business owners can be persuaded to report their earnings more accurately. More audits may not be the answer.
lead_paragraph: Sizing up the honesty of small-business owners is one of the Internal Revenue Service’s most vexing problems.

headline: A ‘Brexit’ Battle on the Thames Between Nigel Farage and Bob Geldof
abstract: The question of whether Britain should remain in the European Union devolved into a naval confrontation in London on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Like so many decisive moments in British history, the question of whether to leave the European Union devolved on Wednesday into a naval confrontation.

abstract: The central bank, which entered the year planning to raise rates four times, has scaled back those plans as economic growth has disappointed expectations.

headline: Not Just a U.S. Problem: Black Lives Matter Here, Too, Canadians Say
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity']

lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Police shootings and abuses are all-too-familiar flashpoints in the United States’ tense national conversation about race, privilege and power, but until recently, many Canadians believed that those problems stopped on the American side of the border.

headline: Bloomsday and ‘Ulysses’
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Celebrating Bloomsday with a look back at an early review of “Ulysees,” shortly after it was published in Paris in 1922.
lead_paragraph: Bloomsday commemorates the life of the writer James Joyce. Celebrated on June 16, it is named after Leopold Bloom, the central character in Joyce’s “Ulysses.” Below is an excerpt from the review of the novel, shortly after it was published in Paris, in February 1922.

headline: For Musicians, More Access Means More Vulnerability
abstract: Artists, responding to industry and fan expectations, must make themselves accessible while contending with harassment and the threat of violence.
lead_paragraph: For Tiffany Alvord, an independent singer with a YouTube following of 2.8 million people, interacting with fans in person is her favorite part of playing concerts. It is also a business necessity that inspires loyalty by deepening the connections she has made online.

lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — It has been a roller coaster ride.

headline: Even With Confession of Cheating, World’s Doping Watchdog Did Nothing
abstract: The World Anti-Doping Agency’s response to warning signs of Russian doping raises questions of whether the agency is capable, or even willing, to aggressively combat doping.
lead_paragraph: In December 2012, the World Anti-Doping Agency received an email from an Olympic athlete from Russia. She was asking for help.

headline: A Trippy, Tongue-in-Cheek Music Video, Starring Alan Cumming
abstract: The actor also contributes lead vocals to the Hot Sardines’ cover of Ella Fitzgerald’s “When I Get Low I Get High.”
lead_paragraph: “I think the descriptor we used for the video was ‘Weimar acid trip,’” says Elizabeth Bougerol, the lead singer of the jazz collective the Hot Sardines, of the visual accompaniment to “When I Get Low I Get High,” an Ella Fitzgerald cover that’s the centerpiece of the band’s new album, “French Fries and Champagne.” “As we were brainstorming what exactly we meant by that, our director Alex Peacock brought us these Rorschach blotch smoke puffs and created ‘Fantasia’-style animations of the band, and we were off and running.”

headline: Yes, Obamacare Premiums Are Going Up
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A new study shows health plans are asking for rate increases twice as high as last year’s. Two health reporters discuss what it means for the future.
lead_paragraph: Get ready for big increases in premiums under the Affordable Care Act. A new analysis from the Kaiser Family Foundation examined the most popular individual plans under the new health care law in 14 major cities around the country and found that insurers were asking for increases in 2017 that are twice as big as this year’s. There is wide variation, including some places where rates will go down, but the average requested increase is 10 percent.

headline: ‘Many Echoes of My Family’s Journey’: Readers React to School Segregation
abstract: I heard from hundreds of people about my article on sending my daughter to a low-income, segregated school in New York City. Here are some of their questions and comments, along with my responses.
lead_paragraph: When the magazine published my article on how my husband and I navigated selecting a school for our daughter in New York City — one of the most segregated school systems in the country — it certainly touched a nerve. Since it went online last Thursday, it has garnered hundreds and hundreds of comments, emails, Facebook shares and Twitter conversations.

headline: A FanDuel-DraftKings Merger Might Be Worth a Chance
abstract: There would be some obvious savings from turning two daily fantasy sports sites into one big one.
lead_paragraph: A fantasy merger may not help FanDuel and DraftKings escape a harsh reality.

lead_paragraph: Ichiro Suzuki led off Wednesday afternoon’s game against the San Diego Padres by doing what he has so often done in his illustrious career in Japan and the United States: He beat out a ground ball for an infield single.

headline: The Peril that Lurks as People and Reptiles Flourish in Florida
abstract: The alligator attack on a toddler at an artificial lake in Disney World will not be the last violent encounter as people and reptiles increasingly overlap in Florida.
lead_paragraph: The Orlando area continues to reel, most recently after a two-year-old boy, relaxing with his family in shallows along the white-sand beach of the Seven Seas Lagoon at the Walt Disney World Resort, was snatched by an alligator Tuesday night. This afternoon, authorities said divers found the body of the toddler, Lane Graves of Elkhorn, Neb., in the murky water not far from where he vanished. [On June 22, state wildlife officials said they were “confident that the alligator responsible for the attack has been removed.”]

headline: Bypassing Private Equity to Get a Slice of the Big Deal
keywords: ['Private Equity', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: So-called emerging buyers are becoming involved in deals on their own, without paying fees to private equity firms, but the risks are higher.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the buyers in some of the largest deals had come in three forms: private equity firms, corporations and public market investors.

headline: Domestic Abuse Case Looms Large as Rockies Drop Jose Reyes
abstract: Colorado has 10 days to trade or release Reyes, the former All-Star shortstop who recently returned from a suspension for domestic violence.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — When the Colorado Rockies decided to swallow hard — $38 million must require quite a chaser — and designate Jose Reyes for assignment on Wednesday, it was hard to know exactly how much of a role his suspension in a domestic violence incident played in their decision.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Would ‘Accept’ Visit by Kim Jong-un
abstract: Mr. Trump said he would not go to Pyongyang, but if the North Korean leader came to Washington, he would meet with him — but without the traditional state dinner.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Since becoming the presumptive Republican nominee, Donald J. Trump has changed little at his rallies, often building on his caustic comments from the primary campaign.

headline: EgyptAir Flight 804 Wreckage Reported in Mediterranean
abstract: A search vessel in the Mediterranean found “several main locations of the wreckage” of Flight 804, the Egyptian government said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Searchers in the Mediterranean have found the first sunken wreckage of the EgyptAir flight that mysteriously veered off course and plunged from 37,000 feet last month, the Egyptian government reported Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: This is the buzz saw that Janet Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, walked into as she addressed the news media — and by extension, every trading floor on earth — Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Shortages. Rebels. Kidnappings: Life as a Foreign Correspondent

lead_paragraph: Child soldiers. Abductions. Infant mortality. Earthquakes. Caches of Kalashnikovs — in teenage hands.

headline: Review: In ‘Finding Dory,’ a Forgetful Fish and a Warm Celebration of Differences
abstract: The friendly blue fish with short-term memory problems goes looking for her family and takes a star turn in this sequel to “Finding Nemo.”
lead_paragraph: In “Finding Nemo,” Pixar’s 2003 masterpiece, the ocean was a vast realm of menace and wonder, newly charted by rapidly advancing digital-animation technology. The movie, a visual revelation, was also a welcome defense of risk-taking in an era of anxiety, and something of a cautionary tale about the downsides of helicopter parenting. As often happens in adventure stories, the hero was occasionally upstaged by his sidekick. We rooted for Nemo and choked up when he was found, but the best lines and sweetest grace notes belonged to Dory, the absent-minded blue tang voiced by Ellen DeGeneres.

headline: To Secure Loans, Chinese Women Supply Perilous Collateral: Nude Photos
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Credit and Debt', 'Nudism and Nudity']
abstract: Women are sending photos of themselves to peer-to-peer lenders, who then sometimes blackmail them when they cannot pay high interest rates, Chinese state media reported.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Women in China are sending naked photographs of themselves holding their ID cards to peer-to-peer lenders as collateral, Chinese state media have reported, in a trend that may involve thousands of people.

headline: Employee of Panama Papers Law Firm, Mossack Fonseca, Is Arrested in Switzerland
abstract: The man was arrested after the firm filed a complaint, but it was not clear if the arrest was connected to the leaked documents that have led to investigations of globally prominent figures.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — An employee of the law firm at the center of the leaks of the Panama Papers, which have revealed offshore wealth held in secretive accounts worldwide, has been arrested here on charges of data theft, one of the employee’s lawyers, Romain Jordan, said on Wednesday.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Alysia Reiner Reads ‘Those Aren’t Fighting Words, Dear’
abstract: The “Orange Is the New Black” actress reads the story of a woman who chooses not to react when her husband tells her: “I don’t love you anymore. I’m not sure I ever did.”
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actress Alysia Reiner (“Orange Is the New Black,” “How to Get Away With Murder”) reads the Modern Love essay “Those Aren’t Fighting Words, Dear,” about a woman who chooses not to react when her husband tells her: “I don’t love you anymore. I’m not sure I ever did.”

headline: Water Hazard – Florida Tries to Keep People and Alligators Apart
abstract: As far back as 1988, Florida’s booming human and alligator populations were clashing in ways that took up half of some wildlife officials’ workdays.
lead_paragraph: I wrote the following article, on increasing human-alligator conflicts in Florida, in the summer of 1988 for Discover Magazine. I’m posting it here in full because of its relevance after the tragic loss of a toddler to an alligator on an artificial beach at the Walt Disney World Resort near Orlando. You can download a pdf here. Here’s my related Dot Earth post: “The Peril that Lurks as People and Reptiles Flourish in Florida.”

headline: Hillary Clinton Mocks Donald Trump’s National Security Ideas

lead_paragraph: HAMPTON, Va. — Hillary Clinton rebuked Donald J. Trump on Wednesday for proposing national security ideas that she argued would put America in greater danger and inspire more terrorist attacks.

headline: Orlando Shooting Witness Tells Her Story
abstract: Jeannette McCoy survived the shooting in Orlando. She was inside the nightclub Pulse when the attack began, and she described how she managed to escape.
lead_paragraph: Jeannette McCoy survived the shooting in Orlando. She was inside the nightclub Pulse when the attack began, and she described how she managed to escape.

headline: Review: ‘Dead End,’ With Its Open Structure, Addresses Orlando
abstract: The last-minute, open structure of this music, dance and recitation performance allowed it to address the mass shooting in Orlando, Fla.
lead_paragraph: First came a trigger warning. At Roulette in Brooklyn on Tuesday, “Dead End: Don’t Let Me Down,” by Yoshiko Chuma & the School of Hard Knocks, opened with the announcement that a prop gun would be fired during the performance. Following Chekhov’s rule, Ms. Chuma did eventually pull the trigger after intermission, but instead of a bang, the fake weapon emitted only a sad click.

headline: Review: ‘The Dreaming Room’ Follows Laura Mvula’s Highs and Lows

headline: Improv Troupe’s Appeal: Imagine the ‘Friends’ Cast Doing ‘Game of Thrones’
abstract: “The Cast,” directed by Hannah Chase, is an example of how this Magnet Theater group comes up with creative ways to play with genre and presentation.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday, members of the improv show “The Cast” were swept from a rehearsal space in Midtown Manhattan to the medieval fantasy world of HBO’s “Game of Thrones.” After being assigned a name befitting a George R. R. Martin character, the performers improvised monologues. “I am Chessalind Algolith, and I own this brothel,” began one.

headline: Review: Following ‘Figaro’ From Room to Room in a Townhouse
abstract: The audience follows the performers, along with a roving band of instrumentalists, in this On Site Opera presentation of Marcos Portugal’s work.
lead_paragraph: The valet Figaro bustles about, measuring the floor space of the new quarters he will soon occupy with Susanna, while, off to the side, she tries on a bridal hat. These are the beloved characters we know from Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro.” But the unfamiliar music is by Marcos Portugal, born in Lisbon in 1762 and renowned in his time.

headline: Review: Jessica Lang Dance Looks at Soldiers and Sonnets
abstract: The troupe, celebrating its fifth anniversary, returned to the Joyce Theater with three New York premieres on its program.
lead_paragraph: It’s all about imagery: army fatigues, ink splatters and a train of fabric that stretches long or gathers in a swirl around a woman’s ankles. Is it a lake or quicksand? Probably both. Jessica Lang’s dances may be subdued, but they don’t embrace subtlety.

headline: Polio Strain Found in Hyderabad, India, Prompts Vaccination Drive
abstract: The health authorities in the southern state of Telangana said that no one had been infected, but they announced that they would try to vaccinate 300,000 children.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The health authorities in the southern Indian state of Telangana have issued a high alert in Hyderabad, the state capital, after finding a strain of polio in sewage water there, a state health official said Wednesday.

headline: House Panel Recommends Censure of I.R.S. Commissioner
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling']
abstract: The Oversight and Government Reform Committee recommended that the House censure John A. Koskinen, accusing him of betraying the trust of Congress and the public.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A polarized House committee on Wednesday recommended that the House censure the commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, John A. Koskinen, and seek to strip him of his office and his federal pension for “a pattern of conduct” that betrayed the trust of Congress and the public.

headline: ‘A Bronx Tale’ Heads to Broadway
abstract: Chazz Palminteri’s largely autobiographical story, made famous in the film featuring Robert De Niro, will arrive at the Longacre Theater this fall.
lead_paragraph: “A Bronx Tale” is Broadway bound.

headline: What Does Bernie Sanders Want?
abstract: While the nominating contest ended with a whimper, Mr. Sanders hopes to go out with a roar.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the tragedy in Orlando, few seemed to notice that the Democratic primary season finally ended on Tuesday, when Hillary Clinton, already the Democrats’ likely nominee, won 79 percent of the D.C. vote.

headline: Review: In ‘Louis D. Brandeis: American Prophet,’ Moral Vision and a True Believer’s Zeal
abstract: Jeffrey Rosen’s book is a concise exploration of this Supreme Court justice’s main intellectual causes, which included a mistrust of big business.
lead_paragraph: Louis Brandeis geared up for combat when J. P. Morgan’s New Haven Railroad tried to buy the Boston and Maine lines. Brandeis hated the thought of what he called “a monster corporation controlling all transportation facilities of New England,” and lobbied fiercely against the merger. Morgan prevailed, “but it took all the power of the Republican machine and of the bankers’ money to do it,” Brandeis wrote, “and I am well content with the fight made.”

headline: Expiration Date on China’s Promises Stokes Unease in Hong Kong Housing
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Mortgages']
abstract: Most banks have yet to formulate mortgage policies beyond 2047, when an agreement guaranteeing the city a high degree of autonomy runs out.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — To buy a tiny but coveted apartment in the vertiginous towers of South Horizons, a middle-class housing development overlooking the South China Sea in the world’s most expensive real estate market, would cost a family about a million United States dollars.

lead_paragraph: The forthcoming Matthew McConaughey drama “Free State of Jones” lays claim to being the first Hollywood film in decades to depict Reconstruction, the still controversial post-Civil War period that attempted to rebuild the South along racially egalitarian lines.

headline: Orlando Medical Examiner: ‘Take a Typical Homicide Scene, Multiply It by 50’
abstract: A team led by Dr. Joshua D. Stephany, Orange County’s chief medical examiner, has conducted autopsies on all of the 49 victims of the attack at the Pulse.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Corpses do not faze him but Joshua D. Stephany, Orlando’s chief medical examiner, still has the image of what he saw inside the Pulse nightclub on the morning of the slaughter seared into his head.

headline: Among Olympians’ Zika Precautions: Fewer Guests, Frozen Sperm
abstract: As those headed to Rio come up with plans to battle the mosquito-borne virus, John Speraw, an American volleyball coach, is preserving sperm in case he is infected.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — As thousands of athletes headed to the Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro worry, to varying degrees, about the Zika virus, at least one American has taken a pre-emptive measure: freezing his sperm.

headline: ‘Goodbye Christopher Robin’ Stars Are Announced
abstract: The film, about the author of “Winnie-the-Pooh” books, will feature Domhnall Gleeson and Margot Robbie.
lead_paragraph: Domhnall Gleeson, recently seen in “The Revenant,” will play A. A. Milne, the author of the “Winnie-the-Pooh” books, in a new film, “Goodbye Christopher Robin.” The movie will also star Margot Robbie (soon to be seen in “The Legend of Tarzan”) as Milne’s wife, Daphne.

headline: Modern Dance Alfresco at Bryant Park This Summer
abstract: Works from Nicole Philippidis, Earl Mosley, Clifton Brown and Amy Marshall Dance Company are heading to the park on Fridays.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a summer dance festival? Try going outside: More and more New York City parks are becoming outdoor festival sites, and every Friday through July 8, Bryant Park Presents Modern Dance hosts companies representing many contemporary styles.

headline: A Millennial-Friendly Russian Designer Is a Hit in Florence
keywords: ['Millennial Generation', 'Fashion Shows', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: From Russia, with love for youth culture, comes Gosha Rubchinskiy, a pied piper of international streetwear.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — Like baby rabbits, so pale and unformed are the teenage models cast by the Russian street style phenomenon Gosha Rubchinskiy — whose rapid ascent to cult design status was slyly overseen by the marketing masterminds of the Japanese designer Rei Kawakubo’s company, Comme des Garçons.

headline: ‘The Tunnel,’ on PBS, Is Britain’s Answer to ‘The Bridge’
abstract: The show stars Clémence Poésy and Stephen Dillane as detectives.
lead_paragraph: It’s a perfect show for the age of Brexit: A woman is found dead at the midpoint of the Channel Tunnel, half her body in France and the other half in Britain, and detectives from both countries are called to investigate. But what begins as one murder becomes two, with the bodies bisected at the waist and positioned to form a single corpse, in “The Tunnel,” debuting Sunday, June 19, on PBS. “Look, she comes apart like the eurozone!” the butcher — nicknamed the Truth Terrorist because he claims to kill to shed light on societal woes — later taunts.

headline: Anderson Cooper Covering Orlando Shooting With Touch of Empathy
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The CNN anchor has seemed to embrace an advocacy role in his coverage of the massacre that is rarely seen among top network anchors.
lead_paragraph: Anderson Cooper was reading the names of victims of the Orlando massacre on CNN this week when, uncharacteristically, his voice wavered and he drew up short. For moments, viewers around the country heard only silence, and then the sounds of the anchor struggling to compose himself.

headline: Werner Herzog Contemplates the Implications of the Internet
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Mr. Herzog’s new documentary, which explores the past, present and future of the web, will screen at BAMcinemaFest.
lead_paragraph: Werner Herzog, whose enthusiasm for human development led him to some of mankind’s earliest communications in “Cave of Forgotten Dreams,” extends his fascination in “Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World.” Colored in both awe and whimsy, this documentary explores the internet and the technologies it has spawned or aided. From a brief history of the internet’s beginnings in the 1960s, to stories of abusive cyberbehavior, to interviews with roboticists, astronomists and spaceflight futurists, the film muses where this new age might be headed.

headline: Gilbert Gottfried to Perform Rare Set at Carolines
abstract: Mr. Gottfried has been known to show off his creative, filthy and utterly singular mind.
lead_paragraph: After the Tony Awards, Broadway gets quiet, as shows announce closing notices and openings become scarce. But a distinctive screeching sound around Times Square will raise the volume in the area for at least a night, when Gilbert Gottfried performs at Carolines on Thursday, June 23.

headline: A Musical Biography About Astor Piazzolla
abstract: “That’s Not Tango,” Written by Lesley Karsten and Stephen Wadsworth, is running at SubCulture through June 25.
lead_paragraph: “That’s Not Tango” may seem like an odd title for a musical biography about Astor Piazzolla. After all, no other composer did more to pluck tango out of the seedy, seething bars it was associated with and translate it into sophisticated concert music bursting with erotic energy. But this show, which opens at SubCulture on Wednesday, June 22, seems willing to question everything.

headline: Théodore Rousseau Gets His Due at the Getty Museum
abstract: “Unruly Nature: The Landscapes of Théodore Rousseau” opens on June 21 in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Théodore Rousseau (1812-1867) ranks high on the list of underappreciated 19th-century European painters. A mystic who thought trees spoke to him, and a materialist prone to unorthodox mixtures of media on canvas, panel and paper, he was a leader of the Barbizon school, yet his name is far less familiar than those of Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot or Jean-François Millet. Not interested in the human figure, Rousseau attended to nature’s textures and moods, zeroing in on details of leaves and bark, while using light and weather to render nature as a source of terror and contemplation.

headline: How Donald Trump Tends His Media Blacklist
keywords: ['Editorials', 'News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Blacklisting']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s media-bashing is another instance of his targeting entire groups for criticism and control.
lead_paragraph: Few public figures have more avidly tended their relationships with the media than Donald Trump. For four decades he has courted the press to promote himself and his enterprises. Yet when the coverage doesn’t go his way, he can retaliate with lawsuits and childish fits of pique.

headline: Yankees’ Losing Streak Reaches Four With Defeat in Colorado
abstract: Ivan Nova gave up five runs in five innings as the Yankees got swept in a two-game series at Coors Field.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — A couple of innings after D. J. LeMahieu lay prone after taking a fastball to the helmet, he stepped into the batter’s box for what should have been a very gingerly at-bat against Aroldis Chapman and the major leagues’ fastest fastball.

headline: Let Me Compete in Rio
abstract: Don’t punish me because other Russians have used banned substances; I have not.
lead_paragraph: Volgograd, Russia — In less than two months, I hope to be competing in the pole vault at the Olympic Games in Rio. This would be my fifth and final Olympics — a unique accomplishment for a woman, one that seemed just a faint dream when I started my career almost two decades ago.

headline: The 5 Types of Trump-Averse Republicans
abstract: After a stream of incendiary comments by the presumed presidential nominee, lawmakers run, walk or contort themselves.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His unrelenting stream of incendiary remarks have left horrified congressional Republicans divided into five loose categories about the problem that is Donald J. Trump.

headline: Iran Accuses Thomson Reuters Charity Official of Sedition
abstract: The charge was the first explanation for the arrest in April of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, a British-Iranian program coordinator for the Thomson Reuters Foundation.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A British-Iranian employee of the Thomson Reuters Foundation, arrested in Iran more than two months ago for unexplained reasons, has been accused of plotting to overthrow the government, Iranian news media reported Wednesday.

headline: Orlando Shooting Renews Debate Over Limits on Gay Men Donating Blood
abstract: Gay rights activists have protested a ban on donations from sexually active men, but health officials say their position is based on science.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the Pulse nightclub shooting in Orlando, Fla., 53 people were alive but wounded, many in desperate need of blood. Blood banks in the area put out a call for donors.

headline: Speed of a MetroCard Swipe
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority provided an inquirer with data on how fast one should move a transit card through the turnstile.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Alcohol, Gambling and Golf: The Long History of Blue Laws in New York
keywords: ['ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Restaurants', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Law and Legislation', 'State Legislatures', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: With the Legislature and the governor agreeing to earlier Sunday sales of alcohol at restaurants and bars, another vestige of Puritan-imposed morality falls.
lead_paragraph: Legend has it that in 1789, George Washington, the nation’s newly elected president, was riding on horseback from Connecticut to New York when he was detained by a local official for violating the Sunday “blue law” ban against traveling. The president supposedly got off with just a reprimand after explaining that he was on his way to church.

headline: Draymond Green, Contrite Yet Chatty, Rejoins the Warriors
abstract: Green returned after a one-game suspension just in time to help out the Warriors, who will be without the injured Andrew Bogut.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Draymond Green, fresh off his one-game suspension, returned to Quicken Loans Arena on Wednesday afternoon, and he had some things he wanted to say.

headline: Tencent Nears Deal to Buy Supercell, Maker of Clash of Clans
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: If completed, the transaction for control of the Finnish game maker would show the growing power of China’s internet giants and bolster their presence in the global gaming market.
lead_paragraph: One of China’s internet giants, Tencent, is near a deal to buy control of Supercell, the maker of the popular Clash of Clans game, in a transaction that would value the Finnish game company at more than $9 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Redstone Says in a Letter He No Longer Trusts Viacom’s Chief
abstract: Sumner Redstone said in an emailed letter that he longer trusts Viacom’s chief, Philippe Dauman, or the company’s board.
lead_paragraph: The ailing media mogul Sumner M. Redstone declared in a rare missive sent on Wednesday that he no longer trusted Philippe P. Dauman, Viacom’s embattled chief executive, or those who support him.

headline: Government Discloses Hearing Transcripts for Ex-Prisoners of C.I.A.
abstract: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union, the government has disclosed new portions of transcripts from military hearings in 2007, in which "high value" detainees described being tortured by the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union, the government has disclosed new portions of transcripts from military hearings in 2007, in which "high value" detainees described being tortured by the C.I.A.

headline: Detainees Describe C.I.A. Torture in Declassified Transcripts
abstract: The government disclosed the transcripts, from military hearings of former C.I.A. prisoners, in response to a lawsuit by the American Civil Liberties Union.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After the Central Intelligence Agency transferred Abu Zubaydah to the American military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, and he was brought before a panel of officers for a hearing in March 2007, he described in broken English how he had been tortured in the agency’s black-site prisons.

headline: Ex-Classmate of Murdered Brooklyn Girl Is Indicted 10 Years After Her Death
abstract: Veron Primus, accused of killing Chanel Petro-Nixon, is in custody on a Caribbean island and awaiting extradition.
lead_paragraph: On Father’s Day in 2006, a Brooklyn high school student named Chanel Petro-Nixon went for a job interview at an Applebee’s restaurant just blocks from her apartment in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood. Chanel, 16, was an avid reader and a straight-A student. She never came back.

headline: World Anti-Doping Agency Accuses Russian Athletes of More Violations
abstract: The agency, citing specific episodes, said efforts by athletes to flout drug-testing programs have not stopped since Russia was accused of government-sponsored doping last fall.
lead_paragraph: A track and field athlete tried to smuggle in a clean urine sample for drug testing, concealing a container inside her body and offering a bribe when her scheme failed. Sports officials refused to provide a list of the athletes who were present at a boxing training camp, revealing the names after stalling for a full hour. Armed federal police officers threatened drug testers who showed up to collect athletes’ urine, and packages containing doping samples sent from abroad were tampered with by customs workers.

headline: Gawker Founder Nick Denton Confident of Company’s Future
abstract: Mr. Denton expressed hope in a new owner, and the possibility that the court penalty will be reduced on appeal.
lead_paragraph: Nick Denton has been relatively quiet since his company, Gawker Media, filed for bankruptcy and put itself up for sale on Friday, posting just a handful of tweets.

headline: Man Who Ran Flophouses Facing New Fraud Charges
keywords: ['Group Homes and Supportive Housing', 'Evictions', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Yury Baumblit, who along with his wife was indicted on money laundering charges, has now been charged with illegally evicting tenants.
lead_paragraph: A former operator of flophouses who was profiled in an investigation last year by The New York Times is facing additional criminal charges that he defrauded tenants and illegally evicted them, prosecutors said.

headline: Opposition to Judge in Stanford Sexual Assault Case Grows, In and Out of Court
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The Santa Clara district attorney’s office removed Judge Aaron Persky from another sexual assault case and jurors have objected to serving in his courtroom.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A California judge who was criticized for handing down a short jail term in a case involving a sexual assault at Stanford University is facing a growing number of impediments both inside and outside the courtroom.

headline: Oakmont Country Club Sets Standard for U.S. Open Play
abstract: The site of the 116th United States Open, beginning Thursday, is considered one of golf’s most challenging courses, so the unprepared have no reason to gripe.
lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — The United States Open does not sneak up on anyone, but every year, many players feel ambushed.

headline: Red Tape on Spanish Visa Leaves Syrian Girl’s Surgery in Limbo
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: The girl, not yet a year old, is stranded with her family in Jordan as lawyers try to clear the way for her to receive an urgent and complex operation.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Sham Aldaher came into the world in Jordan last July, safe from the horrors of the Syrian war that her family had fled, but born with a disfigured face and missing an eye. Doctors said she required urgent and complex surgery.

headline: Gregory Rabassa, a Premier Translator of Spanish and Portuguese Fiction, Dies at 94
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Spanish Language', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Professor Rabassa was known in particular for making the wave of dynamic and powerful fiction that emerged in Latin America in the 1960s accessible in English.
lead_paragraph: Gregory Rabassa, a distinguished translator from Spanish and Portuguese who brought the work of luminaries like Gabriel García Márquez and Mario Vargas Llosa to a wide English-speaking public, died on Monday in Branford, Conn. He was 94.

headline: After Orlando, a Political Divide on Gay Rights Still Stands
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Republicans offer spiritual support and sympathy for the massacre victims in Orlando, Fla., but do not appear to budge on legal protections for gays.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a fleeting moment this week, it seemed as if the massacre in Orlando, Fla., was having the unlikely and unintended impact of helping to bridge the chasm between Republicans and many in the gay community.

headline: Hoosick Falls Residents Take Anger Over Tainted Water to New York’s Capitol
abstract: A toxic chemical known as PFOA has been found in the upstate village’s water, and people there called on the Legislature to hold hearings on the state’s response to the contamination.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The residents of Hoosick Falls came to the State Capitol on Wednesday with the numbers hung around their necks, scribbled on their arms, and described on hand-drawn posters:

headline: Clinton Talks Tough on Terror, as Obama Weighs His Words
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s more aggressive stance is just one of several policy differences that could create challenges as the president begins campaigning for her.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and Hillary Clinton have been in lock step in denouncing Donald J. Trump’s response to the mass shooting in Orlando, Fla. Yet their united front against Mrs. Clinton’s likely Republican opponent in the presidential election this fall masks differences in how they portray the threat from Islamic terrorism at home and how they would wage the campaign to defeat it abroad.

headline: Led Zeppelin’s Jimmy Page Testifies in ‘Stairway to Heaven’ Copyright Trial
keywords: ['Music', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: Mr. Page, 72, defended himself in court, saying that when he finally heard the song “Taurus” by the lesser-known group Spirit, it sounded “totally alien” to him.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Jimmy Page of Led Zeppelin, testifying in a closely watched copyright trial on Wednesday, said that until recently he had never heard the song he has been accused of plagiarizing in the band’s 1971 hit “Stairway to Heaven.”

headline: Move On
abstract: Timothy Polin gives us some good advice.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — At first, I thought it had to be a rebus. It’s almost unheard of for me to take a first pass through the clues on a Thursday with only three entries filled in. One of which was wrong.

headline: At Pride Event, Police Move to Mend Bond With Gay New Yorkers
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Police', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)']
abstract: The Gay Officers Action League of New York held a community gathering as an effort to show that the city had a diverse force with officers who shared similar experiences.
lead_paragraph: Inside the brick fortress near the Brooklyn Bridge that is 1 Police Plaza, the headquarters of the New York Police Department, the auditorium is a place where officers come for jubilant events, where cadets are sworn in and where members of the force shake the hand of the commissioner after a promotion.

headline: Noah Syndergaard Strikes Out 11 as Mets Rout Pirates
abstract: Syndergaard was charged with two runs in eight and a third innings, and the Mets collected 19 hits, including Kelly Johnson’s first homer with the Mets this season.
lead_paragraph: Noah Syndergaard fell short of a shutout but still pitched strongly enough to strike out 11, and the Mets amassed a season-high 19 hits for a thorough 11-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates on Wednesday at Citi Field.

headline: Ravens Release Eugene Monroe, Who Advocated for Medical Marijuana
abstract: The Ravens tried to trade the seven-year veteran, who had been hampered by injuries, but talks with the Giants fell through.
lead_paragraph: Baltimore Ravens offensive tackle Eugene Monroe was released Wednesday, several months after he had publicly called on the N.F.L. to let players use medical marijuana to treat injuries.

headline: U.S. Expects Boost From Seattle Crowd at Copa América
abstract: The American team, which faces Ecuador on Thursday night, is looking to return to the final four of the tournament for the first time in 21 years.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Looking to get back into the final four of the Copa América for the first time in 21 years, the United States men’s national soccer team is expecting thunderous support from fans at Thursday night’s quarterfinal against Ecuador in Seattle.

abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, June 16, 2016.

headline: A Hungarian Artist Comes Into His Own
abstract: Sam Havadtoy’s wanderings took him from communist Europe to New York and Yoko Ono.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — The common element to the eclectic group of works that Sam Havadtoy created for his exhibit “Only Remember the Future” at the Mudima Foundation here is not immediately noticeable to the eye.

headline: Uber Rival’s $28 Billion Valuation Shows Size of China’s Ride-Sharing Market
abstract: Didi Chuxing brought in $7.3 billion in its latest fund-raising round, giving it a valuation of almost half that of Uber, its main competitor in China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — With more internet users than any other country and a fast-rising middle class, China is one of the most sought-after markets in the world.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Michael Shannon and Rachel Bloom face off on “Lip Sync Battle.” And catch up on “Curb Your Enthusiasm” before its return to HBO.
lead_paragraph: Now that’s crazy: Michael Shannon and Rachel Bloom face off on “Lip Sync Battle.” Jerry Seinfeld takes Jim Gaffigan for a ride in “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee.” And catch up on “Curb Your Enthusiasm” before its return to HBO.
