headline: Filibuster for Gun Limits Plays Out on Social Media
abstract: Led by Senator Christopher S. Murphy, dozens of Democrats talked into early Thursday.
lead_paragraph: It started as a lone voice for gun control in the Senate, but the message was amplified in real time to millions on Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Black Dandies, Style Rebels With a Cause
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'Photography', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The traveling exhibit “Dandy Lion” presents striking images of dapper men of African descent whose sartorial flair challenges notions of race and masculinity.
lead_paragraph: “The Waiting Man I,” by the American photographer Kia Chenelle, represents the epitome of male sartorial elegance. The man (Slide 9) wears a double-breasted blazer, tweed trousers and sleek sandals. A mass of dreadlocks issues from under his dapper hat. Sunglasses and a pocket square complete his look.

headline: A Sport Without Referees? It’s the Ultimate Debate
abstract: Ultimate Frisbee officials disagree about the best practice for officiating, as the sport has relied since its inception on players making their own calls.
lead_paragraph: When teams from 39 nations were to convene in London on Saturday for the world ultimate championships, the scene quite likely looked like many other international sports competitions. There would be 3,000 athletes competing in men’s, women’s and mixed divisions. There would be flags and an opening ceremony.

headline: European? British? These ‘Brexit’ Voters Identify as English
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Foreign Workers', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: In the debate over whether Britain should leave the European Union, a fierce sense of English identity could prove critical to the outcome.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH BENFLEET, England — The topic of the local debate was Britain’s imminent vote on whether to leave the European Union, and the discussion in this English town on the southeastern coast turned to the influx of European citizens into Britain.

headline: Found Poem Favorite | ‘The Sound of War’
abstract: A piece by Sebastian Quevedo, taken from two 2016 Op-Eds, “Frozen Life in Wartime Syria” and “The Segregation of India.”
lead_paragraph: We are honoring the top winners of our Seventh Annual Found Poem Student Contest by publishing their work from June 6 to 17. You’ll be able to read the whole collection here as we go.

headline: Visa Abuses Harm American Workers
abstract: Some companies use loopholes in a work-permit law to replace American employees with lower-paid foreigners.
lead_paragraph: There is no doubt that H-1B visas — temporary work permits for specially talented foreign professionals — are instead being used by American employers to replace American workers with cheaper foreign labor. Abbott Laboratories, the health care conglomerate based in Illinois, recently became the latest large American company to use the visas in this way, following the lead of other employers, including Southern California Edison, Northeast Utilities (now Eversource Energy), Disney, Toys “R” Us and New York Life.

headline: Omar Mateen, American Monster
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Hate Crimes', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: This was both an act of domestic terror and a hate crime. This norm of ours simply isn’t normal.
lead_paragraph: The massacre in Orlando, where 49 people were gunned down at an L.G.B.T. nightclub and dozens of others were wounded, came at the hands of a coward and a monster, but make no mistake: This was our monster.

headline: A Pistol for Every Bar Stool
abstract: Trump is ready to lock and load.
lead_paragraph: The nation hasn’t exactly joined hands in a united response to the Orlando massacre. But since this terrible mass shooting happened in one of the most weapons-friendly places in the country, maybe we can at least all agree that having wildly permissive gun laws does not make a city safer.

headline: The N.R.A.’s Complicity in Terrorism
abstract: The American gun lobby’s refusal to accept even mild controls has made the U.S. a favorite of terrorists who want to use guns.
lead_paragraph: “America is absolutely awash with easily obtainable firearms,” one spokesman for Al Qaeda said in a 2011 recruitment video. “So what are you waiting for?”

headline: An Olympic Antidoping Champion
abstract: Yuliya Stepanova risked everything to expose Russian cheating, so let her run in Rio.
lead_paragraph: Baltimore — THE International Olympic Committee recently announced that 10 refugee athletes from troubled or war-torn nations would be allowed to compete in the summer Olympic Games. The committee believes that the group, officially known as the Refugee Olympic Team, will serve as a “symbol of hope” in Rio de Janeiro.

keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Muslim Americans', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Firearms have their valid uses, but we should keep them out of the hands of violent people.

headline: Desperation Rising at Home, Africans Increasingly Turn to Risky Seas
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Drownings', 'International Relations', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: More than 1,300 migrants have died trying to cross the Mediterranean in boats from North Africa in the last few weeks alone.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Samba Thiam knew exactly what would happen after his older brother drowned with 800 other migrants last spring in one of the worst Mediterranean shipwrecks in recent history.

headline: Shanghai Disneyland Opens Amid Rain and Pageantry
abstract: The first Disney park on the mainland, built for $5.5 billion, is being held up as nothing less than a historic symbol of United States-China relations.

abstract: OceanOne is designed to look like a human. Why? How does it use its head, arms and hands?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activity is based on the article “OceanOne, a Mer-Bot Dive Buddy With a ‘Friendly Face.’ ”

headline: Measuring the Trump Effect
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Trump vs. Clinton is changing the shape of the Toomey-McGinty Senate race in Pennsylvania. A visit to deindustrialized Pottstown helps us see why.
lead_paragraph: POTTSTOWN, Pa. — At the moment, Donald J. Trump casts a long shadow over this once-thriving community, where steel mills, furnaces, bridge works, brickyards, textile plants and boiler shops provided steady jobs for the city’s working and middle classes.

headline: The Chosen Life
abstract: There are only a few doctors left in Alabama who provide abortions. Yashica Robinson is one of them.
lead_paragraph: I first met Dr. Yashica Robinson while I was in Huntsville, Ala., filming a feature documentary about the impact of regulation on abortion clinics in the South, called “Trapped.” I’d heard about her but never met her, and finally we were introduced by another abortion provider in the South, Dr. Willie Parker.

headline: The Chosen Life

lead_paragraph: There are only a few doctors left in Alabama who provide abortions. Yashica Robinson is one of them.

headline: In Brooklyn, a Home and Home Brewery
abstract: Melissa and Jesse Peretz watched the price drop on a Kensington house, and eventually put in a bid.
lead_paragraph: When they married nearly two years ago, Melissa and Jesse Peretz were living in a $2,500-a-month rental in a new building in Gowanus, Brooklyn. A one-bedroom, it had 700 efficient square feet — none of “those weird quirks where a long hallway counts for 100 square feet and isn’t usable,” Mrs. Peretz said. They outgrew it quickly.

headline: You Want Tastier Coffee? Freeze Beans, Then Grind
abstract: The colder the bean, the more uniform the grind and the more flavorful the brew, a study found.
lead_paragraph: Percolator, French press, AeroPress, espresso, pour over, vacuum pot, automatic brew, tin can: People go to great lengths for a good cup of coffee. (A friend of mine filters his cold brew with pantyhose.) But to achieve consistent flavor you may just need to chill your beans before grinding them. Colder beans produce smaller, more consistently sized particles when ground, yielding more flavor from less coffee, according to a study published in Scientific Reports.

headline: ‘It’s Pretty Lonely’: A Democratic Incumbent in a Sea of Texas Red
abstract: Judge Lawrence E. Meyers, elected in 1992 as a Republican to the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals, switched parties in 2013. Now he’s up for re-election.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — There are 29 statewide elected offices in Texas. Republicans control 28 of them. And then there’s Lawrence E. Meyers, 68, the senior judge on the state’s highest criminal court and the sole Democrat.

headline: Rise at 11? China’s Single Time Zone Means Keeping Odd Hours
abstract: Some days, the sun doesn’t come up until 10 a.m. in Urumqi, where clocks are set to Beijing time despite being 2,000 miles to the west.
lead_paragraph: Some days, the sun doesn’t come up until 10 a.m. or later. People eat lunch after 2 p.m., or even after 4 if they’re not in a rush. The school day stretches so late that children can’t get home in time to catch their favorite cartoon shows.

headline: The Garrison Keillor You Never Knew
abstract: After more than four decades of hosting “A Prairie Home Companion,” which he created and which, in turn, created him, the public radio legend is retiring.
lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL, MINN. — Garrison Keillor was riding shotgun in a rented Chevy, motoring east through the steamy Midwestern heat.

headline: Susan Faludi’s ‘In the Darkroom’
abstract: In this rich, arresting memoir, Faludi writes about discovering that her estranged father, 76 at the time, had undergone gender reassignment surgery.
lead_paragraph: IN THE DARKROOMBy Susan Faludi417 pp. Metropolitan Books/Henry Holt & Company. $32.

headline: L.G.B.T. People Are More Likely to Be Targets of Hate Crimes Than Any Other Minority Group
abstract: How L.G.B.T. people are frequent targets of hate crime, and a closer look at some of the victims.
lead_paragraph: How L.G.B.T. people are frequent targets of hate crime, and a closer look at some of the victims.

headline: Eastern Europe Is Both Dreading Brexit and Ready for It
abstract: As Britain prepares to vote, memories of the communist collapse color Eastern Europeans’ expectations.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — IN the final days of June 1914, a telegram arrives in a remote garrison town on the border of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. On it is a single sentence in capital letters: “Heir to the throne rumored assassinated in Sarajevo.”

headline: China Is Said to Rescind Invitation to Taiwan Children’s Choir
abstract: Organizers of an event in Guangdong Province canceled the invitation to the Puzangalan Choir after a performance at the presidential inauguration in Taiwan in May.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For a children’s choral group, it was a big stage: singing the national anthem at the inauguration of President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan last month. But it came with a cost. The Puzangalan Choir had been scheduled to perform in Guangdong Province in southern China in July, but the organizers of that event canceled the invitation, according to the official Central News Agency of Taiwan.

headline: Stella McCartney Is Making Men’s Wear
abstract: The designer’s first men’s collection will debut in November alongside her spring women’s collection.
lead_paragraph: After decades spent transforming the tenets of men’s wear for women, imbuing the traditional Savile Row trouser suit with a sexual insouciance, Stella McCartney is finally doing the inevitable: making men’s wear for actual men. On Thursday — as the men’s fashion circus swirled in Florence at the Pitti Uomo trade fair — the designer confirmed long-rumored plans for a men’s line, to debut Nov. 10 in London alongside her spring women’s collection, the one that used to be presented in May but that has now moved to a see-now/buy-now schedule, with the show taking place just before the clothes go on public sale. Similarly, the men’s wear will be sold a month after the big reveal, hitting shelves in early December.

headline: Parents Should Avoid Comments on a Child’s Weight
abstract: New research suggests that careless comments about weight gain can have repercussions for years afterward.
lead_paragraph: Should parents talk to an overweight child about weight? Or should they just keep their mouths shut?

headline: Orlando, Donald Trump, U.S. Open: Your Thursday Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Advocates for Release of 9/11 Documents Worry About Potential Delay
abstract: With the declassification of parts of a congressional report nearing, concerns have arisen that the White House might ask Congress to release it, which could create holdups.
lead_paragraph: With the Obama administration nearing declassification of the still-secret 28 pages of a congressional report on the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, new worries have surfaced that the White House might hand Congress the responsibility for releasing the document, which is said to suggest high-level Saudi complicity in the episode.

headline: Slow Cooking at District Saigon
abstract: Father and son cook side by side at this new Vietnamese spot in Astoria, Queens.
lead_paragraph: Father and son cook side by side at this new Vietnamese spot in Astoria, Queens.

headline: The Secret to District Saigon’s Broths: Slow Cooking
abstract: A new Vietnamese restaurant in Astoria, Queens, simmers its pho with patience and attention to ingredients.
lead_paragraph: At District Saigon in Astoria, Queens, there is always a pot of pho broth making a low quarrel on the stove, with eddies of marrow from sunken bones. The broth has to hit the eight-hour mark before Lam Lien, the chef, will even consider serving it.

headline: New York Today: A Flurry of Bills
abstract: Thursday: An end to Albany’s legislative session, a thrill ride at Penn Station, and reclaiming restaurant space.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this sprinkly Thursday.

headline: Morning Agenda: Visium Hedge Fund Managers Charged With Insider Trading
keywords: ['Art', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hedge Funds', 'Insider Trading', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Tencent Nears Deal to Buy Maker of Clash of Clans | Investors Bypass Private Equity
lead_paragraph: VISIUM HEDGE FUND MANAGERS CHARGED WITH INSIDER TRADING Federal authorities filed criminal and civil securities charges against three current and former traders at Visium Asset Management, a multibillion-dollar hedge fund focused on health care, Alexandra Stevenson reports in DealBook. Prosecutors said that the fund had an inside view of the drug approval process at the Food and Drug Administration that gave it trading windfalls of $32 million.

headline: Volkswagen Looks to Deal With Cost Problems, but Faces Constraints
abstract: The carmaker said it would increase the number of battery-powered cars it sells and cut spending on research and development, but it will find it tough to reduce its work force.
lead_paragraph: WOLFSBURG, Germany — Volkswagen on Thursday outlined an ambitious plan to increase profit after an emissions scandal by sharply increasing the production of electric vehicles and reducing costs.

headline: The Doctor’s Ties
abstract: Perhaps I’m in the minority of men, but I appreciate being given ties.
lead_paragraph: I carefully unwrapped the lilac-colored tissue paper as my patient watched, expectantly. Given its size and shape, I was pretty sure I knew what was in this package.

headline: How to Master Pierogies
abstract: Sometimes perfecting a dish means making it the same every time. And sometimes it means embracing change.
lead_paragraph: Julia Hlinka’s mother was tired of making pierogies. She’d already dug up the potatoes on her small Slovakian farm, harvested the wheat and milled the flour, so who could blame her for enacting a pierogi succession plan? She gathered her kids around. She kneaded and rolled the skins out thin. She mashed potatoes with sheep’s cheese and drew the dough around them, dumpling after dumpling, hundreds at a sitting. One day, she turned the task over to the children. Hlinka was 10.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Bunk Beds
abstract: Sharing a single vertical axis, each person is made to be vulnerable before the other.
lead_paragraph: The punishing rents of New York City breed unusual compromises. Sophomore year of college, I snagged a one-bedroom at the top of a seventh-floor walk-up in Lower Manhattan. The week I moved in, a neighbor pulled me aside and offered wisdom on the climb: “Your legs will get used to it,” she said, “but your heart never will.” How literally she meant this, I was never sure.

headline: A. B. Yehoshua: By the Book
abstract: The novelist, playwright and author, most recently, of “The Extra,” avoids suspense and sci-fi: “Very possibly I am missing out on important genres. But it’s too late to change my conservatism.”
lead_paragraph: The novelist, playwright and author, most recently, of “The Extra,” avoids suspense and sci-fi: “Very possibly I am missing out on important genres. But it’s too late to change my conservatism.”

headline: For Warriors’ Stephen Curry, Staying Power Is Pushed to the Limits
abstract: Curry is focused on the 48-minute task of winning an N.B.A. title, shaking off talk of possible injuries taking a toll.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Steve Kerr, the coach of the Golden State Warriors, recently recalled the first time he watched Stephen Curry play basketball.

headline: The Parasite Underground
abstract: A shadow network of patients are trying to treat their own debilitating diseases — by infecting themselves with gastrointestinal worms.
lead_paragraph: When Vik was in his late 20s, blood started appearing in his stool. He found himself rushing to the bathroom as many as nine times a day, and he quit his job at a software company. He received a diagnosis of severe ulcerative colitis, an inflammatory condition of the colon. Steroids, which suppress inflammation, didn’t work for him. Mesalamine suppositories offered only the slightest relief. A year and a half after his diagnosis, Vik’s gastroenterologist warned him that because his disease was poorly controlled, he risked developing a condition called toxic megacolon: His inflamed intestines might rupture, leading to blood infection, septic shock or death.

headline: If Not Lyme Disease, What Caused This Man’s Fever?
abstract: A doctor thought he knew what brought on this patient’s flulike symptoms, but antibiotics weren’t helping.
lead_paragraph: A doctor thought he knew what brought on this patient’s flulike symptoms, but antibiotics weren’t helping.

headline: 1941: Roosevelt Expels Germans
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Propaganda', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In June 1941, President Roosevelt orders to close German consulates and propaganda offices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Roosevelt took the initiative today [June 16] in the diplomatic warfare with Germany by ordering German consulates and propaganda offices in the United States to close before July 10 and by charging that these agencies had engaged in activities ‘‘inimical to the welfare of this country.’’ His action requires all German nationals employed by the agencies to get out of the United States by the July 10 deadline because they have engaged in ‘‘improper’’ activities ‘‘wholly outside the scope of their legitimate duties.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, June 17, 1941

headline: Macy’s and Union Have a Deal, Averting a Strike

headline: Looking the Orlando Shooter in the Eyes
abstract: Tiara Parker, right, was trapped in a bathroom stall at the Pulse nightclub when she locked eyes with Omar Mateen, the gunman. She and her cousin Akyra Monet Murray were shot, and Ms. Murray died. Natalie Murray, left, Akyra's mother, recalled her daughter's frantic phone call.
lead_paragraph: Tiara Parker, right, was trapped in a bathroom stall at the Pulse nightclub when she locked eyes with Omar Mateen, the gunman. She and her cousin Akyra Monet Murray were shot, and Ms. Murray died. Natalie Murray, left, Akyra's mother, recalled her daughter's frantic phone call.

headline: Welcome to Davao, the Philippine Leader’s Town: ‘No Smoking, No Crime’
abstract: President-elect Rodrigo Duterte’s strict policies may be a tough sell in much of the country. But in Davao City, where he was mayor, residents say they feel safe.
lead_paragraph: DAVAO CITY, Philippines — Residents who are 18 or younger are not allowed on the street without an adult between 10 p.m. and 5 a.m. Liquor cannot be sold after 1 a.m. Smoking is banned throughout the city, except in a few designated areas.

headline: Apple Faces an Artificial Intelligence Challenge
abstract: The titan of consumer technology has a conundrum: Can it create consumer delight in technology without snooping on its customers?
lead_paragraph: Software is the strangest invention in economic history: a great wealth creator and an industry destroyer. But software is also insubstantial; no one can bring you a bucket of software. Code is a series of propositions about arranging transistors in a computer.

headline: Unhitching the PC From OneDrive
abstract: Microsoft’s online file-storage service is there to copy your files to the cloud, but you can decline the offer.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I make all my files stop automatically downloading to the OneDrive in Windows 10 Home Edition? Can I just get rid of OneDrive? I never use it.

headline: Danny Lyon’s Camera Seeks Truth in Marginalized Lives
abstract: Mr. Lyon gets close to his subjects, physically and emotionally, whether observing a tattoo artist or pressing up against prison bars.
lead_paragraph: Art and life are never entirely separate, but different artists lean more toward one than the other for inspiration. For the photographer Danny Lyon, the world of live humans has been the bigger draw. “You put a camera in my hand,” he once said, “I want to get close to people. Not just physically close, emotionally close; all of it.”

headline: He Bridges Worlds: Dance and Fashion, Uptown and Downtown
abstract: Reid Bartelme, a dancer turned costume designer, has helped bring together the worlds of ballet and contemporary dance.
lead_paragraph: If the dance landscape were a Venn diagram, Reid Bartelme, a dancer turned costume designer who can’t seem to stop performing (he has tried), would fill the center space. Mr. Bartelme bridges worlds.

headline: 1941: A Strange War in the Promised Land
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune Archives: Russell Hill reports from the front lines in Syria in 1941.
lead_paragraph: In 1941, the New York Herald correspondent Russell Hill spent a week in Syria, covering the war there between Axis powers and Allied forces. More than 70 years later, the country finds itself torn apart by civil war. Here is an excerpt from Hill’s writings, a sort of original reporter’s notebook:

headline: Judge Denies Reza Zarrab’s Bail Request for Self-Financed House Arrest
abstract: Mr. Zarrab, a gold trader from Turkey, had asked to be allowed to live in an apartment under 24-hour armed guard and GPS monitoring, all at his own expense.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday rejected a request that a gold trader from Turkey be granted an unusual form of release pending trial that would have allowed him to sign a $50 million bond, secured by $10 million in cash, and to live in a kind of self-financed gilded cage.

headline: Omar Mateen Posted to Facebook Amid Orlando Attack, Lawmaker Says
abstract: The gunman raged against the “filthy ways of the west” and spoke of “Islamic state vengeance,” a United States senator revealed.
lead_paragraph: JENSEN BEACH, Fla. — The gunman who committed the massacre at a popular gay nightclub in Orlando used multiple Facebook accounts to write posts and make searches about the Islamic State. “Now taste the Islamic state vengeance,” he declared, denouncing “the filthy ways of the west.” He even searched for references to the massacre while he was carrying it out, a United States senator said.

headline: Donald Trump, Chasing Campaign Cash, Veers From Battleground States

headline: 50,000 Cans of Beer on the Wall
abstract: “Zoning is an easy subject to grasp in Houston: It doesn’t exist here.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this first in a series of postcards from Texas, our Houston bureau chief muses on the Lone Star State’s freewheeling, “Don’t Tread on Me” attitude.

headline: Dragan Bender, a Top N.B.A. Draft Prospect, Talks About Kristaps Porzingis, Croatia and Sitcoms
abstract: Bender, who was born in Bosnia and Herzegovina and plays for Croatia, is projected to go early in the draft on June 23.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Dragan Bender knows the comparisons are coming. One year after the Knicks took Kristaps Porzingis, a young, tall, lanky Eastern European, with the fourth pick in the N.B.A. draft, Bender — who is young, tall, lanky and from Eastern Europe — is being projected to go near the top of the draft on June 23.

headline: A Natural Beauty Guru’s Guide to Wellness — and Astrology
abstract: During a recent reading of her friend Linda Rodin’s stars, Rose-Marie Swift (of RMS makeup fame) shared her secrets to a happy, healthy lifestyle.
lead_paragraph: Though best known as a top makeup artist and the organic beauty mogul behind RMS Beauty, Rose-Marie Swift has a semisecret side hobby: astrological readings. “The thing is, I’m an Aquarian — Aquarians rule astrology,” she explained on a recent rainy day in her Union Square home. Her fascination with celestial charts began when she was 15: “I hated my stepfather and wanted to know the reason he acted the way he acted. I went, ‘Let’s look up Scorpios, man’” — and she discovered “The Only Astrology Book You’ll Ever Need.” Today, she gives one-hour readings to clients and friends in the fashion and beauty industry, including Linda Rodin, who stopped by for a reading that afternoon.

headline: Facebook Asked to Provide Details of Gunman’s Postings
abstract: Senator Ron Johnson, chairman of the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, has asked the chief executive of Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg, to provide details of the postings of Omar Mateen, the gunman in the Orlando shooting.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ron Johnson, chairman of the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs, has asked the chief executive of Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg, to provide details of the postings of Omar Mateen, the gunman in the Orlando shooting.

headline: Is ‘Shrew’ Worth Taming? Female Directors Keep Trying
abstract: “The Taming of the Shrew,” now at the Delacorte Theater, reminds women of their duty to their husbands. Here’s a take from a critic — and how some female directors view it.
lead_paragraph: The director Julie Taymor was on a quiet rooftop in Shanghai late one recent Saturday night, talking on the phone. She was in China with “The Lion King,” but the topic of conversation was “The Taming of the Shrew.”

headline: Meet Some Wild Superheroes at the Brooklyn Children’s Museum
abstract: The museum, with its menagerie, is inviting children to exercise their creativity and learn some science through Superhero Weekend.
lead_paragraph: Peter Parker, a.k.a. Spider-Man, grew up in Queens, and several superheroes have lived in Manhattan, including Captain America, a son of the Lower East Side. But this Saturday and Sunday, Brooklyn will pack the most kapow of any borough, producing dozens of its own young challengers, ready to vanquish evil and soar to great heights (at least in their imaginations).

headline: 1948-2016 | A Times Art Treasure Comes to an Omaha Library
abstract: A mural of Earth — or at least its Western portion — hung in The Times’s lobby for more than 40 years. Now it’s getting a new life in a Nebraska library.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David W. Dunlap, a Metro reporter, looks back at a  mural that has been given new life.

headline: The White House’s Pick-Up Artists
abstract: When Obama commuted the sentences of nonviolent drug offenders, he chose two ex-cons to collect them on the day they were released from prison.
lead_paragraph: Last July, President Obama announced, in a video message, that he was commuting the sentences of 46 nonviolent drug offenders in federal prison. Not since the Johnson administration had so many sentences been commuted in a single day. It was a small corrective, Obama said, to the “inequities in the criminal-justice system” and the unnecessarily harsh sentences with which these men and women had been saddled. He had already commuted 30 such sentences the previous winter and has since kept going: The latest 42 grants of clemency, announced by the White House two weeks ago, brings the total to 348. More than a third of these prisoners were serving life sentences, often with no possibility of parole.

headline: As Russian Hackers Probe, NATO Has No Clear Cyberwar Strategy
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'International Relations']
abstract: When it comes to deterring the low-level attacks that flow through European computer networks every week, NATO commanders do not seem prepared to take aggressive countermeasures.
lead_paragraph: TALLINN, Estonia — In the six months since part of Ukraine’s power grid came crashing down, turned off by highly sophisticated hackers, cyberspace allies of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have been leaving their mark here in the Baltics and across the sea in Finland and Sweden.

headline: Palestinian Killed by Israeli Soldier Posed No Danger, Commander Testifies
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Palestinians', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The commander said the Palestinian, who had already been shot and wounded after stabbing another soldier, was no longer a threat when Sgt. Elor Azaria shot him in the head.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The commander of an Israeli soldier who fatally shot an already-wounded Palestinian attacker in Hebron testified in court on Thursday that the Palestinian had posed no danger to anyone in the moments before he was killed, and that “there was no justification for firing.”

headline: Tasting Rosés With a Winemaker Who Knows Them Best

lead_paragraph: Rosé is the hardest wine to make well, said Sacha Lichine, who is perhaps the most prominent rosé winemaker in the world. But, he added, smiling, it is the easiest to sell.

headline: Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival Draws Inspiration From India

lead_paragraph: The choreographer Mark Morris, who has long been drawn to the arts and culture of India, has programmed a 10-part series exploring the music and dance of South India that will form the centerpiece of this fall’s White Light Festival, Lincoln Center announced Thursday.

headline: The First Big Company to Say It’s Serving the Legal Marijuana Trade? Microsoft.
abstract: As the marijuana industry grows inexorably more mainstream, an established company moves to enter the government compliance side of the business.
lead_paragraph: As state after state has legalized marijuana in one way or another, big names in corporate America have stayed away entirely. Marijuana, after all, is still illegal, according to the federal government.

headline: Opening Ceremony Honors New York Gay Bars
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Bars and Nightclubs']
abstract: The massacre in Orlando brings a sudden urgency to a new capsule collection celebrating the legacy of gay nightspots.
lead_paragraph: For years, Opening Ceremony, the pioneering New York concept store, has produced special collections for LGBT Pride Month. This year’s collection, a celebration of New York’s historic gay bars, was well underway when the June 12 terrorist attack at Pulse, an Orlando, Fla., gay club, provided a chilling reminder of how crucial such clubs are as all-too-rare and fragile safe spaces for generations of gay men and women.

headline: Christo’s Newest Project: Walking on Water
abstract: For 16 days, “The Floating Piers,” a saffron-colored walkway, will connect two small islands in a lake in Northern Italy to the mainland.
lead_paragraph: PILZONE, Italy — It was a long-held dream, but finally, this week, the conceptual artist Christo walked on water.

headline: Daniel Sturridge Plays Hero for England, Leaving Wales Stunned
abstract: After an aggressive double substitution, England scored twice in the second half to win for the first time in a game in which it trailed at halftime in the World Cup or the Euros.
lead_paragraph: LENS, France — The forward danced. The fans sang. The goalkeeper ran a hundred yards to leap on the dog pile in the corner.

headline: Skeptics of Self-Driving Cars Span Generations

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Blindfolded and handcuffed, the bookseller was abducted from Hong Kong’s border with mainland China and taken to a cell, where he would spend five months in solitary confinement, watched 24 hours a day by a battery of Chinese guards.

keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Referendums', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Campaigners for leaving the European Union want to “take back control.” But what will they be left with?
lead_paragraph: London — IT was Queen Elizabeth’s official 90th birthday celebration last Sunday, and tables for 10,000 guests were set along the Mall in central London. Steadily the rain fell, dripping out of the tubas of the bands and softening the sandwiches, but Her Majesty’s subjects munched on with stoic British spirit, standing up to cheer as she passed.

keywords: ['Soccer', 'Sports Injuries', 'UEFA Champions League (Soccer)', 'Copa America (Soccer)', 'UEFA European Football Championship']

And the Argentine ironman Lionel Messi — despite missing a number of games this season to injury — racked up his 56th appearance this week.

abstract: Travel experts’ tips include complying with age restrictions, packing a small first aid kit, and being cautious with water and food.
lead_paragraph: They’re not your everyday vacation incidents, but they do happen: on Tuesday evening, a 2-year-old boy, Lane Graves, was dragged into a lake by an alligator at Disney’s Grand Floridian Resort and Spa and found dead on Wednesday afternoon, and last month, a 4-year-old boy was tossed around by a gorilla at the Cincinnati Zoo after he slipped through the exhibit’s barrier (the gorilla was shot and killed; the boy survived).

lead_paragraph: After Orlando and San Bernardino and Paris, there is new urgency to understand the signs that can precede acts of terrorism. And with the Islamic State’s prolific use of social media, terrorism experts and government agencies continually search for clues in posts and Twitter messages that appear to promote the militants’ cause.

headline: I Used an Assault Rifle in the Army. I Don’t Think Civilians Should Own Them.
abstract: These weapons were intended for the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: I was 19 the first time I held an assault rifle. It was on a concrete court inside a National Guard armory in Bloomington, Ind., where I’d gathered with fellow R.O.T.C. cadets for weapons training. A sergeant opened an olive-drab arms case and handed out M-16A2s. We each took one apart and reassembled it, learning the sequence, learning how to safely clear it, learning to check its functions. It has been years since I held one, but regardless of the model — an M-16, an M-4 or a civilian variant like the AR-15 or Sig Sauer MCX — I’m confident I could disassemble it blindfolded.

headline: How Climate Change Could Make the Ground Collapse
abstract: Craters called “slumps” can form as permafrost thaws, endangering plants and animals.

abstract: Fan violence has marred the start of the Euro 2016 tournament and heightened security concerns in a country already under high alert.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — More than 300 people have been arrested in France since the Euro 2016 soccer tournament began last week, and 24 are being deported after violent clashes between fans, the French authorities said Thursday. The violence has marred the start of the event and heightened security concerns in a country that is still under high alert for terrorist threats.

headline: Soda Tax Passes in Philadelphia. Advocates Ask: Who’s Next?
abstract: The question is if this “watershed” vote presages similar measures around the country.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Forty times, city or state governments had proposed taxes on sugary soft drinks, failing each time. Then, in 2014, liberal Berkeley, Calif., passed such a tax, but most people saw it as an aberration. Several measures, including one in New York, never won much support.

Trump has slipped markedly in polls against Hillary Clinton amid a cascading series of self-inflicted controversies, culminating with his heated call after last weekend’s massacre in Florida for a crackdown on Muslim immigration and for stricter scrutiny of Muslim communities in the United States.

headline: When the Family Business Is a Gallery
abstract: All over the globe, art dealers are ceding their turf to their sons and daughters — but it’s a complicated kind of inheritance.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Parisian gallerist Almine Rech announced that her son, Paul de Froment, will be the director of her forthcoming New York outpost. The news brought to mind another recent opening: Lisson’s New York gallery, where the second-generation dealer Alex Logsdail serves as the international director. His father, the British art dealer Nicholas Logsdail, co-founded Lisson in 1967, brought Alex into the business in 2009 and made him director in 2011. Logsdail and Rech are not alone: many major players, including David Zwirner, Arne Glimcher and Sean Kelly, have made room for their children in their businesses.

headline: 1966: Mississippi Marchers Arrested
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In June 1966, civil rights marchers are arrested in Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: GREENWOOD — Police arrested three leaders of the Mississippi civil rights March today [June 16] when they tried to pitch the marchers’ tents on school grounds. Those arrested were Stokely Carmichael, head of the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee; Bob Smith, a committee worker, and Bruce Baines, an official of the Congress of Racial Equality. They were handcuffed and taken to jail, where they were charged with trespassing. ‘‘What the hell are you going to do?’’ said city police commissioner B.A. (Buff) Hammond after ordering the arrest. ‘‘I told them they couldn’t set up those tents and they went right on doing it.’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, June 17, 1966

headline: Taika Waititi Narrates a Scene From ‘Hunt for the Wilderpeople’
abstract: The film’s writer and director discusses a one-shot sequence featuring Julian Dennison and Sam Neill. The movie opens June 24.
lead_paragraph: A rebellious boy and his foster uncle go on the run in the woods of New Zealand in the new comedy adventure “Hunt for the Wilderpeople,” opening June 24. The film was written and directed by Taika Waititi, who, in a recent interview, discussed a scene from the film that consists primarily of one shot. Below are edited excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Melvin Dwork, Once Cast From Navy for Being Gay, Dies at 94
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Dwork became a renowned interior designer and, in 2011, won his fight to have his 1944 dishonorable discharge deemed honorable.
lead_paragraph: When the M.P.s came for him in 1944, Melvin Dwork was in class, a 22-year-old gay Navy enlisted man in officer candidate school in Charleston, S.C. His companion, under arrest in New Orleans, had given him away. Jailed, found “deviant” by psychiatrists, he was discharged in World War II as “undesirable.”

headline: Why the Orlando Shooting Is Unlikely to Lead to Major New Gun Laws
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Terrorism']
abstract: After the worst mass shooting in American history, Congress is showing little sign of rallying around bipartisan legislation in a bitter election year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It didn’t happen after a congresswoman was shot in the head at an official event. It didn’t happen after 20 children were gunned down in their elementary school classrooms. It didn’t happen after terrorists fired on a holiday party at an agency that provided services for people with disabilities in Southern California.

headline: In Orlando, a Son of a Muslim Immigrant Rushed to Heal Pain Caused by Another
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Terrorism', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Muslim Americans']
abstract: Even as he spent hours repairing gun shot wounds, Dr. Joseph Ibrahim could not escape the parallels between his background and the gunman’s.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — When Dr. Joseph Ibrahim heard that the attack at the Pulse nightclub may have been linked to terrorism, he caught himself fearing any kind of link to his own Muslim, Middle-Eastern roots.

headline: Review: Annie Proulx’s ‘Barkskins’ Is an Epic Tale of Logging and Doom
abstract: This novel plays out across 717 pages and more than 300 years, and is a jeremiad about the loss of North America’s “monstrous pine finery.”
lead_paragraph: Like the Lorax, Annie Proulx speaks for the trees. Her new novel, “Barkskins,” is a clamorous epic of environmental despoliation. It plays out across 717 pages and more than 300 years, from the arrival of woodcutting French settlers in Canada in 1693 through an eyewitness account of melting glaciers in 2013.

keywords: ['Organic Foods and Products', 'Beds and Bedding', 'Sustainable Living', 'E-Commerce']

lead_paragraph: The markets have been sending out distress signals. Stock volatility has risen sharply and bond yields have fallen below zero in part of the world while rising sky high elsewhere — all indications of distress as Britain approaches a pivotal vote on whether to exit the European Union.

headline: In Russian Doping Scandal, Time for a Punishment to Fit the Crime

abstract: Orthodox and Hasidic Jews in Brooklyn embrace sushi. But hold the shellfish, please.
lead_paragraph: Orthodox and Hasidic Jews in Brooklyn embrace sushi. But hold the shellfish, please.

headline: A Funeral for a Fire Chief, 15 Years After He Died on 9/11
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Forensic Science']
abstract: Battalion Chief Lawrence T. Stack perished on Sept. 11, 2001; no trace of him has ever been found. He will finally have a funeral Mass on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The printers buzzed to life in every firehouse in New York City last week, and each spit out an identical bulletin. It bore the worst sort of news the Fire Department must relay to its members, the Code 5-5-5-5. A death in the line of duty.

abstract: Orthodox and Hasidic Jews in Brooklyn are increasingly turning to the Japanese dish (but without shellfish) because it provides dietary flexibility.

headline: Watch the Orlando Shooting Story Take Shape
abstract: A look at how The Times’s treatment of the Orlando shooting evolved as we learned more and discovered the scope of the horror.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times.

headline: Review: Handel’s ‘Rinaldo,’ With Period Brass in Good Repair
abstract: The company operamission advanced its campaign to perform all 39 of Handel’s Italian operas with a concert production of his tale set in the Crusades.
lead_paragraph: Despite its understated, lowercase name, operamission is a company with big and varied ambitions — none bigger, surely, than its multiyear campaign to perform all 39 of Handel’s Italian operas, with a full orchestra on period instruments. It reached No. 4 on Tuesday night with “Rinaldo” at Merkin Concert Hall, and it was hard to know which was more remarkable: the presence of four countertenors, two of them very fine; or of four Baroque trumpets, and players to wield them adequately.

headline: Review: Sundance Film Festival Short Films, a Group of Hits and Misses
keywords: ['Movies', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A touring program from this year’s lineup, including “The Procedure,” “Bacon & God’s Wrath,” “Justice” and more, is opening at the IFC Center.
lead_paragraph: To get the full Sundance Film Festival experience, you need high altitudes, steady hydration and a diet of convenience store foodstuffs. But for a less robust outing, the IFC Center is hosting a touring program of shorts from this year’s lineup.

headline: Review: In ‘Seoul Searching,’ Teenagers Explore Their Korean Roots to an ’80s Soundtrack
abstract: Set in 1986, the film introduces globally scattered youngsters to their heritage in a plot that both critiques and embraces stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: An appealingly gung-ho cast and let’s-get-along message make “Seoul Searching” a buoyant, if undisciplined comedy about foreign-raised South Korean teenagers getting in touch with their ethnic roots.

headline: A New Glass Museum Will Open in a Historic Factory
abstract: From a Pennsylvania town came crystal goblets good enough for formal dinners at the White House, as well as a glass baseball bat and other items.
lead_paragraph: The sleepy town of White Mills in northeastern Pennsylvania relied for decades on one family, the Dorflingers. From the 1860s to the 1920s, hundreds of locals worked 11-hour shifts at the Dorflingers’ glass factory, where they shaped products with molds and acid and stoked furnaces, sending plumes of smoke from brick chimney stacks. With a train station and canal dock nearby, the company imported raw materials from overseas and shipped crystal vessels worldwide, and its employees and visitors provided a stream of customers for hotels, stores and even an opera house.

headline: Review: In ‘Parched,’ Women in an Indian Village Chafe Against Oppression
abstract: Despite the appalling events it depicts, Leena Yadav’s film has such affection for its female characters that it often achieves a buoyant tone.
lead_paragraph: The title of this movie, written and directed by Leena Yadav, is an apt description of the desert village in northwestern India which its three female leads toil and suffer. The women themselves, however, are thankfully not arid in any sense, though frequently starved for tenderness.

headline: A Walk on Water
abstract: The artist Christo inaugurated his first outdoor installation in over a decade, also the first since the death of his partner Jeanne-Claude in 2009.
lead_paragraph: The artist Christo inaugurated his first outdoor installation in over a decade, also the first since the death of his partner Jeanne-Claude in 2009.

headline: Is It Going to Be Me, or the Cat?
keywords: ['Pets', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: Also, navigating big-ticket social issues, sexual mismatches and what to bring to dinner.
lead_paragraph: Twice a year, my husband and I drive eight hours to visit our son, his wife and baby. Their place is small, so we stay at a hotel nearby. I have always been afraid of cats and dogs; they have a large cat. But the playroom is in the basement. It would be easy to close the door so the cat stays upstairs. When I suggested this, my daughter-in-law said: “Why should I? The cat lives here.” I was insulted but did not say anything. Next time, I am not planning to visit their home. I do not feel welcome. Thoughts?

headline: Review: A Couple’s Adoration After 76 Years of Marriage in ‘My Love, Don’t Cross That River’
abstract: A film that captures the extraordinary love and profound bond of a couple living in Gangwon Province in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: There is visual poetry in Jin Mo-young’s documentary, “My Love, Don’t Cross That River,” and unblinking observation as well. The film covers 15 months with Jo Byong-man and Kang Gye-yeul, married for 76 years and living in a modest, rural riverside home in Gangwon Province in South Korea.

headline: Review: ‘Land and Shade,’ Set Among Colombia’s Sugar Farmers
abstract: A Colombian farmer returns home after years away to be with his ill son in this film, which won best first feature at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: It is difficult to look at a sugar packet the same way after seeing “Land and Shade,” which won the Caméra d’Or (best first feature) at the Cannes Film Festival last year. The writer and director, César Augusto Acevedo, has set his movie among the sugar farmers of the Valle del Cauca region in Colombia. They work long hours in the fields — the cane leaves, we’re told, cut like razors — and are shortchanged pay.

headline: Russian Track Team Faces Ban From Olympics: Here’s What We Know
abstract: Track and field’s governing body, the I.A.A.F., will announce Friday if Russia’s track and field team will be barred from the Olympics this summer in Rio de Janeiro.
lead_paragraph: What is happening on Friday?

headline: When a Phrase Takes On New Meaning: ‘Radical Islam,’ Explained
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A dispute between President Obama and Donald Trump in the aftermath of the Orlando massacre can be traced to the rise of the Islamic State, scholars say.
lead_paragraph: It was nearly 18 months ago, shortly after the Charlie Hebdo attacks in Paris, when a reporter for National Public Radio, Mara Liasson, observed at a White House press briefing that President Obama and his aides had “bent over backwards” to avoid using the phrase “radical Islam.” The press secretary, Josh Earnest, said this was because “these terrorists are individuals who would like to cloak themselves in the veil of a particular religion,” opening a debate over the phrase that has taken on new rancor amid the massacre in Orlando.

headline: 36 Hours in Chicago
abstract: The neighborhoods on Chicago’s near northwest side are an invigorating blend of reflection and reinvention.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhoods on Chicago’s near northwest side are an invigorating blend of reflection and reinvention.

headline: In Race for Mayor of Rome, a Prize and a New Face for the Five Star Movement
abstract: Born as a voice of anti-establishment protest in Italy, the movement is poised to win the city’s mayoral runoff on Sunday behind Virginia Raggi, a relative newcomer.
lead_paragraph: ROME — When it was founded seven years ago, the Five Star Movement was the voice of anti-establishment protest in Italy, and its biggest voice was the movement’s often bombastic founder and president, the comedian Beppe Grillo.

headline: Families Bearing Up a Year After Slayings in a Charleston Church
abstract: Survivors and family members reflected on forgiveness, race relations, gun violence and the suspect, a year after nine people died at Emanuel A.M.E. Church.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — A year ago, the nation was transfixed by a different horrific crime, the shooting deaths of nine church members during Bible study at the Emanuel A.M.E. Church here. With the backdrop of the Orlando shootings, survivors and family members of the victims of the Charleston slayings on June 17, 2015, sat down to reflect on forgiveness, race relations, gun violence and the suspect, Dylann S. Roof, called Prime Evil by some of the survivors. On Friday, they joined parishioners from Emanuel A.M.E. Church, political leaders and congregations from around the region for a memorial service at the TD Arena in Charleston, where a year earlier President Obama delivered a eulogy that culminated with his singing “Amazing Grace.”

headline: Bloomsday Is Over but Joyce Left Plenty of Trail to Trace
abstract: A guided tour of James Joyce’s life in Dublin, London and Paris.
lead_paragraph: This year, more than most, offers plenty of excuses to celebrate the life and work of James Joyce. This January marked the 75th anniversary of his death. Bloomsday – June 16 – is the date on which his novel “Ulysses” is set. And December is the 100th anniversary of the publication of his first novel, “A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man.”

headline: Review: ‘A Conspiracy of Faith’ Tracks a Message Written in Blood
abstract: This thriller is by far the darkest of the Department Q stories. For this pitch-black film trilogy, that’s saying something.
lead_paragraph: “A Conspiracy of Faith”  is part of a trilogy of films in the “Department Q” series. Read the reviews for the other films, “The Absent One” and “The Keeper of Lost Causes.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Absent One,’ a Killer Confesses, and an Inquiry Ensues
abstract: This is the second film in “The Department Q Trilogy,” based on the Nordic noir novels by Jussi Adler-Olsen and directed by Mikkel Norgaard.
lead_paragraph: “The Absent One” is part of a trilogy of films in the “Department Q” series. Read the reviews for the other films, “The Keeper of Lost Causes” and “A Conspiracy of Faith.”

headline: Nicole Najafi of Industry Standard in Cuba
abstract: The designer shares her photographs of the Old City, Hemingway’s former home and more.
lead_paragraph: The designer shares her photographs of the Old City, Hemingway’s former home and more.

headline: An American Jeans Maker Discovers Cuba (and Color)
abstract: Nicole Najafi of Industry Standard recently spent a week in Havana and its environs, and took T along for the ride.
lead_paragraph: “I sort of long to live in the 1950s or ’60s… or ’70s; I’d take any one of those decades,” muses the denim designer Nicole Najafi. Her pining for classic Americana runs through Industry Standard, her jeans label inspired by unfussy, mid-20th-century silhouettes — and was stoked during a recent, spur-of-the-moment trip to Cuba with her best friend, the artist Mary Corman. “She’s also very nostalgic, perhaps even more than I am. She called me on a Friday and said, ‘It’s about to be summer, and it’s too hot to go then, and who knows how different it’ll be by the fall,’ so we booked it.” And they were en route to Havana two weeks later.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, June 18 Through June 26
abstract: A 1965 Shelby 427 Cobra is one of the cars to be displayed at the Fourth Annual Car Show of the Shelter Island Historical Society this month.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Art in review, from Times critics.

headline: Review: In ‘Swan Lake,’ the Drama Depends on the Dancers
abstract: Each performance by American Ballet Theater varies, depending on the lead couple, but the production tends to lack dynamic contrast.
lead_paragraph: Balletomania, a form of madness to be found in many cities round the world, traditionally reaches an annual peak of jubilant clamor in June, when American Ballet Theater performs “Swan Lake” and “Romeo and Juliet” at the Metropolitan Opera House. Love in each ballet leads to the deaths of both heroine and hero. You may be sure that the fans greet each star partnership as if the dancers had truly sacrificed themselves.

headline: Review: ‘The Keeper of Lost Causes,’ Pitch-Black Nordic Noir
abstract: Detective Carl Morck has one mood, and boy, it’s bad. The film, based on a novel by Jussi Adler-Olsen, is part of “The Department Q Trilogy.”
lead_paragraph: The film adaptations of Jussi Adler-Olsen’s Nordic crime novels were a hit in Denmark, and now all three, known as “The Department Q Trilogy,” are being released on Friday in the United States. This pitch-black series, with its brooding protagonist, may draw comparisons with “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” but consider this: The stories are even sharper. Here are reviews of the other films in the trilogy, “The Absent One” and “A Conspiracy of Faith.”

headline: At Art Basel, Upbeat Dealers and Brisk Sales
abstract: Boldfaced names were willing to wait in a long line in the rain to be first to sample the wares of more than 280 international dealers.
lead_paragraph: BASEL, Switzerland — An art fair like the one here this week can feel as hermetic and all-consuming as a casino, so focused are the crowds on buying art — arguably its own form of gambling — and double-kissing that they lose track of time or what’s happening outdoors (in this case, gray skies and sporadic drizzle).

headline: A Plan to Spread Dada Worldwide, Revisited at MoMA
abstract: “Dadaglobe Reconstructed” illustrates unrealized plans for an art movement’s ambitious anthology.
lead_paragraph: It’s 1920. The Great War is over; revolution has come to Russia; a new German constitution has been adopted in Weimar. Tristan Tzara, the Romanian poet and gadfly who waited out the war in Switzerland, has moved to Paris. He is just 24, but he was at the core of Dada, the previous decade’s most eruptive cultural phenomenon — and he is in the mood for publicity. He sends letters to people on both sides of the Atlantic seeking artistic contributions to a magnum opus for the anti-movement that turned the senselessness of world war into something convulsive.

headline: A Photo Series, with Audience Participation
abstract: The photographer Thomas Brown depicts sculptural still lifes of crumpled paper that resemble meteorites — and then asks viewers to “adopt” and name them.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Thomas Brown depicts sculptural still lifes of crumpled paper that resemble meteorites — and then asks viewers to “adopt” and name them.

headline: Russians Make an Impact on Mixed Martial Arts
abstract: Mixed martial arts is a growing sport in Russia as competitors seek fame and fortune of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, the sport’s most prestigious battleground, a continent away in the United States.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Inside the Fight Nights gym just off Kutuzovsky Prospekt, a street named after the Russian general who defeated Napoleon, a few dozen pugilists were in training recently. It was late morning, and an instructor barked commands to the men as they grappled, punched, ducked and sweated on the front line of Moscow’s mixed martial arts scene.

headline: Review: In ‘Central Intelligence,’ a Weaponized Kevin Hart
abstract: This espionage comedy, which also stars Dwayne Johnson, accomplishes its mission of being aggressively juvenile.
lead_paragraph: To call “Central Intelligence” juvenile is to miss the larger point — namely, that juvenile was most likely the goal. A majority of studio comedies have been written at an eighth-grade level or lower for so long that it’s astonishing how resilient our hope for greater sophistication is.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, June 18 Through June 26
abstract: In ‘The Whipping Man,’ a soldier returns home from the Civil War and is cared for by his former slaves during Passover. The play is at the Robert Shackleton Playhouse through June 24.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Two Men Kiss, an Act of Love and Activism
abstract: In response to the Orlando attacks, posting photos of gay men showing affection has become an act of defiance and a demonstration of solidarity.
lead_paragraph: Last Sunday morning, Americans woke up to news of a shooting at a nightclub — 49 people dead, most of them gay men. Hours after the news broke, the gunman’s father suggested to the news media that the sight of two men kissing may have prompted his son to kill.

headline: Political Substance Abuse: Donald Trump on Immigration and Terrorism
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Terrorism']
abstract: At a rally in Atlanta, the unscripted Mr. Trump was back.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s rally in Atlanta on Wednesday provided his fellow Republicans, and the nation, with further evidence that a more presidential Mr. Trump may be a long time coming. After two teleprompter-assisted speeches, the unscripted Mr. Trump was back.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, June 18 Through June 26

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: In ‘Argentina,’ a Call to Save Traditions
abstract: Carlos Saura’s film captures a wide array of artists as they perform the folk music and dances of Argentina.
lead_paragraph: “Argentina” provides a fine introduction to that country’s traditional music and dance for those already familiar with it. The contradiction in that statement is why this pretty film is also a frustrating one.

headline: Why We Should Politicize the Orlando Massacre
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Political action is how L.G.B.T. people have won many rights. It is also how they should try to prevent another Orlando.
lead_paragraph: CALLS to resist “politicizing” tragedy have become a standard feature of our political discourse following mass shootings. From Newtown, Conn., to Aurora, Colo., politicians and pundits have urged us to refrain from politics as predictably as they have offered hollow “thoughts and prayers” as a condolence to victims and their families.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: In ‘Raiders!,’ Two Boys’ First, Great Movie Crush
abstract: In 1982, two Mississippi boys set out to create a shot-by-shot remake of Steven Spielberg’s “Raiders of the Lost Ark.” This is their story.
lead_paragraph: As its title boldly, somewhat hopefully announces, the documentary “Raiders! The Story of the Greatest Fan Film Ever Made” recounts the amusing ups and periodic alarming downs of a singular handmade project. In 1982, two Mississippi boys — Eric Zala, 12, and Chris Strompolos, 11 — set out to create a shot-by-shot remake of Steven Spielberg’s “Raiders of the Lost Ark,” which had hit theaters the year before. For seven years, as these boys became men, they called action and rolled camera, painstakingly, feverishly, recreating Indy and his high-flying adventures.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, June 18 Through June 26
abstract: Inflatable works are on display at the William Benton Museum of Art. Items include a 10-foot white elephant and a 17-foot replica of the 1977 “Smokey and the Bandit” Trans Am.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Defining, and Proclaiming, a New Black Power
abstract: In shows like “Shuffle Along” and albums like “Lemonade,” a form of black self-love and empowerment is emerging, in ways not seen since the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Black America has a lot of anthems. If you’re at a wedding in the Philadelphia area, for instance, and hear the opening keyboard blasts of “Before I Let Go” by Maze featuring Frankie Beverly, the secular spirit might compel you to the dance floor, spilling the “Woah-woah-ohhh-ho” of the first few seconds behind you as you sprint.

headline: Review: ‘Tickled’ Is Fun and Giggles Until It Isn’t Anymore
abstract: Two filmmakers had barely begun their reporting for this documentary when threats from the private world of tickling began.
lead_paragraph: For many people, I suspect, tickling is a verb, not a world. You would be wrong! Tickling has more going for it than a red plush toy named Elmo — it has scholars, scientists, deep thinkers. In his multivolume classic “Studies in the Psychology of Sex,” the psychologist and pioneering sexpert Havelock Ellis dedicates an entire section to tickling, defining it as both “a specialized modification of touch” and “the most intellectual mode of touch sensation.” Everyone from Aristotle to Darwin and Freud had something to say about the teasing art of the tickle, as did the Marquis de Sade.

headline: Samira Wiley on ‘Orange Is the New Black’ and Being a Role Model
abstract: The Juilliard-trained actress talks about her career, coming out to her parents and what’s in store for Poussey this season.
lead_paragraph: When Samira Wiley was first cast as Poussey Washington in “Orange Is the New Black,” she kept her night job.

headline: Review: ‘Cosmos’ Is a Madcap Plunge Into Retro Avant-Gardism
abstract: The Polish director Andrzej Zulawski’s final film is a witty and energetic — if somewhat labored — mélange of styles and ideas in a cosmopolitan mode.
lead_paragraph: “Cosmos,” Andrzej Zulawski’s first film since 2000, is both a comeback and a swan song. Mr. Zulawski, 75 when he died in February, was an important figure in the history of Polish cinema and in the emergence of a borderless, cosmopolitan European style of filmmaking during the Cold War and after. His last work pays tribute to his roots and to his subsequent wanderings. Based on a novel of the same name by the Polish writer Witold Gombrowicz, this French-Portuguese co-production is a witty and energetic — if also somewhat labored — mélange of languages, tones and ideas.

headline: Review: ‘Bang Gang,’ Seaside Orgies to a Soundtrack of Yawns
abstract: This film about middle-class teenagers having group sex during a long hot summer in Biarritz, France, is remarkable for its shrugging attitude.
lead_paragraph: What is distinctively contemporary about the French director Eva Husson’s teenage sex film, “Bang Gang: A Modern Love Story,” is its characters’ nonchalance. This portrait of middle-class teenagers fueled by Ecstasy, cocaine and pot, whiling away the hours and having group sex during a long hot summer in Biarritz, France, is remarkable for its shrugging attitude. Opposite in spirit to a shocker like Larry Clark’s “Kids,” “Bang Gang” doesn’t aim to titillate or to alarm.

headline: Judge in Kenya Upholds Use of Anal Exams for Men Suspected of Being Gay
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Discrimination', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: The court denied a petition to overturn the use of mandatory anal exams in Kenya, where homosexual sex can lead to an arrest.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Human rights groups expressed outrage on Thursday over a Kenyan court’s decision to uphold mandatory anal examinations of men who are suspected of being gay.

headline: Atwood, Rushdie Among 300 Authors to Appear at 2016 Brooklyn Book Festival
abstract: Margaret Atwood, Salman Rushdie, Sherman Alexie and Stephanie Danler are among those who will appear at the 11th annual event.
lead_paragraph: Readers will swarm downtown Brooklyn for the 11th annual Brooklyn Book Festival on Sunday, Sept. 18, and we now know many of the authors they will be there to see. On Thursday, the festival announced nearly 200 of the 300 authors who will appear, including Margaret Atwood, Sherman Alexie, Russell Banks, Salman Rushdie and Joyce Carol Oates.

headline: Low-Budget Highlights After Midnight: ‘Decker’ and ‘Brule’
abstract: For the less-discerning postmidnight viewer, there’s the special-ops goof Jack Decker in “Decker: Unclassified” and “Check It Out! With Dr. Steve Brule.”
lead_paragraph: A “24” without Jack Bauer? Believe it; it’s coming this winter. But there’s more unimaginable news on the secret-agents-named-Jack front: Jack Decker is dead.

headline: The Rough Read That Was ‘Ulysses’
abstract: Bloomsday, the celebration of James Joyce’s “Ulysses,” was Thursday. Read our 1922 review of a novel then considered obscene and banned in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Did you celebrate Bloomsday on Thursday? Yes, yes, yes? You needn’t have read the book. In many Bloomsday celebrations, huge chunks of the book, the incomparable “Ulysses,” are read for you and to you. It’s a perfectly good way to experience the Odyssean slog without having to, you know, do the work.

headline: Home Should Not Be a War Zone
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Veterans', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Some of our politicians and the people who back them seem to promote a culture of gun ownership that does not conform with what I learned in the military.
lead_paragraph: A BATTLEFIELD on our soil.

headline: Federal Judge Tosses Texas’ Lawsuit to Bar Syrian Refugees
abstract: A federal judge in Dallas ruled Texas has no legal merit to sue the Obama administration over the resettlement of Syrian refugees in the state.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Texas’ efforts to bar Syrian refugees from settling in the state were dealt a legal blow on Wednesday when a federal judge in Dallas dismissed the state’s lawsuit against federal officials and a nonprofit group that assists refugees.

headline: Years After United Merger, Flight Attendants Work for Two Airlines
keywords: ['Flight Attendants', 'Organized Labor', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The lack of an agreement to integrate the work force has complicated scheduling and contributed to flight delays.
lead_paragraph: Despite the name on its airplanes, United Airlines is anything but fully unified.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A hint that a small, but growing, crowd in the financial world is warming up to the idea of backing Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is holding a fund-raiser in New York City next week to be hosted by a who’s who of the financial world, including John A. Paulson, whose hedge fund made billions betting on the collapse of the housing market.

headline: 51 U.S. Diplomats Urge Strikes Against Assad in Syria
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: An internal memo, critical of Obama administration policy, says military action is necessary to stop violations of a cease-fire in the civil war.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than 50 State Department diplomats have signed an internal memo sharply critical of the Obama administration’s policy in Syria, urging the United States to carry out military strikes against the government of President Bashar al-Assad to stop its persistent violations of a cease-fire in the country’s five-year-old civil war.

headline: Weapons Cache and Bomb-Making Instructions Found at Long Island Home
keywords: ['Firearms', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Edward Perkowski, 29, was arrested on weapons and drug charges after the police discovered assault rifles, $40,000 in cash, Nazi paraphernalia and marijuana.
lead_paragraph: YAPHANK, N.Y. — A Long Island man was arrested on weapons charges on Thursday after police officers found assault rifles, bomb-making instructions, over $40,000 in cash and Nazi paraphernalia in his house, the authorities said.

headline: Kenneth Walton, F.B.I.’s Bold New York Face in the ’80s, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Walton, who mixed the flair of a central-casting G-man with the nerve to defy rigid protocol, was the bureau’s public face in cases involving a Tylenol poisoning scare and a Brink’s truck robbery.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Walton, a flamboyant official with the Federal Bureau of Investigation who galvanized the agency’s New York office against violent political radicals and entrenched organized crime bosses in the early 1980s, died on May 25 in Albuquerque. He was 76.

headline: With Final Goodbyes in Orlando, a Stark Reckoning for Loved Ones
abstract: After grappling with shock and anger, the families and friends of those killed in Orlando find themselves confronting the raw emotions of saying goodbye.
lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — His hair was carefully styled, a chestnut wave atop his head, slicked to the left. His slender face looked pale under heavy makeup. A rosary with white beads and a gold crucifix threaded his hands, which rested on the white T-shirt bearing his image and name: Luis Omar Ocasio-Capo.

headline: Exxon Mobil Fights Back at State Inquiries Into Climate Change Research
abstract: After 20 state attorneys general supported an investigation into the company, Exxon Mobil is using the courts to try and stop the legal momentum.
lead_paragraph: In the eight months since the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, announced the first investigation of Exxon Mobil over its past research statements about climate change, nearly 20 other state attorneys general have voiced their support.

headline: Archbishop Sheen’s Family Sues to Move His Body, From New York to Illinois
abstract: Relatives of Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, well known as the host of a 1950s television show, want him to be buried in Peoria, where church officials are behind the cause for his canonization.
lead_paragraph: Archbishop Fulton J. Sheen, known by millions as the Emmy Award-winning host of a television show in the 1950s, made one of his last public appearances at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in Manhattan, rising from his chair and kneeling before Pope John Paul II during a visit in 1979.

abstract: The invitations to many of Donald J. Trump's fund-raisers may conspicuously lack host lists, but that's not the case for the events with Mr. Bush, like this one for Mr. Blunt. headline: An Unlikely Savior Emerges to Help Endangered Republicans: George W. Bush
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Elections, Senate', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The former president has largely stayed away from politics. But he is deeply bothered by Donald J. Trump’s inflammatory talk.
lead_paragraph: After eight years of largely abstaining from politics, former President George W. Bush is throwing himself into an effort to save his party’s most vulnerable senators, including several whose re-election campaigns have been made more difficult by Donald J. Trump’s presence at the top of the ticket.

headline: Rain Stops Play at United States Open, Bringing Some Players Relief
abstract: With only seven players under par, Andrew Landry, ranked 624th in the world, is leading after bad weather suspended play at Oakmont Country Club.
lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — The first rain delay Thursday morning at the 116th United States Open was greeted like recess in grammar school, except in reverse. Golfers dashed from their playground to the nearest dwelling. Some impishly pilfered chocolate chip cookies from the media center as a gaggle of their European colleagues watched soccer broadcasts from their home continent. There were smiles and laughs, and selfies posted on social media.

headline: Classical Music Listings for June 17-23
abstract: A critical guide to classical music performances in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

headline: Gene Cavallero Jr., Who Ran the Colony Restaurant, Dies at 92
abstract: The Colony occupied a lofty perch in New York City’s dining scene, becoming a destination for boldface names like Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and Frank Sinatra.
lead_paragraph: Gene Cavallero Jr., who took over his father’s fabled Manhattan restaurant, the Colony, and maintained it as a gilt-edged gathering place for the social elite and the international jet set, died on June 4 in Phoenix. He was 92.

We call that “hitting for the cycle,” and it requires both gumption and persistence, because constructing early-week puzzles requires a much different skill set than constructing late-week, themeless puzzles.

Brooks.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal regulators on Thursday took up the fight for their right to label certain financial institutions as “too big to fail” after a Federal District Court threw out their designation of the insurance company MetLife earlier this year.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
