lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — The primaries are officially over. Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump are attacking each other over the Orlando tragedy. Final touches are being made to convention plans. Running mates are being vetted.

headline: Old New York Police Surveillance Is Found, Forcing Big Brother Out of Hiding
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Archives and Records', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Boxes found in a Queens warehouse contain files about the Black Panthers, the Nation of Islam and the Young Lords.
lead_paragraph: From the mid-1950s to the early 1970s, police surveillance of political organizations in New York was extensive enough to require more than half a million index cards, simply to catalog and cross-reference the many dossiers. But over the ensuing decades, the dossiers themselves were presumed missing or lost. Police Department lawyers said they had no idea where the files had gone.

headline: Bartolo Colon Gives Mets a Much-Needed Lift and a Win Over the Pirates
abstract: The rotund pitcher delivers on the mound and at the plate on a day of dispiriting news for the team.
lead_paragraph: It was understandable if the Mets entered Thursday’s game with the Pittsburgh Pirates with as much self-esteem as a Charlie Brown-led team, after David Wright, their anchor for the last 13 years at third base, had neck surgery, with no timetable for a return.

headline: The Wedding Was Quirky. Now the Government Is Submitting Its Bill.
abstract: J. Felix Strevell owed New York State money after admitting to fraud, but in a civil complaint, federal prosecutors accused him of spending it on his daughter’s farm wedding instead.
lead_paragraph: The wedding guests sat on bales of straw lined up evenly in rows. Heads of wheat served as boutonnieres for the groomsmen. Two flower girls, actually cows named Mona and Lisa, were led by their handler.

headline: Hints of Deal Emerge as Lawmakers Make Late Push in Albany
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Homeless Persons', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'State Legislatures', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Legislators were piecing together agreements on a variety of issues Thursday evening, which was scheduled to be the last day of the legislative calendar.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — State lawmakers were assembling the skeleton of a long-awaited deal on a number of issues on Thursday evening, including a one-year extension of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s control of New York City schools and an ethics reform measure that would strip state pensions from elected officials convicted of a felony.

headline: United States Advances to Copa América Semifinals
abstract: The United States advanced to the semifinals of the Copa América Centenario in front of a boisterous home crowd at CenturyLink Field in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The first time the United States men’s national soccer team played in the Copa América was in 1993 in Ecuador. In its second game of that tournament, the hosts soundly defeated a United States team that was still largely composed of former college players.

keywords: ['Referendums', 'International Relations', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: A vote by Britain to leave the European Union could create pressure for Scottish independence and harden the border between Ireland and Northern Ireland.
lead_paragraph: AUGHNACLOY, Northern Ireland — With nothing to mark the point where one country ends and another begins, there is little sign of the border between the United Kingdom and Ireland, a frontier that was once controlled by military checkpoints.

headline: Why LinkedIn Will Make You Hate Microsoft Word
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Social Media', 'Word Processing', 'Software', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The two companies envision a world where someone’s always bothering you while you’re writing.
lead_paragraph: IF Microsoft has its way, the vast membership of LinkedIn, the business networking site with more than 433 million members, will be instantly available to you while you use Microsoft products like Outlook or Skype. How many of LinkedIn’s members do you want to consult while also using Excel or typing away in Word? Microsoft is betting it’s a lot; this is part of its rationale for its $26.2 billion acquisition of LinkedIn, announced on Monday.

headline: Fear, Loathing and Brexit
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Referendums', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Britons have a choice between bad and worse.
lead_paragraph: There are still four and a half months to go before the presidential election. But there’s a vote next week that could matter as much for the world’s future as what happens here: Britain’s referendum on whether to stay in the European Union.

headline: Trust Deficit at the Red Cross
abstract: A Senate report raises new troubling questions about how the charity spent the $488 million raised after the 2010 Haiti earthquake.
lead_paragraph: After calamities, people donate millions of dollars to the American Red Cross, believing it is uniquely equipped to provide prompt humanitarian aid. The latest evidence that their faith has been misplaced came this week in a report by Senator Charles Grassley about the charity’s poor response to the 2010 earthquake in Haiti.

headline: The New York Jail Break That Exposed a Broken System
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Prison Escapes', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The ease with which employees were able to smuggle items to prisoners shows the need for serious changes.
lead_paragraph: The New York State corrections system was ridiculed last June when two employees at a maximum-security prison were arrested for smuggling in tools — including hacksaw blades — that helped two convicted murderers escape. The two employees went to jail. But a troubling report from the state inspector general, Catherine Leahy Scott, shows that malfeasance and security lapses were the order of the day at the Clinton Correctional Facility when the two men escaped.

headline: A Week for All Time
abstract: Seal it. Put it in a time capsule. Teach it. History will remember. But come November, will we?
lead_paragraph: They will remember, a century from now, who stood up to the tyrant Donald Trump and who found it expedient to throw out the most basic American values — the “Vichy Republicans,” as the historian Ken Burns called them in his Stanford commencement speech.

headline: Religion’s Wicked Neighbor
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Religion and Belief', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Terrorism isn’t central to Islam, and terrorists aren’t practicing religion.
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama is clearly wrong when he refuses to use the word “Islam” in reference to Islamist terrorism. The people who commit these acts are inflamed by a version of an Islamist ideology. They claim an Islamist identity. They swear fealty to organizations like ISIS that govern themselves according to certain interpretations of the Quran.

headline: Britain’s Dangerous Urge to Go It Alone
abstract: If voters approve a “Brexit” from the European Union, it would be a blow to the British economy and to hopes for greater cooperation across the Continent.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s moment of truth is fast approaching. Next Thursday, the country will vote on whether to remain in or to leave the European Union. The referendum has generated a torrent of analyses, commentaries and appeals — including President Obama’s urging Britain to stay in. Most serious studies have concluded that Britain would be economically and politically damaged by “Brexit,” a British exit from the E.U.

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Suburbs', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: High prices in New York City are driving up demand in certain nearby towns.

Then living in an apartment in Manhattan, the couple (she’s an accountant, he’s a founder of Thinkmodo, which creates viral video campaigns) were in need of more space for their two toddlers. After their real estate agent, Arthur L. Scinta, an associate broker with Houlihan Lawrence, advised them to move quickly, they went to see the house the very next day.

Dawson died April 15, 1912.”

headline: An Expensive Law Degree, and No Place to Use It

He graduated from Valparaiso University Law School — a well-established regional school here in northwestern Indiana — in the top third of his class this past December, a semester ahead of schedule. He passed the bar exam on his first try in February.

headline: What David Sedaris Can’t Travel Without
abstract: When the author travels, several items travel with him, from a backscratcher to room spray.
lead_paragraph: David Sedaris, the author of “Let’s Explore Diabetes With Owls” and “When You Are Engulfed in Flames,” spends his time in West Sussex, England, when he isn’t on his twice-yearly 45-city lecture tours. Hotels figure highly in his repeat vacation spots. He returns to the Four Seasons Resort the Biltmore Santa Barbara again and again (“Everyone there looks like Mitt and Ann Romney”), and he loves the Ambassade Hotel in Amsterdam (“I’ve probably stayed there at least a dozen times, and they keep the same people there. It’s a nice feeling to go to another country and have people remember your name and be so warm”).

abstract: Rural areas are emerging as a frontier for designers as urban residents tire of environmental crises and food scares and become interested in organic lifestyles.
lead_paragraph: LING’AN, China — Nestled in verdant hills amid bamboo forests and feathery grass meadows, the Sun Commune is a thriving eco-farm about 60 miles from the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou. Its centerpiece is a pig barn.

headline: With Our Father’s Death, a Chance for Brothers to Connect
abstract: The most powerful reminders of our dad resided in my brothers and in me. He was the one who might finally draw us close.
lead_paragraph: When I was a small boy my dad used to ask me for show tunes. “Sing ‘Happiness!’” he’d say to me on the ferry to Shelter Island, and I’d happily comply, the wind blowing the notes out into the Peconic Bay. And he liked to call me into the living room when he and my mom had company and say, “Sing something for us, Artie!”

headline: 2 Chinese Activists Sentenced to Over 10 Years on Subversion Charges
abstract: Lu Gengsong and Chen Shuqing were convicted for publishing pro-democracy essays on overseas websites and promoting the banned China Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Two longtime members of China’s beleaguered democratic opposition each received prison sentences of over a decade on Friday after being pronounced guilty of subversion by a court in Hangzhou, an eastern city that will host a gathering of world leaders later this year.

headline: Looking for Enlightenment in the Himalayas
abstract: A sit-down with a women who meditated in a cave for 16 years.
lead_paragraph: Nani Ma was standing in a white sari outside her hut, a bare concrete block with a tin roof, when I arrived. The villagers who told me about her had described her accurately — a slender British woman in her late 60s who radiated calm. For 16 years she had meditated alone in a cave in the Indian Himalayas. Recently she had broken her vow of silence and moved to this hut in Uttarkashi, in the foothills of the mountains. I had hiked four kilometers through a dense forest to meet her.

headline: How to Nap
abstract: Aim to sleep for 20 minutes. Find a safe space.
lead_paragraph: “Duration is very important,” says Damien Léger, a doctor who runs the sleep-research center at the Hôtel-Dieu hospital in Paris. Aim to sleep for 20 minutes. Anything longer, and you risk drifting into what scientists call slow-wave sleep, a state of languid brain-wave activity considered important for consolidating memories. Set an alarm clock. A slow-wave encounter is likely to leave you with what Léger calls “sleep drunkenness” instead of a feeling of rejuvenation.

headline: Beth Comstock of General Electric: Granting Permission to Innovate
abstract: To Ms. Comstock, vice chairwoman of G.E., leadership is about understanding that things will never be perfectly balanced, and using that tension to move forward.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Beth Comstock, vice chairwoman of G.E., was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant

headline: One Man’s Quest to Get Americans to Care About Rugby
abstract: In the U.S., the sport has long been overshadowed by football. Now a former bond trader is working to bring it back to the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: He was hard-pressed to explain it even to himself. Possibly the whole idea was daft. His “rugby dream,” the aspiration to start a professional rugby league in North America, had taken over his life. It had him raiding his bank account to pay for logos, trademarks, websites. For visa specialists, branding wizards, a high-powered sports lawyer. It had him hacking through jungles of marketing jargon. His Midtown Manhattan office was cluttered with cartons of new business cards, boxes of hats, sample jerseys. There was a litter of unorganized receipts on the desk. In 18 months he’d racked up 250,000 frequent flier miles. He’d watched the Rugby World Cup in London from the Royal Box at Olympic Stadium; someone joked he could plunge New Zealand into a national depression if he lured their stars to America. He’d delved into venue contracts, hot-dog sales projections and turf heights on rugby-compliant fields. In conversation after conversation, on the phone, by email and in person, at mixers and conferences, in airports and foyers and hallways, he pitched his plans, parried critics and cajoled skeptics into the fold. Some guardians of amateur rugby were threatened by the prospect of losing prized club players to a pro league. Some just wondered who the hell he was — Douglas Schoninger, a not-particularly-athletic 55-year-old former bond trader who had never played rugby, who dimly remembered seeing a few games 30 or 40 years ago but didn’t know a ruck from a maul or a lock from a hooker until he bought a copy of “Rugby Union for Dummies.”

Attlee, Lord Privy Seal, speaking in the House of Commons, and Air Marshal Sir Phillip Joubert de la Ferte, at a press conference yesterday [June 17], revealed what some Britons have suspected but which has never before been officially admitted — that the Royal Air Force possesses a secret radio spotting device which operates amazingly in warning of enemy raiding planes long before they reach Great Britain’s shores.

The attack came barely two days after an American, Omar Mateen, who had pledged allegiance to the Islamic State, killed 49 people at a gay bar in Orlando, Fla.

headline: 1966: Johnson Warns Hanoi of Heavier Air Blows
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In June 1966, President Johnson warns Vietnam of heavier air attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Johnson served notice on North Vietnam yesterday [June 18] that the United States will ‘‘raise the cost of aggression at its source’’ by intensified use of air power. His stern warning at the White House news conference evoked speculation that the United States is now prepared to extend air attacks to oil and other supply dumps in North Vietnam. This wider air action reportedly was imminent just before the outbreak of political turmoil in South Vietnam in March.

lead_paragraph: For the first time in over a decade, the  death rate in the United States is getting worse, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported. The news is the latest in a string of headlines about the shortening lives of Americans, particularly the white middle-aged. “Disparity in Life Spans of the Rich and the Poor Is Growing.” “White Americans Are Dying Younger as Drug and Alcohol Abuse Rises.” “U.S. Suicide Rate Surges to a 30-Year High.”

But in 1980, he was just another young assistant at Scribner fighting to have his voice heard, when he tried to acquire “The River Why,” a debut novel by David James Duncan about a young fly fisherman on a spiritual quest in the Pacific Northwest.

headline: 4,223 Central Park Benches With Stories to Tell
keywords: ['Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: The Adopt-a-Bench program began in 1986, as a way to finance the maintenance of areas within the park. Today, the benches, each adorned with a plaque, are more than simply places to sit.
lead_paragraph: In the park, there are 9,485 of them. You sit on them. To rest. Read a book. Sip coffee. Polish off a pulled-pork sandwich. Feed the pigeons. Wait for a friend, maybe a spy. Or it’s a sluggish day when you have nothing to do, and this is a delicious place to accomplish absolutely nothing.

headline: Giselle Potter’s ‘This Is My Dollhouse,’ and More

lead_paragraph: A familiar place, a pungent smell, the distant chatter of children’s voices: You never know what might arouse a childhood memory, a moment of pure sensation as you recall hours of playful abandon. Four new picture books featuring children absorbed in creative worlds of their own making are likely to evoke such memories in their grown-up readers. Children lucky enough to encounter these books will not only enjoy them, they may even be inspired to find a slow day, roam through their imaginations and make something — the simplest of pleasures.

The music was pounding, and lights flashing, but when your eyes adjusted to the neon and then the dim, there they were: 266 mannequins wearing vintage Raf Simons, paired in groups or hanging over stairways like partygoers at a thumping club.

headline: One Man’s Mission to Keep Musicians’ Legacies Alive

The fate of unreleased Kurt Cobain recordings has had his former Nirvana bandmates and widow, Courtney Love, fighting (and reconciling) in public for two decades.

headline: Did Infamous Tuskegee Study Cause Lasting Mistrust of Doctors Among Blacks?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Medicine and Health', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Research', 'Longevity']
abstract: A study makes a leap to causality, but it’s not as if racism stopped: We should be careful about blaming a single incident in the past.
lead_paragraph: There is no question that the Tuskegee study is one of the most horrific examples of unethical research in recent history. For 40 years, ending in 1972, members of the United States Public Health Service followed African-American men infected with syphilis and didn’t treat them (although they told some men they did) so that they could see the disease take its course.

headline: Lawsuit Says Texas Students Wrapped Rope Around Black Girl’s Neck
keywords: ['Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Rope and Twine', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: A private school in Texas has been sued for more than $3 million by the family of a black girl who accused three white classmates of wrapping a rope around her neck and dragging her to the ground during a school trip — leaving her with severe rope burns and a mark that looked like a necklace.

Ms. Rathore stopped herself, sinking her head into her hands. “You finished it,” she whispered.

headline: Totally Cool: Max Martin Wins Polar Prize
abstract: Mr. Martin, the producer and writer behind hits for Taylor Swift and Katy Perry, won, along with the Italian mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli.
lead_paragraph: Max Martin, the Swedish producer and songwriter who worked on hits for Taylor Swift (“Blank Space”), Britney Spears (“… Baby One More Time”) and Katy Perry (“Teenage Dream”), has been awarded the 2016 edition of Sweden’s Polar Music Prize, along with the Italian mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli. The award comes with a cash prize of one million Swedish krona (about $119,825).

headline: 15 Minutes With Ai Weiwei
abstract: At Cambridge, where his work is now on view, the artist sat down exclusively with T to discuss social media, his work with refugees — and Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Five shadowy, ominous, twisted wooden sculptures loom over the neo-Classical backdrop of the Downing College Chapel in Cambridge, England. Ai Weiwei has come to town — and he’s brought his “Trees” (and “Cubes”) with him. Earlier this week, the artist, wearing an equally dark linen suit, was unperturbed by the fact that two trees were still at large, en route from London where they went on view last summer as part of his blockbuster show at the Royal Academy. Before that, they’d been hidden inside his Beijing studio for years. “We’ve been getting a tree a day,” quipped John Tancock, the guest-curator of “Ai Weiwei: Trees and Cubes,” which opens today. During the installation, the artist caught up with T — until being stopped short by a fire alarm. (Weiwei maintains he had nothing to do with it.)

headline: Nicolas Winding Refn Dissects His Bloody Confection
abstract: Mr. Refn calls his horrific “The Neon Demon” a “funny movie” and says it could even be seen as a twisted take on “A Star Is Born.”
lead_paragraph: Halfway though “The Neon Demon,” Nicolas Winding Refn’s new film about envy, duplicity and cannibalism on the Los Angeles fashion circuit, a smarmy designer forces a young man to judge two models. One of them, an icy product of plastic surgery, is manufactured, the designer says; the other, a 16-year-old waif (Elle Fanning) who transfixes everyone she meets, is an example of being “born beautiful.” Her boyfriend says that a person’s insides are what really matter.

headline: Foggy on Police Transparency
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'News and News Media', 'Law and Legislation', 'Cameras']
abstract: A New York administration truly committed to generating greater trust in its police force wouldn’t waste its money fighting efforts to facilitate the transparency it claims to value.
lead_paragraph: Late last month, the New York City police commissioner, William J. Bratton, as if he were a burdened star too often besieged by paparazzi, delivered critical words about our reliance on cameras. The commissioner had been speaking at a conference of police chiefs in Manhattan and was asked about an investigation into a cellphone video that had materialized showing a police officer in Harlem pointing a gun at a group of people looking on as he was trying to make an arrest. Without defending what the officer had done, Mr. Bratton spoke of the practice of ordinary people filming unsettling behavior by the police as a “very serious” issue that had reached “epidemic” levels in this country. Wayward law enforcement was not the problem; it was all these aspiring Weegees, inciting citizens, sometimes completely innocent ones, to resist arrest.

Every meeting she has with another person is always the first. Her own parents have forgotten that they ever had two daughters, not just one.

headline: Why ‘Transcending Race’ Is a Lie
abstract: The highest compliment America will pay black people — whether O. J. Simpson, Muhammad Ali or Prince — is to claim they escaped their own blackness.
lead_paragraph: I was born in the shadow of the 21st century, so I never knew O. J. Simpson as an athlete or as an actor. I wasn’t quite a year old on Jan. 1, 1989, the day Simpson beat his wife, Nicole Brown-Simpson, so badly that she fled their house screaming, “He’s going to kill me!” I was only 6 on June 17, 1994, when the N.B.A. finals broadcast cut away to a shot of Simpson’s white Ford Bronco creeping down a California highway, escorted by a line of black-and-whites, as if in a funeral procession. That was four days after Brown-Simpson, 35, and her friend Ronald Goldman, 25, were found dead in pools of blood, nearly decapitated. Some of my earliest memories are of that white Bronco, and of the “Trial of the Century” that followed, and of my parents’ happiness when Simpson was acquitted.

That was when her mother, Ida Horowitz, checked herself into the mental ward of Mercy Hospital in San Diego. Ida was then a Chevy-driving mother of four and a struggling artist who kept a suicide contingency plan — a plastic bag just the right size to fit snugly over her head — at the bottom of her purse.

headline: Review: Aumm Aumm in North Bergen Is a Naples Nearby
abstract: Ingredients are imported from Italy to ensure flavor and quality are as close to Neapolitan-style authenticity as possible.
lead_paragraph: Though I hadn’t eaten it yet, I was almost sure that the pizza at Aumm Aumm Pizzeria and Wine Bar in North Bergen would be a winner. My dining party was sitting at a table near the entrance and perusing the menu when a family of four walked in speaking Italian. We ended up engaging in small talk, and I found out that they were tourists from Bari, a seaside city in Italy’s Puglia region. They had been to the restaurant two days before, they told us, and had enjoyed the pizza so much that they’d come back for more.

To investigate how Americans date now, he teamed up with a sociologist and interviewed hundreds of people about their fears and ­habits in this humorous exploration.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The work of 23-year-old Rupi Kaur, whose debut poetry collection is No. 8 on the paperback trade fiction list, is like a cross between Charles Bukowski and Cat Power.
lead_paragraph: Pop Poet: Who says nobody reads poetry anymore? On the paperback trade fiction list, a debut collection called “Milk and Honey,” by the Canadian writer Rupi Kaur, is going strong at No. 8 after nine weeks. Kaur is a 23-year-old social media phenom from Toronto who gained attention last year when she fought Instagram’s removal of a photo she posted showing menstrual blood. As her audience grew — she now has 475,000 followers on Instagram and 34,500 on Twitter — Kaur earned a reputation not only for her photos and ­sketches but also for brief, plain-­spoken ­poems tackling feminism, love, trauma and healing in short lines that can be as smooth as pop music (“love will hold you / love will call your name”) or as jagged as rusty metal (“the hurt / the loss / the pain / the breaking”). Much of Kaur’s appeal comes from this artless vulnerability, like a cross between Charles Bukowski and Cat Power, and from an ingénue’s willingness to blurt out whatever is on her mind. “I was always writing for myself,” she told The Times of India this month. “I wrote what I needed to write and hear — that’s what makes it powerful. And it’s this honesty that has got me where I am today.” Well, that and some serious marketing savvy: Besides “Milk and Honey,” which she initially self-­published, visitors to Kaur’s website can also buy jars of artisanal honey branded with her name, “from the hives of distinguished queen bees.” And she has ideas about how to expand her reach. “There have been articles saying that all women need to read my book,” she told The Times of India. “I ask, why not all men? In fact, that would be even more valuable because we women want to sit down with men and tell them — this is how we feel, this is what we go through.”

headline: Review: Salt & Barrel Oyster and Craft Cocktail Bar in Bay Shore
abstract: The family behind the well-known seafood restaurant Flynn’s Fire Island, a mainstay in Ocean Bay Park since 1937, brings a more upscale option to the shore.
lead_paragraph: Say “seafood restaurant” and many Long Islanders will think of Flynn’s Fire Island, a mainstay in Ocean Bay Park since 1937. About three months ago, the Flynn family opened a very different spot in Bay Shore. Salt & Barrel Oyster and Craft Cocktail Bar is not a rustic, by-the-water, keep-it-casual place like Flynn’s. It is much more upscale, has a New American, seafood-based menu, and is within a brand-new apartment complex on West Main Street.

headline: When Virtue Fails
abstract: Maybe moral failings aren’t the euro’s problem.
lead_paragraph: There are two narratives about the euro crisis. One – favored by English-speaking economists, including yours truly – sees it all through the lens of optimum currency area theory. Basically, shocks happen, and when you establish a common currency without a shared government, you give countries no good way, fiscal or monetary, to respond to these shocks.

headline: Searching for Rhythm in a Director’s Complex Universe

lead_paragraph: Slumped in his chair, Dmitry Krymov seemed the personification of the brooding Russian director. On the first day of the third week of rehearsals, his new play, “The Square Root of Three Sisters,” had just completed its first run-through. And with less than three weeks of rehearsals left before its world premiere, it was still very much a work in progress.

headline: Barring Russia’s Team, Not Just Individuals, Is a Powerful Move
abstract: Penalizing a country for doping seems to be a much more effective way to ensure rapid and enduring change.
lead_paragraph: Track and field’s world governing body, the International Association of Athletics Federations, still has a very long way to run before earning back our trust. Its former president, Lamine Diack, faces charges of corruption in France. Its new president, Sebastian Coe, who received Diack’s electoral stamp of approval, is back to answering prickly questions about what he knew and when he knew it.

headline: How Bill Nye, the Science Guy, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Nye divides his time between Los Angeles and Manhattan, where he is writing a book and working on a project to send a spacecraft to other planets.
lead_paragraph: William Sanford Nye got his start doing sketch comedy, made his name as Bill Nye the Science Guy in children’s television and now runs an organization dedicated to sending spacecraft to other planets. Two years ago, he added the title of bicoastal New Yorker, dividing his time between Los Angeles and Manhattan’s Upper West Side, where he is finishing work on a book called “Everything All at Once: How Nerds Solve Problems” and a series of children’s books called “Jack and the Geniuses.” Among his favorite things about life in New York: the subway system. “Are you kidding me?” Mr. Nye, 60, said. “It’s amazing. Carries a billion people a year. For $2.75 you can go anywhere. Come on, people.”

lead_paragraph: After years of work and study culminating in an assistant conductorship at the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, Kazem Abdullah decamped to Aachen, Germany, where he became the city’s general music director. Four years on, he has programmed and conducted a wide range of symphonic music and opera from the core Western repertory.

headline: Review: The New York Philharmonic Pays Tribute to Orlando
abstract: Some 50,000 people were in Central Park on Wednesday for a concert dedicated to the memory of the victims of the shooting. The orchestra also played there on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The scene always feels festive when the New York Philharmonic presents its annual free concerts in the city’s parks. But as Alan Gilbert, the Philharmonic’s music director, said in welcoming the crowd of some 50,000 on the Great Lawn in Central Park on Wednesday for the summer series’s opening, the “entire country is suffering in the aftermath of the horrific attacks” at a gay nightclub in Orlando.

headline: Review: ‘I Remember Mama’ at Two River Theater Profits From Creative Casting
abstract: Older actresses, dressed in everyday clothes instead of period costumes, inhabit a range of roles and excite the imagination.
lead_paragraph: “People’s hearts don’t break,” a character claims in “I Remember Mama.” Then she adds, “Only in books.”

headline: ‘Oslo’ and the Drama in Diplomacy
abstract: Upon meeting with a diplomat, the playwright J.T. Rogers knew there was a special story to tell, and he set out to do it.
lead_paragraph: The story of “Oslo” begins with a Norwegian diplomat in a restaurant with an American playwright.

headline: Chicago Man Records Own Fatal Shooting
abstract: Antonio Perkins was streaming video of himself on Facebook Live on Wednesday when he was shot and killed in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Perkins was streaming video of himself on Facebook Live on Wednesday when he was shot and killed in Chicago.

abstract: This week’s properties include a contemporary in Fort Lee, N.J., and a colonial in Millwood, N.Y.

abstract: This week’s properties include a contemporary in Fort Lee, N.J., and a colonial in Millwood, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a contemporary in Fort Lee, N.J., and a colonial in Millwood, N.Y.

headline: Fathers and Stepfathers Join Hands at Weddings
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Marriages', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Parenting', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Weddings don’t always bring out the best in people, but some fathers and stepfathers are setting aside their differences for the sake of the children.
lead_paragraph: It’s long been said that weddings bring out the best and the worst in people. In a society where divorce has become commonplace, and where the accompanying hurt has been longstanding, some couples and their complicated families are finding that a wedding can present the perfect opportunity to break the emotional logjam.

headline: Review: Billowy Bloomers Made Her the Talk of Düsseldorf
abstract: “The Underpants,” the comedian’s adaptation of a German farce, shows a sweet young housewife struggling with lust in 1910.
lead_paragraph: A German flag with a barely noticeable strip of lace added to its bottom serves as a stage curtain at the beginning of “The Underpants,” a comedy adapted by Steve Martin from a German farce by Carl Sternheim, at Guild Hall in East Hampton.

headline: Viacom to Pay Chief’s Legal Bills in Fight Over Redstone Empire
abstract: The company said its profit for the current quarter will be far below Wall Street’s expectations.
lead_paragraph: As he wages legal battles in multiple states to keep his position in Sumner M. Redstone’s media empire, Philippe P. Dauman’s legal bills are being paid by Viacom.

headline: It Has Been a While Since Mighty Stephen Curry Has Fouled Out
abstract: Curry, who fouled out of Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday night, had not fouled out since 2013, before he won his first Most Valuable Player Award.
lead_paragraph: The dramatic climax of Game 6 of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday night came when Stephen Curry picked up his sixth foul, hurled his mouthpiece in protest and was ejected.

headline: Schatzie the Butcher Cuts Meats and Chews the Fat
abstract: Alan Tony Schatz has been wielding a cleaver for 60 years, most recently from his meat shop on Broadway near 101st Street.
lead_paragraph: Alan Tony Schatz, 72, who has been cutting meat for 60 years, initially in his father’s shop in the Bronx, is better known by his nickname.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Sisterhood on Wheels: Bushwick’s Rugged Roller Derby Girls
abstract: Gotham Girls Roller Derby created its junior league for girls in 2012 to provide “a positive, empowering space for girls to learn, practice and play a contact sport.”
lead_paragraph: Blossom Bettles is 12 years old and lives on a tree-lined street in Brooklyn. Her father, who is British, is a photographer; her mother is a meditation and mindfulness teacher from New Zealand. She has a little brother named Sunny. Blossom is petite, with blue eyes and a dimpled smile, and wavy light-brown hair. Her name seems to suit her perfectly, until she straps on skates, dons her gear and becomes Dark Pixie, a fierce competitor in a gritty junior roller derby league in Bushwick.

headline: Premier of Ukraine Urges Europe Not to Ease Russia Sanctions
abstract: Remarks by Prime Minister Volodymyr B. Groysman came as European officials appeared to make an effort to temper the worst estrangement in relations with Russia since the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: The new prime minister of Ukraine appealed to European countries to maintain economic sanctions against Russia, warning that those who might ease pressure would serve as the “aggressor’s accomplices.”

headline: As Zika Threat Grows in U.S., Testing Lags for a Vulnerable Group
abstract: Health officials and doctors found that large numbers of women, many uninsured or low-income immigrants from the Caribbean and Latin America, were not being screened and tested in a systematic way.
lead_paragraph: As the Zika virus swept north from Brazil into the Caribbean, bringing with it frightening risks for pregnant women and their unborn children, United States health officials decided in February that all expectant women who had visited the countries affected should be tested for the disease.

headline: Number of Zika-Positive Puerto Ricans Surprises Health Officials
abstract: The C.D.C. said recent blood donations suggest that a substantial portion of the island’s population will become infected by the virus.
lead_paragraph: Roughly 1 percent of recent blood donors in Puerto Rico showed signs of active infection with the Zika virus, suggesting that a substantial portion of the island’s population will become infected, federal health officials reported on Friday.

headline: Russians on Barring of Olympic Team
abstract: A former Russian Olympic ice skater, Svetlana Zhurova, and Moscow residents criticized the barring of Russia’s track and field team from the Rio Games.
lead_paragraph: A former Russian Olympic ice skater, Svetlana Zhurova, and Moscow residents criticized the barring of Russia’s track and field team from the Rio Games.

headline: Review: You Know, This ‘Tunnel’ Feels Really Familiar
abstract: The Scandinavian series “The Bridge” inspired FX’s “The Tunnel,” and now a very similar British-French series of the same title on PBS.
lead_paragraph: The discovery of a body, apparently cut in half and straddling an international border, forces bickering cops from neighboring countries to cooperate. It’s out there, as premises go, and it doesn’t seem as universally appealing as those of, say, “Law & Order” or “CSI.” But the Danish-Swedish series “The Bridge” has proved surprisingly exportable. It inspired an American remake of the same title, which ran for two seasons on FX, and then a British-French series, “The Tunnel,” whose second season ended recently.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Steven Erlanger, Kim Severson and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Review: This is New York? An Urban Montage Traffics in the Well Worn
abstract: Jane Comfort and Company’s “You Are Here,” part of the American Dance Institute’s season at the Kitchen, is short on convincing aggression or malice.
lead_paragraph: To view the hustle and bustle of pedestrian traffic as a kind of dance is a poetic way of looking at city life. It is also a choreographic cliché, and Jane Comfort and Company’s “You Are Here” doesn’t transcend it.

headline: With the Sun Out, a Big Name and a Newcomer Are Tied at the U.S. Open
abstract: Dustin Johnson, who finished second last year, played 36 holes on Friday while Andrew Landry, ranked 624th, swung a club just once. Both players were 4-under par.
lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — A wave of golfers trudged off the Oakmont Country Club golf course at midmorning Friday, looking weary but happy to have finally finished a round that for many had started 24 hours earlier. Stepping from grass saturated by a deluge the previous day, they stamped their feet on pavement near the clubhouse trying to shed the dampness from their shoes.

headline: Angelo Mozilo Will Not Face U.S. Charges for Mortgage Fraud
abstract: The Justice Department said it had decided against filing a civil fraud case against Mr. Mozilo, co-founder of Countrywide Financial.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s pursuit of Angelo R. Mozilo, one of Wall Street’s most recognizable names tied to the subprime mortgage crisis, is ending with a whimper.

headline: Jo Cox, Brexit and the Politics of Hate
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: Is a member of Parliament’s killing a sign of how toxic British politics have become?
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jo Cox, a Labour member of Britain’s Parliament, was killed on Thursday in the northern English area she represented by a man wielding a knife and a gun. Initial reports suggested that the suspect, Thomas Mair, was a “loner” with “a history of mental illness.” But as more details have emerged, it is becoming clear that he had a commitment to white supremacist and neo-Nazi politics. According to some witnesses, he shouted either “Britain first” or “put Britain first” as he stabbed and shot Ms. Cox, who was a vocal defender of immigration and diversity.

headline: Review: Hints of Eternity at Trinity Wall Street
abstract: Gavin Bryars’s new composition, “The Fifth Century,” was performed Thursday evening by the Crossing, a Philadelphia chorus, and the Prism Quartet.
lead_paragraph: In Gavin Bryars’s “The Fifth Century,” a haunting work for choir and saxophone quartet that had an eloquent New York premiere at Trinity Wall Street on Thursday evening, the word “eternity” was clearly audible when intoned by the sopranos at the start of the fourth movement. The syllables of the word were then sung with stately grace before resurfacing later in the section.

headline: Review: 2 Murderous Men in 2 Operas About Killing for Politics
abstract: From Salman Rushdie and Shakespeare, in Kashmir and Scotland, the Opera Theater of St. Louis focuses on men who kill.
lead_paragraph: St. LOUIS — Macbeth’s weapon of choice is a dagger: long, thin and apt for plunging into a sleeping man’s chest. Shalimar’s is a hunting knife that can gut a cafe guest in broad daylight and looks shockingly like those used in the Islamic State’s execution videos.

headline: Man Inadvertently Broadcasts His Own Killing on Facebook Live
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Social Media', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A 28-year-old man in Chicago who accidentally caught his own fatal shooting on video is the latest example of the “no gatekeeper” world of live streaming.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Jack Ruby killed Lee Harvey Oswald on live TV in 1963, broadcasters have worried about accidentally showing an act of violence on camera. With tools like Facebook Live and Periscope available to anyone with a smartphone, the chances of unexpectedly streaming a grisly moment have drastically increased.

headline: DSquared2: Spring 2017
abstract: The spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The spring 2017 collection.

headline: Think Less, Think Better
abstract: A wandering mind has less innovative thoughts.
lead_paragraph: A FRIEND of mine has a bad habit of narrating his experiences as they are taking place. I tease him for being a bystander in his own life. To be fair, we all fail to experience life to the fullest. Typically, our minds are too occupied with thoughts to allow complete immersion even in what is right in front of us.

headline: Review: ‘Clown’ — At Least Bozo Never Ate the Kids
abstract: This horror film, directed by Jon Watts, finds a man putting on a costume — yes, with a red nose — and becoming a possessed killer.
lead_paragraph: This glib and repellent exercise in “can you top this” genre opportunism has a 2013 copyright. Why its distributors, Dimension and Anchor Bay Entertainment, opted to release it on this weekend is anyone’s guess. It is hardly likely that an executive mused, “American culture isn’t quite degraded enough; might be a good idea to give it another whack.” Or is it?

headline: Where Cuba’s Gays Meet Up
abstract: With its night clubs, bars and other social venues, the hip Vedado neighborhood in Havana has become a hotspot for the country’s gay population.
lead_paragraph: With its night clubs, bars and other social venues, the hip Vedado neighborhood in Havana has become a hotspot for the country’s gay population.

headline: In Havana, Gay Bars Hold Their Own Against the Internet
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Limited access to the web means that most gay social life in Cuba takes place in bars and on the streets — not online.
lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Just before midnight on a recent Thursday here along the Malecón, the capital’s five-mile concrete sea wall boardwalk, Wilder Calderon Peña, 24, a bartender and Airbnb agent, was doing his thunder dance.

abstract: Ms. Soo’s performance as Eliza Hamilton is her Broadway debut. She was nominated for a Tony award for the role.
lead_paragraph: Phillipa Soo, currently starring in “Hamilton” on Broadway, will leave the show and take the title role in a musical adaptation of the film “Amélie.”

headline: At Memorial for Charleston Shooting, a Call for ‘Meaningful Action’ on Guns
abstract: A service held on the first anniversary of the deadly attack was marked by prayers, music and impassioned demands to curb unceasing gun violence.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — A year after nine members of a historic black church were killed here, politicians and pastors joined with congregations from around the region on Friday to mark the occasion with prayers, tambourines and clapping hands, but also with impassioned, almost desperate calls for action in the face of unceasing gun violence.

headline: A Ferryboat Named Roosevelt, and a Missing County
abstract: How the nation’s longest serving president was like a Staten Island Ferry, and why New York seems to snub dukes.
lead_paragraph: Q. I vaguely recall an old political story that compared Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Staten Island Ferry. Could you tell me how it goes?

headline: A Twist in the Zappa vs. Zappa Spat
keywords: ['Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: After one name change, Dweezil Zappa is rechristening his show again to avoid legal conflict with a brother who controls the family trust.
lead_paragraph: For Dweezil Zappa, one name change was not enough.

headline: Saturdays at Gotham’s Crash Pad
abstract: Sharing a feminist ethos, the roller derby girls of Bushwick are whipping it.
lead_paragraph: Sharing a feminist ethos, the roller derby girls of Bushwick are whipping it.

headline: Marco Rubio, Reversing Plans, Is Leaning Toward Running for Senate Again
abstract: Mr. Rubio has vowed that he would not seek re-election after six years in the Senate, but is reconsidering. With him on the ballot, Republicans have a greater chance of keeping the seat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida is leaning heavily toward running for re-election to the seat he swore he was giving up after six often frustrating years and a failed presidential run, associates said on Friday, a reversal that would upend one of the most competitive races in the country.

headline: Review: ‘ChimaTEK’ Offers Crystal Visions at a Transit Hub
abstract: Saya Woolfalk’s Fulton Center creation, combining dance, video, animation and sculpture, features floating crystals, if you have the right app to see them.
lead_paragraph: With all public art, the real test is making an audience out of those most elusive beings: passers-by. On Thursday night at the Fulton Center, the challenge was even greater — to delay the subway ride home. One transfixed man in the crowd was filming the scene when he received a call. “I’m going to hit the train in a minute,” he told the person on the other end, “but I’ve gotten caught up with some interpretive dance.”

headline: A Saudi Imam, 2 Hijackers and Lingering 9/11 Mystery
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: To some, a classified section of an inquiry into the terrorist attacks points to Saudi involvement, while the country’s foreign minister says, “There is no there there.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Inside an opulent palace in Riyadh late one evening in February 2004, two American investigators interrogated a man they believed might hold answers to one of the lingering mysteries of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks: What role, if any, did officials in Saudi Arabia’s government play in the plot?

headline: My Fill-In Father
abstract: It was love, and fear, at first sight. The man was engineered to elicit such a response.
lead_paragraph: FEW days on the calendar are more emotionally fraught for me, more psychologically stacked, than Father’s Day. A proud father, a proud grandfather, I’m also a grieving father, having lost my oldest son 12 years ago, and a grieving son, having lost my father in 1981.

headline: Friday Night Music: A Song for Brexit
abstract: In spite of all temptations.
lead_paragraph: But W.S. Gilbert was being ironic …

headline: A Nuclear Weapon That America Doesn’t Need
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: The Air Force’s development of a cruise missile called the Long-Range Standoff Weapon is costly and dangerous.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT OBAMA spoke last month in Hiroshima about charting a course to a future free of nuclear weapons. He discussed the “persistent effort” necessary to eliminate the threat of nuclear war.

headline: IEX Group, Critical of Wall St., Gains Approval for Stock Exchange
abstract: After a brutal lobbying battle, and months of delays, America is getting a new stock exchange from the most prominent high-profile critics of high-frequency trading.
lead_paragraph: America is getting a new stock exchange from the most prominent critics of high-frequency trading.

headline: State Department Draft Dissent Memo on Syria
abstract: In a draft version of a dissent memo filed with the State Department's senior leadership, dozens of diplomats and other mid-level officials called for military strikes against President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.
lead_paragraph: In a draft version of a dissent memo filed with the State Department's senior leadership, dozens of diplomats and other mid-level officials called for military strikes against President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

headline: John Kerry Is Said to Side With Diplomats’ Critical Memo on Syria
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Administration officials say the secretary of state has been urging President Obama to put pressure on the Assad government to abide by a cease-fire and agree to a transition of power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For a cabinet member whose department had just erupted into open disagreement with the White House, Secretary of State John Kerry’s reaction to a critical memo on Syria policy signed by 51 diplomats was remarkably mellow. “It’s an important statement,” he told reporters in Copenhagen on Friday, “and I respect the process very, very much.”

headline: $7 Million in Donations to Go Directly to Orlando Kin and Survivors
abstract: The money will bypass charities and nonprofit groups because survivors of the nightclub attack need help immediately, Mayor Buddy Dyer of Orlando said.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The city announced Friday that the $7 million it collected after the nightclub shooting would be given directly to family members and survivors instead of being distributed through charities and nonprofit groups.

headline: The Trump Disaster Chronicle
abstract: Nobody knows empathy like The Donald.
lead_paragraph: It’s natural to wonder how our next president would respond, on a human level, to a disaster like Orlando. The candidates have been pretty clear on policy, but how would he/she relate to a community, and country, in pain?

headline: Palestinians Enter Talks With Egypt to Stake Mediterranean Claims
abstract: A Palestinian envoy said the negotiations were possible because of the Palestinian territories’ United Nations status as a nonmember observer state.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The Middle East peace process is stalemated in part because of disagreement over the appropriate land borders for Israel and a future state of Palestine. Now the Palestinians are taking the first steps toward establishing what their state would claim at sea.

headline: Historians, Police and Others Argue What Makes Orlando Massacre ‘Worst’
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Some have protested that describing the attack as the worst mass shooting in United States history ignores other acts of violence that may have claimed more lives.
lead_paragraph: Is the massacre in Orlando the worst mass shooting in United States history? News organizations and government officials have said so since Sunday, when a gunman killed 49 people and wounded 53 others at a gay nightclub there.

headline: Visium to Sell and Liquidate Funds After Insider Trading Charges
abstract: The unexpected announcement came two days after federal authorities filed criminal and civil charges against the hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: Visium Asset Management, a multibillion-dollar hedge fund that is the focus of an insider trading case, will wind itself down.

headline: Gunman’s Employer Dealt Another in a Series of Black Eyes
abstract: The past few years have not gone smoothly for G4S, the giant security firm based in Britain that employed the Orlando nightclub killer, Omar Mateen.
lead_paragraph: The past few years have not gone smoothly for G4S, the giant security firm based in Britain that employed the Orlando nightclub killer, Omar Mateen.

headline: Five Choices in New York Congressional Primaries
abstract: Recommendations in races, three for open seats, that could make a difference locally and even nationally.
lead_paragraph: Heads up, New York, there’s an election coming up. Congressional primaries are on June 28. Here are recommendations in five races — three of them for open seats — that could make a difference locally and even nationally.

headline: A Thud of Retribution Reverberates in Russia
abstract: Olympic politics are inseparable from national and global politics, and President Vladimir Putin has embraced sporting dominance as a symbol of Russia’s global power.
lead_paragraph: So the bear will be left to wander the athletic wilderness this August.

headline: Monuments for Future Generations
abstract: While Congress is unlikely to approve any additions to the national park system, there is much that President Obama can do on his own.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s visits this weekend to Carlsbad Caverns and Yosemite national parks give him a timely opportunity to think about how, in the twilight of his presidency, he can add to what has already been an admirable record of protecting America’s public lands and marine reserves. The parks themselves are in a celebratory moment, the 100th anniversary of the founding of the National Park Service. But given Congress’s preference for partisan infighting over environmental stewardship, it is unlikely to approve any additions to the park system. Still, there is much that Mr. Obama can do on his own using the 1906 Antiquities Act, which allows a president to unilaterally protect areas of great natural or historical value as monuments when Congress is unlikely to act.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, June 18, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “When you present politics as a matter of life and death, as a question of national survival, don’t be surprised if someone takes you at your word.”

headline: At U.S. Open, an Upstart-Friendly Course Favors Wisdom, for Now, Over Youth
abstract: In the first round of the 116th United States Open, which took two days to complete, Oakmont smiled on the field’s elders and spanked some young stars.
lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — For an old, cantankerous blue blood of a course, Oakmont Country Club has shown a surprising tolerance of youth. It has accommodated a 22-year-old Jack Nicklaus’s coronation at the 1962 United States Open at the expense of the older, more popular Arnold Palmer; a 26-year-old Johnny Miller’s crowning in 1973; and a 24-year-old Ernie Els’s major title baptism in 1994.

headline: Thomas Mair, Suspected in the Jo Cox Killing, Is Charged With Murder
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Referendums', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The shooting and stabbing death of Ms. Cox, a member of Parliament, has stunned Britain ahead of a vote on whether to stay in the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BIRSTALL, England — The police in Britain on Saturday charged a 52-year-old man with murdering Jo Cox, the lawmaker whose death shocked Britons and led to a suspension of campaigning in a referendum on whether Britain should leave the European Union.

headline: New York’s Voice at the M.T.A. Gets Louder, as 2 Mayoral Board Picks Are Confirmed
abstract: Over the past year, Mayor Bill de Blasio has had just one representative at the transit agency. Two more were approved by the State Senate.
lead_paragraph: The State Senate has confirmed two people recommended by Mayor Bill de Blasio to serve on the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board, strengthening New York City’s voice at the state-run agency that oversees subways and buses.

headline: An Unwelcome Tourist Arrives in New Jersey: Clinging Jellyfish
abstract: Without invitation or a clear explanation, this small-but-mighty variety of jellyfish has been found for the first time in the Garden State.
lead_paragraph: When Paul A. X. Bologna heard that a local fisherman had brought a dime-size jellyfish to a New Jersey aquarium, he had a hunch that it might be a Gonionemus vertens, or clinging jellyfish.

headline: C.C. Sabathia May Be Friends With LeBron James, but His Heart Remains in the Golden State
abstract: Sabathia, the owner of a miserly 0.86 E.R.A since May 4, was pulling for the Warriors on Thursday even as he delivered another sterling performance.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — C. C. Sabathia was surprisingly upbeat Friday. His beloved Golden State Warriors had lost to the Cleveland Cavaliers in the N.B.A. finals on Thursday night, but that could not tarnish his sense of accomplishment in having thrown six demanding innings to beat the Minnesota Twins, 4-1.

headline: Knock on Wood
abstract: A spotty puzzle from Todd Gross.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial PDF Alert! Due to reasons, the Sunday, June 19 puzzle will look different depending on where you are solving. We recommend using the PDF, or alternatively the web game, for solving this puzzle, as it contains elements that other formats cannot reproduce. [NECESSARY SPOILER ALERT] Specifically, six squares which normally would be black instead each have their four edges colored, alternating between green and red. These colored squares occur at the intersections of 31A/11D, 34A/5D, 46A/26D, 62A/45D, 92A/67D and 98A/75D.

headline: Dominic Thiem, the Hardest-Working Man in Tennis
abstract: Thiem has labored through an unrelenting churn of matches at smaller tournaments, far surpassing the workload of any other man in the top 50.
lead_paragraph: HALLE, Germany — As Dominic Thiem has cemented his place this year as a rising star of men’s tennis, his quality has been matched with quantity.

headline: A Height Rory McIlroy Hopes to Never Reach Again
abstract: McIlroy shot a first-round 77 at the United States Open, the same score he had to open the tournament in 2012, when he missed the cut.
lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — Third-ranked Rory McIlroy, the 2011 United States Open champion, equaled his worst start in eight appearances in the event with a seven-over-par 77.

headline: More Guilty Pleas in Fraud Scheme Connected to False 9/11 Claims
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Disability Insurance', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: More than 130 people used fake health claims to collect disability payments, prosecutors said. Many claimed mental illness caused by 9/11.
lead_paragraph: The photo was featured on the cover of New York City’s tabloids: a man in shorts and sunglasses sitting on a water scooter, a smile on his face, middle fingers extended to the sky.

headline: Matt Harvey and the Mets Take a Step Back
abstract: Harvey had shown improvement over the past two weeks, but he regressed in Friday’s loss to the Braves.
lead_paragraph: Two and half months into the season and Matt Harvey remains an enigma. His improvement over past two weeks offered a glimmer of hope that he had solved the problems behind his wretched start. But Friday, in a 5-1 loss to the Atlanta Braves, Harvey lapsed.

headline: Colombia Slumps to Victory Over Peru in Copa América Quarterfinal
abstract: A scoreless game full of flops and frustrated chances ended with Colombia’s outshooting Peru in the penalty kick phase.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It is, traditionally, one of the weirder features of the Copa América: There is no extra time in case of a 90-minute draw, in the quarterfinal and semifinal knockout rounds. Teams skip the 30-minute overtime and go directly to penalty kicks, unless a tie occurs in the tournament’s final.

headline: Robert Paine, Ecologist Who Found ‘Keystone Species,’ Dies at 83
abstract: Dr. Paine identified certain species, like sea otters and starfish, that if removed, could disproportionately affect their ecosystems and neighboring species.
lead_paragraph: Robert Paine, a groundbreaking, hands-on ecologist who found that removing what he called a “keystone species” from an environment could profoundly affect the fortunes of neighboring species, died on Monday in Seattle. He was 83.

headline: Young New York Muslims, Robbed of a Respite
abstract: The massacre in Orlando, Fla., has intruded on the Ramadan traditions of the city’s high school students, who value the holiday as a refuge in their typical teenage lives.
lead_paragraph: The massacre in Orlando, Fla., has intruded on the Ramadan traditions of the city’s high school students, who value the holiday as a refuge in their typical teenage lives.

headline: Orlando Killings Rob Young New York Muslims of a Cherished Holiday Respite
abstract: For Muslim high school students, it has been a Ramadan of contrasts and conflicting emotions. The joy of breaking the fast. The drudgery of exams. And the frustration of defending their faith yet again.
lead_paragraph: For Muhammad Hannan and other Muslim high school students in New York City, this has been a Ramadan of contrasts and conflicting emotions.

headline: Pleading Poverty, Rio Governor Seeks Aid for Olympics

headline: What’s on TV Saturday

lead_paragraph: In “Whiskey Tango Foxtrot,” Tina Fey transports her nerdy workaholic screen persona to the war in Afghanistan. In “Sleeping With Other People,” Jason Sudeikis and Alison Brie play sexaholics trying to keep it in the friend zone. And if you don’t want to brave the lines for “Finding Dory,” watch “Finding Nemo” instead.

headline: Rested Pitcher Guides Yankees Past Twins for Second Straight Win
abstract: The Yankees’ bats provided ample run support, but their starting pitcher Masahiro Tanaka didn’t need it as the last-place Twins failed to muster much offense.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The Minnesota Twins left-hander Pat Dean grew up a Yankees fan in Naugatuck, Conn., the same hometown as 1940s Yankees star Francis Shea, known as Spec. Dean had eagerly anticipated his first career appearance against the Yankees on Friday night at Target Field.

abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has not yet indicated that he will sign the bill, which would classify fantasy sports as games of skill, not chance.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Months after being halted by the New York attorney general, daily fantasy sports won a major victory early Saturday as state lawmakers moved to legalize the online games.

headline: A Letter About Barack H. Obama Sr.'s Record in College
abstract: Barack Obama Sr. had hoped to graduate from Harvard University with a Ph.D. in economics, but he struggled there academically in his first year. He graduated with a master’s degree. The 1963 letter is one of many documents discovered by an archivist at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem.

abstract: Police raids interrupted a plot against fans gathering in Brussels to watch a telecast of a match between the Belgian national team and Ireland, officials said.

headline: China’s Last Wild River Carries Conflicting Environmental Hopes
keywords: ['Hydroelectric Power', 'Levees and Dams', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Coal', 'Environment']
abstract: With global temperatures rising, can a nation afford to protect a pristine waterway and forgo the building of dams as an alternative to burning coal?
lead_paragraph: QIUNATONG, China — Three great rivers rush through parallel canyons in the mountains of southwest China on their way to the coastal plains of Asia. At least 10 dams have been built on two of them, the Mekong and the Yangtze. The third remains wild: the remote, raging Nu, known as the Salween in Myanmar, where it empties into the Andaman Sea.

headline: Raghuram Rajan Says He’ll Step Down as Head of India’s Central Bank
abstract: Mr. Rajan, who as governor of the Reserve Bank of India has been popular with investors but faced opposition from India’s ruling party, said he would leave when his term ends in the fall.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The governor of India’s central bank, Raghuram G. Rajan, announced on Saturday that he would step down in September and return to academia, ending a three-year tenure that enhanced India’s standing in international markets but frustrated conservatives and small business owners eager for deep interest rate cuts.

headline: 50 Years Later, Still Working for the Airline
abstract: Peter Ho started at Cathay Pacific Airways as a traffic officer. Almost 50 years later, he is now a regional catering manager.
lead_paragraph: Peter Ho, 69, is the Vancouver-based regional catering manager for North America at Cathay Pacific Airways.

lead_paragraph: As you read this episode, dear readers, keep in mind: The Haggler does not set out to annoy anyone. He does not hope that people will shout at him. Honest.

headline: Remote? That’s No Way to Describe This Work
abstract: Those who “work in place,” where a central office is distant or doesn’t even exist, are growing in number and don’t fit existing molds.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2007, during a weekly check-in, my wife’s manager delivered some unexpected good news: “You don’t have to be in the office to do this job,” she said. “You could work from wherever you want.” A fast six months later, we left hot, crowded Austin, Tex., and moved into an apartment on Munjoy Hill in Portland, Me., with a commanding view of Casco Bay only steps away.

headline: A Question For the Fed
abstract: Why, exactly, should rates rise?
lead_paragraph: There is a near-consensus at the FOMC that rates must eventually move up. But here’s my question: why, exactly? Specifically, which component of aggregate demand do we believe will continue to strengthen in a way that will require monetary tightening to avoid an overheating economy?

headline: ‘Always Agitated. Always Mad’: Omar Mateen, According to Those Who Knew Him
abstract: The recollections of those who knew Omar Mateen or encountered him conjure a man forever aggrieved; forever not at peace; forever out of step.

But soon enough he was mingling at the lakeside pavilion in West Palm Beach, where a diverse gathering of guests dined on chicken tikka masala and goat biryani while admiring the view of the Intracoastal Waterway just beyond the floor-to-ceiling windows.

lead_paragraph: In an address after the Orlando massacre punctuated with dire warnings of impending violence, Donald J. Trump said he would “suspend immigration from areas of the world when there is a proven history of terrorism” against the United States or its allies. Mr. Trump promised fixes to the immigration system that would be “tough” and “smart” and “fast.”

headline: With Swat of Stephen Curry, LeBron James Jolted a Debate
abstract: James’s block of Curry’s shot late in Game 6 was an exclamation point to the convincing argument that James had already made about who remains the N.B.A.’s premier impact player.
lead_paragraph: Size still matters when it comes packaged in an unmatched amalgam of skill, strength, speed and smarts while garnished with the hustle of a fringe veteran treating every last play as if his next paycheck depended on it.

headline: A Glimpse of Omar Mateen's Past, From School Reports to Job Dismissal
abstract: As investigators comb through Omar Mateen’s past to glean an understanding of the young man whose attack on an Orlando nightclub left 49 dead and 53 wounded, a portrait of a complicated childhood and young adulthood is emerging. These documents offer a glimpse into Mr. Mateen’s life.

headline: Michelle Cliff, Who Wrote of Colonialism and Racism, Dies at 69
abstract: Ms. Cliff, the partner of the poet Adrienne Rich, who died in 2012, devoted herself to giving voice to suppressed histories, starting with her own.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Cliff, a Jamaican-American writer whose novels, stories and nonfiction essays drew on her multicultural identity to probe the psychic disruptions and historical distortions wrought by colonialism and racism, died on June 12 at her home in Santa Cruz, Calif. She was 69.

headline: Desmond Heeley, an ‘Alchemist’ of Theater Design, Dies at 85
abstract: At home in theater, opera and ballet, Mr. Heeley created costumes for the likes of Laurence Olivier, Beverly Sills and Margot Fonteyn and imaginative sets for productions throughout the world.
lead_paragraph: Desmond Heeley, a celebrated designer for the theater, the opera and the ballet, whose costumes dressed the likes of Laurence Olivier, Beverly Sills and Margot Fonteyn, and whose sets were used in major productions throughout the world, died on June 10 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Lois Duncan, 82, Dies; Author Knew ‘What You Did Last Summer’
abstract: Though her books had their share of violence, Ms. Duncan said she was “utterly horrified” when she saw the film adaptation of “I Know What You Did Last Summer.”
lead_paragraph: Lois Duncan, whose suspenseful young adult novels inspired the slasher movie “I Know What You Did Last Summer” and who later wrote about the unsolved murder of her daughter, died on Wednesday at her home in Bradenton, Fla. She was 82.

headline: Regardless of ‘Brexit’ Vote, Experts Say, E.U. Must Rethink Status Quo
keywords: ['Referendums', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Tribulations for the euro, a debt standoff with Greece and a flawed approach to migration all inflamed the angry nationalism spreading across the Continent and Britain.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Among the well-heeled bureaucrats of the European Union, it is an article of faith that the bloc always emerges stronger from a crisis. The idealistic founders who six decades ago dreamed of stitching warring nations into a peaceful whole knew the path would be bumpy. But always, the union wobbled forward.

headline: A Touchy-Feely Approach From Hillary Clinton
abstract: In her first ad of the general campaign, Mrs. Clinton highlights lesser-known aspects of her work on behalf of families and children.
lead_paragraph: Just days after the massacre at a gay nightclub in Orlando, and after a long primary campaign in which Republican candidates often seemed preoccupied with war, terrorism and related fears, Hillary Clinton’s first ad of the general election strikes a gentler and more reassuring tone. It seeks to reintroduce her to voters, ostensibly by highlighting lesser-known aspects of her work on behalf of families and children.

headline: Russia’s Track Team Will Miss the Olympics. American Audiences? Not Likely.
abstract: The absence of the Russian track and field team is unlikely to hurt NBC’s prime-time ratings for several reasons, among them the likelihood that the removal of a major rival might help the United States win more medals.
lead_paragraph: Russia, a perpetual powerhouse at the Olympics, sent more than 400 athletes to the last Summer Games, in London in 2012. At the opening ceremony in Rio de Janeiro in seven weeks, the country’s delegation may appear relatively meager during the parade of nations in Maracanã Stadium.

headline: David Wright, the Forever Met, Recedes Into the Background Again
abstract: Four years after signing the largest contract in franchise history, Wright is indefinitely sidelined after surgery for a herniated disk.
lead_paragraph: Already, it is easy to think of David Wright in the past tense. His lockers at Citi Field, with helmets of the Giants and Virginia Tech hanging from hooks in the corner, remain intact. Packages and notes pile up on his chair. Wright is a presence around the Mets, but a ghostly one. Again.

headline: ‘I’m Sorry, No More Ducks’
abstract: We rejoice at the miracles of our child’s earliest years, but then there is the sadness that they will never happen again.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks before she turned 2 last month, my daughter decided she would not be going to bed on her own anymore.

headline: Bradford Parkinson
abstract: The father of GPS on mountain climbers, classical music and following Johnny Appleseed’s lead.
lead_paragraph: Bradford Parkinson is an engineer, inventor and retired Air Force colonel widely recognized as the father of the Global Positioning System, or GPS, now critical for navigation, whether it’s in the skies, the high seas or just traveling down the highway.

headline: A Kiddie Party for Us All, Even Me
abstract: Don’t make me try those organic cheese doodles.
lead_paragraph: I KNOW you’re under a lot of pressure with your toddler’s birthday party only a week away. I get it. I’d be just as stressed if I were tasked with baking a vegan Caillou-shaped cake. And I really hate to pile on. But, I — the one single, childless friend you’ve invited — do have some special requests for the birthday party I’m hoping you can accommodate. To make this simple, I’ve created a handy list for your reference to ensure you’re planning an event I can enjoy. Or at least, almost enjoy.

headline: I’m Ghanaian-American. Am I Black?
abstract: Growing up the daughter of immigrants, I considered myself different from “black Americans.” I learned that I wasn’t.
lead_paragraph: THE first time I was ever called a nigger was also the first time I was not called a nigger.

lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
