keywords: ['Parenting', 'Paid Time Off', 'Working Hours', "Women's Rights", 'Women and Girls', 'Child Care']
abstract: For women, balancing child-rearing and work outside the home may be more challenging than ever.
lead_paragraph: Balancing child-rearing and work outside the home may be more challenging than ever.

headline: A Real War Story, in Drawings
abstract: A Lakota warrior’s drawings tell us much about not only Custer’s Last Stand, but also the eternal brutality of war.
lead_paragraph: JUNE 25 marks the 140th anniversary of the Battle of the Little Bighorn, otherwise known as Custer’s Last Stand, part of the 1876 counterinsurgency campaign we call the Great Sioux War. Given that the United States today is engaged in two deadly counterinsurgency wars, fighting the Taliban in Afghanistan and the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, it is useful to study this history for what it can tell us about an adversary and ourselves. Examining the stunning drawings made in 1881 by Red Horse, a Mnicoujou warrior who fought at the Little Bighorn, provides timeless lessons about war.

headline: Why I Was Wrong About Welfare Reform
abstract: A well-intentioned change has made a problem worse.
lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — IN 1996, President Bill Clinton signed a controversial compromise bill for welfare reform, promising to “end welfare as we know it.”

headline: Donald Trump’s Place
abstract: A year into his campaign, it’s still not clear exactly where he’s coming from or where he’s going.
lead_paragraph: SO now we know.

headline: Mr. Ryan’s Plan to Revert, Regress and Deregulate
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The speaker’s plan would let businesses that have hurt Americans in the past resume their discredited ways.
lead_paragraph: House Speaker Paul Ryan presented his economic agenda last week, but it does not deal with the country’s problems with jobs, wages, investment, trade, inequality or other pressing economic issues. Rather, its 57 pages boil down to one idea: Roll back hundreds of federal regulations that protect consumers, investors, employees, borrowers, students and the environment.

headline: Heading Off the Next Extremist
abstract: How does a democratic society prevent domestic attacks by those who have absorbed the call of terrorist groups to kill innocent civilians?
lead_paragraph: Though the motives of Omar Mateen may never fully be known, the massacre he committed in Orlando has raised an urgent question. How does a democratic society counter self-radicalization and prevent domestic attacks by those who have absorbed the call of terrorist groups to kill innocent civilians?

headline: Trump in the Dumps
abstract: If 70 percent of Americans don’t like you, is it too late to pivot?
lead_paragraph: Washington — HE won’t pivot. So I have to.

headline: Two Dads, Two Kids, One Experiment in Family
keywords: ['Parenting', "Father's Day", 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Our household adheres to one ideal of family even as we challenge some people’s preconceptions.
lead_paragraph: HERE’S what I’m going to do on Father’s Day, with my kids who are 6 and 3. The younger one will wake at 5:52 (he can never manage the eight minutes that would make all the difference) and rouse his brother, one bunk up. My husband will take them downstairs so I can sleep, but really I’ll lie in bed and look at my phone until the need for coffee overwhelms me. My husband will make pancakes if he’s feeling ambitious and bowls of cereal if he’s not. Special enough, if not a special occasion; this is every Sunday in our house.

headline: The Republicans’ Big Hot Mess
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: It’s not just Donald Trump. It’s the utterly unimaginable convention he’ll gin up.
lead_paragraph: IN normal times, a party’s leaders and comers grovel for roles in the convention and prime time on its stage.

headline: Bribery and Corruption, or ‘Honest Graft’?
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Gifts to Public Officials', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: A case before the Supreme Court could determine if Sheldon Silver and Dean Skelos go to jail.
lead_paragraph: IN a tradition dating to the 1600s, the departing municipal officials of High Wycombe in England are weighed each May to assess whether they have literally gained off the fat of the land, perhaps at public expense. If not, a macebearer cues their constituents to cheer by proclaiming, “And no more.” In the 1800s, Thomas Nast caricatured the typically portly Boss Tweed as disingenuously protesting he was “too thin” to have pocketed kickbacks from New York City contractors.

headline: Has Political Fear-Mongering Lost Its Appeal?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Fear (Emotion)', 'Terrorism', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Since 9/11, fear-mongering has been a foolproof political tactic. After Orlando, it’s unclear whether it still works.
lead_paragraph: THIS was an important and even revelatory week in American politics, and we should take note of it. Contrary to what I’d argue has been the single most firmly held conviction about this campaign by observers left and right, a terrorist attack did not help the Republican candidate in the race for president. Indeed, it seems to have weakened him.

headline: Drinking by Numbers
abstract: I can easily make out the slippery slope where two glasses of wine a day becomes three, where mayhem begins.
lead_paragraph: Berkeley, Calif. — AT a recent physical, I was surprised by the way the usual questionnaire jolted me with one query in particular: How many drinks do you have a week, on average? There was a time about 10 years ago when I’d have said two a week as a baseline; now it’s more like two a day.

headline: Neil Barrett: Spring 2017
abstract: Mr. Barrett’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Barrett’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: Olympic Officials Back Ban on Russian Track Team From Rio Games
abstract: The decision by the International Olympic Committee effectively ended any hopes that the team, accused of widespread doping, can participate in the Games this summer.
lead_paragraph: One day after an unprecedented ruling that barred Russia’s track and field team from the Summer Olympics, Olympic officials said Saturday that they agreed with it, ending any hope the team had of gaining entry into the Rio Games.

headline: A Common Goal at the Top of the Leaderboard: Winning a First Major
abstract: The six golfers who were leading the U.S. Open field at the end of play on Saturday were being chased by Jason Day, the world No. 1.
lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — It is a compliment that stings, the golf equivalent of being known for a winning personality. Over the last decade, Dustin Johnson, Sergio García and Lee Westwood have taken turns wearing the “best golfer never to have won a major” label.

abstract: The shootings in Orlando cast a shadow over the campaign this week and candidates attacked their rivals’ gun and immigration policies.

headline: Shaken by Sex Scandal, Oakland Police to Get New Leader, Again
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Text Messaging', 'Sex Crimes', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Oakland’s city administrator will oversee the police department, which has been in turmoil following a widening sex scandal and an investigation into racist text messages.
lead_paragraph: For the fourth time in less than two weeks, the police department in Oakland, Calif., is answering to a different leader.

headline: For Many Golfers, Fathers Serve as the Caddies of Life
keywords: ['Golf', 'Parenting', 'United States Open (Golf)', "Father's Day", 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: The United States Open, which concludes on Father’s Day, is a convenient time for players to recall how they are shaped by their fathers and their own children.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Wilkes-Krier was warming up on Thursday morning for his United States Open debut next to the defending champion, Jordan Spieth. Suddenly he stopped, leaned his club against his golf bag and, with a few loping strides, appeared at the side of his father, James Krier, who had been wordlessly watching him. Krier nuzzled his father’s neck and gave him a kiss. After a long embrace, he pulled away, retraced his steps and resumed hitting balls.

headline: A War of Brothers in Iraq: ‘I Will Kill Him With My Own Hands’
abstract: For Iraqi Sunnis, the struggle to retake Falluja from the Islamic State underscores the personal nature of war: a conflict of sons and brothers, nephews and neighbors.
lead_paragraph: FALLUJA, Iraq — In the days leading up to the storming of Falluja by Iraqi forces, Brig. Gen. Hadi Razaij, the leading Sunni police commander in the campaign, sat on a cot in an abandoned house near the front line. He described the resistance that lay ahead: a determined force of hundreds of jihadists that had months to prepare.

headline: Chelsea Clinton Gives Birth to a Boy, Aidan
abstract: Hillary Clinton, who often talks about being a grandmother on the campaign trail, now has twice the reason for doing so.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton, who often talks on the campaign trail about being a grandmother, now has twice the reason for doing so as her daughter Chelsea Clinton has given birth to her second child.

headline: Karch Kiraly Now Setting Up U.S. Women’s Volleyball Team to Succeed
abstract: Kiraly, named the best volleyball player of the 20th century by the sport’s international governing body, got his start in coaching only about 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — It was an unusually warm afternoon in Southern California and an unusual time to get the chills. But the tanned arms and legs of Karch Kiraly — the famous volleyball player, now 55, coaching the United States women’s national indoor team in search of its first-ever Olympic gold medal — were covered in goose bumps.

headline: U.S. Carriers Sail in Western Pacific, Hoping China Takes Notice
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Aircraft Carriers']
abstract: Ships carried out exercises in the Philippine Sea as a show of strength before an international court’s ruling on China’s claims in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a show of strength before an international court’s ruling on China’s claims in the South China Sea, the United States Navy sent two aircraft carriers and their accompanying ships on training drills in the western Pacific Ocean on Saturday.

lead_paragraph: Mike Emrick’s connection to hockey is so strong — and his play-by-play so vivid — that it may be surprising that he has such a strong love for baseball.

lead_paragraph: A joint photography project, and conversations over breakfast, rekindle a relationship severed two decades ago.

lead_paragraph: The Kansas City Royals return to Citi Field on Tuesday, facing the Mets in a two-game series at the site of their triumph last fall. The Royals won the World Series in Flushing last Nov. 1 in a 12-inning thriller that Whit Merrifield watched from home in Winston-Salem, N.C.

abstract: The team has been able to rely on a deep bench, but that hasn’t been the case in the last two games.
lead_paragraph: It has become a fad among teams to adopt a catchphrase to sum up their approach (while also helping sell T-shirts). As with most things, not all are created equal.

headline: Daniel Suarez, a Mexican Driver, Sets New Course for Nascar
abstract: He has 11 top-10 finishes in the Xfinity Series this season, including the first national series win for a Mexican-born driver.
lead_paragraph: Besides learning how to race a stock car in much faster traffic, Daniel Suarez was confronted with another considerable challenge — the English language — after moving to the United States from Mexico in 2012. So he watched movies with subtitles, plus lots of cartoons.

headline: Mets Are Hitting the Ball Far, but Not Often Enough
abstract: Exactly 53 percent of the Mets’ runs this season have come from home runs, according to the Elias Sports Bureau, an inconsistent offense that has feast-or-famine tendencies.
lead_paragraph: As the Mets meander through June and weigh their options for improvement, their offense remains an issue. The Mets have produced the second-fewest hits in the major leagues and sit third-to-last in runs per game, not enough to support their talented pitching staff. But in one telling offensive category, the Mets were the best in baseball entering Saturday.

headline: Yankees Climb Back to .500 With Win Over Twins
abstract: The Yankees scored all their runs in the final three innings to win their third game in a row.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Since the start of 2014, the Minnesota Twins right-hander Ricky Nolasco had a 5.49 E.R.A., the highest mark of any starting pitcher in the major leagues with 250 or more innings. That Nolasco held the Yankees scoreless for six innings on a steamy Saturday afternoon counted as a significant surprise.

headline: Pulse D.J.s Recall How Joyful Beats Gave Way to Massacre Gunfire
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Disc Jockeys', 'Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Hate Crimes', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The disc jockeys at Pulse recall the moment when their Orlando club became a scene of unforgettable carnage.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Hundreds of partyers were bringing their best to the dance floor as the reggaeton beats emanated from the D.J. booth to the main floor at Pulse, where the revelers swayed to the music, which has roots in Jamaican dance hall, Trinidadian soca and Panamanian Spanish reggae.

headline: Traffic Intersections
abstract: Driving around with David Woolf.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial PDF Alert! Due to reasons, today’s puzzle will look different depending on where you are solving. We recommend using the PDF or alternatively the web game for solving this puzzle, as it contains elements that other formats cannot reproduce. [NECESSARY SPOILER ALERT!] Specifically, six squares that normally would be black instead have their four edges colored, alternating between green and red. These colored squares occur at the intersections of 31A/11D, 34A/5D, 46A/26D, 62A/45D, 92A/67D and 98A/75D.

headline: Dancing With Defiance in Orlando, but Gay Clubs and Bars Feel ‘Eerie’
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Hate Crimes', 'Terrorism']
abstract: On Friday night, clubgoers did not come in their usual numbers and many of those who did turned out with a newfound wariness.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — They came for the flashing neon lights, hip-swiveling tunes, cocktails and glitzy drag queens. Some arrived with a sense of purpose and defiance, to show that everything is going to be all right, to remember the loved ones they lost. Others just wanted to move on.

headline: De Blasio Keeps Control of City’s Schools, but Only for a Year

lead_paragraph: For the New York City schools and their governance structure, annual cliffhangers seem to be here to stay.

headline: Lives Still in Limbo, One Year After Southeast Asia Migrant Crisis
abstract: While most of the migrants from Myanmar and Bangladesh have been sent home or smuggled elsewhere, many still languish in refugee camps and detention centers.
lead_paragraph: BAYEUN, Indonesia — When Mohammed Salim washed ashore on the coast of Aceh Province in Indonesia during the Southeast Asian refugee crisis last year, he was hungry, thirsty, emaciated and exhausted.

abstract: Federer said he was “fairly satisfied” with his play soon before Wimbledon, which included a semifinal loss Saturday at the Gerry Weber Open in Halle, Germany.
lead_paragraph: HALLE, Germany — On paper, it was Roger Federer’s least auspicious Wimbledon preparation in years. But on his path to recovery from an injury-plagued start to the season, his semifinal losses at two grass-court events in Germany were marked progress.

abstract: A steady stream of unclaimed opportunities made a 0-0 draw against Austria an exercise in frustration for Portugal’s Cristiano Ronaldo.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Many different words have been used to describe Cristiano Ronaldo’s face.

headline: As Warriors Prepare for Game 7 Pressure, LeBron James Says He Doesn’t Feel Any
abstract: Needing to make history to bring the first championship to his team and his city? James calls that “an opportunity to do something special.”
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Steve Kerr, the coach of the Golden State Warriors, told his players that they ought to feel pressure.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, June 19, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “If I catch him during the battles, I will kill him with my own hands because he is a criminal.”

headline: Grégory Bourdy’s Bogeys Are Par for France
abstract: The Frenchman’s late struggles at Oakmont on Saturday were the latest chapter of the country’s 109-year frustration in major golf championships.
lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — Grégory Bourdy, the 34-year-old Frenchman who briefly held the lead at the 116th United States Open on Saturday and also threatened to shoot a record-tying 63, knows his homeland’s golf history.

keywords: ['Social Security (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Democrats’ proposals would amount to the biggest changes in Social Security since 1983, when the program faced a financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, Hillary Clinton and other Democrats are rallying around proposals to expand Social Security and increase benefits, a sea change after three decades dominated by concern over the program’s rising costs.

headline: Leaks of Answers Before Egypt’s National Exams Embarrass Government
abstract: One test was canceled, and the Education Ministry, along with the police and military officers who guard the exams, faced a wave of criticism.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As Egyptian high school students take their final exams this month, the government is facing a wave of criticism and mockery after copies of at least two test papers — and their answers — were leaked on Facebook.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 2, Episode 11: Off With His Head
abstract: Mary and Claire get revenge for their attacks, but the show doesn’t fully wrestle with what this means for either of them going forward.
lead_paragraph: At one point during this week’s episode of “Outlander,” one of Prince Charles’s not quite loyal generals says, “the truth is often vexing.” It’s a line that neatly encapsulates the nature of this season, much of which has been about the way lying shapes the course of one’s life.

headline: Bronx Teenager Is Stabbed to Death Over $2
abstract: Carl Ducasse and a friend had gone out for a milkshake when they were confronted by two men asking for money, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Carl Ducasse’s family in the Bronx had been planning something big to mark two approaching milestones: his graduation from high school this month, and his 18th birthday in August.

headline: U.S. Tells Russia of ‘Strong Concerns’ About Strikes on Syrian Rebels
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Videophones and Videoconferencing']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior American and Russian defense officials held what the Pentagon described as an “extraordinary” videoconference on Saturday to discuss Russian airstrikes that days earlier hit a garrison manned by Syrian rebels backed by the United States.

abstract: Philippe Martinez, whose views were shaped by longtime ties to the Communist Party, has refused to back down in his union’s fight against a proposed labor law.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — All up and down the boulevard, store windows were smashed — at a Starbucks, a supermarket, a handbag store. Young men clambered on top of bus shelters. Even a children’s hospital was attacked. The police brought out tear gas and a rarely used water cannon.

headline: Unseen Violation Prompts a Striking Act From Shane Lowry

lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — Shane Lowry placed the putter behind his golf ball on the 16th green Saturday to line up a long birdie putt. He then saw the ball move ever so slightly backward. No one else saw the ball change positions.

headline: Phoenix Focuses on Rebuilding Downtown, Wooing Silicon Valley

headline: 1916: President Orders Troops to Mexican Border

In reply to General Carranza’s insolent and imperative demand – which was accompanied by the threat that if the United States failed to comply within seven days war would be declared — President Wilson has issued a call for the mobilization of the National Guard of all the States of the Union, about 150,000 men, for service on the Mexican frontier.

headline: 1891: Searing Heat in New York
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Searing heat in New York in 1891.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The heat for the past few days has been phenomenal even for New York. Yesterday afternoon [June 16] the thermometer stood at 99deg. in the shade, and with much humidity in the atmosphere it seemed almost impossible to live. Several deaths occurred, and a large number of persons were prostrated. Today the thermometer has been close on 100deg., and the atmosphere was still very humid, despite a thunderstorm which occurred last night, when great damage was done in various parts of the State by lightning.

Rival measures from Republicans and Democrats to be taken up on Monday seek to address the so-called “terror gap” allowing people on terrorist watch lists to buy firearms, and to expand background checks for purchases at gun shows and online. Separately, President Obama wants to ban the sale of semiautomatic “assault” weapons similar to those used in recent attacks, but that issue is not on the Senate’s agenda.

abstract: The pianist alternated the fifth and ninth piano sonatas with Prokofiev’s popular two violin sonatas on Saturday at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: At a certain point in a complete musical traversal — of all Shostakovich’s string quartets, say, or all nine Beethoven symphonies — you inevitably reach the less popular works. On Saturday, in the final concert of a season-long survey of the nine Prokofiev piano sonatas at Zankel Hall, Yefim Bronfman got to the often overlooked fifth and ninth.

headline: Review: ‘I’ll Say She Is’ Revives a Marx Brothers Revue
abstract: Noah Diamond delivers a precise revival of Groucho and Company’s first assault on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Some impersonations don’t need to be very precise. What comedian doesn’t have a lazy Mae West or Arnold Schwarzenegger in the kit bag that’s good for a quick, cheap laugh? But if you’re going to presume to resurrect the Marx Brothers in a full-length stage musical, your Groucho, Harpo, Chico and Zeppo had better be spot on.

headline: 3 Leaders at the Metropolitan Museum of Art Step Down
abstract: The museum’s first chief digital officer, Sree Sreenivasan, is among the high-ranking employees who departed amid the Met’s financial troubles.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced in April that it faced a $10 million deficit and would begin to scale back costs. That process began on Friday as three high-level employees, including the museum’s first chief digital officer, Sree Sreenivasan, stepped down from their posts.

headline: Omar Mateen’s Birth Certificate
abstract: Omar Mateen was born on Nov. 16, 1986, at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Omar Mateen was born on Nov. 16, 1986, at Long Island Jewish Medical Center in Queens.

headline: Review: ‘Raised by Wolves’ Reimagines an Unusual Childhood
abstract: This British comedy, based on two sisters’ offbeat childhood, is a raunchy take on an insular home-schooled family.
lead_paragraph: Germaine, the eldest (at 15) of an offbeat brood in the British West Midlands, is a hormone bomb in perpetual explosion. Trailing a musclebound yob she adores (he calls her the Gruffalo), she licks the wall of the house where she thinks he lives and puts her hand through the mail slot, whispering, “And I’m in.” When her sister complains that Germaine sexually harasses everything she comes in contact with, she replies: “I can’t help it. The world is hot.”

headline: ‘Made in L.A.,’ at the Hammer, Excavates Hollywood’s Past
abstract: Old silent films and even a buried stage set are source materials for this biennial exhibition.
lead_paragraph: GUADALUPE, Calif. — Daniel R. Small climbed the sand dunes here as carefully as a tour guide scaling ancient Egyptian ruins. “Up there,” he said, sidestepping a scrap of wood and motioning to a pile of rubble in the distance, “was where the temple once stood. To the right, half of a sphinx is still buried in the sand.”

headline: Twins Drop the Yankees Back Below .500
abstract: The Yankees had an early 2-0 lead, but they could not hold on against Minnesota, which avoided a four-game sweep.

headline: Venezuela Casts a Long Shadow on Elections in Spain
abstract: Leaders of the leftist Podemos party once advised the government of Hugo Chávez in Venezuela, a country whose economic collapse is an issue in national elections next Sunday.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Europe is facing a migration crisis, the threat of Islamic terrorism and the prospect that Britain will exit the European Union. But the big foreign policy issue before Spain’s national elections next Sunday? Venezuela, of course.

headline: Review: Natashia Deón’s ‘Grace,’ a Tale of Slavery, Its Ghosts and Legacy
abstract: With her debut novel, Ms. Deón has announced herself beautifully and distinctively. She has delivered something whole, and to be reckoned with, right now.
lead_paragraph: With her debut novel, “Grace,” Natashia Deón has announced herself beautifully and distinctively. Her emotional range spans several octaves. She writes with her nerves, generating terrific suspense. And her style is so visual it plays tricks on the imagination — did I just watch that scene? Or did I read it?

headline: 11 Syrian Refugees Reported Killed by Turkish Border Guards
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Smuggling', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Most, including at least three children, were from the same extended family and were shot near the crossing at the town of Jisr al-Shoughour, Syrian activists and a monitoring group said.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkish border guards killed at least 11 Syrian refugees, including at least three children, who were trying to cross into Turkey illegally on Sunday, Syrian activists and a monitoring group said.

headline: Review: The Cure Revels in Its Contradictions and History
abstract: The band kicked off a three-night run at Madison Square Garden, wailing through decades of songs in what was a club show writ large.
lead_paragraph: They work hard for it, Robert Smith & Company. You understand Dolly Parton’s show business dictum, “It takes a lot of money to look this cheap”? Then you understand the generative contradictions of the Cure: It must take a lot of optimism to look that disenchanted. But in a certain corner of the band’s work, the opposite holds true, too: It has to take a lot of disenchantment to look that optimistic. And from there you can spin out other noun-adjective combinations, which similarly work in forward or reverse: confidence/shaky. Centrality/marginal. Generosity/self-absorbed. Forethought/nostalgic. Hardness/tender. Severity/sweet.

headline: Review: In ‘Suited,’ Searching for Clothes That Truly Fit
abstract: HBO’s “Suited” focuses on a Brooklyn clothier that specializes in clients with gender nonconforming identities.
lead_paragraph: “Suited” concerns a Brooklyn garment maker, but it’s half over before you see any custom-made clothes, because it’s not primarily about the clothier at all. The documentary, showing Monday night on HBO, is about the customers and the paths that brought them to the company, Bindle & Keep in Park Slope.

lead_paragraph: A more appropriate title for “Out of the Mouths of Babes,” a new play by Israel Horovitz that opened on Sunday at the Cherry Lane Theater, might be “Dead Man’s Harem.” In this improbable and eventually even fantastical comedy, enlivened by an excellent cast including Judith Ivey and Estelle Parsons, four women who have all been involved with the same man gather to mourn him in his Paris apartment.

headline: What Does the First Day of Summer Look Like in New York City?
abstract: Share your photos and help us document the first day of summer.
lead_paragraph: View the final selection of photographs here.

headline: Unfairly Left in the Dark at the U.S. Open While Officials Consider a Rule
abstract: The game’s necessary devotion to the exactness of its rules failed to include a dollop of common sense.
lead_paragraph: OAKMONT, Pa. — Because golf is an outdoor sport played on a field of competition that changes from place to place and day to day, its rules are inherently more complex than those of other sports. There are so many factors to weigh, and the golf rule book considers thousands of them, addressing things like what to do if a ball comes to rest on a live snake or a dead snake.

headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Season 3, Episode 9: What Exactly Is Pied Piper?
abstract: Mining comedy from a group of socially awkward engineers trying to sell a technology that people need but don’t fully understand.
lead_paragraph: This seems like an odd question to ponder nearly three full seasons into “Silicon Valley,” but it’s worth asking: What exactly is Pied Piper anyway? We know that it offers lossless file compression, which is appealing to anyone who doesn’t want their music, movies and photos to bump against the memory limits of their computers, phones and other devices. But a lot of the cutting-edge concepts that make Pied Piper a technological breakthrough — the neural net, the peer-to-peer distribution cloud, the centralized data store — remains abstract and elusive. We trust that it will improve our lives, but how might the app actually work? And how can we be sure that its “machine-learning” function won’t lead to a robot apocalypse, like Skynet in “The Terminator”?

headline: Cavaliers Defeat Warriors to Win Their First N.B.A. Title
abstract: The Cavaliers became the first team in history to rally from a 3-1 series deficit in the finals, and it was the first major sports title for the city of Cleveland since 1964.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Vilified when he left and celebrated when he returned, LeBron James had spent the past two seasons lugging his city’s championship dreams like a bag of rocks. The weight had only grown more cumbersome — the weight of history, of disappointment, of missed opportunities.

lead_paragraph: News of the arrest splashed across the front pages of New York City’s newspapers: Willie Sutton, an infamous bank robber who was one of the F.B.I.’s most-wanted fugitives since escaping from a Pennsylvania prison, had been captured in Brooklyn on Feb. 18, 1952, by two young patrolmen and a detective.

headline: Cleveland Is Believeland
abstract: My city has been losing for 52 years. Do we even know what it feels like to be champions?
lead_paragraph: Cleveland Heights, Ohio — THERE is no song called “I Left My Heart in Cleveland.” Cleveland is the flip side of California and the Golden State Warriors, whom they have met in the last two N.B.A. finals. The former Cleveland Cavaliers basketball coach David Blatt once said: “We’re in Cleveland. Nothing is easy here.” Then he got fired.

headline: ‘Veep’ Season 5, Episode 9: The Ties That Bind
abstract: Catherine Meyer may think she’s nothing like her mother, but this episode traces an emotional line through three generations.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, “Veep” shook up its formula with “Testimony,” an episode which wrapped up Season 4’s big lobbying/hacking story line by having nearly all the major characters explain themselves in front of Congress, one snappy one-liner at a time. It was one of the show’s finest half-hours, and so self-contained that even a person watching for the first time could enjoy it. Now we get this year’s version of “Testimony” in “Kissing Your Sister,” an offbeat episode that both summarizes and comments on everything that’s happened so far in Season 5. It’s a conceptual tour de force — and, more important, it’s very, very funny.

headline: What Do This Season’s Political Books Tell Us About the Election?
abstract: The divisions on display in this election year are not unique in our history. This season’s books offer insights on how we got here.
lead_paragraph: Is there a useful precedent for this most unpredictable of election seasons? Some have pointed to 1976, when Republicans were split in two and had to settle their differences at the national convention that summer. Others point to the chaos and violence of 1968. But a more pertinent example may be the election of 1936. The country was lifting itself out of the Great Depression, helped by the policies of Franklin Roosevelt, but the climb back to prosperity was long and slow, and a mood of populist unrest began to steal across the land. “The followers of the demagogues mostly came from the old lower-middle classes, now in an unprecedented stage of frustration and fear, menaced by humiliation, dispossession and poverty,” Arthur Schlesinger Jr. wrote in “The Politics of Upheaval,” published in 1960. “They came from provincial and traditionally nonpolitical groups in the population, jolted from apathy into near-hysteria by the shock of economic collapse.” Many also “came from the evangelical denominations; years of Bible reading and fundamentalist revivalism had accustomed them to millennial solutions.” Outsider candidates became the vehicles of an existential protest, “Old America in resentful revolt against both contemporary politics and contemporary economics.”

headline: A Fight Over ‘Aliens’
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'English Language', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Indexers and Indexing', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Library of Congress planned to drop the term “illegal aliens.” But Republican lawmakers don’t approve.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, Melissa Padilla, an immigrant from Mexico, was dismayed to find while doing research for a paper at Dartmouth College that all articles about undocumented students were archived under the heading “illegal aliens.” When she led a group of students to ask the college library to consider phasing out the term, they expected, at best, to make a statement at the campus. But their request triggered a political fight that has drawn in lawmakers engaged in the immigration debate.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Cynical Gay Ploy
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'United States Politics and Government']

headline: Protecting Students From Bad Colleges
keywords: ['For-Profit Schools', 'Student Loans', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Obama administration has proposed rules to shield students and taxpayers from for-profit schools, while making it easier for those defrauded to seek redress through the courts.
lead_paragraph: By failing for decades to regulate for-profit colleges, the federal government encouraged a predatory industry that saddled poor and working-class people with crippling student debt, often in return for useless degrees or no degrees at all. The industry accomplished this by relying on the federal student aid program for virtually all of its revenue. But the Obama administration took steps last week that could keep future students from falling into this trap.

headline: A Tale of Two Parties
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why is Hillary Clinton holding up so well against Donald Trump? And why were establishment Republicans so hapless?
lead_paragraph: Do you remember what happened when the Berlin Wall fell? Until that moment, nobody realized just how decadent Communism had become. It had tanks, guns, and nukes, but nobody really believed in its ideology anymore; its officials and enforcers were mere careerists, who folded at the first shock.

abstract: When ignorance and power join forces, history itself can be erased.

Giroux, a professor in the department of English and Cultural Studies at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario. His latest book is “America at War With Itself” (City Lights).

headline: The Broken Promise of Closing Guantánamo
abstract: Congress appears likely to block President Obama from closing Guantánamo, but nothing prevents him from allowing human rights monitors to visit.
lead_paragraph: Eight years ago, presidential candidates John McCain and Barack Obama agreed on one issue: It was time to shut down the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

headline: Bob Kerrey and the ‘American Tragedy’ of Vietnam
abstract: A narrative of forgiveness and redemption obscures the very real price the Vietnamese paid for a war.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles — EVEN today, Americans argue over the Vietnam War: what was done, what mistakes were made, and what were the lasting effects on American power.

headline: The Consequences of a Brexit
abstract: What would this move mean for Britain, Europe and the global economy?

headline: Finding Beauty in the Ordinary
abstract: The color photographer Joel Meyerowitz has turned his eye toward the mundane objects that inspired the Italian painter Giorgio Morandi.
lead_paragraph: The color photographer Joel Meyerowitz has turned his eye toward the mundane objects that inspired the Italian painter Giorgio Morandi.

headline: Obama Needs to Protect the Iran Deal
abstract: Europe‘s banks still fear U.S. punishment if they enter Iran. Iranians ask if they’ve been betrayed. The president must rule out prosecution. Now.
lead_paragraph: The United States, along with France, Germany, Britain, China and Russia, reached a historic deal with Iran last July that lifts most sanctions in return for curbs on Iran’s nuclear program. The deal, codified in the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action and endorsed by the United Nations Security Council Resolution 2231, specifically includes allowing non-American banks to operate in Iran.

headline: Nationalism and the Brexit Vote
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The referendum has become something of a battleground for all democracies where anti-immigrant hostilities are building.
lead_paragraph: Rarely has a vote in one country attracted as much active kibitzing abroad as Britain’s approaching referendum on whether to stay in the European Union. President Obama, Chancellor Angela Merkel, the head of the International Monetary Fund, five former supreme commanders of NATO and a host of other leaders have openly urged the British not to leave, and the chorus is growing by the day.

headline: The ‘Active Shooter’ Is Never Far Away
keywords: ['English Language', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Firearms', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)']
abstract: How the rampaging gunman became a defining feature of 21st-century American life.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-two hours after Omar Mateen began murdering people with a Sig Sauer MCX rifle at Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla. — the deadliest mass shooting in modern American history — an entrepreneur named Jeffrey Isquith arrived at the Merchandise Mart in Chicago, a cavernous Art Deco building overlooking the Chicago River, for the NeoCon trade show, which bills itself as “North America’s most important design exposition and conference for commercial interiors.” The show would bring the official debut of a product that his company, Ballistic Furniture Systems, had been developing for five years: bullet-­resistant panels that could be fitted inside chairs, cubicles and doors.

headline: Senate Rejects 4 Measures to Control Gun Sales
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Days after the worst mass shooting in U.S. history, senators voted against legislative amendments, largely along party lines.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Monday failed to advance four separate measures aimed at curbing gun sales, the latest display of congressional inaction after a mass shooting.

headline: An Amphitheater. A Laptop Bar. It’s a New York Library Like No Other.
abstract: Eight years after the Donnell Library Center in Manhattan closed, its long-awaited replacement, the 53rd Street Library, is opening.
lead_paragraph: More a theater for learning than a citadel of research, the new 53rd Street Library offers one surprise after the next as it unfolds below the sidewalks of New York.

headline: What Donald Trump Learned From Joseph McCarthy’s Right-Hand Man
abstract: Roy Cohn, the Red-baiting Senate adviser and fearsome lawyer, counseled a young Mr. Trump for many years, nurturing a style of bluster and smears.
lead_paragraph: The future Mrs. Donald J. Trump was puzzled.

headline: Joel Meyerowitz Finds Beauty in the Ordinary
abstract: The color photographer has turned his eye toward the mundane objects that inspired the Italian painter Giorgio Morandi.
lead_paragraph: Joel Meyerowitz is famed for his pioneering use of color in his New York street photography and his Cape Cod seascapes. Recently, he has turned to exploring photographic still lifes, using the same humble everyday objects that the Italian painter Giorgio Morandi depicted.

headline: Closest Thing to a Wonder Drug? Try Exercise
abstract: If the effects of exercise could be put in a pill and prescribed, it would be rightly hailed as an almost miraculous cure. So get off the couch.
lead_paragraph: After I wrote last year that diet, not exercise, was the key to weight loss, I was troubled by how some readers took this to mean that exercise therefore had no value.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

abstract: Monday: Summer solstice, sultry weather, and your summer photos.

headline: Indonesia Confirms Seizing Fishing Boat in South China Sea, Defying Beijing
abstract: The boat and its crew were taken Friday after warships fired warning shots at Chinese vessels suspected of illegal fishing, an Indonesian official said.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia is holding the crew of a Chinese fishing boat it says was fishing illegally last week in the South China Sea, an official confirmed on Monday. It was the third maritime skirmish — all involving warning shots — between the two countries in the past three months.

headline: Senate Set to Consider Gun Proposals Seen as Unlikely to Pass
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Gun Control', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Firearms', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: There is little optimism that the two parties can come to an agreement on the issue despite the killings in Orlando, Fla.
lead_paragraph: The Senate is to vote on Monday on competing gun control proposals that gained renewed attention in the aftermath of the Orlando, Fla., killings. But there is little optimism that the two parties can come to an agreement on the contentious issue despite another horrific attack.

headline: No Such Thing as a Healthy Smoker
keywords: ['Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease', 'Emphysema', 'Lungs', 'Respiratory System', 'Smoking and Tobacco']
abstract: Current or former smokers may not realize they have lung damage, because tests can fail to detect it.
lead_paragraph: Smokers who think they are escaping the lung-damaging effects of inhaled tobacco smoke may have to think again, according to the findings of two major new studies, one of which the author originally titled “Myth of the Healthy Smoker.”

headline: Morning Agenda: Energy Transfer and Williams Near a Reckoning
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Discrimination', 'Financial Brokers', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Start-ups', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

Warren, the chief executive of Energy Transfer Equity, has been scrambling to find a way out of a $38 billion merger with Williams Companies and his time is swiftly running out,Julie Creswell and Leslie Picker report in DealBook.

lead_paragraph: President de Gaulle in Russia in 1966. British Pathé.

headline: Why Handwriting Is Still Essential in the Keyboard Age

lead_paragraph: Do children in a keyboard world need to learn old-fashioned handwriting?

headline: China Wins New Bragging Rights in Supercomputers
abstract: China has the largest number of computers among the top 500 — a first for any country other than the United States.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A new list of the world’s fastest supercomputers provides more evidence that the once-yawning technology gap between the United States and China is closing.

headline: Donald Trump’s June Stumbles Mirror Those of Mitt Romney
abstract: In June 2012, Mr. Romney emerged from a slashing primary race close to broke. This June, several national surveys have shown Mr. Trump’s poll numbers sinking sharply.
lead_paragraph: In the 2012 presidential campaign, June was a pivotal month for President Obama’s re-election efforts. Mitt Romney had emerged from a slashing primary race close to broke, looking to get to the nominating convention so he could reset his candidacy and get an infusion of cash.

headline: Two Astonishing Views of O.J. Simpson and His Trial
keywords: ['Television', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: A pair of programs about race, celebrity and justice as seen through the prism of Mr. Simpson may have seemed like overkill. They were barely enough.
lead_paragraph: In the last part of ESPN’s “O. J.: Made in America,” the prosecutor Marcia Clark remembers seeing the jubilation and grief across the country after the not-guilty verdict in the O. J. Simpson trial: “It was all so much bigger than we were. So much bigger.”

headline: Jo Cox and Britain’s Place in Europe
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Referendums']
abstract: The “out” campaign countenanced the hatred that produced a political murder. Cox's legacy should be an open Britain in the European Union.
lead_paragraph: In politics, as in life, there is the question of the company you keep.

headline: Mysterious Rite of Reproduction
abstract: Watch corals in their procreative dance, a spectacular event that happens once a year after a full moon.
lead_paragraph: Watch corals in their procreative dance, a spectacular event that happens once a year after a full moon.

headline: In Secrets of Coral Spawning, Hope for Endangered Reefs
abstract: Scientists are racing to understand the bizarre reproduction rites of coral as declining water quality and climate change devastate reefs worldwide.
lead_paragraph: At night, just after the full moon, teams of scientists dive beneath the waves to study one of the planet’s most prolific and mysterious rites of reproduction.

headline: 3 N.Y.P.D. Commanders Are Arrested in Vast Corruption Case
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Gifts to Public Officials', 'Campaign Finance', 'Politics and Government']

lead_paragraph: Three New York Police Department commanders were arrested on Monday, along with a Brooklyn businessman, on federal corruption charges linked to one of several continuing investigations into Mayor Bill de Blasio’s campaign fund-raising.

headline: Not Forgotten: Benjamin “Bugsy” Siegel, Las Vegas Visionary
abstract: Benjamin “Bugsy” Siegel is mainly remembered as a vicious mobster, but he also helped turn Las Vegas from a sleepy desert town into a grown-up playground.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin “Bugsy” Siegel is mainly remembered as a vicious mobster, but he also helped turn Las Vegas from a sleepy desert town into a grown-up playground.

headline: Protests Return to Wukan, Chinese Village That Once Expelled Its Officials
abstract: The protests called for the release of a detained local leader and the resolution of a long-simmering dispute over land sales, residents said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Protesters in a Chinese fishing village that earned renown for its activism have taken to the streets in recent days to call for the release of a detained local leader and the resolution of a long-simmering dispute over land sales, residents said on Monday.

headline: A Face in the Crowd at Moncler Gamme Bleu: Big Sean
abstract: The rapper on Rihanna, Amsterdam and Kanye’s contribution to his closet.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — On Sunday night in Milan, Thom Browne staged his latest collection for Moncler Gamme Bleu, a campsite fantasy complete with tents, a carpet of grass and sod, and a pair of helpful costumed bears. In the audience, alongside the Giants football player Victor Cruz, the Oklahoma City Thunder basketball player Serge Ibaka and the actor Édgar Ramírez, was the Grammy-nominated rapper and Kanye West protégé Big Sean, there to take in his first Milan Fashion Week show.

headline: Tens of Thousands Gather in Orlando to Honor Shooting Victims
abstract: At the vigil, there were few mentions of Omar Mateen, the man who entered the club on June 12, firing at its mostly Latino, mostly gay clientele.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — It seemed as if all of Orlando was here, crowded around a glittering lake to remember the 49 people who died in a fit of violence.

headline: Emporio Armani: Spring 2017
abstract: Emporio Armani’s spring 2017 men’s designs.
lead_paragraph: Emporio Armani’s spring 2017 men’s designs.

headline: A Long-Sought Title Belongs to LeBron James
abstract: James, the star of the Cavaliers’ win, was the first player to lead both teams in an N.B.A. playoff series in points, rebounds, assists, steals and blocks.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — To try to pick the inflection point in this spectacular and deciding game of the N.B.A. finals, to lay a wager on which arcing shot, improbable steal or rebound would turn this game, was to ensure you’d go flat broke.

headline: Virginia Raggi of Five Star Movement Sweeps Election for Rome’s Mayor
abstract: An anti-establishment candidate also won in Turin, in major blows to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi and his governing Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Angry voters have swept anti-establishment candidates to power in Rome and Turin, dealing a severe blow to Prime Minister Matteo Renzi’s political standing — and highlighting his vulnerability as he moves forward with a plan to revise Italy’s Constitution.

headline: Yes, Political Ads Are Still Important, Even for Donald Trump
abstract: He has started off slowly with ads, but there’s a reason he won’t skip them, even though the effects are small and short-lived.
lead_paragraph: General election advertising will soon begin in earnest. Just last week, Hillary Clinton announced she was launching her general election ad campaign in many battleground markets, but there is no indication where and when Donald Trump’s campaign will respond.

headline: How Many Die in a Typical Terror Attack? Fewer Than You Think
abstract: Even so, what used to be symbolic acts have turned increasingly deadly, according to the Global Terrorism Database at the University of Maryland, which includes 140,000 attacks.
lead_paragraph: Headline-grabbing attacks like those last week in Orlando, Fla., or on 9/11 are as bloody as they are horrifying, but what they are not is typical. The average death toll in terror attacks, it turns out, is close to zero.

headline: 1916: British Aviators Raid Egypt
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'World War I (1914-18)']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In June 1916, British aviators raid Egypt.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Press Bureau issues the following report of a British aerial raid in Egypt: A big enemy aerodrome, with ten sheds, was located on June 13 by our aerial scouts five miles south of El Arisch and a hundred miles from our nearest aerodrome. A raid was carried out by eleven British aeroplanes on June 19. On arriving, an enemy aeroplane was observed on the point of leaving the ground. One of the raiders descended to within a hundred feet and destroyed the machine, killing the pilot, observer and mechanics. Another aeroplane was destroyed, while two of the sheds were set on fire and destroyed and four others damaged by bombs. The sheds are believed to have contained aeroplanes. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 21, 1916

headline: Supreme Court Turns Away Challenge to Connecticut Ban on Semiautomatic Weapons
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)', 'States (US)', 'Local Government']
abstract: The justices on Monday refused to hear a Second Amendment challenge to gun-control measures put in place after the Sandy Hook Elementary School massacre.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court refused on Monday to hear a Second Amendment challenge to a Connecticut law banning many semiautomatic rifles. The law, enacted in 2013 in the wake of the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., made it a crime to sell or possess the firearms, which critics call assault weapons.

headline: Donald Trump Fires Corey Lewandowski, His Campaign Manager
abstract: The dismissal on Monday came amid concerns from allies and donors about Mr. Trump’s preparedness for the rigors and expenses of a general election.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump fired his divisive campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, on Monday as he confronts urgent challenges heading into the general election — a strategic shift after months of concerns from party officials and donors about Mr. Lewandowski’s stewardship of the campaign.

headline: Daily Report: Airbnb and Social Control in the Sharing Economy
abstract: Modern tech companies love to talk about openness, transparency and information sharing. But in reality, they sometimes find a way muzzle their customers.
lead_paragraph: Technology has all kinds of ways to make life easier — particularly for the tech companies themselves.

headline: Martin Winterkorn, Ex-C.E.O. of Volkswagen, Is Under Investigation
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)']
abstract: Mr. Winterkorn, who resigned in September, is the first member of the carmaker’s top management to be identified as a suspect in the emissions scandal.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The investigation into Volkswagen’s emissions scandal has for the first time reached the top echelon of management, threatening to undermine the company’s claim that wrongdoing was limited to a handful of lower-ranking managers and potentially increasing the already enormous financial damage.

headline: After Orlando, Pushing Apart Instead of Pulling Together
abstract: The mass shooting in Florida shows what happens when people assign their own meaning to an event and use it to advance their own agendas.
lead_paragraph: The United States, a nation that once prided itself on pulling together when faced with tragedy and crisis, seems increasingly prone to factionalism even in the most somber of moments.

headline: Book Review: ‘Ordinarily Well: The Case for Antidepressants’
abstract: For all his supporting data (there’s plenty), Dr. Peter Kramer goes with what he’s seen work.
lead_paragraph: In a telling passage toward the end of his latest celebration of antidepressant drugs, Dr. Peter Kramer looks back on the pleasures of his long psychiatric career. He mentions the good company of his patients, his teachers, his colleagues. Then he turns to his favorite medications. He seems to choke up a little.

headline: A Great-Tailed Grackle's Innovation Test
abstract: Flexibility and innovation aren't the same, studies of this bird suggest.
lead_paragraph: Flexibility and innovation aren't the same, studies of this bird suggest.

headline: The Grackle’s Secret to Success
abstract: The great-tailed grackle is one of the most invasive species in the United States. A new experiment tests whether it develops new behaviors.
lead_paragraph: There’s an aura of power around invasive species. How is it that they can sweep in and take over from the locals? Are they more adaptable, tougher? What are their secrets?

headline: Elliott and Private Equity Firm to Buy Dell’s Software Unit
abstract: The buyers are getting a mix of software makers that Dell acquired over the years, including SonicWall and Quest Software.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, the hedge fund Elliott Management has focused on shaking up technology businesses with activist shareholder campaigns, urging companies to sell themselves.

headline: MSGM: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: Orlando Police Defend Actions as Clock Ticked in Massacre
abstract: As partial transcripts of phone calls by the killer, Omar Mateen, were released, officials withstood lingering questions about the timing of the assault against him and whether police gunfire hit any victims.
lead_paragraph: Some details of the Orlando nightclub massacre are known to the minute: The first reports of gunfire came at 2:02 a.m. The gunman made a 911 call at 2:35 a.m., in which he pledged allegiance to the Islamic State. By 5:15 a.m., as hostages fled to safety, he lay dead or mortally wounded in a scene of unimaginable carnage.

headline: Tracing Your Google History
abstract: Google keeps a log of your searches, location and other information shared when you use the company’s services, but you have a say in what gets saved.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is it true that Google keeps the recordings of your voice searches on the site?

headline: U.S. Senate Committee Has Questions for Global Doping Watchdog
abstract: The action follows a Times investigation that found the World Anti-Doping Agency mishandled multiple warnings about Russia doping.
lead_paragraph: United States lawmakers are demanding answers from the World Anti-Doping Agency, the global regulator of doping in Olympic sports, in the wake of a New York Times investigation that found that the agency mishandled multiple warnings about Russia — including a 2012 appeal from a Russian Olympian who confessed to cheating, pleaded for help and offered to cooperate with the agency.

headline: A Chameleon’s Hunting Secret: Sticky Spit
abstract: The animals can grab prey as far as two body lengths away.
lead_paragraph: Chameleons snack by shooting out their impressive tongues, zapping a meal as far as two body lengths away. But no one has figured out how those tongues latch onto the prey and snap it back into the animal’s mouth.

headline: What Sent a Reporter Back to First Grade — Even During Maternity Leave
abstract: At P.S. 188 on Manhattan’s Lower East Side, nearly half the kids are homeless.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Elizabeth Harris, a Metro reporter on the education beat, explains why she spent several months sitting in tiny plastic chairs.

headline: Suicide Bombs Rock Kabul
abstract: Nepalese security guards traveling by bus were killed by a suicide bomber in Kabul on Monday. The Taliban took responsibility.
lead_paragraph: Nepalese security guards traveling by bus were killed by a suicide bomber in Kabul on Monday. The Taliban took responsibility.

headline: Romano Beans for Salads, Tempura or the Grill
abstract: A California-based grower is making what are sometimes called runner beans more regularly available in the Northeast.
lead_paragraph: I love these large, flat green beans, often called Romano beans or runner beans and popular in Europe. They may show up at some farm stands and Greenmarket purveyors later in summer but now, thanks to a California-based grower who harvests them in Mexico, they’re available more regularly. Cook them a good 10 minutes for meaty tenderness; crunchy is not the goal. Serve them whole, doused with vinaigrette; fry them dripping tempura batter; cut them up to add to salads; or slap them on the grill: Mann’s Tenderbite Beans, $3.99 a pound at Eataly, Agata & Valentina stores and Grace’s Marketplace stores.

headline: Message to Workers Under Scrutiny: Cooperate or Get Fired
abstract: A recent court decision makes it clear that a company under government investigation can fire uncooperative employees with little fear of reprisal.
lead_paragraph: When a company learns it is the focus of a government investigation, the first step is to start an internal investigation to figure out what happened. To determine any potential exposure for wrongdoing, it needs the cooperation of its employees who were involved with the conduct.

headline: Food in Art, and on the Plate
abstract: A tour of the Metropolitan, followed by dinners that reflect the art.
lead_paragraph: Whether pharaohs’ tombs or Warhol’s paintings, food shows up frequently in art. Now Judith Walsh, who runs Art Smart museum tours, is offering a food-themed tour at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And after the visit, participants can choose a meal that reflects the work. The meals are served either at the Aldo Sohm Wine Bar, 151 West 51st Street, where the food is paired with wine and beer, $120 for two ($60 a person for larger groups), or at Amali, 115 East 60th Street, where a six-course dinner for four to 20 guests is $100 a person, with wine extra: Feast Your Eyes Tours, $175  an hour for up to five people, in addition to dining costs, 212-595-4444, artsmart.com.

headline: A Breakfast (or Lunch or Brunch) Sandwich, Sweet or Savory
abstract: From Sonoma County to the Upper West Side, biscuits with jam, or even pulled pork or salmon.
lead_paragraph: These biscuits, with that classic, sweetly metallic flavor, are puffy and square, as if one parent were a Parker House roll. They come from Guerneville in Sonoma County, Calif., where they brought fame to the Big Bottom Market, a tiny offshoot of which has opened on the Upper West Side. Order them with butter and jam, whipped cream and berries, pulled pork or even smoked salmon and crème fraîche, to enjoy from a sidewalk perch or to takeaway, from 7 a.m. to 2 p.m. on weekdays (8 to 11 a.m. weekends): biscuits $4 to $10 at Big Bottom Biscuit Bar, Osteria Cotta, 513 Columbus Avenue (85th Street), 212-873-8500, bigbottommarket.com/biscuit-bar-nyc/.

headline: Iran Says It Foiled One of the ‘Biggest Terrorism Plots Ever’
abstract: Several people were arrested over bombing attacks planned for June 16, and explosives were seized, the Intelligence Ministry said.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s Intelligence Ministry issued a statement on Monday saying it had foiled one of the country’s “biggest terrorism plots ever.”

headline: Lighthouse Pepper Mill as a House Gift
abstract: Treat your weekend host, or yourself, to this addition to the summer table.
lead_paragraph: Whimsy and practicality make this pepper mill a winning house gift for that coveted beach weekend. Or treat yourself instead; it would be a great addition to the summer buffet table. The pepper mill functions well and is easy to fill: Lighthouse Pepper Mill, $49.95, Crate and Barrel stores, crateandbarrel.com.

headline: Senator John Thune's Letter to WADA
abstract: On Monday Mr. Thune sent a letter to the World Anti-Doping Agency, asking the agency’s president to explain why it had taken years to investigate claims of a government-run doping program in Russia.
lead_paragraph: On Monday Mr. Thune sent a letter to the World Anti-Doping Agency, asking the agency’s president to explain why it had taken years to investigate claims of a government-run doping program in Russia.

headline: From Canadian Club, a True Rye
abstract: This new whisky from the company that has been in business for more than 150 years is suited to a perfect manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Many people assume that Canadian whisky is rye, probably because the popular post-World War II order of “rye and ginger” often meant ginger ale mixed with Canadian Club. But that is a blended whisky with rye as merely one element. Now, with the growing interest in fine rye whiskies, the company that makes Canadian Club, which has been in business for more than 150 years, has introduced a whisky that’s 100 percent rye, 80 proof, with a rich amber color and smooth with an earthy, spicy bite. It’s on the light side and lovely in a perfect manhattan: Canadian Club 100 Percent Rye, $19.99, canadianclub.com.

headline: Timeline and Transcript of Calls During Orlando Shootings
abstract: The F.B.I. on Monday released the timeline and partial transcript of the hostage negotiation calls between the Orlando gunman, Omar Mateen, and the authorities. Hours later, the F.B.I. released what it said was an unedited transcript of the first 911 call.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. on Monday released the timeline and partial transcript of the hostage negotiation calls between the Orlando gunman, Omar Mateen, and the authorities. Hours later, the F.B.I. released what it said was an unedited transcript of the first 911 call.

headline: Grilled Lobster Tails as Street Food Skewers
abstract: In the Battery, sustainably sourced lobster served with lemon-butter or blueberry sauce, as in Maine.
lead_paragraph: Instead of a lobster roll, how about a grilled lobster tail, sold from a cart in the Battery run by the people at Luke’s Lobster? The cart serves meaty five- and eight-ounce tails still in the shell from sustainably sourced Maine and Canadian lobsters. They are skewered, seared and offered with either lemon butter or Maine blueberry sauce. The sturdy wooden skewer allows you to yank the luscious meat from the shell and eat it off the skewer like corn on the cob: Lobster tails from $6 (for five-ounce, $11 for two) to $10 (for eight-ounce, $19 for two), Luke’s Tail Cart, State and Water Streets at the Battery, steps from the SeaGlass carousel, lukeslobster.com.

headline: Charges Against N.Y.P.D. Officers and a ‘Community Liaison’
abstract: The accusations made against Deputy Chief Michael J. Harrington, Deputy Inspector James M. Grant and Jeremiah Reichberg, who has described himself as a community liaison to the New York Police Department, included bribery, honest services wire fraud and conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: The accusations made against Deputy Chief Michael J. Harrington, Deputy Inspector James M. Grant and Jeremiah Reichberg, who has described himself as a community liaison to the New York Police Department, included bribery, honest services wire fraud and conspiracy.

headline: Drug Company Lunches Have Big Payoffs
abstract: A free lunch may be all it takes to persuade a doctor to prescribe a brand-name drug instead of a cheaper generic, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: A free lunch may be all it takes to persuade a doctor to prescribe a brand-name drug instead of a cheaper generic, a new study suggests.

headline: How Our Fears About Money Could Swing the 2016 Election
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Personal Finances', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: When we view this election cycle through the lens of financial fear, some of the outlandish things happening in both parties start to make a little more sense.
lead_paragraph: I’m getting more questions about what this election will mean for people’s personal financial situations than I’ve received in any previous election that I can remember. Financial advisers almost twice my age tell me the same thing.

headline: In This ‘Romeo and Juliet’ Ballet, a Rebel Juliet
abstract: Kenneth MacMillan’s 1965 version — at American Ballet Theater this week — depicts a heroine transformed by sexual desire.
lead_paragraph: The most famous music in Prokofiev’s “Romeo and Juliet” does not go to the lovers of the title. It’s a dance of patriarchy, often called the “Dance of the Knights,” halfway through Act I. Ballet is usually an art in which men chivalrously allow women to shine; not so in the Verona conceived by Shakespeare and reimagined for dance theater by Prokofiev. To the pounding bass line of the brass (oom-pah–oom-pah), the men of Juliet’s family, the Capulets, demonstrate their authority, ceremoniously marching forward in splendor.

headline: Is This Heaven? No, It’s Cleveland
abstract: Disappointment had been an annual ritual among sports fans in Cleveland. Not anymore, not after the Cavaliers were crowned N.B.A. champions.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — On a warm June night in Cleveland, 20,562 pairs of hands gathered to lift a curse.

headline: Couturiers Paired with Choreogaphers for City Ballet Gala
abstract: New York City Ballet’s Fall Fashion Gala will outfit its dancers in the designs of Rosie Assoulin, Narciso Rodriguez, Dries Van Noten and Jason Wu.
lead_paragraph: The annual mash-up of choreography and couture that is New York City Ballet’s Fall Fashion Gala will outfit its dancers this September in the designs of Rosie Assoulin, Narciso Rodriguez, Dries Van Noten and Jason Wu, the company announced on Monday.

headline: Hockey Problems
abstract: What is the probability your team will win a best-of-seven series?

headline: Would America Have Fewer Missing Workers if It Were More Like France?
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Unemployment', 'Paid Time Off', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Fewer prime-age American men are in the labor force than in many other advanced countries, a possible downside of a flexible U.S. job market.
lead_paragraph: What if the very thing that is often viewed as one of the United States’ sources of dynamism — flexible labor markets — is the driving force behind the economy’s greatest weakness: millions of people who are neither working nor looking for a job?

headline: Conversations: Poking Fun at Tech Culture on ‘Silicon Valley’
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Start-ups', 'Television', 'Women and Girls', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A writer for “Silicon Valley” talks about the show’s female characters and influence on the real Valley.
lead_paragraph: Carrie Kemper is something of a workplace-comedy veteran. After writing for “The Office,” she’s now a writer and supervising producer for HBO’s “Silicon Valley,” a show about the perpetually embattled startup Pied Piper. Co-created by Mike Judge, who also created “King of the Hill” and “Beavis and Butt-Head,” “Silicon Valley” skewers tech culture — in one episode in the first season, a succession of startup founders claim to be “making the world a better place” with highly specialized products like “software-defined data centers for cloud computing.”

headline: Saiga Population Grows After Mysterious Epidemic

headline: Three’s a Trend: Men’s Tracksuits
abstract: Christopher Shannon, Topman Design and Gosha Rubchinskiy all offered high-fashion versions of the leisure look.
lead_paragraph: The tracksuit, with its matching zip jacket and jogger pants, is a sartorial symbol of leisure — and, sometimes, laziness. It’s a look straight out of ’80s hip-hop videos, “The Royal Tenenbaums” or “Goodfellas.” But on the runways at London Collections Men and Pitti Uomo, the look took on a distinctly luxury feel. Christopher Shannon offered a version entirely of denim, and color-blocked with different washes, while Topman Design showed one with a pair of loafers. And the designer Gosha Rubchinskiy, the invited guest designer at this season’s Pitti, looked to his ’90s Eastern Bloc roots and dressed his models in a number of tracksuits, including some that were collaborations with the original Italian purveyors of the style: Fila, Kappa and Sergio Tacchini.

headline: Even Without Detonation, 4 Hydrogen Bombs From ’66 Scar Spanish Village
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Radiation', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Series', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Plutonium']
abstract: Decades after an Air Force bomber and a refueling jet collided, Palomares remains haunted by high radiation levels, a hurried cleanup, health fears and stigma.
lead_paragraph: PALOMARES, Spain — José Manuel González Navarro, a mechanic, headed out of this seaside village on his motorbike one morning 50 years ago when he heard explosions overhead and looked up to see a ball of fire in the sky. Debris started to shower down, some “falling very slowly, like if a giant tree was shedding shiny metal leaves,” he recalled in an interview.

keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Referendums', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
