headline: Bathroom Debate Complicates Mexican Town’s Acceptance of a Third Gender
abstract: A push for transgender bathroom rights is unsettling the Zapotecs of southern Oaxaca, despite their long embrace of a third gender.
lead_paragraph: JUCHITÁN DE ZARAGOZA, Mexico — To the people of this town in southern Oaxaca State, the existence of a third gender is as much a part of life as the ancient Zapotec language they speak and the huge, spiny iguanas that laze in the trees.

headline: Illustrating Your Thoughts in iOS Notes
abstract: Apple’s iOS 9 operating system includes an upgraded Notes app that can handle more than just typed text.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do you draw with the iOS Notes app?

headline: Qatari Investment Group Acquires Parisian Fashion House Balmain
abstract: The sale to Mayhoola for Investments, a private investment group linked to Qatar’s royal family, will fund the expansion of the label’s accessories business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Balmain, the Parisian fashion house beloved by Hollywood, the European jet set and the Kardashian clan, has been bought by a private investment group linked to Qatar’s royal family and that has sought to build a luxury-brand empire.

headline: Here Come the Drones
abstract: Now that the F.A.A. has set the rules for commercial drones, it’s time to test them and push for much more.
lead_paragraph: Now that commercial drones have navigated Washington, they should be headed for a town — or work site — near you.

headline: Can a New Owner Take ‘Balmainia’ to the Next Level?
abstract: Maybe Mayhoola for Investments, the Qatari fund, will help move Instagram’s favorite fashion brand beyond the Kardashian clan.
lead_paragraph: So, Mayhoola for Investments — the Qatari sovereign wealth fund that owns Valentino, Anya Hindmarch and Pal Zileri, and that is backed by Qatar’s royal family — has bought Balmain, the Paris fashion house backed by the Kardashians (well, not exactly backed, but they are its biggest cheerleaders). This could have big repercussions on what we all wear.

headline: The Men’s Shows Roll Into Paris. Ho-hum or Quite Good?
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Some critics have been grumbling but retailers, focusing on standouts like Gucci, look at the sunny side of sales.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It is a telling detail that at fashion shows, critics and retailers tend to sit on opposite sides of the runway. Agreement on the merits or failings of any individual collection, or the fashion season as a whole, is as hard to come by in this world as accord across the aisle is in politics. A few collections manage the feat of pleasing everyone, but many others are critically beloved while impossibly unsalable, or till-ringingly commercial but poorly or begrudgingly reviewed.

headline: North Korea’s Successful Missile Test Shows Program’s Progress, Analysts Say
abstract: The Musudan ballistic missile’s launch was a success, state media said, quoting Kim Jong-un as boasting that North Korea could strike United States forces in the Pacific.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A day after North Korea launched an intermediate-range ballistic missile into high altitude — after five consecutive launch failures — the country’s state-run media proclaimed the test a success on Thursday, and quoted Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, as boasting that his arsenal could strike United States forces in the Pacific.

headline: In Reversal, Marco Rubio to Seek Re-election to Senate
abstract: Mr. Rubio, the Florida Republican, has decided to seek re-election to the Senate after months of insisting that he would not run again.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida said Wednesday that he would run for re-election, abandoning plans to pursue a more lucrative career in the private sector and jolting a competitive race that is crucial to Democrats’ plans to retake control of the Senate.

headline: Corinthian Colleges Used Recruiting Incentives, Documents Show
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'For-Profit Schools', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Consumer Protection', 'Student Loans']
abstract: The disclosure, found in internal documents in a suit filed by employees of the defunct for-profit education company, could help former students get loans forgiven.
lead_paragraph: Corinthian Colleges, once one of the nation’s largest for-profit education companies, engaged in apparently unlawful practices by paying its recruiters based on how many sales leads they converted into actual students, according to documents unsealed late last week.

headline: 1891: Social Life in the Capital
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Washington’s society queens having a lively time of it in June 1891.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON D.C. — Although drawn blinds and closed front doors confront you at every turn, many of Washington’s society queens are not gone yet. Neither are their admirers. I find the Bar Harbor contingent is all here and having a lively time of it, pending the transfer of its Lares and Penates to that northern city by the sea. It is the fashion now-a-days to eat your dinner anywhere else but at home; so that the country clubs, roadside inns, and the various easily reached river resorts have very swell companies every afternoon — provided, of course, it does not rain. — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 23, 1891

headline: Documents on For-Profit Corinthian Colleges
abstract: Documents unsealed by a federal court show that the company routinely assessed its recruiters based on how many sales leads they converted into actual students.
lead_paragraph: Documents unsealed by a federal court show that the company routinely assessed its recruiters based on how many sales leads they converted into actual students.

headline: Cavaliers Parade Caps Off Cleveland Victory Party
abstract: An estimated crowd of more than 1.3 million people descended on downtown Cleveland on Wednesday to celebrate the Cavaliers’ first N.B.A. title with the players.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The victory party commenced Sunday night after the Cleveland Cavaliers defeated the Golden State Warriors, 93-89, to become the first team to rally from a three-games-to-one deficit to win the N.B.A. finals, and it has only grown in size and stature since.

headline: Polygamous Sect Leader Is on the Run, Officials Say
keywords: ['Money Laundering', 'Polygamy', 'Embezzlement', 'Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Lyle Jeffs, the leader of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, has disappeared while awaiting trial on fraud and money-laundering charges.
lead_paragraph: The leader of a polygamous breakaway sect of the Mormon Church has gone on the run less than two weeks after he was released from jail and confined to a home in Salt Lake City pending a trial on fraud and money laundering charges, officials said.

headline: Donald Trump’s Speech: What You Missed and Our Fact Checks
abstract: After a rough week, Donald J. Trump tried to refocus his campaign on Wednesday with a speech attacking his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton. But he took liberties with the truth.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has had a rough week, overseeing a shake-up of his campaign staff and reporting a dismal fund-raising total. The presumptive Republican presidential nominee tried to refocus his campaign on Wednesday with a speech attacking his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton. But he took liberties with the truth, delivering a series of inaccurate and misleading statements.

headline: Is the Idea of ‘Art for Art’s Sake’ a Sign of Social Privilege?
abstract: Pankaj Mishra and Rivka Galchen discuss who gets to make art for art’s sake.
lead_paragraph: In Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Pankaj Mishra and Rivka Galchen discuss who gets to make art for art’s sake.

headline: Trying to Get Past Airport Security Faster? Get in Line
abstract: A surge in applications for PreCheck, the Transportation Security Administration’s solution to long lines, has led to processing delays and enrollment waiting lists.
lead_paragraph: Officials at the Transportation Security Administration thought they had the solution for long lines at airports: PreCheck, a program that allowed people to move through security without taking off their shoes or removing electronics from their luggage.

headline: Obama Fracking Rule Is Struck Down by Court
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Federal Lands', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: A federal judge in Wyoming said the Interior Department had overreached when it issued a regulation for hydraulic fracturing on government-owned lands.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Tuesday night struck down an Obama administration regulation on the use of hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, for oil and gas on public lands, a blow to President Obama’s muscular stand on the extraction of fossil fuels on government lands.

headline: Mitsubishi Predicts $1.39 Billion Loss After Fuel Economy Fraud
abstract: The net loss, forecast for the fiscal year to March, would be Mitsubishi’s first in eight years.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Mitsubishi Motors said Wednesday that it expected to incur a loss of 145 billion yen, or $1.39 billion, this year as it faces the fallout from a scandal over falsified fuel-economy ratings.

headline: Cook Without a Recipe!
abstract: Riff on your favorite recipe, or try out crab croquetas and a cucumber-watermelon salad.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: The State Department’s Dissent Memo on Syria: An Explanation
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'No-Fly Zones']
abstract: A memo issued last week that criticizes the Obama administration’s Syria policy is written in language that can be difficult to parse. Here’s what it means.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, The New York Times obtained a draft version of a State Department memo that sharply criticizes the Obama administration’s Syria policy and calls for limited military strikes against that country’s government. The memo, signed by 51 diplomats, was sent through an agency “dissent channel” that was established during the Vietnam War to air internal criticism.

headline: FARC Rebels in Colombia Reach Cease-Fire Deal With Government
abstract: The FARC rebels agreed to lay down their weapons in a conflict believed to have killed more than 200,000 people over half a century.
lead_paragraph: The Colombian government and the country’s largest rebel group said Wednesday that they had agreed to a cease-fire, clearing a major hurdle in the effort to end one of the world’s longest-running conflicts.

headline: ‘Birdsong,’ by James Sturm
abstract: A wordless picture book about two naughty children is inspired by the Japanese “paper theater” tradition.
lead_paragraph: BIRDSONGA Story in PicturesBy James Sturm56 pp. Toon Books. $12.95. (Picture book; ages 4 and up)

headline: ‘Brexit’ Debate Even Divides Cats (and Dogs) on Twitter
abstract: #CatsAgainstBrexit, #CatsForBrexit and other pet hashtags have started to appear as Twitter users inject some humor into the European Union debate.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Battle lines have been sharply drawn ahead of the vote on Thursday about whether Britain should remain a member of the European Union.

headline: Neil deGrasse Tyson and Al Gore Explore Climate Change, Life in a Naval Observatory and More
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Podcasts', 'Science and Technology', 'Solar Energy', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Telescopes and Observatories']
abstract: Neil deGrasse Tyson and Al Gore talk about climate change activism, the “GoreSat” satellite, “spider goats” and paths to abundant clean energy.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, the astrophysicist and science-literacy evangelist Neil deGrasse Tyson recorded a conversation for his Star Talk Radio program with former Vice President Al Gore exploring Gore’s decades-long campaign for action to stem climate change, what it’s like to live in the United States Naval Observatory (the official vice presidential residence), the path from the vice president’s “GoreSat” vision in 1998 to the functioning Deep Space Climate Observatory satellite, and more.

headline: The Republicans and Court Vacancies
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: “The Republican Senate majority’s inaction has perpetuated and worsened the lower federal court vacancy crisis,” a law professor writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Taylor Mac’s 24-Hour Song Cycle Sets Date for World Premiere
abstract: The production will open the St. Ann’s Warehouse season in September.
lead_paragraph: “A 24-Decade History of Popular Music,” the 24-hour-long magnum opus of the playwright and performance artist Taylor Mac, will be presented in its entirety for the first time this fall at St. Ann’s Warehouse.

headline: New Ways to Treat Pain Meet Resistance
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Pain', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Addiction (Psychology)']
abstract: For a number of reasons, alternatives to often-addictive painkillers are slow to be accepted, by insurers, doctors and patients.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Douglas Scott, a property manager in Jacksonville, Fla., was taking large doses of narcotic drugs, or opioids, to deal with the pain of back and spine injuries from two recent car accidents.

headline: No Food in the Library
abstract: Mimi Sheraton, former restaurant critic for The Times, says allowing food will lead to noise, offensive aromas and trash.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bill Berkson, Poet and Art Critic of ’60s Manhattan In-Crowd, Dies at 76
abstract: His friends were legion, an endless roll call of the geniuses, provocateurs and poseurs who gave the decade its distinctive cultural tang.
lead_paragraph: In the artistic Manhattan of the 1960s, when the small worlds of experimental poetry, film, theater, visual art and dance bled into one another, an animated figure seemed to appear everywhere at once. Bill Berkson, poet and art critic, was the ever-present third man from the left in the group photographs that chronicle the era.

headline: Lewis Black to Perform on Broadway This Election Season
abstract: The comedian will perform a one-man stand-up set centered on politics.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Lewis Black will perform four nights of stand-up at the Marquis Theater on Broadway this fall at the peak of election season.

headline: Veterans Use Battlefield Experiences to Build Businesses
abstract: The number of veterans starting businesses has dropped since World War II, but new programs and technologies are inspiring those formerly in the military to pursue start-ups.
lead_paragraph: After years of operating within a regimented chain of command, many veterans are ready to become their own bosses. Many would-be business owners are finding that the skills and experiences honed in the military are directly translating into start-up ideas.

headline: Men’s Fashion Shows: Giorgio Armani
abstract: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collection, which was presented on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collection, which was presented on Tuesday.

headline: Smoking May Damage Sperm
abstract: It could reduce the chance of fertilization and might also lead to health problems in the baby, a new study says.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that a woman who smokes and plans to become pregnant should stop smoking. A new study suggests that the future father should quit, too.

headline: Anatomy of a Broadway Flop: What Sank These 4 Shows?
abstract: Exploring the box-office struggles of “American Psycho,” “Bright Star,” “Disaster!” and “Tuck Everlasting.”
lead_paragraph: The woeful wordplay writes itself. “American Psycho” met a gruesome end. “Tuck Everlasting” was not immortal. “Bright Star” ran out of fuel. And “Disaster!” proved to be — well, you can finish that one yourself.

headline: Texas’s Strict Abortion Law
abstract: A doctor writes, “Nowhere in my medical training was I taught how to circumvent needless barriers to care.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Mom Who Wore Supreme
abstract: One woman’s fashion journey, from Matthew Modine in “Married to the Mob” to a recent streetwear drop.
lead_paragraph: A recent Thursday found me and a male friend huddled over his iPhone. It was 11 a.m. sharp, and the men’s skate-clothing label Supreme was having its weekly drop of new merchandise. My friend, a Supreme fan, has admitted in the past that he goes into something of a fugue state during its weekly online drop, clicking near blindly to secure himself something, anything, before it’s gone. This time, I was a fellow traveler.

headline: Tesla’s Plan to Buy SolarCity Has Major Flaws
abstract: Tesla’s stock fell more than 8 percent on Wednesday, as investors viewed the deal as a bailout of SolarCity, one that could sink both companies.
lead_paragraph: The market hates the idea of Tesla Motors acquiring SolarCity.

headline: Donald Trump Returns Fire, Calling Hillary Clinton a ‘World-Class Liar’
abstract: In his speech, Mr. Trump delivered blistering attacks on his rival interspersed with his own policy proposals.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump delivered a blistering attack on Wednesday against Hillary Clinton, calling her unreliable and more concerned with herself than with the American people as he sought to regain his footing after a tumultuous month that imperiled his candidacy.

headline: House Democrats’ Gun-Control Sit-In Turns Into Chaotic Showdown With Republicans
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The standoff continued until early Thursday as the House speaker took the remarkable step of calling a vote on a major appropriations bill in the wee hours and without any debate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Democratic protest demanding votes on gun-control legislation led to pandemonium in the House chamber that did not end until early Thursday, when Speaker Paul D. Ryan and his fellow Republicans reclaimed control long enough to force through a major spending bill. They then abruptly adjourned and left the Capitol.

headline: Cancer Is Contagious Among Clams. What About Us?
abstract: Once considered a rarity, infectious tumors appear to be more common in the animal world than once believed.
lead_paragraph: The ocean contains a vast number of living things, including many, many pathogens — from bacteria that thrive on coral to fungi that infect lobsters. A drop of seawater may hold 10 million viruses.

headline: Living With a Teenage Data Hog
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Text Messaging', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Figuring out who should pay for the data, how much, and according to what rules, can be a giant headache.
lead_paragraph: After children reach a certain age, most parents give in to their desire for a mobile phone. We like being able to find them at any moment, and they risk being left out if their friends can’t ping them. A Pew Research Center report from last year found that 88 percent of American teenagers now have phones.

headline: Michigan Attorney General Sues 2 Companies Over Flint Water Crisis
abstract: The companies, Veolia North America and Lockwood, Andrews & Newnam, were hired to advise the city about using the Flint River as its drinking water source.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Blame for the tainted water in Flint, Mich., has engulfed federal regulators, the governor, state employees and city officials. On Wednesday, the Michigan attorney general took sharp aim elsewhere: the private sector.

headline: Medicare and Social Security Trustees Warn of Shortfalls
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Social Security (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A report could add a note of fiscal reality to a presidential campaign that has given scant attention to the fiscal challenges of an aging population.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Wednesday that the financial outlook for Medicare’s hospital insurance trust fund had deteriorated slightly in the last year and that Social Security still faced serious long-term financial problems.

headline: Lab-Grown Bones Successfully Implanted in Pigs
abstract: Jaw bones grown in a nutrient solution were implanted in 14 animals, who are now doing fine.
lead_paragraph: The pigs, all 14 of them, are doing fine. Considering they’d been retrofitted with bone grown in a laboratory, that came as a pleasant surprise.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Men’s Tailoring, With a Sporty Twist
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: At Prada, Marni and Versace, shirts and suits were reinterpreted with outdoorsy touches, like nylon straps and hiking sandals.
lead_paragraph: Velcro, hiking sandals, nylon straps and cycling shorts aren’t details typically associated with tailored men’s wear. But on many of the spring/summer 2017 men’s runways this week in Milan, designers have shown utilitarian, outdoorsy takes on suiting. At Prada, Miuccia Prada riffed on the idea of the global nomad, with even formal looks paired with oversize camping bags. At Marni, classic men’s shirts and suits came complete with velcro adjustments, which enable the wearer to alter the fit and silhouette. And at Versace, tailored looks were paired with Teva-like sandals and pieces from the new Versace Active performance line — such as a topcoat, which was worn over a biker top and shorts. Because, why not?

headline: In San Francisco, Opera Impresario David Gockley Hangs Up His Cloak
abstract: After leading the San Francisco Opera for the last decade, Mr. Gockley is bringing down the curtain on a career that changed American opera.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — He commissioned a staggering 45 new operas, including John Adams’s “Nixon in China.” His 1976 production of Gershwin’s “Porgy and Bess” helped make the case for that work as an opera. He gave quite a few leading singers, including Renée Fleming, their big breaks. And he strengthened the two opera companies he ran: Houston Grand Opera, which he led for 33 years, and San Francisco Opera, where he has been for the last decade.

headline: After Nearly 75 Years, and Countless Knots, a Boy Scout Leader Is Retiring
abstract: Julio Balde joined the scouts when he was 15. Now, a week after his 95th birthday, he will step down as leader of Troop 102 of Newark.
lead_paragraph: NUTLEY, N.J. — His arthritic fingers brought the ends of the rope together, intertwining them slowly but with obvious familiarity.

headline: Chile Soccer Team Strengthened by Forays Away From Home
abstract: Chile has used this month’s Copa América Centenario to erase any doubts over its emergence as a power player from South America.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Regardless of what happens when Chile plays Colombia on Wednesday night, one thing is plain: The world now knows that Chile’s soccer team is for real. Fresh off a 7-0 thrashing of Mexico, arguably the best team in the North American region, Chile has used this month’s Copa América Centenario to erase any doubts over its emergence as a power player from South America.

headline: The New Panama Canal: A Risky Bet
abstract: After a Spanish-led consortium won the right to build locks for bigger ships at a rock-bottom price, internal arguments soon gave way to larger problems.
lead_paragraph: After a Spanish-led consortium won the right to build locks for bigger ships at a rock-bottom price, internal arguments soon gave way to larger problems.

headline: Devices That Deserve to Go Along on Vacation
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Android (Operating System)', 'Smartphones', 'Wireless Communications', 'Tablet Computers', 'iPad', 'Google Phone', 'Electronics']
abstract: Don’t burden your trip with expensive or very heavy devices that you may not use. Here are some worth packing for use on an airplane, in a rental car or hotel, outdoors and overseas.
lead_paragraph: CHILDREN are usually forced to pick just one or two of their beloved stuffed animals to take with them on summer vacation. Adults should consider doing the same with their electronic devices.

headline: Home and Work: Danielle Clough, Embroidery Artist
abstract: The 28-year-old brings T into her Cape Town studio, where she decorates everything from coffee filters to vintage athletic rackets.
lead_paragraph: The 28-year-old brings T into her Cape Town studio, where she decorates everything from coffee filters to vintage athletic rackets.

headline: Vivid, Artful Embroidery — on Unusual Surfaces
abstract: Inside the Cape Town home studio of Danielle Clough, whose modern take on an old-school craft has captured the attention of Vans and the United Nations.
lead_paragraph: At just 12 years old, Danielle Clough got the first indication that her artwork might catch on with others. “I doodled something on paper, and a friend said: ‘I would totally tattoo that on myself,’” she recalls. Among preteen girls, there could be no higher praise, and Clough went on to experiment with various forms of visual expression in her formative years, including fashion design, photography and graphic art. “I tried a lot of things on for size,” she says.

headline: Facebook Shareholder Vote Produces Odd Results
abstract: A vote on the company’s governance was a brainteaser that suggests that institutional investors are more inclined to tick boxes than follow their heads.
lead_paragraph: Facebook shareholders sent a curious message about the social network’s governance this week. More than half of Facebook owners not named Mark Zuckerberg clicked the corporate equivalent of a “Like” button for just three of the company’s directors.

headline: Wedding Gifts, Under $100, for Summer Serving
abstract: Eight gifts under $100 for making and serving beverages.

abstract: A reader takes issue with Donald Trump and Wayne LaPierre’s belief in the value of an armed bystander who stops a terrorist.

headline: Lightning in India Kills More Than 70, Mostly Farmworkers
abstract: Lightning strikes that punctuated the monsoon season’s inaugural heavy rains left scores of farmers and others dead in the country’s northeast.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Farmers in India have been fervently awaiting this year’s monsoon season after two consecutive years of inadequate rains. But they were ill prepared for the lightning.

headline: Standouts in Mobile Gaming
abstract: A selection of innovative, beautiful and meaningful games with music, cartoons or even real-world themes.
lead_paragraph: NUMEROUS video game titles were showcased at the E3 industry show last week, and many exhibitors emphasized mobile gaming. I recently looked through some app stores to find games that are innovative, beautiful and meaningful.

headline: Troubles for New Panama Canal
abstract: As ships got larger, the Panama Canal needed to expand to avoid becoming obsolete. A bigger channel will open Sunday, but many are concerned that it might not work as planned.
lead_paragraph: As ships got larger, the Panama Canal needed to expand to avoid becoming obsolete. A bigger channel will open Sunday, but many are concerned that it might not work as planned.

abstract: Nicholas Kristof acknowledged being “wrong” in endorsing welfare reform 20 years ago, saying it hasn’t worked. Readers offer their views.

headline: Alessandra Ferri Makes the Most of a Dance With Father Time
abstract: Ms. Ferri, once retired, is continuing her career at 53 as she performs with American Ballet Theater in “Romeo and Juliet.”
lead_paragraph: It was late April, and the ballerina Alessandra Ferri was rehearsing the balcony pas de deux from Kenneth MacMillan’s “Romeo and Juliet” with Herman Cornejo in American Ballet Theater’s Lower Manhattan studios. The liquid fluidity, gorgeously arched feet and dramatic intensity that have characterized Ms. Ferri’s long career were all in evidence, and onlookers were watching with rapt appreciation.

headline: Eight Red Sandals for Summer
abstract: With a bright hue and thin straps, these vibrant heels pack a colorful punch.
lead_paragraph: With a bright hue and thin straps, these vibrant heels pack a colorful punch.

headline: Nicholas Clinch, Who Took On Unclimbed Mountains, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Clinch led the first ascent of Hidden Peak, in northeast Pakistan, in 1958, and of Mount Vinson, in Antarctica, in 1966.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Clinch, an audacious and intrepid mountaineer who led first-ascent expeditions of skyscraping peaks in the Himalayas and in Antarctica, died on June 15 in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 85.

headline: In Wisconsin, a Backlash Against Using Data to Foretell Defendants’ Futures
abstract: Several states are using algorithms in the sentencing process, part of a broader national push to incorporate data into law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — When Eric L. Loomis was sentenced for eluding the police in La Crosse, Wis., the judge told him he presented a “high risk” to the community and handed down a six-year prison term.

headline: HBO Unexpectedly Cancels Low-Rated ‘Vinyl’ After One Season
abstract: The program, a 1970s music drama created by Mick Jagger and Martin Scorsese, was besieged by a series of problems following the end of the first season in April.
lead_paragraph: The good news for HBO: “Game of Thrones,” still enormously popular after six seasons, will close out another successful season Sunday night.

headline: Street Style: Milan
keywords: ["Men's Fashion Week", 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Milan is the next stop on the street style tour as men’s fashion week makes the trip through Europe.
lead_paragraph: Milan is the next stop on the street style tour as men’s fashion week makes the trip through Europe.

headline: De Blasio Finds His Support From Gay New Yorkers Still Has Limits
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio has taken steps to make New York City a welcoming place for gay and transgender people, but some say there’s “still much left to be desired.”
lead_paragraph: A day after the massacre in a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla., thousands of gay and transgender men and women gathered outside the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village for a vigil where Mayor Bill de Blasio, among others, was to speak before the names of the dead were to be read.

headline: Mark Zuckerberg Covers His Laptop Camera. You Should Consider It, Too.
abstract: A photo of Mr. Zuckerberg’s laptop camera covered in tape had curious observers wondering if it was paranoia or just good practice.
lead_paragraph: Mark Zuckerberg is one of the most powerful men in the world because billions of people give Facebook, which he founded, free access to their personal data. In return, users receive carefully curated snapshots of his life: baby photos, mundane office tours and the occasional 5K.

headline: Bitter ‘Brexit’ Campaign Could Turn on Record Number of Voters
abstract: The decision to remain in the European Union or leave the bloc will likely turn on which side can better motivate supporters to leave the home or office to vote.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Politicians campaigning for and against British withdrawal from the European Union fanned out on Wednesday in a final, frenetic effort to build support on the eve of a referendum that could reshape the nation’s place in the world and upend the Continent’s dreams of closer integration.

headline: A New Spot in Paris for Healthy Japanese — and Natural Wines
abstract: The chef behind Le Petit Keller, who formerly worked at Rose Bakery and launched the bento empire Nanashi, shares a recipe for matcha cake.
lead_paragraph: Opened just in time for the start of men’s fashion shows (and soon, couture) in Paris, the two-month-old restaurant Le Petit Keller offers a fresh perspective on healthy cuisine. The Japanese menu was designed by Kaori Endo, who was a chef at Rose Carrarini’s Rose Bakery in the late aughts before launching Nanashi in 2010, a Parisian bento empire that drew in an equally fashionable crowd for its wholesome bentos and delicate desserts. And Endo co-owns Le Petit Keller with her husband, the wine shop owner Michael Lemasle, who curated the restaurant’s list of small-production, natural French bottles.

headline: For Patrons at Julius’, Orlando Doesn’t Seem Very Far Away
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']

keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Bars and Nightclubs', 'Celebrities']
abstract: Jane Lynch, Alexander Wang, Rosie O’Donnell and others reflect on what gay bars mean to them, in the aftermath of the shooting in Orlando, Fla.
lead_paragraph: For generations of gays and lesbians, especially those for whom walking into the sometime secret and darkened doorway of one was often the first step in the coming-out process, gay bars have long held a significant place in their personal histories.

headline: Variety and Verve at Make Music New York
abstract: Our critics and reporters took in some of the more than a thousand free concerts offered around the city to celebrate the arrival of summer.
lead_paragraph: With the arrival of summer, critics and reporters for The New York Times spread throughout the city on Tuesday to take in some of the more than a thousand free concerts that are part of Make Music New York.

headline: Haider Ackermann: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring collection.

headline: Review: Pascal Rioult Turns Greek Tragedies Into Antiwar Statements
abstract: With Kathleen Turner sometimes narrating, Mr. Rioult’s company presents “Women on the Edge ... Unsung Heroines of the Trojan War” at the Joyce.
lead_paragraph: Finding out that a celebrity follows a dance company can be a shock to the system. (After all, the dance world is a small place.) Kathleen Turner and the choreographer Pascal Rioult? Really?

headline: Troy Ave Pleads Not Guilty to Attempted Murder in Irving Plaza Shooting
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: The rapper was not charged with murder in the shooting that killed his friend during a concert that featured the rapper T.I. at the club in Union Square.
lead_paragraph: Nearly one month after a shooting at the Irving Plaza concert hall in Manhattan that left one dead and several others injured, the rapper Troy Ave pleaded not guilty on Wednesday to attempted second-degree murder and four counts of criminal possession of a weapon.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Men’s Western Shirts
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Milan Fashion Week', "Men's Fashion Week"]
abstract: Topman Design, Cmmn Swdn and Missoni all showed modern versions of the classic American style.
lead_paragraph: European designers have often found influence in time-honored Americana — and on the spring/summer 2017 men’s runways this season, there have been several updated takes on the Western shirt. In London, Topman Design rendered the classic pearl-snap style in silk, replacing the traditional hibiscus flower with sea gulls and ice cream cones, while Cmmn Swdn showed a ’70s-inspired short-sleeved version in woven gingham, evoking a kind of Nordic urban cowboy. And in Milan, Missoni’s interpretation came in mixed shades of blue and green, camouflaged with monochromatic triangles and Breton stripes, with contrasting embroidery across the chest.

headline: On Capitol Hill, Yellen Finds Partisan Heat, Not Economic Light
abstract: Janet Yellen’s testimony before a House committee highlighted how real debate about the economy has been overshadowed by partisan politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Year after year of disappointing growth in the United States. Disappearing middle-class jobs. Turmoil overseas, including the looming possibility that British voters will decide on Thursday to part ways with Europe. Urgent economic issues all.

headline: Maharashtra State in India Grants Jews Minority Status
abstract: Maharashtra, which is home to an estimated 3,000 of India’s 4,500 Jews, approved the application for official recognition.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Jews in the Indian state of Maharashtra were granted minority status this week, a decision that was celebrated by local Jewish leaders, though they said they were still trying to grasp the full range of benefits Jews might derive from the new status.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Message: Yes, the Economy Is Messed Up. But I Can Fix It.
abstract: She embraced the economic discontent that has fueled the rise of her opponents, while presenting herself as the person most qualified to address it.
lead_paragraph: It has been a year dominated by populist rage, embodied in Bernie Sanders’s calls for a political revolution and Donald J. Trump’s angry assertions that the United States, and its workers, are losing badly in the global economy.

headline: Knicks Acquire Oft-Injured Derrick Rose From the Bulls
abstract: The Knicks sent center Robin Lopez and guards Jose Calderon and Jerian Grant to Chicago for Rose, guard Justin Holiday and a 2017 second-round draft pick.
lead_paragraph: In a move designed to upgrade a conspicuously ineffectual backcourt, the Knicks completed a blockbuster deal with the Chicago Bulls on Wednesday and acquired point guard Derrick Rose, who won the Most Valuable Player Award in 2011 before struggling with a string of serious knee injuries.

headline: Amjad Sabri, Famed Sufi Singer, Is Gunned Down in Pakistan
abstract: Mr. Sabri, a prominent singer of Sufi devotional songs, had been named in a blasphemy case, and a wing of the Pakistani Taliban made an unconfirmed claim of responsibility in the killing.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — One of the most prominent Pakistani singers of Sufi devotional songs, Amjad Sabri, was killed by gunmen who fired into his car in Karachi on Wednesday, raising a new outcry over sectarian and extremist violence in Pakistan.

headline: Poignant, Exuberant Photos of Gay Life in the ’70s — Just in Time for Pride
abstract: T shares a selection of images from a show focusing on the post-Stonewall, pre-AIDS decade, on view now at the Leslie-Lohman Museum in SoHo.
lead_paragraph: T shares a selection of images from a show focusing on the post-Stonewall, pre-AIDS decade, on view now at the Leslie-Lohman Museum in SoHo.

headline: Orlando Gunman Excelled at Firing Range Tests, Records Show
abstract: State records show that Omar Mateen repeatedly passed the tests, which he needed to secure a firearms license, with high scores.
lead_paragraph: The gunman who committed the massacre in an Orlando, Fla., nightclub was a skilled marksman who repeatedly passed firing range tests with near-perfect scores, state records released Wednesday showed.

headline: Review: ‘Queen of the South’ Oozes Violence and Excess
abstract: This adaptation of the telenovela “La Reina del Sur” focuses on drugs and a seemingly indestructible lead character.
lead_paragraph: The English-language wing of American television has had a small but steady appetite for telenovela adaptations. “Ugly Betty,” “Devious Maids” and “Jane the Virgin,” based on Colombian, Mexican and Venezuelan originals, have all lasted for multiple seasons in the United States.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Vote Already Has a Winner: The Gambling Industry
abstract: As Britain goes to the polls to determine whether to leave the European Union, bookmakers are anticipating record-setting gambling on the outcome.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ask for his opinion, and David Howe eagerly tells you how he hopes Britain will leave the European Union.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Lauren Molina, Amirah Vann and Michaela Watkins Read Three Essays
abstract: The actresses took part in Werk It, a women’s podcast festival, to read some of our best Modern Love essays, including “What Shamu Taught Me About a Happy Marriage.”
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, three actresses read Modern Love essays as a part of the WNYC Studios Werk It podcast festival, which ran through June 17. The Broadway actress and musician Lauren Molina reads Rosemary Counter’s essay, “A Craigslist ‘Missed Connection’ Lure”; the actress Amirah Vann (“Underground,” “Girls”) reads Elizabeth Fitzsimons’s essay, “My First Lesson in Motherhood”; and the actress Michaela Watkins (“Casual,” “Veep”) reads Amy Sutherland’s essay, “What Shamu Taught Me About a Happy Marriage.”

headline: Democrats Stage Protest on House Floor
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Gun Control', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Democratic lawmakers, led by Representative John Lewis, held a sit-in on the floor of the House chamber on Wednesday morning, demanding a vote on gun control legislation. When Republicans shut off the cameras by calling a recess, the Democrats continued to broadcast on social media.
lead_paragraph: Democratic lawmakers, led by Representative John Lewis, held a sit-in on the floor of the House chamber on Wednesday morning, demanding a vote on gun control legislation. When Republicans shut off the cameras by calling a recess, the Democrats continued to broadcast on social media.

headline: Abortion Pill Orders Rise in 7 Latin American Nations on Zika Alert
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Zika Virus', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Abortion Drugs']
abstract: Orders rose from 36 to 76 percent in nations where the disease is causing babies to be born with tiny heads and damaged brains, a new study says.
lead_paragraph: Orders for abortion pills by women in seven Latin American countries with Zika outbreaks increased after health officials in those countries warned that the virus might cause severe birth defects, according to a women’s organization supplying such pills.

headline: Justices Disclose Privately Paid Trips and Gifts
abstract: Justice Stephen G. Breyer took 19 trips that were paid for by private sponsors, according to a cursory list of trips and gifts to Supreme Court justices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of the Supreme Court took scores of trips paid for by private sponsors last year, according to the financial disclosure forms of eight justices released Wednesday.

headline: Tips on Paying for College
abstract: Students and their families can ease the burden of college costs if they are willing to dive into the financial aid game.
lead_paragraph: Students and parents navigating the college-selection process for the first time may benefit from the advice of experts familiar with college financing.

headline: Bernie Sanders Admits ‘It Doesn’t Appear’ That He’ll Be the Nominee
abstract: Taking a step closer to accepting defeat, the senator said he would still push Hillary Clinton to listen to the “millions of people in this country who supported me.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders came one step closer to accepting defeat on Wednesday, telling C-SPAN in an hourlong interview that he most likely would not be the Democratic presidential nominee.

headline: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Attack Each Other’s Temperament
abstract: The two lobbed similar criticisms at each other, but Mrs. Clinton’s landed more squarely.
lead_paragraph: In dueling speeches this week, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump accused each other of being temperamentally unfit for the presidency. Temperament is a useful concept, a teleprompter-ready euphemism. Someone who is temperamentally unfit to lead the country might be careless, reckless, dangerous — or all three. As Mrs. Clinton said in her speech in Ohio on Tuesday: “Every day, we see how reckless and careless Trump is. He’s proud of it. Well – that’s his choice. Except when he’s asking to be our President. Then it’s our choice.”

headline: Educators Discuss the Future of Higher Education
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Tuition', 'Graduation Rates', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: At a forum held by The New York Times, leading educators discussed teaching a digital generation, college costs and graduation rates.
lead_paragraph: Finding new ways to teach the digital generation, bringing down the cost of a college education and ensuring that more students graduate are among the biggest challenges facing institutions of higher learning today — and meeting those challenges has never been more crucial than it is now.

headline: Watermelon Snow: Not Edible but Important for Climate Change
abstract: A study called for better understanding of potential effects on the climate of red algae that grows on snow in warmer months.
lead_paragraph: Summer is the season to cool off with a big chunk of watermelon. But there’s another kind of watermelon that’ll have you trading in your sandals for hiking boots if you want to experience it. While you’re not going to want to eat what some people call “watermelon snow,” researchers have found that having a better understanding of it could be important in a warming world.

headline: A-Fib Is More Dangerous for Blacks Than Whites
abstract: Atrial fibrillation, an irregular heartbeat associated with various types of cardiovascular problems, is more dangerous in black people than in whites, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: Atrial fibrillation, or A-fib, an irregular heartbeat associated with various types of cardiovascular problems, is more dangerous, and more often fatal, in black people than in whites, a new study has found.

lead_paragraph: Antonio Guzmán makes a living by knowing how to peel the perfect orange. Part of a series about the workers of Jerome Avenue, in the Bronx.

headline: How to Stretch the Summer Solstice
abstract: A fashion pop-up for charity, a Baja East tarot takeover at Brookfield Place, Feit’s first-ever sample sale, and more.
lead_paragraph: It’s officially summer, and the Society Boutique, the Society of Memorial Sloan Kettering’s thrift shop, is teaming up with the luxury fashion e-tailer Halsbrook to stretch the longest day of the year a little longer: a Summer Solstice charity pop-up benefiting the research hospital is open through Thursday with discounts of up to 70 percent on breezy bits like a No. 21 lace-embroidered cotton dress ($321, originally $1,070). At 1440 Third Avenue.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Handbags and Purses']

abstract: Schools seek to balance the conflicts between allowing free expression and maintaining a sensitivity to those offended by language that is deliberatively upsetting.
lead_paragraph: Ask Andrea M. Quenette if she thinks that colleges and universities are doing a good job refereeing the debate over free speech, and she’ll respond with an emphatic ‘no.’

headline: Campus Sexual Assault: A Timeline of Major Events

lead_paragraph: Although the outcry over sexual assault on college campuses has intensified recently, the issue has a long history.

abstract: Catharine Bond Hill has taken steps to increase the number of low-income and first-generation students and military veterans during her decade-long presidency at the liberal arts college.
lead_paragraph: When Catharine Bond Hill walked the campus of Williams College as an undergraduate in the mid-1970s, the “whiteness” of the campus was apparent.

headline: Teaching Professors to Become Better Teachers
abstract: Many colleges are taking steps to help faculty members motivate and engage their students as new technology and research on effective techniques become available.
lead_paragraph: NEW LONDON, Conn. — Between forkfuls of pad Thai, chicken and tofu, 20 Connecticut College faculty members listened as Michael Reder talked about teaching.

headline: With Big Gift, Carnegie to Name Tier of Boxes for Blavatnik Family
abstract: The move comes in recognition of a $25 million gift from Len Blavatnik, a trustee there since 2014, and his family foundation.
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall announced on Wednesday that it was renaming its first level of boxes the Blavatnik Family First Tier in recognition of a $25 million gift from Len Blavatnik, a trustee there since 2014, and his family foundation.

headline: Kodak Black’s ‘Lil B.I.G. Pac’ Wrestles With Hard Choices
abstract: The rapper, who is back in jail, has released a vivid mixtape that spouts bravado but also includes a stark reckoning about his personal choices.
lead_paragraph: Kodak Black, all of 19 years old, works fast. His strong new mixtape, “Lil B.I.G. Pac,” is his fourth, but it arrives an inopportune moment: Kodak Black is in jail, the latest chapter in a string of legal struggles that have pockmarked his otherwise rapid ascent.

headline: Opening India to Foreign Investors
abstract: What are the promises and problems with India's new economic liberalization and what will it mean to the average Indian?

headline: Law Schools Are Going Online to Reach New Students
abstract: Faced with declining enrollment and revenue, law schools are blending classroom and online instruction to try to attract new students.
lead_paragraph: Law schools, in the face of marked declines in enrollment, revenue and jobs for graduates, are beginning to adopt innovative new ways of delivering legal education.

headline: In ‘The Wonder Trail,’ Steve Hely Takes a Comedic Detour
abstract: Mr. Hely, a comedy writer for TV shows including “30 Rock” and “The Office,” travels from Los Angeles to Patagonia, joking all the way.
lead_paragraph: It’s possible that there are lazier travel writers than Steve Hely, whose new book describes going from Los Angeles all the way down the Americas’ western coast to Patagonia, without eliminating the suspicion that he never actually left home. But if you can let Mr. Hely’s joking offset his featherweight work ethic, there aren’t many who make better company.

headline: Revamping Community Colleges to Improve Graduation Rates
abstract: Community colleges across the United States are re-evaluating their curriculums and support structures to address the reasons so many students drop out.
lead_paragraph: Offer students a less confusing array of courses.

headline: Mets Get a Win, and Good News About Syndergaard and Cespedes
abstract: Yoenis Cespedes and Noah Syndergaard left midgame with possible injuries, putting a cloud over the Mets’ win over the Royals. But they received relatively positive results from doctors.
lead_paragraph: Terry Collins did not want to acknowledge the Mets’ latest injury. He was about to walk back to the clubhouse after his postgame news conference when a Mets spokesman reminded him of the reality.

headline: How Public Universities Are Addressing Declines in State Funding
abstract: Educators from the University of California, University of Kansas and University of Wisconsin-Madison discuss ways to raise revenue, lower costs and maintain high standards.
lead_paragraph: Public colleges and universities are grappling with diminishing resources, largely because of significant declines in state funding over the years.

headline: Food Pantries Address a Growing Hunger Problem at Colleges
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Food', 'Food Banks and Pantries', 'Graduate Schools and Students']
abstract: As tuition and the enrollment of low-income students rise, food pantries have become more prevalent, opening on more than 300 campuses.
lead_paragraph: Tucked away in a discreet office at Brooklyn College’s Student Center, beyond the pool tables and wide-screen TVs where her classmates congregate, Rebecca Harmata discovered a lifeline.

headline: On the Front Lines in Falluja
abstract: As Iraqi forces take control of the city, a picture of what life was like under the Islamic State is becoming clearer, though fighting continues.
lead_paragraph: As Iraqi forces take control of the city, a picture of what life was like under the Islamic State is becoming clearer, though fighting continues.

headline: A Tour of Falluja Reveals Grim Remnants of Life Under ISIS
abstract: Iraqi forces liberating the city are finding beheaded bodies, apocalyptic streetscapes and clumps of hair from fighters who shaved to blend in with fleeing civilians. Our reporter describes what he saw.
lead_paragraph: FALLUJA, Iraq — As Iraqi forces move through Falluja, the city is yielding the grim remnants of more than two years of Islamic State rule. Beheaded and decaying bodies. Clumps of facial hair from fighters who shaved their beards to blend in with fleeing civilians. A prison where detainees were held in cages suitable for a medium-sized dog.

headline: What Experts Said at The New York Times Education Conference
abstract: The nation’s top educators exchanged ideas on the future of education at a two-day Higher Ed Leaders Forum sponsored by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s top educators exchanged ideas on the future of education at a two-day Higher Ed Leaders Forum sponsored by The New York Times. Here are some excerpts from the conversations.

headline: Giving Young People an Alternative to College
abstract: In the next decade, as many as 25 million new job openings will be middle-skills positions that will not necessarily require a four-year degree.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 40 percent of American workers hold a bachelor’s degree. College graduates are found in virtually every profession: 15 percent of mail carriers have a four-year degree, as do one in five clerical and sales workers and 83,000 bartenders.

headline: Teaching Inclusion in a Divided World
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Constitution (US)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: To protect American values and promote civic discourse, universities need to show that disagreement is not oppression and argument is not assault.
lead_paragraph: One of the most difficult intellectual and emotional challenges I faced earlier this year at Yale was finding an answer to a Native American student’s poignant question: Why should she put any faith in institutions in our society — including our judicial system and universities – when those institutions had clearly betrayed her people in generations past?

headline: College Unaffordable Even in Higher Income Brackets
abstract: Rising tuition and fewer funds for public universities have priced even some of the upper middle class out of a college education.
lead_paragraph: College is becoming less and less affordable to more and more families higher and higher on the socioeconomic ladder.

headline: Learning to Educate an Increasingly Diverse Nation
abstract: With minorities making up a majority of America’s student body, it is vital for places of higher education to train faculties in teaching and diversity issues.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, for the first time, the nation’s student body — from kindergartners to 12th graders — was majority-minority. And the change is spilling out into the nation’s colleges and the country over all.

headline: Student Success Is a Community Responsibility
abstract: Young people need adults who can support them in their pursuit of college degrees by setting expectations and helping them develop a sense of self.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I visited my hometown, Birmingham, Ala., to recognize high-achieving eighth graders from the city’s public schools. I found myself reflecting on my own experiences as a 12-year-old in that city, participating in the Children’s March of 1963 to fight for access to a better education. As I sat there, I kept wondering: Just how far have we come?

headline: Review: Barbara Cook, a Lioness Who Still Has Some Bite Left
abstract: At 88, Ms. Cook holds forth at Feinstein’s/54 Below in both song and word. She channels the wisdom and humanity of the American songbook.
lead_paragraph: As Barbara Cook concluded a dreamy rendition of “Send in the Clowns” at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Tuesday night, a wave of love swept through the club, where she had come to promote her just-published autobiography, “Then and Now: A Memoir.” Here for a moment was the Barbara Cook her fans know and love, conveying the emotional essence of a great song with her customary generosity. As though waving an invisible wand, she evoked a profound mixture of resignation, reassurance and understanding.

headline: Starlin Castro’s Walk-Off Homer Lifts Yankees Over the Rockies
abstract: The Yankees took a 4-0 lead with an early grand slam but had to rally from a four-run deficit to beat the Rockies.
lead_paragraph: As Starlin Castro rounded third base, his eyes were fixed on his Yankees teammates, who had gathered around home plate ready to mob him after his home run leading off the ninth inning capped a 9-8 comeback win over the Colorado Rockies on Wednesday at Yankee Stadium.

headline: Give More Low-Income Students a Path to College
abstract: A report found that just one in 10 people from low-income families had a bachelor’s degree by age 25, compared with half of those from high-income families.
lead_paragraph: For most of its history, America ignored the talents and potential of most Americans. We will never know what great progress might have been made in science, medicine, business and many other fields if we had taken advantage of the brainpower and abilities of all our people — regardless of gender, race, ethnicity or income level.

headline: No Light Between Diversity and Free Expression
abstract: Our campuses must be places where students can learn from those of different races, ethnicities and beliefs and do so with genuine openness.
lead_paragraph: It is a mistake to say that diversity and free expression cannot coexist. And yet, this academic year, on campus after campus, that has been the choice served up: You are either for diversity, equity and inclusion in our communities, or you are for free expression. The strength of our communities depends upon a commitment to upholding both, perhaps especially when that is hardest to do so.

headline: Reforming Rape Policies on Campus
abstract: Universities’ response to sexual assault demands a focus on their core mission: providing education in a way that does not discriminate based on sex.
lead_paragraph: Campus rape is finally receiving the attention it merits. But efforts to address the problem are developing in too scattershot a fashion, largely because of widespread confusion about the role of the university in responding to sexual assault.

headline: Today’s Students May Be Emotionally Unprepared
abstract: College students are facing more stress than their parents did, and the resultant anxiety and depression are worrisome to educators and policy makers.
lead_paragraph: Regardless of all the honors classes and A.P. courses they took in high school, or the science, technology and engineering classes they cram into their college curriculum, students today will not be fully prepared to compete in an increasingly global business environment.

headline: Higher Education at a Crossroads
abstract: Much like American educators of the 1960s, those of today must ask themselves how they can best serve students who face an array of challenges.
lead_paragraph: With student activism sweeping the country over issues that include sexual assault, police brutality and racial inequality, American higher education is at a crossroads, as it was in the 1960s when college students were galvanized by the Vietnam War and the civil rights movement.

headline: Season 4 of ‘Orange Is the New Black’: It’s About Time
abstract: The series, available in its entirety on Netflix, is focused on serving time and counting time, and with ideas on the prison-industrial complex.
lead_paragraph: The following essay discusses plot points throughout Season 4 of “Orange Is the New Black,” available in its entirety on Netflix.

headline: Making the Case for More Than Just STEM
abstract: The writer says the humanities encourage schoolchildren to solve problems creatively, a skill not fostered solely through science and technology.
lead_paragraph: One of the most important issues that educators in institutions of higher learning must face is skepticism about the efficacy of liberal arts education in an era that seems to be pushing what educators call STEM — science, technology, engineering and math — as the answer to everything. This is not just happening in the United States, of course. Calls to cut support for students who want to study literature, history or other so-called soft disciplines are also made in Europe and Asia.

headline: Lightening the Load of Student Loan Debt
abstract: Students who educate themselves so they may educate others should not have to graduate with heavy debt.
lead_paragraph: For people who choose educating others over enriching themselves, college debt can seem insurmountable — because it is insurmountable. To cultivate a well-educated, globally competitive American work force, we must make college affordable.

headline: Teacher and Tech: Making the Most of Learning Technologies
abstract: In education, learning technologies are only as helpful as the teachers and principals who use them.
lead_paragraph: Learning technologies offer great potential to improve education, but whether that potential will be realized depends on three key factors, which have less to do with technology itself and more to do with the people using it.

headline: Taking On the Challenge of College Completion
abstract: While it is student debt that often draws headlines, the related challenge of ensuring that students graduate deserves greater attention.
lead_paragraph: The $1.2 trillion that borrowers and their parents owe on student loans for college is an eye-popping number — one that some policy analysts, pundits and journalists often cite in declaring a student loan crisis.

headline: Affirmative Action as a Tool for a Racially Integrated Society
abstract: Preserving the consideration of race in college admissions is critical, but a broader view of the issue is necessary.
lead_paragraph: A decision by the Supreme Court overturning its 2003 ruling in Grutter v. Bollinger and ending the ability of universities and colleges to consider race as one among several factors informing “holistic” admissions decisions would be far-reaching in its harm.

headline: Robert Cox, Man Behind the ‘Just Say No’ Antidrug Campaign, Dies at 78
abstract: He was also responsible for the Amtrak “All aboard” slogan, and Ford’s “Quality is Job 1.”
lead_paragraph: Robert Cox, a leading New York advertising executive who helped transform “Just Say No” into the slogan of Nancy Reagan’s crusade against illegal drugs, died on Saturday at his home in Sherman, Conn. He was 78.

headline: Postcard From Shanghai Disney: China’s Mirror on the Wall
abstract: After riding the Seven Dwarfs Mine Train with her family, Didi Kirsten Tatlow wonders, Who do these 7 near-identically dressed men remind me of?
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this article, Didi Kirsten Tatlow, a Beijing-based Times correspondent, takes her family to Shanghai and shares what happens when The Magic Kingdom meets The Middle Kingdom.

headline: N.F.L. Is Teaming With Cirque du Soleil to Draw New Fans
abstract: The two high-flying acts will open an interactive exhibit and theater in Times Square next year.
lead_paragraph: Cirque du Soleil, known for breathtaking acrobatics, and the N.F.L., known for bone-crushing hits, are joining forces in the latest iteration of the sports world’s race for young and international fans. Together, they will open an interactive exhibit and theater in the heart of Manhattan next year.

headline: Commuting on No-Money Thursday
abstract: She promised herself she would not spend anything that day, but New York traffic wears down even the best intentions.

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In an era of unprecedented scrutiny of automotive safety, Fiat Chrysler is learning that one celebrity’s death can turn a seemingly routine recall into a corporate crisis.

headline: Twilio I.P.O. Raises $150 Million
abstract: Twilio’s offering, the largest but only the third of technology stock debuts this year, was a test of the market.
lead_paragraph: Twilio, which makes software that helps companies such as Uber and Nordstrom communicate with their customers, raised $150 million in an initial public offering that priced late Wednesday, the largest within the technology sector so far this year.

headline: Grand Cherokee Product Placement Becomes Awkward for Fox
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Movies', 'Product Placement', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: The S.U.V. featured in “Independence Day: Resurgence,” has gained notoriety after being involved in a crash that killed the actor Anton Yelchin.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood product-placement deals are often wince-worthy. But the reason is usually not because of events beyond a studio’s control.

headline: Copa América: After U.S. Is Thrashed, Coach Asks for More
abstract: Jurgen Klinsmann said after a 4-0 loss to Argentina that the only way for his players to learn is to keep taking on top teams.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — For some of the thousands of American soccer fans who steadfastly chanted, “U-S-A! Newscasts showed South Vietnamese desperately trying to scale the walls of our embassy in Saigon to board the last helicopter flights out of the country. The fear in their eyes was chilling. Many of these Vietnamese had assisted the American mission. As the North Vietnamese advanced on the city, these people knew that they faced a harsh fate if they were left behind.

headline: Cynthia Ozick’s Long Crusade
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The author is considered one of the greatest fiction writers and critics alive today. At 88, she shows no signs of slowing down.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1978, the literary critic Harold Bloom was invited to take part in “an amiable discussion of the rival claims of Judaism and the aesthetic” at the Jewish Museum in Manhattan. His interlocutor was to be Cynthia Ozick, the author, at the time, of three well-reviewed but not-much-read works of fiction. Bloom, who had never met Ozick but rated her novellas “Envy; or, Yiddish in America” and “Usurpation (Other People’s Stories)” as “unequaled in her generation,” agreed to participate with the understanding that neither of them was to read from a prepared text.

headline: Annie Proulx: By the Book

headline: Review: ‘Swiss Army Man’ Is a Buddy Movie in Which One Pal Is Dead
abstract: Starring Daniel Radcliffe and Paul Dano, this impossible-to-categorize film about a castaway and a corpse is an original mix of the macabre and the magical.
lead_paragraph: Weird and wonderful, disgusting and demented, “Swiss Army Man” is about how one man’s dead body nudges another man back to life. Impossible to categorize, this stunningly original mix of the macabre and the magical combines comedy, tragedy, fantasy and love story into an utterly singular package that’s beholden to no rules but its own.

headline: 1916: Arabs Revolt Against Turkey
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The beginning of the Arab revolt against the Ottoman Empire in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Latest advice dealing with the revolt of the Arabs, under the Shereef of Mecca, against Turkish rule, go to show that the disaffection is more widespread than first accounts indicated, and should the capture of the sacred cities of Mecca, Jeddah and Taif encourage the remainder of the Arabs throughout the Ottoman dominions to overthrow the Sultan’s authority, the Turkish Government will find itself faced with insurmountable difficulties, and German intrigue will have sustained a crushing blow. —The New York Herald, European Edition, June 24, 1916

headline: The Gospel Singer Mavis Staples to Get Kennedy Center Honor

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The gospel singer Mavis Staples has toured the world with her family as part of the Staple Singers, sang for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at the height of the civil rights movement, spent weeks on the Billboard charts, experienced a midcareer resurgence in the 1980s thanks largely to Prince, and once turned down a marriage proposal from Bob Dylan. Now the soon to be 77-year-old will be a Kennedy Center honoree, the second gospel singer, after Marion Williams in 1993, to be recognized in the awards’ history.

Now, it’s planning its next hot-potato exhibition: “Home Land Security,” a group show on the human costs of war and nationalism, to take place in deactivated military structures in the Presidio national park near the foot of the Golden Gate Bridge.

headline: Why The New York Times is Working With Matter
abstract: The New York Times, to me, has always manifested a masterful balance of innovation and tradition. So it’s exciting to be partnering with Matter Ventures for their inaugural Matter NYC class. We’re looking forward to learning from others and to sharing our own expertise.
lead_paragraph: For years I’ve followed the progress of Matter Ventures, the San Francisco-based media accelerator run by Corey Ford. I can no longer remember exactly how I was introduced to Matter and to Corey, but I do remember the first demo day that I attended a few years ago, at an event space associated with WNYC. Somehow I had gotten an invitation, but I was on the fence about whether to go. I had recently started in a new role, and was feeling pressed for time. In the end, I went, mostly because an engineering lead I was trying to hire was likely to be there and I was hoping to stalk him in his natural habitat.
