keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Batteries', 'Solar Energy']
abstract: Whether Elon Musk’s “vertically integrated energy company” is the right model, some experts see virtue in the theory.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a world in which every home and building is a miniature power plant, with solar panels on the roofs and electric vehicles and stationary battery banks in the garages.

headline: Who Is a Jew? Maybe Not Woman Converted by Esteemed New York Rabbi
abstract: An American convert engaged to an Israeli was turned down by a local rabbinical court when she tried to register for marriage.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Critics of Israel’s chief rabbinate have long complained that scores of American converts to Judaism have trouble getting approval to marry in Israel. Now, one such case with a celebrity connection could break open the rabbinate’s longstanding secrecy over which foreign rabbis are approved to conduct conversions.

headline: Brooklyn Park’s Gift: Diversity
abstract: Two Brooklyn residents say of Brooklyn Bridge Park: “We believe that the diversity the park brings only enriches our two young boys’ lives.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In “Punk Weekender,” a Spotlight on Women of the Punk Scene
abstract: Photographs from Anita Corbin, Derek Ridgers and more are on view at the Photographers’ Gallery in London.
lead_paragraph: Photographs from Anita Corbin, Derek Ridgers and more are on view at the Photographers’ Gallery in London.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling on Police Stops
abstract: A law professor writes that the court’s decision “renders vast numbers of citizens vulnerable to an unlawful stop by the police.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In London, a Celebration of All Things Punk
abstract: This weekend welcomes “Punk Weekender,” a three-day event incorporating exhibitions, screenings and a performance marking 40 years since the subculture’s birth.
lead_paragraph: “Punk itself was about being on the cutting edge of anything new,” says the photographer Anita Corbin, whose portraits of women in the punk scene are on show at the Photographers’ Gallery in London this weekend. “So if you could shock people by wearing ripped tights and piercing your mouth — that would be a great statement to show the authorities that we were young and we weren’t too innocent anymore.”

headline: Paul Giamatti, a Baseball Commissioner’s Son, Makes His Own Calls
abstract: Mr. Giamatti, star of the new baseball film “The Phenom,” isn’t much of a sports fan. But don’t get him started on Bob Stanley of the Red Sox.
lead_paragraph: You might think that as the son of the former Major League Baseball commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti and as a star of the new national-pastime-theme drama “The Phenom” (due in theaters and on video on demand on Friday), Paul Giamatti would be a baseball aficionado. But Mr. Giamatti, who plays a sports psychologist trying to help a tormented pitching prospect (Johnny Simmons) work through a mental block, said that was not the case. “I’m not a big sports fan, but I like sports movies,” he said. Still, he took a swing at some baseball questions during a recent interview at the Jue Lan Club in Manhattan. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: What Old Monkeys and Old Humans Have in Common
abstract: Monkeys get more picky about certain relationships with age, suggesting biological origins to similar behavior in distantly-related humans.
lead_paragraph: Humans spend less time monkeying around as they get older, and according to a study published Thursday, so do monkeys.

headline: A Civil Rights Legacy
abstract: The brother of Andrew Goodman, one of the slain activists in Mississippi in 1964, asks us to “fulfill the dream of a just democratic process for all.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 1952 | ‘Eisenhower,’ a True Campaign Logo
abstract: The Times faced a quandary in 1952: a Republican presidential candidate named Eisenhower and no possibility of calling him “Ike.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David W. Dunlap, a Metro reporter, looks back at a typographical quandary introduced by Dwight D. Eisenhower’s presidential campaign.

headline: A New Restaurant for (and of) the Berlin Art Scene
abstract: Panama opens today on a gallery-filled street, and with its own set of works.
lead_paragraph: There is a much-loved German children’s book from the ’70s called “Oh, wie schön ist Panama” (Oh, how beautiful Panama is) about a little bear and tiger who live in a tiny cabin by a river and forage for fresh fish and mushrooms. One day, an empty crate smelling of bananas and stamped with the word “Panama” floats by, convincing the pair that Panama must be the land of their dreams. So they set out — and, on the way, meet all sorts of characters. Eventually a crow advises them to climb a high tree in an attempt to spot the land of their dreams from above. At the top, they marvel at the amazing view and see an abandoned cabin by a river. They decide that the spot is so beautiful that it must be Panama. What they don’t realize is that it is their old home. So they wander back, fix it up, add a sofa, and live there happily ever after.

headline: Should Your Driverless Car Hit a Pedestrian to Save Your Life?
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Research', 'Artificial Intelligence', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: Surveys show that people generally believe autonomous vehicles should make an emergency decision for the greatest good — except if it might kill them.
lead_paragraph: People say that one day, perhaps in the not-so-distant future, they’d like to be passengers in self-driving cars that are mindful machines doing their best for the common good. Merge politely. Watch for pedestrians in the crosswalk. Keep a safe space.

headline: Ad From Trump Ally, Citing ’90s Scandals, Depicts Hillary Clinton as Anti-Woman
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Political Action Committees', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton is shown in the screen’s left corner, as a female narrator intones: “So who is all for women, until she isn’t? Hillary Clinton.”
lead_paragraph: An aggressive new ad from Rebuilding America Now, a “super PAC” supporting Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign, tries to paint Hillary Clinton, his presumptive Democratic opponent, as anti-woman.

headline: Ruling on Caesar R. Goodson Jr. Charges in Freddie Gray Case
abstract: The Baltimore police officer who drove the van in which Freddie Gray sustained a fatal spinal injury was acquitted on Thursday of second-degree murder and six lesser charges.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore police officer who drove the van in which Freddie Gray sustained a fatal spinal injury was acquitted on Thursday of second-degree murder and six lesser charges.

headline: Photography’s Shifting Identity in an Insta-World
abstract: In “Public, Private, Secret,” a stimulating and unsettling exhibition, the International Center of Photography embraces a new orientation.
lead_paragraph: The International Center of Photography is back, and welcome. Two years after losing its Midtown Manhattan quarters, the center has reopened on the Bowery, across from the New Museum. The duplex galleries, on street and basement levels, are, technically, larger than the old ones, though they feel boxy and closed-in, at least for the opening show, “Public, Private, Secret.” As if to offset this impression, the show gives evidence that the center’s view of photography itself has expanded.

headline: Adele’s ‘25’ Finally Comes to Streaming Services
abstract: Seven months after its release, the album will be available on Spotify, Tidal and Apple Music in full for the first time.
lead_paragraph: After seven months and many, many millions of albums sold, Adele’s “25” is finally coming to streaming services.

headline: Affirmative Action in College Admissions, Here to Stay
keywords: ['Segregation and Desegregation', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION']
abstract: The Supreme Court’s ruling on a University of Texas policy means the constitutionality of race-consciousness in admitting students is settled.
lead_paragraph: THE Supreme Court’s decision upholding the admissions policy of the University of Texas is a huge victory for supporters of affirmative action, and the most deceptive thing about it is its first words: “Justice Kennedy delivered the opinion of the court.”

headline: Take the Learning Network Survey. Tell Us What You Think.
abstract: Before you pack up and head out to wherever this summer will be taking you, we’d be grateful if you’d take a few minutes and fill out our survey.
lead_paragraph: Dear Readers,

headline: Senate Votes to Keep Gun Proposal Alive, but in Limbo
abstract: A compromise measure to block gun sales to terrorism suspects had emerged as the one piece of legislation since the Orlando massacre with a chance of passing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate voted on Thursday to keep a proposal to block gun sales to terrorism suspects alive, but placed it in a procedural limbo that made its adoption unlikely anytime soon.

headline: Corey Lewandowski, Ex-Campaign Manager for Donald Trump, Joins CNN
abstract: Mr. Lewandowski, who was fired on Monday amid concerns about the campaign’s financial and organizational status, has been hired as a political commentator.
lead_paragraph: Corey Lewandowski, the former campaign manager for Donald J. Trump, is joining CNN as a political commentator, effective immediately, a spokeswoman for the network said Thursday.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto: Spring 2017
abstract: The label’s spring 2017 collection.
lead_paragraph: The label’s spring 2017 collection.

headline: Led Zeppelin Did Not Steal ‘Stairway to Heaven,’ Jury Says
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Music']
abstract: A federal jury said the hit song did not contain enough similarities to “Taurus,” a song released three years earlier by the band Spirit.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s long, it’s classic and, a jury decided on Thursday, it’s an original.

headline: Chaos in the House Over Gun Control
abstract: “Selfish cowards” is how one reader describes politicians who oppose stricter gun rules. Another finds the Democratic sit-in to be childish behavior.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Donald Trump to Convert $50 Million Loan Into a Contribution
abstract: The decision fulfills a pledge he made last month and may stem talk that he would seek to use campaign donations to recoup his out-of-pocket costs.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump announced on Thursday that he would convert $50 million that he had lent to his presidential campaign into a contribution, fulfilling a pledge he made in mid-May.

headline: ‘The Humans’ Will Stay on Broadway but Switch Theaters
abstract: The Tony-winning play will have its final performance at the Helen Hayes Theater on July 24, then start again at the Gerald Schoenfeld on Aug. 9.
lead_paragraph: “The Humans,” which recently won the Tony Award for best new play, will take the unusual step of changing theaters to extend its run.

headline: Bank of America to Pay $415 Million to Settle S.E.C. Inquiry
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The regulator accused the bank’s Merrill Lynch business of misusing billions of dollars of client money to finance its own trades.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission will examine the brokerage industry for potential violations in the way companies handle customer cash after the regulator reached a $415 million settlement with Bank of America. The S.E.C. found the bank’s Merrill Lynch to have misused billions of dollars of client money to finance its own trades.

headline: Dior Is Expected to Name Maria Grazia Chiuri as Artistic Director
abstract: In a move that will cause major disruption in the fashion landscape, the Valentino co-creative director is changing brands.
lead_paragraph: Christian Dior has finally found its designer.

headline: N.H.L.’s Warm-Weather Outposts Produce Some Hot Prospects
abstract: Friday’s N.H.L. draft will include Auston Matthews, who grew up watching the Coyotes in Arizona, and Jakob Chychrun of Florida.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Once upon a time, N.H.L. origin stories resounded, like a slap shot in an empty arena, with familiar tropes. They started on, say, frozen ponds and backyard rinks in Boston or Toronto, Detroit or Minneapolis. South meant St. Louis. West was Alberta and British Columbia.

headline: The Supreme Court Has Upheld Affirmative Action. So Let’s Dump Mismatch Theory.
abstract: Now that Texas’ plan has been upheld, we should finally move on from the idea that such policies harm minority students.
lead_paragraph: NOW that the Supreme Court has upheld affirmative action in its second Fisher v. University of Texas decision, the debate over the “mismatch” theory — the idea that affirmative action harms minorities by admitting students to challenging schools where they cannot succeed — should also be put to rest.

headline: Men’s Fashion Shows: Balenciaga, Lemaire and Walter van Beirendonck
abstract: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented on Wednesday.

headline: Justice Department Reaches Deal With Mississippi County on Prison Reform
abstract: The settlement with Hinds County requires, for the first time, a local government to provide an array of options intended to reduce mass incarceration.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department announced on Thursday that it had reached an agreement with a Mississippi county that, for the first time, requires a local government to provide an array of options intended to reduce mass incarceration. It includes programs offering alternatives to jail, re-entry services for inmates leaving incarceration and the prohibition of some jail sentences for failure to pay court-ordered fines and fees.

headline: How Has Food Shaped Your Identity?
abstract: The New York Times would like to hear from readers about how cooking has influenced their identity.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times would like to hear from readers about how cooking has influenced their identity.

headline: Reaction to Court Immigration Ruling
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Outside the Supreme Court on Thursday, protesters expressed disappointment with a ruling that blocked President Obama’s plan to allow some illegal immigrants to work legally.
lead_paragraph: Outside the Supreme Court on Thursday, protesters expressed disappointment with a ruling that blocked President Obama’s plan to allow some illegal immigrants to work legally.

headline: ‘Catastrophic’ Conditions Reported in Camp for People Fleeing Boko Haram
abstract: Doctors Without Borders said nearly 200 people died of malnutrition and illness since May 23 in northeastern Nigeria. Boko Haram attacks have displaced millions.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Nearly 200 people who fled Boko Haram attacks have died of malnutrition and sickness in a single camp in northeastern Nigeria in the past month, the medical charity Doctors Without Borders said on Thursday, describing a “catastrophic humanitarian emergency.”

headline: Supreme Court Decision on Affirmative Action Cheered by College Admissions Experts
keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Colleges and Universities', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION']
abstract: After the Supreme Court upheld a University of Texas admission plan that considers factors like race and diversity, college officials praised the decision.
lead_paragraph: College admissions experts breathed a sigh of relief on Thursday when the Supreme Court upheld a University of Texas admissions plan that allows race and ethnicity to be considered as one of many factors in admission.

headline: The Queens of Dish
abstract: Scenes from the Sunday Drag Brunch at Señor Frog’s in Times Square.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Sunday Drag Brunch at Señor Frog’s in Times Square.

headline: 36 Hours in Valencia, Spain
abstract: Artistic and culinary innovation continue to transform every corner of this perpetually sunny city.
lead_paragraph: Artistic and culinary innovation continue to transform every corner of this perpetually sunny city.

headline: ‘Leave’ Takes the Lead as Britain Awaits Outcome of E.U. Referendum
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The vote on Britain’s continued membership in the European Union sent currency traders scrambling and the pound first up and then down.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Supporters of a British exit from the European Union opened up a substantial lead over advocates of staying in the bloc as the nation tallied the votes early Friday on one of its most momentous decisions in generations.

headline: Buybacks by Companies Like Apple May Signal Danger, Not Growth
keywords: ['Corporations', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: When companies funnel money into their own shares, earnings per share look better, but the buybacks can siphon money away from investments in innovation.
lead_paragraph: IPhone sales are down and Apple has run into obstacles in China, its second-most-important market. Investors have beaten down Apple’s once highflying shares this year, and the company’s troubles have been a drag on the entire stock market.

headline: 1930s Travel Films by the “Park Avenue Cubists”
abstract: Newly restored videos of the abstract-artist couple Suzy Frelinghuysen and George L.K. Morris’s trips around the world are now on view at their Berkshires home.
lead_paragraph: Newly restored videos of the abstract-artist couple Suzy Frelinghuysen and George L.K. Morris’s trips around the world are now on view at their Berkshires home.

headline: Review: Matthew McConaughey Rebels Against Rebels in ‘Free State of Jones’
abstract: Mr. McConaughey plays Newton Knight, the Mississippi farmer who led a dissident Confederate group in the Civil War, and a political coalition after.
lead_paragraph: “Free State of Jones” begins on the battlefield, with a flurry of the kind of immersive combat action that has long been a staple of American movies. The setting is familiar in other ways, too. As a line of Confederate troops marches across a field into Union rifle and artillery fire, a haze of myth starts to gather over the action, a mist of sentiment about the tragedy of the Civil War and the symmetrical valor of the soldiers on both sides of it. But this is a sly piece of misdirection: The rest of the movie will be devoted to blowing that fog away, using the tools of Hollywood spectacle to restore a measure of clarity to our understanding of the war and its aftermath.

headline: My Undocumented Mom, America’s Housekeeper
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Domestic Service', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums']
abstract: The Supreme Court lets immigrants down once again.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the earliest memories I have in New York City is of scrubbing toilets alongside my mother. She worked as a housekeeper for wealthy families and because she could not afford a babysitter, she would often take me with her. I would do my homework while catching glimpses of my mother as she was dusting television sets or folding bedsheets in homes that we would visit once a week.

headline: Vintage 1930s Travel Films, Taken by the Berkshires’ Most Creative Couple
abstract: This summer, newly restored videos of the artists George L.K. Morris and Suzy Frelinghuysen’s journeys can be seen at their Bauhaus home.
lead_paragraph: Beyond the quaint center of Lenox, Mass., past Gilded Age Berkshire cottages and down a winding, tree-lined path, a bright white stucco and glass building stands out against the pines: the Frelinghuysen Morris House & Studio. Built 75 years ago, the Bauhaus structure was home to George L.K. Morris and Suzy Frelinghuysen, an artist couple often referred to as “Park Avenue Cubists.” Morris and Frelinghuysen met in 1933 during intermission at the Metropolitan Opera, when Morris hummed arias and challenged Frelinghuysen — who would go on to join the New York City Opera as dramatic soprano in 1947 — to name the tunes. (She guessed each correctly.) In 1935 they married, and in 1941 moved into their Modernist home on a 46-acre Lenox estate, filling each room with works by Picasso, Léger, Braque and Gris, and their own abstract frescoes and paintings.

headline: Why Do We Inherit Mitochondrial DNA Only From Our Mothers?
abstract: New research investigates why paternal mitochondria perish in embryos.
lead_paragraph: For a long time, biologists thought our DNA resided only in the control center of our cells, the nucleus.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Spring 2017
abstract: Spring men’s looks from the Belgian fashion designer.
lead_paragraph: Spring men’s looks from the Belgian fashion designer.

headline: Review: ‘Yarn’: And You Thought It Was Just for Knitting Mittens
abstract: This documentary looks in on people working in yarn, from artists making graffiti to those fashioning playground structures.
lead_paragraph: You have almost certainly never seen a better documentary about yarn than “Yarn.” It isn’t perfect — it’s a little too airy and artsy in spots — but still, thread and string should be jealous.

headline: A Year After the Same-Sex Marriage Ruling, How Goes It, Newlyweds?
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The anniversary of the court decision is on June 26. If you got married as a result of the ruling, we invite you to share your story.
lead_paragraph: The anniversary of the court decision is on June 26. If you got married as a result of the ruling, we invite you to share your story.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Big, Boxy Shoulders
abstract: At Gosha Rubchinskiy, Balenciaga and Dolce & Gabbana, silhouettes grow to exaggerated proportions.
lead_paragraph: Squared-off, strong-shouldered jackets have been all over the runways this season. First, they showed up in Gosha Rubchinskiy’s grown-up collection in Florence — a sort of homage to American Gigolo-era suits — and made up the bulk of Demna Gvasalia’s debut Balenciaga men’s show in Paris, where the silhouette was further exaggerated with narrow bottoms. Elsewhere, in Milan, we saw Dolce & Gabbana reinterpret its classic suiting with a ’50s jazz influence, as in this oversize double-breasted jacket and cropped trousers. The look teeters somewhere between “Stop Making Sense”-era David Byrne and Uncle Fester Addams — not one for everyone, to say the least.

headline: It’s Gay Pride Weekend: Dress the Part
abstract: The annual parade and PrideFest are the main events for gay pride in New York, but there’s another way to celebrate: an all-drag weekend.
lead_paragraph: IS it O.K. to cry at a drag show? That’s what drag artists and their fans have been asking in the aftermath of the massacre at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla., this month. For the drag queen Sasha Velour, tears make drag about more than a funny man in a dress.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘The Neon Demon’
abstract: Nicolas Winding Refn narrates a sequence from “The Neon Demon," starring Elle Fanning.
lead_paragraph: Nicolas Winding Refn narrates a sequence from “The Neon Demon," starring Elle Fanning.

headline: Nicolas Winding Refn Narrates a Scene From ‘The Neon Demon’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film featuring Elle Fanning.
lead_paragraph: In Nicolas Winding Refn’s dark drama “The Neon Demon,” a young woman (Elle Fanning) has dreams of becoming a model in the cutthroat fashion world in Los Angeles. In a recent interview, Mr. Refn discussed this scene featuring Ms. Fanning, Abbey Lee as a competitive model and Alessandro Nivola as a fashion designer. Here are edited excerpts from that discussion.

headline: Nation’s Biggest Banks Would All Withstand Recession, Fed Says
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In its annual stress tests, the Fed looked at how America’s 33 largest banks would do in a recession with sustained high unemployment and negative interest rates.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s biggest banks have all built up big enough buffers to weather a severe recession in decent shape, United States regulators said on Thursday.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Art in review, from Times critics.

headline: Review: ‘T-Rex’ Fights Like a Girl. And That’s Worth Gold.
abstract: Claressa Shields, the first female boxer to win an Olympic gold medal, is the indomitable center of Drea Cooper and Zackary Canepari’s impressive documentary.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to be a boxing fan to be awed by Claressa Shields, the first woman to win an Olympic gold medal in the sport. But if you are, you’ll still be knocked out. Ms. Shields — the indomitable center of Drea Cooper and Zackary Canepari’s impressive documentary “T-Rex” — is an American sports phenomenon. (The title derives from her sobriquet in the ring.) A native of Flint, Mich., Ms. Shields found her calling at 11, when her steady and paternal coach Jason Crutchfield began her training. Mr. Crutchfield, a former pro, had always dreamed of cultivating a future champion. But, he says, “I never thought it’d be a girl.”

headline: Bank Report Card: Part One
abstract: Even with $526 billion losses, stress tests found that all of the big banks would remain in relatively good financial health.
lead_paragraph: Even with $526 billion losses, stress tests found that all of the big banks would remain in relatively good financial health.

headline: Review: In ‘The Phenom,’ Landing on the Couch for Losing the Strike Zone
abstract: A baseball movie with little baseball, this film asks: When a hot pitching prospect melts down, can an overzealous parent be far behind?
lead_paragraph: “The Phenom” is a baseball movie with virtually no baseball, which would be fine if the thing it relied on instead — lots and lots of talking — exhibited zest and originality. It doesn’t.

headline: Review: ‘Septembers of Shiraz’ Revisits the 1979 Iranian Revolution
abstract: This well-meaning yet nuance-free film focuses on a prosperous and friendly couple targeted for harassment during political upheaval.
lead_paragraph: If the script of “Septembers of Shiraz” looked anything like the film sounds, each sentence would be printed in bold, increased to an extra-large font and thrice underlined. At least that’s how most scenes play out in this well-meaning yet nuance-free film.

headline: Review: In ‘The Kind Words,’ Siblings and a Secret
abstract: This film, by the Israeli writer and director Shemi Zarhin, follows a family looking to uncover buried truths.
lead_paragraph: In “The Kind Words,” Dorona (Rotem Zisman -Cohen) has given up trying to become a mother after a series of miscarriages. Fertility mocks her at every turn. Her brother Natanel (Roy Assaf) has triplets, and their little brother, Shai (Assaf Ben-Shimon), has a child with a woman in Hungary, although these days he dates men. Even their mother (Levana Finkelstein) looks pregnant, with a huge tumor she manages to deny. And the way dances around her Jerusalem apartment, singing along to a scratchy old LP, you would never know that a delicate surgery lies ahead, or that her husband has dumped her for a young, pouty-lipped singer.

headline: A Comeback for Gabby Douglas at Age 20. That’s Gymnastics.
abstract: Four years later and about three inches taller, Douglas is trying to return to the Olympics to defend her all-around title. She knows it won’t be easy.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — When asked to pick the best moment of her life since becoming the Olympic all-around champion four years ago, Gabby Douglas had to stop and think.

headline: Review: In ‘Breaking a Monster,’ a Plea to Play Heavy Metal
abstract: As three black seventh-graders from Brooklyn rise as potential music stars in this documentary, they must face much more than the music.
lead_paragraph: There’s more than one scene in “Breaking a Monster” — Luke Meyer’s patchily revelatory documentary about the Brooklyn heavy-metal band Unlocking the Truth — that could make viewers uncomfortable. It’s not that the subjects, three black seventh graders whose musical style is primarily enjoyed by white audiences, are working a gimmick. Neither are they simply naïve children in the grip of possibly greedy adults. These youngsters are sharp; they know exactly where their talent lies and what they want to do with it.

headline: Review: ‘Eat That Question,’ on Frank Zappa, the Media and Cultural Upheavals
abstract: A documentary about Zappa is rich in archival interviews that say worlds about this musician — who was well known but not well understood — and his times.
lead_paragraph: On “The Daily Show,” especially in Jon Stewart’s early years, correspondents perfected the art of the punk sit-down, in which the interviewees seemed not to realize that the interviewers were mocking them. There’s a mirror image of that dynamic, and it’s on delightful display in “Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words.”

headline: ‘Disguise: Masks and Global African Art,’ Where Tradition Meets Avant-Garde
abstract: This show at the Brooklyn Museum features 25 artists who are African or of African descent, whose work incorporates historical influences but also contemporary twists.
lead_paragraph: African masks had an enormous influence on the development of Modern art, as luminaries like Picasso, Matisse and Giacometti appropriated and interpreted their startling forms and materials. But what about modern artists of African descent? Do they have a distinct relationship of their own to that history? That’s a question raised, if not definitively answered, by “Disguise: Masks and Global African Art,” an intermittently edifying and generally entertaining exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: Review: ‘From This Day Forward’ Attests to Love’s Adaptability
abstract: Sharon Shattuck’s documentary tells her family story of growing up with a transgender parent.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Shattuck’s gently winning documentary “From This Day Forward,” an account of having a transgender parent, is effective for what it is not: a flashy portrait or big-city story. Rather, it depicts the marriage of Ms. Shattuck’s mother, Marcia, and Michael, now Trisha, who raised Ms. Shattuck and her younger sister, Laura, largely in small-town Michigan. (Sharon Shattuck has contributed to The Times’s Op-Docs forum.)

headline: Before He Was a Cubist, Picasso Was an Invertebrate
abstract: An article in The New York Times in 1911 explained that Cubist artists went by that moniker when they first burst on the scene in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Somebody paid nearly $64 million for Picasso’s “Femme Assise” at Sotheby’s in London on Tuesday. It was the highest price ever paid at auction for a painting made by an Invertebrate.

headline: Review: In ‘The Neon Demon,’ Beauty Masks a Rotting Core
abstract: This puerile movie from the Danish filmmaker Nicolas Winding Refn is set in the high-fashion modeling world of Los Angeles. Elle Fanning and Keanu Reeves star.
lead_paragraph: “The Neon Demon,” a ridiculous and puerile movie from the Danish filmmaker Nicolas Winding Refn, is set in the high-fashion modeling world of Los Angeles. In Mr. Refn’s conception of this milieu, apartments for models don’t exist, and so the fresh-faced, extremely underage aspiring model Jesse (the doe-eyed Elle Fanning) has to shack up in a sleazy Pasadena motel overseen by a shady Keanu Reeves, playing against virtuous type.

headline: Review: Angel Blue Makes Her Met Debut
abstract: Ms. Blue, a California-born soprano who financed her music education with beauty pageant prize money, opened the Summer Recital Series in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: On a balmy Wednesday evening, a large crowd turned up at Rumsey Playfield in Central Park to see the soprano Angel Blue’s first appearance with the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: The Museum of the City of New York to Examine a Gay Underground
abstract: The Museum of the City of New York scrutinizes a subculture through the prism of 10 creators in its coming exhibition “Gay Gotham.”
lead_paragraph: The Museum of the City of New York could not have predicted how timely it would be to mount an exhibition exploring how creativity became both an outlet and a refuge for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender artists in New York.

headline: Same Character, Different Film: Recurring Roles in Non-Sequels
abstract: A look at recurring characters like Ray Nicolette, played by Michael Keaton in “Jackie Brown” and “Out of Sight.”
lead_paragraph: In the 1996 black comedy “Welcome to the Dollhouse,” Heather Matarazzo and Brendan Sexton III played Dawn Wiener and Brandon McCarthy, grade-school outcasts, nerd and bully. At first antagonists, they become tentative allies, only to be separated by suburban fate. “Wiener-Dog,” the new film also from the writer-director Todd Solondz, is not — title aside — a “Dollhouse” sequel. But it does depict Dawn and Brandon reunited (and it feels so weird).

headline: ‘Brexit’ and the Risks of Democracy
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Referendums', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Referendums can distill complex issues into a simplistic choice. But sometimes the people just need to be heard.
lead_paragraph: The Brexit ballot puts one of democracy’s riskiest tools, the referendum, to the test.

headline: Review: ‘Wiener-Dog,’ the Tail That Wags Through a Few Bitter Lives
abstract: As usual, Todd Solondz focuses on the awfulness of our species, dramatized in this film through dark, deadpan comic vignettes in the presence of a dachshund.
lead_paragraph: Some filmmakers range across genres and styles, reinventing themselves from one project to the next. Todd Solondz is the other kind. At this point in their careers, we don’t expect documentary-style naturalism from Wes Anderson, bittersweet romance from Quentin Tarantino or violent action from Whit Stillman. And we don’t turn to Mr. Solondz for warm affirmations of human decency.

headline: Review: ‘Three’ Asks, Any Mozart Aficionados in the House?
abstract: This action-packed crime film by Johnnie To offers mayhem, comical desperation, surreal visuals and compounding excitement. Classical music, too.
lead_paragraph: The prolific Hong Kong director Johnnie To’s new film, “Three,” begins in an operating room and contains something I’ve never seen before: a perspective from the inside of an internal human organ, as a scalpel makes an incision. Mr. To is a master of “because I can” cinematic creativity, but after this scene “Three” settles down a bit to establish a knotty dynamic.

headline: Former Dallas Museum Director to Join African-American Art Foundation
abstract: Maxwell L. Anderson, who left the Dallas Museum of Art last year, will become the president of the Souls Grown Deep Foundation.
lead_paragraph: Maxwell L. Anderson, a longtime museum leader who left the Dallas Museum of Art last year after four years as its director, will become the president of the Souls Grown Deep Foundation in Atlanta, which preserves and promotes works by self-taught African-American artists, primarily in the South.

headline: Theater Listings for June 24-30
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: Review: ‘The Shallows’: Surfer Girl. Peckish Shark. Uh-Oh!
abstract: Blake Lively stars as a young woman on a surfing mission in this thriller. But a really, really big shark has its own ravenous plans.
lead_paragraph: Blake Lively is introduced in this thriller riding in a rugged roadster and peering at a smartphone while a scraggly-bearded, longhaired driver navigates rough forest terrain. Ms. Lively’s character, Nancy, is not a tech addict, as such: She’s looking at pictures of her mother, now dead, who was pregnant with her when she visited the secret Mexican beach Nancy is now seeking. Once she hits the sand, Nancy proves game and capable and in the moment. After using the phone one more time, to check in with her little sister and her dad for some back story, she tethers herself to her surfboard, puts on the top half of a wet suit, and hits the waves.

headline: Galleries Shift Shape to Survive in a Changing Art World
abstract: Art galleries are determined to find ways to survive and remain relevant in an increasingly hostile environment.
lead_paragraph: Art galleries, like museums, are in a state of flux, determined to find ways to survive and remain relevant in an increasingly hostile environment shaped by rising rents; development; absurd auction prices and a dearth of old-school collectors — ones who think for themselves.

headline: Sorry, Kids: Flu Shots Work Better Than Nose Spray
abstract: FluMist does not work against the H1N1 strain, which has been circulating more widely in recent years and causes the most serious disease in children.
lead_paragraph: The nasal flu vaccine spray, preferred by millions of anxious parents looking for a needle-free way to get their children immunized against the flu, as well as by adults who would rather not get a flu shot, is ineffective and should not be used in the upcoming flu season.

headline: Aubrey Beardsley, Racing Creatively Against the Clock
abstract: A two-volume set of books analyzes some 1,200 works of art that range well beyond the artist’s wraithlike temptresses and sexually aroused men.
lead_paragraph: The British artist Aubrey Beardsley knew early on that his life would be short. He was only 7 when, in 1879, he learned that he had tuberculosis.

headline: Review: In ‘Right Now, Wrong Then,’ a Double Take and Its Choices
abstract: The South Korean director Hong Sang-soo twice tells the tale of a first meeting between an older man and younger woman, with different outcomes.
lead_paragraph: A story is a series of choices, which in retrospect take on an aura of inevitability. With a handful of notable exceptions, most movies take narrative linearity for granted, proceeding from one thing to the next in what seems to be an almost mathematically necessary sequence. The exceptions — “Rashomon,” say, or “Pulp Fiction” — tend to make a big deal of defying the rules of chronological order and cause-and-effect logic.

headline: Review: In ‘Les Cowboys,’ a Girl Vanishes, and Her Father Can’t Bear It
abstract: Directed by Thomas Bidegain, “Cowboys” uses the narrative codes of the classic western, like John Ford’s “The Searchers,” to tell a modern story.
lead_paragraph: Reaching across 15 years and multiple countries, “Les Cowboys” repurposes the narrative codes of the classic western to explore the complexities of a disrupted world.

headline: Review: Ranger vs. Preacher? In ‘The Duel,’ It’s No Contest
abstract: Woody Harrelson, who plays a charismatic preacher, delivers a strong performance, but this film is largely characterized by unpersuasive story turns.
lead_paragraph: The film western has survived numerous world-historical milestones, including the putative closing of the American frontier, the death of John Wayne and genre hijacking by the likes of Kathryn Bigelow (in the vampire western “Near Dark”) and George Miller (the “Mad Max” series). Few westerns set in the American Old West, though, make it to the big screen anymore, and those that do — “The Lone Ranger,” “The Hateful Eight” — tend to be under-loved, under-seen or both. And so critics keep churning out obituaries for a genre that refuses to die, even while they also hope for the best. We can’t quit it.

headline: Review: In ‘Hunt for the Wilderpeople,’ Lighting Out for the Bush
abstract: Taika Waititi’s comedy centers on a foster child in New Zealand first placed with an older couple and then on the run.
lead_paragraph: “Hunt for the Wilderpeople” takes a troika of familiar story types — the plucky kid, the crusty geezer, the nurturing bosom — and strips them of cliché. Charming and funny, it is a drama masquerading as a comedy about an unloved boy whom nobody wants until someone says, Yes, I’ll love him. Much of the humor comes from the child, who’s at once a pip and a gloriously expressive ambassador for the director Taika Waititi’s cleareyed take on human nature and movies. Mr. Waititi knows that we love to cry at sad and bad times, but he also knows that people in pain need to get on with their lives.

headline: Democratic Party, Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: For Muhammad Ali, an Endless Round of Books
abstract: No surprise that Ali has inspired an uncommon amount of stellar writing, but the newest books hardly rise to the top of the stack.
lead_paragraph: He said it best, of course: He was “the astronaut of boxing” who “handcuffed lightning,” threw “thunder in jail”; the dazzling warrior “with iron fists and a beautiful tan”; “the greatest fighter that ever will be” who could “run through a hurricane” and not get wet.

headline: How Jaap van Zweden Became America’s Best-Paid Conductor in 2013
abstract: Mr. van Zweden, the incoming music director of the New York Philharmonic, received more than $5.1 million that year, according to recent tax filings.
lead_paragraph: The next music director of the New York Philharmonic, Jaap van Zweden, may not exactly be a household name yet. But he apparently set a record as the nation’s top-paid conductor when his current ensemble, the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, paid him $5,110,538 in 2013, according to an analysis of the orchestra’s tax filings that was released this week.

headline: Review: In One-Woman Show, Dillie Keane Is Silly With a Purpose
abstract: The British singer, songwriter and comedian combines twinkle with toughness in her show of personal stories and songs at 59E59 Theater.
lead_paragraph: “Regretting is only for fools.” That declaration by Dillie Keane, the very funny British singer, songwriter and comedian, on Wednesday typifies the hardheaded wisdom of a performer whose twinkling sense of merriment evokes a more down-to-earth descendant of Beatrice Lillie.

headline: A Russian Oil Company Is for Sale — Again
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Privatization', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: In a yo-yo privatization pattern, cash-hungry Russia is offering stakes in an oil company it privatized in the 2000s and recently repossessed.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — For sale in Russia this summer: one repossessed asset, well loved and maintained. Seller is motivated. Everything must go.

keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Videophones and Videoconferencing']
abstract: Goldman’s in-person screening was mostly at elite colleges. With video interviews, it hopes to find more applicants with “grit.”
lead_paragraph: To stem attrition, Goldman Sachs has given its young workers more time off, higher salaries and less busy work.

headline: Warrants Required to Test Blood, but not Breath, Supreme Court Rules
keywords: ['Tests (Sobriety)', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The court found blood tests are “significantly more intrusive” than breath tests in a case stemming from laws making it a crime for drunken-driving suspects to refuse either.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The police must obtain warrants to test the blood of motorists arrested on suspicion of drunken driving, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday, but no warrants are needed to conduct a breath test.

headline: At SeriousFun Messtival, Getting Drippy, Sloppy and Silly for a Cause
abstract: The event, on Saturday in Prospect Park, benefits a network of some 30 free camps and related programs worldwide for young people with serious illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Making a grand, glorious mess is one of childhood’s greatest joys. Cleaning it up is often one of parenthood’s worst headaches.

headline: When the Car’s Gear Shifter Is Too Clever by Half
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Design']
abstract: Automobile electronics have freed designers from mechanical constraints — but also from the tactile clues that tell us whether a car is safely in Park.
lead_paragraph: IF you are among the multitudes of drivers recently baffled by an encounter with the basic controls of a new car, you’re in good company. That sometimes-confused cohort would include people like myself, whose livelihoods as automotive journalists depend on knowing about the latest models in showrooms.

lead_paragraph: In a speech last week to a group of New York lawyers, a federal judge from Brooklyn assailed the criminal justice system in which he has worked for more than 40 years, saying that the country had to “jettison the madness of mass incarceration” and find an alternative to overly punitive sentencing to address the problem of crime.

abstract: Citigroup, which is issuing the new Visa cards for Costco, has logged more than 1.5 million customer service calls on them.
lead_paragraph: The banner at the top of Costco’s Facebook page reads “Costco + Visa = ♥,” but for many customers, the first few days of the retailer’s new charge-card alliance have been anything but heartwarming.

keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']

keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Deportation', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Editorials']

lead_paragraph: With a maddening 4-to-4 nondecision announced Thursday, the Supreme Court failed to decide the fate of President Obama’s 2014 executive actions on immigration. The program remains blocked — and there is no realistic way to resuscitate it before Mr. Obama leaves office.

keywords: ['AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Supreme Court saved a race-conscious admissions program in Texas, and admitted there is no such thing as a colorblind society.
lead_paragraph: Over the past four decades, the Supreme Court has repeatedly addressed the question of whether public universities may consider an applicant’s race in admissions decisions. Its answer, with some important caveats, has always been yes.

headline: In New York, Gay Marchers Weigh Pride, Prejudice and the Police
abstract: Plans for a heightened police presence at the pride parade, amplified by the mass killings in Orlando, Fla., have highlighted a rift over the very definition of “security.”
lead_paragraph: As the annual march, with its dozens of floats and some 20,000 participants, proceeds down Fifth Avenue in Manhattan in a celebration of lesbian, gay, transgender and bisexual pride on Sunday, thousands of New York City police officers will be spread among the crowd.

headline: National Briefing
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Bribery and Kickbacks']
abstract: News from around the country.
lead_paragraph: A former suburban Dallas police officer who resigned after video showed him forcing a bikini-clad black 15-year-old girl to the ground will not be charged in the matter, the police said on Thursday. A Collin County grand jury decided not to indict the former McKinney officer, Eric Casebolt, who pushed the girl to the ground after a June 2015 party at a pool that drew a crowd of predominantly black teenagers. The episode drew protests from civil rights groups. It was not clear just what charge the jury was considering. Police commanders plan to hold a community meeting on Monday to discuss the investigation with residents. Cellphone videos showed Mr. Casebolt, who is white, running after black teenagers and ordering them to the ground, then forcing the girl onto her stomach and placing his knees on her back. He drew his firearm after two young men charged forward in apparent protest, but holstered the weapon when two other officers intervened. (AP)

headline: Review: In ‘Stet,’ Rape, Journalism and the Elusive Truth
abstract: Written by Kim Davies, this play focuses on an apparently brutal rape, its aftermath and the writer for a national magazine who covers the story.
lead_paragraph: In a week with continued coverage of Brock Turner’s six-month jail sentence for the rape of an unconscious woman on the Stanford campus, and of a guilty verdict in the retrial of Brandon Vandenburg, a former Vanderbilt University football player charged with aggravated rape and sexual battery, Kim Davies’s “Stet,” an absorbing if somewhat unfocused drama at Abingdon Theater Company, could hardly be more topical.

headline: Like the Papacy of Pius IX
abstract: It’s a very Patrick Berry Friday.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — We move into our solving weekend with a 66-worder by Patrick Berry. I generally love Mr. Berry’s puzzles and there are some nice entries in this one, but it seemed to me to lack the sizzle of his other work.

headline: Why Trash Bags That Repel Rats Have the F.B.I. Sniffing Around in New York
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Rats', 'Elections, City Councils']
abstract: Legal or not, an episode involving the parks department’s purchase of mint-scented garbage bags shows the collapse of the city’s carefully constructed defenses against “pay to play” government.
lead_paragraph: You’d hardly expect the mayor of New York City, with its $82 billion budget and 300,000 employees, to get involved with buying garbage bags.

headline: Judge Holds Ice Cream Truck Owner in Contempt in Cone War
abstract: A battle between Mister Softee and New York Ice Cream continues, moving from the streets of Manhattan to a federal courtroom.

Speaking quietly, almost somberly, with reporters before the N.B.A. draft on Thursday night, Jackson said, of the newly acquired Derrick Rose:

headline: Mets Get Rare Good News on Injuries, Then Fall to Braves
abstract: Two key players saw team doctors on Wednesday. Yoenis Cespedes, who had injured a hand, got the day off on Thursday, and Noah Syndergaard is scheduled to make his next start on Monday.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — As the Mets were rejoined Thursday by two of their most important players, Noah Syndergaard and Yoenis Cespedes, the injury-riddled team moved closer to its version of normal. The alarms that went off when Syndergaard and Cespedes left Wednesday afternoon’s game against the Kansas City Royals with injuries were calmed later that night.

headline: New York Taxi Drivers Denounce Proposed Shift Limits
keywords: ['Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Working Hours']

headline: Track Chief Expects Dispute Over Russians’ Olympic Bid to Be Settled
abstract: Sebastian Coe, president of track’s international governing body, said details could be worked out to allow some Russian athletes to compete under their flag or a neutral one.
lead_paragraph: A disagreement over how a select group of Russian track and field athletes can compete at the Olympics — either under their country’s flag or a neutral one — should eventually be settled, said Sebastian Coe, the president of the International Association of Athletics Federations.

headline: Ralph Stanley, Whose Mountain Music Gave Rise to Bluegrass, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Stanley was a singer, banjo player and guardian of unvarnished mountain music whose staple, updated for “O Brother, Where Art Thou?,” introduced him to a new generation of listeners.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Stanley, the singer, banjo player and guardian of unvarnished mountain music who was also a pivotal figure in the recent revival of interest in bluegrass, died on Thursday. He was 89.

abstract: After choosing to leave the European Union, Britain confronts the need to define a new role on the world stage even as it heals deep wounds at home.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Asked to vote in or out, Britain has chosen decisively to cast off its 43-year-old membership in the European Union, leaving it to face a more complex question: What kind of nation will it be now?

keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Constitutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: State lawmakers have finally agreed to fully pay for lawyers for poor defendants.
lead_paragraph: For half a century, New York State has been violating its constitutional duty to provide a lawyer to every person charged with a crime, regardless of ability to pay.

headline: At the Edge of Inside
abstract: Organizations have insiders and outsiders, and then there’s a third position.
lead_paragraph: In any organization there are some people who serve at the core. These insiders are in the rooms when the decisions are made. Hillary Clinton, for example, is now at the core of the Democratic Party.

headline: Can Poets Save the Parks?
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Sadly, our great public lands rarely get much attention unless some knucklehead tries to feed a grizzly bear.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I went to the top of Crater Mountain searching for a trace of the last living Beat poet, Gary Snyder. His fire lookout at 8,128 feet, where he scanned the summits of the North Cascades for the Forest Service in 1952, is long gone. But I later found his work — his words enlivening new generations at a camp below — and the man himself, kinetic in California.

lead_paragraph: WHEN people hear about campus sexual assaults, they rarely understand the true impact such an attack has on the survivor and her family. But I do.

lead_paragraph: The London-based designer kicks off his “Making & Unmaking” collection at Camden Arts Center in London.

headline: China Censors WeChat Rumors, Including the One About Robots Taking Over
abstract: Censorship there is well known, but bureaucrats are also focusing on more mundane matters, seeking to prevent rumors, fabricated news and superstitious premonitions from going viral.
lead_paragraph: To the list of things that should not be uttered in modern China, add these: Padded bras cause cancer. The earth is on the brink of falling into a period of darkness for six days. Robots will soon conquer entire industries and eliminate the need for human labor.

headline: How the ‘Dining Dead’ Got Talking Again
abstract: Passionate conversation brought them together, but after seven years of marriage, they had nothing to say. What to do?
lead_paragraph: As two people newly in love, we talked and talked. We were in our early 30s then, so our talk included a history and a reckoning of all our previous loves, how they endured and how they ended. We talked about our past loves to see how they stacked up against the present one.

headline: The Anti-Power Couple: Duro Olowu and Thelma Golden
abstract: Joined at the heart but not at the hip, the couple make a rare public appearance together.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Before Thelma Golden, chief curator of the Studio Museum in Harlem, met her future husband, the London-based designer Duro Olowu, she had been on a Barneys waiting list for one of his dresses for months.

headline: As the Olympics Near, Brazil and Rio Let the Bad Times Roll
abstract: A struggling economy, government corruption and the Zika virus have generated unwanted publicity before the Games.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, when Rio de Janeiro won the right to host the 2016 Olympic Games — beating out Madrid, Tokyo and Chicago — Brazil was flying high. Although it had not escaped the consequences of the 2008 financial crisis, it had suffered less economic damage, and come back more quickly, than other countries, including the United States. With the economy booming, the federal government felt so flush that its popular president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, had instituted a series of expensive social programs that helped push millions of poor Brazilians toward a better life. The Economist magazine predicted that Brazil would soon be the world’s fifth-largest economy, leapfrogging Britain and France.

headline: Once and Always a New Yorker
abstract: Many people bond with New York as young adults, then move away. For some, that time inspires a return, even after many years elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: I left Manhattan in 1988, the morning after marrying a peripatetic advertising executive whose career would take us to six different cities over the course of 26 years. On the ascent out of LaGuardia, I turned my head to the clouds and cried.

headline: Bernie Sanders Campaign Showed How to Turn Viral Moments Into Money
abstract: Mr. Sanders raised roughly $216 million of his nearly $230 million total online, through emails, digital advertising and, most notably, social media.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a serendipitous moment during an otherwise uneventful Bernie Sanders campaign rally in Portland, Ore.: A small bird landed on Mr. Sanders’s lectern mid-speech and locked eyes with him before flying away to applause from an appreciative crowd.

headline: A Marriage Decades in the Making
abstract: Dr. Helene Gayle and Dr. Stephen Keith had worked together and been platonic friends for years. On June 4 in Washington, they finally became husband and wife.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Helene Gayle and Dr. Stephen Keith had worked together and been platonic friends for years. On June 4 in Washington, they finally became husband and wife.

abstract: Two doctors who had known each other for decades finally decided to let their hearts take the lead.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Stephen Keith had dined with Dr. Helene Gayle many times during the more than three decades that they had known each other. The meals were always convivial, and always platonic.

headline: A Poster Family for Diversity
keywords: ['ADOPTIONS', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Children and Childhood', 'Minorities', 'Parenting', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Schools and camps love to feature images of children of different races, but I didn’t want my kids being used to promote an ideal that didn’t exist.
lead_paragraph: Clicking through the new website of the private school my three children attend, I landed on a close-up photo of my oldest child’s smiling face. I shouldn’t have felt jarred, but I did. The picture, accompanied by a short interview highlighting everything she loves about the school, had been posted on the admissions page. Born in India and adopted by my husband and me, who are white, she’s a minority student at a majority white school that’s striving to become more diverse. Her interview was one of many, but for me, her mother, it generated a spotlight’s heat.

headline: How to Be a Paparazzo
abstract: Memorize license-plate numbers. Avoid frightening famous children.
lead_paragraph: Invest in good equipment. At a minimum, you’ll need a digital SLR camera; ­short-, mid- and long-range lenses; multiple batteries; extra cords; and a laptop. Rick Mendoza, a veteran paparazzo based in Los Angeles, carries 50 pounds of gear in a backpack. Expect start-up costs of at least $8,000.

headline: Populist Anger Upends Politics on Both Sides of the Atlantic
abstract: Britain’s vote to leave the European Union brings into focus the power of disaffected voters to force change on a reluctant establishment.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — From Brussels to Berlin to Washington, leaders of the Western democratic world awoke Friday morning to a blunt, once-unthinkable rebuke delivered by the flinty citizens of a small island nation in the North Atlantic. Populist anger against the established political order had finally boiled over.

headline: What to Do When Your Boss Needs a Reprimand
abstract: A supervisor ordered nonstandard personal items in an employee’s name, and now the employee wants to know whether to confront him or report him to H.R.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: Justices’ Immigration Ruling Will Ripple Through Presidential Race
abstract: The decision by the Supreme Court, blocking his executive actions delaying the deportations of undocumented immigrants, was a political loss for President Obama.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s split-decision ruling blocks President Obama’s executive actions delaying the deportations of undocumented immigrants and will have repercussions in the 2016 presidential race that could be felt through to Election Day.

headline: Blaming Muslims, at First, in Norway
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: After a mass shooting, an Afghan refugee finally meets his neighbor.
lead_paragraph: This was five years ago, when I was living in Kongsberg, a small Norwegian city. I had an apartment with two other refugees from Afghanistan. Our clothesline stretched between our window and a window in the next building, and sometimes we saw the family who lived in that apartment — a husband, wife and their teenage daughter — hanging their clothes. But we never talked to them, and they never talked to us. Well, no one talked to us. After three years in Kongsberg, I thought, the people in Norway are like the weather: a little cold.

headline: Do You Want Bubbles With That?
abstract: A dash of Champagne is just one of many ways to get some fizz in your glass.
lead_paragraph: It’s supposed to be festive. It’s supposed to be fun. But most of the time, if I’m out with a friend for cocktails, and she excitedly says, “Let’s start with something fizzy!” I deflate a little. Unpleasant visions of endless-mimosa brunches in my 20s and their aftermaths arise.

headline: Lisa Gersh of Goop: Treat Meetings Like Improv Sessions
abstract: Lisa Gersh, chief executive of the wellness company Goop, says managing a creative team requires a willingness to listen and play with people’s ideas.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Lisa Gersh, chief executive of Goop, a wellness company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 2 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
abstract: You may have been riveted by any number of stories in this busy news week, but whatever got your attention, we’d like to know about it. Post here through June 30 in order to enter this week’s contest.
lead_paragraph: Update | Winners for this week have been announced.

headline: A Lawyer Finds a Niche as an Agent for Rabbis
abstract: Abby Kelman is one of the very few lawyers representing rabbis and cantors in contract negotiations with synagogue boards.
lead_paragraph: CREVE COEUR, Mo. — When the world’s Conservative rabbis gathered for their annual convention in 2011, Abby Kelman took up her position in a Las Vegas hotel corridor clotted with vendors selling the usual array of Jewish books, tours, jewelry, crafts. Passing out business cards and stationery, Ms. Kelman was offering something different: legal representation.

lead_paragraph: The impulse when the stock market abruptly plunges is to do something. Anything. Our life savings are often on the line, after all.

headline: Rings, and Cat Pictures, Highlight Sale of Whitey Bulger’s Possessions
abstract: Auction proceeds will benefit the families of victims of one of South Boston’s most notorious crime bosses, who lived in hiding in California for 16 years before being arrested.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When James (Whitey) Bulger and his girlfriend, Catherine Greig, were on the lam in Santa Monica, Calif., they befriended a stray cat, Tiger, feeding it and taking it to the veterinarian. But Tiger did not repay the kindness, leading, unwittingly, to the duo’s arrest in 2011 after a former neighbor, who knew them as the cat’s protectors, recognized them from F.B.I. photos and turned them in.

headline: What to Watch for in Trading After Shock of ‘Brexit’

lead_paragraph: The global financial system has in recent years managed to absorb rolling debt crises in Greece, military clashes in Ukraine, down-to-the-wire budget fights in Washington and a shock currency devaluation by China.

headline: Diplomat’s Death Reignites Debate Over China’s Role in the World
abstract: In retirement, Wu Jianmin warned that the nationalism that had grown under President Xi Jinping should be kept in check.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — From his start as an aspiring diplomat in China’s Foreign Ministry in 1959 to his days as an ambassador in Paris and Geneva, Wu Jianmin represented the best of his country’s diplomacy: firm but reasonable, gracious but not unctuous.

headline: Britain Leaves on a Cry of Anger and Frustration
abstract: A vote that weakens Europe and reshapes Britain’s role as a leader of the West.
lead_paragraph: The anticipation of a calamity is never the same as the calamity. For all that was said and written about what would or could happen if Britain voted to quit the European Union, nothing quite matches the shock and confusion that Britain and the world felt on Friday.

headline: What the Sleeping Hermaphrodite Tells Us About Art, Sex and Good Taste
abstract: Blurring the borders of identity feels modern, but ambiguity has ancient roots.
lead_paragraph: Blurring the borders of identity feels modern, but ambiguity has ancient roots.

headline: A Palm Springs Restaurant That Focuses on Alfresco
abstract: Palm Springs has always been known more for its palm trees and party scene than its culinary prowess. SO.PA is hoping to change that perception.
lead_paragraph: Palm Springs has always been known more for its palm trees and party scene than its culinary prowess.

headline: An Artsy Hotel Brightens the Scene in Ohio’s Capital City
abstract: A local art lover, Ron Pizzuti, filled this Columbus hotel with contemporary pieces from the collection he and his wife, Ann, have built over decades.
lead_paragraph: Rooms from $239.

headline: Hitting the Road With Carla Gugino
abstract: The actress Carla Gugino dishes on her role in the new Showtime series “Roadies,” what it’s like traveling on a tour bus and her road trip essentials.
lead_paragraph: When she was a child, the actress Carla Gugino, 44, best known for her roles in the “Spy Kids” movies and on the television show “Entourage,” accompanied her mother on road trips along the California coast and thought that they were the most exhilarating getaways possible. “There was such a sense of freedom and an adventurous spirit to them,” she said.

headline: In ‘The 5,000 Fingers of Dr. T,’ Practice Makes Pandemonium
abstract: Dr. Seuss’s sole live-action effort, from 1953, was a one-of-a-kind movie in many ways. So is the 2015 stop-motion curiosity “Anomalisa.”
lead_paragraph: “The 5,000 Fingers of Dr. T” (1953) was, and is, one of a kind — and the only feature-length live-action movie to have been conceived, written and designed by the illustrator Theodor Geisel (1904-1991), otherwise known as Dr. Seuss.

headline: Bernie Sanders Says He Will Vote for Hillary Clinton (to Defeat Donald Trump)
abstract: Mr. Sanders, who has yet to suspend his own campaign and continues holding rallies, said that the alternative, Mr. Trump, would be dire for the country.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders said on Friday that he will vote for Hillary Clinton in the November presidential election, offering one more indication that he has given up on his own candidacy.

headline: 1941: Soviets Strike Nazis in Poland
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In June 1941, the Soviets strike back against Nazi invasion of Poland.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces, counter attacking violently in the direction of Kaunas, capital of Lituania, destroyed an entire German motorized regiment yesterday, the Soviet high command announced today [June 24]. The communiqué, claiming the destruction of 381 enemy planes, as compared with a loss of 374 Russian planes since the war started, said devastating blows had been struck by the Red air force at Nazi bases, including Warsaw, Danzig and Koenigsberg.

headline: Goodbye, Old-School Amenities
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Laundry and Laundromats', 'Home Appliances', 'Washing Machines and Dryers', 'Condominiums']
abstract: Amenities once considered standard in the city’s residential buildings are declining in size and importance, or being phased out altogether.
lead_paragraph: At the Grand at Sky View Parc, a luxury condominium development in Flushing, Queens, there are a health club, a pool and a children’s play area, among other amenities, but no laundry room. That’s because the developer, Onex Real Estate Partners, has outfitted each apartment with a washer and dryer, eliminating the need for common laundry facilities.

headline: Obama Says ‘Special Relationship’ With Britain Will Endure
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Referendums']
abstract: The vote by Britons to leave the European Union threw a shadow over the technology-friendly president’s trip to the Global Entrepreneurship Summit at Stanford University.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — President Obama on Friday sought to assure Britain and the European Union that the United States would not pick sides once the two are divorced. But he acknowledged, somewhat ruefully, that Britain’s vote to leave the union, which he had publicly opposed, spoke “to the ongoing changes and challenges raised by globalization.”

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Despite Russia’s Somber Facade, Glimpses of Joy Over E.U. Referendum
abstract: The government, which has worked assiduously to undermine European solidarity in recent years, has any number of reasons to celebrate Britain’s vote, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia received the geopolitical equivalent of manna from heaven when British voters opted to leave the European Union, speeding his long-term goal of weakening the most powerful alliance confronting the Kremlin as it seeks to rebuild its superpower muscles.

headline: New York Asian Film Festival Includes a Bit of Japanese Horror
abstract: “Creepy,” from Kiyoshi Kurosawa, has its premiere on June 29 in the wide-ranging festival, which runs through July 9.
lead_paragraph: The New York Asian Film Festival, which runs through July 9, always casts a commendably wide net, and this year’s slate has coming-of-age stories, thrillers and romantic comedies. There is horror, too, including the latest from Kiyoshi Kurosawa, whose aptly titled “Creepy” has its premiere on Wednesday, June 29, at Lincoln Center’s Walter Reade Theater.

headline: Writer Looks to Soccer Field for Peaks and Valleys of Argentine Life
abstract: The writer Eduardo Sacheri has found critical and commercial success by reviving the soccer story as a literary genre.
lead_paragraph: CASTELAR, Argentina — It was with low expectations a couple of decades ago that a young Argentine history teacher dropped off a selection of his short stories on soccer with the host of a weekly soccer-themed radio show. He knew that the host, Alejandro Apo, frequently read stories about the sport on the air, but usually the work of famous authors in the popular local genre.

headline: Donald Trump, in Scotland, Calls ‘Brexit’ Result ‘a Great Thing’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Golf', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Referendums']
abstract: Touching down in Scotland to visit his luxury resort and golf course, Mr. Trump took a victory lap of sorts after Britain voted to leave the European Union.
lead_paragraph: AYRSHIRE, Scotland — Donald J. Trump arrived in Scotland just as Britain was deciding to leave the European Union and proclaimed the momentous departure “a great thing” and the subsequent decline of the British pound good for local companies — including his own Turnberry golf course.

headline: Jonathan Anderson on ‘Brexit’: ‘It’s a Nightmare’
abstract: The designer, in Paris to show his spring collection for Loewe, said he thought Britain’s vote to leave the European Union was “a very big problem.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — If Jonathan Anderson looked a little tired today, as he showed the media and buyers around his spring 2017 collection for Loewe, it was understandable. He said he had been up all night watching the returns of Britain’s “Brexit” vote, the country’s decision to leave the European Union.

headline: A Family-Friendly Policy That’s Friendliest to Male Professors
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Tenure', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Parenting', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Men who became parents used an extended tenure clock to publish their research, but there was no parallel rise in the output of female economists.
lead_paragraph: The underrepresentation of women among the senior ranks of scholars has led dozens of universities to adopt family-friendly employment policies. But a recent study of economists in the United States finds that some of these gender-neutral policies have had an unintended consequence: They have advanced the careers of male economists, often at women’s expense.

headline: Brexit: The Morning After
abstract: Keep calm and grieve for Europe.
lead_paragraph: Well, that was pretty awesome – and I mean that in the worst way. A number of people deserve vast condemnation here, from David Cameron, who may go down in history as the man who risked wrecking Europe and his own nation for the sake of a momentary political advantage, to the seriously evil editors of Britain’s tabloids, who fed the public a steady diet of lies.

headline: When Machines Will Need Morals
abstract: A new study looked at what people would want their self-driving cars to do in a life-or-death situation. The conclusion? People would really like to stay alive.
lead_paragraph: You’re driving through an intersection and three people step into the road; the only way to avoid hitting them is to steer into a wall, possibly causing serious injury to yourself. Would you sacrifice yourself?
