headline: After ‘Brexit,’ 3 Centuries of Unity in Britain Are in Danger
abstract: The United Kingdom is what the European Union aspired to be but never became: a multinational state. The vote to leave the union may push Scotland and Northern Ireland to undo that arrangement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When people discuss the stakes of Britain’s decision to leave the European Union, they often talk about implications for the “European project,” the continuing post-World War II effort to unify the Continent politically and economically. But within hours of the polls’ closing on Thursday, it appeared that something much more basic could be at risk: Britain as a multinational state.

headline: Who Pays for Air-Conditioning Repairs in Rentals?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Air Conditioning', 'Cooperatives', 'Rent Control and Stabilization']
abstract: Keeping a rental cool, rules for overnight guests, and buying property with friends.
lead_paragraph: My partner and I rent a market-rate apartment with a built-in heating and air-conditioning unit, but the air-conditioning component does not work. An air-conditioner repairman told us that the unit is 20 years old, rusted, and will likely start leaking into our apartment and the one below us if it is not replaced. He said replacing it would cost $1,800. The landlord refuses to replace the unit, saying he is not responsible for air-conditioning, only heat. Our apartment will be unbearable this summer without air-conditioning. Who is responsible?

headline: Fear of Zika Virus Is Putting a Damper on Destination Weddings
abstract: Couples having destination weddings are running up against an unseen obstacle: fear sparked by the presence of Zika carrying mosquitoes.
lead_paragraph: Fear, if not the reality of the Zika virus and the mosquitoes that carry it, has not only cast its shadow on the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro in August, but is upending the carefully laid plans of couples who have long wanted a wedding in an exotic tropical locale.

headline: David Cameron’s Brexit Bust
abstract: Re-elected only a year ago, Britain’s prime minister has been swept aside by a raging torrent.
lead_paragraph: London — FOR a sense of how historically important Thursday’s referendum result in Britain is, consider the following. The last time British voters were formally consulted on continued membership of what was then called the Common Market, in 1975, mainstream politicians of the major parties joined forces with experts and establishment figures to persuade Britons that leaving was too great a risk. The “In” campaign prevailed.

headline: Men’s Fashion Shows: Comme Des Garçons Homme Plus, Junya Watanabe Man, Hood By Air and Berluti
abstract: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in Paris on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections which were presented in Paris on Friday.

headline: In Search of the Felon-Friendly Workplace
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Second Chance Act', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: By pitching ex-cons as good for business, the Eastern District of Missouri’s prison-to-work program has become a model for inmate re-entry nationwide.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Rick Plowman’s business, installing suspended ceilings in offices, schools and hotels, could use new blood. But hiring is tough, he tells the man sitting in his office. The 20-somethings he sees haven’t had the work ethic, haven’t had the hustle.

headline: Explosion at Hotel in Mogadishu
abstract: A suicide bomber detonated an explosives-laden vehicle at the gate of the Somalia hotel. A second explosion was heard inside the hotel as gunmen fought their way in, the police said Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A suicide bomber detonated an explosives-laden vehicle at the gate of the Somalia hotel. A second explosion was heard inside the hotel as gunmen fought their way in, the police said Saturday.

headline: Billionaire Lists Are Battling to Feed a Hunger for Rankings
abstract: A lucrative industry has grown up to measure and rank billionaires, and companies’ often wildly varying lists show how contentious valuations can be.
lead_paragraph: Never before have we had so much information about the world’s billionaires.

headline: A Patagonia Gear Developer Who’s Saving Lives in the Big Surf
abstract: Andrew Reinhart is helping Patagonia create a self-inflating vest that keeps big-wave surfers from being thrashed around underwater when they wipe out.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Reinhart, 30, is a surf product developer at Patagonia in Ventura, Calif.

headline: China-Led Development Bank Starts With $509 Million in Loans for 4 Projects
abstract: With its first four loans, the new Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank planned to fund projects in Bangladesh, Indonesia, Pakistan and Tajikistan.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A new Chinese-led international development bank announced its first four loans on Saturday, pledging to lend $509 million for projects to spread electric power in rural Bangladesh, upgrade living conditions in slums in Indonesia, and improve roads in Pakistan and Tajikistan.

headline: At King Arthur Flour, Savoring the Perks of Employee Ownership
keywords: ['Stock Options and Purchase Plans', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: King Arthur is one of thousands of American companies with employee stock ownership programs, which have helped attract talent and foster workplace unity.
lead_paragraph: Last month, a recipe for lemon cake filled with pastry cream and lemon curd spread quickly on Facebook, garnering 6,200 shares and 9,900 likes. Of the 300-plus commenters, some had followed the recipe and were displaying photos of their frosted creations, while others asked baking questions or inquired about dairy- and gluten-free versions of the recipe. Another contingent was just plain hungry. “I need a piece of that cake right now,” one person wrote.

headline: Dior Homme: Spring 2017
abstract: Kris Van Assche’s spring 2017 looks for men.
lead_paragraph: Kris Van Assche’s spring 2017 looks for men.

headline: Arizona Scraps Use of Sedative for Lethal Injections
abstract: State lawyers said in a court filing on Friday that the supply of midazolam has expired, while supplies of the controversial lethal-injection drug have dried up.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX (AP) — Arizona has eliminated its use of the sedative midazolam as one of the drugs it relies on in carrying out executions.

headline: Variety Puzzle: Acrostic
abstract: The acrostic puzzle by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — In evolutionary biologist Beth Shapiro’s “How to Clone a Mammoth,” a scientific road map is presented for “de-extinction,” a process in which a close relative of an extinct animal is outfitted, through a mix of cloning and selective breeding, with what it needs to survive in today’s environment. I have no idea how viable this is, but it’s an exciting idea.

headline: As Novak Djokovic Shines, Boris Becker Basks in a Rediscovered Glory at His Side
abstract: The partnership between Djokovic and Becker, his coach, has been beneficial to both men, with one atop the rankings and the other back in the swing again.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — An underwhelming television analyst, Boris Becker has turned out to be quite successful at analyzing what makes Novak Djokovic tick.

headline: Artificial Intelligence’s White Guy Problem
keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Discrimination', 'Science and Technology', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Our world is increasingly shaped by biased algorithms that have been built with little oversight.
lead_paragraph: ACCORDING to some prominent voices in the tech world, artificial intelligence presents a looming existential threat to humanity: Warnings by luminaries like Elon Musk and Nick Bostrom about “the singularity” — when machines become smarter than humans — have attracted millions of dollars and spawned a multitude of conferences.

headline: The Secret Power Behind Local Elections
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Campaign Finance', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: Because of Citizens United, corporations and PACs have an outsize influence on elections for city councils and utility commissions.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the history of elections in 2016 is written, one of the central points is likely to be how little voters knew about the donors who influenced the contests. At the federal level, “dark money” groups — chiefly social welfare nonprofits and trade associations that aren’t required to disclose their donors and, thanks to the Supreme Court’s Citizens United ruling, can spend unlimited amounts on political advertising — have spent three times more in this election than they did at a comparable point in 2012.

headline: Wimbledon: Six Rising Stars Who Could Make a Run on the Grass
abstract: Madison Keys, CoCo Vandeweghe, Alison Riske, Milos Raonic, Alexander Zverev and David Goffin all have the game to contend for a title.
lead_paragraph: Beyond the favorites, here are six players who have the skills to succeed at Wimbledon, which begins Monday.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Revolt Casts a Shadow Over Hillary Clinton’s Cautious Path
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton offers messages about stability that are similar to the ones put forth by the defeated “Remain” campaign in Britain’s referendum on leaving the European Union.
lead_paragraph: For Hillary Clinton, Britain’s emotionally charged uprising against the European Union is the sort of populist victory over establishment politics that she fears in the coming presidential election.

headline: Lawyers in a Lurch
abstract: Readers comment on “The Law School Bust” (June 19).
lead_paragraph: “The Law School Bust” (June 19) by Noam Scheiber looked at the increasing cost of law school, which has left some graduates with large debts at a time that employment prospects have dimmed. The law school at Valparaiso University in Indiana, a focus of the article, has offered buyouts to faculty members and plans to reduce its student body by about a third.

headline: China Suspends Diplomatic Contact With Taiwan
abstract: Beijing said it had cut off contact because Taiwan’s new president failed to endorse the idea that Taiwan and the mainland are part of one China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a sign of growing friction between China and Taiwan, mainland diplomats said Saturday that they had suspended contact with their Taiwanese counterparts because the island’s new leader would not endorse the idea of a single Chinese nation.

headline: West Virginia Appeals for Help After Deadly and Destructive Floods
abstract: The governor of West Virginia requested federal assistance on Saturday to help the state deal with record flooding that has led to more than 20 deaths.
lead_paragraph: The governor of West Virginia requested federal assistance on Saturday to help the state deal with the record flooding that has cut a wide path of destruction across a sector of the state and led to the deaths of at least 24 people.

headline: At Dad’s Knee as Cleveland Fell and Fell and Then ...
abstract: The author gratefully recalls how her father turned her into a die-hard Cleveland sports fan, no matter how painful that might have been until this month.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — About 92 hours had passed since the city secured its first major professional championship in 52 years, and here we were sitting together at Progressive Field, waiting for the Indians’ game to start and basking in the glow of a scoreboard that read, “Cleveland Cavaliers 2016 NBA Champions.”

headline: A Biblical Ark for the Secular Age
abstract: An enormous model of Noah’s ark is rising in Kentucky. Ken Ham, the man behind it, wants to use the boat to promote his belief in "young earth" creationism.
lead_paragraph: An enormous model of Noah’s ark is rising in Kentucky. Ken Ham, the man behind it, wants to use the boat to promote his belief in "young earth" creationism.

headline: A Young Cancer Survivor Scolds Donald Trump
abstract: A new digital ad campaign from a “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton equates fighting hatred with stopping the presidential candidacy of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: A new digital ad campaign from Priorities USA, a “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton, equates fighting bigotry with stopping the presidential candidacy of Donald J. Trump. Priorities is spending $500,000 — a large amount for an online ad — on the first commercial, “Dante,” which portrays Mr. Trump as biased against the disabled.

headline: Kanye West’s Latest Provocation: Lying Naked Next to Taylor Swift in ‘Famous’ Video
abstract: The rapper’s latest meant-to-shock clip features realistic likenesses of the pop singer, along with those of Donald Trump, Rihanna and Caitlyn Jenner.
lead_paragraph: In his latest meant-to-shock music video, Kanye West puts himself and his wife, Kim Kardashian West, in a special breed of rarefied company. Splayed out on a huge bed, the couple — or realistic figures in their likenesses — are surrounded by nude depictions of family (Caitlyn Jenner), former flames (Ray J, Amber Rose), friends and colleagues (Rihanna, Chris Brown, Anna Wintour) and some of this era’s most polarizing men (Donald J. Trump, George W. Bush, Bill Cosby).

headline: Let’s See How Sixers’ ‘Process’ Plays Out
abstract: General Manager Sam Hinkie resigned in April after a woeful stretch, but the draft picks he assembled could really pay off.
lead_paragraph: As the Mets pitched their way to a World Series appearance last year, the name Omar Minaya kept coming up. He may have been fired in 2010, but moves he had made were largely responsible for the team’s talented young roster.

headline: A Born-Again Donald Trump? Believe It, Evangelical Leader Says
abstract: James Dobson, founder of Focus on the Family, says Mr. Trump recently came “to accept a relationship with Christ” and was now “a baby Christian.”
lead_paragraph: Has Donald J. Trump become a born-again Christian?

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: To Preserve a Sport, More Power to the Players

headline: After an Eventful Day, the Mets Slip Past the Braves
abstract: The Mets beat the Braves in extra innings after signing Jose Reyes, demoting Michael Conforto and calling up outfield prospect Brandon Nimmo.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The Mets’ sputtering offense was transformed last summer through trades, the return of injured players and the promotion of a top outfield prospect. Before Saturday’s 1-0 win in 11 innings over the Atlanta Braves at Turner Field, the Mets made three moves that they hope can again enliven their slumping lineup into one with playoff potential.

headline: Gov. Christie’s Toxic School Plan
abstract: New Jersey’s governor is trying to strip poor communities of desperately needed school aid in order to fund property tax cuts for suburbanites.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is using the worst kind of demagogy to distract attention from his sagging poll numbers and burnish his reputation as a Trump-style Republican. That’s the only way to view his deeply irresponsible proposal for stripping New Jersey’s poorest communities of desperately needed education aid to fund property tax cuts for well-heeled suburbanites.

headline: Ban Animal Use in Military Medical Training
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: The animal activist group PETA appears to have the upper hand in its fight with the Pentagon.
lead_paragraph: For years, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals has been waging a guerrilla war against the Pentagon over its use of live goats and pigs to train combat medics. Their primary tactic: obtaining footage of training sessions to expose the barbarity of a practice that’s cruel and unnecessary.

headline: Why I’m Choosing to Become an Irish Citizen
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Passports']
abstract: Brexit has suddenly made my life more difficult.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — BREAKING up is never easy. But how do you break up with a country?

headline: Uzo Aduba
abstract: The actress on music from Leontyne Price to Jay Z, sibling loyalty and laughing babies.
lead_paragraph: Uzoamaka Aduba, known as Uzo, is an Emmy Award-winning actress and classically trained vocalist best known for her role as Suzanne Warren, a.k.a. Crazy Eyes, in the Netflix series “Orange Is the New Black.”

headline: Going Dirty
abstract: Will negative campaigning work as effectively for Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump as it has for past candidates?
lead_paragraph: OVER the course of the past two months, Donald J. Trump has assailed Hillary Clinton as “a world-class liar,” suggested that she had a role in the death of a White House aide while Bill Clinton was president, darkly referenced Mr. Clinton’s marital affairs and said — in a 41-minute rip of a speech on Tuesday — that Mrs. Clinton had “perfected the politics of personal profit and theft.” Once again, the nation seems to be marching toward another brutally nasty presidential campaign, with Mr. Trump leading the parade.

headline: 20-Something, With Menopause
abstract: How cancer made me live my life out of order.
lead_paragraph: CANCER aged me.

headline: A Letter From the Edge of the Abyss
abstract: My father, a Libyan dissident, was kidnapped from Cairo in 1990. I never saw him again.
lead_paragraph: FATHER warned in his first letter, which we received in 1993, that no one should learn of the correspondence he had sent — “or else,” he wrote, “I will fall into a bottomless abyss. I would prefer to die under torture than give the names of those who have delivered this letter.”

headline: Can You Get Over an Addiction?
keywords: ['Addiction (Psychology)', 'Brain', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Alcohol Abuse']
abstract: Neuroscience is giving us new insights into people who abuse drugs and alcohol and new hope for their treatment.
lead_paragraph: I SHOT heroin and cocaine while attending Columbia in the 1980s, sometimes injecting many times a day and leaving scars that are still visible. I kept using, even after I was suspended from school, after I overdosed and even after I was arrested for dealing, despite knowing that this could reduce my chances of staying out of prison.

headline: Hell Is Other Britons
abstract: I grew up in a small, closed-off place. The Brexit vote will make the whole country more like it.
lead_paragraph: ALRESFORD, England — IN summer, the land around Alresford, the rural market town in the south of England where I grew up, blooms in a way that seems almost terrible.

headline: Obama’s Death Sentence for Young Refugees
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Gangs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Drug Cartels']
abstract: A U.S.-Mexico deportation policy can mean death for youths targeted by the gangs they fled.
lead_paragraph: ON THE GUATEMALAN-MEXICAN BORDER — CRISTÓBAL, a 16-year-old Honduran refugee fleeing a drug gang that wants to kill him, has never heard of anyone named Barack Obama. Neither can he name the Mexican president, Enrique Peña Nieto.

headline: The Security Consequences of Brexit
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: The alliances that have helped keep the peace in Europe have been shaken by Britain’s stunning vote.
lead_paragraph: Apart from creating economic turmoil, Britain’s calamitous vote to leave the European Union could have no less profound foreign policy consequences, weakening the interlocking web of Western institutions and alliances that have helped guarantee international peace and stability for 70 years.

headline: Don’t Ban Photos of Skinny Models
keywords: ['Models (Professional)', 'Weight', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Prohibiting ads because of body types reinforces stereotypes instead of changing them.
lead_paragraph: IT’S been another big month for talking about women’s bodies.

headline: The Bad Faith of the White Working Class
keywords: ['Evangelical Movement', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Religion and Belief', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Church is an important social support. But the people who need it most no longer attend.
lead_paragraph: I THINK I was 11 when, teary-eyed and exhausted, I asked my grandmother whether God loved us. It had been an unusually terrible day for my sister and me. Our mother had called us worthless, threatened us, and then nearly crashed our car during a violent outburst. Things like this happened often in my family and among my friends, but not all on the same day.

headline: 14 Young Democrats to Watch
abstract: A gray-haired party with a shallow bench? That’s the rap. The reality is this group of rising stars.
lead_paragraph: A gray-haired party with a shallow bench? That’s the rap. The reality is this group of rising stars.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Silent Failure on Immigration
abstract: The justices made a big mistake by not disclosing how they voted.
lead_paragraph: THE Supreme Court has never won medals for transparency. After a case is argued, it vanishes into a black box, often for months, until an opinion emerges one morning without prior warning. The justices reject thousands of appeals every year without a word of explanation beyond “denied.”

headline: Out of Prison, Pitcher Relishes a Second Chance With the Rangers
abstract: Matt Bush, who spent more than three years in prison for a D.U.I. crash that nearly killed a motorcyclist, is now a vital part of the Texas bullpen.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — When Doug Brocail meets with Matt Bush during a game, he finds a pitcher completely at ease with his surroundings. The mound is where Bush finds peace.

headline: Was the Orlando Gunman Gay? The Answer Continues to Elude the F.B.I.
abstract: At least half a dozen men claim to have seen Omar Mateen at gay clubs or encountered him online, but investigators have not found any independent corroboration.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — After news media reports suggested that the man who carried out the massacre at a gay nightclub here may have himself been gay, the company that bills itself as “the world’s largest gay hookup site” put out what amounted to a distress call, asking members who may have been in contact with the gunman, Omar Mateen, to come forward.

headline: Balmain: Spring 2017
abstract: Olivier Rousteing’s spring designs for men.
lead_paragraph: Olivier Rousteing’s spring designs for men.

headline: Jack Daniel’s Embraces a Hidden Ingredient: Help From a Slave
abstract: On its 150th anniversary, the Tennessee whiskey distillery concedes that its official history didn’t tell the whole story of its origins.
lead_paragraph: LYNCHBURG, Tenn. — Every year, about 275,000 people tour the Jack Daniel’s distillery here, and as they stroll through its brick buildings nestled in a tree-shaded hollow, they hear a story like this: Sometime in the 1850s, when Daniel was a boy, he went to work for a preacher, grocer and distiller named Dan Call. The preacher was a busy man, and when he saw promise in young Jack, he taught him how to run his whiskey still — and the rest is history.

headline: Argentina Seeks to Conjure Away Its Tournament Demons
abstract: Argentina, ranked No. 1 in the world, will have an opportunity to end 23 years of frustration in major soccer tournaments when it plays Chile in the Copa América Centenario final on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: It seems remarkable — given its perpetually deep well of talented players, its longstanding global cachet, and the sheer number of international soccer competitions — that Argentina has not won a major soccer tournament since 1993. That is not to say there have not been chances; Argentina has lost major finals the past two summers. The team’s next chance comes Sunday, in the final of the Copa América Centenario in East Rutherford, N.J.

headline: French Photographer’s Woe Turns to Joy After a Collective Effort
abstract: The theft of a freelance photographer’s equipment spurred Alizé Cornet, a leading French tennis player, and hundreds of others to lend a helping hand.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was the first Sunday of the Miami Open in March, and the French photographer Corinne Dubreuil left the media workroom to eat a quick lunch.

headline: What to Do About Guns? John Lewis Revives Civil Rights Tactic
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Georgia representative and other House Democrats borrowed from an old playbook when they staged a sit-in to try to force a vote on gun legislation.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The mural of Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, looms seven stories high over Auburn Avenue, the storied center of black life here during the days of segregation. Above Mr. Lewis’s blocky, instantly recognizable head is a single word: HERO.

headline: At College World Series, Difficult Ballpark Is Negating a High-Flying Ball
abstract: Prevailing winds blow in at TD Ameritrade Park in Omaha, and the distant fences have contributed to an E.R.A. through the first 10 games of only 2.08.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Coastal Carolina, known for its elegant, Chaucer-inspired nickname, slugged its way to its first College World Series. The Chanticleers hit 94 home runs, the most in Division I, reflecting the coziness of a renovated home stadium as much as the flatter-seam baseball the N.C.A.A. introduced last season. The ball, which flies farther than the old one, increased scoring nationwide.

headline: Britain Rattles Postwar Order and Its Place as Pillar of Stability
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Referendums', 'United States International Relations', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: A historic vote to leave the European Union is raising questions about the future of the post-1945 order imposed on the world by the United States.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s historic vote to leave the European Union is already threatening to unravel a democratic bloc of nations that has coexisted peacefully together for decades. But it is also generating uncertainty about an even bigger issue: Is the post-1945 order imposed on the world by the United States and its allies unraveling, too?

headline: Dear Hillary Clinton: Readers’ Advice on Your V.P.
keywords: ['Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Elizabeth Warren was the clear favorite, followed by the current V.P., Joe Biden, and Sherrod Brown. Several readers urged her to pick a moderate Republican.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Warren was the clear favorite, followed by the current V.P., Joe Biden, and Sherrod Brown. Several readers urged her to pick a moderate Republican.

headline: Yankees Top Twins in Mark Teixeira’s Return
abstract: The first baseman, who tore cartilage in his right knee earlier this month, returned from the disabled list, going 0 for 3 in the Yankees’ win.
lead_paragraph: With one of the few payrolls in baseball exceeding $200 million, patience is nearly a vice to the Yankees.

headline: Islamist Militants Storm Hotel in Somalia, Killing at Least 6
abstract: The Shabab militant group claimed responsibility for an attack in Mogadishu, in which all four fighters were reported killed in a shootout.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Islamist militants stormed a hotel in central Mogadishu, Somalia’s capital, on Saturday afternoon, killing at least six people in what has become a well-established tactic to sow terror.

headline: Milos Raonic Enlists Two High-Profile Coaches, John McEnroe and Carlos Moya, to Raise His Game
abstract: Raonic, of Canada, has surrounded himself with two former No. 1 players in the hope that they can help him advance past the semifinals of a Grand Slam tournament.
lead_paragraph: At 25, Milos Raonic of Canada has yet to advance past the semifinals of a Grand Slam tournament. But he has surrounded himself with champions. At Wimbledon, where he reached the final four in 2014, he will be taking the super-coach trend this week to a new level by working with two former No. 1 singles players simultaneously: Carlos Moya and John McEnroe.

headline: Marijuana Use Rises in Iran, With Little Interference
abstract: The same government that executes hundreds of drug dealers every year seems curiously oblivious to the growing popularity of marijuana.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — At the Tehran party there was alcohol, of course, though it was a quiet affair, nothing like the wild, over-the-top events of urban legend. People just sat at a table, sipping drinks and talking as they would in many places across the world. After a while, someone made a phone call, and a few minutes later the doorbell rang and in walked a nondescript-looking man getting on in years.

headline: Frank Chapot, Olympic Show Jumper and Mainstay of the Sport, Dies at 84
abstract: Chapot competed in six Olympic Games and coached the United States Equestrian Team’s show-jumping squad in six more.
lead_paragraph: Frank Chapot, a two-time Olympic silver medalist who as competitor and coach was a mainstay of United States show jumping for half a century, died on Monday in Bound Brook, N.J. He was 84.

headline: Hermès: Spring 2017
abstract: Véronique Nichanian’s spring 2017 collection for men.
lead_paragraph: Véronique Nichanian’s spring 2017 collection for men.

headline: In the Life of Bill Cunningham
abstract: Mr. Cunningham preferred to be a spectator, not a spectacle, but he got his fair share of attention.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Cunningham preferred to be a spectator, not a spectacle, but he got his fair share of attention.

headline: Africa’s Charcoal Economy Is Cooking. The Trees Are Paying.
abstract: In Madagascar, the booming charcoal business is contributing to deforestation and may exacerbate the effects of global warming.
lead_paragraph: TOLIARA, Madagascar — When Julien Andrianiana started selling charcoal 14 years ago, he was just one of a few dealers around. Most households in Toliara, a coastal city in southwestern Madagascar, still used firewood for cooking.

headline: Bill Cunningham on Bill Cunningham
abstract: The photographer on what he did, why he did it, and how it all began.
lead_paragraph: This article was first published in 2002. The author, a longtime Times photographer, died on Saturday.

headline: Bill Cunningham, Legendary Times Fashion Photographer, Dies at 87
abstract: In nearly 40 years working for The New York Times, Mr. Cunningham operated both as a chronicler of fashion and as an unlikely cultural anthropologist.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cunningham, who turned fashion photography into his own branch of cultural anthropology on the streets of New York, chronicling an era’s ever-changing social scene for The New York Times by training his busily observant lens on what people wore — stylishly, flamboyantly or just plain sensibly — died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: What It Was Like to Be Photographed by Bill Cunningham
abstract: Anna Wintour, Isabella Blow, John Fairchild and more on how they met Mr. Cunningham and what it meant to be photographed by him.
lead_paragraph: This article was first published in 2002.

headline: An Own Goal by Northern Ireland Gives Wales a Victory
abstract: In a match destined to end a remarkable tournament run either way, Gareth McAuley tipped the ball into his own net and sent Wales to the European Championships quarterfinals.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It is soccer’s cruel and unusual punishment, a fate as embarrassing as it is emasculating. The own goal — or o.g., as it is often recorded in the match report — is brutal enough during a regular match on a regular day. But in a crucible like Saturday’s round of 16 match at the European Championships, it is, quite simply, mortifying.

headline: George Will Leaves the G.O.P. Over Donald Trump
abstract: The conservative columnist and prominent Republican said he switched his party registration to unaffiliated, saying on Friday, “This is not my party.”
lead_paragraph: George F. Will, a conservative columnist and prominent Republican pundit for the past 40 years, said he has left the Republican Party because Donald J. Trump is the party’s presumptive presidential nominee.

headline: Jose Reyes Returns to the Mets, Baggage and All
abstract: While there are questions about what Reyes has left as a player, his domestic violence case was also part of any interested team’s evaluation.
lead_paragraph: When Jose Reyes left the Mets after the 2011 season, the parting seemed inevitable. The Mets were in the midst of a tear-down induced by the Bernard L. Madoff scandal, and although Reyes won the National League batting title that season, the principal owner Fred Wilpon had already declared that he would not pay him “Carl Crawford money.”

headline: Sports Page Headlines
abstract: Priscilla Clark makes her New York Times Crossword debut, assisted by Jeff Chen.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Another debut today! It’s nice to see so many new bylines, and all three of this week’s debuts were by women. Since there are far more men making puzzles than women, I consider this to be a good week’s work.

headline: New Jersey Boy, 4, Is Fatally Shot by His 6-Year-Old Brother
abstract: The older boy was playing with his mother’s gun at the family’s apartment in East Orange when the shooting occurred, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A 4-year-old boy was fatally shot by his 6-year-old brother in East Orange, N.J., on Saturday, the authorities said.

headline: Donald Trump, Over 18 Holes in Scotland, Plays 20 Questions
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Touring one of his golf resorts, Mr. Trump spoke on the Brexit vote, his call to ban Muslim immigrants, and how easy he thinks it will be to beat Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: BALMEDIE, Scotland — On the 10th hole of his golf resort here, Donald J. Trump — asked if defeating Hillary Clinton in November was more of “a par-3 or a par-5” — said it would “be very easy.” And on the 18th, when asked if he had more or fewer candidates on his vice-presidential short list than the par of the hole (a five), Mr. Trump allowed, “I’m getting calls from a lot of people, and they want it.”

headline: Mourning the Death of Bill Cunningham
abstract: Luminaries far and wide remembered the legendary photographer on social media.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, the legendary fashion photographer Bill Cunningham died in Manhattan at age 87. Shielded from the elements by a simple blue coat and with a camera always in his hand, Mr. Cunningham was a fixture on the streets of New York City and in the front rows of fashion’s most prestigious shows. Many took to Twitter to mourn the loss of Mr. Cunningham and to honor the man for whom everybody dressed — even Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue.

abstract: Internal criticism of the leader, Jeremy Corbyn, led to his firing the shadow foreign secretary, and at least 11 other members of the party’s cabinet resigned.

headline: A Pioneering Break Dancer Returns to Battle
abstract: Rich Colon, also known as Crazy Legs, is preparing for his first competition in two years, an event in Russia that is being called the “Battle of the Gods.”
lead_paragraph: Rich Colon is 50 years old, an age when thoughts of mortality creep into men’s minds and invitations to join AARP start appearing in their mailboxes. Faced with midlife crises, some men buy sports cars, join the Hair Club or start to prowl nightclubs. Mr. Colon has taken a different approach: He is going to St. Petersburg, Russia, for a dance-off on Friday against Storm, a German break dancer, in what is being called the “Battle of the Gods.”

headline: Against Eurotimidity
abstract: A manifesto that misses.
lead_paragraph: I’m on vacation, but want to take a minute to react to this new “consensus” piece on shoring up the eurozone from Voxeu. The authors really are the best and brightest, economists who have been superb guides to the crisis and in some cases have made material contributions to solving or at least dealing with it. So I’d really like to say nice things.

headline: 1891: A Platonic Strike in Paris
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: In June 1891, a general strike of the journeymen bakers of Paris proved to be platonic.
lead_paragraph: Paris was agreeably surprised to find yesterday morning that its daily bread had been baked as usual. The declaration of a general strike of the journeymen bakers made the previous evening proved to have been a platonic pronouncement, as the bakehouses from which the wonted amount of bread was not turned out were decidedly in a minority. However, the strike leaders are not yet disheartened. They called a fresh meeting yesterday afternoon at the Bourse du Travail, where about two thousand men gathered towards two o’clock. The heat in the hall speedily became tropical, and the majority of the audience doffed their coats and waistcoats.

headline: 1966: 25,000 Participate in Freedom March
abstract: From the archives of The International Herald Tribune: 25,000 attend “freedom” march in Mississippi in June, 1966.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Twenty-five thousand screaming, chanting demonstrators marched on the heavily guarded state capitol today [June 26], climaxing the “freedom” march that James Meredith began three weeks ago. The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. called it “the greatest demonstration for freedom in the history of Mississippi.”

headline: Bill Cunningham Looked Past the Runway to Capture Modern Identity
abstract: Bill was among the first to recognize the value of what people wore in their everyday life, and he created an invaluable portrait of society.
lead_paragraph: This is the age of street style, an era when we talk about “the show outside the show”: the people who dress to be photographed by the growing hordes of snappers on the sidewalk waiting to capture the ever-more exaggerated fashions necessary to stand out from the peacocking crowd and bestow upon them their 15 minutes, or seconds, of fame. Go to any fashion show and you can see it: a woman or man in a colorful, kooky get-up, swarmed by photographers jostling for the best shot and calling, “Look over here!” and, “Who are you wearing?” — lemmings in the land of the look-at-me.

headline: Ballot Is Expected to Offer Stark Choice on Economy

abstract: Hillary Clinton shows that most of her initiatives are paid for, while Donald J. Trump, in defiance of Republican orthodoxy, seems unfazed by debt.
lead_paragraph: The contempt that Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump express for each other will continue to play out in vitriolic sound bites. But their profound differences on what to do about the economy and the struggling middle class are far more important.

headline: A Lesson From ‘Brexit’: On Immigration, Feelings Trump Facts
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Workers']
abstract: Most research shows that immigration has boosted the British economy. But evidence doesn’t vote — people do.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The economic fallout from Britain’s vote to leave the European Union was swift and stark. The pound cratered to its lowest level in three decades. When the London Stock Exchange opened the next morning, its leading share index immediately fell by more than 8 percent, the largest single-day drop since the 2008 financial crisis.

headline: ‘The Merchant of Venice,’ With Mercy, at Shakespeare & Company
abstract: Tina Packer, who is directing the play for Shakespeare & Company, tackles a work in which, she says, each character is “racist and sexist.”
lead_paragraph: Will the quality of mercy prove unstrained enough to embrace a work in which every single character is “racist and sexist”? That assessment of the dramatis personae in “The Merchant of Venice” comes from Tina Packer, who is directing the most problematic of the so-called “problem plays” for Shakespeare & Company in Lenox, Mass. As the founder of this venerable outpost of bardolatory in the Berkshires and for many years its artistic director, Ms. Packer has long been celebrated for her untiringly exploratory approach to the canon.

headline: Bill Cunningham Looked for Subjects. And They Looked for Him.
abstract: The New York Times asked readers to share their sightings — and photos — of Mr. Cunningham.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cunningham worked as discreetly as he could. “My whole thing is to be invisible,” he wrote in 2002. “You get more natural pictures that way, too.” But while he looked for subjects, his subjects also looked for him. After his death on Saturday at age 87, we asked New York Times readers to share their sightings — and personal photos — of Mr. Cunningham on the streets of New York City and beyond. The responses have been edited for clarity and length.

headline: Intel Tells Stories That Go Beyond Chips
abstract: Intel’s internal advertising group and video and digital studio have produced a slew of original content that shows some incredible ways innovators are using its technology.

headline: Twins Defeat Yankees With a Barrage of Home Runs
abstract: The Twins hit six homers as the Yankees finished an 11-game stretch against sub-.500 teams at 6-5.
lead_paragraph: As the first round of boos rained from the stands at Yankee Stadium on Sunday afternoon, Nathan Eovaldi shuffled around behind the pitcher’s mound trying to regain his equilibrium. In a quick succession of swings — first by Brian Dozier, then by Trevor Plouffe — Eovaldi’s outing had imploded. With back-to-back home runs in the sixth inning, the woebegone Twins had broken open a previously one-run game.

headline: La MaMa to Release Expanded Version of Digital Archive
abstract: A revitalized version including a program from a Philip Glass opera and items from Warhol’s Factory will be posted at catalog.lamama.org.
lead_paragraph: Their names read like a who’s who of the past half-century’s downtown performance scene. Among them: the playwright Sam Shepard, the composer Meredith Monk and the transgender actress and Warhol superstar Candy Darling. Early works by these artists and dozens more are coming to light Monday when La MaMa, the East Village performance space synonymous with the downtown avant-garde, releases an expanded version of its digital collections website.

headline: In Chasing a Legend, Katie Ledecky Discovers a Buoyant Ally

headline: Review: Moves Versatile Enough for Philip Glass and James Brown

lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 1970, Philadanco has earned a reputation for versatility. During any one program, the members of this repertory dance troupe from Philadelphia are expected to shift among many styles. The breadth is always impressive, which makes it all the more disappointing that the aesthetic caliber of the choreography tends to get stuck in a much narrower range, seldom extending very high.

lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Cole Chapman and his wife, Silvia Gabriel Fields, were having coffee on their deck when a nearby creek suddenly burst its banks, sending them and their two children sprinting to their pickup truck for safety.

headline: Review: In ‘An Abbreviated Life,’ Ariel Leve Escapes Her Mommie Dearest
abstract: This painful, strangely mesmerizing memoir tells of a traumatic childhood and how the author unlearned the siege mentality in her upbringing.
lead_paragraph: There comes a moment in young adulthood when many of us decide that one or both of our parents are crazy. But then we compare notes with friends, share stories with colleagues and discover, much to our astonishment, that crazy is relative, and the bell curve in this case is plump, and that our mothers or fathers, whom we once considered uniquely deranged, are really only averagely so.

headline: Two Tony-Winning ‘Hamilton’ Stars Step Out With New Albums
abstract: New releases by Leslie Odom Jr. and Daveed Diggs serve as a reminder of life after “Hamilton,” but also of life before it.
lead_paragraph: One of the thrills of “Hamilton” is in watching the flexibility of its performers as they effortlessly bounce between musical styles — it’s a testament to the versatility of the talents they brought in the door with them. Musical theater has its own native grammar, but this show and its stars hammer away at it with every song, rebuilding it in their own image.

Britain would “take back control” of immigration, reducing the number of arrivals. And it would be able to spend about 350 million pounds, or about $470 million, a week more on health care instead of sending the money to Brussels.

headline: Bill Would Require Relatives’ Consent for Schools to Use Cadavers

headline: Nervous and Contrite, Jose Reyes Returns to New York

headline: Panama Celebrates Expanded Canal’s Successful First Passage

headline: John Santucci, Prosecutor in High-Profile Cases in New York, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Santucci, a former Queens district attorney, drew praise and controversy in trials involving municipal corruption, police conduct and a racial attack.
lead_paragraph: John J. Santucci, who as the Queens district attorney from 1977 to 1991 became a lightning rod of controversy in high-profile cases involving a fatal racial attack, a municipal corruption scandal and allegations of lethal police brutality, died on Sunday in Mineola, N.Y. He was 85.

headline: Gerald Walpin, Watchdog Fired Over AmeriCorps Inquiry, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Walpin was a staunch conservative appointed by President George W. Bush as inspector general of the Corporation for National and Community Service.
lead_paragraph: Gerald Walpin, a former inspector general for the Corporation for National and Community Service whose 2009 firing by President Obama was harshly criticized by Republicans, died on Friday after being struck by a vehicle while crossing the street in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Ryan Lochte, ’12 Olympic Champion, Misses Rio Cut in 400 I.M.
abstract: Chase Kalisz and Jay Litherland will represent the United States in the event after beating Lochte in Sunday’s final at the Olympic trials.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Ryan Lochte was off to a rough start at the United States Olympic trials even before he climbed on the blocks Sunday night for the second step in his defense of his Olympic gold medal in the 400-meter individual medley.

headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Season 3 Finale: An Empire Built on Quicksand
abstract: The true satirical bite of this series lies in its suggestion that Silicon Valley, and that it, like Pied Piper, could one day sink into the earth.
lead_paragraph: In “Silicon Valley,” the ups and downs of Pied Piper’s fortunes are part of its comedic formula: Week after week, and sometimes within the space of a single episode, the company can go from “the belles of the balls” to the brink of tech-bubble oblivion. That gnawing tension brings the best out of the characters, too, turning Richard into a quivering, inarticulate ball of anxiety, and goosing Erlich into the bong-fueled pontification necessary to save his helpless incubees. There are times when you watch it with your eyes half-covered, like a horror movie, because the specter of failure pursues Pied Piper as relentlessly as a slasher villain in a hockey mask.

headline: Pride Marches On, With Jubilation and Solemn Tributes to Victims of Massacre
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Parades', 'Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: The gay pride march reflected the event’s evolution from a defiant protest by a marginalized community into a freewheeling day that included political leaders and a diverse crowd.
lead_paragraph: There were scores of men and women, some uninhibited by cares or much clothing, dancing to pulsing beats on a sunny Sunday afternoon along Fifth Avenue. Revving motorcycle engines and honking horns drowned out the cheers of the swelling crowds that lined a two-mile route that started in Midtown Manhattan and reached down to the West Village.

headline: Yankees Are Said to Enter Deal With StubHub
abstract: The Yankees’ decision this season to enact mobile ticketing and do away with print-at-home tickets was seen as a shot at StubHub, a nationwide ticket-resale broker.
lead_paragraph: Bedeviled by dwindling attendance and criticism from fans about their ticketing policies, the Yankees are entering into a partnership with StubHub, a longtime nemesis, to take over the Yankees Ticket Exchange from Ticketmaster, according to a person familiar with the negotiations.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Worries British Cultural Institutions Facing Loss of Aid
abstract: The movie industry and dance companies, in particular, expect to be affected, but there is uncertainly over what the repercussions will be.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British cultural organizations and prominent figures in theater, dance and film reacted with dismay after Britain voted to leave the European Union. But as with many British industries and institutions, uncertainty prevails over what withdrawal will mean.

headline: In American Markets, Panic Begins to Subside
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Referendums', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'British Pound (Currency)']
abstract: Stocks closed lower in the second-day aftermath of the British vote to leave the European Union, but there were signs a gradual calming.
lead_paragraph: The market panic that initially met Britain’s vote to leave the European Union showed signs of subsiding on Monday.

headline: Lionel Messi and Argentina Miss Again as Chile Wins Copa América
abstract: Lionel Messi missed Argentina’s first attempt in a penalty shootout; after the game, he suggested that he was quitting the national team.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Lionel Messi had the collar of his shirt pulled up to his nose. With his eyes peeking out just over the fabric, he watched a nightmare unfold.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 6 Finale: Setting Up the Endgame
abstract: This season’s female-driven revolution culminated with the show’s most brazen power grab yet.
lead_paragraph: Over 10 weeks in the sixth season of “Game of Thrones,” it has become a cliché to note that the powerful women have come to the fore. But there was one character whose trajectory seemed to be the exception to the feminist revolution remaking this story.

keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Mr. Brown led efforts to protect the spaces inside Radio City Music Hall and Grand Central Terminal, among other buildings.
lead_paragraph: R. Michael Brown, a designer who helped preserve the lavish interiors of some of New York City’s most famous buildings, including Radio City Music Hall and Grand Central Terminal, by ambitiously applying an expansion of the city’s landmarks preservation law, died on June 16 in Kingston, N.Y. He was 78.

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: “Bill Cunningham New York” follows the New York Times fashion photographer, who died on Saturday. Josh Fox concludes “Gasland” on a note of hope.
lead_paragraph: “Bill Cunningham New York” shows the beloved New York Times fashion photographer, designated a living landmark in 2009, in action. Mr. Cunningham died on Saturday. Josh Fox wraps up his “Gasland” trilogy by trying to find some good news amid climate change. And “UnREAL” just got nastier.

abstract: New Jersey needs the money that a higher gas tax would bring in, to repair deteriorating highways and bridges.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey drivers buy their gasoline on the cheap. They pay less at the pump because New Jersey’s 14.5-cent-a-gallon gas tax is one of the lowest in the country, but it is insufficient to improve or maintain the state’s roads, bridges and rails.

headline: How Should We Respond to ‘Evil’?
abstract: The attempt to “destroy” evil is an ethical version of a fool’s errand.
lead_paragraph: For a student of evil, Stephen Colbert’s exchange with Bill O’Reilly on “The Late Show” two days after the Orlando killings was an education. “This guy was evil,” O’Reilly said of the gunman, Omar Mateen.

abstract: The full brutality of slavery is strangely missing in a retelling of a Civil War story.
lead_paragraph: The movie “Free State of Jones” certainly doesn’t lack in ambition — it sprawls so that it feels like several films stitched together — but I still found it woefully lacking.

headline: Ken Starr’s Squalid Second Act
abstract: The prosecutor who exposed Bill Clinton to disgrace has finally discovered some of his own.
lead_paragraph: Houston — EDWIN EDWARDS, the colorful former governor of Louisiana, had a favorite quote often attributed to the Chinese military strategist Sun Tzu: “If you wait by the river long enough, the bodies of your enemies will float by.”

headline: The World Bank Should Champion Human Rights
abstract: By mandate, the World Bank is an apolitical institution. That does not preclude it from doing more to protect human rights.
lead_paragraph: Much of the evidence supporting the emerging consensus that strong human rights safeguards promote and enhance development has come out of research from the World Bank. Yet the institution has been far too reluctant to make adherence to human rights a core principle by which it evaluates projects intended to reduce poverty and improve the lives of the world’s most vulnerable people.

headline: Clinton’s Day Care Plan: A Good Start, but Not Enough
abstract: Donald Trump is right, for once: Companies need to chip in to help workers with their kids.
lead_paragraph: Las Vegas — OF all the milestones that have come from the first viable female presidential candidacy, one should come as no surprise: Unfortunately, it takes a “woman card” to finally get a detailed plan to address the child care crisis in the United States.

headline: Good News From Diablo Canyon
abstract: California’s decision to phase nuclear power out for greenhouse-gas-free electricity is an important milestone for the country. New York must be next.
lead_paragraph: Few nuclear power plants have been as contentious as Diablo Canyon. The plant, which went online in 1985 after years of ferocious opposition, sits on a gorgeous stretch of California coastline, surrounded by several earthquake faults and reliably producing enormous quantities of power — almost a tenth of California’s in-state generation. It also reliably kills enormous quantities of marine life with a cooling system that depends on huge intakes and discharges of seawater. David Brower, the executive director of the Sierra Club, got so angry with the organization when it refused to oppose the plant that he left to establish Friends of the Earth.

headline: Rediscovering Joy After War, a Photographer Returns to Africa
abstract: Burned out after decades covering death and mayhem, a photographer rediscovered the joy of his craft while covering a fashion show in Senegal, where his career began.
lead_paragraph: I put my cameras down in 2014, after covering the war in Gaza. I’d spent a month photographing entire neighborhoods leveled by the Israeli offensive, and the shattered bodies of countless men, women and children blown apart by bombs.

headline: Cartoons Keep Order at Japanese Construction Sites
abstract: Road signs and traffic cones have gone “kawaii,” or cute, all over the country in an effort to entertain passers-by during commuting disturbances.
lead_paragraph: The construction site outside the train station in one of Tokyo’s central night life and shopping districts had the typical workers in hard hats and fluorescent vests. And, not so typical, two pink-and-white Hello Kitty figures hanging off the barriers that keep pedestrians from stumbling into a hole in the road.

headline: Ricky Martin Calls Balmain the Future of Fashion
abstract: The singer says his twin 7-year-olds are part of the generation pushing for such style and creativity.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Crowds form wherever Olivier Rousteing of Balmain decides to hold his show. The solid odds that one of his famous friends — ideally a Kardashian, Jenner or West — might attend are a powerful lure.

headline: The Challenges of Male Friendships
abstract: Consciously or otherwise, many men believe that talking about personal matters with other men is not manly.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Beemer, a 75-year-old Brooklynite, is impressed with how well his wife, Carol, maintains friendships with other women and wonders why this valuable benefit to health and longevity “doesn’t come so easily to men.”

headline: ISIS Is Said to Claim Responsibility for Attack at Jordan-Syria Border
abstract: The assault last week killed seven members of the Jordanian security forces, said a news agency that often serves as a conduit for reports about the group.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — The Islamic State has claimed responsibility for a suicide attack that killed seven members of the Jordanian security forces and wounded 13 others on Tuesday at a border crossing with Syria, according to a news agency that frequently serves as a conduit for reports about the militant group.

headline: Senate to Take Up House Bill on Zika Funding, Barbs and All
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Zika Virus', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Lawmakers will consider a measure that contains $1.1 billion for Zika preparation and prevention, but that also has some poison-pill provisions likely to drive off any Democratic support.
lead_paragraph: The House is not in session this week, providing lawmakers a timeout after last week’s tumultuous Democratic sit-in. But senators will be in town, and they have a fight of their own coming over a spending package to address the Zika public health threat.

headline: The Connections Between Spanking and Aggression
abstract: In a study, children who were spanked were more likely to show disruptive, aggressive behaviors later on — and to be spanked more in the future.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, in my first month in practice as a pediatrician, I asked the mother of a 4-year-old about discipline and she told me that her son was often out of line and wild, and spanking was the only thing that worked, though she was sure I was going to tell her not to, just as her previous pediatrician had done. Around the same time, my colleague in the same clinic walked into an exam room to find a cranky toddler who was acting out, and a frustrated father who was taking off his belt and threatening punishment. In each case, and in many others, we had to decide how to talk to the parents, and whether to bring up the issue of child abuse — which is definitely an issue when a child is being struck, or threatened, with a belt.

headline: New York Today: A Primary Primer
abstract: Monday: Congressional races, “Brexit” in New York, and Mad Libs hit the road.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:04 a.m.

headline: Fly-Fishing Lessons in Chile
abstract: It had long been my ambition to learn the skill, but I hadn’t thought about traveling 8,000 miles to do it.
lead_paragraph: ON THE RIVER MAULLÍN, Chile — Eight thousand miles is a long way to go to catch a trout. But there I was, balancing precariously in a boat on a river in Chile, having my first lesson in fly-fishing. The tranquillity of the scene was disturbed only by the gurgling of the water and the murmured instructions of my teacher. And my noisy flailing about as I tried to keep my balance while standing up in the boat.

headline: Morning Agenda: Markets Shaky As Political Chaos Continues in the Wake of ‘Brexit’
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'British Pound (Currency)', 'Corporations', 'Currency', 'Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Executive Compensation', 'Foreclosures', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Mortgages', 'Private Equity', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Referendums', 'Relocation of Business', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Yen (Currency)']
abstract: In Private Equity’s Hands, Public Services and Housing in Disarray
lead_paragraph: MARKETS SHAKY AS POLITICAL CHAOS CONTINUES IN THE WAKE OF ‘BREXIT’ | The turmoil that roiled markets on Friday gave way to weak sentiment on Monday morning, as uncertainty created by Britain’s vote to leave the European Union weighed on Asian stocks, Reuters reports. The pound tumbled further, sliding 2 percent in Asia on Monday, but the extreme volatility of last week receded a little. The euro also remained under pressure, while European stocks started the week with a slump and continued to slide later in the day. As with last week, banking stocks were battered. Shares in Barclays and RBS fell so much that they were suspended from trading.

headline: Text of Statement by George Osborne, Chancellor of Exchequer, on ‘Brexit’
abstract: Mr. Osborne, who is in charge of economic policy, appealed for calm before financial markets opened in London.
lead_paragraph: Below is the statement that George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer and effectively the No. 2 official in the British government, after Prime Minister David Cameron, made at the Treasury on Monday morning. He spoke before the opening of the markets, in an effort to calm them.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Elizabeth Warren Take Aim at Donald Trump
abstract: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts campaigned with Hillary Clinton in Cincinnati, the first event that featured the two Democrats together.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — They stormed the stage together wearing similarly colored clothes — hues that almost perfectly matched the bold blue of Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign logo. With a “Stronger Together” sign hanging in the background and a Katy Perry pop song blaring from the speakers, they cheered each other on like old pals, cracking jokes about Donald J. Trump and pointing with enthusiasm at a young supporter who waved a placard that read “Girl Power.”

headline: Exit Polls, and Why the Primary Was Not Stolen From Bernie Sanders
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: It’s true that he did better in exit polls than in actual elections. But the problem was the flaws in those polls, not a conspiracy.
lead_paragraph: The background music of my life is the steady drumbeat of tweets about how Hillary Clinton stole the presidential primary from Bernie Sanders.

headline: ScienceTake | Hatching Treefrogs
abstract: Exploring the science of how treefrogs hatch.
lead_paragraph: Exploring the science of how treefrogs hatch.

headline: When Under Attack, These Frogs Hatch Themselves
abstract: The embryos of red-eyed treefrogs can hatch within seconds when threatened, if they are in the last third of their development.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good thing for frog embryos to be able to hatch early. Suppose there’s a drought or some other environmental change that means the growing tadpoles would be better off in the water than in the egg.

headline: Britain to Leave Europe for a Lie
abstract: The E.U. is flawed. But the dream is noble and still worth the fight. It did not deserve to be trashed by hucksters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — I have been overcome by gloom since Britain voted to leave the European Union. It’s not just the stupidity of the decision. It’s not merely the lies of the charlatans who led the “Leave” campaign. It’s not only the absence, now so evident, of any “Nextit.” It’s not even the betrayal of British youth. It’s far more: a personal loss. Europa, however flawed, was the dream of my generation. The European Union was an entity, a bloodless noun, yet it had a beating heart.

headline: A Young Prostitute, Police Scandals and a Rocky Renaissance in Oakland
abstract: A cascade of controversies has left the city without a police chief at a time when crime rates are down and once-dilapidated neighborhoods are reviving.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The mayor came into office promising a “Safer Oakland” and greater trust between the residents of California’s most crime-ridden city and a police force notorious for abuse and misconduct. Until a few weeks ago, the mayor, Libby Schaaf, a lawyer who took the post in January 2015, seemed to be delivering. Burglaries, robberies and murders are down, as are complaints of police misconduct.

headline: Texas Woman Fatally Shoots 2 Daughters and Is Killed by the Police

headline: Low Prices for Vaccines Can Come at a Great Cost
abstract: Sometimes raising the prices of drugs makes sense to prevent shortages.
lead_paragraph: A $30,000 price tag for cancer drug therapy that extends life only a few weeks is understandably alarming. But a $2,000 price tag for all childhood vaccines — credited with eradicating smallpox, preventing a million or more cases of other diseases and averting thousands of deaths each year — is a bargain. In fact, the price of childhood vaccines may be too low for our own good because it contributes to shortages.

Bono will become an investor in Counter Brands, the parent company of Beautycounter, and Ms. Hewson will become a board member.
