headline: 1941: Arms to Ireland Weighed
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In June 1941, Roosevelt considers sending arms to Ireland.
lead_paragraph: HYDE PARK, N.Y. — President Roosevelt, indicating that he is well satisfied with the progress of some phases of the national defense program but dissatisfied with others, revealed today [June 27] that he is considering sending some rifles to Ireland, but that the United States cannot spare ammunition to go with them. The President made it clear that no arms will be sent to Eire until the United States receives assurances that they will be used to repel any Nazi invasion. — New York Herald Tribune, June 28, 1941

headline: Pro-‘Brexit’ City of Sunderland Glad to Poke Establishment in the Eye
abstract: Sunderland, England, a former shipbuilding center with high unemployment, voted overwhelmingly for leaving the European Union, though the city benefited from the bloc.
lead_paragraph: SUNDERLAND, England — In places like Sunderland, with its once-robust shipyards silent and dead and its citizens leery of both London and Brussels, the idea of the European Union never really took hold.

headline: A Plastic Glass to Enjoy Drinking From
abstract: Wine, beer and rocks glasses, and a cordial, that are thoughtfully designed.
lead_paragraph: The undeniable practicality of plastic glassware for outdoors is combined with attractive design in these glasses from Pubware. There’s a stemless wine glass, heavy in the hand and thin at the drinking edge, while still thick enough to insulate so the rosé stays cool. The same thoughtful design applies to the 16-ounce beer glass, as well as a 20-ounce version, a rocks glass and a cordial. All are dishwasher-safe and BPA-free, and claim resistance to clouding and cracking: Pubware,  $24.99 to $54.99 for four glasses, $17.99 each with monogram or other lettering, pubware.com.

headline: Reactions to the Supreme Court Ruling on Texas’ Abortion Law
abstract: The ruling struck down parts of a law that would have forced dozens of clinics to close.
lead_paragraph: In a major abortion ruling Monday, the Supreme Court struck down parts of a Texas law that would have forced dozens of clinics to close. Here are reactions from all sides of the issue.

headline: Made to Order for an Authentic Scampi
abstract: Try langoustine tails with good olive oil, garlic, parsley and a splash of wine.
lead_paragraph: Scampi in Italy are not shrimp. They’re langoustine tails, and fresh wild ones from Iceland — very large, sweet and moist but firm — are available at FreshDirect. Extract the meat to toss in a sauté pan with good olive oil, garlic, parsley and a splash of white wine, or boil them in very salty water for about six minutes to serve chilled with a sauce: Wild langoustines, $5.99 each, $18 for four, three to four a pound, freshdirect.com.

headline: A Nordic Food Hall in Grand Central Terminal
abstract: Pastries, smorrebrod open-faced sandwiches, granola, coffee and, after 4 p.m., beer
lead_paragraph: The vision behind this collection of Nordic-accented food stands in the stately landmark Vanderbilt Hall at Grand Central Terminal belongs to Claus Meyer, the Danish food entrepreneur, a partner in Noma who is juggling several projects in New York. As a food hall, not a market, it is all about prepared food to eat in or take out. The bakery stand, Meyers Bageri, has breads, pastries, sandwiches and whole grain flatbreads with various toppings including richly burnished cauliflower. Open Rye specializes in smorrebrod open-faced sandwiches and the Grain Bar starts the day with granolas, then segues into a beer bar after 4 p.m. Almanak specializes in salads and smoothies and will soon offer small plates. A seating area with waiter service is adjacent, as is a liquor bar: The Great Northern Food Hall, Vanderbilt Hall, Grand Central Terminal, greatnorthernfood.com.

headline: Jewish Cookbook Exhibit and History Lecture
abstract: Stories told through the recipes from the past.
lead_paragraph: Among the many thousands of books and artifacts at the Center for Jewish History are cookbooks and manuscripts. A small but well-curated selection of them is on display. Bonnie Slotnick, who owns the vintage cookbook store in the East Village, will talk about the books June 29 in a lecture starting at 6 p.m. The cookbooks come from the collections of the five partner organizations of the Jewish history center, including the Yeshiva University Museum and the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research: “Nourishing Tradition: Jewish Cookbooks and the Stories They Tell” through Sept. 9, Center for Jewish History, 15 West 16th Street, 212-868-4444, cjh.org. Admission to the talk and a reception afterward is free with reservations, cjh.org/event/2895.

headline: For Fourth of July, Sausages With Provolone and Pickled Peppers
abstract: From Pig Beach on the Gowanus, links to take home and grill.
lead_paragraph: Just for the Fourth of July, Yankee Red Hots sausages are being sold to take home from Pig Beach, a seasonal, mostly outdoor restaurant serving smoked meat overlooking the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. The links are made in-house from pork riddled with bits of provolone and pickled hot cherry peppers. The restaurant smokes them before grilling; home cooks should roast them at 250 degrees for 20 minutes, then brown them on the grill or in a skillet. As they cook, they ooze cheese: Yankee Red Hots, $20 for four to pick up at Pig Beach, 480 Union Street (Bond Street), Gowanus, Brooklyn, 718-737-7181, pigbeachnyc.com; to order in advance at info@pigbeachnyc.com.

headline: Ah, a Cocktail at the Ritz’s Bar Hemingway in Paris
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: A renovation has given the hotel three bars instead of two. All are compelling.
lead_paragraph: A cocktail at the Ritz Paris is more compelling than ever. A renovation has given the hotel three bars instead of two. First choice is still the wood-paneled memorabilia-filled Bar Hemingway in the back. There, Colin Field mixes drinks like the Mach2, four parts Scotch and two parts green Chartreuse with a good splash of ginger syrup, served on the rocks and light and refreshing enough for summer. Opposite is the new Ritz Bar, bistro-style with food all day and a deep wine list. And then there is Bar Vendôme, steps from the hotel’s main entrance and a magnet for fashionistas: Ritz Paris, 15, place Vendôme, Paris, 011-33-1-43-16-30-30.

headline: Making Art From Pakistan’s Chaos
abstract: The country suffers from terrorism, sectarianism and a failing government. Out of this, art blooms.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — A drain, clogged with pink plastic bags and filled with black water, separates Bahar Colony, a Christian neighborhood, from the rest of this city. On one side is the Arfa Software Technology Park, a soaring modern complex of steel and green glass. On the other, the broken facades of low-lying brick houses are hung with rags. A sign reads: “Faith Gospel Assemblies, Lahore.”

headline: Takata Airbag Linked to Another Death in Malaysia
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A woman was killed over the weekend after an accident in a Honda. The company said the car had been recalled, but had not been brought in for repairs.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — An airbag made by the auto supplier Takata has been linked to a crash that killed a woman in Malaysia over the weekend, the vehicle’s manufacturer said on Monday.

headline: Disney Princesses Do Change Girls — and Boys, Too
abstract: A study found that for both boys and girls, higher princess involvement (through toys, products and media consumption) was associated with higher levels of stereotypically female behavior.
lead_paragraph: When you’re a parent of children of a certain age, the Disney princesses seem to be everywhere.

headline: 10 Great Monday Reverie Recipes
abstract: Contemplate your recipe choices over coffee, and then take a gander at some beautiful paintings by J.M.W. Turner.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking seven days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: ‘Veep’ Season 5 Finale: Hell to the Chief
abstract: Selina Meyer is no longer the president or the vice president, and worse is that many of the people from her circle are on the rise.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to be a sitcom called “Veep” that’s no longer about a vice president? Even though Selina Meyer has been the actual POTUS for two of this show’s five seasons, the whole time she’s been campaigning to secure an office that she was never actually elected to — which means that, in a way, she’s remained in a political purgatory. Whether sitting in the first or second chair, Selina’s never really had any “mandate.” She’s never had much political capital to spend, or any ambitious set of initiatives to spend it on.

headline: Kurdish Rebels Clash With Iran’s Revolutionary Guards
abstract: Kurds and Iranians have been fighting for decades on the Iraq-Iran border, a desolate area that was once the seat of a short-lived Kurdish republic.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Kurdish rebels and Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps have engaged in armed clashes along the mountainous Iranian border with Iraq in recent days, raising tensions in the region, Iranian state television reported.

headline: What to Do When a Wild Animal Attacks
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hikes and Hiking', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Accidents and Safety', 'ANIMALS', 'Bears', 'Sharks', 'Mountain Lions and Cougars', 'Self-Defense']
abstract: How to respond to an encounter with a wild animal depends on which animal it is.
lead_paragraph: Run or fight? That is the question prompted by a series of recent animalattacks on humans, including an alligator that dragged a 2-year-old to his death in an Orlando lake last month. And CNN reported recently that a mountain lion in Colorado had attacked a 5-year-old boy, who was saved when his mother pried the child away from the animal.

headline: Pew Research Center: On Race and Inequality, Blacks and Whites Are Worlds Apart
abstract: Black and white Americans experience life in profoundly and persistently different ways, according to a new Pew Research Center survey.
lead_paragraph: Black and white Americans experience life in profoundly and persistently different ways, according to a new Pew Research Center survey.

headline: Touches of Whimsy at World Trade Center’s Liberty Park
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: The elevated park, which will be dedicated on Wednesday, will offer tiered teak seating, a “living wall” and an intimate perspective of the National September 11 Memorial.
lead_paragraph: “This is one of the most beautiful garages in the world,” Steven Plate said about the 25-foot-high structure that leads into and out of the underground vehicle security center at the World Trade Center.

headline: Reaction to Texas Abortion Decision
abstract: On Monday, the Supreme Court struck down parts of a restrictive Texas law that would have severely limited abortion access in the state. Activists outside the Supreme Court reacted to the news.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the Supreme Court struck down parts of a restrictive Texas law that would have severely limited abortion access in the state. Activists outside the Supreme Court reacted to the news.

headline: RJR Nabisco Ruling Bolsters Justice Dept.’s Pursuit of FIFA
abstract: A RICO case against FIFA, the international soccer organization, can move forward without concern that the charges might not be a permissible use of federal law.
lead_paragraph: The government may not always get what it wants from the Supreme Court, but federal prosecutors received exactly what they asked for last week when the justices decided in a case involving RJR Nabisco, the food and tobacco conglomerate, how far the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO, applies to foreign conduct.

headline: Jordan Ellenberg: The Lottery Scheme
abstract: Ten years ago a group of M.I.T. students cracked the Massachusetts State Lottery. Can you figure out how they did it? A challenge from superstar mathematician Jordan Ellenberg.
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was suggested by Jordan Ellenberg, a math-world superstar and current professor of mathematics at the University of Wisconsin. Jordan is the child prodigy who turned out well. After teaching himself to read at age 2, he attained a perfect 800 on the math portion of the SAT at age 12, won two gold medals in the International Math Olympiad (with perfect scores), and was a two-time Putnam Fellow at Harvard.

headline: An Enduring Heroin Market Shapes an Enforcer’s Rise and Fall
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Series', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Tit-for-tat killings between rival crews preceded the death of Francisco Perez, whose life on a South Bronx drug corner spanned nearly three decades.
lead_paragraph: Up the block came three young men, shoelaces lapping at the sidewalk, faces half-hidden in hoods, to pay their respects to a fallen street soldier.

headline: Spirit Airlines Wants to Stay Cheap but Not So Tawdry
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Luggage and Packing', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: Spirit, the no-frills airline that attracts customers and complaints, plans to improve on-time performance and clean up its image.
lead_paragraph: It’s the airline that had unabashedly advertised its product as a “cheap seat for a cheap-ass.”

keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Blacks', 'Black People']

lead_paragraph: Black and white Americans experience life in profoundly and persistently different ways, according to a new Pew Research Center survey examining racial attitudes in the United States.

headline: What You Should Watch if You’re Missing a Favorite Show
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next few days.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Watching, The New York Times’s what-to-watch guide. We comb through releases big and small, famous and esoteric, to email readers twice a week with our timely recommendations. Our most recent suggestions also appear below. To receive our guide straight to your inbox, sign up here.

headline: Atop the Gymnastics World, Simone Biles Can’t Suppress Her Grin
abstract: Marveling at Biles’s happy-go-lucky attitude could be its own Olympic sport after she won her fourth consecutive United States title in the all-around on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — At the end of the United States women’s gymnastics championships here on Sunday night, so many gold medals hung around Simone Biles’s neck that when she walked, they clinked so loudly it made her giggle. A few times, she grabbed her medals to silence them and laughed yet again.

headline: The W.H.O. Versus the C.D.C.
abstract: In a time of high anxiety about the Zika virus, these two health-advisory organizations sometimes seem to be saying different things. So who are you going to trust?
lead_paragraph: Ask The Times, a Times Insider feature, draws on New York Times expertise to answer questions about current events, science, sports, culture and whatever else is making headlines.

headline: Making Mochi, a Japanese Treat That’s All About Texture
abstract: A Brooklyn pastry chef has mastered the age-old art. You can, too.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the pleasures of food aren’t packed in remarkable tastes, but in textures. And when it comes to mochi, the Japanese rice dough, much of its appeal can be attributed to a glorious bounce or a gelatinous squish or a comforting kind of gloop.

headline: U.S. Investigates Whether Airstrikes Killed Taliban Hostages
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Afghan officials agree that the American military conducted drone strikes in a remote area dominated by the Taliban, but give widely divergent accounts of what happened.
lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — American airstrikes in northern Afghanistan killed at least seven hostages being held in a Taliban prison on Saturday, according to accounts from the families of victims and local officials from the immediate area. Some accounts put the death toll as high as 16.

headline: Wild, Wonderful, Wacky Hair on the Men’s Runways
abstract: On the fall/winter 2016 runways, designers from Comme des Garçons to Gosha Rubchinskiy festooned men’s heads in spiky hair, flower crowns and splashes of color.
lead_paragraph: On the fall/winter 2016 runways, designers from Comme des Garçons to Gosha Rubchinskiy festooned men’s heads in spiky hair, flower crowns and splashes of color.

headline: What Leaders Said Before ‘Brexit,’ and What They Say Now
abstract: Political leaders on both sides of the debate are saying distinctly different things now to the promises they made before last week’s referendum.
lead_paragraph: Political leaders on both sides of the debate in Britain over whether to leave the European Union are now saying distinctly different things about some central issues than what they said before the referendum. Here are some examples.

headline: Opinion Transforms Texas’ Abortion Landscape
abstract: The Supreme Court ruling on a restrictive Texas law allows 10 clinics to remain open, while giving abortion providers and advocates their biggest win in a three-year legal fight.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Supreme Court’s ruling Monday tossing out two of the main elements of Texas’ 2013 law regulating abortion, one of the most stringent in the country, has transformed the environment for abortion in the state.

headline: A Narrow Diversity at Vassar
abstract: An alumnus faults a “hostile campus climate characterized by intellectual bullying and profound narrow-mindedness.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: No Steph Curry. No LeBron James. It Won’t Matter for U.S. Basketball in Rio
abstract: Kevin Durant heads a 12-man roster that features three members of the Golden State Warriors and a largely interchangeable cast.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Curry isn’t on the team, and neither is LeBron James or Russell Westbrook. Nor is Kawhi Leonard, Chris Paul or James Harden.

headline: 1916: Hughes Hits Out at President
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In June 1916, the Progressive National Convention supports Republican candidate Judge Hughes.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — In response to a telegram informing him that the Progressive National Convention had decided to support him for the Presidency of the United States, Judge Hughes, the Republican candidate, telegraphed his thanks last night [June 26] for the Convention’s support in the common cause which would assure national security and honor. Judge Hughes added that the grave difficulties with which the present Wilson Administration is confronted are due to its own weakness and indecision. ‘‘I am convinced,’’ wrote the Republican candidate, ‘‘that prompt and decisive action would have prevented the tragedy of the Lusitania.’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, June 28, 1916

headline: Central American Refugees
abstract: A reader writes that “the root cause of their problem is not United States immigration policy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: American Ballerina Leaps Into Euro-Sorcery in a Gothic Fairy Tale
abstract: “I Want You to Want Me” is the choreographer Jack Ferver’s campy, comic entry in the dark-side-of-ballet sweepstakes.
lead_paragraph: There’s a part of us that delights in watching seemingly perfect things be mussed up, taken down or wickedly exposed. Ballet is an art form that often wraps itself in purity and propriety, but there’s pleasure in occasionally watching it get nasty, as it did in the 2010 film “Black Swan” and last year’s TV series “Flesh and Bone.”

headline: On Bill Cunningham: ‘Dim the Lights on Seventh Avenue’
abstract: Remembering the legendary New York Times fashion photographer.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: House Democrats Release Benghazi Report to Blunt Republican Inquiry
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The Democrats’ findings cast the investigation by a Republican-led House committee as a politically motivated crusade that wasted time and money.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats on Monday moved to pre-empt the findings of a two-year Republican-led investigation into the attacks in Benghazi, Libya, in which four Americans were killed, by issuing their own 339-page report that cast the inquiry as a politically motivated crusade that wasted time and money.

headline: In ‘Dead of Summer’ on Freeform, Horrors Await Campers
abstract: Camp Stillwater proves less idyllic than advertised in this new TV series, whose cast includes Zelda Williams, daughter of Robin.
lead_paragraph: The summer-camp horror genre, so familiar to moviegoers, gets a hair-raising television incarnation in “Dead of Summer,” a series that starts Tuesday, June 28, on Freeform. It’s 1989, and Camp Stillwater looks lovely as the young counselors (one of them played by Zelda Williams, Robin’s daughter) arrive to get ready for the season. Most were campers there themselves as children, but there’s also a newbie, Amy (Elizabeth Lail), who is somewhat skittish for reasons that are doled out slowly.

headline: Brahms Sonatas, Pianissimo From Taka Kigawa, Zorn’s Bagatelles
abstract: Even in a slower-paced classical week, affordable or free treats await at Bargemusic, Manhattan Inn and the Stone.
lead_paragraph: Even during a relatively sleepy week on New York’s classical calendar, there are tantalizing performances. On Sunday, June 26, the violinist Johnny Gandelsman and the pianist Ethan Iverson come together for Brahms’s three sonatas at Bargemusic, a cozy spot for chamber music. (4 p.m., Fulton Ferry Landing, next to the Brooklyn Bridge, bargemusic.org.)

headline: Bill Callahan to Perform in Brooklyn
abstract: The singer-songwriter, whose last album was “Dream River,” will appear at Baby’s All Right for three nights.
lead_paragraph: The work of the singer-songwriter Bill Callahan has become intensified with purpose over the last 10 years; the songs on “Dream River,” his last studio album, from 2013, can seem as if they were constructed one word at a time, one sound at a time, to be sung in his soft, abstracted baritone voice. Yet, weirdly, the songs aren’t stiff; they’re light-bodied and place trust in the universe. (“I have learned,” he sang in the last lines of “Winter Road,” that record’s final song, “when things are beautiful/to just keep on.”)

headline: Revisiting Hubert Robert and His Romantic Ruins
abstract: One of France’s most popular 18th-century painters, Robert is the focus of a show of more than 100 works at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Although not well known today, Hubert Robert was one of the most popular painters of 18th-century France. Renowned for landscapes in which ancient monuments and modern buildings were arranged in imaginary scenes called architectural capriccios, he was nicknamed “Robert des ruines” by the philosopher Denis Diderot. An interior decorator and landscape designer as well, he frequented intellectual and artistic circles that included the painter Élisabeth Louise Vigée le Brun and the Enlightenment philosopher Marie Thérèse Rodet Geoffrin.

headline: Obama White House Veterans Gleefully Enter the Podcast World
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Podcasts']
abstract: More than a dozen current and former officials have followed the president in embracing the medium of podcasting. Sometimes they make news.
lead_paragraph: David Axelrod was having a candid conversation with an old colleague when, almost accidentally, the two made some news.

headline: Executive Summary of the Democrats' Report on Benghazi
abstract: House Democrats released a report on Monday to pre-empt the findings of a Republican-led investigation into the attacks in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.
lead_paragraph: House Democrats released a report on Monday to pre-empt the findings of a Republican-led investigation into the attacks in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.

headline: An 8th Straight Week at No. 1 for Drake’s ‘Views’
abstract: Drake is having the longest consecutive run for a male artist since an Eminem’s album of 2000; the Red Hot Chili Peppers’ “The Getaway” is No. 2.
lead_paragraph: The big winner on the music chart this week? Streaming. The loser, if there is one, is sales.

headline: World’s Largest Uncut Diamond Heads to Auction, a Break With Tradition
abstract: The Sotheby’s auction for the 1,109-carat white diamond represents a new approach that aims to take advantage of wealthy individuals’ desire for trophy objects.
lead_paragraph: The world’s largest uncut diamond is about to be sold in a most uncommon way.

headline: Why Aren’t We Managing Children’s Pain?
abstract: Experts say that pediatric pain has long been underrecognized and undertreated, with serious long-term consequences.
lead_paragraph: It began with a simple roller-skating accident three years ago. Taylor Aschenbrenner, then 8 years old, lost her balance amid a jumble of classmates, tumbled to the floor and felt someone else’s skate roll over her left foot. The searing pain hit her immediately.

headline: Hotels That Help You Fight Jet Lag
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Jet Lag', 'Massage', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Jet-lag treatments being offered at hotels include facials, massages and scrubs.
lead_paragraph: “It’s annoying to be in a great destination and not enjoy it because your body isn’t adjusted to the current time,” said Michael Holtz, the founder of the New York City travel consultancy SmartFlyer, who makes more than two dozen international trips a year.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Is Locking In the Forces That Already Haunt the Global Economy
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Interest Rates', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: Those forces have self-reinforcing, vicious-cycle dimensions that make it a perilous time for the world’s economies.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, something bad happens, and it creates huge financial market swings and long-lasting economic ripples. The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks were an example, as was the 2011 Japanese nuclear disaster.

headline: Men’s Fashion Shows: Thom Browne, Paul Smith and Lanvin
abstract: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in Paris on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the spring/summer 2017 collections that were presented in Paris on Sunday.

headline: Reasons Behind the British Vote to Leave the E.U.
abstract: Readers cite a yearning for “old England,” a desire for self-determination, anti-immigrant views and insulting rhetoric toward the Leave camp.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How ‘The Sleeping Beauty’ Tells Its Story Through Ballet
abstract: The New York Times’s chief dance critic takes us through the ballet “The Sleeping Beauty,” performed by American Ballet Theater this week.
lead_paragraph: Does the Tchaikovsky ballet “The Sleeping Beauty” tell a story, or is it just a nonstory? On the face of it, the ballet demonstrates the opposite of suspense. It has a prologue and three acts — but, before the Prologue is over, two rival divinities, the vengeful Carabosse and the beneficent Lilac Fairy, have told us what’s going to happen. So guess what? Then it happens. What’s more, it all happens during Acts I and II. Act III has no narrative at all, just the happy couple’s wedding and their fairy tale guests. The whole thing sounds daft.

headline: A Connecticut Tribe Fights for Recognition, and a Piece of the Casino Industry
abstract: While other Indian tribes in the state have gained federal recognition, and the resulting largess, the Schaghticoke Tribal Nation has been shut out.
lead_paragraph: In Connecticut, two Indian tribes, the Mohegans and the Mashantucket Pequots, years ago built shiny monuments to American capitalism in the form of their casinos, which have made them extraordinarily wealthy.

headline: Bad Behavior Is Exposed as the Shale-Oil Market Shrinks
abstract: The S.E.C. claims that the oilman Chris Faulkner inflated his shale companies’ prospects to attract cash, then blew $80 million of investors’ money.
lead_paragraph: A legal case against the self-described Frack Master is a sure sign that the so-called bezzle in the shale-oil industry is shrinking.

headline: Donald Trump’s Running Mate?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Readers, whom do you think Donald Trump should or will pick?
lead_paragraph: Last week we asked readers to advise Hillary Clinton on her running mate. Now we turn to the Republican ticket. Whom do you think Donald Trump should pick, or will pick, and why?

headline: StubHub Will Serve as Yankees’ Ticket Reseller
abstract: The Yankees and StubHub announced an agreement under which the company next month will replace the Yankees Ticket Exchange, which was offered through Ticketmaster.
lead_paragraph: After years of feuding, the Yankees and StubHub announced an agreement on Monday under which the company will become the team’s official ticket reseller but with caveats that include a floor on how much tickets can be discounted.

headline: Supreme Court’s Abortion Decision Reverberates in Presidential Campaign
abstract: Democrats and Republicans both quickly looked to rally voters by reminding them that the future of the court rested in the next president’s hands.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision to strike down parts of a restrictive abortion law in Texas rippled through the presidential campaign after its release on Monday, with Democrats and Republicans looking to rally voters with reminders that the future of the court was at stake in November.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Finale: Nikolaj Coster-Waldau on Cersei’s Madness and Jaime’s Evolution
abstract: Mr. Coster-Waldau, who plays Jaime, talks his character’s changes and possible spinoffs for the series.
lead_paragraph: Jaime Lannister set the tone for “Game of Thrones” in the pilot episode, shoving the young Bran Stark out of a window, paralyzing him, in the first of the show’s many unspeakably cruel acts.

headline: Diplomatic Deal With Turkey Upsets Israelis Wary of Conceding Too Much
abstract: Israel will pay $20 million to families of activists killed during an Israeli raid and will allow aid to enter Gaza, but the bodies of two Israeli soldiers will not be returned.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As Israeli and Turkish leaders announced the formal resumption of full diplomatic relations after a six-year fissure, the front page of the popular Hebrew newspaper Yediot Aharonot summed up the predicament for many Israelis: “Reconciliation or surrender.”

headline: As Migrants Face Abuse, Fear That ‘Brexit’ Has Given License to Xenophobia
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Hate Crimes', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Referendums']
abstract: Amid reports of attacks and graffiti aimed at Britain’s immigrants, human rights advocates and politicians expressed alarm that the vote had unleashed simmering hatred.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In Birmingham, protesters held a banner outside a mosque that said “rapefugees not welcome.”

headline: Italy Displays New Flair as Spain Shows Its Age
abstract: Suddenly aggressive on offense, the Italians knocked off the two-time defending champ to set up a matchup with Germany.
lead_paragraph: ST.-DENIS, France — The first two days of the knockout rounds at the European Championships were wholly, and remarkably, forgettable. The Wales-Northern Ireland game was drab. Croatia-Portugal was dreary. France offered just one decent half against Ireland. Belgium-Hungary felt like a limp.

headline: Meet the Lingerie Brand Marieyat
abstract: The line, now in its second collection, consists mainly of high-waisted and medium-rise underwear, bras and bodysuits.
lead_paragraph: The line, now in its second collection, consists mainly of high-waisted and medium-rise underwear, bras and bodysuits.

headline: Brand to Know: Subversive, Super-Comfortable Lingerie
abstract: Marieyat, a year-old London-based underwear brand, finds freedom in flaws.
lead_paragraph: When a pair of much-loved underwear starts sprouting holes, most people throw them in the trash. But for the London-based designer Marie Yeung, it was a pair of tattered undergarments that inspired her to start an underwear line, Marieyat, last year. “I was over at my friend Gwyneth’s house, and she was doing what girls do — showing each other clothes, putting on outfits, taking them off, putting them on again,” recalls Yeung. “I see that she is wearing a pair of underwear, made of a really sheer delicate fabric and that the binding has ripped, because they’re falling apart and because she just wears them at home, and obviously doesn’t care. The binding was so perfectly cut, just under the butt cheek. And I realized, this is actually appealing in a really weird way.”

headline: Pastors Praise Anti-Gay Massacre in Orlando, Prompting Outrage
keywords: ['Orlando, Fla, Shooting (2016)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: One preacher received a torrent of denunciation when he said, “The tragedy is that more of them didn’t die.”
lead_paragraph: After the massacre in Orlando, Fla., American religious leaders spoke in a largely unified voice, condemning the killer and mourning the dead. But at some extreme conservative Christian churches, there was another message: good riddance.

headline: An N.Y.U. Study Gone Wrong, and a Top Researcher Dismissed
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Research', 'Falsification of Data', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists']
abstract: The university and a federal investigation discovered a series of violations in the study of an experimental, mind-altering drug.
lead_paragraph: New York University’s medical school has quietly shut down eight studies at its prominent psychiatric research center and parted ways with a top researcher after discovering a series of violations in a study of an experimental, mind-altering drug.

headline: When You Write a Memoir, Readers Think They Know You Better Than They Do
abstract: After my second memoir, people stopped asking me questions. They thought they had the answers.
lead_paragraph: I once knew a woman who had been famously kidnapped as a child. She confessed to me that she longed to talk about her kidnapping, but no one ever brought it up. “Why?” she wondered. The story had been in print, after all, the subject of national headlines; it preceded her into every room. She was left with an acute sense of apartness, her unspoken story roiling inside her. “What am I supposed to do?” she asked me. “Pick up the phone and call Patty Hearst?”

headline: The Problem With Modern Policing, as Seen From the Right and From the Left
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Two books offer opposing arguments on crime and law enforcement.
lead_paragraph: Ferguson, Mo. The name alone identifies the problem, though it typically is reinforced by an equally familiar roll call: Eric Garner, Michael Brown, Laquan McDonald, Tamir Rice, Walter Scott. Since 2014 the nation has been engaged in an endless debate about whether it is crime or policing that is out of control.

headline: AstraZeneca Pushes to Protect Crestor From Generic Competition
keywords: ['Crestor (Drug)', 'Cholesterol', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Generic Brands and Products']
abstract: The drug maker is trying to get its popular anticholesterol pill approved to treat children who have a rare disease characterized by high cholesterol.
lead_paragraph: No more than a few hundred American children have a rare disease characterized by ultrahigh levels of bad cholesterol.

headline: In Paris, It’s a Cruel Fashion Summer
abstract: A stormy mood hits the men’s wear shows put on by Acne Studios, Lanvin and Sacai.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For weeks, hundreds of fashion professionals have been following fashion shows much the way that groupies once followed the Grateful Dead: in like-minded packs, across countries and nations, communicating among themselves in their own argot, focused to the exclusion of nearly everything else on the entertainment at hand.

headline: Getting Back on the Court at Wimbledon
abstract: Victoria Duval, 20, said returning to Wimbledon was “really hard emotionally” after long breaks for treatment of Hodgkin’s lymphoma and then, this year, for repair of a torn meniscus.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Shortly after 11:30 a.m. Monday, on Court 4 in the shadow of Centre Court, Daria Kasatkina won the first point of the 2016 Wimbledon tournament.

headline: Review: ‘The Return,’ a Son’s Pained Search for a Missing Father
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Hisham Matar’s memoir centers on his father, a Libyan dissident who was kidnapped in 1990 and taken to the notorious Abu Salim prison, and whose fate remains unknown.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of this eloquent memoir, Hisham Matar quotes these words, spoken by Odysseus’ son Telemachus in “The Odyssey”:

headline: Celebrating Black Culture With a Careful Eye
abstract: Sarah Lewis discusses the special issue of Aperture magazine she edited, devoted to photography of the black experience.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Lewis studies photography and its power to shape ideas of race and identity with a depth few others can match. Before joining the faculty at Harvard, where she is an assistant professor of history of art and architecture and African and African-American studies, she held curatorial positions at the Museum of Modern Art and the Tate Modern, where she often shaped provocative exhibitions dealing with race, representation and other topics.

headline: A Major Victory for Abortion Rights
abstract: The Supreme Court saw Texas’ dishonest anti-abortion law for what it is: an effort to end legal abortion.
lead_paragraph: In the most significant victory in a generation for a woman’s right to make decisions about her own body, the Supreme Court  on Monday struck down Texas’s harsh and dishonest anti-abortion law by a vote of 5 to 3.

headline: History in the Making
abstract: The recent installation of a series of historical photographs in The New York Times’s third-floor newsroom provides a chance to reflect on snapshots from the paper’s history.
lead_paragraph: The recent installation of a series of historical photographs in The New York Times’s third-floor newsroom provides a chance to reflect on snapshots from the paper’s history.

headline: Review: ‘Dead of Summer’ Tugs at Horror and Mystery
abstract: Scary visions and hormonal horseplay are part of this new series on Freeform, set at a haunted camp in 1989.
lead_paragraph: Before Adam Horowitz and Edward Kitsis (with Ian Goldberg) created the new series “Dead of Summer” for Freeform, they worked on a little show called “Lost.” Knowing that might keep you watching “Summer,” about young counselors at a haunted summer camp, longer than you would otherwise. It would be a small satisfaction to find out that these dimwits were dead all along.

headline: Edward Snowden Criticizes ‘Big Brother’ Measure in Russia
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Mr. Snowden, who took refuge in Russia after leaking classified United States data, called a Russian bill an assault on free speech.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Edward J. Snowden, an American who took refuge in Russia after leaking a trove of classified United States data from global surveillance, has criticized a proposed Russian law as an assault on freedom of speech, and has been rebuffed in an effort to collect a free-speech prize in Norway.

headline: In ‘Game of Thrones,’ the Pleasures of a Quickened Pace
abstract: If Season 6 was not the best season, it was its most entertaining, with faster and simpler plots.
lead_paragraph: This article includes spoilers for Season 6 of “Game of Thrones.”

headline: For ‘The Color Purple,’ a Delayed Box Office Bump
abstract: Last week the show grossed $799,021, up 42 percent over the previous week. It was the musical’s best showing since Jennifer Hudson left the cast.
lead_paragraph: “The Color Purple” got its post-Tonys bounce, one week late.

headline: Chicago and Jazz at Play, Ideally
abstract: Four musicians with strong ties to this city — Marquis Hill, Jeff Parker, Makaya McCraven and Greg Ward — have released quite different new albums that still form a bond.
lead_paragraph: There are a couple of ideal notions about jazz that I wish were more often true in practice. One is about regionalism: that a place, and the experience people have living in that place, shape the sound of the music. The other is about relativity of style: that musicians drawn to different parts of the jazz tradition can have no problem playing together.

headline: Gay Catholic Groups Want Pope Francis to Do More Than Apologize
abstract: Pope Francis’ comments about the church’s needing to apologize to gays for previous mistreatment must be followed by changes in teachings, the groups said.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Leaders of gay Catholic groups on Monday praised Pope Francis for saying that all Christians and the Roman Catholic Church owed an apology to gays for previous mistreatment, even as the groups called on the church to take more concrete steps to repudiate past teachings and condemn anti-gay violence.

headline: Review: ‘Here I Sit, Broken Hearted,’ Answering Nature’s Call With Bathroom Humor
abstract: Seth Panitch’s play, an hourlong exercise in puerile scatology, is built around men’s room graffiti, sight gags and comic riffs.
lead_paragraph: An hourlong exercise in puerile scatology, Seth Panitch’s “Here I Sit, Broken Hearted … A Bathroom Odyssey,” at the Samuel Beckett Theater, seemingly aspires to emulate, oh, perhaps, “The Book of Mormon” in its exaltation of the coarse and the crude. In skits built around men’s room graffiti, the show fleshes out primitive anatomical renderings and dime store doggerel with song, dance and lightning-fast comic riffs. But its frantic exertions and straining after wit prove exasperating.

headline: Putting Breast Cancer on a Diet
abstract: Doctors are studying whether weight loss improves survival for heavy patients.
lead_paragraph: Should weight loss be prescribed as a treatment for breast cancer?

headline: The Facts Win Out on Abortion
abstract: Without rhetorical flourishes, the Supreme Court forecloses the strategy of closing down clinics in the supposed aim of protecting women’s health.
lead_paragraph: SOMEONE landing from Mars on Monday and coming upon Justice Stephen G. Breyer’s majority Supreme Court opinion in the Texas abortion case would have had no hint of the decades-long battle over women’s right to abortion and the dogged efforts by states to put obstacles in their way.

headline: With Phillips Auction, Art Market Feels Effects of ‘Brexit’
abstract: The art market on Monday night felt the first effects of Britain’s momentous “Brexit” vote when Phillips held an auction of 20th-century and contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The art market on Monday night felt the first effects of Britain’s momentous “Brexit” vote when Phillips held an auction of 20th-century and contemporary art at its grand European headquarters in London.

headline: Williams Appeals Delaware Decision to End Pipeline Merger
abstract: Williams Companies shareholders voted in favor of a merger with Energy Transfer Equity, opening the way for Williams to file its appeal.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders of the Williams Companies voted on Monday to approve a merger with Energy Transfer Equity, the Dallas-based pipeline operator, paving the way for Williams to appeal a Delaware judge’s decision last week that allows the deal to be terminated.

headline: On a Heating Planet, ‘Gasland’ Filmmaker Josh Fox Lets Go and Loves
keywords: ['Coal', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Global Warming', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Natural Gas', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Oil Spills', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: A film on fighting climate change from the director of “Gasland” points the finger within instead of at familiar, insufficient, targets.
lead_paragraph: Josh Fox’s first and second films, “Gasland” and “Gasland Part 2,” were high-octane polemics aimed at ending fracking, shorthand for the revolutionary method of fracturing deep layers of shale to liberate natural gas and oil previously deemed unreachable. From “The Cove” (on Japan’s dolphin hunts) to “Pandora’s Promise” (on the benefits of nuclear energy) this strategy, meshing a film and a campaign, has become commonplace.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Brexit, Abortion, ‘Game of Thrones’
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: No Speaking Slots? Ted Cruz and John Kasich Brush Off Trump’s Threat
abstract: The two former primary rivals to Donald Trump said they did not care if he excluded them from speaking at the Republican convention, which he vowed to do unless they endorsed him.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz and John Kasich have a message for Donald J. Trump: They don’t care if they are not invited to speak at his convention.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: The Alternative Medical Bill: $30.2 Billion
keywords: ['Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Alternative and Complementary Medicine']
abstract: That is how much Americans spend each year on alternative and complementary medicines and procedures. None of it is covered by insurance.
lead_paragraph: Americans spend $30.2 billion a year on alternative and complementary medicines and procedures, including $1.9 billion on children 4 to 17 years old. None of it is covered by insurance.

headline: Upset Loss to Iceland Has England Gnashing Its Teeth
abstract: Iceland, a country of about 300,000 people, beat England, 2-1, in the round of 16 at the European Championships.
lead_paragraph: England lost a game on Monday. That has happened before.

headline: Peter Hutton, Filmmaker With Austerely Romantic Worldview, Dies at 71
abstract: All of Mr. Hutton’s films were silent. Generally devoid of camera movement and montage, they suggest sketchbooks or photographic albums.
lead_paragraph: Peter Hutton, an experimental filmmaker noted for his contemplative, sensuous, masterfully photographed portraits of landscapes and cities, died on Saturday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He was 71.

headline: Florida Jury Finds Former Chilean Officer Liable in ’73 Killing
abstract: A jury decided that Pedro Pablo Barrientos, a naturalized American, was behind the killing of a popular folk singer, Víctor Jara, in Chile during the coup that brought Pinochet to power.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — Four decades after the bullet-riddled body of the Chilean folk singer Víctor Jara was discovered in the mayhem of the military coup that upended his country, Mr. Jara’s family found some measure of justice on Monday in a Florida courtroom.

headline: Why the Supreme Court’s Texas Abortion Decision Is So Momentous
abstract: The ruling gives proper weight to medical expertise and scientific evidence — and gives respect to women and the choices they make.
lead_paragraph: Monday morning, the United States Supreme Court struck down parts of a Texas law that would have significantly reduced the number of abortion clinics in the state. Emily Bazelon, a staff writer for the magazine; Eric Posner, a professor at the University of Chicago Law School; and William Baude, an assistant professor at the University of Chicago Law School, have been exchanging emails about the meaning and impact of the court’s decision.

headline: Volkswagen to Pay $14.7 Billion to Settle Diesel Claims in U.S.
keywords: ['Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The automaker, federal officials and lawyers for a half-million diesel owners have reached a deal meant to resolve a big piece of the emissions cheating scandal.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen has agreed to pay up to $14.7 billion to settle claims stemming from its diesel emissions cheating scandal, in what would be one of the largest consumer class-action settlements ever in the United States.

headline: Seeking to Improve Ties With Russia, Turkey Apologizes for Downing Warplane
abstract: The same day Turkey announced a rapprochement with Israel, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan expressed regret about the downing of a Russian warplane last year.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey continued its diplomatic fence mending on Monday, apologizing for downing a Russian jet near its border with Syria last year.

headline: Abortion Ruling Could Create Waves of Legal Challenges
abstract: Monday’s Supreme Court ruling that a Texas abortion law was unconstitutional will prevent the threatened shutdown of clinics in some states, many of which have been operating in a legal limbo.
lead_paragraph: From Texas to Alabama to Wisconsin, more than a dozen Republican-run states in recent years have passed laws requiring that abortion clinics have hospital-grade facilities or use doctors with admitting privileges at nearby hospitals.

headline: A Single Senator Stymies the Export-Import Bank
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Senator Richard Shelby has held up the nomination of a board member of the bank, blocking $20 billion for American exports.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Thursday is an ignominious anniversary for the government agency that helps finance foreigners’ purchases of American exports. Thanks to a single senator, it has been a full year since the 82-year-old Export-Import Bank could approve deals exceeding $10 million, a limit that rules out high-dollar deals on airplanes, power generators, heavy equipment and nuclear reactors.

headline: How Britain Could Exit ‘Brexit’
abstract: The country has a few options for how it might remain in the European Union. Each carries significant risks — but, then again, so does leaving.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the days since Britons voted to leave the European Union, the so-called “Brexit” referendum has created such severe turmoil that public attention is increasingly focused on an extreme option: Can they get out of it?

headline: Michael Graves’s Residence, Rejected by Princeton, Is to Be Sold to Kean University
abstract: The architect’s home and two other properties are slated to be purchased by Kean for $20 and devoted to educational purposes.
lead_paragraph: Kean University, home of the nascent Michael Graves College for architecture and design, has received permission from its board of trustees to purchase three of Graves’s properties in Princeton, N.J. — including his residence and studio, the Warehouse — for $20.

headline: Spain’s Vote Deals Setback to Podemos, a Rising Protest Party
abstract: The radical left-wing party fell short of expectations in Sunday’s election as the Popular Party of Mariano Rajoy won the most votes.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — While no party emerged with a clear mandate from Spain’s second round of national elections over the weekend, the results did demonstrate that it was possible, after all, to stop the advance of Europe’s protest parties.

headline: Emigrant Savings Bank Discriminated Against Minorities, Brooklyn Jury Says
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgages', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Minorities', 'Discrimination']
abstract: A federal jury found that the bank had targeted minority homeowners with low credit scores, marketing subprime mortgages to them from 2005 to 2009.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury in Brooklyn found on Monday that the Emigrant Savings Bank had discriminated against eight minority homeowners by purposefully marketing to them subprime mortgages with what were described as predatory interest rates of as much as 18 percent a year.

headline: Sam Bell, Exacting Mentor of College Runners, Dies at 88
abstract: Bell coached track and field and cross-country at Indiana for nearly three decades, producing several Olympic athletes in the process.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bell, who turned out some of America’s best middle-distance runners as a college track and field and cross-country coach, died on Monday in Bloomington, Ind., the home of Indiana University, where he had spent most of his 40-year career. He was 88.

headline: What the Volkswagen Settlement Could Mean for Car Owners
keywords: ['Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Diesel Power', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: The company’s proposed deal includes an offer to buy back or fix faulty diesels — and either way, additional cash compensation of up to $10,000.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen has agreed to pay almost $15 billion to settle claims in the United States over its diesel emissions scandal, affecting nearly half a million cars. This is what that could mean for vehicle owners:

headline: Climate Change High on Agenda as Obama and Trudeau Meet for Summit
keywords: ['United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'United States International Relations', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Leaders of the United States, Mexico and Canada will announce a climate partnership, synchronizing their national policies to cut greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — When Justin Trudeau, the prime minister of Canada, appeared at the United Nations this spring to sign the Paris climate accord, the rapturous ovation he received was worthy of the celebrity he had become, a leader full of promise and of promises, especially on climate change.

headline: Justices Decline to Hear Case Limiting Debt Collectors
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Interest Rates', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'States (US)', 'Debt Collection']
abstract: The Supreme Court declined to review a 2015 ruling by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, limiting debt collectors to state usury laws.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court declined on Monday to hear a case that could undermine the ability of some lenders to charge high interest rates.

headline: Supreme Court Complicates Corruption Cases From New York to Illinois
keywords: ['Gifts to Public Officials', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Within moments of the court’s corruption ruling, defense lawyers were citing it as grounds to challenge past and pending cases brought by the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After Dean G. Skelos, the once-powerful New York state senator, was sentenced last month on federal corruption charges, one of his lawyers asked the judge to allow Mr. Skelos to remain free on bail while he appealed his conviction.

headline: Unicef Says Its Development Goals for Children Are at Risk
keywords: ['Infant Mortality', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: The United Nations children’s agency projected that by 2030, almost 70 million children will have died from preventable causes.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations said Monday that its global development goals for 2030 were at risk of failure, estimating that if current trends continue, nearly 70 million children will die from mostly preventable causes and that 750 million girls will be married while still children.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Doesn’t Mean Game Over, but It May Be Just the First Domino
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Referendums', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Yes, Britain’s economy is likely to suffer in the near term, but the most dire effects of the country’s split from the E.U. may be felt on the Continent.
lead_paragraph: This isn’t meant to scare you, but let’s consider the absolute worst-case scenarios of “Brexit.”

headline: Dominican Candidates in New York Tout Their Pioneer Status, but History Is Complicated
abstract: Adriano Espaillat or Guillermo Linares could become the first elected member of Congress born in the Dominican Republic. But earlier politicians also claim a Dominican heritage.
lead_paragraph: In the race to replace Representative Charles B. Rangel, the buzz around two of the candidates, Adriano Espaillat and Guillermo Linares, has been heightened by their chance to make history: Each is seeking to become the first person born in the Dominican Republic to be elected to Congress.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, June 28, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I think it is absolutely essential that we stay focused on how, in this transitional period, nobody loses their head, nobody goes off half-cocked, people don’t start ginning up scatterbrained or revengeful premises, but we look for ways to maintain the strength that will serve the interests and the values that brought us together in the first place.”

headline: American Swimmers Leave Father Time in Their Wake
abstract: Eight competitors from the U.S. swimming trials in 2000 are still seeking Olympic berths, with Dana Vollmer capturing a spot in the 100-meter butterfly.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — At her first Olympic trials, Dana Vollmer was upset because she did not win. Never mind that she was 12 years old, the youngest competitor striving to qualify for the United States team in 2000. After she tied for 43rd in the 100-meter butterfly, Vollmer stomped off the pool deck scowling.

headline: Pitching Woes Threaten Foundation of the Mets’ Hopes
abstract: Steven Matz has a bone spur, and Noah Syndergaard denied that he had one after lasting just three innings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pitching is the bedrock of the Mets’ championship hopes. The ground shook below them before Monday’s game, then crumbled during it. More nights like this will swallow up the season.

headline: Donald Trump Hires Former Adviser to Ted Cruz
abstract: Jason Miller will oversee interactions with the news media, a significant move as Mr. Trump shifts toward a more traditional campaign structure.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has hired a veteran political strategist and former adviser to Senator Ted Cruz as his de facto communications director, a significant move as Mr. Trump shifts toward a more traditional campaign structure.

headline: Wimbledon: Marcus Willis Beat the Odds. Next Up Is Roger Federer.
abstract: Willis, who had to win three matches in prequalifying to earn a wild card into Wimbledon qualifying, beat No. 53 Ricardas Berankis in the first round.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Roger Federer, tennis’s perennial sentimental favorite, will have to surrender that crown on Wednesday.

headline: Accused in Two Rapes, Former Student at Indiana University Avoids Prison With Plea Deal
abstract: John P. Enochs, 22, accepted a plea deal dismissing both charges, with a year’s probation and no prison time.
lead_paragraph: A former Indiana University student who was charged with rape in two separate cases in September accepted a plea deal last week in which both felony charges were dismissed and he was sentenced to a year’s probation with no prison time for a misdemeanor.

headline: Long Way to Go
abstract: Alex Vratsanos spins a Tuesday puzzle for us.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — One of my favorite stories when I was a child was E. B. White’s “CHARLOTTE’s Web.” I loved the book, I loved the 1973 cartoon and I especially loved CHARLOTTE, who was a mother-figure to the piglet Wilbur.

headline: For the Second Year, Rents in Some Stabilized Apartments in New York City Will Not Increase
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Landlords', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: The Rent Guidelines Board also voted to raise rents by 2 percent on two-year leases. The decision mirrored previous increases under Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: The board that sets rents for more than one million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City voted on Monday to freeze rents for one-year leases for the second year in a row.

headline: Randy Levine Has Strong Words for Reporters, Not Yankees
abstract: Levine, the team’s president, said that he was not frustrated with its performance and that there was a lot of baseball still to be played.
lead_paragraph: As president of the Yankees, Randy Levine can be a feisty defender of his team. And he seemed in a particularly combative mood Monday when asked about the Yankees’ struggles to get above .500 and whether the team would end up a buyer or a seller as the July 31 trading deadline approached.

headline: Elaborate Suicide Attack Hits Christian Village in Lebanon
abstract: While bombings have hit Beirut and elsewhere during the Syrian war, such assaults have been rare in the area of Monday’s attack.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Eight suicide bombers launched two waves of attacks on the Christian town of Al Qaa in northeastern Lebanon on Monday, killing at least five people and raising fears that violence from the civil war in neighboring Syria will further destabilize Lebanon, its fragile neighbor.

headline: Katie Ledecky Falls Short of a Record but Gains a Challenger
abstract: Ledecky finished 0.61 of a second off her two-year-old world record in the 400-meter freestyle, qualifying for an Olympic berth alongside Leah Smith.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Katie Ledecky was answering questions from reporters after winning the 400-meter freestyle Monday night at the United States Olympic swimming trials when a roar from the warm-down area drowned out her voice. The explosion of noise was for Leah Smith, the second-place finisher, who had arrived to cool down after giving Ledecky a roof-raising race at CenturyLink Center.

headline: Cuomo and Billy Joel Ride for Breast Cancer Awareness
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed a bill into law that is supposed to make it easier for women to get screened for breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: It is probably safe to say that in the history of bill signings by governors in the State of New York, few, if any, featured the entrance that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made on Monday.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Takes a Seat Again as the Yankees Cite His Anemic Numbers
abstract: General Manager Brian Cashman pointed to Rodriguez’s poor performance against right-handed pitching and said he wants to see the Yankees contend before the trade deadline.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez emerged from the Yankees’ clubhouse two hours before the game against the Texas Rangers on Monday at Yankee Stadium. He hunched over on the dugout steps, looking meditatively out at the field.

headline: Somewhere, John Sorensen, 92, Is Smiling
abstract: Mr. Sorensen, one of the six people followed in a series of articles about the oldest New Yorkers, died June 26, after falling in his apartment in May.
lead_paragraph: John Sorensen turned 92 the day after Christmas, and from the first time I met him, almost a year earlier, he said he wanted to die. Some days he had a sense of humor about it. “The only thing about dying,” he said one day, “is that I won’t be alive long enough to enjoy the fact that I finally died.”

headline: Amra Sadikovic Faces Serena Williams at Wimbledon Two Years After She Walked Away
abstract: After Sadikovic spent over a year outside the professional circuit, her career bloomed, highlighted by her entry to Wimbledon through the qualifying draw.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — For Amra Sadikovic, a 27-year-old Swiss player who is facing Serena Williams in the first round Tuesday, playing at Wimbledon has been a dream 18 years in the making — except for a 14-month stretch in which she gave up on it entirely.

headline: Noah Syndergaard Exits Early, Putting Mets on Alert
abstract: A pedestrian Mets offense staked Syndergaard to an early four-run lead, but he gave up a season-high five runs and left after the third inning.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the midst of a third-inning meltdown Monday, Mets starter Noah Syndergaard summoned catcher Travis d’Arnaud to the mound. Something was not right with Syndergaard; his command had oddly disappeared. Moments later, Syndergaard called for d’Arnaud again, and boos rained down from Washington Nationals fans.

headline: What’s on TV Tuesday
abstract: “Frontline” investigates reform at the Newark Police Department. “Dead of Summer” brings scary campfire stories to life. And a new season of “Very British Problems” starts.
lead_paragraph: “Frontline” investigates reform within the Newark Police Department after a three-year Justice Department investigation. “Dead of Summer” goes back to camp in the 1980s, where scary campfire stories come to life. And “Very British Problems” returns, with James Corden and David Tennant.

headline: Order of Business for E.U. in Brussels? Weeds, Then ‘Brexit’
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: As leaders gather for the first time since Britain’s vote, regulatory minutiae will come first, illustrating why so many view the bloc as a meddling bureaucratic machine.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Less than 24 hours after Britain threw Europe’s postwar order into disarray last Thursday by voting to leave the European Union, dozens of officials from the bloc’s 28 member countries and its executive arm met behind closed doors in a drab Brussels office block to discuss the urgent issues at hand.

headline: Corrections: June 28, 2016

headline: 졸업생들에게 전하는 메시지: 지금은 매우 힘든 시대지만, 여러분은 해낼 수 있습니다
abstract: 만약 졸업식 축사가 우리가 사는 시대를 반영한다면, 올해 미국 대학교 졸업식 축사들은 우리에게 다가올 날이 힘겨울 수 있음을 시사한다. 그렇지만 여전히 희망의 끈을 놓지 않을 이유는 있다.
lead_paragraph: 만약 졸업식 축사가 우리가 사는 시대를 반영한다면, 올해 미국 대학교 졸업식 축사들은 우리에게 다가올 날이 힘겨울 수 있음을 시사한다. 그렇지만 여전히 희망의 끈을 놓지 않을 이유는 있다.

headline: A New Treatment for Dogs Scared by Thunder and Fireworks
abstract: A new drug, Sileo, has been developed to help with canine noise phobia. But you play the key role in making your pet more comfortable.
lead_paragraph: It is entirely possible that no one dreads the dog days of summer more than dogs themselves.

headline: NASA’s Juno Spacecraft Arrives at Jupiter
abstract: The Juno spacecraft successfully entered orbit around Jupiter on July 4.
lead_paragraph: The Juno spacecraft successfully entered orbit around Jupiter on July 4.

headline: Juno: Piercing Jupiter’s Clouds
abstract: On July 4, 2016, NASA’s Juno spacecraft arrived to study Jupiter after a trip of nearly two billion miles.
lead_paragraph: On July 4, 2016, NASA’s Juno spacecraft arrived to study Jupiter after a trip of nearly two billion miles.

headline: NASA’s Juno Spacecraft Will Soon Be in Jupiter’s Grip
abstract: The spacecraft is to orbit the largest planet in the solar system, perhaps providing insight into the origin of Earth.
lead_paragraph: After traveling for five years and nearly 1.8 billion miles, NASA’s Juno spacecraft will announce its arrival at Jupiter with the simplest of radio signals: a three-second beep.

headline: Marine Le Pen : Après le Brexit, le printemps des peuples est inévitable !
abstract: La décision que vient de prendre le peuple britannique est un acte de courage — le courage de ceux qui assument leur liberté.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — S’il est bien une chose qui chatouille l’orgueil d’un Français, c’est qu’un Anglais vienne lui voler la vedette. Mais devant la valeur du courage, même le Français le plus fier ne peut que s’incliner : il ne lui reste qu’à tirer son chapeau. Et c’est bel et bien un acte de courage que la décision que vient de prendre le peuple britannique, le courage de ceux qui assument leur liberté.

headline: Marine Le Pen: After Brexit, the People’s Spring Is Inevitable
abstract: The decision that the British just made was an act of courage — the courage of a people who embrace their freedom.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — IF there’s one thing that chafes French pride, it’s seeing the British steal the limelight. But in the face of real courage, even the proudest French person can only tip his hat and bow. The decision that the people of Britain have just made was indeed an act of courage — the courage of a people who embrace their freedom.

headline: Election Choices From the Editorial Board
abstract: Here are some recommendations in Tuesday’s Democratic primary races for Congress.
lead_paragraph: Here are some recommendations in today’s Democratic primary races for Congress in New York. The polls in New York City will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

keywords: ['Social Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The loyalty culture and the flavor of the working-class rebellion.
lead_paragraph: Anybody who spends time in the working-class parts of America (and, one presumes, Britain) notices the contagions of drug addiction and suicide, and the feelings of anomie, cynicism, pessimism and resentment.

headline: From Uruguay, a Model for Making Abortion Safer
abstract: Even when abortion was illegal, doctors organized to inform pregnant women of their choices and promise post-abortion treatment.
lead_paragraph: With the announcement in April that the Zika virus spreading across Latin America can cause microcephaly in the womb, leaders across the region have come under increased pressure to relax some of the world’s most restrictive laws against abortion.

headline: The Brexit Spillover
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Editorials', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Referendums', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Hedge Funds']
abstract: By deciding to leave the European Union, Britain has created global economic uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: Economic policy makers had already turned cautious even before Britain voted last week to leave the European Union. This month, when the Federal Reserve refrained from raising interest rates, chairwoman Janet Yellen cited uncertainty over the outcome as a reason to wait.

headline: Brexit Proponents’ False Promises Crumble
abstract: Some of the most prominent politicians behind the Leave campaign are now changing their tune.
lead_paragraph: Well, that didn’t take long. Some of the most prominent politicians behind the “Leave” campaign are backing away from the false claims and dubious promises that they made in the run-up to the referendum to take Britain out of the European Union.

headline: Don’t Mess With Texit
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The British are going. Arthur C. Brooks and Gail Collins ask what it means for populists and secessionists at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Brooks: What a week, Gail. The Brits decide to leave the European Union. Anyone who doubts that major nations can take a big populist turn just got a wake-up call, to put it mildly. Everyone wonders who’s next. The Dutch? The French? I’ve been seeing a lot on Twitter about “Texit,” which Greg Abbott, the governor of Texas, apparently felt the need to explain won’t be happening.

headline: How to Save Venezuela
abstract: What should be done to address the civil, economic and humanitarian crisis in the country?

lead_paragraph: Before the start of the ninth inning of the Yankees’ game against the Texas Rangers on Monday night, Aroldis Chapman warmed up in the bullpen, preparing to help the Yankees escape with a one-run victory in what had become a rain-soaked affair.

headline: Oakland Votes to Block Large Shipments of Coal
abstract: The California city’s decision is a blow to a developer’s plans to use a former Army base as an export terminal to ship coal to overseas markets.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The city of Oakland, Calif., on Monday banned the transport and storage of large coal shipments, a blow to a developer’s plans to use a former Army base as an export terminal to ship coal to China and other overseas markets.

keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Airbnb has charmed and strong-armed lawmakers around the world to allow it to operate in their communities. But two cities, Airbnb’s hometown, San Francisco, and New York, the service’s largest United States market, have not been so compliant.

abstract: A new exhibit of photos made by young soldiers in war zones features poignant images of daily life in a distant, and dangerous, land.
lead_paragraph: A new exhibit of photos made by young soldiers in war zones features poignant images of daily life in a distant, and dangerous, land.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times Book Review asked the acclaimed novelist Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie to write a short story about the American election. A second work of election fiction — by a different writer — will follow this fall.

headline: How Young Soldiers Saw Life in Wartime Vietnam
abstract: A new exhibit of photos made by young soldiers in war zones features poignant images of daily life in a distant, and dangerous, land.
lead_paragraph: The photographs are almost banal.

headline: A Sea of Charter Schools in Detroit Leaves Students Adrift
abstract: Michigan leapt at the promise of charters 23 years ago, betting that more competition would improve public education. Instead, old problems grew worse.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — On the face of it, Ana Rivera could have had almost any choice when it came to educating her two sons. For all the abandoned buildings and burned-down houses in her neighborhood in the southwest part of this city, national charter school companies had seen a market and were setting up shop within blocks of each other, making it easier to find a charter school than to buy a carton of milk.

headline: It’s Dogs vs. Poachers in the Fight to Protect Elephants
abstract: Tanzania has trained four Belgian Malinois to check cargo and luggage for smuggled ivory at the main airport and port in Dar es Salaam.
lead_paragraph: The government of Tanzania has gone to the dogs in its effort to stop the flow of ivory taken from elephants.

headline: Takata Chief Executive to Resign as Financial Pressure Mounts
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The departure of Shigehisa Takada comes as the embattled car parts supplier deals with the fallout from the largest automotive recall in history.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The chief executive of Takata said on Tuesday that he would step down, as the embattled car parts supplier looks to attract much-needed financial support to deal with the fallout from the largest automotive safety recall in history.

headline: Adichie on Mrs. Trump
abstract: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie says, “Fiction can remind us . . . that the players in politics are first human beings.”
lead_paragraph: In an election season widely seen as stranger than fiction, we decided to turn to fiction to see how it might illuminate today’s befuddling political climate. For the first time ever, the Book Review has commissioned an original short story. The assignment: Write anything about this election season you like. The result, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s “The Arrangements,” on our cover this week, updates Virginia Woolf’s “Mrs. Dalloway” — with Melania Trump as Clarissa.

lead_paragraph: The presidential primaries are history, but plenty of congressional preliminaries remain, with Tuesday’s round featuring some crucial matchups in Colorado, New York and Oklahoma.

keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Crestor (Drug)', 'Currency', 'Debt Collection', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Medical Devices', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Start-ups', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'US Dollar (Currency)', 'Venture Capital', 'Yen (Currency)']
