headline: Three Mornings With Muhammad Ali
abstract: The photographer John Stewart recounts the first time he met the late boxer in 1977.
lead_paragraph: In 1977, the photographer John Stewart was commissioned by Muhammad Ali to take his portrait. “Two franchisers of Muhammad Ali came to see me,” he recalls. “They had seen a show of my work in New York and had suggested to Ali he should have me photograph him. I was summoned to Chicago to meet ‘the Greatest.’” The late boxer gave Stewart, now 96, worldwide exclusivity of his portrait for one year — rights that Stewart eventually sold to his friend Andy Warhol.

headline: Many Women Prefer to Groom, Citing Hygiene (and Baffling Doctors)
abstract: A new study confirmed the widespread practice of pubic hair grooming, and indicated that the thinking behind the practice is changing.
lead_paragraph: For years, gynecologists have had a bird’s-eye view on a phenomenon that is now so popular as to be almost commonplace: female genitalia, bereft of hair.

headline: A Multisensory Art Experience That Starts in Chelsea — and Ends in Beacon
abstract: Isabel Lewis’s commission for Dia spans the art foundation’s two sites, and the train ride connecting them.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday night, inside an industrial building on West 22nd Street, guests slumped into white sofas, sipped beers and chatted; some studied the foliage that had been installed in the space with a web of cords. The Berlin-based artist Isabel Lewis took the mic, lowered the volume of the music and thanked the crowd for coming. She named a few of the people she’d already met; then she asked a man who identified himself as “Doug from around the corner” if he thought he had a soul.

headline: A Bayer Deal for Monsanto Would Get E.U. Regulatory Scrutiny
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: European Union competition authorities said they would examine concerns raised about the potential impact of a merger of Bayer and Monsanto.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — European competition regulators will closely review a potential takeover of Monsanto by the German chemical maker Bayer if a deal were to be consummated, according to a letter released on Wednesday.

headline: While Limited, Wi-Fi-First Phones Are a Good, Frugal Bet
abstract: Only some phones work with the services, which seek out Wi-Fi networks to carry call and data before turning to cell towers.
lead_paragraph: YOUR household Wi-Fi router has a hidden power: It is also a cellphone service provider. In fact, most mobile data traffic travels through smaller networks like Wi-Fi routers, not those hulking cell towers outside.

headline: An Index of Uncertainty Surges After ‘Brexit’
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Quantifying the tremors that the British vote has spread, not just in Britain but across the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: This morning, my 3-year-old son asked what was going to happen after breakfast. I misheard, and launched into a disquisition on the political disturbances in Britain, the challenge of maintaining an integrated Europe and threats to the world economy in the wake of “Brexit.”

headline: In Australian Election, Discontent Is the Front-Runner
abstract: Ahead of voting on Saturday, approval ratings for the leaders of Australia’s two major parties have tumbled, and voters seem to be drawn to the fringes.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Australia has burned through six prime ministers in the last nine years, a pattern that its current leader, Malcolm Turnbull, hoped to break by dissolving Parliament and calling an election for this weekend.

headline: Amazon Inspire Removes Some Content Over Copyright Issues
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: Amazon Inspire, a resource site where teachers share lesson plans, removed three items after complaints that the products were copyrighted materials.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — File this under how not to roll out a high-profile digital education platform.

headline: Fast Walkers of New York
abstract: A reader answers a tourist’s query about why New Yorkers always seem to be in a hurry.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Contract for United Airlines Flight Attendants Would Truly Unite Them
abstract: The deal would raise attendants’ pay and combine work forces that have remained separate since the 2010 merger of United and Continental.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines and leaders of its flight attendants’ union have agreed to a new labor contract that will unify the cabin crews for the first time since United’s merger with Continental Airlines more than five years ago.

headline: Two Summery Cocktail Recipes, One Handy New App
abstract: A CFDA-award winning Instagrammer and James Beard-award winning bartender collaborate on the new Liquor Cabinet offering on iTunes.
lead_paragraph: There have long been apps for making cocktails. But now, there’s one that’s as nice-looking as it is authoritative, thanks to its founding partners: a CFDA Award-winning Instagrammer and a James Beard Award-winning bartender. The Liquor Cabinet, available on iTunes beginning today, offers classic recipes tested and refined by Maxwell Britten, who slung drinks at Williamsburg’s Maison Premiere when it was recognized for its Outstanding Bar Program at the Beard awards earlier this year.

headline: 1966: British Premier Faults Bombings in Vietnam
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Prime Minister Harold Wilson of Britain speaks against the bombing of Hanoi and Haiphong in June 1966.
lead_paragraph: Bombing is extended in Vietnam in 1966. British Pathé.

headline: New Rules for Drones
abstract: The Future of Privacy Forum writes that “best practices can help promote responsible data practices.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Cleveland Relaxes Rules on Protests Near G.O.P. Convention Site
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: A lawsuit filed by the American Civil Liberties Union led to looser rules on the amount of space to be used by protesters, and the amount of time.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The city of Cleveland agreed Wednesday to allow protests closer to the site of the Republican National Convention next month, approving rule changes that increase the amount of space demonstrators can occupy and extend the amount of time that demonstrations will be permitted.

headline: On Centre Court, Roger Federer Shares in an Everyman’s Glory
abstract: Federer defeated the British qualifier Marcus Willis in straight sets as the Wimbledon crowd cheered on one of their own.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — There was an extended roar from the collective heart and a standing ovation.

headline: For Sara and Erin Foster, the Worst Is Yet to Come on VH1
abstract: “Barely Famous,” the sisters’ mock reality show, which lampoons “real” reality shows and Hollywood narcissism, returns for its second season.
lead_paragraph: Sara and Erin Foster know what you probably think of them.

headline: Cruise Ship Sewage
abstract: Friends of the Earth writes, “It is time for the E.P.A. to crack down and stop allowing the cruise industry to use our oceans as a toilet.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Needed: Urgent Action to Fight Zika
abstract: The Infectious Diseases Society of America writes that “public health demands leadership in a time of such crisis.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Turkey’s Twin Terrorist Threats, Explained
abstract: The Islamic State and Kurdish militant groups are themselves enemies, but their violence has become part of an overlapping set of problems rooted in Syria.
lead_paragraph: When three suicide bombers attacked Istanbul’s main airport on Tuesday, killing at least 41 people, Turkey began a ritual that it has refined with so many recent bombings: looking for hints as to which of the country’s two major terrorism threats was responsible.

headline: Jessica Williams Is Leaving ‘The Daily Show’
abstract: Thursday’s episode will be the last for Ms. Williams, who joined the show in 2012.
lead_paragraph: As the television news business — the programs that report it and those that mock it — braces for the presidential conventions next month, one correspondent at “The Daily Show” has determined that this is as good a time as any to exit the series.

headline: Who Is Valie Export? Just Look, and Please Touch
abstract: This artist’s works were among the most radical feminist statements in Europe of the ‘60s and ‘70s.
lead_paragraph: In 1967, the Austrian artist Waltraud Hollinger jettisoned her family name and the last name her husband had given her and became Valie Export, a nom de guerre inspired by a popular brand of cigarettes. But late last week, at a hotel in the West Village where she was supposed to be staying, the front desk could find no record of a Valie Export having checked in.

headline: Puerto Rico Relief Measure Clears Senate, Goes to Obama
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Credit and Debt', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: The Senate voted for a House bill, backed by the Obama administration, to create a control board and help the island restructure its $72 billion debt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just two days before Puerto Rico plans to default on a large debt payment, the Senate on Wednesday passed and sent to the White House a relief measure to help the financially desperate island surmount its fiscal crisis, ending a grueling, monthslong effort to rescue the commonwealth.

headline: A 25-Year-Old Nova in the Smoked Fish Universe
abstract: Manhattan’s lox temples are well known: Zabar’s, Barney Greengrass, Russ & Daughters. Sable’s, on the Upper East Side, is unsung, considered a newcomer at 25 years old.
lead_paragraph: The phrase most often spoken at Sable’s, an appetizing shop established on the Upper East Side in 1991, is probably, “Can I get a ——?”

headline: Airport Attack Hits Symbol of Turkey’s Global Aspirations
abstract: The 41 victims of the suicide bombing at Istanbul Ataturk Airport reflected the city’s cosmopolitan and international character.
lead_paragraph: The 41 victims of the suicide bombing at Istanbul Ataturk Airport reflected the city’s cosmopolitan and international character.

headline: Three Elegant Chronograph Watches That Clock Distance and Speed
abstract: They merge a sporty tachymeter with a dressy profile.
lead_paragraph: A classier chronograph that merges a sporty tachymeter, for clocking distance and speed, with a dressy profile.

headline: Shedding ‘Too Big to Fail’ Label Was Worth $50 Billion to G.E.
abstract: Since G.E. announced its plans to offload almost all of GE Capital’s assets, its stock has added about $50 billion in overall market capitalization.
lead_paragraph: What is the cost of being labeled a systemically important financial institution? In the case of General Electric, the magic number looks to be about $50 billion.

headline: He’s Gay. He’s Lonely. And He’s Coming to Broadway.
abstract: “Significant Other,” a comedic drama by Joshua Harmon about a young gay man yearning for love, is coming to Broadway next winter.
lead_paragraph: A comedic drama about a young gay man yearning for love is the first new American play planned for the current Broadway season.

headline: Victim of Racist Taunts in England: A Mexican-American Who Backs ‘Brexit’
abstract: Juan Jasso, 38, said his views had not been changed by the xenophobic insults he endured on a tram in Manchester.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He kept his cool as foul-mouthed hooligans taunted him on a crowded tram in Manchester, England, one of them demanding that he “get back to Africa.” He became the face of the resolve shown by migrants who have endured xenophobic insults in the tense days since Britain voted last week to leave the European Union. A local newspaper praised him as “SuperJuan.”

headline: Bill Clinton and Mark Cuban Talk at a Casual Dinner Party
abstract: The encounter, at the home of a Hollywood agent and a top bundler for Hillary Clinton, comes amid one of the more unusual political courtships of the 2016 campaign.
lead_paragraph: On a fund-raising swing to the West Coast last weekend, Bill Clinton had a casual dinner with Mark Cuban, the outspoken businessman and TV star who has inserted himself into the 2016 campaign, criticizing Donald J. Trump and even offering himself as a potential vice-presidential candidate for Hillary Clinton.

headline: Dear Bernie Sanders: What You Didn’t Say
abstract: “Mr. Sanders fails again to put his full weight behind the one person standing between us and a Trump presidency: Hillary Clinton,” a reader writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Paris, Modeling Takes a Back Seat to Soccer
keywords: ['Paris Fashion Week', 'Soccer', 'Models (Professional)', "Men's Fashion Week", 'UEFA European Football Championship']
abstract: ‘I don’t care about castings and fittings,’ one model says. ‘I came here to watch matches.’
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On the Sunday that France bested Ireland to advance to the quarterfinals, the men’s fashion shows were winding down, but soccer’s European Championships were ramping up. It was a bright and breezy afternoon, a happy respite from days of stifling heat, and a gang of male models was settling down in front of an outdoor screen at Au Grand Turenne, a bar in the Marais, to watch the Germany-Slovakia match.

headline: How to Talk to Fireflies
abstract: Most fireflies have their own flash pattern to light up at night. A new device tries to get people talking to them.
lead_paragraph: As Earth rotates in the summer, fireflies whisper sweet nothings to each other in the most beautiful language never heard. For millions of years the insects have called to one another secretly, using flashes of light like a romantic morse code. With some rather simple technology — a light and a battery — scientists have been decoding their love notes for years. But recently I learned that you don’t have to be an entomologist to try to talk to fireflies.

headline: Auto Insurance Is Costlier at Lower Incomes, Study Says
abstract: Lower socioeconomic factors like blue-collar work or renting can mean higher rates for even good drivers, the Consumer Federation of America says.
lead_paragraph: Being on the lower end of the wage scale can mean paying much more for car insurance, even for good drivers.

headline: The Photographer Who Captured London Life in the ’70s
abstract: Al Vandenberg, the focus of a new book, photographed the city’s interwoven subcultures.
lead_paragraph: Al Vandenberg, the focus of a new book, photographed the city’s interwoven subcultures.

headline: Portraits of London Life (and its Many Subcultures) in the ’70s and ’80s
abstract: Al Vandenberg’s street photos offer a summery, idiosyncratic vision of the city’s youth culture.
lead_paragraph: On fine afternoons in the mid-1970s and early ’80s, the photographer Al Vandenberg spent hours walking through London with his camera. After years in the music and advertising industries, he had become bored with feeding the egos of famous people — instead, he aimed to seek out anonymous subjects on the city streets. So he photographed everyone from rockabillies and teenagers in their customized school uniforms to shop workers and proto-punks, art students to so-called Sloane Rangers. Together, his images — many of them unpublished and unseen for decades — offer a rich portrait of the city’s interwoven subcultures.

headline: Alvin Toffler, Author of ‘Future Shock,’ Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Toffler wrote the prophetic 1970 best seller and other books anticipating how people would deal with runaway change and an explosion of information.
lead_paragraph: Alvin Toffler, the celebrated author of “Future Shock,” the first in a trilogy of best-selling books that presciently forecast how people and institutions of the late 20th century would contend with the immense strains and soaring opportunities of accelerating change, died on Monday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 87.

headline: Europe Is Expected to Approve E.U.-U.S. Data Transfer Pact
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The decision is based on renewed assurances by United States officials that Europeans’ data will be sufficiently protected when it is transferred.
lead_paragraph: European officials are expected to approve a new agreement with the United States aimed at helping companies like General Electric and Google, among others, move online data between the two regions despite concerns about how the digital information of Europeans may be retrieved by the American government.

headline: Traveling to Turkey? What Tourists Should Know
abstract: The latest on the terrorist threat in Istanbul and other parts of Turkey, including updates on flights and areas to avoid.
lead_paragraph: A suicide attack Tuesday night at Istanbul Ataturk Airport killed dozens of people and wounded more than 200. Here’s what travelers should know about the terrorist threat in Turkey, including updates on flights and areas to avoid.

headline: Who Are VW’s Victims?
abstract: A reader says everyone who breathes the poisoned air, and not just the car owners, is a victim.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Small Mouth Sounds’ Grunts Again
abstract: Well received last year, Bess Wohl’s Off Broadway play about six characters at a silent retreat starts a new run at the Pershing Square Signature Center.
lead_paragraph: “Brexit”! Trump! Audra McDonald’s pregnancy closes “Shuffle Along”! This chaotic world makes a quiet respite at a spiritual retreat — the setting for Bess Wohl’s “Small Mouth Sounds” — seem mighty appealing.

headline: Competing on Good-Will Tour in U.S., a Cuban Team Sends Mixed Signals
abstract: On a tour of North America, Cuba’s baseball federation showed signs of old-world stubbornness despite pronouncements that it welcomed the thawing of relations with the United States.
lead_paragraph: LITTLE FALLS, N.J. — In a private interview after a news conference in which only baseball-related questions were requested, Higinio Vélez was asked one that veered well outside the preapproved lines.

headline: Lawmakers Urge John Kerry to Press U.N. for Haiti Cholera Response
keywords: ['Cholera', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Angry over a six-year epidemic traced to United Nations peacekeepers, 158 members of Congress asked Mr. Kerry to push for a solution, including reparations.
lead_paragraph: Angry over a six-year cholera epidemic in Haiti traced to infected United Nations peacekeepers, 158 members of Congress asked Secretary of State John Kerry on Wednesday to pressure the United Nations for a more effective response, including reparations to victims.

headline: 5 Noteworthy Hotels Opening This Summer
abstract: New hotels include a Nickelodeon property in the Dominican Republic, a W in Goa, India, and a resort in the mountains of Oman.
lead_paragraph: Summer isn’t the busiest time for buzzy hotel openings. According to Kristen Korey Pike, who owns the Atlanta travel consultancy KK Travels Worldwide, many splashy properties tend to debut in the fall. That said, there are some noteworthy lodgings that will be open for business as of this summer. Below is a list of five we’ve gathered from hotel industry experts.

headline: Crossing Borders With Free Music
abstract: The Latin Alternative Music Conference features a range of acts, including Carla Morrison, Hurray for the Riff Raff and Buscabulla.
lead_paragraph: In a year when immigration has become political tinder, the annual Latin Alternative Music Conference is a timely reminder of immigration’s cultural side: an influx of ideas, recombined as they traverse new territories. The conference’s big free outdoor shows could introduce many New Yorkers to musicians who rarely visit the city, most notably Carla Morrison, a songwriter born in Mexico who has lived on both sides of the United States border.

headline: String Delicacies of Bach and Beethoven at Bargemusic
abstract: It’s a week of masterworks for violin and cello at the floating recital hall in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: It’s immersion week in masterworks for violin and cello at Bargemusic, Brooklyn’s popular floating recital hall. On Sunday afternoon, July 3, the cellist Jeffrey Solow presents Part 1 in a survey of Bach’s six solo cello suites, playing the first three of these seminal works and offering spoken commentaries. (4 p.m., Fulton Ferry Landing, bargemusic.org.)

headline: Letting Beckett Seep Into a Hamptons Summer
abstract: Jonah Bokaer’s exhibition at the Parrish Art Museum will feature choreographic project based on the opera “Neither.”
lead_paragraph: The tender summer light of the Hamptons will do battle with the existentially icy light of Samuel Beckett — “then gently light unfading on that unheeded neither” — when the media artist and choreographer Jonah Bokaer opens “Platform: Jonah Bokaer” at the Parrish Art Museum in Watermill, N.Y., on Saturday, July 9. The work, on view through Oct. 16, will feature a projection of a new choreographic work for film, shot within the museum, and 122 choreographic drawings — based on the score for the opera “Neither,” Beckett’s 1977 collaboration with Morton Feldman — installed on the wooden beams that form the austere museum’s spine. (279 Montauk Highway, 631-283-2118, parrishart.org.)

headline: Walking and Watching at Elastic City’s Final Festival
abstract: “Their Shoes,” a tour of Tompkins Square Park in the East Village devised by the artist Aki Sasamoto, kicks off the Last Walks.
lead_paragraph: Since 2010, the organization Elastic City has hosted free, artist-led walking tours that move through urban spaces in unconventional ways. Whether taking tiny steps through Stuyvesant Town or using plastic bags as pillows on the pavement in Union Square, participants are invited to be curious, playful pedestrians.

headline: A Retrospective of Warren Oates, Symbol of Frontier Machismo
abstract: The character actor from the 1960s and ’70s is being celebrated by the Film Society of Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The character actor Warren Oates, a symbol of anarchic frontier machismo, is being celebrated by the Film Society of Lincoln Center in a retrospective that focuses on his western noir “Private Property,” directed by Leslie Stevens and long thought lost. The black-and-white movie, which runs the first week in July, was reassembled from film elements recently discovered by the U.C.L.A. Film & Television Archive. In it, Oates, who died in 1982, stars with Corey Allen as a pair of drifters who invade the life of a lonely housewife. The retrospective, which runs through July 7, also includes Sam Peckinpah’s hallucinatory, ultraviolent 1974 masterwork, “Bring Me the Head of Alfredo Garcia”; Terrence Malick’s “Badlands,” in which Oates played Sissy Spacek’s father; Thomas McGuane’s surreal seriocomedy “92 in the Shade,” set in Key West, Fla.; and three films directed by Monte Hellman, including “Two-Lane Blacktop,” a favorite of drag racing fans. (filmlinc.org.)

headline: Idris Elba, Starring in His Very Own Death Wish
abstract: In a new series on Discovery, Mr. Elba, actor and adrenaline junkie, goes faster than he probably should.
lead_paragraph: Spend the Fourth of July with a man who can ignite even the dampest fuse: “Idris Elba: No Limits” (Monday at 7 p.m. on Discovery) follows the actor and adrenaline junkie as he goes fast and furious in rally driving, street racing, aerobatics and powerboating.

headline: Review: In ‘Here Comes the Sun,’ a Hustle to Thrive in Jamaica
abstract: Far from touristy beaches, a woman harboring a hazardous secret does what it takes to transcend poverty, in this novel from Nicole Dennis-Benn.
lead_paragraph: In “Here Comes the Sun,” Nicole Dennis-Benn has written the ultimate antibeach novel. It may take place entirely in Montego Bay, but be not deceived: If you’ve come for palm trees and umbrella drinks, you’ve boarded the wrong plane. This lithe, artfully-plotted debut concerns itself with the lives of those for whom tourists can barely be bothered to remove their Ray-Bans, and the issues it tackles — the oppressive dynamics of race, sexuality and class in post-colonial Jamaica — have little to do with the rum-and-reggae island of Sandals commercials.

headline: Travelers to Dominican Republic Lead New York City in Positive Zika Tests
abstract: Results from the latest tests were a stark reminder that many of the most popular destinations for New Yorkers in the Caribbean and Latin America pose a serious health risk.
lead_paragraph: More than half of those who have tested positive for the Zika virus in New York City had traveled in recent months to the Dominican Republic, the city’s health department said on Wednesday, releasing data from its latest round of testing.

headline: Shakespeare: Actor. Playwright. Social Climber.
abstract: Newly discovered documents suggest the playwright cared very much about a coat of arms that reflected his status as a “gentleman.”
lead_paragraph: Shakespeare biography has long circled a set of tantalizing mysteries: Was he Protestant or secretly Catholic? Gay or straight? Loving toward his wife, or coldly dismissive?

headline: Impossibly Modern 1930s Fashion and Ad Photos
abstract: Paul Outerbridge, a friend of Man Ray’s and Duchamp’s, brought a witty eye and careful composition to early color photography.
lead_paragraph: Paul Outerbridge, a friend of Man Ray’s and Duchamp’s, brought a witty eye and careful composition to early color photography.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Lance Reddick of ‘The Wire’ Reads ‘In the Waiting Room of Estranged Spouses’
abstract: The actor reads the story of a former soldier who finds hope in a chance meeting with a mother and her young son.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the actor and producer Lance Reddick (“Fringe,” “The Wire”) reads the essay “In the Waiting Room of Estranged Spouses,” about a former soldier rocked by infidelity who finds hope in a chance meeting with a mother and her young son.

headline: A Real Rock of a Diamond Fails to Sell at Auction
abstract: The 1,109-carat stone was offered at a public auction at Sotheby’s in London, but financial uncertainty after last week’s “Brexit” vote may have affected bidding interest.
lead_paragraph: A 1,109-carat uncut diamond offered in an unusual public auction is still waiting for a buyer.

headline: Newly Released Books Include ‘Chronicle of a Last Summer’
abstract: Novels from Cathleen Schine, Daniel Saldaña París and a new edition of a Jane Gardam work are also available.
lead_paragraph: By Cathleen Schine

headline: Norwegian Court Approves Extradition of Mullah Krekar, a Terror Suspect
abstract: The mullah, an Iraqi formally known as Najmuddin Faraj Ahmad, faces charges in Italy. He has been accused of leading a militant group.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — A Norwegian court on Wednesday cleared the way for the extradition of an Iraqi Kurdish imam to Italy to face terrorism-related charges.

headline: Basquiat Portrait Sells for $6.8 Million in London
abstract: The bidding at Christie’s postwar-art auction pointed to some market resilience, even though the sale’s top lot was abruptly withdrawn.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Be brave,” Jussi Pylkkanen, Christie’s global president, urged the crowd at Wednesday evening’s postwar and contemporary art sale as he began taking bids for one of two works by Jean-Michel Basquiat.

headline: F.D.A. Ruins Raw Cookie Dough for Everybody
abstract: Investigations traced the source of an E. coli outbreak to flour that was produced in November 2015 at the General Mills facility in Kansas City, Mo.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you’ve swiped a bite of raw cookie dough while preparing a batch to bake. Or perhaps you’ve let your children lick the batter from the cake bowl, or use homemade “play dough” to make crafts. But even if the dough is free of raw eggs, which you think might give you a pass, don’t eat it.

headline: Mining for Bitcoin in China
abstract: A handful of Chinese companies that own vast farms of computer servers dispersed around the country have majority control of the Bitcoin network.
lead_paragraph: A handful of Chinese companies that own vast farms of computer servers dispersed around the country have majority control of the Bitcoin network.

headline: How China Took Center Stage in Bitcoin’s Civil War
abstract: Through vast server farms and canny investments, Chinese companies have effectively centralized control over a currency designed to be borderless.
lead_paragraph: A delegation of American executives flew to Beijing in April for a secret meeting just blocks from Tiananmen Square. They had come to court the new kingmakers in one of the strangest experiments in money the world has seen: the virtual currency known as Bitcoin.

headline: Third-Party Keyboards Give Mobile Users More Options
abstract: Besides offering autocorrection and anticipating a user’s next words, keyboard apps provide search features and can customize the keys’ layout.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE the iPhone arrived in 2007, no one really thought typing on touch-screen keyboards was a good idea. Since then we have become expert at tapping on the glass of our phones and tablets.

headline: Bank Report Card: Part Two
abstract: The one American-based bank that did not pass unconditionally was Morgan Stanley. The Fed also gave failing grades to the American subsidiaries of Deutsche Bank and Santander.
lead_paragraph: The one American-based bank that did not pass unconditionally was Morgan Stanley. The Fed also gave failing grades to the American subsidiaries of Deutsche Bank and Santander.

headline: Review: A Sophisticated Journey Continues
abstract: The choreographer Ronald K. Brown and his dance company, Evidence, convey a sense of passage at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: The power of Ronald K. Brown’s choreography lies in its myriad layers. There are the undulating bodies that form strong diagonal lines, which suddenly dissipate as dancers drift across the stage like mist. There is his agile use of stillness that subtly brushes the surface of raw emotions. And there is the undeniable way his propulsive movement crosses beyond the stage. Yes, this is the rare choreographer who makes you want to get up and dance.

headline: ‘Brexit’ May Lead to Diminished British Voice on Hong Kong
abstract: A shrunken economy and political isolation, possible outcomes if Britain withdraws from the E.U., could weaken London’s influence on Hong Kong affairs.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — “The trouble with committing political suicide is that you live to regret it,” Christopher F. Patten, the last British colonial governor of Hong Kong, wrote about Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, attributing the aphorism to Winston Churchill.

headline: Toward a More Perfect Lincoln Center Union
abstract: Lincoln Center Festival. Mostly Mozart. Midsummer Night Swing. Lincoln Center Out of Doors. One critic argues that less could be more.
lead_paragraph: The way Lincoln Center organizes its summer offerings makes little sense. The world’s largest performing-arts complex currently fields no fewer than four festivals and series that run in great overlapping waves from the end of June until the end of August. Consumers might rightly feel they’re drowning amid these choices. Even critics paid to know the ins and outs of all the presentations find themselves confused at what belongs in what container — and how, exactly, audiences are served by the clutter of brands.

headline: Wyoming Schools Look for a Middle Way for Transgender Students
abstract: The district in Laramie, Wyo., won’t adopt a new policy but will address students by the names they prefer and help them find a bathroom or locker room that fits.
lead_paragraph: LARAMIE, Wyo. — When the debate over allowing transgender students to use the bathrooms of their choice rolled into town like a high-plains thunderstorm, Laramie’s school board took its own multiple-choice test.

headline: Film Academy Broadens Voting Pool After Oscars Criticism
keywords: ['Minorities', 'Women and Girls', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Movies', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES']
abstract: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences more than doubled the number of invitations to make good on a promise to increase female and minority membership.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences invited many more minorities and women to join on Wednesday as the first major step in reshaping its membership after the #OscarsSoWhite controversy this year.

headline: Nearly All U.S. Banks Pass Fed’s Stress Test
abstract: Only Morgan Stanley did not pass unconditionally, and the American subsidiaries of Deutsche Bank and Santander failed outright.
lead_paragraph: All but one of the nation’s largest banks earned an unconditional passing grade from federal regulators on their annual stress tests, which measure their preparedness to weather a financial crisis.

headline: If These Dresses Could Talk
abstract: Imaginary conversations with designers from Dior to Poiret make for ideal couture reading.
lead_paragraph: The force that gives one couture house, or one fashion designer, the power to shape the tastes of women has always verged on the magical — sometimes literally.

headline: Ten Famous People on What to Read This Summer
abstract: Just in time for the Fourth of July, T revisits highlights of its recurring booklist column.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. Every Friday for the last year, we’ve run one of those lists on TMagazine.com. So many books have been recommended — by everyone from James Franco to Alice Waters — that it might feel like you need a lifetime (and then another one) to read them all. So, in honor of the July 4th weekend, we’re giving you that time to catch up — or at least pick a good book to bring along to the beach. Here, excerpts from 10 of the individuals who have recommended titles over the last several months. Click the link beneath each name to read their whole list. Enjoy!

headline: Jerome Fisher, a Founder of Nine West, Dies at 85
abstract: Mr. Fisher and Vince Camuto produced fashionable shoes at reasonable prices.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Fisher, who helped found Nine West, a women’s shoe company that imitated designer styles at affordable prices, and turned it into an industry juggernaut, died on June 23 in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 85.

headline: Google Capital Ventures Into Public Companies With Care.com
abstract: The Alphabet investment unit has invested $46.35 million in Care.com, a publicly traded company that helps connect families and caregivers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In its three years of existence, Google Capital has been known for its investments in privately held start-ups like SurveyMonkey and Credit Karma.

headline: Review: In ‘Marcella,’ Is That Blood? A Tire Iron? Sorry, I Blacked Out.
abstract: Anna Friel plays a police officer who is pretty much a violent basket case in this British drama. But somebody has to be the hero.
lead_paragraph: Television is full of cops who bend the rules, and of cops whose personal demons both hinder and help their work. But you’ve never seen a cop who’s quite as big a mess as Marcella Backland, the heroine — by default — of the British series “Marcella,” which makes its American debut on Netflix on Friday.

headline: Simon Ramo Dies at 103; Helped Develop ICBMs in the Cold War
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Cold War Era', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: Dr. Ramo advised presidents on science and technology, and was a postwar force in the aerospace and electronics industries.
lead_paragraph: Simon Ramo, an engineer and entrepreneur who helped develop the rocket technology that changed the nature of the Cold War’s nuclear face-off and powered the first Americans into space, died on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 103.

headline: In Blink-182’s ‘California,’ a Melancholy Nostalgia
abstract: The band’s seventh album, and its first since 2011, has several songs about regret and exhaustion, yet the sound projects juvenile joy.
lead_paragraph: California is Blink-182’s home state and also its state of mind. For more than two decades, this band has made gleaming, sugary pop-punk about life without complications or consequences that could only truly grow in sunshine. That it has named its new album — its seventh, and first since 2011 — “California” feels like the sort of summation statement a band makes as it’s nearing its conclusion: here we were born, here we raged, here we will rage until the sun is no more.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Gay an Lesbian Couples Reflect on Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The Supreme Court legalized same-sex marriage a year ago. We asked couples who married after the ruling to tell us how it has been going.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court legalized same-sex marriage a year ago. We asked couples who married after the ruling to tell us how it has been going.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Actors With Disabilities Are Ready, Willing and Able to Take More Roles
abstract: For performers with disabilities, theater casting has taken steps forward. But frustrating challenges remain.
lead_paragraph: “Have you ever been hit?” a man named John asks his caregiver in “Cost of Living,” a new play by Martyna Majok. “That’s what it’s like,” he continues. “Like people hitting me from beneath my skin.”

headline: Kenyan Filed a Complaint Against the Police, Then He and His Lawyer Disappeared
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Missing Persons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: After leaving court and climbing into a taxi last week, the pair and their driver vanished, alarming Kenya’s human rights community and roping in Western embassies.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The day started like any other for Willie Kimani, a Nairobi lawyer. He put on his gray trousers, jungle-green jacket and black shoes. He said goodbye to his wife and two young sons. And he walked out the door.

headline: Kim Jong-un Takes an Additional Title in North Korea
abstract: In a bid to solidify his one-man rule, Kim Jong-un gained yet another leadership role — chairman of a new agency created by North Korea’s parliament.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, put himself in charge of a new governing agency created during a meeting of his country’s rubber-stamp parliament, the Supreme People’s Assembly, on Wednesday.

headline: Glasslands Owners Reseeding the Club’s Ethos
abstract: Even before the 2014 closing of the influential Williamsburg nightclub, its owners were planning a new Brooklyn performance space, Elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: When Glasslands Gallery, the influential independent club on the Williamsburg waterfront in Brooklyn, closed at the end of 2014, its owners had already been thinking about what was next.

headline: How to Protect Your Skin Against Air Pollution
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Air Pollution', 'Skin', 'ANTIOXIDANTS', 'Sunscreen', 'Ozone', 'Ultraviolet Light', 'Vitamins', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Here, doctors outline a savvy defense against environmental attacks.
lead_paragraph: Environmental attack. Free radical assault. Noxious gas: From some dire beauty headlines of late, you’d think the very air was contriving, if not to kill us, then to make us look older.

headline: Miss Teen USA Pageant Dumps the Swimsuit
keywords: ['Bathing Suits and Swimwear', 'Beauty Contests', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The teenage contest is switching to athletic wear, but there are no such plans for the Miss Universe Organization’s competitions for women.
lead_paragraph: Miss Teen USA is getting rid of swimsuits and swapping bikinis for athletic wear starting with the next pageant, on July 30.

headline: Ronald Perelman Donates $75 Million for Arts Complex at World Trade Center Site
abstract: The long-stalled performing arts center, which will sit on an emotionally resonant and highly visited spot in the city, will be named for Mr. Perelman.
lead_paragraph: Less than a year since he stepped down as the chairman of Carnegie Hall after clashing with its staff, Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire businessman, announced Wednesday that he was donating $75 million to revive plans to build a performing arts center at the World Trade Center site.

headline: What to Expect at Couture: 5 Brands New to the Schedule
abstract: A rundown of the upcoming crop of guest designers, from Iris Van Herpen to Vetements.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, the haute couture shows start in Paris — and a handful of new names will be welcomed to the fold. The members of Paris’s Chambre Syndicale de la Haute Couture have picked five guest designers to join the calendar for the season and stage shows. (Also of note: Giles Deacon, who set aside his ready-to-wear line for fall 2016, will be holding a series of presentations.) Here’s a rundown of the upcoming crop of participants at couture, which runs July 3 to 7.

headline: Don’t Get on the Wrong Side of This New Tarantula
abstract: Kankuamo marquezi, a newly discovered member of the tarantula family, uses bristles on its rear end to attack foes.
lead_paragraph: Tarantulas know how to fight. Many of these arachnids defend themselves by launching javelin-like hairs from their abdomens at potential attackers. But a newly discovered member of this family prefers to settle its confrontations up close.

headline: Mining Companies Buy Political Influence in Australia, Report Says
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Campaign Finance', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Conflicts of Interest']
abstract: A report cited six instances where political donations were made and companies received favorable legislation for mining projects.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Political donations by mining companies preceded legislative approval for several Australian mining operations, including plans to develop the country’s biggest coal mine, according to a report by an independent Australian policy institute released on Thursday.

headline: Bill Cunningham, Tributes Now and to Come
abstract: He loved a parade, and now the parade comes to him.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the southwest corner of 57th Street and Fifth Avenue was Bill Cunningham’s main perch.

headline: Donald Trump Assails U.S. Chamber of Commerce Over Trade
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']
abstract: A day after saying he would rip up all trade accords, Mr. Trump accused the Chamber of being “totally controlled by the special interest groups.”
lead_paragraph: BANGOR, Me. — Pressing his staunch opposition to trade deals, Donald J. Trump escalated his attacks on the U.S. Chamber of Commerce on Wednesday, saying it was “totally controlled by the special interest groups.”

headline: Homepolish: Hire Interior Design Help by the Hour
abstract: Homepolish is a custom design service started by Noa Santos, who wanted to make interior design expertise more available and cost-effective.
lead_paragraph: Name Noa Santos

headline: What Comes After the Istanbul Airport Attack?
abstract: Turkey can’t solve its terrorism problem until the country heals itself.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — ON Tuesday night, just as millions of Muslims here were breaking their Ramadan fasts, three terrorists attacked the city’s busy airport. They fired randomly at passengers with automatic weapons before blowing themselves up. They killed 41 innocent people, most of them Muslims, supposedly in the name of Islam.

headline: 2 Groups Call to Oust Saudis from U.N. Human Rights Council
abstract: But the suspension of any country from an elected body of the United Nations is extraordinary, and it would be all the more so for a country with powerful friends like the United States.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Saudi Arabia should be ousted from the United Nations Human Rights Council for its unlawful killings of civilians in Yemen, Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International said jointly on Wednesday, an unusual demand meant to draw attention to one of the world’s most powerful countries, embroiled in one of the world’s most brutal wars.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News from around the country.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Kansas, Georgia and Alabama will have to prove they are citizens when registering to vote for federal elections using a national form, a judge ruled Wednesday. Judge Richard Leon of Federal District Court sided against voting rights groups that sued a federal elections official who changed the proof-of-citizenship requirements on the federal registration form at the request of the three states and without public notice. Residents of other states need only to swear that they are citizens. The judge refused to issue a temporary injunction sought by voting rights advocates to overturn the move by Brian Newby, executive director of the United States Election Assistance Commission, until the case can be decided at trial. The groups said Mr. Newby’s February action contradicts the commission’s mission to provide an easy form to encourage voter registration. They argue the proof-of-citizenship requirements hurt their ability to conduct registration drives and deprive eligible voters of the right to vote. (AP)

headline: Extradition of ‘El Chapo’ to U.S. Is Halted in Mexico
keywords: ['Extradition', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Lawyers for the drug kingpin, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, who is also notorious for multiple escapes from jail, have filed several appeals.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Judges here have temporarily halted the extradition of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug kingpin known as El Chapo, pending the outcome of appeals filed this week by Mr. Guzmán’s lawyers.

headline: Violinist’s Attempted Murder Charge Is Dropped
abstract: Stefan Arzberger, a violinist with the Leipzig String Quartet in Germany, had been accused of trying to strangle a fellow guest in a Manhattan hotel last year.
lead_paragraph: The most serious charges against the violinist Stefan Arzberger, who had been accused of trying to strangle a fellow guest in a Midtown hotel, were dismissed Wednesday in New York State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

headline: Behind the Cruel Attack on Turkey
abstract: For too long, the government in Ankara underestimated the threat from the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: The world is once again stunned and grieving over a brutal terrorist attack. This time it was in Turkey, where three suicide bombers killed at least 41 people and wounded more than 200 others at the international airport in Istanbul. The timing on Tuesday was especially cruel for a Muslim majority country, coming during the 10 holiest days of the holy month of Ramadan.

headline: Red, White and New: Get Your Shop On for the Fourth of July
abstract: #FendiRoadTrip arrives in Montauk, Ralph Lauren opens a fragrance salon, the Met Store has an accessory sale, and more.
lead_paragraph: Headed out east for the long weekend? Fendi is kicking off #FendiRoadTrip, a traveling retail concept in which a customized Apé — a version of the distinctive three-wheeled Italian truck created in the late 1940s — loaded with accessories like Dotcom bags ($2,400) and ABC fur charms ($600) will roll into the Surf Lodge on Thursday through Monday as its first stop on a tour of the United States and Canada. At 183 Edgemere Street, Montauk.

headline: The E.U. Is Democratic. It Just Doesn’t Feel That Way.
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Elections']
abstract: The bloc was designed to rise above and defuse nationalist politics. That is why, for many Europeans, it does not feel like a functioning democracy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Does the European Union have a democracy deficit?

headline: Conservative to Fund Republicans Who Back Climate Change Action
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Global Warming', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The spending comes as Republican leaders have questioned or denied the established science of human-caused climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A self-described conservative North Carolina businessman has promised to spend at least $5 million through his political action committee to back five Republican congressional candidates who have supported taking action to curb climate change.

headline: Dramatic Comeback Gives Yankees a Glimmer of Hope
abstract: The perennial contenders are trying to figure out their status before the trading deadline.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees find themselves at a precarious moment, facing a crossroads just up ahead. With a short winning streak — just a tick above mediocre — they could feel like contenders. With a long patch of losing, they could be forced to confront a harsh new reality.

headline: Bernie Sanders Returns to the Capitol, His Campaign in Tow
abstract: Sounding campaign themes and exploring the reaches of his newfound clout, the senator looked to turn an apparent defeat in the primaries into success in Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The lusty applause that greeted his return to the Capitol is behind him now, as are the pecks on the cheek he received as he sat at his desk on the Senate floor, looking vaguely glum, receiving good wishes like a warrior returned to civilization, injured but intact.

headline: Brooklyn School’s Supporters Say the City Bet Against Its Progress
abstract: Despite improvements, a struggling middle school will lose classrooms to a charter as part of a plan drawn up by the city’s Education Department.
lead_paragraph: When the New York City Education Department put a new Success Academy charter school in a building housing a troubled Brooklyn middle school in 2012, many believed the middle school was on its way to closing.

headline: Turkey, a Conduit for Fighters Joining ISIS, Begins to Feel Its Wrath
abstract: For years, Turkey served as a rear base, transit hub and shopping bazaar for the Islamic State, but now, officials say Tuesday’s attack bore ISIS hallmarks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When the bodies of Islamic State fighters are recovered on the Syrian battlefield, the passports found on them have often been stamped in Turkey, which thousands of recruits pass through on their way to join the terror group.

headline: Huma Abedin Says Clinton’s Email Server Caused Frustration
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Freedom of Information Act', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The aide to Hillary Clinton said her boss only wanted to protect her personal information and never intended to sidestep federal record-keeping laws.
lead_paragraph: Huma Abedin, Hillary Clinton’s longtime aide and confidante, acknowledged that Mrs. Clinton’s use of a private email server while secretary of state created frustration at times because of computer glitches but said she did not raise concerns about the unusual arrangement, according to a transcript of a deposition made public on Wednesday.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Raises $1.4 Billion With Two Funds
abstract: The venture capital firm joins a list of peers that have recently raised more than a billion dollars, despite talk of a Silicon Valley lull.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With more start-ups and venture firms working harder to raise capital, there has been talk of a Silicon Valley slowdown. But investors in several venture funds are bucking that notion.

headline: Father Killed in Turkey Attacks Was Trying to Save Son From ISIS
abstract: His son had called a month after reaching the Islamic State in Syria, asking for help and to return home.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Fathi Bayoudh was a respected officer and doctor in the Tunisian military, but on Tuesday night at Istanbul’s main airport he was a father worried about his wayward son.

headline: Operative Tied to Cuomo Is Accused of Bribing Judge to Get Favorable Rulings
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Supreme Courts (State)']
abstract: John A. Michalek of State Supreme Court in Buffalo pleaded guilty in the scheme, detailed in a criminal complaint. G. Steven Pigeon is expected to be charged.
lead_paragraph: A political operative with ties to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is expected to be charged on Thursday in connection with a bribery scheme that involved a State Supreme Court justice in Buffalo, who has already pleaded guilty in the case.

headline: House Democrats Try to Sustain Push for Gun Control
abstract: Democratic lawmakers hosted 40 events across the country, trying to maintain the momentum created by their 25-hour sit-in.
lead_paragraph: FARMINGTON, Conn. — As a pastor, Sam Saylor knows how draining the fight against gun violence can be. For years he attended vigils and comforted families until he could not take it anymore; he could not find the words for the grieving parents.

headline: The Battle for Surt
abstract: Led by militias from nearby Misurata, the attack force has corralled Islamic State fighters into the city center, where they are being pummeled with bombs and gunfire.
lead_paragraph: Led by militias from nearby Misurata, the attack force has corralled Islamic State fighters into the city center, where they are being pummeled with bombs and gunfire.

headline: A Slow, Steady Siege on an ISIS Stronghold in Libya
abstract: With a willing commander, a Times correspondent and photographer set off down a highway strewn with the charred remains of vehicles destroyed in suicide bombings.
lead_paragraph: SURT, Libya — Perched on a doorstep, the teenage Juma brothers whiled away the afternoon with a lazy game of checkers, pushing pebbles around a board chalked in the dust, seemingly oblivious to the crackle of gunfire and boom of artillery a few miles away.

headline: After Congressional Primary, Harlem’s Reign as a Power Base May Be Over
abstract: Upper Manhattan’s congressional seat has long been identified with Harlem and black political power. That has changed with the apparent victory of Adriano D. Espaillat in the Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: As Washington Heights rejoiced on Wednesday over the apparent victory of Adriano D. Espaillat in the Democratic primary to choose a successor to Representative Charles B. Rangel, the scene and tone could not have been more different a few dozen blocks to the south.

headline: Frank Whipple, Whose Nun Paintings Drew Hollywood Fans, Dies at 93
abstract: Over more than half a century, he turned out thousands of whimsical nun paintings. His celebrity patrons included Frank Sinatra, Cary Grant and John Wayne.
lead_paragraph: Frank Whipple, whose whimsical paintings of nuns wearing the winglike headdresses of the Daughters of Charity found favor with a host of Hollywood celebrities, died on June 8 in Los Angeles. He was 93.

headline: Refill to Capacity
abstract: Jonathan Kaye makes half a debut.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Facebook Live Group Solve Alert! Want to join me and hopefully the entire internet in a group crossword solve? Without a net nor with any regard for my personal safety, I will be solving the crossword LIVE on The New York Times’s Facebook page at lunchtime (noonish, Eastern Time) on Thursday. There’s power in numbers, so bring the puzzle and your favorite writing implement, and let’s conquer this thing together!

headline: Mining for Bitcoin in China
abstract: A handful of Chinese companies that own vast farms of computer servers dispersed around the country have majority control of the Bitcoin network.
lead_paragraph: A handful of Chinese companies that own vast farms of computer servers dispersed around the country have majority control of the Bitcoin network.

headline: Knicks Look to Young Blood and Free Agency to Patch Porous Roster
abstract: The Knicks are set for a summer of change, with just five players under contract for next season and an expected $30 million to spend under the salary cap.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN, Fla. — Jeff Hornacek, the new Knicks coach, delivered some truth Wednesday afternoon after his team’s first summer league practice.

headline: Pool Rules: No Running, No Eating and, Three Times a Week, No Men
abstract: Two New York agencies are trying to resolve a complaint that says female-only hours catering to Hasidic women in Brooklyn violate a city law.
lead_paragraph: Under slate-colored light slanting from the skylights, the women entered the city pool on Wednesday morning, its oxidized copper ceiling lending a mint-green cast to the water’s surface. Their swimming outfits would have been considered prudish even by the standards of 1922, when the pool was built. They swam in dresses, some with long sleeves. One paddled in thick black tights. Inside the locker room, wigs sat upside down on window ledges and benches while their owners swam with heads under ruffled swimming caps or knotted silk scarves.

headline: Lionsgate Is Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Starz
abstract: If an agreement is reached, it would be the end of a long road for Starz, which has been the subject of merger speculation for three years.
lead_paragraph: Lionsgate is near a deal to buy Starz, uniting the film studio behind “The Hunger Games” with the premium cable home of the “Outlander” television series, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Missy Franklin Breaks Through in Trials and Earns a Return to Olympics
abstract: After earlier frustrations in the Olympic trials, the defending gold medalist finished second in the final of 200-meter freestyle, earning individual and relay berths in Rio de Janeiro.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — In the first three races of her third Olympic trials — two heats of the 100-meter backstroke and the 200-meter freestyle preliminaries — Missy Franklin swam scared. She put together a more composed race in the semifinals of the 200, and then a day later, in Wednesday’s final, Franklin broke free of the chains of anxiety that had constrained her.

headline: Once at Michael Phelps’s Feet, and Still Chasing Them
abstract: Phelps, who inspired a generation to swim, qualified for his fifth Olympic team by winning the 200-meter butterfly at the United States trials.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — The United States Olympic swimming trials are the spectacle that Michael Phelps built. If he had not strapped the sport to his broad back and climbed to the Olympic summit six times in Athens in 2004 and eight times in eight nights in Beijing in 2008, there would be no pre-finals light show at CenturyLink Center, no ticket scalpers. The crowds would be far smaller than 14,000, and fewer athletes would be extending their careers past college with the help of corporate endorsements.

headline: Tekserve, Precursor to the Apple Store, to Close After 29 Years
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: The eclectic store on West 23rd Street in Manhattan sold and serviced Apple computers in an era when help wasn’t a Google search away.
lead_paragraph: It was the Apple Store in New York City before there was such a thing as an Apple Store.

headline: Three Men Charged in Killing of Cuomo Administration Lawyer
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Gangs', 'West Indian-American Day', 'Parades']
abstract: Three defendants were indicted in the killing of Carey Gabay at a pre-dawn celebration preceding the annual West Indian American Day Parade.
lead_paragraph: In the early morning hours of Labor Day last year, a group of gunmen from the 8-Trey street gang made their way through a crowd of revelers gathered near a Brooklyn public housing project to celebrate J’ouvert, a pre-dawn party that precedes the annual West Indian American Day Parade. The housing project was “enemy territory,” the authorities said, the stronghold of a rival gang, the Folk Nation.

headline: 4 Blockbuster Supreme Court Decisions, 12 Pre-Written Stories Waiting in the Wings
abstract: Our Scotus correspondent anticipated every possible outcome.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this article, Adam Liptak, The Times’s Supreme Court correspondent, describes taking preparation to an extreme.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Counsel to Leave Next Month to Lead Police Review Board
abstract: Maya Wiley, chief legal adviser to Mayor Bill de Blasio, will resign to become chairwoman of New York City’s independent oversight agency for the Police Department.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s counsel and chief legal adviser, Maya Wiley, is resigning next month from her City Hall position to become the chairwoman of the Civilian Complaint Review Board, New York City’s independent oversight agency for the Police Department.

headline: Yankees End Losing Skid With Three Swings in the 9th
abstract: The Yankees’ overcame a 7-2 deficit as Didi Gregorius capped off a ninth-inning rally with a two-run homer to beat the Rangers and end a three-game losing streak.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees were three outs from hitting the nadir of their season, about to fall 10 games behind the Baltimore Orioles for first place in the American League East.

headline: Nationals’ Max Scherzer Again Baffles Mets, Completing a Sweep
abstract: The Mets did not score until the ninth, when a two-run homer by James Loney off Washington reliever Shawn Kelley snapped a streak of 23 scoreless innings.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Stellar pitching kept the Mets afloat in the first half of last season despite their offensive woes. But they cannot produce an encore of their pennant-winning season if their lineup keeps floundering while their pitching is nicked, bruised and stretched thin.

headline: Reflecting on a Suspension, Tennis Player Resolves to Move On
abstract: Kateryna Kozlova of Ukraine, who tested positive for a banned substance last year, was found not to be at fault and returned to Wimbledon this year after a six-month ban.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Kateryna Kozlova of Ukraine played her first-round Wimbledon match on a rainy Wednesday under the Centre Court roof, but no longer under a cloud of suspicion.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, June 30, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Here we are, fighting the West’s war against terrorism. But although the West promises help, it never comes.”

headline: Corrections: June 30, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, June 30, 2016.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: BroadwayHD live streams “She Loves Me.” And Jennifer Saunders and Joanna Lumley talk “Ab Fab.”
lead_paragraph: “Eye in the Sky” features a riveting final screen performance from Alan Rickman, as a military officer pondering a drone strike. BroadwayHD live streams “She Loves Me” from the Roundabout Theater Company. And Jennifer Saunders and Joanna Lumley talk “Ab Fab” on “The Graham Norton Show.”

headline: Beijing Rejects South China Sea Case Ahead of July 12 Ruling
abstract: The case centers on an argument by the Philippines that China’s claims over much of the sea are illegal under a United Nations convention.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague said on Wednesday that it would announce its rulings in a contentious case between China and the Philippines over the South China Sea on July 12.

headline: Sports Investor Buying Specialist in Broadcasts
abstract: George Pyne’s Bruin Sports Capital is acquiring deltatre, which helps broadcast soccer and other sporting events.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Over much of his career, George Pyne has worked at the intersection of sports and media, helping turn Nascar into a multimedia giant and leading the talent and management agency IMG.

headline: Congress’s Failure to Fund Zika Response
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Law and Legislation', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Funding for an adequate response to the virus is being held hostage by a debate over Planned Parenthood.
lead_paragraph: In late February, the White House asked Congress for $1.9 billion in emergency money to stem the spread of the mosquito-borne Zika virus, which at the time had been tentatively linked to birth defects in South America. Since then, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has concluded that the virus does cause birth defects, including microcephaly. More than 2,600 people in American states and territories have been diagnosed with Zika. As of June 16, federal health officials were tracking 481 cases of pregnant women who appeared to be infected.

headline: The State of Race in America
abstract: What is worrisome in a new report is how far apart whites and blacks are in their optimism about relations improving.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the Pew Research Center released a fascinating and expansive report on the state of race relations in America. It serves as a stark reminder that although events like this insane and historic presidential election, continuing terrorist attacks and global shocks like Brexit overtake news cycles, the issue of racial inequality is just as urgent as ever.

headline: Hope Takes a Beating in France, Too
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Editorials', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: The vote in Britain to leave the European Union is bad news for the French, who face economic strains and terrorist threats that feed their own nationalist movement.
lead_paragraph: PANTIN, France — My French husband doesn’t think Britain’s vote to leave the European Union is such a bad thing. “Good!” he replied when I told him what to me was terrible news. “They never really wanted to be European,” he complained. “Let them go.”

headline: Patriotic Presidential Quiz
abstract: If you’re still following the race, here’s a reward for your dedication.
lead_paragraph: If you’re still following the race, here’s a reward for your dedication.

headline: How Not to Deal With Climate Change
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Natural Gas', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The closing of the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant in California will hurt the environment, not help it.
lead_paragraph: Berkeley, Calif. — CALIFORNIA has a reputation as a leader in battling climate change, and so when Pacific Gas & Electric and environmental groups announced a plan last week to close the state’s last nuclear plant, Diablo Canyon, and replace much of the electricity it generates with power from renewable resources, the deal was widely applauded.

headline: The Changing Face of Urban Power
abstract: Demographic shifts in the nation’s capital show us how the Democratic and Republican coalitions are taking shape.
lead_paragraph: Black political power is declining in cities across the country, including Oakland, St. Louis, Cleveland and Atlanta — even as African-Americans are gaining majority status in an increasing number of suburbs.

headline: The Trickle-Down Myth Meets the Reality of School Aid
abstract: Gov. Sam Brownback and the Republican-controlled Legislature have reluctantly agreed to greater fairness between rich and poor in Kansas’s school-aid subsidies.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Sam Brownback and the Republican-controlled Legislature have reluctantly agreed to demands for greater fairness between rich and poor in Kansas’s school-aid subsidies. With a bill that takes effect Friday, they yielded to a state court mandate to either treat poor districts more equitably or see the public school system shut down on July 1.

headline: PG-13 Blockbusters and the Sugarcoating of Violence
abstract: Is it dangerous to depict violence without its gory consequences?

headline: Surrounded by Industry, a Historic Community Fights for Its Future
abstract: The residents of Marktown, a historic district ringed by industrial behemoths in East Chicago, Ind., are trying to stay put, relying on each other in the face of change.

headline: In China, Cheese Is Strange, but Pizza Is Hot
abstract: Dairy is not part of the mainstream Chinese diet, but one cheese seller’s prospects may improve as fast food, especially pizza, catches on.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China may be the hardest place in the world to sell cheese, but Liu Yang has been trying anyway — and Western fast food may be his salvation.

headline: Surrounded by Industry, a Historic Community Fights for Its Future
abstract: The residents of Marktown, a historic district ringed by industrial behemoths in East Chicago, Ind., are trying to stay put, relying on each other in the face of change.
lead_paragraph: The houses of Marktown were not exactly what Alyssa Schukar expected to find when she moved to Chicago and started looking for a community project. In an industrial corner of East Chicago, Ind., she came across a tiny, nearly century-old community of narrow streets with gable-roofed homes whose windows faced gardens.

headline: The Upper West Side Wins
abstract: Joan and Robert Khoury had lived in New York before, and knew what they did and did not want.
lead_paragraph: In their almost 30 years of marriage, Joan and Robert Khoury have moved a fair amount, sometimes for her career and sometimes for his.

headline: Would You Slather on Sunscreen if New York City Gave It Away?
abstract: A proposal by the city’s comptroller modeled on programs in Boston and Miami Beach would bring sunscreen dispensers to the city’s parks, pools and beaches in an effort to combat skin cancer.
lead_paragraph: Levi Goldhirsch, who was celebrating his 21st birthday in Coney Island on Wednesday, learned the hard way what happens to summertime beachgoers with no sunscreen on.

headline: Donald Trump Has Long Benefited From Trade Practices He Now Scorns
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Foreign Workers', 'Outsourcing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: As a businessman, Mr. Trump has relied on the type of cheap foreign labor that he vows to clamp down on if elected president.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump vowed on Tuesday that as president, he would put an end to policies that send American jobs overseas, threatening to impose tariffs on Chinese imports and promising to punish companies that relocate their manufacturing to countries with cheaper labor.

headline: The Trio to Rio
abstract: The marathon-running Luik sisters of Estonia are believed to be the first triplets to have qualified for an Olympics.
lead_paragraph: TARTU, Estonia — As Lea Luik waited in a Soviet-era taxi, her husband, Henno, carried their newborns from the nursery. One, then two, then three.

headline: Refugees Encounter a Foreign Word: Welcome
abstract: How Canadian hockey moms, poker buddies and neighbors are adopting Syrians, a family at a time.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — One frigid day in February, Kerry McLorg drove to an airport hotel here to pick up a family of Syrian refugees. She was cautious by nature, with a job poring over insurance data, but she had never even spoken to the people who were about to move into her basement.

headline: Palestinian, 19, Stabs 13-Year-Old to Death in West Bank Settlement
abstract: The attack in the Kiryat Arba settlement was the latest in a series that began eight months ago; the assailant was shot and killed.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian teenager scrambled over a fence surrounding a Jewish settlement in the West Bank, ran into a house and stabbed an Israeli-American girl to death as she slept in her bed on Thursday morning.

headline: French Feminist Pulp That Spares No Pain
abstract: Virginie Despentes’s feminist pulp, gory and marked by sexual violence, looks to the lives of women unwilling to make nice or play along.
lead_paragraph: “I am writing as an ugly one for the ugly ones.” So begins “King Kong Theory,” the French writer and filmmaker ­Virginie Despentes’s agreeably dyspeptic feminist manifesto published in France in 2006 and America four years later, in a translation by Stéphanie Benson. Despentes offers the book as a love letter to her kin: the “too fat,” “too hairy,” “too masculine,” “women who don’t turn men on.” This is no ploy for pity, mind you. “I would never swap ­places,” she declares. “Being Virginie Despentes is a more interesting business than anything else going on out there.”

headline: Ian Frazier Is a Master of the Essay. Here Are Some of His Best.
abstract: Frazier approaches the world with curiosity and enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: HOGS WILDSelected Reporting PiecesBy Ian Frazier375 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $26.

headline: Philippines’ New President, Rodrigo Duterte, Vows Tough Stance on Crime
abstract: He said in his inaugural speech that the harm of corruption and drugs justified his approach, and he dismissed concerns that such a campaign would abuse the rule of law.
lead_paragraph: Rodrigo Duterte was sworn in on Thursday as president of the Philippines, promising to carry out an uncompromising crackdown on crime across the country.

headline: Boris Johnson Won’t Seek to Lead Britain, but Michael Gove Will
abstract: Mr. Johnson’s decision not to seek leadership of the Conservative Party came after Mr. Gove, a onetime ally, entered the contest.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a day of intrigue and betrayal, predictions about the next prime minister of Britain were overturned on Thursday as the presumed favorite, Boris Johnson, said he would not run after his ally in the Brexit campaign, Michael Gove, suddenly announced his candidacy.

headline: Phil-Am Kusina, a Ray of Philippine Sun on Staten Island
