lead_paragraph: It is 25 years and less than a half-block from Phil-Am Foods, the grocery where Manny Imperial started working at age 5, to Phil-Am Kusina, the restaurant he runs now.

headline: At the End of Life, What Would Doctors Do?
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: They don’t really die differently. But many speak of a deepening connection to the people who matter most.
lead_paragraph: Americans have long been chided as the only people on earth who believe death is optional. But the quip is losing its premise. A recent profusion of personal narratives, best-selling books and social entrepreneurs’ projects suggest that, as a culture, we are finally starting to come to terms with our mortality. Nationally, the Conversation Project is engaging people to discuss their wishes for end-of-life care. Death Cafes and Death Over Dinner events are popping up across the country, reflecting an appetite for exploring these matters. So too, the Dinner Party and the Kitchen Widow are using meals as a communal space to explore life after loss.

headline: Roadside Attack Near Somali Capital Leaves at Least 14 Dead
abstract: There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but officials in the town of Lafoole said they believed the assault was the work of Islamist Shabab militants.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — At least 14 people were killed on Thursday when the bus they were on was struck by a roadside bomb in a town near Mogadishu, the Somali capital, local officials said.

headline: Morning Agenda: Puerto Rico Relief Measure Clears Senate
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Law and Legislation', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Nearly All U.S. Banks Pass Fed Stress Test | Lionsgate Is Said to Be Near Deal to Buy Starz
lead_paragraph: PUERTO RICO RELIEF MEASURE CLEARS SENATE The Senate passed and sent to the White House a relief measure to help Puerto Rico surmount its fiscal crisis, just two days before the territory planned to default on a large debt payment, Jackie Calmes reports in The New York Times. President Obama will sign the measure, which his Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, negotiated and lobbied for.

headline: The ‘Intentional Summer’ Challenge: Play an Outdoor Game
abstract: If you remember late suburban nights playing flashlight tag or Ghost in the Graveyard under the streetlights, this one’s for you.
lead_paragraph: Don’t let summer slip away! Challenge No. 2: Play (and teach your kids) a classic outdoor game, like Capture the Flag.

headline: Summer Camp Under Siege
abstract: Children in Gaza have little enough to look forward to. Now their holiday fun is under threat.
lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Balloons emblazoned with an Olympic-style torch bobbed cheerfully in the sky above a swimming meet. For 12-year-old Adam Nairab and the other children on the beach, they provided inspiration. The balloons meant there was more to life than drones, explosions and the threat of sudden death.

headline: The 6.19.16 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: RE: NETFLIX

headline: Geoff Dyer: By the Book
abstract: The novelist, essayist, critic and author, most recently, of “White Sands” says reading William Finnegan’s “Barbarian Days” made him realize his whole life has been pretty much a waste. “I suspected this anyway.”
lead_paragraph: The novelist, essayist, critic and author, most recently, of “White Sands” says reading William Finnegan’s “Barbarian Days” made him realize his whole life has been pretty much a waste. “I suspected this anyway.”

headline: How to Swallow a Sword
abstract: Desensitize your gag reflex. Concentrate.
lead_paragraph: Tilt your head back, tucking in your chin until your mouth and esophagus align with your spine. “Get everything in a straight line,” says Dai Andrews, who travels the world as a sword-swallowing performer. Under the guidance of a mentor, begin with a blunt object. Many novices start with a metal clothes hanger bent straight. Learn to control your gag reflex by desensitizing it with regular practice and cultivating what Andrews calls “mind-body connection.” Practice tai chi, yoga, meditation, anything that trains you to see fear arising — or the need to retch — and serenely let those feelings pass. “If you have a sword inside you and you panic,” Andrews says, “you need to remain still.”

headline: Vito Acconci Invites You to Watch Him as He Watches Us
abstract: “Vito Acconci: Where We Are Now (Who Are We Anyway?), 1976,” at MoMA PS1, is made up of nearly 60 short pieces.
lead_paragraph: Vito Acconci, who bushwhacked the path to video art in New York in the 1960s and early 1970s, makes many of today’s young artists look tame. The nearly 60 short videos in “Vito Acconci: Where We Are Now (Who Are We Anyway?), 1976,” the excellent early-career survey at MoMA PS1, manage to be unnervingly funny, pathetically gross and politically razor-sharp. And even with a decades-old patina of age, they’re still too funky to fit into MoMA’s scrubbed white Manhattan premises.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Too Many Trips to Ohio With Your Baby
keywords: ['Comedy and Humor', 'Babies and Infants', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Do you want to raise some abomination who doesn’t know whether to say “soda” or “pop”?
lead_paragraph: Alex writes: My wife and I are from Ohio, and we moved to Belmont, Mass., six years ago. We have a 20-month-old daughter, and my wife feels our families are missing out, so she thinks we should visit Ohio once every couple of months. I argue that three times a year is plenty.

headline: How Polling Can Go Wrong
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Population', 'Census']
abstract: Pre-election polls show Democrats doing better among white voters than the exit polls do.
lead_paragraph: When people complain to me about a poll, it’s usually because they think the demographics are wrong. The pollsters polled too many white people, commenters might say, or too many old people. Or perhaps the sample of Hispanic voters doesn’t seem quite Democratic enough.

headline: Democratic Group Prepares Trove of Research to Unload on Donald Trump
abstract: The opposition research group American Bridge is maintaining an archive of digital video footage, with 6,500 clips of Mr. Trump speaking or being mentioned.
lead_paragraph: The opposition research group American Bridge made its mark in the 2012 election cycle with a video clip of a Missouri Senate candidate, Todd Akin, saying that “legitimate rape” rarely leads to pregnancy.

headline: Return of the Sun King
abstract: Reviving and updating Crab Louis, a perfect salad for a summer night.
lead_paragraph: “Taste in works of art,” writes the Duchess of Devonshire in my dog-eared copy of her 2011 collection, “All in One Basket” — where I’ve heavily marked her feelings about chickens, plastic packaging, guests’ stealing books, plumbing, the Turner prize and Elvis — “is notoriously susceptible to fashion.”

headline: Our Agreement
abstract: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.
lead_paragraph: Selected by Matthew Zapruder.

headline: Maxwell Is on His Own Timetable
abstract: Maxwell, gone for seven years, is returning to an almost unrecognizable musical landscape with his new album “BlackSUMMERS’night.”
lead_paragraph: The first time Maxwell disappeared, he was gone about eight years. After starting his career in the mid-90s with three platinum albums in a row, each delivered punctually, this soul and R&B singer all but vanished. He opted not to tour and didn’t release the expected follow-up to “Now,” from 2001. Instead, he faded into near anonymity.

headline: In the Russian Army, With Lust
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Sex', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Missing single life in Moscow to a perilous degree.
lead_paragraph: By the time I joined the Russian Army two years ago, I was much older than the average recruit. At 25, I had eluded obligatory military service for years. But being born into the family of a career officer and war correspondent, I had also continually endured a sense of guilt for failing to meet my duty in serving my motherland.

headline: The Secrets in Guatemala’s Bones
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Forensic Science', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: In the face of death threats, a forensic anthropologist has spent two decades exhuming the victims of a “dirty” civil war. Now his work might help bring justice for their murders.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in 1994, during his senior year in college, Fredy Peccerelli sat at an anthropology conference in Atlanta and stared at the man onstage. Peccerelli had seen the renowned bone detective Clyde Snow before, but only in a textbook. Snow, who was in his 60s, leaned forward at the lectern, speaking in his genial Texas drawl about blindfolded skulls and bodies dumped in clandestine graves. He wore his usual attire of an Irish tweed jacket, cowboy boots and a fedora.

headline: Review: In ‘The BFG,’ Walking Gently and Wearing Huge Shoes
abstract: In Steven Spielberg’s adaptation of a Roald Dahl story, restraint and Mark Rylance prevail in the face of digital wizardry and belabored wonderment.
lead_paragraph: “The BFG” — it stands for “big friendly giant” — is a small, friendly movie, an attempt to reconcile the scale and dazzle of modern filmmaking with the quiet, mischievous charm of Roald Dahl’s book. Directed by Steven Spielberg and written by his frequent collaborator Melissa Mathison (who died in November), it chronicles the relationship between the title character (Mark Rylance) and a young orphan named Sophie (Ruby Barnhill).

headline: Not Forgotten: Upton Sinclair, Whose Muckraking Changed the Meat Industry
abstract: Sinclair’s novel “The Jungle” spurred public outrage that led to legislation in 1906 aimed at regulating the food and drug industries.
lead_paragraph: Sinclair’s novel “The Jungle” spurred public outrage that led to legislation in 1906 aimed at regulating the food and drug industries.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Briefing: Boris Johnson Isn’t Running; Jeremy Corbyn Seeks Labour Revolution

headline: How Much Do We Love TV? Let Us Count the Ways
keywords: ['Television', 'Digital Video Recorders', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']

lead_paragraph: You still love television. You use your tablet more than ever. And now you are as likely to have paid services like Netflix or Amazon Prime as you are to have a DVR service.

headline: Meryl Streep, Diane Lane and Others on the Legacy of Elizabeth Swados

lead_paragraph: For Elizabeth Swados, being nominated for four Tony Awards in one year while still in her 20s — for “Runaways,” in 1978 — led to success in an unexpected direction. Or, rather, in several unexpected directions.

headline: Taliban Attack on Afghan Police Cadets Kills at Least 33
abstract: The double bombing on a police convoy was the second large-scale assault by the insurgents in Kabul in less than two weeks.

headline: In Syria, Starving Instead of Fasting
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Syrians have spent Ramadan under siege while the world does nothing.
lead_paragraph: Every Ramadan, Hussein’s grandmother cooks him fatayer, a savory pastry stuffed with cheese or meat and baked in an oven. This year, she replaced the filling with grass and cooked the dish on a fire of burning plastic. “I promise you, it tasted better than it sounds,” Hussein told me last week, just after he broke his fast.

headline: Beijing Police Officers Arrested in Environmentalist’s Death
abstract: An autopsy found that Lei Yang had died of suffocation after the police seized him, and two officers have been charged with “dereliction of duty.”

headline: Taiwan-Owned Steel Factory Caused Toxic Spill, Vietnam Says

headline: Chris Christie Becomes Powerful Figure in Donald Trump Campaign
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Despite taunts from both sides of the aisle, the governor has emerged as the candidate’s right-hand man — and as a potential running mate.
lead_paragraph: Defeated by Donald J. Trump in the 2016 primaries and derided by fellow Republicans for his subsequent embrace of Mr. Trump, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has quietly emerged as one of the most influential advisers to his party’s presumptive presidential nominee and one of the leading contenders to be his running mate.

headline: Naked Man in Times Square Taunts and Spits at Police, as Cameras Roll
abstract: The man stood atop the TKTS booth before falling to the street, but there was no immediate word on his condition.

headline: 1966: Soviets and French Seek Peace
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Soviets and French seek peace in July 1966.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Soviet Union and France declared their intention tonight [June 30] to try bringing security and lasting peace to Europe. The agreement came in a declaration ceremoniously signed by French President Charles de Gaulle and Soviet President Nikolai V. Podgorny in the great Kremlin Palace on the last night of the French leader’s 11-day state visit. Along with the declaration the presidents watched as Foreign Ministers Andrei Gromyko and Maurice Couve de Murville signed agreements on a joint space research program and scientific and technical cooperation. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, July 1, 1966

headline: Feeling Stung by a Fickle Friend Named Facebook

headline: Joint Base Andrews Locked Down After Unfounded Gunman Report
abstract: The Maryland base was planning an “active shooter exercise.” Then things became confusing.
lead_paragraph: The word ricocheted around the world at internet speed Thursday morning: Joint Base Andrews, best known as home to Air Force One, was on lockdown because of reports of an active shooter. Security forces scrambled, cable news zeroed in, a flight by the vice president was put off, and Twitter users repeated thirdhand reports of a gunman holed up in a bathroom.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, July 2 Through 10

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Retrieving Your Google Photos
abstract: Automatic backup keeps your pictures in the cloud, but you can download copies if you want to edit them with your favorite desktop photo program.
lead_paragraph: Q. I like having the automatic online backup and storage for my pictures with Google Photos, but I’d also like to edit certain shots and albums with my desktop photo-editing program. How do I grab those photos back from Google?

headline: Owner’s Manual, Out of the Glove Box and Onto the App
abstract: Automakers are putting the owner’s manual online and onscreen, knowing today’s drivers are unlikely to read the print version.
lead_paragraph: THE recent death of the actor Anton Yelchin has spurred a class-action lawsuit against Fiat Chrysler, maker of the 2015 Jeep Grand Cherokee that rolled backward after he stepped out and crushed him.

headline: A Mood-Ring Ingredient Makes Cocktails Change Color
keywords: ['Cocktails and Mixed Drinks', 'Flowers and Plants', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES']
abstract: The butterfly pea flower is suddenly in demand at bars across the country.
lead_paragraph: Megan Deschaine, the bar manager at 492, a restaurant on King Street in Charleston, S.C., sometimes despairs that the Disco Sour, a cocktail that has never left her menu, is so popular that it “will be on my tombstone.”

headline: Tour de France Is Ready to Roll With Chris Froome as the Favorite
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Cycling, Road', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)']
abstract: Froome, of Team Sky, is a good bet to win for the third time, but challengers include Nairo Quintana of Colombia and Richie Porte of Australia, a former Sky member.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Marie Leblanc should probably have been more concerned about doping in cycling. His time as director of the Tour de France included the 1998 police raids that almost shut down cycling’s most famous race as well as Lance Armstrong’s now-erased record of seven straight wins.

headline: Veteran Pollsters to Join Donald Trump’s Campaign
abstract: Mr. Trump will now have five firms working for him, as his team shifts gears toward a general election with new urgency.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump will expand his roster of pollsters, with plans to add three new ones as his team shifts gears toward a general election with new urgency, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, July 2 Through July 10
abstract: “Project Lives” explores perspectives of New York as seen from residents who live in public housing. The exhibit will at the Art League of Long Island through August.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Poking at Politics, Without a Stick, on Big and Small Screens
keywords: ['Movies', 'Television', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The world is more farcical than the most ridiculous screen comedy and more preposterous than any superhero franchise movie.
lead_paragraph: The European postwar order is a shambles. A rich celebrity with no political experience and a flagrant disregard for the niceties of political behavior has become the presumptive nominee of a major American political party. I’ll leave it there for now, though the litany of the dreadful, the unlikely, the inexplicable and the absurd could be extended in every direction. Over in the other major party, the wife of a former president fought off a serious challenge from a 74-year-old socialist. The political institutions that have taken turns governing Britain for most of the last century are in chaos. Let’s not even talk about what’s happening in Russia, Bolivia and Brazil. Who could make this stuff up?

headline: Milk and Other Surprising Ways to Stay Hydrated
abstract: A new “beverage hydration index” provides evidence-based suggestions for how to most efficiently hydrate.
lead_paragraph: Most Americans have heard that they should drink eight glasses of water a day to stay hydrated, but there is surprisingly little data to support this advice.

headline: Justice Department Won’t Alter Music Industry Royalty Rules
keywords: ['Music', 'Royalties', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: Ascap and BMI, clearinghouses for royalties, say that modifying their consent decrees was urgently needed to adapt to the new world of online music.
lead_paragraph: The music industry sent a wish list to Washington, but the response was not quite what it had expected.

keywords: ['Sand and Gravel', 'Coast Erosion', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: The Natural Resources Defense Council writes about the need to plan for the sustainable use of offshore public resources like sand.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, July 2 Through July 10
abstract: Gabriel Iglesias, a comedian, will perform in July at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, where Beres Hammond, a reggae artist, is also performing later in the month.

headline: Review: ‘Seinfeldia,’ on Why We Still Can’t Escape ‘Hello, Jerry’
abstract: Jennifer Keishin Armstrong delivers a solid history of this influential TV series, while exploring its cultural staying power.
lead_paragraph: It’s not as if “Seinfeld” didn’t have its critics. Writing in New York magazine, John Leonard called the show a “Cheez Doodle of urban fecklessness.” The New Republic’s longtime literary editor, Leon Wieseltier, a professional lowerer of the boom, said it was “the worst, last gasp of Reaganite, grasping, materialistic, narcissistic, banal self-absorption.” Newman, the show’s villain, reduced these sentiments to two words: “Hello, Jerry.”

headline: More Operatic Drama at Bayreuth as Andris Nelsons Pulls Out
abstract: In a statement, the conductor cited “a differing approach in various matters” in his decision to leave the festival’s opening production of “Parsifal.”
lead_paragraph: The Bayreuth Festival in Germany, which Richard Wagner conceived to stage his operas, has a reputation for backstage drama that rivals its music dramas, and this year is no different. Andris Nelsons, one of the world’s leading conductors, announced Thursday that he had withdrawn from the new production of “Parsifal” that will open the festival next month.

headline: Review: A ‘Tarzan’ With a Few Twists in the Hollywood Vine
abstract: Alexander Skarsgard is Tarzan, who returns to the jungle with his man-muscles, in Congo, with an American who believes people are being enslaved.
lead_paragraph: “The Legend of Tarzan” has a whole lot of fun, big-screen things going for it — adventure, romance, natural landscapes, digital animals and oceans of rippling handsome man-muscle. Its sweep and easy pleasures come from its old-fashioned escapades — it’s one long dash through the jungle by foot, train, boat and swinging vine — but what makes it more enjoyable than other recycled stories of this type is that the filmmakers have given Tarzan a thoughtful, imperfect makeover. That must have been tough given the origin story’s white supremacy problems.

headline: Video Review: Hyundai’s Plug-In Sonata Saves Fuel With Understatement
abstract: The conservatively handsome and roomy Sonata Plug-in Hybrid, Hyundai’s entry in a field with few competitors, doesn’t look like a science experiment.
lead_paragraph: THE 2016 Hyundai Sonata Plug-in Hybrid should be an easy sell. At road speed, it’s hushed. It keeps sharp bumps from reaching your keister, is spacious for the car pool gang and conservatively handsome. And of course, it’s very fuel-efficient.

headline: Fired VW Employee Withdraws Wrongful Dismissal Lawsuit
abstract: Daniel Donovan had said in the lawsuit that he tried to stop company employees from destroying electronic documents related to emissions cheating.
lead_paragraph: A former Volkswagen employee in Michigan has withdrawn a lawsuit claiming he was fired illegally because he was about to report the company for obstruction of justice, according to court documents.

headline: After Soggy First Round, Restless Wimbledon Plays Catch-Up
abstract: After two days of rain, the All England Club was bustling with matches. Winners included Donald Young, John Isner and Timea Bacsinszky.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — At 12:46 p.m. Thursday, when Barbora Strycova hit a forehand winner on Court 14 to beat Anett Kontaveit, the first round of Wimbledon finally ended.

abstract: The remarks from the Utah senator reflect the raw feelings among some Republicans toward Mr. Trump that are lingering after an unpleasant primary race.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has asked Republicans who do not have anything nice to say about him to not say anything at all.

abstract: HUD officials said that private buyers of delinquent mortgages would have to consider options to keep struggling borrowers in their homes.
lead_paragraph: A federal program that sold more than 100,000 soured mortgages to private investors at discounted prices is getting a major overhaul.

lead_paragraph: Remember grüner veltliner? Of course you do.

headline: There’s More to Rosé Than You May Think
abstract: Once freed from the tyranny of marketing clichés, a wine shows that it has much to offer.
lead_paragraph: Summer arrives, and along with it, rosé and enough wine clichés to float a cruise ship. You may have heard endless odes to “the pink wine” and its “moment in the sun,” how “it’s not just a drink, it’s a lifestyle,” and so on.

headline: All Eyes (and Ears) on Jupiter

lead_paragraph: As NASA’s Juno spacecraft closes in for its Monday arrival at Jupiter, many other eyes are also staring at the solar system’s largest planet.

headline: Zlatan Ibrahimovic Says He Is Joining Manchester United
abstract: Ibrahimovic announced on his social media accounts that he would be joining Manchester United next season, confirming weeks of reports.
lead_paragraph: Zlatan Ibrahimovic announced on his social media accounts Thursday that he would be joining Manchester United next season, confirming weeks of reports that he would make England’s Premier League his new home.

headline: The Challenges That Remain for L.G.B.T. People After Marriage Ruling
abstract: L.G.B.T. leaders reflect on the obstacles the community still faces one year after same-sex marriage was legalized.
lead_paragraph: As L.G.B.T. Pride Month comes to an end, the massacre of 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Fla., cast a pall over this year’s celebrations to commemorate milestones for the community.

headline: The Illicit Perks of the M.D. Club
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Nepotism']
abstract: The insurance system is broken. No wonder doctors take shortcuts when it comes to their own care.
lead_paragraph: ONE of my patients recently had her request for a relatively common medication for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, Vyvanse, denied by her insurance provider. I tried to appeal the decision, but her father — the chief executive of a health care company who purchased insurance for hundreds of employees — had better luck. He called up the head of the insurance company and got the drug approved.

headline: Garbiñe Muguruza and Dominic Thiem Join Exodus of Wimbledon Seeds
abstract: No. 2 Muguruza, No. 7 Belinda Bencic and No. 14 Samantha Stosur were among the women to depart, and No. 8 Thiem and No. 13 David Ferrer were among the men.
lead_paragraph: WIMBLEDON, England — Instead of rain, seeded players were falling Thursday at Wimbledon.

headline: Parenting Our Children After We Die
abstract: Following the lead of other patients with cancer, I have composed two different documents to buffer my girls from the misery that ensues when a parent dies, writes Susan Gubar.
lead_paragraph: Accounts of the grief children suffer after the deaths of their mothers or fathers reinforced my desire to use the time granted by treatment to help my adult children cope with my demise. We always parent our offspring to survive us, but cancer intensifies the urgency to do so.

headline: 1891: Literary Copyrights Protected
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: President Harrison proclaims the International Copyright Law in July 1891.
lead_paragraph: President Harrison has been of late in frequent consultation with Mr. Spofford, the Librarian of Congress, and will soon issue the proclamation prescribed by the International Copyright Law. In anticipation of the new law coming into force, the Governments of Great Britain, France, Belgium and Switzerland have signified to the United States, through the proper diplomatic channels, their readiness to avail themselves of the facilities offered by the Act to their citizens for copyright here, and will grant to American authors privileges equal to those of their own citizens. — The New York Herald, European Edition, July 1, 1891

headline: The 5 Conservatives Vying to Become Britain’s Next Prime Minister
abstract: After Boris Johnson’s decision not to seek the leadership of the Conservative Party, these are the main contenders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Boris Johnson’s surprising announcement on Thursday that he would not seek the leadership of the British Conservative Party — and by extension, succeed David Cameron as prime minister — leaves five candidates for the job.

headline: Art by Jan Brady? Wally Cleaver? Lando Calrissian? See It Off Broadway
abstract: The set of “Out of the Mouths of Babes,” featuring works by film and TV stars, is New York’s newest art gallery.
lead_paragraph: ROSIE O’DONNELL’S painting hangs high above the kitchen door. Below it is an abstract work by the “Gilligan’s Island” star Tina Louise. On the opposite wall hangs a giclée figure of a blues musician by Billy Dee Williams of “Star Wars.”

headline: Reactions to West Bank Stabbing
abstract: A Palestinian infiltrated a Jewish settlement in the West Bank on Thursday and killed a teenage girl. The suspect was killed by a resident.

headline: Calum McSwiggan, YouTube Star, Charged With Filing False Report
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Social Media', 'Hate Crimes', 'Assaults', 'Frauds and Swindling']

headline: A Rapper’s Killing Puts Baltimore, Grief-Stricken and Angry, on Edge
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Music', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The hip-hop artist Lor Scoota, praised for documenting the city’s trauma and counseling youth after Freddie Gray’s death, was gunned down after a charity event.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — When riots broke out last year over the death of Freddie Gray, a promising young hip-hop artist named Lor Scoota, who rapped about “selling scramble, coke and smack” yet ran a football team for inner-city children, made the rounds of local high schools at the invitation of a city councilman. He told students to get their diplomas and shared his dream of escape.

headline: How to Make Sure Your Overseas Wedding Is Legal
abstract: Some countries require couples to live there before marrying. Others require divorce certificates to be translated from English.
lead_paragraph: As romantic as it may be to wed in a castle in another country, it is important to pay attention to the laws of the land. Here are some tips to make sure your wedding is legal.

headline: British Woman, 60, Wins Legal Round in Fight to Give Birth to Grandchild
abstract: A British appeals court handed a legal victory to a woman who wants to fulfill her daughter’s dying wish: to have her mother carry her baby and raise the child.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A 60-year-old woman determined to use her dead daughter’s frozen eggs to give birth to her own grandchild won a crucial legal victory on Thursday in second-highest court in Britain.

headline: Preliminary Injunction Against Indiana Abortion Law
abstract: The preliminary injunction issued Thursday that blocked an Indiana law banning abortions sought because of a fetus's genetic abnormalities.
lead_paragraph: The preliminary injunction issued Thursday that blocked an Indiana law banning abortions sought because of a fetus's genetic abnormalities.

headline: Ozone Hole Shows Signs of Shrinking, Scientists Say
abstract: Three decades after a treaty to phase out the use of chemicals known as CFCs, there are indications that the hole in the ozone layer is healing.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three decades after the world banned chemicals that were destroying the atmosphere’s protective ozone layer, scientists said Thursday that there were signs the atmosphere was on the mend.

headline: Nancy Grace to Leave HLN After More Than a Decade
abstract: Ms. Grace, a former prosecutor, became a polarizing TV personality as she aggressively covered tabloid crime stories for the cable network.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Grace, the polarizing television personality who for more than a decade used her platform on the HLN network to aggressively cover tabloid crime stories, will leave the network in October.

headline: Memorial at Istanbul Airport for Victims
abstract: Turkey held a day of mourning on Thursday to honor dozens killed in an attack at the Ataturk airport. The airport has since reopened, but travelers paused for a moment of silence and a short memorial.
lead_paragraph: Turkey held a day of mourning on Thursday to honor dozens killed in an attack at the Ataturk airport. The airport has since reopened, but travelers paused for a moment of silence and a short memorial.

lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece, Julie Turkewitz, a reporter at The Times, describes what it is like to have covered a series of mass shootings.

headline: Celebrating the National Park Centennial
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: In honor of its 100th birthday, the National Park Service is organizing cultural events, canoe trips, hikes, stargazing parties and even musical performances.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the National Park Service shattered its previous attendance record by 14 million, attracting more than 307 million visitors. This year, traffic is already up nearly 3 million in year-to-date comparisons. And while the service won’t project another record-breaking year, 2016 is shaping up to be perhaps its busiest summer, as judged by events created to celebrate its centennial year.

headline: After ‘Brexit,’ Finding a New London for the Financial World to Call Home
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Relocation of Business', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']

headline: How (and Why) to Camp in the National Parks
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Camps and Camping', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Chris Santella’s new book, “Fifty Places to Camp Before You Die” (Abrams Books),showcases some of the world’s most beautiful campsites.
lead_paragraph: Chris Santella says he wasn’t raised by “outdoorsy” parents. But as a young man growing up in Connecticut, with grandparents who lived in Maine, he developed a kinship with nature — in particular, a love for standing knee-deep in rivers and fly-fishing. The East Coaster ultimately moved West, settling in Portland, Ore., and put aside a corporate career in marketing to write about his outdoor adventures, including trips to at least a dozen national parks.

headline: U.S. Warns Honda and Acura Owners to Replace Airbags
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The transportation secretary, Anthony Foxx, said certain 2001-3 Hondas and Acuras needed to be repaired immediately because of faulty Takata airbags.
lead_paragraph: In an urgent plea to car owners, federal safety regulators on Thursday warned that airbags in more than 300,000 older Honda and Acura vehicles were at an unacceptably high risk of exploding, and needed to be replaced immediately.

headline: ‘An Alcohol-Laced Society’
abstract: Citing wine sales at Starbucks and in drugstores, a reader worries about the effects of easing access to alcohol.

keywords: ['Credit Cards', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']

lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Thursday overturned a historic antitrust settlement between retailers and Visa and MasterCard, reviving more than a decade of legal battles over processing fees.

headline: Donald Trump Warns of a Liberal Supreme Court if Hillary Clinton Wins
abstract: Citing the decision to strike down abortion restrictions in Texas, Mr. Trump reassured skeptical conservatives that he would nominate justices they approve of.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump broke his silence on Thursday about the Supreme Court’s decision to block parts of a Texas law restricting abortion access, promising that such outcomes would be different if he was elected president.

headline: Still Want to Get the News on Facebook? Read All About It
abstract: Facebook’s change to its news feed algorithm could mean you’ll see fewer articles, videos or photos shared by the media. But there’s a way around that.
lead_paragraph: Facebook announced on Wednesday that it would change its news feed algorithm to put a higher priority on content shared by friends and family. That most likely means you will see fewer articles, videos or photos shared by the media companies you follow on Facebook.

headline: Russia Fires Dozens of Military Officers in Baltic Region
abstract: Citing “dereliction of duty” and distortion of “the real state of things,” the Russian defense minister blamed the commanders for poor organization.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — In a sweeping military shake-up, Russia has replaced the top commanders of its Baltic Fleet, which patrols a region that has become the main fault line between Russia and the West.

headline: Hershey Rejects Mondelez’s $23 Billion Takeover Offer
abstract: If the two companies made a deal, it would be among the most prominent in a year that has been lacking in daring deal-making.
lead_paragraph: For more than a century, Hershey — an American candy icon so well known it gave its name to its Pennsylvania hometown — has stood independent, rebuffing numerous attempts to buy the maker of Kisses and Reese’s Peanut Butter Cups.

headline: N.B.A. Free Agency: Who’s Going Where
abstract: Kevin Durant is the main prize, but there are plenty of other big names who may be changing teams.
lead_paragraph: Over the last two seasons, the proposed solution to nearly every N.B.A. team’s problems has been simple: Sign Kevin Durant when he hits free agency. Now that he is about to hit the open market, only a handful of teams will even have a chance to talk to him.

headline: When Pals Bash Their Spouses, Should You Speak Up?
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Gifts', 'Letters', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: Also, what to do when you are cooking for an empty kitchen, dealing with an unanswered condolence letter and how to give a very belated wedding gift.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have two sets of longtime-couple friends whom we often see as a group. Recently, the wives (with little or no provocation) have taken to being sharp and nasty with their husbands. We are shocked by this because the offending remarks by the husbands are things that would usually cause us to laugh at each other’s foibles. The husbands seem embarrassed. I try to interject a new line of conversation. Should we continue to ignore this, or should I speak to the wives privately about how poorly their behavior reflects on them?

headline: After the ‘Brexit’ Vote
abstract: Readers react to the stunning result of the referendum.

headline: Animals Sly Enough to Surprise David Attenborough
abstract: At 90, Mr. Attenborough, a veteran of many captivating nature programs, still has wild worlds to share as the narrator of “The Hunt” on BBC America.
lead_paragraph: It presumably takes quite a lot these days to surprise David Attenborough when it comes to nature programs, since he is a veteran of so many of them. But a plunging polar bear and a tiptoeing tiger, among other creatures, did the trick in Alastair Fothergill’s seven-part docu-series “The Hunt,” which begins Sunday on BBC America.

headline: Italian Navy Recovers Ship Containing at Least 300 Migrants’ Bodies
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Human Trafficking']

headline: ‘Quiet Fireworks’ Promise Relief for Children and Animals

lead_paragraph: Quiet fireworks — it sounds like an oxymoron. Usually those bright bursts of color come with equally impressive bangs. But some fireworks shows are designed to please the eyes without pummeling the ears.

headline: Swimmer David Plummer Can Finally Call Himself an Olympian

lead_paragraph: OMAHA — Four years ago, David Plummer touched the wall at the end of the 100-meter backstroke final at the United States Olympic swimming trials and looked up at the scoreboard. He placed third, missing the team by 12-hundredths of a second.

keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Referendums', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: Mark Carney, the governor of the central bank, also shrugged off a suggestion he might be forced to resign after a new prime minister was chosen.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England may be forced to cut a key interest rate this summer as it grapples with economic uncertainty created by Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, Mark Carney, the bank’s governor, said in a speech on Thursday.

headline: New York’s Sidewalks Are So Packed, Pedestrians Are Taking to the Streets
abstract: A world-class walking city has turned into an obstacle course, and transportation officials are moving to ease the congestion.
lead_paragraph: Ivette Singh hardly bothers to walk on the sidewalk on her way to work in Midtown Manhattan anymore. Too many people, too little space. Not enough patience.

headline: Daniels Narrate a Scene From ‘Swiss Army Man’
abstract: Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, the writers and directors of “Swiss Army Man,” discuss a sequence featuring Paul Dano and Daniel Radcliffe.
lead_paragraph: A man makes friends with a corpse in “Swiss Army Man,” the not-easy-to-classify debut feature from Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, professionally known as Daniels. When the film played at Sundance, it became known mostly for its flatulent corpse character. But it has since gone on to receive positive reviews in limited release. It expands to more theaters July 1. In one scene, the main character Hank (Paul Dano) tries to get his corpse friend, Manny (Daniel Radcliffe), to recall the joys of living by creating a makeshift bus and taking him for a ride.

headline: Review: With Chests Held Proud, These Argentine Dancers Storm the Stage
abstract: The troupe Che Malambo brought its blend of drumming and percussive dance, a gaucho art form, to Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — An avid dancegoer is likely to cross paths every so often with flamenco, Irish dance, tango or tap, packaged and polished for the concert stage. Sightings of malambo, a cousin of those fleet-footed styles, are less common. It wasn’t until City Center’s Fall for Dance festival last year that I first encountered the form, a blend of drumming and percussive dance practiced by gauchos, or South American cowboys, since the 17th century. The dancers were the 14 men of Che Malambo, an Argentine company founded and directed by the French dancer Gilles Brinas, and they sent the audience into uproarious applause.

headline: Adnan Syed, of ‘Serial’ Podcast, Gets a Retrial in Murder Case
abstract: A Maryland judge made his decision in the case of Mr. Syed, who has served 16 years of a life sentence after he was convicted of the 1999 killing of his ex-girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Maryland has granted a new trial to Adnan Syed, setting aside his conviction for the 1999 murder of his former girlfriend, in a case that was the subject of the first season of the hit podcast “Serial.”

headline: Meeting Between Bill Clinton and Loretta Lynch Provokes Political Furor
keywords: ['E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Republicans said the airport encounter compromised the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s emails, but Ms. Lynch said the conversation did not touch on the inquiry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An airport encounter this week between Attorney General Loretta E. Lynch and former President Bill Clinton has welled into a political storm, with Republicans asserting that it compromised the Justice Department’s politically sensitive investigation into Hillary Clinton’s email practices while she was secretary of state.

headline: Williams Faces Uphill Battle in Fight With Energy Transfer
abstract: The Williams Companies is fighting a judge’s decision to allow a merger with Energy Transfer to be terminated, but appeals like these normally lose.
lead_paragraph: The Wiliams Companies is in Delaware court, appealing the termination of a contentious deal to merge with the pipeline operator Energy Transfer Equity. But if you want to understand the chances the Williams Companies has in winning its appeal, you need to understand merger agreements.

headline: Yankees Use a Passed Ball, Not a Long Ball, to Win Again in Ninth
abstract: Michael Pineda struck out 12 in six innings before Chase Headley broke a 1-1 tie by scoring on a passed ball in the ninth.
lead_paragraph: For an encore on Thursday, the Yankees did it again — a walk-off victory over the Texas Rangers in the bottom of the ninth inning. Except this one was hardly as emphatic, with the Yankees scoring the winning run on a passed ball less than 24 hours after they had triumphed on Wednesday night on a two-run home run by Didi Gregorius.

headline: The Macroeconomics of Brexit: Motivated Reasoning?
abstract: Sloppy thinking is always a vice.
lead_paragraph: I’m still on vacation, but had some time to catch up today, and felt an urge to scratch an itch I’ve been feeling. You see, much of the discussion of Brexit and its impacts bothers me. I believe that Brexit is a tragic development, which will do substantial long-run economic harm. But what we’re hearing overwhelmingly from economists is the claim that it will also have severe short-run adverse impacts. And that claim seems dubious.

headline: Review: Revisiting an Unlikely Campaign in ‘Roseanne for President!’
abstract: Eric Weinrib’s documentary is a fascinating record of Roseanne Barr’s pursuit of a spot on the Green Party’s national ticket in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Politics meets celebrity in Eric Weinrib’s fascinating documentary “Roseanne for President!,” a record of Roseanne Barr’s pursuit of a spot on the Green Party’s national ticket in 2012. Ms. Barr, of course, starred in the groundbreaking, Emmy-winning sitcom “Roseanne” (1988-1997), one of the first network shows to include gay characters and offer a comparatively realistic depiction of a working-class family. A campaign, we discover, is a very different vehicle.

headline: Self-Driving Tesla Was Involved in Fatal Crash, U.S. Says
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The federal highway safety agency said that the driver of a Tesla on “autopilot” died in a crash in May, thought to be the first death in a self-driving car.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The race by automakers and technology firms to develop self-driving cars has been fueled by the belief that computers can operate a vehicle more safely than human drivers.

headline: Review: Once Lost, ‘Private Property’ Is a Genuine Rediscovery
abstract: This sex-crime thriller from 1960, written and directed by Leslie Stevens, stars Corey Allen and Warren Oates.
lead_paragraph: This 1960 picture, long considered lost, and newly restored courtesy of the bold indie distributor Cinelicious Pics, is a sex-crime thriller that teeters on the edge of morbidity before its galvanic climax. Seen today, it’s also a fascinating mélange of cinematic semiotics.

headline: Reassembling Hamilton Palace, Room by Room, All 150 of Them
abstract: A group of historians is attempting to track down parts of this residence, now demolished, far-flung from their original home in Glasgow.
lead_paragraph: A domed mausoleum and some ghosts of cellars are all that remain of Hamilton Palace, once considered one of the most imposing homes in Britain. After a visit in 1706, the writer Daniel Defoe described it as “fit rather for the Court of a Prince than the Palace or House of a Subject.”

headline: Review: Bruce Willis Is a Banker With Issues in ‘Marauders’
abstract: In this film, robberies vex Mr. Willis’s character and an F.B.I. agent played by Christopher Meloni.
lead_paragraph: Folks complain a lot these days about the excess of superhero movies, but that’s not the most nettlesome glut in the overcrowded movie scene. What about overbaked, mediocre thrillers trading on the marquee value of one or more big-name lead actors (almost always male), who, in turn, phone in performances of perfunctorily written roles?

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, July 2 Through July 10
abstract: Sunset yoga in the Bronx, a reading of the Declaration of Independence in Mount Vernon, and Afro Latin jazz in Woodstock are just a few of the events that are lined up for the coming days.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: In ‘Life, Animated,’ a Bound Mind Finds Freedom
abstract: This documentary, based on Ron Suskind’s book, recounts how Disney films helped his autistic son learn to communicate, and explores his growing up.
lead_paragraph: The disparity between what we want for our children and what they might achieve can be especially painful for parents of autistic youngsters. Yet you’d barely know that from Roger Ross Williams’s relentlessly cheerful documentary, “Life, Animated.” Like the Disney movie clips that flood its frames, this too-tentative look at how a bound mind found freedom in animation leaves us in little doubt of a happy ending.

headline: Review: In ‘Carnage Park,’ the Hills Have Eyes, and a Sniper, Too
abstract: Vivian (Ashley Bell) is taken hostage during a robbery, but that’s just the start of her nightmare in Mickey Keating’s new horror film.
lead_paragraph: Mickey Keating takes the adage “less is more” to heart in his “Carnage Park,” and it pays off pretty well. This no-frills horror film about a murderous psycho who terrorizes people unlucky enough to wander into his corner of California hill country has no fancy special effects or supernatural goings-on. Its dialogue would probably fit on a couple of sheets of paper. But it sure is creepy, in a throwback sort of way.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Art in review, from Times critics.

headline: Review: A ‘Sleeping Beauty’ Revival Rich in Details and Rewards
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky’s staging for American Ballet Theater is looking even better than it did in its premiere season.
lead_paragraph: Young dancers with American Ballet Theater have been taking to new roles this week like ducks to water. The company is playing Alexei Ratmansky’s production of “The Sleeping Beauty,” new last year; the choreography, to a large extent, is not Mr. Ratmansky’s but by Marius Petipa, restored from records of the 1890 original and with a startling command of period style. Experienced dancers have matured. Multiple interpreters have found different rewards from the same roles. The production, running all this week at the tail end of Ballet Theater’s eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House, is looking even better than it did in its premiere season.

headline: Review: ‘The Purge: Election Year’ Offers a Campaign Platform of Blood Lust
abstract: In the third chapter of James DeMonaco’s dystopian series, a senator joins insurgents who oppose the yearly overnight killing spree in the title.
lead_paragraph: “The Purge” is a scrappy little franchise — three movies so far — built on a solid premise. In a dystopian future (the only kind we get these days), the American government has decreed that one night a year will be given over to lawlessness. Otherwise responsible citizens can unleash their blood lust in an orgy of mayhem without consequences.

headline: A Remark on Israel by Jeremy Corbyn Incites Outrage in Britain and Abroad
abstract: Speaking at an event designed to address accusations of anti-Semitism in his Labour Party, Mr. Corbyn made a comment that was initially interpreted as comparing Israel to the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Trying to address accusations of anti-Semitism in Britain’s opposition Labour Party, its embattled leader, Jeremy Corbyn, provoked more outrage on Thursday by comparing Israel to “self-styled Islamic states or organizations.”

headline: Review: A Professor Drawn to the Mob in ‘Our Kind of Traitor’
abstract: The film, based on John le Carré’s 2010 novel of the same name, includes complications both geopolitical and conjugal.
lead_paragraph: Every so often, a news story shows up that seems to beg for fictionalization. It’s no wonder that so many journalists love playing make-believe producers, as when they write that the news they’re covering “has all the makings of a Hollywood movie.” These days, though, the major American movie studios are more in the business of comic-book intrigues than in realism. Even so, the continued trickle of adaptations of John le Carré’s work (including the recent miniseries “The Night Manager”) suggests that someone still believes that there’s a market for adult stories about real-world stakes.

headline: This Week’s Movies: July 1, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “The BFG,” “The Legend of Tarzan” and “Our Kind of Traitor.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “The BFG,” “The Legend of Tarzan” and “Our Kind of Traitor.”

headline: A ‘Sleeping Beauty’ Kind of Day
abstract: Cassandra Trenary, a soloist for American Ballet Theater, danced her New York City debut as Aurora in “The Sleeping Beauty” on Wednesday. First, though, she had class.
lead_paragraph: Cassandra Trenary, a soloist for American Ballet Theater, danced her New York City debut as Aurora in “The Sleeping Beauty” on Wednesday. First, though, she had class.

headline: Tony Oursler’s Grand Illusions, Science Left at the Door
abstract: A fascinating exhibition at the Hessel Museum of Art features ephemera from Mr. Oursler’s archive, and his film “Imponderable” is at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: In Paris in the early 1780s, Franz Anton Mesmer was attracting attention for his showy demonstrations of “mesmerism,” or what would later be called hypnotism. King Louis XVI appointed a commission that included Benjamin Franklin, America’s ambassador to France, to investigate.

headline: Cassandra Trenary on Having (Just) Danced ‘The Sleeping Beauty’
abstract: Ms. Trenary, a 22-year-old American Ballet Theater soloist making her New York debut as Aurora, discussed her memorable performance.
lead_paragraph: To conquer Aurora is proof that a dancer is on her way to becoming a ballerina. On Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, Cassandra Trenary killed it.

headline: Bruce Conner’s Darkness That Defies Authority
abstract: “Bruce Conner: It’s All True,” at MoMA, is the first New York retrospective of this polymathic artist. It features some 250 works in nearly 10 media.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Conner was one of the great outliers of American art, a polymathic nonconformist whose secret mantra might have been “Only resist.” In multiple media, over more than five decades, this restless denizen of the San Francisco cultural scene resisted categorization, art world expectations and almost any kind of authority.

headline: Istanbul, Donald Trump, Boris Johnson: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Lionsgate’s Deal for Starz Bears Malone’s Hallmarks
abstract: After its $4.4 billion acquisition of Starz, Lionsgate plans to create a new class of nonvoting shares.
lead_paragraph: The movie studio Lionsgate’s $4.4 billion deal to acquire the pay-TV company Starz has media mogul John C. Malone’s fingerprints all over it. A complex structure? Check. New governance-skewing nonvoting stock? Yup. More influence for the man known as the Cable Cowboy? You bet. Starz shareholders should not be surprised at the modest premium on the offer.

headline: Obama Picks New York Architects to Design Presidential Library
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Libraries and Librarians']
abstract: The president and his wife, Michelle, spent months poring over proposals for the project and meeting with prospective architects at the White House
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and the team planning his life after the White House have selected Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, a New York-based husband-and-wife architectural duo, to design his presidential library in Chicago, tapping two modernists who are known for their refined work creating cultural and academic institutions.

headline: Lacking Brains, Plants Can Still Make Good Judgments About Risks
abstract: Researchers examined how pea plants grow in a study of risk assessment theory that could have applications for studies of human behavior.
lead_paragraph: Plants may not be getting enough credit. Not only do they remember when you touch them, it turns out that they can make risky decisions that are as sophisticated as those made by humans, all without brains or complex nervous systems. And they may even judge risks more efficiently than we do.

headline: Review: A House Car? For ‘Microbe and Gasoline,’ It’s Freedom
abstract: This coming-of-age tale centers on two adolescent outsiders who hit the road in a zany homemade vehicle that doubles as a dwelling.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s face it. We’re not exactly normal: you the hopeless romantic and me the grease monkey,” declares Théo (Théophile Baquet), the scruffier of two likable adolescent misfits who gallivant around France in a homemade vehicle. That souped-up car, constructed from junk that includes a discarded carburetor that Theo repairs, is the real star of Michel Gondry’s good-natured coming-of-age road movie, “Microbe and Gasoline.” With additions, this crude motorized buggy becomes a zany wooden mobile home. No matter that its limited horsepower requires it to be pushed up hills; it promises unlimited freedom on the open road.

headline: Edward Snowden Will Join Daniel Radcliffe in ‘Privacy,’ via Video
abstract: Beginning this weekend, Mr. Snowden will appear in performances of the play at the Public Theater with Mr. Radcliffe, who plays a writer in the show.
lead_paragraph: Be not afeard, indeed.

headline: Review: In ‘The Innocents,’ Not Even Nuns Are Spared War Horrors
abstract: The film, based on real events in postwar Poland, depicts how atrocities test the faith of Catholic nuns in their own convent.
lead_paragraph: Much of Anne Fontaine’s blistering film “The Innocents” is set within the walls of a Polish convent in December 1945, just after the end of World War II. What at first appears to be an austere, holy retreat from surrounding horrors is revealed to be a savagely violated sanctuary awash in fear, trauma and shame. The snow-covered, forested landscape of the convent is photographed to suggest an ominous frontier that offers no refuge from marauding outsiders.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: New York City Council Delays Scrutiny of Deed Changes
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Nursing Homes']
abstract: The lifting of a deed restriction for a Lower East Side nursing home prompted questions among Council members, but now with a hearing put off, answers may have to wait.
lead_paragraph: When New York City agreed to remove a deed restriction on a nursing home on the Lower East Side in exchange for $16.15 million, it did not foresee all the complications that would follow.

headline: The Many Faces of Alexander Hamilton, Just in Time for the Fourth
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Independence Day (US) (July 4)', 'Museums']
abstract: After digging deep into their storage rooms, four institutions are showing off what they’ve got related to the country’s new favorite founder.
lead_paragraph: Lin-Manuel Miranda may have announced that he’s leaving the Broadway show “Hamilton” on July 9. But Alexander Hamilton himself, as local museums and libraries are eager to remind people, is hardly leaving New York City.

headline: Celebrating Bison, Two Zoos Offer a Wild and Woolly Weekend
abstract: The Bronx and Queens Zoos have special activities this Fourth of July weekend involving bison, recently designated the American national mammal.
lead_paragraph: Eagles are notoriously defensive about their nests. You have to wonder what one would do if a bison lumbered up and suddenly wanted to share the space.

headline: Theater Listings for July 1-7
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: Auctioneer at Sotheby’s Confident in London as Art Hub
abstract: The first sale of the spring season by Sotheby’s in London brought $63.7 million for a Picasso and $56.7 million for a portrait by Amedeo Modigliani.
lead_paragraph: Early this week, when the art world braced for the potential fallout from “Brexit,” at least one auctioneer was resolute.

headline: Why Will Markets Recover From ‘Brexit’? Clues From Past Crises
keywords: ['Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Recession and Depression', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'United States Economy']
abstract: History provides some limited reassurance to the market turmoil after Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.
lead_paragraph: The markets looked very shaky when Britain voted on June 23 to leave the European Union. They have firmed up nicely since then.

headline: U.N. Panel Moves to Curb Bias Against L.G.B.T. People
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Discrimination', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The Human Rights Council, over the objections of Muslim and Arab nations, approved measures to strengthen protections for gay, bisexual and transgender people.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations’ main human rights body on Thursday adopted measures to strengthen protections for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people, despite fierce resistance from Muslim and African countries.

headline: Comedy Listings for July 1-7
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Transgender Troops Protected at Last
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Editorials']
abstract: A new Pentagon policy that allows transgender people to serve openly makes the military a fairer employer and a stronger institution.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the Pentagon began allowing openly gay people to serve in the military in 2011, a small group of transgender veterans quietly began to plan for the next battle. They thought it would take 15 years, perhaps more, for the military to openly accept transgender people in uniform.

headline: Wright Concedes to Espaillat in Primary for House Seat
abstract: In the contest to replace Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, Adriano D. Espaillat is likely to become the first Dominican immigrant elected to Congress.
lead_paragraph: State Assemblyman Keith L. T. Wright conceded defeat on Thursday in the Democratic congressional primary to replace Representative Charles B. Rangel, shaking hands with the winner, State Senator Adriano D. Espaillat, who is on track to become the first Dominican immigrant to be elected to Congress.

headline: Christie’s ‘Defining British Art’ Brings Out Bidders
abstract: At this sale, a mysterious patron spent tens of millions on Henry Moore’s “Reclining Figure: Festival” and two other pieces.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With the art world still wondering about the long-term impact of Britain’s vote to exit from the European Union, Christie’s themed evening sale on Thursday, “Defining British Art,” seemed to prove that buyers are still out there for top works.

headline: Zenefits Compensates Investors Over Past Misconduct
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Shareholders in Zenefits, a troubled human resources company, will get larger stakes as it tries to make up for the former chief executive’s unlawful corner-cutting.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Zenefits investors are getting a larger piece of the troubled human resources start-up because they overpaid for their stakes, unaware that the company’s sales teams flouted regulations to enhance growth, Zenefits announced on Thursday. The move will cut the company’s valuation in half, to about $2 billion.

headline: Boris Johnson and the Years of a Clown
abstract: The colorful Conservative politician won Brexit, only to lose his chance to be prime minister.
lead_paragraph: London — THE problem with spending your whole life pretending to be a buffoon is that eventually people start to believe you.

headline: Classical Music Listings for July 1-7
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
